text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: CARDIOTHORACIC
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
chest pain 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
cardiac catheterization ___
 
History of Present Illness:
Please see the CT surgery admission note and Cardiology consult 
H&P for full details.  
In brief, this is a ___ M w/CAD s/p CABG X 3 who presented to 
an OSH with chest pain that began after shoveling snow on 
___. He describes the pain as a sharp sensation below his 
right lower rib. He took 2 NTG tablets without effect and 
presented to ___ (___ where biomarkers were 
positive (peak Tn 2.4, CKMB 10.8, CK 147). He underwent cardiac 
catheterization which showed a patent vein graft to the LAD with 
the remaining grafts and native vessels occluded or severely 
diseased. Following the procedure he had persistent chest pain 
despite high dose nitro gtt. He was felt not to be a candidate 
for re-do bypass by the surgeon at the OSH. An intraaortic 
balloon pump was placed and he was transferred to ___ under 
for evaluation by Dr. ___. On arrival to the CCU, he 
continued to c/o CP but soon thereafter became pain free on a 
heparin gtt, integrilin and a nitro gtt. He was evaluated by CT 
surgery and Dr. ___ was transferred to the CCU service on 
___ to proceed with  
.  
Family reports he developed slurred speech 3 days ago the day 
prior to the onset of his chest pain. Denied motor deficits or 
disorientation. Of note, he had run out of his oxycodone for 
several days. He has had chronic anterior chest pain as a result 
of his repeated sternotomies for which he takes oxycodone x ___ 
years.  
.  
On cardiac review of symptoms, cardiac and musculoskeletal chest 
pain as above. No PND, orthopnea, ___, ___.  

 
Past Medical History:
DM  
HTN  
Hyperlipidemia  
CAD  
chest pain syndrome  
Cardiac Risk Factors include diabetes, hyperlipidemia and 
hypertension.  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC 
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: T99.6 HR 60 BP 150/50 RR 17 O2 sats 94% 4L  
GENERAL: Well-appearing, NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect 
appropriate.  
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were 
pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.  

NECK: Supple with JVP flat.  
CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular 
line. RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or 
S4.  
LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp 
were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, 
wheezes or rhonchi.  
ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not 
enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits.  
EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. L Femoral catheter in 
place with IABP.  
SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.  
PULSES:  
Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  

 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:
___ 10:08PM BLOOD WBC-6.1 RBC-3.03* Hgb-10.1* Hct-27.8* 
MCV-92 MCH-33.2* MCHC-36.2* RDW-13.5 Plt ___
___ 05:26AM BLOOD ___ PTT-31.5 ___
___ 10:08PM BLOOD Glucose-360* UreaN-12 Creat-0.9 Na-132* 
K-3.5 Cl-97 HCO3-24 AnGap-15
___:26AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-71
___ 04:44AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-53
___ 11:08AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-55
___ 10:08PM BLOOD CK-MB-3 cTropnT-0.21*
___ 04:44AM BLOOD CK-MB-NotDone cTropnT-0.22*
___ 11:08AM BLOOD CK-MB-NotDone cTropnT-0.26*
___ 10:08PM BLOOD Calcium-8.1* Phos-3.7 Mg-1.8
___ 04:44AM BLOOD Cholest-117 Triglyc-161* HDL-31 
CHOL/HD-3.8 LDLcalc-54
___ 07:34AM BLOOD Type-ART pO2-84* pCO2-38 pH-7.46* 
calTCO2-28 Base XS-2
--------------
DISCHARGE LABS:

--------------
STUDIES:
.
ECG ___: SR 64 bpm. Q III, small avF. t wave flattening III, 
avL, avF. Unchanged from EKG ___ from OSH.  
.  
CARDIAC CATHETERIZATION ___ at ___: patent 
SVG-LAD, LMCA 80% distal stenosis, LAD occluded at midportion, 
LCx proximally occluded, RCA occluded, SVG->OM/Diag not able to 
be engaged despite use of JR4, ___ or ARI.  
.  
ECHO ___:  
The left atrium is moderately dilated. Left ventricular wall 
thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is top 
normal/borderline dilated with focal hypokinesis of the distal 
septum. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 55 %). 
The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with depressed 
free wall contractility. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, 
ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets 
(3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. 
Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears 
structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is 
mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no 
pericardial effusion.  
.  
IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Right ventricular cavity 
enlargement with free wall hypokinesis. Focal left ventricular 
systolic dysfunction c/w CAD. Mild pulmonary artery systolic 
hypertension.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with severe CAD s/p CABG x 3. He is not a 
surgical candidate per CT surgery.  
.  
#. CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE: Patient with CAD s/p CABG x 3. Prior 
to transfer from OSH to ___, he underwent cardiac 
catheterization which showed a patent vein graft to the LAD with 
the remaining grafts and native vessels occluded or severely 
diseased. Following the procedure he had persistent chest pain 
despite high dose nitro gtt. He was felt not to be a candidate 
for re-do bypass by the surgeon at the OSH.  An intraaortic 
balloon pump was placed and he was transferred to ___ for 
evaluation by Cardiac Surgery (Dr. ___. On arrival to the 
CCU, he continued to c/o CP but soon thereafter became pain free 
on a heparin gtt, integrilin and a nitro gtt. On HD 3, patient 
spiked a fever to 103.7 with accompanying low flank pain and 
there was concern that this represented an infection of the 
IABP. His IABP was then pulled on HD 4, but given his persistent 
fever cardiac catheterization was postponed and Vancomycin 
started. Patient c/o abdominal pain and a CT abdomen/pelvis was 
obtained after removal of the IABP that demonstrated 
inflammation of his ascending colon so he was started on Flagyl 
& Ciprofloxacin. On HD 6, he became afebrile and all of his 
blood cultures were negative, so his Vancomycin was stopped. He 
was cleared for cardiac catheterization, but his Hct was 20.0 
and the patient refused blood products because of his religious 
beliefs. He subsequently underwent a cardiac catheterization on 
HD6 with a radial approach to minimize blood loss, but none of 
his lesions were intervenable. He was advised to return for 
repeat cardiac catheterization in approximately 1 month when his 
blood counts improve for a re-attempt. As an inpatient, he was 
maintained on his home Gemfibrozil 600 mg PO BID, Zetia 10mg 
daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Aspirin 325mg daily and 
Metoprolol 12.5mg BID. He was discharged on the above 
medications in addition to Imdur 30mg daily, Toprol XL 50mg 
daily, and Lisinopril 10mg daily. He was scheduled for 
Cardiology and PCP ___.  
.  
#. Fever & Abdominal/Flank pain: Patient with fever, abdomen & 
flank pain on HD3 as noted above. After removal of balloon pump, 
patient had CT abdomen & pelvis that demonstrated thickening of 
the cecum and ascending colon, so his IV Flagyl/Cipro/Vancomycin 
was continued. After the balloon pump was removed, he remained 
pain free and defervesced quickly. His blood cultures remained 
negative and his Vancomycin was held. He was continued on his 
Ciprofloxacin and Flagyl and was discharged to complete a 10 day 
course.
.
#. Anemia: Patient with Hct of 27.8 on admission, that dropped 
to 20.0 by HD 6. This was thought to be ___ hemolysis from the 
balloon pump and from some bleeding at the IABP site. His 
Heparin gtt was held and pneumoboots started. He was found to be 
guaiac positive, but had no e/o frank blood in his stools. U/A 
was negative for blood. CT did not demonstrate an RP bleed or 
free fluid in the abdomen. As the patient is Jehovah's Witness, 
he declined pRBC's, so he was started on Epogen & Ferrous 
Sulfate on HD 5 and monitored closely. He was advised to have an 
outpatient GI work-up for his anemia.
.
#. PUMP: TTE showed distal septal hypokinesis, EF 55%. Patient 
appeared euvolemic on exam without evidence of failure.  He was 
maintained on Metoprolol and Captopril as an inpatient and 
transitioned to long-acting agents as an outpatient. 
.  
#. RHYTHM: Patient was in sinus rhythm, he was monitored on 
telemetry and maintained on Metoprolol.  
.  
#. DIABETES: His home Glyburide and Metformin were held as an 
inpatient in lieu of a humalog sliding scale. A HbA1c was 8.0%.
.  
#. HYPERCHOLESTEROLEMIA: Patient's lipid profile showed 
Cholest-117 Triglyc-161* HDL-31 CHOL/HD-3.8 LDLcalc-54. He was 
continued on Gemfibrozil 600 mg PO BID, Zetia 10mg daily and was 
placed on Atorvastatin 80mg daily. 
.  
#. FEN: Patient was given cardiac/diabetic diet, he tolerated 
POs well. 
.  
#. Code Status: FULL  
.
To do:
F/U outstanding blood cultures from ___/, and ___
 
Medications on Admission:
TRANSFER MEDICATIONS:  
ASA 325mg qd  
Atenolol 50mg bid  
Norvasc 10mg qd  
Zetia 10mg qd  
Gemfibrizol 600mg bid  
Glyburide 5mg qd  
Protonix 40mg bid  
Quinapril 10mg bid  
Ranexa  
Zocor 80mg qd  
Integrilin gtt  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary: 
Non ST elevation myocardial infarction
Ascending Colitis (likely ischemic)

Secondary: 
Iron Deficiency Anemia
Diabetes Mellitus, Type II
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status:Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness:Alert and interactive
Activity Status:Ambulatory - Independent

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for chest pain and a small 
heart attack.  In the hospital, you were seen by cardiac surgery 
and they determined that you were not a surgical candidate. You 
were also seen by interventional cardiology and they started a 
procedure to reopen a blocked vessel.  Unfortunately, due to 
your low blood count, they did not feel that an opening 
procedure would be safe at this time.  Therefore, we recommended 
that you return in approximately 1 month when your blood counts 
are higher to re-attempt an intervention.

Additionally, in the hospital you had some fevers and abdominal 
pain. A CT was performed that showed inflammation in your colon. 
The surgery team saw you and did not feel that you required 
surgery at this time. You were started on antibiotics and your 
fever and abdominal pain resolved.  You will need to finish six 
more days of antibiotics after your discharge.  

The following medications were STARTED: 
-Isosorbide Mononitrate (IMDUR): This is a NEW medication to 
treat your blood pressure and chest pain
-Metoprolol Succinate (TOPROL XL): This is a NEW medication to 
treat your blood pressure and heart rate. It is intended to 
REPLACE your home Atenolol. 
-LISINOPRIL: This is a NEW medication to treat your blood 
pressure. It is intended to REPLACE your home Quinapril.
-Ferrous Sulfate: This is a NEW medication to treat your anemia.
-Ascorbic Acid (Vit C): This should be taken with the iron and 
will help absorb it
-Ciprofloxacin (CIPRO): This is an antibiotic to treat the 
inflammation in your gut. Please continue to take this 
medication as prescribed until ___.
-Metronidazole (FLAGYL): This is an antibiotic to treat the 
inflammation in your gut. Please continue to take this 
medication as prescribed until ___.

The following medications were STOPPED:
Atenolol
Quinapril
Amlodipine (NORVASC)
Ezetimibe (ZETIA)
Clopidogrel (PLAVIX)- stopped while your blood counts are low
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / Red Dye / Septra
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Hypoglycemia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with T1DM presents from psychiatric facility with 
hypoglycemia, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea. She is at a 
psychiatric facility for failure to care for herself from a 
diabetes standpoint. This morning took her usual dose of Lantus 
(120 units) and regular insulin but did not eat due to 
nausea/vomiting/diarrhea. She was then found to be less 
responsive. They attempted to force her to eat, but she refused. 
EMS was called and her ___ was 14. She was given glucagon and two 
oral tubes of glucose. She states she started taking Augmentin 
4d ago for a fractured tooth and had some mild abdominal pain 
prior to admission. States her BMs have been "watery" and 
profuse, several times/day, denies blood or melena. Denies h/o C 
diff. Last diarrhea was upon arrival to the floor, last vomitus 
in the ED, no blood or bile. Denies current SI/HI. She is 
___ because she came from an inpatient psych facility. 
.  
In the ED, initial VS were:
T 98 HR 98 BP 117/70 RR 12 O2 Sat 99% RA 
BG was "HIGH" and slowly trended down to the ___. She was then 
given ___ an amp of D50 for hypoglycemia. Labs were notable for 
WBC 22.3 (93.7% PMNs). She continued to refuse to drink or eat. 
She was noted to have an episode of vomiting and loose stool; at 
her psych facility there were other patients with viral 
gastroenteritis symptoms. She was started on D10 drip and is now 
being admitted for insulin washout/monitoring.  
.
On the floor, initial VS were:
T 100.8 BP 140/84 HR 124 RR 18 O2 Sat 97% RA
BG on arrival to the floor was 120. D10 was running at 200cc/hr. 
She was alert and oriented and appropriately responsive. 

 
Past Medical History:
- DM type I with frequent episodes of DKA, diagnosed ___ years 
ago after polyuria and polydipsia
- "acute pancreatitis" diagnosed by amylase elevations with 
normal CT scan and normal ERCP
- ccy: gallbladder wall thick c/w chronic inflammation, mural 
thickening c/w diskinesis
- liver bx nl
- pyelonephritis
- genital herpes
- TAB ___
- substance use (see social history)
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
mother with insulin dependent DM, no h/o diarrheal illness
 
Physical Exam:
Admission Exam:
T 100.8 BP 140/84 HR 124 RR 18 O2 Sat 97% RA

Primary Reason for Admission: ___ y/o woman with DM1 admitted 
from psych facility for inability to take POs due to

Active Problems:
.
# Hypoglycemia: At her psych facility, pt was persistently 
hypoglycemic and not tolerating POs due to vomiting and 
diarrhea. On admission, pt's BG was critically high. No insulin 
was given, and she drifted to to ___, at which point D50 was 
given. She was then started on a D10 drip at 200cc/hr and 
admitted for medicine for ongoing managemet of her BG. On the 
floor, D10 was stopped and the patient was able to eat dinner. 
Overnight, q3h BG was checked: 127->156->151->156->127. The 
following morning, her home 120U Lantus was given and she ate 
breakfast. She was medically safe for discharge back to her 
inpatient psych facility. 
.
# Vomiting/Diarrhea: On admission, there was initial concern for 
C diff given WBC count 22 (93% PMNs), Tm 100.8, recent 
antibiotic use (Augmentin for fractured tooth) and mild 
abdominal pain. Stool C diff was checked and was negative. On HD 
#2, pt reported no further episodes of vomiting or diarrhea and 
stated she felt back at her baseline. Augmentin was held. WBC 
normalized and she had no further episodes of fever. In 
retrospect, she likely had a viral gastroenteritis that was self 
limited and has now resolved. 
.
# DM1: Pt takes 120U Lantus qam and Humalog 20U TID at home. Pt 
received her home Lantus prior to admission and no insulin was 
given the evening of admission. Her BG was well controlled (see 
above) and she was restarted on her home Lantus on HD #2. 
Sliding scale insulin coverage was provided in leiu of standing 
Humalog.
.

Mr. ___ was admitted to the ___ on ___ for surgical 
management of his coronary artery disease. He was worked-up in 
the usual preoperative manner. Plavix was allowed to clear from 
his system. On ___, ___ was taken to the operating 
room where he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting to four 
vessels. Please see operative note for details. Postoperatively 
he was taken to the intensive care unit for monitoring. Within 
the next several hours, he awoke neurologically intact and was 
extubated. Beta blockade, aspirin and a statin were resumed. On 
postoperative day one, he was transferred to the step down unit 
for further recovery. He was gently diuresed towards his 
preoperative weight. The physical therapy service was consulted 
for assistance with his postoperative strength and recovery. His 
foley was replaced for urinary retention. His white count jumped 
to 17, 000 and a urine culture was sent which was negative. He 
was started on flomax and a repeat voiding trial was done prior 
to discharge which he failed and was discharged to home with 
foley in place. He will f/u with urology which needs to be 
arranged through PCP for repeat voiding trial end of next week. 
He was hyponatremic and he was  free water restricted, he will 
need to have his sodium checked on ___. He will need 
to continue on lasix for ongoing diuresis and fluid overload.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the ___ on ___ for surgical
management of his coronary artery disease. He was worked-up in
the usual preoperative manner. Plavix was allowed to clear from
his system. On ___, ___ was taken to the operating
room where he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting to four
vessels. Please see operative note for details. Postoperatively
he was taken to the intensive care unit for monitoring. Within
the next several hours, he awoke neurologically intact and was
extubated. Beta blockade, aspirin and a statin were resumed. On
postoperative day one, he was transferred to the step down unit
for further recovery. He was gently diuresed towards his
preoperative weight. The physical therapy service was consulted
for assistance with his postoperative strength and recovery. His
foley was replaced for urinary retention. His white count jumped
to 17, 000 and a urine culture was sent which was negative. He
was started on flomax and a repeat voiding trial was done prior
to discharge which he failed and was discharged to home with
foley in place. He will f/u with urology which needs to be
arranged through PCP for repeat voiding trial end of next week.
He was hyponatremic and he was free water restricted, he will
need to have his sodium checked on ___. He will need
to continue on lasix for ongoing diuresis and fluid overload.
All f/u appointments arranged.

although he does report that he felt cold. He reports drinking

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o male hx of diabetes, schizophrenia, alcoholism, and 
tobacco abuse with EtOH intoxication s/p fall found to have an 
anion gap metabolic acidosis and hyperglycemia. Given elevated 
EtOH level, he was placed on a CIWA protocol with diazepam and 
monitored for both elecrolyte abnormalities and refeeding 
syndrome. He remained stable with resolution of his intoxication 
and anion gap metabolic acidosis at the time of discharge.  
  
# EtOH Abuse and r/o Withdrawal: ___ presented to the ED 
intoxicated with a serum EtOH of 385. He was placed on a CIWA 
scale with diazepam 10mg q4h for CIWA > 10. He never showed 
objective evidence of withdrawals during admission. He was also 
given a multivitamin, folate and thiamine. Social work was 
consulted to counsel about his alcohol abuse and housing options 
after discharge from the hospital given that the ___ is 
homeless. His serum and urine toxicology screens were negative. 
His electrolytes were monitored for refeeding syndrome and 
remained within normal limits. The ___ was hemodynamically 
stable with an undetectable ethanol level at the time of 
discharge. He was ___ for alcohol abstinence.
   
# Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis: 
___ presented with an anion gap of 17. Given lack of ketones 
in the urine and no serum osmolar gap, lactic acidosis in the 
setting of hypovolemia is the most likely etiology. His acidosis 
resolved with IVF.   
   
# Mechanical Fall: ___ was found down, and it is unclear how 
long he had been down. ___ had a minor headache and forehead 
abrasions during his hospitalization but no other evidence of 
trauma. CT head and ___ showed no evidence of fracture. CK 
was within normal limits ruling out rhabdomyolysis.  
  
# Tobacco Abuse: ___ reported smoking cigarettes although he 
did not specify how much. He was treated with a nicotine patch 
during this admission and counseled on smoking cessation. 
  
# Type II Diabetes: Chronic, insulin dependent, poorly 
controlled, type II, complicated. ___ had elevated finger 
sticks in the 200s and was placed on a humalog sliding scale 
during his admission. He was found to have an HbA1c of 9.6%. He 
was discharged on his home medications, metformin and glipizide. 
As an outpatient would advise continuing titration of his 
diabetic medications.
   
#Hypertension: ___ consistently hypertensive while admitted 
with systolics in the ___. His home lisinopril was 
increased from 20mg to 40mg PO DAILY. In addition, he was 
prescribed metoprolol 50mg XL for cardio protection given 
history of an MI.

#Schizophrenia: ___ recieves monthly paliperidone 
injections. He was continued on home trazodone and hydroxyzine.  


TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
=======================
- f/u with his PCP
- ___ counseled on alcohol cessation and smoking cessation
- Continue titration of diabetic medications as outpatient given 
elevated ___
- Draft discharge summary faxed to ___ (PCP) on ___ @ 
___ - fax success
CONTACT INFO FOR HIS PCP: NP ___ - ___, note that 
they have a walk in clinic at ___ - 
WALK INS for HOMELESS OK 08:30AM - 11:30 AM. 
   
  
HMED ADD:
On initial admission the ___ was frankly intoxicated with 
lab abnormalities which were severe. As a result he was placed 
in inpatient status expecting it would take at least 48 hours 
(two midnights) to improve labs to baseline, control blood 
sugars and monitor for alcohol withdrawal. However once ___ 
became sober and was able to recount story it was clear he has 
never had alcohol withdrawal before, never had DTs or seizures 
and so was deemed low risk for developing withdrawal seizures. 
Additionally, ___ was not interested in alcohol abstinence 
and so was unlikely to remain sober after discharge, limiting 
utility of monitoring in house for withdrawal. He never had 
evidence of alcohol withdrawal in house. Lastly, patients labs 
improved dramatically with IVFs and time returning to normal on 
subsequent checks. As a result he did not require an additional 
midnight for close monitoring or repeat labs.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o male hx of diabetes, schizophrenia, alcoholism, and
tobacco abuse with EtOH intoxication s/p fall found to have an
anion gap metabolic acidosis and hyperglycemia. Given elevated
EtOH level, he was placed on a CIWA protocol with diazepam and
monitored for both elecrolyte abnormalities and refeeding
syndrome. He remained stable with resolution of his intoxication
and anion gap metabolic acidosis at the time of discharge.
# EtOH Abuse and r/o Withdrawal: ___ presented to the ED
intoxicated with a serum EtOH of 385. He was placed on a CIWA
scale with diazepam 10mg q4h for CIWA > 10. He never showed
objective evidence of withdrawals during admission. He was also
given a multivitamin, folate and thiamine. Social work was
consulted to counsel about his alcohol abuse and housing options
after discharge from the hospital given that the ___ is
homeless. His serum and urine toxicology screens were negative.
His electrolytes were monitored for refeeding syndrome and
remained within normal limits. The ___ was hemodynamically
stable with an undetectable ethanol level at the time of
discharge. He was ___ for alcohol abstinence.
# Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis:
___ presented with an anion gap of 17. Given lack of ketones
in the urine and no serum osmolar gap, lactic acidosis in the
setting of hypovolemia is the most likely etiology. His acidosis
resolved with IVF.
# Mechanical Fall: ___ was found down, and it is unclear how
long he had been down. ___ had a minor headache and forehead
abrasions during his hospitalization but no other evidence of
trauma. CT head and ___ showed no evidence of fracture. CK
was within normal limits ruling out rhabdomyolysis.
# Tobacco Abuse: ___ reported smoking cigarettes although he
did not specify how much. He was treated with a nicotine patch
during this admission and counseled on smoking cessation.
# Type II Diabetes: Chronic, insulin dependent, poorly
controlled, type II, complicated. ___ had elevated finger
sticks in the 200s and was placed on a humalog sliding scale
during his admission. He was found to have an HbA1c of 9.6%. He
was discharged on his home medications, metformin and glipizide.
As an outpatient would advise continuing titration of his
diabetic medications.
#Hypertension: ___ consistently hypertensive while admitted
with systolics in the ___. His home lisinopril was
increased from 20mg to 40mg PO DAILY. In addition, he was
prescribed metoprolol 50mg XL for cardio protection given
history of an MI.
#Schizophrenia: ___ recieves monthly paliperidone
injections. He was continued on home trazodone and hydroxyzine.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
=======================
- f/u with his PCP
- ___ counseled on alcohol cessation and smoking cessation
- Continue titration of diabetic medications as outpatient given
elevated ___
- Draft discharge summary faxed to ___ (PCP) on ___ @
___ - fax success
CONTACT INFO FOR HIS PCP: NP ___ - ___, note that
they have a walk in clinic at ___ -
WALK INS for HOMELESS OK 08:30AM - 11:30 AM.
HMED ADD:
On initial admission the ___ was frankly intoxicated with
lab abnormalities which were severe. As a result he was placed
in inpatient status expecting it would take at least 48 hours
(two midnights) to improve labs to baseline, control blood
sugars and monitor for alcohol withdrawal. However once ___
became sober and was able to recount story it was clear he has
never had alcohol withdrawal before, never had DTs or seizures
and so was deemed low risk for developing withdrawal seizures.
Additionally, ___ was not interested in alcohol abstinence
and so was unlikely to remain sober after discharge, limiting
utility of monitoring in house for withdrawal. He never had
evidence of alcohol withdrawal in house. Lastly, patients labs
improved dramatically with IVFs and time returning to normal on
subsequent checks. As a result he did not require an additional
midnight for close monitoring or repeat labs.

regurgitation with bileaflet prolapse. Given her worsening
symptoms and significance of her a mitral valve regurgitation,
she has been refered for surgical management.

some turbulence seen in the LVOT. No significant gradient 
demonstrated in the LVOT. Aorta is intact post decannulation.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ was admitted to the ___ on ___ for surgical 
management of her mitral valve disease. She was taken to the 
operating room where she underwent a  Mitral valve repair with 
resection of the middle scallop posterior leaflet, and a mitral 
valve annuloplasty with  a 28 mm Physio II annuloplasty 
ring/Modified left-sided maze procedure/ Left atrial appendage 
resection with ___ tolerated the procedure well and 
was transferred to the CVICI intubated and sedated. Six
hours status post mitral valve repair and left atrial appendage 
resection and a Maze procedure, was noted to have excessive 
drainage from her chest tube.  She remained
hemodynamically stable.  She was taken back for Mediastinal 
re-exploration/ Evacuation of hematoma/ Repair of left atrial 
appendage bleeder. Please see operative note for details. 
Postoperatively she was taken to the intensive care unit for 
monitoring.  Over the next several hours she awoke 
neurologically intact and was extubated. All lines and drains 
were discontinued per protocol. POD#1 she was in
atrial fibrillation with fluctuating Blood Pressure. Decision 
made to ___ at 1AM with sinus bradycardia and hypotension 
post-DCCV. She was atrially paced at via external leads with 
stable BP on Nitroglycerine. She was later weaned off NTG and 
did not further require atrial pacing. Pacing wires were removed 
per protocol. Beta blocker was not initiated to allow her 
conduction system recovery, as she remained in a 1st degree AV 
block. She was placed on Amiodarone for paroxysmal atrial 
fibrillation, along with anticoagulation with Coumadin. She was 
later transferred to the step down unit for further recovery. 
Mrs. ___ was gently diuresed towards her preoperative 
weight. Ace-Inhibitor was started for blood pressure control. 
The physical therapy service was consulted for evaluation with 
her postoperative strength and mobility. The remainder of her 
postoperative course was essentially uneventful. She continued 
to progress and was cleared for discharge to home on POD# 5 with 
___ services. All follow up appointments were advised.

RADIOLOGY:
MRI head ___: Bilateral frontoparietal subdural late 
subacute hematomas resulting in effacement of the sulci in the 
left frontoparietal region. The maximum dimension of the left 
subdural frontoparietal hematoma measures 1.5 cm in diameter and 
in the right side 1.2 cm in diameter.  There is no evidence 
intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, or hydrocephalus. There is 
no evidence of shift of midline structures.  There are no 
enhancing intracranial masses identified. 
.
CT head ___: Bilateral subdural hematomas.  In conjunction 
with the 
information MRI on ___, consistent with late subacute 
hematomas.  However, on the left, there is evidence of acute on 
subacute hemorrhage. The right subdural collection is 
isoattenuating without high attenuating components.  The 
greatest thickness on the left is 10 mm, the greatest thickness 
on the right is 12 mm.  There is no midline shift.  No CT 
evidence of major vascular territorial infarct.  In comparison 
to MRI from yesterday, the size of the collection appears 
stable. 
.
CT head with contrast ___: Unchanged appearance of bilateral 
subdural hematomas, with evidence of re-bleeding on the left, 
unchanged. 
.
MRA head ___: No evidence of dural sinus thrombosis.
.
CT head post op ___: Status post left craniotomy with 
expected postoperative pneumocephalus and fluid filling the left 
subdural space. moderate amount of pneumocephalus as well as a 
mixed collection of fluid and gas now fill the left subdural 
space, measuring approximately 1.4 cm in maximal diameter, with 
unchanged to slightly increased mass effect on the subjacent 
cortex.  The tiny right subdural hematoma is more isodense 
today, measuring 6 mm in greatest diameter.  No significant 
change in mass effect. 2. Unchanged small right subdural 
hematoma, in terms of size, but somewhat more isodense at this 
time. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ p/w with new subdurals found on follow-up MRI on ___.  
Neurosurgical service was contacted by PCP and pt was instructed 
to report to ED. Upon arrival, CT head showed: Bilateral 
subdural hematomas.  In conjunction with the 
information MRI on ___, consistent with late subacute 
hematomas.  However, on the left, there is evidence of acute on 
subacute hemorrhage. The right subdural collection is 
isoattenuating without high attenuating components.  The 
greatest thickness on the left is 10 mm, the greatest thickness 
on the right is 12 mm.  There is no midline shift.  No CT 
evidence of major vascular territorial infarct.  In comparison 
to MRI from yesterday, the size of the collection appears 
stable.

Given these new findings, the pt was admitted to hospital to 
neurosurgery service.  Follow-up CT on HD#2 was stable.  MRA on 
HD#2 was normal.
.
On HD#3 pt underwent left burrhole minicraniotomy hematoma 
evacution given that abscess could not be ruled out.  The pt 
tolerated the procedure well with no complications (for full 
details of the procedure, please see dictated report). The 
collection appeared to be hematoma grossly, consistent with SDH. 
Intraoperative cultures were sent to check for infectious 
process to be conservative.  Pt's postop CT showed: small amount 
of postoperative pneumocephalus and fluid filling the left 
subdural space. moderate amount of pneumocephalus as well as a 
mixed collection of fluid and gas now fill the left subdural 
space, measuring approximately 1.4 cm in maximal diameter, with 
unchanged to slightly increased mass effect on the subjacent 
cortex.  No significant change in mass effect. For conservative 
measures the patient had supplemental oxygen for 24 hours 
postoperatively given small amount pneumocephalus.  Pt had no 
post-operative neurologic deficits.
.
Neurology and infectious disease services were consulted.  
Neurology recommended MRA which was normal and bleeding 
diathesis workup which was negative to date on discharge.  
Further workup was recommended on outpatient basis.  Infectious 
disease recommended fluid cultures sent.  Gram stain negative 
and cultures were pending on day of discharge.
.
Brief course by system:
Neuro: as above.  On the day of discharge she was completely 
neurologically intact (see exam above) and post-operative pain 
well controlled.  No headaches.
CV: No issues.  hemodynamically stable on discharge.
Pulmonary: No issues.  O2 sat>95% on room air.  
GI: No issues.  pt tolerating full diet on discharge.
GU: No issues.  Pt making adequate urine with no foley on 
discharge
HEME: No issues. HCT stable post-op. Pt recommended to follow-up 
with primary care doctor for any further recommended work-up of 
bleeding disorder.  Workup thus far was negative.
ID: Afebrile, no elevation in ___.  Cultures pending from 
subdural collection.  NO empiric abx started.
Endocrine: Pt was taking prednisone 20mg daily on admission, 
prescribed by neurology for her headaches.  Postoperatively, her 
steroids were begun to be tapered.  She was recommended to 
followup with her neurologist and her PCP regarding this.
.
Pt was seen by physical therapy and evaluated to be safe to be 
discharged home.  
 
Medications on Admission:
ASA, Prednisone 20mg
 
Discharge Medications:

times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

Discharge Instructions:
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS FOR CRANIOTOMY/HEAD INJURY

ÂHave a family member check your incision daily for signs of 
infection
ÂTake your pain medicine as prescribed
ÂExercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
excessive bending
ÂYou may wash your hair only after sutures and/or staples have 
been removed 
ÂYou may shower before this time with assistance and use of a 
shower cap
ÂIncrease your intake of fluids and fiber as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation
ÂUnless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, aspirin, Advil, 
Ibuprofen etc. 
ÂIf you have been prescribed an anti-seizure medicine, take it 
as prescribed and follow up with laboratory blood drawing as 
ordered

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:

ÂNew onset of tremors or seizures
ÂAny confusion or change in mental status 
ÂAny numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities
ÂPain or headache that is continually increasing or not 
relieved by pain medication
ÂAny signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, drainage
ÂFever greater than or equal to 101Â° F

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Bright Red Blood Per Rectum (BRBPR)
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
EGD / Colonoscopy

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with history of 
diverticulosis s/p several GI bleeds, hypertension, 
hyperlipidemia, CAD s/p stent, occipital neuralgia, and 
intractable migraine headaches who presented to ___ as a 
transfer from ___ for BRBPR. Ms. ___ moved 
into an assisted living facility (___ at ___ on ___ and 
had a massive bloody bowel movement that night. She was 
initially seen at ___ around 9:30 ___, where her Hgb/Hct were 5 
and 16.1. At that time, she denied any abdominal pain, or pain 
with defecation. No fever/chills. She did note that she had felt 
lightheaded for the past ___ days, especially after having bowel 
movements. At that time, patient gave no history of ulcer 
disease or excessive NSAID use. She was given fentanyl and 
percocet in the ED for headache. She was transferred to ___ as 
there was no ICU availability at ___.

In the ___ ED, intial VS: 97.6 84 119/55 18 97% RA. Labs were 
significant for a Hgb/Hct of 6.3/20.3, MCV 110, WBC of 2.7, plt 
210, and INR 1. She was given 3U PRBC's and was crossmatched for 
4U PRBC's. Two large bore IV's were placed and she was 
transferred to the FICU. Upon transfer, VS: 98 81 123/63 16 97% 
RA. 
 
Upon arrival to the ICU, futher history was obtained. She 
reports several episodes of massive BRBPR, most recently in ___ resulting in a hospitalization at ___. She reports 
that she did not get imaging at that time, but her daughter 
reported that she had both an upper and lower scope with a 
diagnosis of diverticulosis but no clear source of bleeding. She 
also previously passed out on the toilet from her BRBPR and 
reports chipping a tooth. She reports that her neurologist was 
going to start her on prednisone today, which she has previously 
taken, but she does not know what this is treating.

Upon talking to the patient's daughter ___ (HCP), she reports 
that the patient takes massive doses of NSAIDs for headache 
despite the family's pleas for her not to do so. The daughter 
reports that the patient is not supposed to take any OTC 
medications given rebound headache and that she previously has 
received so much narcotic medication that she had an SBO. She 
also previously had a large nosebleed after taking NSAIDs. In 
___, the patient underwent a prednisone taper for her headaches 
at ___ and experienced some relief. She underwent a 
second taper with Dr. ___ at ___. Her daughter hopes that 
she can do a third taper, as this is the only thing that has 
helped her. ___ also is concerned about her mother receiving 
another scope given that her previous scopes did not find 
anything and given that she was very sedated from the medication 
and took two days to recover. 
 
Past Medical History:
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
CAD s/p stent
Temporal arteritis
Cervical spondylosis
Constipation
Depression
Syncope
GI bleeding
Iron deficiency anemia
Intractable migraine
Myelodysplastic sydrome with 5Q deletion
Occipital neuralgia
Osteoporosis
Hepatic hemangiomas

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Colon cancer in daughter, two grandchildren with celiac disease. 


 
Physical Exam:
ON ADMISSION:
Vitals: T 98 81 123/63 16 97% RA 
___: Alert, oriented, lying in bed with a washcloth over her 
forehead.  
HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear  
Neck: supple, JVP not elevated
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, 
ronchi  
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops  
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, 
no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly
Rectal: Dark brown stool in the vault, guaiac +   
Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or 
edema

ON DISCHARGE:
Vitals: T 99.3 150/70 ___ 18 98% RA 
___: Alert, oriented, lying in bed.
Eyes: PERRL
HENT: MMM, oropharynx clear  
Neck: supple, JVP not elevated

" You may experience increased acid reflux after you stop taking 
your PPI medication (omeprazole, pantoprazole, Nexium, Prilosec, 
etc). In order to decrease the chance of this occurring, we 
recommend that you taper the medication in the following 
fashion.
1. If you are taking the medication twice a day, start by only 
taking it once a day for at least 2 weeks.
2. If you are on 40mg of the medication, decrease this dose by 
50% for at least 2 weeks.
3. Once you are on the lowest dose, you can take the medication 
every other day for 2 weeks. If you experience heartburn during 
this time, you can take 150mg Zantac (Ranitidine) to help 
control the symptoms.
4. If you do not have heartburn at this juncture, you can stop 
the medication.

needed."

# CHF Exacerbation: Admitted with hypoxemia, requiring 
non-rebreather and CXR suggestive of florid pulmonary edema. 
Known EF ___ and LV thrombus on echo in ___. Unclear reason 
for decompensation - medication non-compliance vs. ischemia vs. 
dietary non-compliance. TSH 58 and hypothyroidism (FT4 0.4) can 
lead to worsened diastolic dysfunction so this could be 
contributing. Was actively diuresed at first successfully, over 
past 24h reacted less to lasix and developed othro-hypo, 
Diuresis held ___ with even goal, ___ +300cc for 24h, lungs 
sound more congested this morning but clinically stable and not 
hypoxic. Her metoprolol 12.5mg bid was continued. As her blood 
pressures and creatinine were stable, home lisinopril 5mg was 
started ___. She was also put on a cardiac healthy, low Na diet 
and her I/Os were targeted to be even. She was gradually weaned 
down from 2L delivered via nasal cannulae to O2 sats of the 
low-90s on room air. Patient remained euvolemic with no need for 
diuresis in house on days preceding discharge. Decision made to 
hold diuresis at time of discharge.
.
OUTPATIENT ISSUES:
- Continue metoprolol XL
- Consider performing echocardiography to reassess functional 
status and ejection fraction
- Follow-up with new cardiologist at ___ (Dr. ___ has 
retired) regarding LV thrombus and ?anticoagulation. If goal of 
care is comfort, would only schedule follow-up with primary care 
(done)
- Reassess need for PO diuretic as outpatient
.
# Cough- Persistent, non-productive. Has a history of 
bronchitis. Initially attributed to fluid overload. The concern 
was for pulmonary edema vs aspiration pneumonia vs bronchitis. 
She was afebrile, w/o leukocytosis and w/o infiltrates on repeat 
CXR. Impression was residual bronchitis in the setting of 
resolving pulmonary edema, with no pneumonic process. She was 
assessed by Rehab and placed on aspiration precautions with soft 
solids and thin liquids (Functional Oral Intake Scale (FOIS) 
rating of 7 out of 7). Nebulisers were ordered PRN. Stable and 
largely resolved prior to discharge
.
OUTPATIENT ISSUES:
- Follow-up speech and swallow recommendations
- Follow-up with primary care physician for bronchitis
- Start Albuterol inhaler as needed at home
- Aspiration precautions at home
.
# CAD: Known CAD s/p MI; No stress tests or cath reports 
available in our system. Here with troponin leak, but no 
complaints of chest pain and EKG at baseline with pre-cordial 
anteroseptal ST elevations c/w known LV aneurysm. Enzyme leak 
most likely demand related in setting of CHF exacerbation. 
Troponins peaked at 0.25, MB: 21, and CK rose to 2396 thus far.  
Elevated CK likely secondary to immobilization. Heparin gtt 
d/c-ed on ___. No active issues related to CAD during 
hospitalization.
.
OUTPATIENT ISSUES:
- Continue home ASA
- Continue metoprolol XL
- Continue lisinopril 2.5 mg if BPs remain stable
- Continue simvastatin
.
# RHYTHM: No known history of arrhythmias, been consistently in 
normal sinus rhythm since admission.
.
# Agitation/Dementia: Patient with significant agitation 
(including removing IVs, biting EMS) with some improvement with 
haldol and later zyprexa. Baseline is unknown. Hypothyroidism 
may be contributing given elevated TSH. Per caretakers at 
baseline alert and oriented x3 although dementia is listed in 
her PMH. Mental status possibly improved with 50mg qd then 100mg 
qd levothyroxine replacement. UA was negative, decreasing the 
possiblity of a UTI. She was not hyponatremic. The nurses 
actively engaged her with cards, games and crossword puzzles as 
per ___ protocol. Tether use was minimized as far as possible. 

.
OUTPATIENT ISSUES:
- Consider, if necessary, neurology evaluation for dementia and 
management of behavioural and psychological symptoms of dementia 
(if present)
- Caregiver should continue keeping her engaged in 
mentally-stimulating activities to prevent deterioration of 
cognitive function
.
# Acute on Chronic Kidney Disease: Stage III per ___ 
discharge summary, with creatinine of 1.4 in ___ (unclear if 
this is baseline). Creatinine stably elevated at 1.6 with 
trending. Nephrotoxins and renally dose medications were 
avoided. Diuresis with lisinopril was done to improve forward 
flow. At time of discharge creatinine stable at 1.1.
.
OUTPATIENT ISSUES:
- Continue to trend renal function as outpatient
.
# Hypothyroidism- Pt w/ high TSH of 58. Total T4: 3.2 Per 
discharge summary from ___ was supposed to be taking 
levothyroxine 200 mg PO daily, but per hand written medlist from 
___, does not appear to be taking at home. Per PCP coverage, 
as of ___ (at which time TSH was suppressed) dosing was 
175mcg MWF, 200mcg TThSaSu Restarted levothyroxine initially at 
50mg to prevent excessive myocardial oxygen demand. The free T4 
level was low at 0.4 on ___, and her dosing was increased to 
100mg.
.
OUTPATIENT ISSUES:
- Follow-up for hypothyroidism as this may complicate her 
cognitive function
- Will need repeat TFTs as outpatient
.
# DM-No active issues during CCU stay. She was continued on home 
lantus and put on a novolog sliding scale.
.
# Restless leg syndrome-No active issues during CCU stay. She 
was continued on home mirapex.
.
# Social, goals of care-Contact with son ___ was established 
and her status was changed from full to DNR/DNI. Son agrees for 
rehabilitation.
.
OUTPATIENT ISSUES:
- Hospice consult and care
- ___ at home

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Facial Swelling
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ w/ PMHx of HTN p/w L face swelling. Pt was punched in face 
___ night and had sutures placed at ___. He was also attacked 
at the chest and right temple. He was doing well under this 
morning when he awoke w/ significant pain and swelling on the 
left side of his face. He felt like he had a fever this morning 
with chills and sweats. c/o HA now. He is not having any blurry 
vision, dizziness, difficulty swallowing, SOB, stridor. He was 
taking Percocet for pain. No neck pain. 
 
In the ED, initial vital signs were 10 98.5 83 149/88 20 94% RA. 
Labs significant for a leukocytosis to 12.8 with a left shift. 
Lactate 1.1. Patient was given 4mg IV morphine, 1 dose unasyn, 
and 5mg percocet x2. CT sinus/mandible/maxillofacial 
demonstrated extensive stranding and edema, but no evidence of a 
discrete abscess.
 
Past Medical History:
HTN - untreated for years
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father died of MI at ___
Brother with heart disease
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals- 97.9 ___ 99%RA
General- Alert, oriented, no acute distress  
HEENT - Significant left sided swelling of the cheek, lips, and 
neck; no periorbital involvement.Pain to palpation, no 
underlying fluctuance. Mildly violaceous but without evidence of 
spreading erythema. 5 cm suture line extending laterally and 
superiorly from lip crease that is without purulence.  EOMI 
without pain. 
Neck - Supple although swelling evident along the L side
Lungs - Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, 
ronchi  
CV - Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops. Chest is painful to mid-deep palpation on the right 
side below the nipple along the rib.   
Abdomen - soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, 
no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly  
Ext - warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or 
edema  
Neuro - PEERL
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:20AM BLOOD WBC-8.8 RBC-5.62 Hgb-16.5 Hct-47.1 MCV-84 
MCH-29.3 MCHC-35.0 RDW-12.7 Plt ___
___ 07:10AM BLOOD WBC-9.1 RBC-5.65 Hgb-16.5 Hct-47.2 MCV-84 
MCH-29.3 MCHC-35.0 RDW-12.8 Plt ___
___ 07:04AM BLOOD WBC-12.0* RBC-5.46 Hgb-16.0 Hct-45.7 
MCV-84 MCH-29.2 MCHC-34.9 RDW-12.7 Plt ___
___ 09:00PM BLOOD WBC-12.5* RBC-5.34 Hgb-15.3 Hct-44.6 
MCV-84 MCH-28.6 MCHC-34.3 RDW-12.7 Plt ___
___ 01:20PM BLOOD WBC-12.8* RBC-5.64 Hgb-15.9 Hct-47.9 
MCV-85 MCH-28.2 MCHC-33.1 RDW-12.8 Plt ___
___ 06:20AM BLOOD Glucose-95 UreaN-12 Creat-0.9 Na-138 
K-4.1 Cl-102 HCO3-24 AnGap-16
___ 07:10AM BLOOD Glucose-110* UreaN-9 Creat-0.8 Na-137 
K-4.0 Cl-100 HCO3-25 AnGap-16
___ 07:04AM BLOOD Glucose-111* UreaN-9 Creat-0.7 Na-137 
K-3.8 Cl-101 HCO3-23 AnGap-17
___ 09:00PM BLOOD Glucose-109* UreaN-9 Creat-0.8 Na-138 
K-3.9 Cl-102 HCO3-23 AnGap-17
___ 06:20AM BLOOD Calcium-9.4 Phos-3.8 Mg-2.1
___ 01:39PM BLOOD Lactate-1.1

CT Scan (___):
IMPRESSION:
1.  Extensive soft tissue stranding and hematoma within the left 
cheek and
overlying the left mandible.  No discrete rim-enhancing fluid 
collection to
suggest an abscess.
2.  Reactive cervical lymphadenopathy.
3.  No evidence of fracture.
4.  Periapical lucency about the right maxillary ___ bicuspid 
tooth (#4)
compatible with periodontal disease.

Chest X-Ray (___):
FINDINGS:  On the current chest radiograph, the ribs on the left 
appear
intact.  There is no evidence of cortical changes suggestive of 
fracture.  No pneumothorax, no left pleural effusion.  However, 
a rib series should be
performed if the suspicion for fractures persists.
 
Borderline size of the cardiac silhouette.  Mild tortuosity of 
the thoracic
aorta.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ w/ PMHx of HTN p/w L face swelling s/p trauma with cut along 
L chin requiring sutures most suggestive of facial cellulitis.

*** Active Diagnosis ***

# Facial Cellulitis/Soft Tissue Infection
Patient with significant L sided facial pain with corresponding 
swelling extending from the L cheek to periorbital region to L 
side of the neck. Physical findings with low-grade fever and 
leukocytosis most consistent for possible cellulitis with soft 
tissue infection/traumatic swelling from his initial injury of 
being punched in the face. CT scan of the face and sinuses was 
negative for abscess, airway obstruction, free air, or fracture. 
The patient was started on IV vanc/unasyn, NSAIDs and pain meds 
with significant improvement seen in the swelling and pain, 
allowing for improved PO intake. Fevers and leukocytosis also 
resolved. During the course of admission, no evidence of airway 
compromise was noted with sats of 100% on RA. The patient was 
transitioned to PO equivalents with Augmentin and Bactrim 
prescribed for a total antibiotic course of 10 days (stop 
___ and given ibuprofen for swelling and 
oxycodone-acetominophen for pain control. 

# HTN
Patient with a prior history of hypertension that has been 
untreated for years. During his admission, his BP ranged in the 
upper 150s to 170s/90s despite improved pain control. The 
patient was started on low dose 5mg lisinopril with improved 
control of his BPs to 120s/80s. Chem panel on discharge revealed 
potassium within normal limits. Patient instructed to ___ 
with his PCP which was arranged.

# Facial Laceration
Patient with numerous simple interrupted stitches in the inside 
of his L mouth and external L cheek placed at ___ following 
facial trauma. Patient was instructed to ___ at ___ ER for 
suture removal as requested by ___ physicians.

*** Transitional Issues ***

___ with PCP upon discharge arranged.

- Patient will need to continue to be monitored for BP control 
with a re-check of chemistry recommended

- Continue to assess for improvement in swelling/pain of L face

- Patient agreed he would return to ___ for suture removal as 
instructed prior to being discharged from their ER.

- ___ on BC pending but NGTD
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Amoxicillin-Clavulanic Acid ___ mg PO Q12H 
RX *amoxicillin-pot clavulanate 875 mg-125 mg 1 tablet(s) by 
mouth Twice a day Disp #*14 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Ibuprofen 800 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain 
RX *ibuprofen 800 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Every 8 hours Disp 
#*30 Tablet Refills:*0
3. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY 
RX *lisinopril 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Daily Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*0
4. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
RX *oxycodone-acetaminophen [Endocet] 5 mg-325 mg 1 tablet(s) by 
mouth Every 4 hours Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0
5. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 1 TAB PO BID 
RX *sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim [Bactrim DS] 800 mg-160 mg 1 
tablet(s) by mouth Twice a day Disp #*14 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Facial cellulitis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Hello Mr. ___,

You came in with a soft tissue and skin infection of your face. 
You received IV antibiotics as treatment before switching to 
oral antibiotics. The swelling and other signs of infection such 
as high white blood cell count and fevers all significantly 
improved. For treatment of your infection you will need to 
continue to take antibiotics until ___ for a total of 10 
days of antibioitics.

Your blood pressure was also high while you were here and given 
your history of high blood pressure will need treatment. You 
were started on a blood pressure pill that controlled it well.

Please go and see a physician in the emergency room as 
instructed to remove the stitches in your mouth.

Please take these NEW medications:

- Take 1 tablet of Amoxicillin-Clavulanic Acid ___ mg every 12 
hours until ___: this is an antibiotic to treat your facial 
infection.

- Take 1 tablet of Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS every 12 hours 
until ___: this is an antibiotic to treat your facial 
infection.

- You may take ___ tablets of Oxycodone-Acetominophen ___ 
every 4 hours as needed for pain of the face

- You may take 800mg ibuprofen every 8 hours as needed for 
pain/swelling of the face

- Please take Lisinopril 5 mg daily for your blood pressure.

If you experience worsening swelling, pain, difficulty 
breathing, new difficulty swallowing, fevers, or expanding 
redness then please contact your primary care physician or come 
to the Emergency Room as soon as possible.

Please ___ with your primary care physician ___ 1 week 
after leaving the hospital. Your doctor ___ need to ___ 
on blood culture labs (looking for infection in your blood) that 
is still pending.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
___ w/ PMHx of HTN p/w L face swelling s/p trauma with cut along
L chin requiring sutures most suggestive of facial cellulitis.
*** Active Diagnosis ***
# Facial Cellulitis/Soft Tissue Infection
Patient with significant L sided facial pain with corresponding
swelling extending from the L cheek to periorbital region to L
side of the neck. Physical findings with low-grade fever and
leukocytosis most consistent for possible cellulitis with soft
tissue infection/traumatic swelling from his initial injury of
being punched in the face. CT scan of the face and sinuses was
negative for abscess, airway obstruction, free air, or fracture.
The patient was started on IV vanc/unasyn, NSAIDs and pain meds
with significant improvement seen in the swelling and pain,
allowing for improved PO intake. Fevers and leukocytosis also
resolved. During the course of admission, no evidence of airway
compromise was noted with sats of 100% on RA. The patient was
transitioned to PO equivalents with Augmentin and Bactrim
prescribed for a total antibiotic course of 10 days (stop
___ and given ibuprofen for swelling and
oxycodone-acetominophen for pain control.
# HTN
Patient with a prior history of hypertension that has been
untreated for years. During his admission, his BP ranged in the
upper 150s to 170s/90s despite improved pain control. The
patient was started on low dose 5mg lisinopril with improved
control of his BPs to 120s/80s. Chem panel on discharge revealed
potassium within normal limits. Patient instructed to ___
with his PCP which was arranged.
# Facial Laceration
Patient with numerous simple interrupted stitches in the inside
of his L mouth and external L cheek placed at ___ following
facial trauma. Patient was instructed to ___ at ___ ER for
suture removal as requested by ___ physicians.
*** Transitional Issues ***
___ with PCP upon discharge arranged.
- Patient will need to continue to be monitored for BP control
with a re-check of chemistry recommended
- Continue to assess for improvement in swelling/pain of L face
- Patient agreed he would return to ___ for suture removal as
instructed prior to being discharged from their ER.
- ___ on BC pending but NGTD

continue to take antibiotics until ___ for a total of 10

were started on a blood pressure pill that controlled it well.

If you experience worsening swelling, pain, difficulty
breathing, new difficulty swallowing, fevers, or expanding
redness then please contact your primary care physician or come
to the Emergency Room as soon as possible.

patent to the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.

no abnormality.

HEPATOBILIARY: The liver demonstrates homogenous attenuation 
throughout. 
There is no evidence of focal lesions.  There is no evidence of 
intrahepatic or extrahepatic biliary dilatation.  The 
gallbladder is within normal limits.
 
PANCREAS: The pancreas has normal attenuation throughout, 
without evidence of focal lesions or pancreatic ductal 
dilatation. There is no peripancreatic stranding.
 
SPLEEN: The spleen shows normal size and attenuation throughout, 
without
evidence of focal lesions.
 
ADRENALS:  The right and left adrenal glands are normal in size 
and shape.
 
URINARY: The kidneys are of normal and symmetric size with 
normal nephrogram. There is no evidence of focal renal lesions 
or hydronephrosis. There is no perinephric abnormality.
 
GASTROINTESTINAL: The stomach is unremarkable.  Small bowel 
loops demonstrate normal caliber, wall thickness, and 
enhancement throughout.  The colon and rectum are within normal 
limits.  There is no free intraperitoneal fluid or free air.
 
PELVIS:
The urinary bladder and distal ureters are unremarkable.  There 
is no free fluid in the pelvis.
 
REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS: The reproductive organs are unremarkable.
 
LYMPH NODES: There is no retroperitoneal or mesenteric 
lymphadenopathy.  There is no pelvic or inguinal 
lymphadenopathy.
 
VASCULAR: There is no abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Widely patent 
celiac axis, SMA, and ___.  Mild to moderate atherosclerotic 
disease is noted.
 
BONES AND SOFT TISSUES: There is no evidence of worrisome 
osseous lesions or acute fracture.  The abdominal and pelvic 
wall is within normal limits.
 
IMPRESSION:
1. No acute intrathoracic or intra-abdominal pathology.  
Specifically, no
acute aortic pathology.
2. Mild emphysematous changes.
3. Mild to moderate atherosclerotic disease.

___ EXERCISE MIBI
STRESS
INTERPRETATION: This ___ yo man with h/o HTN, HLD, IDDM, and 
smoking
was referred to the lab from the inpatient floor following 
negative
serial cardiac enzymes for evaluation of chest discomfort. The 
patient
exercised for 12.5 minutes of a Modified ___ protocol and was 
stopped
for fatigue. The estimated peak MET capacity was 10.6, which 
represents
an average exercise tolerance for his age. There were no reports 
of
chest, back, neck, or arm discomforts during the study. There 
were no
significant ST changes noted during exercise or recovery. Rhythm 
was
sinus with no ectopy. There was a blunted heart rate response to
exercise in the presence of beta blockade. There was an 
appropriate
blood pressure response during exercise and recovery.
IMPRESSION: No anginal type symptoms or ischemic EKG changes. 
Average
functional capacity. Nuclear report sent separately.

PERFUSION
FINDINGS:
 
The image quality is adequate but limited due to soft tissue 
attenuation.  
 
Left ventricular cavity size is normal.  
 
Resting and stress perfusion images reveal uniform tracer uptake 
throughout the
left ventricular myocardium.
 
Gated images reveal normal wall motion.
 
The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 54% with an 
EDV of 95 ml.
 
IMPRESSION:
 
1. Normal myocardial perfusion at the level of exercise 
achieved.
 
2. Normal left ventricular cavity size and systolic function.  
 
In the setting of diabetes, normal myocardial perfusion does not 
necessarily
imply a low risk of adverse cardiac events.

SUMMARY STATEMENT:
====================
___ is a ___ current every day smoker, with IDDM 
(A1c 11.5) p/w 3 days of chest pain that radiates to his back, 
shoulders, and head. CTA performed in the ED ruled out aortic 
dissection, trops negative x3, due to symptoms concerning for 
unstable angina he underwent exercise nuclear stress test which 
did not identify any reversible perfusion defects. Due to 
suboptimal study (approx. 12 minutes on modified ___ protocol) 
he was discharged home with instructions to follow up as 
outpatient for stress echo and in cardiology clinic.

The symptoms again worsened when he was walking outside to the

meters. These episodes of pain are associated with 
lightheadedness, pleuritic chest pain, nausea and dizziness 
which are worse with exertion and resolved with rest. He denies 
fever, diarrhea, abdominal pain. Denies cough, hemoptysis, 
recent long travel, unilateral ___ edema or tenderness. Troponins

intrathoracic process. subsequent CTA showed no acute 
intrathoracic or intra-abdominal pathology. There was mild 
emphysematous changes and moderate atherosclerotic disease. He 
underwent a modified ___ protocol, whereby he was on the 
treadmill for 12.5 minute and achieved a 56% target heart rate. 
Nuclear imaging showed no diffusion defects and no ECG changes 
were observed. Due to suboptimal study conditions (patient had 
taken beta blocker that morning) he was discharged home with 
plan to follow up as outpatient for repeat stress echo.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.

WHY WAS I ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?
- You were admitted to the hospital because you had episodes of 
chest pain, lightheadedness and difficulty breathing.

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL?
- In the hospital, we performed some imaging of your chest and 
heart, which were reassuring. Given that these episodes have 
happened before, we also performed a stress test to see if there 
were any changes in the electrical rhythm of your heart during 
exercise or decreased flow of blood through your arteries. Both 
of these studies did not show any abnormalities.

WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?
- Please take all of your medications exactly as prescribed and 
attend all of your follow-up appointments listed below.

- You will have a stress test as an outpatient next week.

We wish you the best!
Your ___ Care Team

exercised for 12.5 minutes of a Modified ___ protocol and was
stopped
for fatigue. The estimated peak MET capacity was 10.6, which
represents
an average exercise tolerance for his age. There were no reports
of
chest, back, neck, or arm discomforts during the study. There
were no
significant ST changes noted during exercise or recovery. Rhythm
was
sinus with no ectopy. There was a blunted heart rate response to
exercise in the presence of beta blockade. There was an
appropriate
blood pressure response during exercise and recovery.
IMPRESSION: No anginal type symptoms or ischemic EKG changes.
Average
functional capacity. Nuclear report sent separately.
PERFUSION
FINDINGS:
The image quality is adequate but limited due to soft tissue
attenuation.
Left ventricular cavity size is normal.
Resting and stress perfusion images reveal uniform tracer uptake
throughout the
left ventricular myocardium.
Gated images reveal normal wall motion.
The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 54% with an
EDV of 95 ml.
IMPRESSION:
1. Normal myocardial perfusion at the level of exercise
achieved.
2. Normal left ventricular cavity size and systolic function.
In the setting of diabetes, normal myocardial perfusion does not
necessarily
imply a low risk of adverse cardiac events.
Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY STATEMENT:
====================
___ is a ___ current every day smoker, with IDDM
(A1c 11.5) p/w 3 days of chest pain that radiates to his back,
shoulders, and head. CTA performed in the ED ruled out aortic
dissection, trops negative x3, due to symptoms concerning for
unstable angina he underwent exercise nuclear stress test which
did not identify any reversible perfusion defects. Due to
suboptimal study (approx. 12 minutes on modified ___ protocol)
he was discharged home with instructions to follow up as
outpatient for stress echo and in cardiology clinic.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
[] Stress echo scheduled for ___ at 8 am
[] Cardiology follow up scheduled with Dr. ___.
ACTIVE ISSUES:
==============
#Chest pain
Patient stated that he has had this pain in the past. About ___
years ago, he was admitted to ___ with similar symptoms but had
a negative cardiac workup including negative echo stress test.
The symptoms ultimately resolved but had similar symptoms 3 days
ago and have been progressively getting worse. The pain started
while he was shampooing his carpet two days prior to admission.
The symptoms again worsened when he was walking outside to the
bus stop to get to work in the AM, an approximate distance of 50
meters. These episodes of pain are associated with
lightheadedness, pleuritic chest pain, nausea and dizziness
which are worse with exertion and resolved with rest. He denies
fever, diarrhea, abdominal pain. Denies cough, hemoptysis,
recent long travel, unilateral ___ edema or tenderness. Troponins
were <0.01 x3. CXR in the ED did not demonstrate any acute
intrathoracic process. subsequent CTA showed no acute
intrathoracic or intra-abdominal pathology. There was mild
emphysematous changes and moderate atherosclerotic disease. He
underwent a modified ___ protocol, whereby he was on the
treadmill for 12.5 minute and achieved a 56% target heart rate.
Nuclear imaging showed no diffusion defects and no ECG changes
were observed. Due to suboptimal study conditions (patient had
taken beta blocker that morning) he was discharged home with
plan to follow up as outpatient for repeat stress echo.
CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
#Diabetes
Held home orals, resumed on discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___
___.
WHY WAS I ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?
- You were admitted to the hospital because you had episodes of
chest pain, lightheadedness and difficulty breathing.
WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL?
- In the hospital, we performed some imaging of your chest and
heart, which were reassuring. Given that these episodes have
happened before, we also performed a stress test to see if there
were any changes in the electrical rhythm of your heart during
exercise or decreased flow of blood through your arteries. Both
of these studies did not show any abnormalities.
WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?
- Please take all of your medications exactly as prescribed and
attend all of your follow-up appointments listed below.
- You will have a stress test as an outpatient next week.
We wish you the best!
Your ___ Care Team

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Dyspnea
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Pericardiocentesis ___

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o woman with a history of breast 
cancer s/p lumpectomy/lymph node dissection/XRT/chemotherapy in 
___ in remission who presented to ___ with two weeks of 
shortness of breath, non-productive cough as well as days of 
abdominal distention, poor appetite, and pleuritic chest pain 
found to have large pericardial effusion on CTA torso and 
transferred to ___ for further evaluation and management. 

Over the past 2.5 weeks, she has developed dyspnea and some 
discomfort in her upper chest "bronchus" area with deep breaths. 
The dyspnea was not particularly associated with exertion or 
position. She does endorse more chest discomfort when lying 
flat. She also had a cough productive of white sputum and fever, 
and
she attributed all these symptoms to bronchitis. The cough and 
fever resolved, but she continued to have dyspnea and pleuritic 
discomfort. She has also had worsening abdominal distention for 
the past 5 days and has not had a bowel movment during that 
time. No abdominal pain or n/v and is passing gas. She has also 
had decreased urine output for the past 2 days, including one 
day
when she did not urinate at all. This is unusual for her. She 
does not feel a sensation of needing to urinate.  

She grew up in ___, but denies any personal history of TB or 
exposure to anyone with TB that she knows of. She denies 
exposure to prisons or homeless shelters. She denies any recent 
travel outside ___. Her last international trip was to 
___ in ___. No recent tick bites.

EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT COURSE
Initial Vitals
- T97.4, HR 86, BP 120/81, RR20, O2 94%RA

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o woman with a history of breast 
cancer in ___ s/p lumpectomy, lymph node dissection, radiation, 
and chemotherapy now reportedly in remission who presented with 
dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain found to have large pericardial

# Pericardial Effusion 
# Pleural effusions
Patent presented with dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain, found to 
have large pericardial effusion on CTA with tamponade physiology 
on echo. She underwent pericardiocentesis with immediate output 
of 1.1L serosanguinous fluid on ___. Pericardial drain was 
kept in place for 1 day and patient monitored in CCU. Etiology 
of the pericardial and pleural effusions was felt secondary to 
possibly viral etiology given recent URI although given known 
h/o breast Ca, malignancy also considered. Her HIV was negative 
and TSH normal. Notably, cytology of pericardial fluid pending 
at time of discharge and will need to be followed up. Remaining

in ___ weeks should be done to evaluate for reaccumulation.

no hypoxemia and given clinical improvement, she was not 
diuresed. She should have CXR in follow up in ___ weeks to 
ensure improvement.

the setting of pericardial effusion as above. Viral HBV and HCV 
negative. Of note, she is not hepatitis B immune and should be 
considered for HBV vaccination

lymph node dissection, chemotherapy and radiation. Reportedly in 
remission but no recent follow up for this.

Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___

Chief Complaint:
sudden onset confusional state and loss of balance
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ yo woman with history of
HTN, CHF (unknown EF), osteoarthritis, impaired hearing and
dementia who presented after an episode of sudden onset
confusional state and loss of balance. Patient was in her usual
state of health this morning and was walking to the elevator 
with
the assistance of her aide.  They were on their way to ___
class.  Suddenly, she lost her balance and fell back into the
aide's arms.  Eyes were closed and she did not respond to her
name being called or anything else.  At that time, her vitals
were BP 150/80 RR ___ ___ 180.  Per nurse at ___, she
felt clammy to the touch.  She was gagging but did not vomit. 
Patient has lived at this facility for a year and has never had 
a
similar episode.  No known history of ischemic stroke or 
seizure.
She has had a decrease in her appetite in the last several days
and felt somewhat warm, but was afebrile.  At baseline, she has
dementia and can answer "simple questions." She requires help
with all of her ADLs--dressing, showering, toileting.     

On arrival to the ED, vitals were 55 115/46 16 100%.  On exam,
NIHSS was 18.  Pt was not following commands, not answering
questions.  Had mild right sided nasolabial fold flattening.  
Was
able to hold up both arms partially but drifted down.  Did not
hold up either leg.  Withdrew both legs to nail bed pressure and
said, "that hurts."  CT head did not show hemorrhage or edema. 
CTA with patent vessels.  CT perfusion scan was wnl.  In the ED,
exam improved over time and pt became more responsive (see
admission exam). 

ROS: unable to obtain, pt minimally communicative. 

 
Past Medical History:
CHF (unknown EF)
HTN
Osteoarthritis
Impaired hearing
Dementia
Critical Aortic stenosis.
Pulmonary HTN.
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non contributory

 
Physical Exam:
Neurologic Examination: (exam 2 hours after code stroke)
Mental Status: Awake, alert, tells me that her name is ___ and
that she is in the hospital.  Does not know what hospital or
city.  Does not know month or year.  Follows 1 step commands,
midline and
appendicular. (Sticks out her tongue, lifts her hand) Language
fluent, but does n with intact repetition (repeats "it is sunny
today.")  and verbal comprehension. Normal prosody. No 
paraphasic
errors. High and low frequency naming intact. No dysarthria. No
apraxia or neglect.

Cranial Nerves
[II] PERRL 2-->1mm; VF full to number counting. 
[III, IV, VI] EOMI, no nystagmus. 
[V] difficult to assess
[VII] mild R sided nasolabial fold flattening
[VIII] baseline impaired hearing
[IX, X] Palate elevation symmetric. 
[XI] SCM/Trapezius strength difficult to assess
[XII] Tongue midline.

Motor: Normal bulk and tone. No tremor or asterixis.
Formal strenght testing not possible as pt unable to cooperate. 
Holds up RUE and LUE for >10 seconds, no drift.  Hold up RLE
transiently.  Does not hold up LLE, however, does withdraw it
quickly with application of nailbed pressure. 

Sensory, coordination, gait: unable to assess

Reflexes
=[Bic] [Tri] [___] [Quad] [Gastroc]
L ___  1  0
R ___  1  0
Plantar response flexor bilaterally.

discharge PH/EX: awake, alert, oriented to her name and place 
but not to time  even with multiple choices.Speech is intact in 
all aspect. No deficite was detected in cranial nerve ,sensory, 
cordination and motor except forhearing difficulty, mild 
weakness in lower extremities bilaterally.
She has hyporeflexia in BIC, TRI, QUAD. plantar reflex: flexion 
bilaterally.
 
Pertinent Results:

Baso-0.3

K-3.7 Cl-102 HCO3-24 AnGap-13
___ 10:45AM BLOOD ALT-25 AST-36 AlkPhos-105 TotBili-0.6
___ 10:45AM BLOOD Lipase-39
___ 01:44PM BLOOD CK-MB-2 cTropnT-0.01
___ 04:55AM BLOOD Calcium-8.1* Phos-2.8 Mg-1.9
___ 05:10AM BLOOD Calcium-8.4 Phos-3.3 Mg-2.1 Cholest-212*
___ 05:10AM BLOOD Triglyc-78 HDL-80 CHOL/HD-2.7 LDLcalc-116
___ 10:45AM BLOOD ASA-NEG Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-NEG 
Bnzodzp-NEG Barbitr-NEG Tricycl-NEG
___ 11:02AM BLOOD pH-7.47*
___ 11:02AM BLOOD freeCa-1.10*
U/C no growth.

Echo: Suboptimal image quality. Critical aortic valve stenosis. 
Severe pulmonary artery hypertension. Moderate mitral 
regurgitation. Mild aortic regurgitation. Symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy with normal regional and low normal 
global biventricular systolic function.

Brain MRI:
No acute infarction. 
2.  Moderate-to-significant chronic microvascular ischemic 
disease.  
3.  Moderate global atrophy. 

CTA head and neck: Mild focal narrowing at the inferior branch 
of M2 of the right MCA, without distal occlusion.  Otherwise, 
essentially normal CTA, without flow-limiting stenosis, aneurysm 
greater than 3 mm or vascular malformation. Mild carotid 
bifurcation calcification, without flow-limiting stenosis. Major 
cervical vessels patent. 
  
EEG: This is an abnormal continuous video EEG telemetry due to 
slow 
posterior dominant rhythm, intermittent focal slowing and 
frequent 
epileptiform sharp waves over left temporo-parietal regions. 
There are no 
pushbutton activations. Automated and routine sampling 
demonstrate frequent sharp discharges over the left 
temporo-parietal regions. No electrographic seizures are seen. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
  ___  ___ is a ___ yo woman with history of HTN, CHF, 
aortic stenosis, osteoarthritis, impaired hearing and dementia 
who presented after an episode of sudden onset confusional state 
and loss of balance while walking toward music class with her 
aide. Upon her arrival, a CODE STROKE was called. CT imaging in 
the ED, including CT perfusion did not show any acute stroke or 
perfusion deificts. An MRI was performed, which did not show any 
acute infarcts. She had an EEG to evaluate for seizure as 
possible cause of her presentation; the EEG showed no 
electrographic 
seizures, though she did have frequent epileptogenic discharges 
over left temporo-parietal regions. As no seizures were seen, it 
was decided that the risk of starting an antiepileptic 
medication outweighed the benefits. She had a TTE, which showed 
critical aortic valve stenosis and severe pulmonary 
hypertension. Her critical AS was previously known to family and 
she has an outpatient cardiologist who follows her for this; it 
was decided as an outpatient to not pursue surgical 
intervention. Her episode of confusional state and loss of 
balance was most likely due to a presyncopal episode of cardiac 
etiology. While being monitored on telemetry, she was noted to 
have long pauses. She also developed an episode of fluid 
responsive hypotension. A Cardiology Consult was placed; they 
recommended that due to the pauses on telemetry, Digoxin and 
Metoprolol should be d/c. Initially, they recommended continuing 
Lasix 40 mg qAM and subsequently to add a 20 mg dose of Lasix in 
the afternoon. After the Metoprolol and Digoxin were held, she 
was no longer having long pauses on tele and her blood pressure 
remained stable. 
  Due to her critical AS, after discussion with family, Code 
Status was changed to DNR/DNI. Her family believed that she 
would be happiest if she would be able to return to her assisted 
living facility. A palliative care consult was placed; who 
recommended that ___ evaluate her and see if she will be able to 
ambulate and thus return to her assisted living facility. Her 
assisted care facility representative came to assess her and 
determined that she would be able to return if a home health 
aide was obtained to be with her overnight; this was obtained 
and she is being discharged to her assisted living facility. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Lasix 40mg daily
Aspirin 325mg daily
Digoxin 0.125mg ___
Enalapril 10mg daily
Metoprolol ER 25mg daily
Cosamin DS 2 caps in the morning, 1 cap in the evening
Vitamin C 1000mg daily
Calcium/Magnesium/Zinc 1 tab daily
