Brief Hospital Course:
___ ___ is a ___ yo woman with history of HTN, CHF,
aortic stenosis, osteoarthritis, impaired hearing and dementia
who presented after an episode of sudden onset confusional state
and loss of balance while walking toward music class with her
aide. Upon her arrival, a CODE STROKE was called. CT imaging in
the ED, including CT perfusion did not show any acute stroke or
perfusion deificts. An MRI was performed, which did not show any
acute infarcts. She had an EEG to evaluate for seizure as
possible cause of her presentation; the EEG showed no
electrographic
seizures, though she did have frequent epileptogenic discharges
over left temporo-parietal regions. As no seizures were seen, it
was decided that the risk of starting an antiepileptic
medication outweighed the benefits. She had a TTE, which showed
critical aortic valve stenosis and severe pulmonary
hypertension. Her critical AS was previously known to family and
she has an outpatient cardiologist who follows her for this; it
was decided as an outpatient to not pursue surgical
intervention. Her episode of confusional state and loss of
balance was most likely due to a presyncopal episode of cardiac
etiology. While being monitored on telemetry, she was noted to
have long pauses. She also developed an episode of fluid
responsive hypotension. A Cardiology Consult was placed; they
recommended that due to the pauses on telemetry, Digoxin and
Metoprolol should be d/c. Initially, they recommended continuing
Lasix 40 mg qAM and subsequently to add a 20 mg dose of Lasix in
the afternoon. After the Metoprolol and Digoxin were held, she
was no longer having long pauses on tele and her blood pressure
remained stable. Due to her critical AS, after discussion with family, Code
Status was changed to DNR/DNI. Her family believed that she
would be happiest if she would be able to return to her assisted
living facility. A palliative care consult was placed; who
recommended that ___ evaluate her and see if she will be able to
ambulate and thus return to her assisted living facility. Her
assisted care facility representative came to assess her and
determined that she would be able to return if a home health
aide was obtained to be with her overnight; this was obtained
and she is being discharged to her assisted living facility.

Brief Hospital Course:
# Respiratory distress:  Treated for Healthcare associated 
pneumonia or aspiration pneumonia. He was oxygenating adequately 
on ___ mask and ventilating adequately with pCO2 39 on VBG 
upon arrival to the ICU, though he was at risk for tiring out if 
tachypnea persisted.  He was empirically started on HCAP 
coverage with vanc and cefepime, and azithromycin was added.  
The initial chest x-ray did not show a definitive pneumonia, but 
a repeat chest x-ray did suggest pneumonia.  Legionella urinary 
antigen was negative.  He was continued on ___ mask and 
transitioned to NC O2.

Upon discharge he was breathing comfortably on 2L NC.

# Sepsis:  Pt met SIRS criteria with fever, leukocytosis and 
tachycardia, likely due to PNA as above.  Doubted UTI given 
bland UA.  He had a pressure sore on his left hip which was well 
appearing.  C. difficile colitis was on the differential since 
pt was recently treated with levofloxacin, but he did not have 
diarrhea and his abdominal exam was benign.  Blood cultures were 
drawn and pt was treated with vanc/cefepime/azithro as above.  
He was continued on broad-spectrum IV antibx until discharge.

# Renal insufficiency:  Cr is 1.6, increased from 1.2 in ___. 
 Ddx included prerenal azotemia which was most likely in setting 
of hypernatremia.  Intrinsic renal disease, possibly due to 
prolonged prerenal state, was also a consideration.  Post-renal 
obstruction was possible and would most likely be relieved by 
placement of foley in ED.  He was rehydrated with IVF and Cr 
improved to 1.0.

# Hypernatremia: Ongoing problem at nursing facility.  Most 
likely due to poor PO intake and limited access to free water 
given immobility.  ___ also be exacerbated by insensible water 
losses in the setting of infection.  He was initially given 
isotonic fluid boluses for now, and after volume resuscitation 
was given D5W to replete free water deficit.

# Anemia:  Macrocytic anemia with MCV 104.  Chart history lists 
anemia though does not characterize which type.  Differential 
diagnosis includes B12 deficiency, folate deficiency, liver 
disease, reticulocytosis, hypothyroidism, MDS.  B12 level was 
greater than normal and TSH was WNL.  H/H on admission was 
9.4/32.2 and decreased to 6.___.0 on the second hospital day. 
Improved and stable in the mid ___ without transfusion.

# Coagulopathy: Elevated ___ and INR but normal PTT.  Suspected 
dietary vitamin K defiency; differential also included liver 
disease, factor inhibitor.  No procedures were planned and there 
was no need for reversing with vitamin K.

# Code status/goals of care

His family was contacted about code status and goals of care, 
and he was made DNR/DNI.  He was continued on albuterol and 
ipratropium nebs PRN. He was weaned off of ___ mask to nasal 
cannula. 

Spoke with son ___ and his wife ___ (a nurse). We 
discussed his poor prognosis in general and likelihood that he 
will have another apsiration event very soon. For quality of 
life issues we will continue to feed him. They still do want 
antibiotics and some therapy, but they do not want aggressive 
treatment such as intubation or operations. we left messages for 
___ the other son. His daughter was not reachable as she is a 
nursing home herself.

I spoke with ___, the nurse practitioner at the ___ and 
updated her on course of care during hospital.

Brief Hospital Course:
# Respiratory distress: Treated for Healthcare associated
pneumonia or aspiration pneumonia. He was oxygenating adequately
on ___ mask and ventilating adequately with pCO2 39 on VBG
upon arrival to the ICU, though he was at risk for tiring out if
tachypnea persisted. He was empirically started on HCAP
coverage with vanc and cefepime, and azithromycin was added.
The initial chest x-ray did not show a definitive pneumonia, but
a repeat chest x-ray did suggest pneumonia. Legionella urinary
antigen was negative. He was continued on ___ mask and
transitioned to NC O2.
Upon discharge he was breathing comfortably on 2L NC.
# Sepsis: Pt met SIRS criteria with fever, leukocytosis and
tachycardia, likely due to PNA as above. Doubted UTI given
bland UA. He had a pressure sore on his left hip which was well
appearing. C. difficile colitis was on the differential since
pt was recently treated with levofloxacin, but he did not have
diarrhea and his abdominal exam was benign. Blood cultures were
drawn and pt was treated with vanc/cefepime/azithro as above.
He was continued on broad-spectrum IV antibx until discharge.
# Renal insufficiency: Cr is 1.6, increased from 1.2 in ___. Ddx included prerenal azotemia which was most likely in setting
of hypernatremia. Intrinsic renal disease, possibly due to
prolonged prerenal state, was also a consideration. Post-renal
obstruction was possible and would most likely be relieved by
placement of foley in ED. He was rehydrated with IVF and Cr
improved to 1.0.
# Hypernatremia: Ongoing problem at nursing facility. Most
likely due to poor PO intake and limited access to free water
given immobility. ___ also be exacerbated by insensible water
losses in the setting of infection. He was initially given
isotonic fluid boluses for now, and after volume resuscitation
was given D5W to replete free water deficit.
# Anemia: Macrocytic anemia with MCV 104. Chart history lists
anemia though does not characterize which type. Differential
diagnosis includes B12 deficiency, folate deficiency, liver
disease, reticulocytosis, hypothyroidism, MDS. B12 level was
greater than normal and TSH was WNL. H/H on admission was
9.4/32.2 and decreased to 6.___.0 on the second hospital day.
Improved and stable in the mid ___ without transfusion.
# Coagulopathy: Elevated ___ and INR but normal PTT. Suspected
dietary vitamin K defiency; differential also included liver
disease, factor inhibitor. No procedures were planned and there
was no need for reversing with vitamin K.
# Code status/goals of care
His family was contacted about code status and goals of care,
and he was made DNR/DNI. He was continued on albuterol and
ipratropium nebs PRN. He was weaned off of ___ mask to nasal
cannula.
Spoke with son ___ and his wife ___ (a nurse). We
discussed his poor prognosis in general and likelihood that he
will have another apsiration event very soon. For quality of
life issues we will continue to feed him. They still do want
antibiotics and some therapy, but they do not want aggressive
treatment such as intubation or operations. we left messages for
___ the other son. His daughter was not reachable as she is a
nursing home herself.
I spoke with ___, the nurse practitioner at the ___ and
updated her on course of care during hospital.

8. Finasteride 5 mg PO DAILY

10. Ranitidine 150 mg PO HS

Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left arm numbness
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ female with a past medical history of fibromyalgia, 
bell's palsy/ Lyme disease, and insulin dependent diabetes 
mellitus presenting with worsening sensation of heaviness and 
decreased sensation in L arm since ___. Pt reports some mild 
subjective weakness but states that feeling is more that the 
limb is heavy. Symptoms started at rest and patient reports no 
trauma. Earlier ___ patient began to feel that the sensation 
was spreading to her chest and into her neck. Symptoms are not 
made worse or brought on with any movement. Pt denies any chest 
pain, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, fevers or chills. 
In ___, pt reported episode of feeling like a veil was coming 
down over her eyes while driving. This lasted only a few seconds 
and then resolved. Pt also reports new occasional stabbing 
temporal pain. Previous episode at age ___ of head pain and L 
sided paralysis lasting 10 days with ?vertebral artery 
dissection vs. complex migraine. Pt was seen at ___ 
___ and MRI, MRA, CT head, and labs were performed. Pt was 
told all studies were normal. Followed up with Neurology who 
were unable to open imaging from OSH. Reordered MRI here which 
showed multilevel disc degeneration with cord contact but no 
cord signal change and some narrowing at C3/4.  
  
In the ED, patient was given ruled out for an myocardial 
infarction with 2 sets of negative troponins (per patient, 
however, both her mother and brother had myocardial infarctions 
with no enzyme bumps). She had a stress test ___ described 
below which was positive. Patient states that the heaviness did 
not change in her arm during the stress test, however, at the 
end of the stress test her arm became more heavy and her left 
leg also became heavy.  
  
On arrival to the floor, patient is doing well and in no acute 
distress.  
  
On review of systems, patient endorses joint pains and myalgias. 
She denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous 
thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, 
cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. She denies recent 
fevers, chills or rigors. She denies exertional buttock or calf 
pain. All of the other review of systems were negative.  

Cardiac review of systems is notable for occasional palpitations 
but absence of chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal 
nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, syncope or presyncope 
.

IMAGING:

STRESS TEST ___: IMPRESSION: Ischemic EKG changes in the 
presence of atypical non-progressive symptoms at a high cardiac 
demand and good functional capacity.

CARDIAC PERFUSION STRESS TEST ___: IMPRESSION: 1. No 
myocardial perfusion defects. 2. Normal wall motion with an  
ejection fraction of 64%. 

MRI/MRA ___: 
IMPRESSION: 
1. No evidence of acute infarct on diffusion images of the 
brain. It should  be noted that the brain examination was 
limited to diffusion images and remaining sequences were not 
obtained.   
2. Normal MRA of the neck.   
3. Normal MRA of the head. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ female with a past medical history of fibromyalgia, 
bell's palsy/ Lyme disease, and insulin dependent diabetes 
mellitus who presented with worsening sensation of heaviness and 
decreased sensation in her L arm x ___ weeks, admitted to rule 
out MI because of positive stress test.  She had a perfusion 
stress test that was negative, and was transferred to the 
neurology service for further evaluation of her arm symptoms.
.
# CARDS:  She was initially put on a 325mg ASA, but was then 
switched to 81mg ASA when her cardiac enzymes and her perfusion 
stress test returned negative.  We decided to restart her on 
lipitor at dispo.  Per cardiology recs she was also started on 
lisinopril 5mg QD to better control her BP and for her strong 
FHx of heart disease.  

# NEURO: Her MRI/MRA showed no acute issue.  Her EEG showed no 
seizure activity.  We continued her on her home gabapentin, 
metaxalone and amytriptyline.  We felt that her sx were likely 
related to her known cervical spine degeneration, however if her 
sx do not improve with a soft cervical collar and rest she will 
have a more extensive workup as an outpatient.

# ENDO: her HgA1C was 6.7.  We held her metformin while an 
inpatient and kept her on an insulin sliding scale with her home 
dose lantus QHS.
  
PENDING LABS:
None

TRANSITIONAL CARE ISSUES:
She will need further follow-up of her neurological issues.  She 
had been instructed to wear her soft cervical collar every day 
and night until she is seen in clinic. She already has a 
follow-up appointment set up to see Dr. ___ in clinic in 2 
weeks.
 
Medications on Admission:
Gabapentin 600mg TID
Metaxalone 800mg BID
Amytriptyline 25mg at night
Metformin 1000mg BID
Lantus 20U qHs
ASA 81mg daily
Lorazepam 1mg PRN

times a day).  
2. metaxalone 800 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times 
a day).  
3. amitriptyline 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at 
bedtime).  
4. metformin 1,000 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day. 
 
5. Lantus 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: Twenty (20) Units 
Subcutaneous at bedtime.  
6. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
7. lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 
hours) as needed for anxiety.  
8. lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
9. Lipitor 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
10. hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once 
a day as needed for leg swelling.  
11. albuterol sulfate 90 mcg/Actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: 
One (1)  Inhalation four times a day as needed for shortness of 
breath or wheezing.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary: Type II diabetes, Dyslipidemia, Fibromyalgia, cervical 
spine degeneration
Secondary: Lyme disease (treated), Bell's palsy. 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

NEURO EXAM: L-sided extensor weakness and L facial droop

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms ___,

It was our pleasure taking care of you at ___.  

You were admitted from the emergency room for heaviness in your 
left arm and a positive exercise stress test.  

We repeated a stress test with nuclear imaging which showed the 
same changes on your EKG as the previous test, but no concerning 
changes in the perfusion/ blood flow to your heart muscle, which 
is reassuring.  We also did an electroencephalogram, measuring 
the electrical activity in your brain, which did not show any 
seizure activity and an MRI of your head to look at the brain 
and vasculature in your brain that did not show any abnormality. 
 Therefore, we sent you home with a soft cervical collar and 
plan to see if you improve in clinic.

We made the following changes to your medications.
Please START Lisinopril 5mg daily
Please START Lipitor 20mg daily.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

ejection fraction of 64%.
MRI/MRA ___:
IMPRESSION:
1. No evidence of acute infarct on diffusion images of the
brain. It should be noted that the brain examination was
limited to diffusion images and remaining sequences were not
obtained.
2. Normal MRA of the neck.
3. Normal MRA of the head.
Brief Hospital Course:
___ female with a past medical history of fibromyalgia,
bell's palsy/ Lyme disease, and insulin dependent diabetes
mellitus who presented with worsening sensation of heaviness and
decreased sensation in her L arm x ___ weeks, admitted to rule
out MI because of positive stress test. She had a perfusion
stress test that was negative, and was transferred to the
neurology service for further evaluation of her arm symptoms.
.
# CARDS: She was initially put on a 325mg ASA, but was then
switched to 81mg ASA when her cardiac enzymes and her perfusion
stress test returned negative. We decided to restart her on
lipitor at dispo. Per cardiology recs she was also started on
lisinopril 5mg QD to better control her BP and for her strong
FHx of heart disease.
# NEURO: Her MRI/MRA showed no acute issue. Her EEG showed no
seizure activity. We continued her on her home gabapentin,
metaxalone and amytriptyline. We felt that her sx were likely
related to her known cervical spine degeneration, however if her
sx do not improve with a soft cervical collar and rest she will
have a more extensive workup as an outpatient.
# ENDO: her HgA1C was 6.7. We held her metformin while an
inpatient and kept her on an insulin sliding scale with her home
dose lantus QHS.
PENDING LABS:
None
TRANSITIONAL CARE ISSUES:
She will need further follow-up of her neurological issues. She
had been instructed to wear her soft cervical collar every day
and night until she is seen in clinic. She already has a
follow-up appointment set up to see Dr. ___ in clinic in 2
weeks.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms ___,
It was our pleasure taking care of you at ___.
You were admitted from the emergency room for heaviness in your
left arm and a positive exercise stress test.
We repeated a stress test with nuclear imaging which showed the
same changes on your EKG as the previous test, but no concerning
changes in the perfusion/ blood flow to your heart muscle, which
is reassuring. We also did an electroencephalogram, measuring
the electrical activity in your brain, which did not show any
seizure activity and an MRI of your head to look at the brain
and vasculature in your brain that did not show any abnormality. Therefore, we sent you home with a soft cervical collar and
plan to see if you improve in clinic.
We made the following changes to your medications.
Please START Lisinopril 5mg daily
Please START Lipitor 20mg daily.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is an ___ yo female with PMHx Afib on apixaban, 
C.diff on flagyl, HTN, and hypothyroidism who presented after an 
unwitnessed fall found to be in Afib with RVR and develop 
hypotension now requiring 1 pressor. Course has been complicated 
by acute delirium. 

#Goals of care:
Initially full code.  Due to Pt's clinical deterioration, as 
well as her lack of improvement despite pressor initiation and 
frequent fluid resuscitation, a goals of care meeting was had 
with the family on ___.  She was transitioned to comfort 
measures only at that time.  Medications not contributing to the 
patient's comfort were stopped after this meeting. She died 
shortly after being called out from the ICU.

# Shock
# Hypotension
Likely due to sepsis from C. diff vs unknown source, compounded 
by hypovolemia due to poor PO intake and diarrhea. Cardiac 
etiology possible, given afib with RVR and extravascular 
overload, though this seemed less likely. Given significant 
fluid repletion during her hospital course (over 18L positive as 
of ICU discharge), given IVC collapsibility and frequent fluid 
responsiveness.  Over the course of her hospital course, she 
required central access for pressor support.  C. diff was 
positive, so PO vancomycin and IV metronidazole were initiated 
in addition to empiric vanc/cefepime for sepsis of other unclear 
source.  AM cortisol negative for adrenal insufficiency.  After 
goals of care meeting as above, antibiotics and other 
medications not focused on comfort were discontinued.

#AFib with RVR: 
Initially requiring amiodarone bolus -> gtt, then PO with 
Dobhoff.  Precedex also initiated to help with agitation and 
provide some rate control given side effect of bradycardia.  She 
was on heparin gtt for anticoagulation given several procedures 
during her hospital course. 
 
#C. Diff: 
Treated with PO vancomycin and IV metronidazole as above.

# Delirium
___ ICU, illness, hypotension. Per discussion with the family, 
has had some element of progressive decline since new diagnosis 
of Afib in ___.  Precedex initially required for 
agitation, but this was discontinued as Pt's mental status 
declined. 

#Acute on chronic kidney injury with
#Volume overload
___ initially improved with fluids, then began to worsen as Pt 
became progressively fluid overloaded.  Unable to improve volume 
overload with diuresis.  After goals of care meeting, further 
fluid and diuretic administration was stopped.

# Unwitnessed Fall
CT head and C-spine without pathology.  Echocardiogram ___ with 
preserved biventricular systolic function, moderate MR and mild 
PA systolic hypertension.  

#Hypothyroidism
Continued ___ levothyroxine 50 mcg

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
# CODE:  DNR/DNI, comfort measures only
# CONTACT:
___ (daughter and HCP) ___
___ (son in law) ___
___ - ___

4. Apixaban 2.5 mg PO BID 
5. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is an ___ yo female with PMHx Afib on apixaban,
C.diff on flagyl, HTN, and hypothyroidism who presented after an
unwitnessed fall found to be in Afib with RVR and develop
hypotension now requiring 1 pressor. Course has been complicated
by acute delirium.
#Goals of care:
Initially full code. Due to Pt's clinical deterioration, as
well as her lack of improvement despite pressor initiation and
frequent fluid resuscitation, a goals of care meeting was had
with the family on ___. She was transitioned to comfort
measures only at that time. Medications not contributing to the
patient's comfort were stopped after this meeting. She died
shortly after being called out from the ICU.
# Shock
# Hypotension
Likely due to sepsis from C. diff vs unknown source, compounded
by hypovolemia due to poor PO intake and diarrhea. Cardiac
etiology possible, given afib with RVR and extravascular
overload, though this seemed less likely. Given significant
fluid repletion during her hospital course (over 18L positive as
of ICU discharge), given IVC collapsibility and frequent fluid
responsiveness. Over the course of her hospital course, she
required central access for pressor support. C. diff was
positive, so PO vancomycin and IV metronidazole were initiated
in addition to empiric vanc/cefepime for sepsis of other unclear
source. AM cortisol negative for adrenal insufficiency. After
goals of care meeting as above, antibiotics and other
medications not focused on comfort were discontinued.
#AFib with RVR:
Initially requiring amiodarone bolus -> gtt, then PO with
Dobhoff. Precedex also initiated to help with agitation and
provide some rate control given side effect of bradycardia. She
was on heparin gtt for anticoagulation given several procedures
during her hospital course.
#C. Diff:
Treated with PO vancomycin and IV metronidazole as above.
# Delirium
___ ICU, illness, hypotension. Per discussion with the family,
has had some element of progressive decline since new diagnosis
of Afib in ___. Precedex initially required for
agitation, but this was discontinued as Pt's mental status
declined.
#Acute on chronic kidney injury with
#Volume overload
___ initially improved with fluids, then began to worsen as Pt
became progressively fluid overloaded. Unable to improve volume
overload with diuresis. After goals of care meeting, further
fluid and diuretic administration was stopped.
# Unwitnessed Fall
CT head and C-spine without pathology. Echocardiogram ___ with
preserved biventricular systolic function, moderate MR and mild
PA systolic hypertension.
#Hypothyroidism
Continued ___ levothyroxine 50 mcg

REPORTS:

CXR
IMPRESSION: 
In comparison with the study of ___, the monitoring and 
support devices are unchanged.  Continued enlargement of the 
cardiac silhouette with decreasing pulmonary vascular 
congestion.  Small pleural effusions with basilar atelectasis 
are again seen bilaterally, more prominent on the left. No 
definite acute focal pneumonia.  However, in the appropriate 
clinical
setting, it would be difficult to unequivocally exclude basilar 
consolidation, especially in the absence of a lateral view.

Echo ___: IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Normal 
biventricular cavity sizes with global hypokinesis in a pattern 
most c/w a non-ischemic cardiomyopathy. 

MICROBIOLOGY

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo female with h/o HTN, COPD, ?neuromuscular disorder who was 
admitted after cardiac arrest with CHB. She developed hypoxemic 
respiratory failure and failed an extubation trial. She went 
into complete heart block, atrial fibrillation with RVR, and 
atrial flutter intermittently, and was put on heparin due to her 
high risk of thromboembolism. She suffered PEA arrest x2 
secondary to retroperitoneal bleed. She went into mixed 
septic/hypovolemic shock requiring multiple pressors. She 
developed acute renal failure requiring CRRT. During this time, 
she remained on ventilator support. On ___, a family 
meeting was held to discuss overall prognosis and further goals 
of care. In accordance with the patient's previously described 
preferences, the decision was made by the family to transition 
the patient to comfort-focused care. The patient died peacefully 
on ___ at 1540.
 
# Cardiac arrest prior to admission: 
Initial arrest occurred due to complete heart block. Admission 
electrolytes were normal and tox screen was negative. She was 
initially treated with heparin gtt x48 hours, asa, atorvastatin 
80, metoprolol, and ACEi as blood pressures tolerated. She 
underwent post-arrest cooling protocol and her sedation was 
weaned on ___. Her mental status improved initially, however, 
she declined after she developed a retroperitoneal bleed and PEA 
arrested on ___. Despite aggressive interventions including 
maximizing her pressor support, she never recovered from this 
event.

#Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient was intubated in 
setting of her initial cardiac arrest. Chest XR showed pulmonary 
edema, so patient was started on diuresis with Lasix 40mg IV 
boluses PRN.  She was also treated for healthcare associated 
pneumonia. She was extubated on ___, as her mental status had 
improved and she had passed RSBI, but was noted to have 
persistently low O2 sats and abundant secretions. She was 
re-intubated on ___ and continued to require ventilator 
support. She was unable to protect her airway without the 
ventilator. She was made comfort measures only on ___ and she 
was terminally extubated.

# Cardiac conduction disease
The patient developed complete heart block, atrial fibrillation 
with RVR, and atrial flutter at various points her admission. 
These were all felt to have occurred secondary to defective AV 
conduction and ventricular dyssynchrony. She was initially put 
on heparin because of her high CHA2DS2-VASc score (3), but this 
was discontinued when she develop a retroperitoneal bleed. She 
was started on amiodarone on ___ for refractory atrial 
fibrillation with RVR and chemically converted shortly 
thereafter.

# PEA arrest x2 during hospitalization, secondary to
# Retroperitoneal hemorrhage/acute blood loss anemia
The patient suffered PEA arrest x2 on ___ due to acute 
hemorrhagic shock in the setting of retroperitoneal bleed. She 
was resuscitated, heparin was stopped, and received multiple 
transfusions for her hypovolemic/hemorrhagic shock.

# Mixed hypovolemic/septic/cardiogenic shock
The patient developed shock requiring multiple pressors. 
Initially, her shock was thought to be more cardiogenic in 
nature, due to poor cardiac output in the setting of her 
arrhythmias. Later, there was more concern for hypovolemic vs. 
septic shock. Multiple blood, sputum, and urine cultures were 
obtained due to the patient's fever and leukocytosis, but a 
causative organism was never found. Hypovolemic shock secondary 
to retroperitoneal bleed was managed with fluid repletion, blood 
transfusions, and multiple pressors, as above. A decision was 
made not to pursue diagnostic CT scan to find a possible source 
of her elevated white count and concern for sepsis given her 
grim prognosis and that additional interventions would not help 
prolong her life. She was continued on antibiotics for empiric 
coverage.

#R Pneumothorax: 
The patient developed a right pneumothorax after her PEA arrests 
on ___,
thought to be due to chest compressions during the 
resuscitation. Thoracic surgery placed a pigtail. Her 
pneumothorax remained stable based on daily chest xrays and did 
not demonstrated any signs of being a tension pneumothorax. 
After consulting with thoracic surgery, it was determined that 
she did not need a chest tube.

#Renal Failure: 
The patient developed acute renal failure after her PEA arrests 
on ___. She had negligible urine output and was put on CRRT. She 
was diagnosed with ATN as her urine output did not recover.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
#Neuromuscular disorder: per report from family. Patient had 
long-standing ___ weakness which was attributed in some 
documentation to CVA. However, family stated that she had no 
history of stroke, and had been diagnosed with a "muscle 
breakdown disorder", was reportedly seen by neurologist and was 
lost to follow up. However, no outside neurologist could be 
located, despite multiple attempts.

#Hypertension: Home antihypertensives were held in the setting 
of shock requiring multiple pressors.

#COPD: The patient received albuterol and ipratroprium MDIs 
while intubated.

#GERD: The patient was placed on IV PPI for ppx while intubated. 
Her home famotidine was held during this time.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. famotidine 20 mg oral BID 
2. amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY 
3. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 
4. Albuterol Inhaler 2 PUFF IH Q4H:PRN SOB 
5. Ipratropium-Albuterol Neb 1 NEB NEB Q6H 
6. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild 
7. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 1 SPRY NU BID 
8. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
9. Magnesium Oxide 400 mg PO BID 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Not applicable as patient is deceased
 
Discharge Condition:
Not applicable as patient is deceased

high risk of thromboembolism. She suffered PEA arrest x2
secondary to retroperitoneal bleed. She went into mixed
septic/hypovolemic shock requiring multiple pressors. She
developed acute renal failure requiring CRRT. During this time,
she remained on ventilator support. On ___, a family
meeting was held to discuss overall prognosis and further goals
of care. In accordance with the patient's previously described
preferences, the decision was made by the family to transition
the patient to comfort-focused care. The patient died peacefully
on ___ at 1540.
# Cardiac arrest prior to admission:
Initial arrest occurred due to complete heart block. Admission
electrolytes were normal and tox screen was negative. She was
initially treated with heparin gtt x48 hours, asa, atorvastatin
80, metoprolol, and ACEi as blood pressures tolerated. She
underwent post-arrest cooling protocol and her sedation was
weaned on ___. Her mental status improved initially, however,
she declined after she developed a retroperitoneal bleed and PEA
arrested on ___. Despite aggressive interventions including
maximizing her pressor support, she never recovered from this
event.
#Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient was intubated in
setting of her initial cardiac arrest. Chest XR showed pulmonary
edema, so patient was started on diuresis with Lasix 40mg IV
boluses PRN. She was also treated for healthcare associated
pneumonia. She was extubated on ___, as her mental status had
improved and she had passed RSBI, but was noted to have
persistently low O2 sats and abundant secretions. She was
re-intubated on ___ and continued to require ventilator
support. She was unable to protect her airway without the
ventilator. She was made comfort measures only on ___ and she
was terminally extubated.
# Cardiac conduction disease
The patient developed complete heart block, atrial fibrillation
with RVR, and atrial flutter at various points her admission.
These were all felt to have occurred secondary to defective AV
conduction and ventricular dyssynchrony. She was initially put
on heparin because of her high CHA2DS2-VASc score (3), but this
was discontinued when she develop a retroperitoneal bleed. She
was started on amiodarone on ___ for refractory atrial
fibrillation with RVR and chemically converted shortly
thereafter.
# PEA arrest x2 during hospitalization, secondary to
# Retroperitoneal hemorrhage/acute blood loss anemia
The patient suffered PEA arrest x2 on ___ due to acute
hemorrhagic shock in the setting of retroperitoneal bleed. She
was resuscitated, heparin was stopped, and received multiple
transfusions for her hypovolemic/hemorrhagic shock.
# Mixed hypovolemic/septic/cardiogenic shock
The patient developed shock requiring multiple pressors.
Initially, her shock was thought to be more cardiogenic in
nature, due to poor cardiac output in the setting of her
arrhythmias. Later, there was more concern for hypovolemic vs.
septic shock. Multiple blood, sputum, and urine cultures were
obtained due to the patient's fever and leukocytosis, but a
causative organism was never found. Hypovolemic shock secondary
to retroperitoneal bleed was managed with fluid repletion, blood
transfusions, and multiple pressors, as above. A decision was
made not to pursue diagnostic CT scan to find a possible source
of her elevated white count and concern for sepsis given her
grim prognosis and that additional interventions would not help
prolong her life. She was continued on antibiotics for empiric
coverage.
#R Pneumothorax:
The patient developed a right pneumothorax after her PEA arrests
on ___,
thought to be due to chest compressions during the
resuscitation. Thoracic surgery placed a pigtail. Her
pneumothorax remained stable based on daily chest xrays and did
not demonstrated any signs of being a tension pneumothorax.
After consulting with thoracic surgery, it was determined that
she did not need a chest tube.
#Renal Failure:
The patient developed acute renal failure after her PEA arrests
on ___. She had negligible urine output and was put on CRRT. She
was diagnosed with ATN as her urine output did not recover.
CHRONIC ISSUES:
#Neuromuscular disorder: per report from family. Patient had
long-standing ___ weakness which was attributed in some
documentation to CVA. However, family stated that she had no
history of stroke, and had been diagnosed with a "muscle
breakdown disorder", was reportedly seen by neurologist and was
lost to follow up. However, no outside neurologist could be
located, despite multiple attempts.
#Hypertension: Home antihypertensives were held in the setting
of shock requiring multiple pressors.
#COPD: The patient received albuterol and ipratroprium MDIs
while intubated.
#GERD: The patient was placed on IV PPI for ppx while intubated.
Her home famotidine was held during this time.
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. famotidine 20 mg oral BID
2. amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY
3. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY
4. Albuterol Inhaler 2 PUFF IH Q4H:PRN SOB
5. Ipratropium-Albuterol Neb 1 NEB NEB Q6H
6. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild
7. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 1 SPRY NU BID
8. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY
9. Magnesium Oxide 400 mg PO BID

Expired

Not applicable as patient is deceased

(>=2.5L/min/m2). Transmitral and tissue Doppler imaging suggests 
normal diastolic function, and a normal left ventricular filling 
pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). The right ventricular cavity is mildly 
dilated with normal free wall contractility. [Intrinsic right 
ventricular systolic function is likely more depressed given the 
severity of tricuspid regurgitation.] The diameters of aorta at 
the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic 
valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet 
excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The 
mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. Mild (1+) mitral 
regurgitation is seen. Moderate to severe [3+] tricuspid 
regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic

pressure.] There is no pericardial effusion.

preserved free wall motion. Mild mitral regurgitation with 
normal valve morphology. No aortic valve pathology or pathologic 
flow. Normal left ventricular cavity size with preserved 
regional and global systolic function. Pulmonary artery 
hypertension.

___ 05:57AM BLOOD Calcium-8.7 Phos-4.5 Mg-2.___ year old female hx of endocarditis and IVDU abuse admitted 
fever and bilateral hand cellulitis and abscess of left forearm.

# Bilateral Hand cellulitis- The patient developed bilateral 
hand cellulitis with overlying ulceration and eschar in the 
setting of active IVDU and skin popping . She was started on IV 
Vancomycin and Unasyn. A plain film of the hand showed no 
evidence of osteomyelitis. CT scan of bilateral upper 
exteremities was concerning for deep space infection of the left 
forearm and multifocal skin defects along the dorsal aspects of 
both hands. CT also demonstrated underlying abscess/phlegmon 
formation as well as fluid tracking throughout the deeper soft 
tissues along the dorsal aspect of the left hand, particularly 
over the third and fourth metacarpals, concerning for early 
abscess formation. She was taken to the OR by hand surgery ( see 
below). In the OR hand surgery inspected the eschars on the 
dorsum of the hands.  These were curetted down to subcutaneous 
tissue without evidence of deeper purulence or air tracking. She 
was continued on IV Vanc/Unasyn for ongoing treatment of the 
cellulitis, with improvement in her wound and eschar. Blood 
cultures from admission were negative. Tissues culture grew 
MSSA. She was transitioned to IV naficillin 2gm IV q4H. The 
patient was not able to be sent to a rehab to complete 
antibiotics ___ insurance issues and ultimately decided to leave 
against medical advice. She was sent home with a script for 
Augmentin 875 mg BID to end on ___, as well as lyrica for 
pain control. She was not sent home with a script for narcotics 
given AMA discharge. She will require follow up in the hand 
clinic every ___ until her wounds heal. She was provided 
with the number to the ___ clinic to schedule a follow up 
appointment since one could not be made before she left AMA. Of 
note, a multidisciplinary meeting was held prior to her 
discharge with social work, case management, and medical team. 
Given limited discharge options, best available plan was 
transition to PO antibiotics, with antibiotic choice reviewed 
with ID consultants. Given patient's desire to leave the 
hospital, unable to monitor clinical response to transition to 
Augmentin.

 # MSSA left forearm  deep space infection- The patient noted to 
have a large area of induration and warmth on the medial aspect 
of her left forearm. CT of bilateral upper extremity showed 
fluid and air tracking along the fascia planes within left 
forearm flexor compartment, particularly along the proximal to 
mid aspect of the radial artery, which is attenuated but patent 
concerning for necrotizing fascitis. She was urgently taken to 
the OR by hand surgery and I and D of the left forearm. She was 
found to have  purulent material in the subcutaenous tissue and 
fascia, but were viable without evidence of nectrotizing 
fascitis. She was also found to have granulation tissue and 
encasement of the radial artery and specimen was sent for 
culture.  A wound vac and she went back to the OR on ___ for 
closeur and removal of the wound vac.  Cultures grew MSSA and 
she was transitioned to Nafcillin 2gm IV q4 and then Augmentin ( 
see above)

# Intravenous drug user- The patient is an active drug user. Was 
recently enrolled in a ___ clinic 2 weeks prior to 
admission. Per her ___ clinic ___ Op Co ( ___, 
she was last dosed on ___. The patient admits to missing clinic 
2 days prior to admission to use heroin and cocaine. She left AM 
and was told to follow up with her ___ clinic.  Hep B, Hep 
C, and HIV were checked and were negative. To manage her 
withdrawal she was maintained on methadone 30 mg daily, and 
received PO clonidine 0.1 mg BID x 2 dose and then a clonidine 
patch that was discontinued after 5 days.

# Iron defeciency anemia/Anemia of chronic inflammation-  The 
patient Hgb naidered at 6.2. Her anemia was likely a combination 
of ACD and Fe def anemia.  ACD suggested by low TIBC and 
transferrin. Fe def anemia suggested by low ferritin, 
microcytosis, and low serum Ferritin however  would expect TIBC 
and transferrin to be elevated. Stool guiac neg x 1. She was 
transfused a total of 2 units PRBCs for Hb<7.

# Murmur- The patient had a murmur on exam; likely from her 
previous episode of tricuspid endocarditis. Repeat echo here 
confirmed moderate-severe tricuspid regurgitation without 
evidence of vegetation. Blood cultures were negative.

Transitonal Issuses
-Augmentin until  ___
-needs to be seen every ___ in hand clinic until wounds heel

formation as well as fluid tracking throughout the deeper soft
tissues along the dorsal aspect of the left hand, particularly
over the third and fourth metacarpals, concerning for early
abscess formation. She was taken to the OR by hand surgery ( see
below). In the OR hand surgery inspected the eschars on the
dorsum of the hands. These were curetted down to subcutaneous
tissue without evidence of deeper purulence or air tracking. She
was continued on IV Vanc/Unasyn for ongoing treatment of the
cellulitis, with improvement in her wound and eschar. Blood
cultures from admission were negative. Tissues culture grew
MSSA. She was transitioned to IV naficillin 2gm IV q4H. The
patient was not able to be sent to a rehab to complete
antibiotics ___ insurance issues and ultimately decided to leave
against medical advice. She was sent home with a script for
Augmentin 875 mg BID to end on ___, as well as lyrica for
pain control. She was not sent home with a script for narcotics
given AMA discharge. She will require follow up in the hand
clinic every ___ until her wounds heal. She was provided
with the number to the ___ clinic to schedule a follow up
appointment since one could not be made before she left AMA. Of
note, a multidisciplinary meeting was held prior to her
discharge with social work, case management, and medical team.
Given limited discharge options, best available plan was
transition to PO antibiotics, with antibiotic choice reviewed
with ID consultants. Given patient's desire to leave the
hospital, unable to monitor clinical response to transition to
Augmentin.
# MSSA left forearm deep space infection- The patient noted to
have a large area of induration and warmth on the medial aspect
of her left forearm. CT of bilateral upper extremity showed
fluid and air tracking along the fascia planes within left
forearm flexor compartment, particularly along the proximal to
mid aspect of the radial artery, which is attenuated but patent
concerning for necrotizing fascitis. She was urgently taken to
the OR by hand surgery and I and D of the left forearm. She was
found to have purulent material in the subcutaenous tissue and
fascia, but were viable without evidence of nectrotizing
fascitis. She was also found to have granulation tissue and
encasement of the radial artery and specimen was sent for
culture. A wound vac and she went back to the OR on ___ for
closeur and removal of the wound vac. Cultures grew MSSA and
she was transitioned to Nafcillin 2gm IV q4 and then Augmentin (
see above)
# Intravenous drug user- The patient is an active drug user. Was
recently enrolled in a ___ clinic 2 weeks prior to
admission. Per her ___ clinic ___ Op Co ( ___,
she was last dosed on ___. The patient admits to missing clinic
2 days prior to admission to use heroin and cocaine. She left AM
and was told to follow up with her ___ clinic. Hep B, Hep
C, and HIV were checked and were negative. To manage her
withdrawal she was maintained on methadone 30 mg daily, and
received PO clonidine 0.1 mg BID x 2 dose and then a clonidine
patch that was discontinued after 5 days.
# Iron defeciency anemia/Anemia of chronic inflammation- The
patient Hgb naidered at 6.2. Her anemia was likely a combination
of ACD and Fe def anemia. ACD suggested by low TIBC and
transferrin. Fe def anemia suggested by low ferritin,
microcytosis, and low serum Ferritin however would expect TIBC
and transferrin to be elevated. Stool guiac neg x 1. She was
transfused a total of 2 units PRBCs for Hb<7.
# Murmur- The patient had a murmur on exam; likely from her
previous episode of tricuspid endocarditis. Repeat echo here
confirmed moderate-severe tricuspid regurgitation without
evidence of vegetation. Blood cultures were negative.
Transitonal Issuses
-Augmentin until ___
-needs to be seen every ___ in hand clinic until wounds heel

and arms. You were treated with IV antibiotics, and had surgery
to drain an abscess in your left arm. You will go home on oral

ventricular systolic dysfunction with inferoapical and 
anteroapical hypokinesis.

stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen.

mitral regurgitation is seen.

slow ventricular response. Preserved biventricular systolic 
function post-cpb. LVEF = 55%. Improved anterior and lateral 
wall motion. MR is 1+. Aortic contour is normal post 
decannulation.

referred for surgery. Pre-op workup completed and went to OR 
with Dr. ___ on ___. Please see operative note for details, 
in summmary had coronary artery bypass grafting x3 with
left internal mammary artery grafted to the diagonal branch of 
the LAD and reverse saphenous vein grafts to the marginal branch 
and the posterior descending artery.
His bypass time was 60 minutes with a crossclamp time of 47 
minutes. He tolerated the operation well and was transferred 
from the operating room to the cardiac surgery ICU in stable 
condition. He remained sedated on the day of surgery because of 
a mild respiratory acidosis. His sedation was weaned and he was 
extubated on the morning of POD1. After extubation he remained 
in the ICU for hemodynamic monitoring seconadary to bradycardia 
requiring Apacing to maintain his blood pressure. During this 
time he also had an episode of post-operative atrial 
fibrillation, he converted back to sinus rhythm with a bolus of 
amiodarone. Chest tubes and pacing wires removed per protocol.
He was transferred from the ICU to the stepdown floor on POD4. 
Once on the floor he was seen by physical therapy to begin 
increasing his activity level. Gently diuresed toward his preop 
weight. The remainder of his post operative course was 
uneventful and he was cleared for discharge home with visiting 
nurses on POD #6.

# Left MCA stroke 
Pt presented ___ with a left MCA syndrome and underwent 
thrombectomy w/ resulting TICI-3 reperfusion, 
Unfortunately, her exam did not dramatically improve s/p 
thrombectomy. She was noted to have an area of infarction that 
encompassed essentially the entirety of her basal ganglia, 
insula, and operculum consistent w/ an infarction of the area of 
the deep branches of the left MCA/incomplete superior division 
of L.MCA infarction. Additionally she was noted to have a small 
punctate focus of infarct in the R. frontal lobe, which raised 
the concern for possible cardioembolic etiology (though could 
also be from the the thrombectomy itself), especially in the 
absence of significant intracranial or extracranial 
atherosclerosis. She was also noted to have an area of 
hemorrhagic transformation. Because of this, the administration 
of an anti-platelet agent was delayed, however she was 
ultimately started on plavix (given the stroke occurred on 
aspirin). Her LDL was 145, and her atorvastatin was increased to 
80mg. A1c was noted to be 6.1. Pt was seen this admission by 
physical therapy and speech therapy. She continued to have a 
dense right sided hemiplegia and a severe global aphasia. She 
was able to understand simple one step commands inconsistently, 
and occasionally able to repeat some phrases. Additionally she 
was often quite sleepy during the day, requiring frequent 
re-cuing to get through a meal or work with therapy. For this 
purpose she was started on modafinil which was uptitrated to 
200mg. Discharged w/ ziopatch which will be followed up. 
- Continue plavix 75mg 
- Continue atorvastatin 80mg 
- Continue modafinil 200mg and uptitrate as able 
[ ] Repeat SLP evals 

#Protein Calorie Malnutrition 
#Dysphagia 
Pt initially had ___ placed for tube feeds and medications, 
eventually her diet was advanced. Despite this her mental status 
remained a barrier to her being able to meet her nutritional 
needs. We had several repeat discussions w/ family about risks 
and benefits of her current nutritional status. We discussed 
that the risks of maintaining a dobhoff for an extended period 
likely don't outweigh the benefits. Family is aware because of 
her mental status, that she may not, and likely will not, be 
able to fully meet her nutritional needs w/o supplementing (ie. 
via ___ or PEG). However, they are willing to accept this 
and patient will
be offered oral supplements, as well as will continue on her 
modafinil to attempt and improve her alertness. They are 
hopeful, as are we all, that her appetite will improve and she 
will be re-evaluated by SLP as well as followed by nutrition 
while in rehab

#Hypertension
Patient was noted to be persistently hypertensive and her BP 
medications were uptitrated. Discharge regimen beow 
- Continue losartan 100 mg daily 
- Continue amlodipine 10 mg daily 
- Continue carvedilol 25 mg twice daily 
- Continue hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily 

#Hypothyroidism: 
- Continue Levothyroxine Sodium 137 mcg PO/NG 4X/WEEK
- Continue Levothyroxine Sodium 68.5 mcg PO/NG 3X/WEEK

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were hospitalized due to trouble speaking and weakness 
resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a condition where a 
blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is 
blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your body that 
controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage 
to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result 
in a variety of symptoms.  Your stroke affected a part of you 
brain that controls your ability to understand and produce 
language, so you are having a lot of difficulty doing these 
things. Because of the size of your stroke there was also some 
bleeding. 

Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are: high cholesterol, hypertension 
(or high blood pressure), and diabetes. 

We are changing your medications as follows:
Added:
- Amlodipine 
- Atorvastatin 
- Plavix 
- Carvedilol 
- Flonase 

Stopped
- Aspirin 

Please take your other medications as prescribed.

Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.

If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:
- Sudden partial or complete loss of vision
- Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth
- Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you
- Sudden weakness of one side of the body
- Sudden drooping of one side of the face
- Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body

Sincerely,
Your ___ Neurology Team

bladder scan Q6H and straight cath as needed
[ ] Pt discharge on insulin sliding scale, please discontinue
this if not requiring additional insulin
# Left MCA stroke
Pt presented ___ with a left MCA syndrome and underwent
thrombectomy w/ resulting TICI-3 reperfusion,
Unfortunately, her exam did not dramatically improve s/p
thrombectomy. She was noted to have an area of infarction that
encompassed essentially the entirety of her basal ganglia,
insula, and operculum consistent w/ an infarction of the area of
the deep branches of the left MCA/incomplete superior division
of L.MCA infarction. Additionally she was noted to have a small
punctate focus of infarct in the R. frontal lobe, which raised
the concern for possible cardioembolic etiology (though could
also be from the the thrombectomy itself), especially in the
absence of significant intracranial or extracranial
atherosclerosis. She was also noted to have an area of
hemorrhagic transformation. Because of this, the administration
of an anti-platelet agent was delayed, however she was
ultimately started on plavix (given the stroke occurred on
aspirin). Her LDL was 145, and her atorvastatin was increased to
80mg. A1c was noted to be 6.1. Pt was seen this admission by
physical therapy and speech therapy. She continued to have a
dense right sided hemiplegia and a severe global aphasia. She
was able to understand simple one step commands inconsistently,
and occasionally able to repeat some phrases. Additionally she
was often quite sleepy during the day, requiring frequent
re-cuing to get through a meal or work with therapy. For this
purpose she was started on modafinil which was uptitrated to
200mg. Discharged w/ ziopatch which will be followed up.
- Continue plavix 75mg
- Continue atorvastatin 80mg
- Continue modafinil 200mg and uptitrate as able
[ ] Repeat SLP evals
#Protein Calorie Malnutrition
#Dysphagia
Pt initially had ___ placed for tube feeds and medications,
eventually her diet was advanced. Despite this her mental status
remained a barrier to her being able to meet her nutritional
needs. We had several repeat discussions w/ family about risks
and benefits of her current nutritional status. We discussed
that the risks of maintaining a dobhoff for an extended period
likely don't outweigh the benefits. Family is aware because of
her mental status, that she may not, and likely will not, be
able to fully meet her nutritional needs w/o supplementing (ie.
via ___ or PEG). However, they are willing to accept this
and patient will
be offered oral supplements, as well as will continue on her
modafinil to attempt and improve her alertness. They are
hopeful, as are we all, that her appetite will improve and she
will be re-evaluated by SLP as well as followed by nutrition
while in rehab
#Hypertension
Patient was noted to be persistently hypertensive and her BP
medications were uptitrated. Discharge regimen beow
- Continue losartan 100 mg daily
- Continue amlodipine 10 mg daily
- Continue carvedilol 25 mg twice daily
- Continue hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily
#Hypothyroidism:
- Continue Levothyroxine Sodium 137 mcg PO/NG 4X/WEEK
- Continue Levothyroxine Sodium 68.5 mcg PO/NG 3X/WEEK

Attack

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Lethargic but arousable.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or
wheelchair.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were hospitalized due to trouble speaking and weakness
resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a condition where a
blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is
blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your body that
controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage
to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result
in a variety of symptoms. Your stroke affected a part of you
brain that controls your ability to understand and produce
language, so you are having a lot of difficulty doing these
things. Because of the size of your stroke there was also some
bleeding.
Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke.
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk
factors. Your risk factors are: high cholesterol, hypertension
(or high blood pressure), and diabetes.
We are changing your medications as follows:
Added:
- Amlodipine
- Atorvastatin
- Plavix
- Carvedilol
- Flonase
Stopped
- Aspirin
Please take your other medications as prescribed.
Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician
as listed below.
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur,
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of
these symptoms:
- Sudden partial or complete loss of vision
- Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth
- Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to
you
- Sudden weakness of one side of the body
- Sudden drooping of one side of the face
- Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body
Sincerely,
Your ___ Neurology Team

IMAGING:
CT Head ___:
TECHNIQUE: Contiguous axial images were obtained through the 
brain. No 
contrast was administered. Multiplanar reformatted images were 
generated. 
FINDINGS: Overlying the anterior left cerebral convexity is a 
collection of mixed attenuation material, consistent with 
subdural hematoma. Heterogeneous attenuation likely represents a 
combination of relatively early and late subacute bleeding. The 
lower attenuation material is not CSF density, suggesting the 
hematoma is not chronic. There is approximately 6 mm of 
associated rightward, subfalcine herniation of the midline. The 
underlying sulci demonstrate hemispheric effacement. The left 
lateral ventricle demonstrates mass effect. There are no other 
foci of intracranial hemorrhage. The basilar cisterns are 
symmetric. The gray-white matter differentiation is preserved. 
There is no fracture. The mastoid air cells and paranasal 
sinuses are well aerated. Soft tissues are unremarkable. 
IMPRESSION: Mixture of early and delayed subacute subdural 
hematoma overlying the left anterior convexity, resulting in 6 
mm of rightward subfalcine herniation and midline shift, with 
sulcal effacement and mass effect on the left lateral ventricle. 
This appears stable compared to the recent MR. 

___ Brain ___:
TECHNIQUE: T1 sagittal and axial and FLAIR T2 susceptibility and 
diffusion 
axial images of the brain were acquired.   
FINDINGS: There is an acute/subacute subdural hematoma seen on 
the left 
extending from frontal to the occipital region. The maximum 
width of the 
hematoma is seen in the frontal region measuring approximately 
18 mm and it is measuring approximately 14 mm in the parietal 
region. The hematoma contains a high T1 and high T2 signal 
indicating subacute hemorrhage. Additionally, low T2 signal 
collection is also seen which indicates acute hemorrhage. There 
is mass effect on the left cerebral hemisphere with obliteration 
of sulci. Mild shift of the midline is seen to the right side 
with deformity of the left lateral ventricle. The hematoma 
slightly extends to the interhemispheric fissure posteriorly. 
There is no acute infarct seen. There is no hydrocephalus. Few 
scattered foci of hyperintensity in the white matter of 
nonspecific nature are seen which could indicate early changes 
of small vessel disease. Note is made of increased signal in the 
right sigmoid sinus and proximal jugular vein on FLAIR and 
T2-weighted images. Increased signal is also seen in this region 
on T1 sagittal images. Although this could be secondary to 
artifact it is unusual to have this much hyperintensity on 
T1-weighted images. Thrombosis of the sinus is suspected. To 
further evaluate MRV of the head or CTA venography of the head 
and neck are recommended. CT venography of the 
head and neck may provide further information . 
IMPRESSION: 
1. Left-sided acute/subacute subdural hematoma extending from 
frontal to the occipital region with maximum width of 1.8 cm. 
Tiny right frontal subdural is also seen. 
2. Abnormal signal in the right sigmoid sinus and proximal 
jugular vein 
suspicious for thrombosis. Further evaluation with CT venography 
of the head and neck recommended. 
3. Mild changes of small vessel disease. 
4. Mild midline shift to the right. 

CTA/V of Head/Neck ___:
TECHNIQUE: Axial acquired images were obtained through the brain 
without 
contrast followed by post-contrast images through the brain and 
neck per CTB protocol. Coronal and sagittal reformations were 
evaluated.   
CT OF THE HEAD WITHOUT AND WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: Evolving 
mixed acute 
and chronic left subdural hematoma displays no significant 
interval change in size from prior exam. The degree of mass 
effect on the adjacent sulci as well as subfalcine herniation 
measuring approximately 6-7 mm is also stable. No new 
parenchymal abnormalities are identified. Mass effect on the 
left occipital and temporal horns is stable. Globes and soft 
tissues are unremarkable. Mild right sphenoid sinus mucosal 
thickening is noted with remaining paranasal sinuses and mastoid 
air cells appearing unremarkable. Small mucous retention cysts 
are also present within the right and left maxillary sinuses. 
Post contrast administration, there is no thrombosis of the 
venous sinuses with appropriate filling of the sigmoid sinuses 
bilaterally. The posterior circulation appears codominant. The 
right PCA displays a fetal-type configuration. Anterior 
circulation is unremarkable with no aneurysmal dilatation noted. 
A somewhat prominent left cortical vein is noted, likely 
appearing more prominent, related to the adjacent subdural 
hematoma. No AV malformation is present. 
CT OF THE NECK WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: Jugular veins are 
patent. Included portions of the aortic arch and great vessel 
origins are normal. There is no flow-limiting stenoses involving 
the origins of the vertebral arteries or internal carotid 
arteries. Soft tissue structures within the neck are 
unremarkable. No pathologically enlarged lymph nodes are 
present. Mild-to-moderate bilateral periodontal disease is 
noted. The septum is noted to be rightward deviated with mild 
spur formation causing mass effect on the right inferior 
turbinate. 
IMPRESSION: 
1. No significant interval change to acute on chronic evolving 
left subdural hematoma with stable rightward subfalcine 
herniation. 
2. Patent jugular veins bilaterally. Patent venous sinuses. The 
abnormality seen on MRI was likely due to flow artifact. 

Head CT ___:
FINDINGS: There has been interval left frontal craniotomy, with 
evacuation of a left subdural hematoma. There is a postoperative 
changes within the left subdural space, residual left subdural 
collection, consisting of air, and residual blood products, 
measuring approximately 13 mm in maximal ___. Local mass 
effect on adjacent sulci, with mild sulcal effacement is 
unchanged. There is a rightward subfalcine herniation of 
approximately 4 mm, which is improved from prior study 
(previously 7 mm). No additional foci of hemorrhage are 
identified. The caliber of the ventricular system is stable, 
without evidence of new hydrocephalus. No infarct is identified. 
Visualized paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells are normally 
aerated. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
1. Status post evacuation of the left subdural hematoma, with 
postoperative pneumocephalus, and residual blood products within 
the left subdural space, measuring approximately 13 mm in 
maximal ___. 
2. Improvement in rightward subfalcine herniation, with 
herniation of 
approximately 4 mm. 
  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ admitted to the Neurosurgery service after complaining of a 
history of recurrent headache and word finding difficutly. CT of 
the head was done revealing a left sided acute on chronic SDH.  
MRI was also performed at the OSH prior to transfer.  Radiology 
reading at ___ had a question of sinus flow-signal 
abnormailty, so a CTA/V of the head and neck to rule out jugular 
thrombosis. This study ultimately proved to be negative. He was 
admitted to the neurosurgery floor with plans to take him to the 
operating room on the subsequent day for left sided crani for 
evacuation of blood components. 

On ___, he was taken to the OR and recovered in the ICU 
overnight. The patient was kept flat for 24 hours and was placed 
on a non-rebreather mask at 100% for 24 hours for 
pneumocephalus. He was transferred to the neurosurgical floor on 
___. The patient ambulated with nursing assistance and did very 
well. Overnight the patient hit his head on the side rail. He 
did not lose consciousness and his neuro exam was unchanged. 
Therefore a head CT was not performed. 

The following day he was ambulating on his own with no 
difficulty. His wound looked clean, dry, and intact. There did 
not appear to be any disruption from striking his head 
overnight. Neurologically he had no deficits and was deemed 
ready for discharge. His dilantin level was slightly low on the 
day of discharge so the patient received a bolus and his dose 
was increased. He went home with his wife on ___.
 
___ on Admission:
atenolol, asa 325, seroquel,xanax

Discharge Instructions:
ÂHave a friend/family member check your incision daily for signs 
of infection.
ÂTake your pain medicine as prescribed.
ÂExercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
ÂYou may wash your hair only after sutures have been removed.  
ÂYou may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
ÂIncrease your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
ÂUnless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
ÂYou have been prescribed Dilantin (Phenytoin) for anti-seizure 
medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with laboratory 
blood drawing in one week.  This can be drawn at your PCPÂs 
office, but please have the results faxed to ___. 
ÂClearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your 
post-operative office visit.
ÂMake sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while at 
home, unless you have been instructed not to. 

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

ÂNew onset of tremors or seizures.
ÂAny confusion or change in mental status. 
ÂAny numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
ÂPain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
ÂAny signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, or drainage.
ÂFever greater than or equal to 101Â° F.

3. Mild changes of small vessel disease.
4. Mild midline shift to the right.
CTA/V of Head/Neck ___:
TECHNIQUE: Axial acquired images were obtained through the brain
without
contrast followed by post-contrast images through the brain and
neck per CTB protocol. Coronal and sagittal reformations were
evaluated.
CT OF THE HEAD WITHOUT AND WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: Evolving
mixed acute
and chronic left subdural hematoma displays no significant
interval change in size from prior exam. The degree of mass
effect on the adjacent sulci as well as subfalcine herniation
measuring approximately 6-7 mm is also stable. No new
parenchymal abnormalities are identified. Mass effect on the
left occipital and temporal horns is stable. Globes and soft
tissues are unremarkable. Mild right sphenoid sinus mucosal
thickening is noted with remaining paranasal sinuses and mastoid
air cells appearing unremarkable. Small mucous retention cysts
are also present within the right and left maxillary sinuses.
Post contrast administration, there is no thrombosis of the
venous sinuses with appropriate filling of the sigmoid sinuses
bilaterally. The posterior circulation appears codominant. The
right PCA displays a fetal-type configuration. Anterior
circulation is unremarkable with no aneurysmal dilatation noted.
A somewhat prominent left cortical vein is noted, likely
appearing more prominent, related to the adjacent subdural
hematoma. No AV malformation is present.
CT OF THE NECK WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: Jugular veins are
patent. Included portions of the aortic arch and great vessel
origins are normal. There is no flow-limiting stenoses involving
the origins of the vertebral arteries or internal carotid
arteries. Soft tissue structures within the neck are
unremarkable. No pathologically enlarged lymph nodes are
present. Mild-to-moderate bilateral periodontal disease is
noted. The septum is noted to be rightward deviated with mild
spur formation causing mass effect on the right inferior
turbinate.
IMPRESSION:
1. No significant interval change to acute on chronic evolving
left subdural hematoma with stable rightward subfalcine
herniation.
2. Patent jugular veins bilaterally. Patent venous sinuses. The
abnormality seen on MRI was likely due to flow artifact.
Head CT ___:
FINDINGS: There has been interval left frontal craniotomy, with
evacuation of a left subdural hematoma. There is a postoperative
changes within the left subdural space, residual left subdural
collection, consisting of air, and residual blood products,
measuring approximately 13 mm in maximal ___. Local mass
effect on adjacent sulci, with mild sulcal effacement is
unchanged. There is a rightward subfalcine herniation of
approximately 4 mm, which is improved from prior study
(previously 7 mm). No additional foci of hemorrhage are
identified. The caliber of the ventricular system is stable,
without evidence of new hydrocephalus. No infarct is identified.
Visualized paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells are normally
aerated.
IMPRESSION:
1. Status post evacuation of the left subdural hematoma, with
postoperative pneumocephalus, and residual blood products within
the left subdural space, measuring approximately 13 mm in
maximal ___.
2. Improvement in rightward subfalcine herniation, with
herniation of
approximately 4 mm.
Brief Hospital Course:
___ admitted to the Neurosurgery service after complaining of a
history of recurrent headache and word finding difficutly. CT of
the head was done revealing a left sided acute on chronic SDH.
MRI was also performed at the OSH prior to transfer. Radiology
reading at ___ had a question of sinus flow-signal
abnormailty, so a CTA/V of the head and neck to rule out jugular
thrombosis. This study ultimately proved to be negative. He was
admitted to the neurosurgery floor with plans to take him to the
operating room on the subsequent day for left sided crani for
evacuation of blood components.
On ___, he was taken to the OR and recovered in the ICU
overnight. The patient was kept flat for 24 hours and was placed
on a non-rebreather mask at 100% for 24 hours for
pneumocephalus. He was transferred to the neurosurgical floor on
___. The patient ambulated with nursing assistance and did very
well. Overnight the patient hit his head on the side rail. He
did not lose consciousness and his neuro exam was unchanged.
Therefore a head CT was not performed.
The following day he was ambulating on his own with no
difficulty. His wound looked clean, dry, and intact. There did
not appear to be any disruption from striking his head
overnight. Neurologically he had no deficits and was deemed
ready for discharge. His dilantin level was slightly low on the
day of discharge so the patient received a bolus and his dose
was increased. He went home with his wife on ___.
___ on Admission:
atenolol, asa 325, seroquel,xanax

Discharge Instructions:
ÂHave a friend/family member check your incision daily for signs
of infection.
ÂTake your pain medicine as prescribed.
ÂExercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining,
or excessive bending.
ÂYou may wash your hair only after sutures have been removed.
ÂYou may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover
your head.
ÂIncrease your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace)
while taking narcotic pain medication.
ÂUnless directed by your doctor, do not take any
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and
Ibuprofen etc.
ÂYou have been prescribed Dilantin (Phenytoin) for anti-seizure
medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with laboratory
blood drawing in one week. This can be drawn at your PCPÂs
office, but please have the results faxed to ___.
ÂClearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your
post-operative office visit.
ÂMake sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while at
home, unless you have been instructed not to.
CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE
FOLLOWING
ÂNew onset of tremors or seizures.
ÂAny confusion or change in mental status.
ÂAny numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
ÂPain or headache that is continually increasing, or not
relieved by pain medication.
ÂAny signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling,
tenderness, or drainage.
ÂFever greater than or equal to 101Â° F.

PERTINENT STUDIES
# Pelvis X-ray (___)
IMPRESSION: 
1. No displaced fracture on this single AP view of the pelvis. 
2. Focal lucent and sclerotic lesion in right proximal femur, 
not fully 
characterized, ? fibrous dysplasia, intraosseous lipoma, or bone 
infarct. If clinically indicated, followup radiograph in six 
months could help to 
establish expected stability. 
.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old F w/ h/o dementia, RA, afib, transferred from OSH 
with bilateral supracondylar femur fracture on ___.

   On ___, patient presented to ED and received intravenous 
pain medication carefully. The patient also received steroids 
because she has been on steroids recently.  Her lactate was 
normal. She was admitted to the orthopedic
surgery service. Her blood pressure was stable in the emergency 
department. She was ordered for 1U PRBCs at 3pm given crit drop 
31->26. Orthopaedics team ordered that patient to be NPO, added 
her on to OR schedule, placed in bilateral knee immobilizers, 
finalized consent with daughter, b/l ORIF, ordered preop 
labs/EKG/CXR, and continue macrobid for UTI.
   She was taken to the OR with Orthopaedics for fixation of her 
bilateral distal femur fractures. She was brought to the 
operating room, was given general anesthesia placed in the 
supine position on her stretcher.
There was much difficulty with getting access to her and 
anesthesia had to place a central line in the subclavian area.  
Her pulse was quite rapid and there was difficulty controlling 
her blood pressure and difficulty establishing good access.  She 
was given a unit of blood, but  given her labile pressures and 
tachycardia, decision was made to hold off on the open 
treatment.  At this point, Ortho team elected to hold both femur 
fractures reduced with traction and knee immobilizers were 
placed.  Plan was to bring her back to the intensive care unit 
for supportive care and consider fixation in the future. The 
patient was taken to the TSICU floor for close observation and 
care under sedation and intubated.
  On ___, the patient was transfused 1u pRBC for HCT drop from 
29.4 to 23.2 in TSICU. She was made NPO overnight for planned 
procedure on ___. A surface echo was ordered to evaluate 
cardiac function in setting of recent hypotension (SBP 50) and 
tachycardia (HR 160) showing Relatively small left ventricle 
with hyperdynamic systolic function; Mild mitral regurgitation; 
Borderline dilation of the right ventricle with moderate 
tricuspid regurgitation. An US of gallbladder was ordered 
showing Cholelithiasis with no sonographic signs of 
cholecystitis and No biliary dilatation seen. 
  On ___, the patient went to the OR and underwent an 
attempted open reduction and internal fixation of left 
periprosthetic supracondylar femur fracture (aborted), closed 
reduction of left femur fracture, open reduction and internal 
fixation of right supracondylar periprosthetic femur fracture. 
Given comminution of the lateral aspect of the femur, 
intraoperative consultation was obtained with one of our 
arthroplastic specialists, Dr. ___.  After formal 
consultation over the telephone, we discussed the options 
including supplementary fixation with bone cement, the option 
for a revision left total knee in the form of a distal
femoral replacement, provisional stabilization with an external 
fixator versus closed reduction.  After consultation with Dr. 
___ elected to proceed with a closed reduction of the 
left femur. She was provisionally going to return to the 
operating room in the next ___ to ___ 
for possible
distal femoral replacement, revision left total knee 
arthroplasty.
  On ___, blood culture results came back positive (from ___ 
show enterococcus, gram(-) rods, gram(+) cocci). Urine cultures 
were also positive ___ shows gram(-) rods). On ___, results 
finalized with positive cultures showing enterococcus, 
moragnella ___, coag neg staph. Antibiotics continued 
appropriately with Meropenem.
  
On ___ pt was called out to regular floor.  In the afternoon, 
pt was found unresponsive, with PEA arrest.  A code was called.  
Pt was intubated.  CPR was given for 5 mins, 1 mg epi and stress 
dose hydrocortisol were given.  Pulse was palpated afterwards 
without defibrillation.  Pt was ___ transferred to MICU.  
Central access was established, and pt was initially pressors.  
Post-code labs were consistent with acute shock liver and 
myocardial injury post arrest.  She was supported with pressor 
and mechanical ventilation.  However, no meaningful return of 
neurological function was observed - she had roving eyes without 
any evidence of higher cortical function during her ICU stay 
post-arrest, concerning for significant hypoxemia brain injury. 
On ___, she manifested a progressive elevation in her 
lactate, increasing pressor requirements, and evidence of 
evolving multiorgan failure. Given her lack of neurological 
function and her overall dire clinical course, her family was 
notified, came in and during a family meeting the consensus 
decision was made to transition to CMO.  Ventilator support was 
withdrawn on ___.  Pt expired at 10:22 AM on ___ with 
her family at the bedside. Autopsy was declined.
