arthroplasty.
On ___, blood culture results came back positive (from ___
show enterococcus, gram(-) rods, gram(+) cocci). Urine cultures
were also positive ___ shows gram(-) rods). On ___, results
finalized with positive cultures showing enterococcus,
moragnella ___, coag neg staph. Antibiotics continued
appropriately with Meropenem.
On ___ pt was called out to regular floor. In the afternoon,
pt was found unresponsive, with PEA arrest. A code was called.
Pt was intubated. CPR was given for 5 mins, 1 mg epi and stress
dose hydrocortisol were given. Pulse was palpated afterwards
without defibrillation. Pt was ___ transferred to MICU.
Central access was established, and pt was initially pressors.
Post-code labs were consistent with acute shock liver and
myocardial injury post arrest. She was supported with pressor
and mechanical ventilation. However, no meaningful return of
neurological function was observed - she had roving eyes without
any evidence of higher cortical function during her ICU stay
post-arrest, concerning for significant hypoxemia brain injury.
On ___, she manifested a progressive elevation in her
lactate, increasing pressor requirements, and evidence of
evolving multiorgan failure. Given her lack of neurological
function and her overall dire clinical course, her family was
notified, came in and during a family meeting the consensus
decision was made to transition to CMO. Ventilator support was
withdrawn on ___. Pt expired at 10:22 AM on ___ with
her family at the bedside. Autopsy was declined.

IMAGING: 
CXR (___): No acute cardiopulmonary process. 

CT Head without contrast (___): 
1. No evidence for acute intracranial abnormalities.
2. Mild cerebellar atrophy.
3. Moderate ventriculomegaly and mild enlargement of the 
cerebral sulci,
findings which most often represent cerebral atrophy with 
central
predominance. However, in appropriate clinical setting, this may 
be related to
communicating hydrocephalus. Please correlate with symptoms.
4. Left subgaleal hematoma. No fracture.

CT C-Spine without contrast (___): 
1. No fracture or malalignment.
2. Multilevel degenerative disease.
3. Caries and periapical lucency involving the last maxillary 
molar. Please
correlate clinically whether active dental infection is present. 
Mild mucosal thickening in the maxillary sinuses may be 
secondary to odontogenic inflammation

Left Humerus (AP&Lat) (___): No acute fracture or 
dislocation

Left Rib films (___): Multiple oblique and a frontal chest 
radiograph show no definitive evidence of rib fracture or 
pneumothorax.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ otherwise healthy male who was assault early ___ morning by 
friend while intoxicated, presented to ED with head laceration 
and AFib with RVR to the 180s, transferred to ___ where trauma 
work-up was otherwise negative. Treated with digoxin and 
converted to sinus rhythm, transferred to medicine for 
management.

# Trauma to head and left body: Pt was assaulted with hit to 
left side of face near eye and subsequent fall to ground on same 
side causing head laceration. On arrival to the ED patient 
received 2 units of PRBCs for scalp bleeding prior to bedside 
suturing and stapling that repaired the laceration. Hct remained 
stable following transfusion. CT head showed mod 
ventriculomegaly and mild enlargement of cerebral sulci without 
signs of acute bleed or intracranial hematoma. CT C-spine and 
CXR were negative. Pt complained of left-sided pain from fall 
with tenderness on exam however left rib films and left humerus 
films were negative. Pt was stabilized and subsequently 
transferred to the medicine service. Over the next several days 
he complained of mild lightheadedness with a sensation of 
disequilibrium, most likely due to head trauma with mild 
post-concussive syndrome symptoms. Pt was rehydrated with IV 
fluids. Pain was controlled with oral oxycodone. He was weaned 
off supplemental oxygen and was satting well on room air. His 
symptoms gradually improved with only mild residual headache 
near laceration at the time of discharge without lightheadedness 
or dizziness. His left sided musculoskeletal symptoms also 
improved and patient was able to ambulate independently. Patient 
was discharged home with limited number of oxycodone pills 
(#15). He has follow-up scheduled with a new PCP at ___. He will 
need to follow-up with Trauma Surgery on ___ for staple 
removal. 

# Paroxsymal Afib with RVR, provoked: Pt has no known cardiac 
history or previous documented episodes of atrial fibrillation. 
Patient was tachycardic on initial exam, found to be in atrial 
fibrillation on admission to TSICU with RVR to the 180's. His 
blood pressures were initially soft. He was loaded with digoxin 
and converted to sinus rhythm within 12 hours of arrival. Blood 
pressures subsequently stabilized. Patient was transferred to 
medicine and remained in sinus rhythm with HR in 70's-90's for 
the remainder of his hospitalization. Trigger for atrial 
fibrillation was most likely the acute stress of trauma in the 
setting of heavy alcohol ingestion. Given conversion to sinus 
rhythm, CHADS score of 0 and recent trauma, the patient was not 
started on systemic anticoagulation. However, this episode of 
atrial fibrillation puts him at higher risk for developing an 
arrhythmia in the future. 

# Alcohol abuse: Pt was intoxicated on presentation to ED with 
EtOH of 261. He got in fight with friends while drinking heavily 
which led to his presentation. He reported 6 beers/day two days 
a week on average. He denied history of severe withdrawal 
symptoms, seizures or DT. He was started on a phenobarbital 
taper, thiamine, folate and multivitamin while in the TSICU. 
Following transfer to medicine he remained clear and coherent on 
exam. His phenobarbital taper was discontinued given relatively 
low risk for severe withdrawal symptoms after further history. 
Pt did not show any signs of withdrawal during remained of 
hospitalization, although phenobarbital likely remained in his 
system during this time given long half-life. It was later 
discovered that the patient is, in fact, homeless, which 
increases his risk for abusing alcohol and other substances. 
Prior to discharge patient was counseled regarding safe drinking 
guidelines and was seen by social work. He will need continued 
support in outpatient follow-up. 

# Transaminitis: Noted to have elevated ALT 90, AST 77 with 
normal alkaline phosphatase and total bilirubin on admission 
labs. These values downtrended slightly to ALT 50, AST 37 prior 
to discharge. The most likely cause of transaminitis was acute 
alcohol intake. CK not elevated to level to suggest 
rhabdomyolysis or muscule tissue injury as cause. Hepatitis 
serologies (B and C) returned negative. LFTs should be repeated 
as an outpatient with continued work-up. 

# Hypoglycemia: Pt was hypoglycemic to 58 on ___ in the 
setting of prolonged fast after transfer from TSICU, remained 
asymptomatic. Alcohol intoxication/withdrawal possibly 
contributed to hypoglycemia due to inhibition of hepatic 
gluconeogenesis. Blood glucose responded appropriately to oral 
sugar intake. Hypoglycemia resolved and BG remained normal 
during last several days of hospitalization with resumption of 
normal diet. 

# Nicotine withdrawal: Reported smoking 2 cigarettes a day 
currently. Pt declined nicotine patch while hospitalized. Will 
need continued smoking cessation counseling as an outpatient. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
# Gave limited number of oxycodone 5mg for pain relief (15) on 
discharge
# Recheck LFTs, continue work-up as outpatient
# Hep B and C serologies negative, consider Hep B vaccine series
# Started patient on folate, thiamine, MV during this 
hospitalization given alcohol use
# Continue counseling regarding safe drinking guidelines and 
smoking cessation counseling
# Pt currently homeless, living at ___
# Has been out of care for some time (without PCP) so will need 
to catch up on health maintenance issues when he establishes 
care
# Follow-up appointment scheduled with General Surgery for 
staple removal on ___
# Contact: Brother ___ ___
# Full code

The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. This patient is not taking any preadmission medications

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain

hours Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0
3. FoLIC Acid 1 mg PO DAILY 
RX *folic acid 1 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 
Tablet Refills:*0
4. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
RX *multivitamin [Daily Multi-Vitamin]  1 tablet(s) by mouth 
once a day Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0
5. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Every four to six (___) 
hours Disp #*15 Tablet Refills:*0
6. Senna 8.6 mg PO DAILY 
RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 tablet by mouth once a day Disp 
#*30 Tablet Refills:*0
7. Thiamine 100 mg PO DAILY 
RX *thiamine HCl 100 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp 
#*30 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Head trauma with scalp laceration and concussive symptoms
Alcohol intoxication
Alcohol abuse
Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, provoked
Transaminitis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___, 

You were admitted to ___ after 
you fell and hit your head, causing a cut on your scalp. This 
was stapled by the Surgery team. You had several imaging studies 
including a CAT scan of your head, an X-RAY of your chest and 
several other bone X-RAYS that did not show any bleeding or 
broken bones. While you were in the ICU you were given fluids 
and a medication called phenobarbital to make sure that you did 
not withdraw from alcohol. Your liver function tests were found 
to be elevated, most likely because of your alcohol intake. 
Please use caution when consuming alcohol in the future, limit 
excessive alcohol intake to prevent future complications. While 
you were here you went into an irregular heart rhythm and your 
heart started beating too fast. We treated you with medication 
and your heart rate went back to normal. This may put you at 
increased risk for abnormal heart rhythms in the future. We have 
scheduled you with a new primary care doctor for follow-up. You 
have an follow-up appointment with Trauma Surgery (Dr. ___ on 
___, at which time your staples will be removed. We will give 
you a small amount of pain medication after you leave - if you 
need more you will need to discuss this with your primary care 
doctor. Please attend your follow-up appointments as scheduled. 
It was a pleasure taking care of you - we wish you all the best. 


Sincerely, 
Your ___ Medicine Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Head trauma with scalp laceration and concussive symptoms
Alcohol intoxication
Alcohol abuse
Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, provoked
Transaminitis
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,
You were admitted to ___ after
you fell and hit your head, causing a cut on your scalp. This
was stapled by the Surgery team. You had several imaging studies
including a CAT scan of your head, an X-RAY of your chest and
several other bone X-RAYS that did not show any bleeding or
broken bones. While you were in the ICU you were given fluids
and a medication called phenobarbital to make sure that you did
not withdraw from alcohol. Your liver function tests were found
to be elevated, most likely because of your alcohol intake.
Please use caution when consuming alcohol in the future, limit
excessive alcohol intake to prevent future complications. While
you were here you went into an irregular heart rhythm and your
heart started beating too fast. We treated you with medication
and your heart rate went back to normal. This may put you at
increased risk for abnormal heart rhythms in the future. We have
scheduled you with a new primary care doctor for follow-up. You
have an follow-up appointment with Trauma Surgery (Dr. ___ on
___, at which time your staples will be removed. We will give
you a small amount of pain medication after you leave - if you
need more you will need to discuss this with your primary care
doctor. Please attend your follow-up appointments as scheduled.
It was a pleasure taking care of you - we wish you all the best.
Sincerely,
Your ___ Medicine Team
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
___ w/ h/o CAD s/p MI and LAD/RCA stents, paroxysmal SVT s/p 
ablation, DMII, Grave's disease, post-thyroidectomy with 
post-surgical hypothyroid on replacement who presents from

.
First presented to OSH (___) on ___ with anasarca and 
recurrent L sided chest pain described as non-radiating, 
non-pleuritic, reproducible with palpation. At that time, her 
work up for possible cardiac etiology was non-revealing 
including negative troponins, BNP of 56, and negative CXR. She 
also had a recent ECHO (___) that demonstrated normal EF and 
no evidence of CHF. She also had LENIs (___) that were 
negative for DVT. She responded well to diuresis with Lasix and 
was discharged home this morning (___). She was walking to 
her Hematology appointment from the garage this morning, and she 
reports that her BLE edema reaccumulated by the time she reached 
the office and she was urged to come to the ED. Of note, she 
carries a diagnosis of Grave's disease s/p thyroidectomy and has 
post-surgical hypothyroidism on 275mcg of Synthroid, but her 
most recent TSH was 0.1 (___). 

In the ED, initial VS were T98, HR94, BP129/68, RR18, O2Sat96 on 
4L. She received supplemntal O2. Her EKG was normal, troponins 
were negative, BNP was 21. CTA chest was negative for PE. She 
did have a WBC of 12.2. She denies any fever, chills, night 
sweats, acute chest pain, abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting, 
diarrhea/constipation, dysuria/hematuria. 
.
On the floor, she has no additional complaints.  
.

issues or any other autoimmune diseases that we know of in the

IMAGING:
=======
___ Chest CTA
IMPRESSION: 
1.  No pulmonary embolism or acute aortic syndrome. 
2.  Numerous sub-4-mm pulmonary nodules of uncertain etiology, 
though non-specific in appearance.  If patient is a smoker or 
high-risk for malignancy, followup chest CT is recommended in 12 
months.  If low risk, no further followup is necessary. 
3.  Fatty liver. 
.
___ Abdominal US
IMPRESSION: 
1. Limited ultrasound exam due to the patient's body habitus.  
Echogenic liver consistent with fatty infiltration.  Other forms 
of liver disease and more advanced liver disease including 
significant hepatic fibrosis/cirrhosis cannot be excluded on 
this study. 
2. No ascites identified. 
.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ w/ h/o CAD s/p MI and LAD/RCA stents, paroxysmal SVT s/p 
ablation, DMII, hx of Graves disease, s/p thyroidectomy, 
currently with post-surgical hypothyroid on replacement who 
presents from ___ clinic with dyspnea and persistent 
bilateral leg edema.

# AMA Discharge: Patient left AMA the night before planned 
discharge because of complaints of 'anaphylaxis' from an 
adjacent patient's flowers. At the time, patient was breathing 
comfortably with good O2 saturation, and there were no other 
clinical signs of anaphylaxis or allergic reaction. She was 
given PRN benadryl dose prior to her decision to leave.

# Lower extremity and abdominal bloating: Etiology not entirely 
clear, her edema was predominantly non-pitting. Iatrogenic 
hyperthyroidism from high doses of levothyroxine thought to be a 
potential etiology. Lower extremity myxedema can occur with 
hyperthyroidism. She had begun to decrease her dose at her last 
hospitalization, so she was maintained at the same dose of 
275mcg to avoid weaning her too quickly. There was no evidence 
of heart failure on work-up at OSH (nl echo, nl proBNP). We also 
considered NAFLD given evidence of fatty infiltration on prior 
imaging, however her LFTs were wnl and she had no ascites on 
ultrasound. She responded well to IV Bumex when hospitalized at 
OSH, but continued to reaccumulate edema on oral diuretics. She 
was started here on IV Lasix and was then transitioned to PO 
torsemide given its better PO bioavailability. She responded 
well to IV lasix as well as PO torsemide. Her ___ abdominal US 
revealed no ascites, but an echogenic liver c/w fatty liver 
disease. Her 11pm cortisol was low-normal, suggesting she does 
not have hypercortisolism. She was given a prescription of PO 
torsamide for continued out-patient diuresis of her lower 
extremity edema. She will follow-up with her outpatient 
endocrinologist for ongoing levothyroxine taper.
.
# Graves' disease s/p thyroidectomy: TSH very suppressed at OSH 
at 0.10. She is on large dose of levothyroxine prior to 
admission, just decreased from 300->275mcg at OSH. We did not 
further taper her levothyroxine on this admission to avoid 
decreasing her thyroid hormone levels too quickly, but will 
encourage her to schedule out-patient follow-up with her 
endocrinologist.

# Dyspnea: She was initially complaining of some dyspnea when 
she was first admitted. However, during her entire 
hospitalization she was satting well on RA. Her ambulatory O2 
Sat was 94-97%.

# DMII: We held her home oral agents and kept her on an insulin 
sliding scale during her hospitalization.

# CAD s/p PCI: Continued her home ASA, statin, and atenolol 
during her hospitalization. We stopped her imdur due to 
headaches.

# Code status: FULL
# Emergency contact: ___ (husband) Phone number: 
___, Cell phone: ___ 

# Transitional issues:
-Continue levothyroxine taper
-Monitor electrolytes and creatinine after discharge given that 
she was started on torsemide

swelling and some shortness of breath. This was the same morning 
following a recent admission to ___ for 
similar symptoms and chest pain where they diuresed ___ with 
lasix and discharged ___ on oral lasix at home. Your work-up 
here revealed no cardiac or liver related cause of your edema, 
and imaging revealed no abdominal ascites (swelling). ___ did 
respond well to IV l=Lasix, and we transitioned ___ to a 
different oral diuretic called torsamide that should have better

History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year old with history of CAD s/p CABG (SVG-OM, 
LIMA-LAD, SVG-RCA) and history of PCI, type II DM, HTN, HL 
presents with chest pain.  
 
He was in his usual state of health until about 1 week ago when 
he began to have stuttering chest pain when getting out of bed 
that resolved with rest. He described it as a mild, non 
radiating chest pressure, that lasted ___ minutes. Yesterday 
morning, he woke up and began to have sudden onset ___ chest 
pain in the ___ his chest. This was accompanied by 
diaphoresis, nausea, vomiting. He took SL NTG without relief.  
  
He was taken to the ED at ___. At ___, he was 
noted to have ST elevations in V1-V2 (though actually improved 
from prior ECG in ___ and was transferred to ___ for STEMI 
and evaluation for cath. En route he was started on heparin gtt 
and was transiently on nitro gtt, but stopped due to SBP ___ and 
resolution of CP. Also received plavix 225 mg.  
  
At ___ ED, he remained CP free. He was continued on heparin 
gtt and received plavix 300. Per chart review, he has an 
"allergy" to ASA though pt denies, and thus ASA was not given.  
  
ROS positive for right sided calf pain with exertion  
  
On review of systems, he denies joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, 
black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or 
rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the 
other review of systems were negative.

cath:
Final Comments:
1. SElective coronary angiography of this right dominant
system revealed three vessel native coronary artery disease. The 
LMCA
had diffuse moderate disease. The LAD was occluded at the 
origin; the
distal vessel fills via the LIMA without significant disease. A 
very
small diagonal branch fills from SVG-OM jump graft. The Lcx av 
groove
branch had moderate diffuse disease. The marginal branches were
occluded; the major OM fills via the SVG without significant 
disease
with collaterals to smaller distal marginal. The RCA was 
occluded
proximally with the distal portion of the vessel filling via the 
SVG-PDA
graft.
2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed severe systemic 
hypertension
with a central pressure of 173/88 mmHg.
3. Saphenous vein graft angiography revealed the SVG-PDA to have 
a 90%
mid vessel lesion as well as more distal haxy 70% lesion just 
prior to
the previously placed stent; the stent was widely patent. The
SVG-diagonal-OM graft had a 90% proximal lesion with sequential 
80% and
60% hazy stenoses more distally.
4. Arterial conduit angiography revealed the LIMA-LAD to be 
patent
without angiographically apparent disease.
5. Successful stenting of the distal SVG-RCA with a 4.0x28 mm 
Promus DES
as well stenting of the proximal SVG-RCA with a 4.0x23mm Promus 
DES.
6. Successful stenting of the distal SVG-diag-OM graft with a 
4.0x28mm
Promus DES and stenting of the proximal SVG-diag-OM with a 
4.0x15mm
Promus DES.
7. Successful closure of right femoral arteriotomy with ___ 
perclose
device.
 
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:    
1. Three vessel native coronary artery disease.
2. Severe systemic hypertension.
3. Patent LIMA-LAD
4. SVG-OM obstructive disease.
5. Patent SVG-RCA stent
6. SVG-RCA obstructive disease.
7. Successful PCI of the SVG-RCA with a 4.0x28mm Promus ___ 
___ and
a 4.0x23mm Promus ___.
8. Successful PCI of the SVG-OM with a 4.0x28mm Promus ___ 
___ and
a 4.0x15mm Promus ___.
9. Successful closure of the right femoral arteriotomy site with 
a ___
Perclose

CXR
UPRIGHT VIEW OF THE CHEST: Linear opacity at the left lung base 
is consistent
with scarring and/or atelectasis. Lungs are elsewhere clear. No 
appreciable
pleural effusion or pneumothorax. There has been prior median 
sternotomy and
CABG. The heart size is normal. Tortuosity of the aorta is noted 
but the
mediastinal silhouette is otherwise normal. Hilar contours and 
pulmonary
vasculature are normal.

Echo ___
The left atrium is mildly dilated. The estimated right atrial 
pressure is ___ mmHg.Left ventricular wall thicknesses and 
cavity size are normal. There is mild regional left ventricular 
systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of the distal half 
of the septum and anterior walls, distal inferior wall, and 
apex. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 40%). No 
masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The 
aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic 
stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The 
mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. There is no 
mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. 
There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is 
no pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Normal left ventricular cavity size with regional 
systolic dysfunction c/w CAD (mid LAD distribution). Mild mitral 
regurgitation with normal valve morphology.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old with history of CAD s/p CABG and history of PCI, 
type II DM, HTN, HL admitted with NSTEMI. 
  
#. Coronary artery disease, NSTEMI: On arrival to the floor, 
patient was chest pain free and hemodynamically stable.  He was 
treated with aspirin, beta blocker, plavix, statin and heparin 
gtt.  There was a question of aspirin allergy, but his 
cardiologist's office and his PCP's office had no record of 
aspirin allergy, so he was given full strength aspirin with no 
adverse reaction.  Cardiac biomarkers were flat.  Cardiac 
catheterization was performed and showed severe stenosis of a 
vein graft to OM and a vein graft to the RCA, and two drug 
eluting stents were placed in each graft.  Patient experienced 
some chest pain during the procedure with mild post-procedural 
cardiac enzyme elevation.  He was started on metoprolol and 
aspirin.  His pravastatin was increased to 80 mg daily.  

# Ischemic cardiac myopathy.  Patient received an echo on 
___ which showed EF of 40%.  He was started on metoprolol 
and lisinopril.

Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left visual inferior visual loss
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Left temporal artery biopsy ___

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ woman who is otherwise healthy, who 
presents to the ED with vision loss ongoing for the last 5 days 
or so.

Symptoms first began in early ___. She first noticed some 
possible swelling of her face bilaterally in the cheeks.  Her 
husband agrees that he noticed swelling as well.  Shortly 
thereafter, she noticed that her jaw was painful especially when 
opening.  She denies feelings of her jaw locking or getting 
stuck when chewing.  The symptoms were present on both sides of 
her jaw.  She also experienced some feelings of pressure in the 
ears. In addition, she had some soreness in the back of her head 
and neck area.  She describes this not really as a pain but more 
of a tenderness to palpation.  She denies headache, but does 
also note that her temples are tender to the touch.

She was initially seen in her primary care doctor's office where 
she was diagnosed with sinusitis and given antibiotics.  At some 
point, the facial swelling to get better but the remainder of 
her symptoms persisted.  She was thought to have possible TMJ 
dysfunction.

However, since the beginning of this week, either ___ or 
___, she has noticed a "gray veil" coming up from the 
inferior aspect of her visual field in the left eye.  She is 
quite positive that this is only in the left eye and symptoms go 
away if she covers left eye.  The symptoms have been constant 
but
seem to have progressed to the point that now almost the entire 
bottom half of her visual field on the left side is gray.  She 
feels she has lost vision in the left side as she has been 
bumping into things on her left past few days. 

Because of the symptoms, she spoke with her PCP who referred her 
to the emergency department for evaluation.

She denies any pain in the eye or painful eye movements.  She 
denies sensitivity in the eye or sensation of foreign body.  She 
denies any positive visual phenomena other than those listed 
above.  She continues to endorse tenderness in the left neck, 
scalp, and temporal area.
 
Past Medical History:
Single lifetime seizure, approximately ___ years ago.  She states
she had a full workup including MRI and EEG but these were
unrevealing. 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No family history of autoimmune disease or any similar 
ophthalmologic issues. 
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION EXAM:
===============
Vitals: T: 99.0 P: 95 r: 16  BP: 136/82 SaO2: 100% room air
General: Awake, cooperative, NAD.
HEENT: NC/AT, no scleral icterus noted, MMM, no lesions noted in
oropharynx.  No adenopathy.  There is some tenderness to
palpation in the left scalp and temporal area.  No palpable 
cord.
Neck: Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated. No nuchal rigidity
Pulmonary: Lungs CTA bilaterally without R/R/W

Neurologic:
-Mental Status: Alert, oriented x 3. Able to relate history
without difficulty. Attentive, able to name ___ backward without
difficulty. Language is fluent with intact repetition and
comprehension. Normal prosody.  There was no evidence of apraxia
or neglect.
-Cranial Nerves:
II, III, IV, VI:  PERRL 3 to 2mm and brisk. EOMI without
nystagmus. Normal saccades.  In the left eye there is 
altitudinal
visual field deficit below the midline, somewhat more prominent
in the nasal aspect.  No red desaturation.  Visual acuity ___
bilaterally. Fundoscopic exam revealed no papilledema, exudates,
or hemorrhages, though view of the fundi somewhat difficult.
V: Facial sensation intact to light touch.  As above, some
tenderness in the left temporal region
VII: No facial droop, facial musculature symmetric.
VIII: Hearing intact to finger-rub bilaterally.
IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically.
XI: ___ strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally.
XII: Tongue protrudes in midline.
-Motor: Normal bulk, tone throughout. No pronator drift
bilaterally.
No adventitious movements, such as tremor, noted. No asterixis
noted.  Strength is full in all muscle groups of the upper and
lower extremities bilaterally
-Sensory: No deficits to light touch, pinprick, cold sensation,
vibratory sense, proprioception throughout. No extinction to 
DSS.
-DTRs:

L  2  2    2    2   1
R  2  2    2    2   1
Plantar response was flexor bilaterally.
-Coordination: No intention tremor, no dysdiadochokinesia noted.
No dysmetria on FNF or HKS bilaterally.
-Gait: Good initiation. Narrow-based, normal stride and arm
swing.

IMAGING:

1. No acute intracranial abnormalities.

CXR ___
No prior chest radiographs available. 
  
Lungs well expanded and clear.  Heart size top-normal.  Hilar 
and mediastinal contours and pleural surfaces are normal. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
PATIENT SUMMARY:
================
This is a ___ year old woman without known cardiovascular disease 
risk factors who presented with acute/subacute loss of vision 
affecting both lower quadrants of the left eye associated with 
jaw pain. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
# Left Jaw Pain
# Altitudinal Vision Loss in Left Eye
Differential diagnosis at this time includes GCA vs. 
non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy given prior 
history of HTN and smoking. ESR 38, CRP 11.7. MRI brain without 
acute process. Started on high dose steroids empirically. Also 
started on ASA and statin. Patient underwent temporal artery 
biopsy this admission on ___. Pathology pending at time of 
discharge. Discharged on 60 mg prednisone daily with vitamin D, 
calcium, and PPI prophylaxis. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
# Discuss bisphosphonate, PCP prophylaxis and prednisone dosing 
during rheumatology follow up on ___. 

# If diagnosis of giant cell arteritis is confirmed, patient 
will NOT need full dose ASA 325 mg. Please discontinue once 
pathology report is available.

# Follow up results from left temporal artery biopsy. 
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY  
2.  Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM  
3.  Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO DAILY  
4.  Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY  
5.  PredniSONE 60 mg PO DAILY Duration: 14 Days  
6.  Thiamine 100 mg PO DAILY  
7.  Vitamin D 1000 UNIT PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY:
========
Giant cell arteritis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

___ was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.

You came to the hospital because of trouble seeing out of your 
left eye. The bottom half of your visual field was particularly 
affected.

You symptoms and neurological exam were consistent with a 
condition called Giant Cell Arteritis. You were treated with 
steroids to held calm down the inflammation in the artery. You 
also underwent a biopsy of the temporal artery with our 
colleagues from ophthalmology. This went well and you were ready 
for discharge.

After leaving the hospital, you will follow up with our 
___ clinic. They will review the pathology 
results from the biopsy and discuss the next steps in treatment. 
You will also follow up with the rheumatologist next ___ 
in clinic. 

In the meantime, you should take all of your medications as 
prescribed. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

her jaw. She also experienced some feelings of pressure in the
ears. In addition, she had some soreness in the back of her head
and neck area. She describes this not really as a pain but more
of a tenderness to palpation. She denies headache, but does
also note that her temples are tender to the touch.
She was initially seen in her primary care doctor's office where
she was diagnosed with sinusitis and given antibiotics. At some
point, the facial swelling to get better but the remainder of
her symptoms persisted. She was thought to have possible TMJ
dysfunction.
However, since the beginning of this week, either ___ or
___, she has noticed a "gray veil" coming up from the
inferior aspect of her visual field in the left eye. She is
quite positive that this is only in the left eye and symptoms go
away if she covers left eye. The symptoms have been constant
but
seem to have progressed to the point that now almost the entire
bottom half of her visual field on the left side is gray. She
feels she has lost vision in the left side as she has been
bumping into things on her left past few days.
Because of the symptoms, she spoke with her PCP who referred her
to the emergency department for evaluation.
She denies any pain in the eye or painful eye movements. She
denies sensitivity in the eye or sensation of foreign body. She
denies any positive visual phenomena other than those listed
above. She continues to endorse tenderness in the left neck,
scalp, and temporal area.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ Mr. ___ came to the hospital for an elective 
admission and underwent an exploratory thoracoscopy, left 
thoracotomy, left upper lobectomy, chest wall resection, 
mediastinal lymph node dissection, intercostal muscle flap 
buttress, and bronchoscopy with lavage with Dr. ___ 
Dr. ___.  He tolerated the procedure well and it was 
completed without complication.  Postoperatively he had an 
epidural placed for pain control.  He was extubated and 
transferred from the OR to the TSICU.

Postoperatively, a bedside swallow evaluation was performed on 
POD1 and he was started on a dysphagia diet. On POD2, his 
pressors were weaned and one of the chest tubes removed. On 
POD3, his respiratory status worsened, and he was intubated. 
Central line, A-line, and oral gastric tube were placed, and the 
epidural was replaced. Bedside bronchoscopy was performed for 
left lower lobe collapse which improved afterwards. Antibiotics 
were started for presume pneumonia possibly secondary to 
aspiration. POD4, oral gastric tube feeds were started, and he 
had improve mucous secretion. Late in the evening, he 
self-extubated and was saturating well with good secretion 
management. POD5, morning CXR showed worsening opacity and CT 
chest showed a left hemothorax. A pigtail catheter was placed 
into the clot with drainage. Later that day, he began showing 
signs of increased work of breathing. He was reintubated and 
bronchoscopy was performed with secretions sent for culture 
again. On POD6, he was given 1u packed red blood cells and a 
dose of lasix for diuresis. He underwent bronchoscopy again on 
POD8, and blood/urine cultures were sent for elevated WBC to 
21.5. After discussion with the family and consent was obtained, 
he was taken to the operating room for a tracheostomy and PEG 
tube placement. Morning of POD9, bronchoscopy was performed. He 
tolerated approximately 4 hours of trach mask before showing 
signs of increased respiratory effort. The anterior pigtail 
placed to drain the hemothorax was removed. POD10, bronchoscopy 
was again performed with minimal mucous removal. POD11, the 
remaining chest tube which had been draining minimal 
serosanguinous fluid was removed. Per ID recommendations, 
antibiotics were removed on POD 13 as Mr. ___ remained 
afebrile with stable vital signs and no culture growths. On POD 
14, he underwent a green dye swallowing test and subsequently a 
video swallow test on POD ___spiration from 
swallowing if any; however barium was aspirated from his 
tracheostomy, so he remained NPO. A repeat swallow evaluation 
was done on ___ and he did well with thin liquids and 
pureed solids.  The barium that was suctioned out of his trach 
after his prior video swallow was likely from esophageal 
dysmotility/reflux and may need further work up.  
recommendations at this time include giving Mr. ___ sips of 
liquids and meds can be crushed in pureed.  His diet can slowly 
be advanced as his strength improves.  I*n the interim he 
continues to receive 100% of his caloric needs from Nepro cycled 
at 80 cc's/hr over 18 hrs. via PEG tube.

From a neurologic standpoint he continues on his ___ meds 
though they have been adjusted during this hospitalization.  He 
has periods of delirium and confusion but is 100% improved over 
a week ago.  Generally during the day he is out of bed, 
conversant and seems at his cognitive baseline.  He occasionally 
has periods of confusion at night but is better with Seraquel.

His left thoracotomy site is healing well except for a small 
area of skin separation superiorly which will need to be 
watched.  Currently the area is dry, without erythema but should 
be covered with a DSD if it starts to drain.

After a long ICU stay he was discharged to rehab on ___ to 
continue pulmonary toilet as well as physical therapy to 
increase his strength and mobility.  He will follow up with Dr. 
___ in the ___ Clinic in ___ days.

Discharge Instructions:
* You were admitted to the hospital for lung surgery and 
unfortunately you've had multiple complications requiring a 
prolonged hospital and ICU stay. You are improving daily and now 
are ready to transion to a rehab setting to help continue your 
pulmonary toilet and nutritional support as well as increase 
your amount of physical therapy to improve your deconitioned 
state and increase your mobility.
* Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or 
drainage.   Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.
* You may need continued pain medication but hopefully Tylenol 
alone will be sufficient.  Make sure that you have regular bowel 
movements.  Use a stool softener or gentle laxative to stay 
regular
* Continue to stay well hydrated with tube feedings to heal your 
incisions and sustain your nutrition until you can take all of 
your calories orally. 
* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat 
dry
* No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed

The fluid collection in the left upper hemithorax, where there
has been
posterior rib resection, moderate dependent left pleural
effusion, and poor
aeration of the left lung have been relatively unchanged for
week.
Right lung consolidation, just above the minor fissure, is also
relatively stable, but overall right lung volume has improved
and there is no longer any pulmonary edema. Another focus of
pneumonia may be developing at the right lung base and should be

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ Mr. ___ came to the hospital for an elective
admission and underwent an exploratory thoracoscopy, left
thoracotomy, left upper lobectomy, chest wall resection,
mediastinal lymph node dissection, intercostal muscle flap
buttress, and bronchoscopy with lavage with Dr. ___
Dr. ___. He tolerated the procedure well and it was
completed without complication. Postoperatively he had an
epidural placed for pain control. He was extubated and
transferred from the OR to the TSICU.
Postoperatively, a bedside swallow evaluation was performed on
POD1 and he was started on a dysphagia diet. On POD2, his
pressors were weaned and one of the chest tubes removed. On
POD3, his respiratory status worsened, and he was intubated.
Central line, A-line, and oral gastric tube were placed, and the
epidural was replaced. Bedside bronchoscopy was performed for
left lower lobe collapse which improved afterwards. Antibiotics
were started for presume pneumonia possibly secondary to
aspiration. POD4, oral gastric tube feeds were started, and he
had improve mucous secretion. Late in the evening, he
self-extubated and was saturating well with good secretion
management. POD5, morning CXR showed worsening opacity and CT
chest showed a left hemothorax. A pigtail catheter was placed
into the clot with drainage. Later that day, he began showing
signs of increased work of breathing. He was reintubated and
bronchoscopy was performed with secretions sent for culture
again. On POD6, he was given 1u packed red blood cells and a
dose of lasix for diuresis. He underwent bronchoscopy again on
POD8, and blood/urine cultures were sent for elevated WBC to
21.5. After discussion with the family and consent was obtained,
he was taken to the operating room for a tracheostomy and PEG
tube placement. Morning of POD9, bronchoscopy was performed. He
tolerated approximately 4 hours of trach mask before showing
signs of increased respiratory effort. The anterior pigtail
placed to drain the hemothorax was removed. POD10, bronchoscopy
was again performed with minimal mucous removal. POD11, the
remaining chest tube which had been draining minimal
serosanguinous fluid was removed. Per ID recommendations,
antibiotics were removed on POD 13 as Mr. ___ remained
afebrile with stable vital signs and no culture growths. On POD
14, he underwent a green dye swallowing test and subsequently a
video swallow test on POD ___spiration from
swallowing if any; however barium was aspirated from his
tracheostomy, so he remained NPO. A repeat swallow evaluation
was done on ___ and he did well with thin liquids and
pureed solids. The barium that was suctioned out of his trach
after his prior video swallow was likely from esophageal
dysmotility/reflux and may need further work up.
recommendations at this time include giving Mr. ___ sips of
liquids and meds can be crushed in pureed. His diet can slowly
be advanced as his strength improves. I*n the interim he
continues to receive 100% of his caloric needs from Nepro cycled
at 80 cc's/hr over 18 hrs. via PEG tube.
From a neurologic standpoint he continues on his ___ meds
though they have been adjusted during this hospitalization. He
has periods of delirium and confusion but is 100% improved over
a week ago. Generally during the day he is out of bed,
conversant and seems at his cognitive baseline. He occasionally
has periods of confusion at night but is better with Seraquel.
His left thoracotomy site is healing well except for a small
area of skin separation superiorly which will need to be
watched. Currently the area is dry, without erythema but should
be covered with a DSD if it starts to drain.
After a long ICU stay he was discharged to rehab on ___ to
continue pulmonary toilet as well as physical therapy to
increase his strength and mobility. He will follow up with Dr.
___ in the ___ Clinic in ___ days.

Discharge Instructions:

unfortunately you've had multiple complications requiring a
prolonged hospital and ICU stay. You are improving daily and now
are ready to transion to a rehab setting to help continue your
pulmonary toilet and nutritional support as well as increase
your amount of physical therapy to improve your deconitioned
state and increase your mobility.
* Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or
drainage. Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.
* You may need continued pain medication but hopefully Tylenol
alone will be sufficient. Make sure that you have regular bowel
movements. Use a stool softener or gentle laxative to stay
regular
* Continue to stay well hydrated with tube feedings to heal your
incisions and sustain your nutrition until you can take all of
your calories orally.
* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat
dry

History of Present Illness:
___ year old female with Factor V Leiden, splenic infarct s/p 
splenectomy, chronic abdominal pain requiring narcotics, and 
portal vein thrombosis presenting with acute on chronic 
abdominal pain and nausea. 

In ___, patient presented to an OSH with LUQ pain and 
was found to have splenic infarct and splenic vein thrombosis 
requiring splenectomy. She was diagnosed with factor V Leiden 
disorder. She was discharged on lovenox and warfarin, and she 
states she has been taking these consistently, but usually has 
subtherapeutic INR. She has also been on chronic narcotics, 
using oxycodone 30mg Q4hrs since ___ due to persistent 
LUQ abdominal pain, which she attributes to having her "organs 
stuck together" as a side-effect of her splenectomy. 

The history of her present illness dates to approximately 2 
weeks prior to presentation, when she presented to ___ 
___ following one day of right sided abdominal pain 
associated with nausea and vomiting, worse with food (causing 
her to have decreased PO intake). She cannot give details of the 
diagnostic work-up or management during this hospitalization, 
but she was on a PCA for pain control and had a CT of the 
abdomen. She was discharged after 6 days, and felt that her pain 
was improved at the time of discharge, but had continued daily 
nausea and vomiting. She was continued on her outpatient regimen 
of oxycodone 30mg Q4hrs and given addition oxycodone 15mg TID 
for breakthrough pain.  She had manageable pain for one day 
after discharge, and then had 3 more days of worsening pain, 
causing her to re-present to the ___ ED on ___. 
She had no relief from Oxycodone QID and breakthrough oxycodone 
(15mg TID PRN), and was given dilaudid. Labs were notable for 
lipase 65, normal electrolytes and renal function; AST 50, ALT 
70, Alk phos 120, bili 0.2, INR of 0.9, and normal PTT.  She was 
transferred to ___ for further management of her abdominal 
pain. 

She states that she has continued pain and nausea, but has not 
vomited because she has not been eating. She has not had 
diarrhea, melena, or hematochezia. 

In the ED initial vitals were: 98 70 110/67 20 96%. Labs were 
notable for mild transaminitis. RUQ ultrasound showed 
nonocclusive thrombus in portal vein.   Patient was given 
dilaudid and zofran and trasnferred to the floor.  

On the floor, the pt reports continued severe RLQ abd pain.

Review of systems was negative for fever, chills, night sweats, 
headache, vision changes, rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, 
cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, 
diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, 
hematuria.

##Abdominal pain: Her abdominal pain was localized to the right 
periumbilical area, and was severe and out of proportion to 
exam, concerning for ischemia. She had a somewhat distractable 
exam, but had tenderness with even light palpation. She had no 
findings of arterial ischemia on CTA, and no bloody diarrhea, 
and lactate was reassuringly negative. CTA showed chronic 
occlusion of the portal vein with cavernous transformation.  An 
omental infarct near the hepatic flexure of the colon was 
demonstrated on CT, which was thought to represent the source of 
her pain.  She received single doses of ceftriaxone and flagyl 
initially out of concern for bowel ischemia in the setting of 
asplenia, but these were stopped on hospital day 2 when it was 
evident that she did have ischemic bowel injury.  She has been 
on chronic opioids since her splenectomy in ___, requiring 
225mg of oxycodone daily.  She was continued on oxycodone 30mg 
PO Q4hrs and initially had a dilaudid PCA for breakthrough pain, 
which she used for one day before being weaned to oral oxycodone 
45mg Q4hrs.  On hospital day 4 her pain gradually diminished, 
and she was ambulatory in the hall and tolerating meals without 
nausea of vomiting.  She was evaluated by the chronic pain 
service, who felt that she may be developing opioid induced 
hyperalgesia given her recurrent bouts of abdominal pain, and 
recommended that she begin taking pregabalin as an adjunct to 
opiates, and encouraged her to follow-up with an outpatient 
provider who will wean her from her high dose of opioid pain 
medicines. 

#Hypercoagulability: patient has stated history of Factor V 
Leiden and antiphospholipid syndrome.  These diagnoses were not 
able to be verified during this admission.  According to 
patient, she has been told that she has both of these diagnoses. 
 However, she is unable to give the names of the surgeon who 
performed her splenectomy or the hematologist who follows her 
and prescribes her anticoagulation regimen.  She states that she 
has been on warfarin since ___ (medication history in 
OMR shows warfarin prescriptions dating back to ___, as 
well as lovenox since she has not been able to reach therapeutic 
INR.  During this hospitalization, she was shown to have 
cavernous transformation of a chronic portal vein thrombus, as 
well as an SMV thrombus. CTA also demonstrated gastric and 
esophageal varices. She was initially placed on a heparin drip, 
and then transitioned to therapeutic lovenox 80mg SQ BID. She 
was discharged on lovenox. 

Of note anticardiolipin antibodies were negative this admission.

hematologist in ___, but is unable to provide the name 
of this doctor. She states that her hematologist prescribes her 
anticoagulation medications, and that she has a follow-up 
appointment scheduled for ___ with her hematologist. She was 
urged to keep this appointment and to establish a plan for 
anticoagulation.

#Pain management: she was continued on home dose of oxycodone, 
and given an 8 day supply of oxycodone, until she is able to see 
the surgeon who prescribes her oxycodone; she was unable to 
provide the name of this doctor. She will need to follow up with 
this provider for ongoing prescriptions of pain medications. 

#Esophageal and gastric varices: CTA findings this 
hospitalization showed esophageal and gastric varices. She 
should have consultation with a gastroenterologist for possible 
EGD to assess the risk of bleeding from these varices and need 
for possible prophylactic medication. 

#Primary care: patient stated she does not have a primary care 
doctor. Due to the complexity of her hypercoagulable disease, 
she was encouraged to find a primary care doctor within the 
___ system so that all records can 
be shared amongst her outpatient providers, in order to 
coordinate her complex care in the future.

on the day of discharge by me in face to face interaction, and 
she verbalized understanding and agreement and all of her 
questions were answered to her satisfaction.

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
dizziness, diplopia, transient left facial droop
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None 

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ heavy smoker with no past medical
history (has not seen a doctor in ___ years) who presents as an
outside hospital transfer for further workup of dizziness and
transient left facial droop (OSH records state right facial 
droop
but per pt and family it was clearly left).  
Briefly, patient reports he was in ___ for the past month 
on
vacation, during the trip he had a constant cold and a cough, 
but
was otherwise in his usual state of health. Yesterday around 8 
___
on his plane ride back to the ___ he noticed that his right eye
started watering and he had rhinorrhea of the right nostril (I
confirmed several times that it was the right). He also started
having double vision,  which lasted only a few minutes and then
self resolved. He did not cover either eye to see if it would
resolve.  When the plane landed he was able to drive back home. 
He and his wife went to bed and then this morning at around 6 AM
he woke up started feeling dizzy. He describes it as a mixture 
of
lightheadedness as well as world around him spinning.  He was
still able to walk to the bathroom, although he felt unsteady. 
He
did not fall, did not sway in any particular side, did not feel
like he was pulled to either side. He also felt nauseous and had
an episode of emesis. Denies any paresthesias, focal weakness,
trouble producing a comprehending speech associated with the
episode. He went back to bed and when his wife saw him she felt
like he looked unwell. She also noted a left-sided facial droop
(mouth was drooping)and felt like his speech sounded slurred. CT
head was obtained and did not show any acute process, but showed
evidence of prior stroke. He was subsequently transferred to 
___ for further workup.

At ___ his blood pressure was
noted to be 177/102, the rest of his vitals were within normal
limits.  Lab work unremarkable.  He continues to experience
intermittent dizziness.  He said the dizziness is worse with
movement and usually lasts between 30 minutes and an hour.  It 
is
associated with nausea, emesis, right-sided headache, right ear
fullness and intermittent diplopia.  This never happened to him
before. No history of stroke or TIA.

Neuro review of symptoms he denies headache, blurred vision,
dysphagia. Denies difficulties producing or comprehending 
speech.
Denies focal weakness, numbness, parasthesiae. No bowel or
bladder incontinence or retention. Denies difficulty with gait.

On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or
chills.  No night sweats or recent weight loss or gain. Denies
shortness of breath.  Denies chest pain or tightness,
palpitations.  Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation 
or
abdominal pain.  No recent change in bowel or bladder habits.  
No
dysuria.  Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash.

 
Past Medical History:
None (hasn't seen a doctor in ___ years)
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Patient is not aware of any family history of stroke, or any
other neurological disease or heart disease                      


 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:
Physical Exam:
Vitals: Afebrile P: 64 177 r: 16  BP: 177/102 SaO2: 99% RA
- General: Awake, cooperative
- HEENT: NC/AT
- Neck: Supple
- Pulmonary: no increased WOB
- Cardiac: well perfused 
- Abdomen: soft, nontender, nondistended
- Extremities: no edema, pulses palpated
- Skin: no rashes or lesions noted.

Neurologic:

-Mental Status: Alert, oriented x 3. Able to relate history
without difficulty. Attentive, able to name the ___ backward
without difficulty. Language is fluent with intact repetition 
and
comprehension. Normal prosody. There were no paraphasic errors.
Pt was able to name both high and low frequency objects.  Speech
was not dysarthric. Able to follow both midline and appendicular
commands.  There was no evidence of apraxia or neglect.

-Cranial Nerves:
I: Olfaction not tested.
II: PERRL 3 to 2mm and brisk. VFF to confrontation. 
III, IV, VI: EOMI with non-fatigable right beating nystagmus on
right gaze.  No skew deviation.  Endorses diplopia when looking
to the right on near and far vision, diplopia resolves when 
right
eye covered but persists when left eye covered.
V: Facial sensation intact to light touch.
VII: mild LNFF, and mild left?ptosis
VIII: States hearing mildly decreased on right side
IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically.
XI: ___ strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally.
XII: Tongue protrudes in midline.

-Motor: Normal bulk, tone throughout. No pronator drift
bilaterally.
No adventitious movements, such as tremor, noted. No asterixis
noted.

-DTRs:

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were hospitalized due to symptoms of dizziness resulting 
from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a condition where a blood vessel 
providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is blocked by a 
clot. The brain is the part of your body that controls and 
directs all the other parts of your body, so damage to the brain 
from being deprived of its blood supply can result in a variety 
of symptoms.
Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:
Diabetes
High Cholesterol
High Blood pressure
Smoking

We are changing your medications as follows:
Start Lisinopril 5 mg daily 
Start Aspirin 81 mg daily 
Start Atorvastatin 80 mg daily 
Increase Metformin as follows: 
- Start Metformin 500 mg daily for one week (___)
- Increase Metformin 500 mg twice daily for one week (___) 
- Increase to Metformin  1000 mg twice daily ___ - 
indefinitely).

We recommend you stop smoking. 

Please take your other medications as prescribed.

Please followup with Neurology, ___ and your primary care 
physician.

If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:
- Sudden partial or complete loss of vision
- Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth
- Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you
- Sudden weakness of one side of the body
- Sudden drooping of one side of the face
- Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body

Sincerely,
Your ___ Neurology Team

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Cardiac Arrest

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Cooling protocol
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr ___ is a ___ with a known history of severe AS and 3VD. 
Over the last ___ weeks he has been
experiencing worsening dyspnea on exertion, precipitated with 
very
mild activity. He also reported a recent increase in
congestion, particularly in the morning with production of white
phlegm and a cough. He was admitted for a ___ cardiac cath 
which demonstrated three vessel coronary artery disease and 
severe aortic stenosis. The pt was planned for CABG+/-AVR on 
___.

Today, around noon, the pt had a witnessed arrest. He was 
reportedly unconscious for ~15 minutes without chest 
compression. EMS responded and found the pt to be pulseless in a 
shockable rhythm and he was given one shock (unknown which 
rhythm). During transport to the ED he had another shockable 
rythm and they shocked him again. He also recieved epi x3. He 
was intubated in the field. On arrival to ___ ED he was found 
to be asystolic. He received epi x1 with ROSC. He was then found 
to be in complete heart block with a RBBB escape at a rate of 
40bpm.  With slowing of the sinus rate, he resumed conduction at 
1:1 with a RBBB/LAFB morphology. The pt was started on levophed 
for BPs ___, and was externally paced but was not getting 
great capture and so a transvenous pacer was placed with 
improvement of BPs 120s-130s. He also got atropine x1 and 
calcium chloride. Dopa and Epi were added for further bp 
augmentation. CT surg evaluated the pt in the ED but did not 
feel emergent intervention was indicated. Post-arrest team 
recommended therapeutic hypothermia assuming BP and HR were 
stabilized. The patient was then taken to the cath lab to get a 
screw in pacer. In the cath lab he had a cardiac index around 2 
and a bedside ECHO showed an EF of approximately 30 percent.

On arrival to the CCU, the pt was found to be overbreathing the 
vent, but not responding to commands or stimuli. BPs remained in 
the ___ on max dose levophed/dopamine/epi drips, with HRs in 
the 120s. He was paralyzed with cisatricurium with improved vent 
mechanics. Post-arrest team reevaluated and recommended slow, 
cautious cooling as tolerated. 

Of note, the pt was diagnosed with e.coli bacteriuria on pre-op 
urine culture and prescribed ciprofloxacin 500mg BID. He had 
taken two tablets prior to his arrest. EKG ___ demonstrated QTc 
396. 

On review of systems, his family denies any prior history of 
stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, 
bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, 
hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. Denies recent fevers, 
chills or rigors. Denies exertional buttock or calf pain. ROS 
limited by pt intubated and paralyzed. 
 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  
1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: - Diabetes, +Dyslipidemia, 
+Hypertension  
2. CARDIAC HISTORY:  History of severe Aortic stenosis. 3VD. Was 
scheduled for a CABG on ___
- PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: ___ cardiac cath 
demonstrating 3 vessel disease - ref note in webomr for details  

3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
Aortic Stenosis
Mild depression

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or 
sudden cardiac death; otherwise non-contributory.  
 

 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION:
VS: Wt=80kgs T=35.8 BP=84/46HR=124RR=22 O2sat=98%  
General: Laying flat in bed, intubated, paralyzed, cooling pads 
in place
HEENT: paralyzed, ET tube in place    
CV: S1,S2 + Systolic murmur around ___ intervertebral space on 
the right parasternal border 
Lungs: CTAB, cannot appreciate crackles or ronchi but patient is 
on ventilator
Abdomen: Soft
GU:Foley's catheter inserted 
Ext:Presence of several lines- refer below, pedal edema   
Neuro: unable to participate
Skin: no rash
PULSES: R+, DP+, CA+, FE+

Cl-105 calHCO___-15*

REPORTS:
CXR
IMPRESSION: 
1.  Venous pacing lead projects over the main pulmonary artery 
and could be 
withdrawn approximately 16 cm.   
  
2.  Likely layering right pleural effusion without pneumothorax. 
 Mild 
pulmonary vascular congestion.   
  
3.  At least 1 right-sided rib fracture. 
  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  ___ with hx of 3VD/severe AS, presented s/p 
cardiac arrest with ROSC after 30 minutes, admitted for 
post-arrest management. On arrival to CCU, pt was requiring max 
doses of epi/levo/dopa drips to maintain sbps ___. He was 
also started on insulin gtt and modified therapeutic hypothermia 
was attempted. He had a significant metabolic acidosis/lactic 
acidosis requiring bicarb gtt and pushes which he did not 
respond to. Overnight his pressor requirement increased and max 
doses of vaso/neo were also added, maintaining sbps in the ___. 
At this point a discussion was had with the pt's daughter and 
the decision was made to not escalate care, and not to do CPR. 
This morning, the pt reverted to a paced rhythm and his sbps 
dropped to the ___ by a-line without waveform. With the pt's 
daughter and wife in the room, the pacer was turned off and 
revealed no heartbeat. The pt was pronounced dead at 810am. The 
medical examiner waived the case. 

# s/p cardiac arrest: Pt with cardiac arrest, 15 minutes down 
with shockable rhythm without chest compressions, followed by 15 
minutes of CPR with ROSC. Unclear etiology of arrest. Likely 
arrhythmia ___ known cardiac disease. Possible exacerbated by 
fluoroquinolone usage. Pt with persistent hypotension requiring 
levophed/dopamine/epi gtts and unstable heart rate which delayed 
onset of cooling. 

# Respiratory Failure: pt intubated in the setting of cardiac 
arrested. paralyzed for overbreathing the vent. 

# Metabolic acidosis: Pt with pH 7.00, likely multifactorial due 
to ___, lactic acidosis in absence of respiratory compensation. 

# s/p CHB: pt with complete heart block after arrest. Screw in 
pacer placed in cath lab. 

# ___: Cr elevated, likely due to hypoperfusion during cardiac 
arrest. 

# Leukocytosis: likely ___ hypoperfusion during prolonged 
cardiac arrest. pt also with UTI, however normal wbc on 
admission, therefore wbc 20 probably associated with global 
injury rather than infection. 

# Elevated liver enzymes: Pt with transaminitis, and elevated 
LDH. Likely due to shock liver, with possible component of 
congestive hepatopathy. Less likely to be infection etiology. 

# UGIB: pt with dark blood from NG tube. Unclear etiology. No 
preceding e/o GI bleed. Possible stress gastritis. Likely 
exacerbated by coagulopathy. 
- pantoprazole IV BID

# CAD/3VD: 
- continue asa PR 
- ct surg evaled in ED, no plan for emergent intervention

# UTI: on cefazolin s/p procedure

# Hyperglycemia: Pt with elevated glucose, last FSG 457. No 
known of hx of DM (last HgA1c 5.6%). Likely ___ stress response. 


#DYSLIPIDEMIA- 
- Hold Simvastatin 20mg 1tab qam

#DEPRESSION-
- Hold Paroxentine HCL 10mg 1tab po
 
Medications on Admission:
AMLODIPINE - amlodipine 10 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth  - 
FUROSEMIDE - furosemide 20 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily
LISINOPRIL - lisinopril 40 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth qam - 

PAROXETINE HCL - paroxetine 10 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth
SIMVASTATIN - simvastatin 20 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth qam
ASPIRIN-aspirin 81mg daily po- 1 tab

reportedly unconscious for ~15 minutes without chest
compression. EMS responded and found the pt to be pulseless in a
shockable rhythm and he was given one shock (unknown which
rhythm). During transport to the ED he had another shockable
rythm and they shocked him again. He also recieved epi x3. He
was intubated in the field. On arrival to ___ ED he was found
to be asystolic. He received epi x1 with ROSC. He was then found
to be in complete heart block with a RBBB escape at a rate of
40bpm. With slowing of the sinus rate, he resumed conduction at
1:1 with a RBBB/LAFB morphology. The pt was started on levophed
for BPs ___, and was externally paced but was not getting
great capture and so a transvenous pacer was placed with
improvement of BPs 120s-130s. He also got atropine x1 and
calcium chloride. Dopa and Epi were added for further bp
augmentation. CT surg evaluated the pt in the ED but did not
feel emergent intervention was indicated. Post-arrest team
recommended therapeutic hypothermia assuming BP and HR were
stabilized. The patient was then taken to the cath lab to get a
screw in pacer. In the cath lab he had a cardiac index around 2
and a bedside ECHO showed an EF of approximately 30 percent.
On arrival to the CCU, the pt was found to be overbreathing the
vent, but not responding to commands or stimuli. BPs remained in
the ___ on max dose levophed/dopamine/epi drips, with HRs in
the 120s. He was paralyzed with cisatricurium with improved vent
mechanics. Post-arrest team reevaluated and recommended slow,
cautious cooling as tolerated.
Of note, the pt was diagnosed with e.coli bacteriuria on pre-op
urine culture and prescribed ciprofloxacin 500mg BID. He had
taken two tablets prior to his arrest. EKG ___ demonstrated QTc
396.
On review of systems, his family denies any prior history of
stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism,
bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough,
hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. Denies recent fevers,
chills or rigors. Denies exertional buttock or calf pain. ROS
limited by pt intubated and paralyzed.
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: - Diabetes, +Dyslipidemia,
+Hypertension
2. CARDIAC HISTORY: History of severe Aortic stenosis. 3VD. Was
scheduled for a CABG on ___
- PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: ___ cardiac cath
demonstrating 3 vessel disease - ref note in webomr for details
3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
Aortic Stenosis
Mild depression
Social History:
___
Family History:
No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or
sudden cardiac death; otherwise non-contributory.
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION:
VS: Wt=80kgs T=35.8 BP=84/46HR=124RR=22 O2sat=98%
General: Laying flat in bed, intubated, paralyzed, cooling pads
in place
HEENT: paralyzed, ET tube in place
CV: S1,S2 + Systolic murmur around ___ intervertebral space on
the right parasternal border
Lungs: CTAB, cannot appreciate crackles or ronchi but patient is
on ventilator
Abdomen: Soft
GU:Foley's catheter inserted
Ext:Presence of several lines- refer below, pedal edema
Neuro: unable to participate
Skin: no rash
PULSES: R+, DP+, CA+, FE+
Pertinent Results:

___ 01:25PM BLOOD WBC-8.3 RBC-3.95* Hgb-12.3* Hct-37.9*
MCV-96 MCH-31.3 MCHC-32.6 RDW-13.5 Plt ___
___ 06:21PM BLOOD WBC-20.4*# RBC-3.83* Hgb-11.8* Hct-37.0*
MCV-97 MCH-30.8 MCHC-31.8 RDW-13.7 Plt ___

K-4.2 Cl-105 HCO3-10* AnGap-24*

AlkPhos-96 TotBili-0.5

calTCO2-16* Base XS--12

Cl-105 calHCO___-15*
REPORTS:
CXR
IMPRESSION:
1. Venous pacing lead projects over the main pulmonary artery
and could be
withdrawn approximately 16 cm.
2. Likely layering right pleural effusion without pneumothorax. Mild
pulmonary vascular congestion.
3. At least 1 right-sided rib fracture.
Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN ___ with hx of 3VD/severe AS, presented s/p
cardiac arrest with ROSC after 30 minutes, admitted for
post-arrest management. On arrival to CCU, pt was requiring max
doses of epi/levo/dopa drips to maintain sbps ___. He was
also started on insulin gtt and modified therapeutic hypothermia
was attempted. He had a significant metabolic acidosis/lactic
acidosis requiring bicarb gtt and pushes which he did not
respond to. Overnight his pressor requirement increased and max
doses of vaso/neo were also added, maintaining sbps in the ___.
At this point a discussion was had with the pt's daughter and
the decision was made to not escalate care, and not to do CPR.
This morning, the pt reverted to a paced rhythm and his sbps
dropped to the ___ by a-line without waveform. With the pt's
daughter and wife in the room, the pacer was turned off and
revealed no heartbeat. The pt was pronounced dead at 810am. The
medical examiner waived the case.
# s/p cardiac arrest: Pt with cardiac arrest, 15 minutes down
with shockable rhythm without chest compressions, followed by 15
minutes of CPR with ROSC. Unclear etiology of arrest. Likely
arrhythmia ___ known cardiac disease. Possible exacerbated by
fluoroquinolone usage. Pt with persistent hypotension requiring
levophed/dopamine/epi gtts and unstable heart rate which delayed
onset of cooling.
# Respiratory Failure: pt intubated in the setting of cardiac
arrested. paralyzed for overbreathing the vent.
# Metabolic acidosis: Pt with pH 7.00, likely multifactorial due
to ___, lactic acidosis in absence of respiratory compensation.
# s/p CHB: pt with complete heart block after arrest. Screw in
pacer placed in cath lab.
# ___: Cr elevated, likely due to hypoperfusion during cardiac
arrest.
# Leukocytosis: likely ___ hypoperfusion during prolonged
cardiac arrest. pt also with UTI, however normal wbc on
admission, therefore wbc 20 probably associated with global
injury rather than infection.
# Elevated liver enzymes: Pt with transaminitis, and elevated
LDH. Likely due to shock liver, with possible component of
congestive hepatopathy. Less likely to be infection etiology.
# UGIB: pt with dark blood from NG tube. Unclear etiology. No
preceding e/o GI bleed. Possible stress gastritis. Likely
exacerbated by coagulopathy.
- pantoprazole IV BID
# CAD/3VD:
- continue asa PR
- ct surg evaled in ED, no plan for emergent intervention
# UTI: on cefazolin s/p procedure
# Hyperglycemia: Pt with elevated glucose, last FSG 457. No
known of hx of DM (last HgA1c 5.6%). Likely ___ stress response.
#DYSLIPIDEMIA-
- Hold Simvastatin 20mg 1tab qam
#DEPRESSION-
- Hold Paroxentine HCL 10mg 1tab po

PAROXETINE HCL - paroxetine 10 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth
SIMVASTATIN - simvastatin 20 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth qam
ASPIRIN-aspirin 81mg daily po- 1 tab
