text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PSYCHIATRY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
"People have been telling me that I have OCD and depression, I 
also think of suicide and I was told that I should take it 
seriously..."

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Pt is ___ with reported h/o OCD and depression, who presented to 
___ per the recommendation of his twin sister for recurrent 
intrusive thoughts about jumping off of a stairwell. He reports 
that these thoughts only occur when he is sitting on the upper 
floor in a ___ library, at which time thoughts will pop into 
his head of jumping head-first from the stairwell. He denies 
ever having any intent of actually go through with this. Of 
note, as pt described his history he was quite tangential, and 
difficult to follow. He frequently preferred to speak in 
metaphors, such as when he described his stressors as: "this 
boat that is the US feels like it's sinking, and ___ is the 
cabin on top that I'm trying to get out of to help the boat from 
sinking, but they keep preventing me from getting out of it." Pt 
initially reports that he is a graduate student at ___, 
studying for a degree in public administration. It is a ___ 
degree, however pt is now in his ___ year of trying to finish 
the requirements for it. He attributes this to not being able to 
get assignments turned in on time due to his OCD. He handed in a 
paper late last semester, and reports that he is now only a 
couple of credits short of graduating. If he completes a 6-week 
course he expects to graduate in ___. 

Re: his h/o OCD pt describes it in relation to writing papers 
for school. He feels that he has a vast amount of knowledge and 
has obsessive thoughts of always wanting to add more to the 
papers. Eventually he will go back and add the material, which 
helps to relieve his stress, but ends of delaying his completion 
of the work.

Pt describes his mood as "dysthymic." He says that he has always 
felt this way. Denies any h/o manic symptoms. On review of NVS, 
pt endorses some difficulty sleeping and excessive feelings of 
guilt that he is not living up to his expectations of his 
ancestors.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: h/o ventricular tachycardia diagnosed at age ___, resolved 
with cardiac ablation. No current PCP; has a family doctor in 
___, ___ where he grew up.

Past Psych Hx: Prior dx of OCD and depression.
No prior hospitalizations. No h/o SA, SIB or assaultive 
behavior.
Has no current out-pt providers.
___ saw a therapist in ___ grade for depressed mood. Saw a 
psychiatrist and therapist for several months ___ years ago. Pt 
took Prozac for about 4 months with minimal improvement in mood 
and developed "angry" outbursts. Pt stopped seeing his therapist 
in ___ b/c he felt the therapist was accusing him of 
using her to get charge for overdue library books taken away. 
(Pt had 50-100 library books at his home that he was keeping to 
work on a school assignment. When discussing this, pt began by 
describing how the books were very neatly stacked up in his apt. 
When further ?'ed about why he never returned them, pt stated 
"there were so many of them... I guess I could have carried ___ 
back each day... that's the kind of thing I've had trouble 
getting done.")
 
Social History:
Pt was born and raised in ___, ___. His parents were never 
married and separated when pt was 2. His father lives in 
___, and pt is not close to him. Pt grew up with his mother, 
grandmother and and twin sister. Pt was particularly close to 
his grandmother. He describes his mother as loving and caring, 
but had to work hard and was not always available. Pt reports 
that his mother came from an upper-middle class family, however 
she got pregnant at a young age and spent her time fluctuating 
between working lower-level jobs and being on welfare. Pt 
identifies this as causing significant conflicts within the 
family. When asked about abuse, pt recalls an episode at age ___ 
at a hospital in which he had to be stuck 13+ times with a 
needle for blood draw... "anytime I've been asked about abuse, I 
always think back to that... but I don't ever have memories of 
being sexually molested or things like that." Pt did well in 
school. He went to ___ at ___ it 
took him ___ years to graduate "b/c I switched majors my senior 
year." He then spent several years teaching K-12 school both 
abroad and in the ___. "It was sort of trial-by-fire; I knew I 
would have difficutly controlling a classroom, so I did this 
rather than take classes for it." Pt enrolled at ___ 
program ___ years ago, and within the first ___ years switched to 
MPA program. Pt has not finished this degree (as described in 
HPI). He is not technically a student at ___, but has plans 
to enroll in a 6-week course that would allow him to graduate in 
several months. Pt has a GF of ___ year. Religion: pt grew up as a 
Catholic; now describes himself as spiritual, not following any 
particular religion. He lives in a house with 1 roommate. Pt 
denies any legal problems.

Substance Abuse Hx: Pt denies any current use of 
tob/etoh/illicits. He quit drinking in ___ b/c he felt he was 
drinking to "self-medicate" to make him feel calmer. Since then 
he drank a beer on one occasion b/c he felt it would cause more 
harm socially to not have the beer (he appears rather distressed 
about this happening). He addamantly denies ever "inhaling 
anything into [his] body", or ever trying illicit drugs.
 
Family History:
Family Psych Hx: Mother: depression, with occasional "fits of 
rage". Great-grandmother with unclear mental illness.
 
Physical Exam:
MSE on admission:
Appearance: thin AA man, appears stated age, dressed neatly in 
button-up shirt that is tucked into blue jeans, good hygeine, 
hair shaved
Behavior: cooperative but somewhat suspiscious, eye contact with 
intense gaze and at times looking around the room suspisciously, 
sitting with a somewhat stiff posture
Speech: articulate, somewhat slow with brief speech latency 
(appears to be thinking about his responses), normal tone and 
prosody
Mood: "dysthymic"
Affect: limited range, smiling occasionally
TP: circumstantial, prefers to speak in metaphors quite often
TC: +SI with intrusive thoughts of jumping from a stairwell; 
denies any intent. Denies any HI. Pt also endorses some paranoid 
ideation: feels that his phone conversations are likely being 
recorded given the current presidential administration, but 
denies that this causes him significant distress. He also 
described some religious/magical thinking: after ___ became a 
___ Court ___ he needed to go to church in order to be 
around "the ___ 
Perceptions: denies any auditory or visual hallucinations
Cognitive Exam:
Sensorium: alert
Orientation: x3
Attention/Concentration: good
Memory: ___ at 5 min
Abstract thinking: Grass...greener: "the grass isn't really 
greener on the other side; it might be dry and yellow; but I 
still want to go and find out for myself." Glass houses... 
stones: "they shouldn't throw hard objects; maybe they should 
throw softer ones, like a cushball; or build it out of a 
sturdier material."
 
Pertinent Results:
CBC, BMP, B12, Folate, TSH, RPR: all WNL
Serum and urine tox negative
head CT: within normal limits
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Psychiatry:  The patient was admitted on a conditional voluntary 
status.  He reported difficulty organizing his thoughts.  He 
demonstrated odd and concrete thinking, loosened associations, 
paranoia, and initially had suicidal ideations. He denied 
audiovisual hallucinations. No bizarre delusions were noted.  
Collateral information obtained from Dr. ___ w 
permission from Mr. ___ who felt relieved that the patient 
had agreed to inpatient psychiatric hospitalization and his 
starting medications.
.
___ testing was inconclusive because patient's answers were 
inconsistent which may be an indication of the high level of 
this patient's disordered thought process/psychosis.  He scored 
very high  in levels of obsessive compulsive traits. He had a 
high level of of concern about his health.
. 
Diagnostically, Mr. ___ appeared to have a primary 
psychotic disorder with prominent thought disorder and negative 
symptoms, as well as mild paranoia.  His diagnosis is likely to 
be schizophrenia, and this was discussed with the patient.  He 
had appropriate questions and concerns about the diagnosis and 
treatment, and these questions were discussed thoroughly with 
the patient.  His prognosis was discussed as well, including the 
possibility that the disorder will improve, and the likelihood 
that treatment and early intervention will be most helpful.
.
Mr. ___ participated in group, individual and milieu 
therapy.  He began taking risperidone without side effects.  He 
responded well, and his thought process became more linear and 
goal-directed, and his affective range improved.  His paranoia 
decreased and his ability to relate to others improved.  Prior 
to discharge he denied suicidal thoughts, intent or plan.  He 
was future oriented and appeared safe and appropriate for 
discharge.
.
Referrals were made to the following programs per patient 
request: CIDAR (a research study for schizophrenia), Prevention 
and Recovery of Early Psychosis (at ___), 
Department of Mental Health.  The patient was assisted with 
applictaion to ___ insurance.   He was referred to the ___ 
___ for primary care, and will be referred from there to a 
psychiatrist and therapist.
.
Medical: There were no active medical problems on this 
hospitalization.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Risperidone 3 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at 
bedtime).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
AXIS I: Psychosis Not Otherwise Specified (rule out 
schizophrenia)
AXIS II: No diagnosis
AXIS III: None active.  History of Ventricular Tachycardia (age 
___
AXIS IV: Unemployed. 
AXIS V: 50

 
Discharge Condition:
Good. Patient appears safe and appropriate for discharge. 
Mental Status Exam: Well-dressed, neatly groomed, no psychomotor 
abnormalities. Appropriate, cooperative, good eye-contact. NAD. 
Gestures with hands while explaining his thought process. Speech 
normal v/t/r/p. Mood 'good.' Affect restricted but some range. 
occasionally smiles appropriately. TP overly inclusive but more 
linear than yesterday. TC:  Mild paranoia. No AVH, no SI/HI. 
Insight good, understands illness and treatment. Judement:  
Good, accepting and participating in treatment appropriately. 

 
Discharge Instructions:
-If you are having thoughts of wanting to hurt yourself or 
others, please call ___ or return to the Emergency Department 
immediately. 
-Please continue to take medications as instructed. 
-Please follow up with outpatient treaters. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

others, please call ___ or return to the Emergency Department
immediately.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o M who was admitted to the General Surgical 
Service on ___ for evaluation and treatment of abdominal 
pain.  Admission abdominal/pelvic CT revealed acute appendicitis 
without abscess or perforation. WBC was elevated at 13.6. The 
patient underwent laparoscopic appendectomy, which went well 
without complication (reader referred to the Operative Note for 
details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the 
patient arrived on the floor on IV fluids, and acetaminophen and 
oxycodone for pain control.  The patient was hemodynamically 
stable.  There was some oozing noted during the OR case, so the 
decision was made to monitor the patient overnight and check a 
CBC in the AM. POD #1 CBC was stable. 

When tolerating a diet, the patient was converted to oral pain 
medication with continued good effect. Diet was progressively 
advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. 
The patient voided without problem. During this hospitalization, 
the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with 
respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively 
participated in the plan of care. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged home without services. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

 
Medications on Admission:
-allopurinol ___ mg daily
-fexofenadine 180 mg daily
-Flonase
-Lisinopril 10 mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Mild  
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
hold for loose stool   
3.  Milk of Magnesia 30 mL PO Q6H:PRN Constipation - Third Line  

4.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
  Reason for PRN duplicate override: Alternating agents for 
similar severity
Wean as tolerated. Patient may request partial fill.  
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*8 Tablet Refills:*0 
5.  Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY:PRN Constipation - Second 
Line  
6.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN Constipation - First Line  
7.  Simethicone 40-80 mg PO QID:PRN abdominal pain  
8.  Allopurinol ___ mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute appendicitis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ with 
acute appendicitis.  You were taken to the operating room and 
had your appendix removed laparoscopically.  This procedure went 
well.  Your blood levels were checked and have remained stable.  
You are now tolerating a regular diet and your pain is 
well-managed with oral pain medication.  You are now ready to be 
discharged home. 

Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the 
appointment listed below.
 
ACTIVITY:
 
o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
o You may climb stairs. 
o  You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
o  Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
o  You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
o  You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
o  You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
You might feel somewhat depressed.
o  You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages 
called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
is normal.
o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
please call your surgeon.
o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
fever
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ postmenopausal female with recent diagnosis of stage 
I (T1c, N0, Mx) grade III invasive ductal carcinoma, ER/PR 
positive, HER-2/neu positive s/p 4 cycles of dose dense 
Adriamycin and Cytoxan, currently ___ ___ Taxol/ 
Herceptin who presents to the ER with fever.  History is 
assisted by her daughter who helps translate.  She states that 
before her chemotherapy on ___, she had a low-grade temp 
of 99 and also felt chills in her room during the infusion.  She 
went home, and after returning from errands the following day 
around 6pm, she felt malaise, took her temperature was 101.  She 
took Tylenol 1g at 9:30pm. She denies any focal symptoms with 
the exception of loose stools x2 the previous day.  She usually 
has constipation with chemotherapy and did not take any colace 
or prune juice, etc. She denies any sick contacts, medication 
changes, or blood in her stool. In the ER, vitals 101.6 121 
115/72 18 100% ra.  She received Ibuprofen 600mg PO, Vancomycin 
1g IV.  On arrival to the floor, she states she feeels well.   
.
Review of Systems:  
(+) Per HPI  
(-) Denies night sweats, recent weight loss or gain. Denies 
blurry vision, diplopia, loss of vision, photophobia. Denies 
headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies 
chest pain or tightness, palpitations, lower extremity edema. 
Denies cough, shortness of breath, or wheezes. Denies nausea, 
vomiting, constipation, abdominal pain, melena, hematemesis, 
hematochezia. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rashes or 
skin breakdown. No numbness/tingling in extremities. All other 
systems negative.
.

 
Past Medical History:
ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: Patient developed a left breast mass that she
felt on her own exam in the early ___ timeframe.  
-diagnostic breast imaging with mammogram on ___,
which demonstrated 1.7-cm breast mass.  
-Targeted ultrasound demonstrated at the 12 o'clock position, 5
cm from the nipple, 1.7 cm x 1.3 cm microlobulated hypoechoic
mass with peripheral vascularity, highly suspicious for
malignancy.  On the same day, the patient underwent left breast
ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy of the mass in the left
breast, which revealed a 5-mm grade 3 invasive ductal carcinoma. 

Immunohistochemical stains were positive for the estrogen and
progesterone receptor and positive for HER-2/neu by FISH with a
ratio of 9.3.  
-Left breast partial mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy,
which was performed on ___ by Dr. ___.  
-Pathology demonstrated a 1.2-cm grade 3 invasive ductal
carcinoma represented as a single focus of disease.  High-grade
ductal carcinoma in situ was present with focal necrosis.  There
was no LVI or extensive intraductal component.  There was no
LCIS.  The closest margin of the invasive carcinoma was more 
than
5 mm and for DCIS 1 mm from the anterior margin.  Two sentinel
lymph nodes were excised, neither of which contained metastatic
disease.  
-Cycle 1 dose dense AC ___  
- ___ C2 DDAC 
- ___ C3 DDAC 
- ___ C4 DDAC 
- ___ C1D1 Taxol/ Herceptin (loading dose) 
- ___ C1D8 Taxol/ Herceptin  

OTHER PMH: 
1) Breast CA as above
2) Hepatitis B carrier state (hep B e-antigen negative, hep B
e-antibody positive) since ___.  The patient has had negative
AFP and normal LFTs.  She is followed by ___, but does 
not
have a hepatologist.
3)  Gastritis seen on EGD, ___, performed by Dr.
___.  Biopsies of the gastric body and antrum revealed
chemical-type gastropathy and focal intestinal metaplasia.
4)  Osteopenia.
5)  History of knee pain.

Upper dermal neutrophilic infiltrate with extensive

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is an ___ year old man with extensive cardiac history now 
presents with diffuse petechial/purpuric rash.
.
# Rash:  Visually appears as a hypersensitivity vasculitis, 
possibly from recent bactrim use.  His other medications were 
reviewed without finding other possible culprit medication.
He clinically appeared well aside from the rash, was non-toxic 
appearing, stable vitals signs, stable renal and liver function 
and other laboratory values.
ESR was measured at 40, CRP was measured at 31, C3 was measured 
at 100, and C4 was measured at 19.
Dermatology was consulted and performed a skin biopsy.  Their 
note is attached to below.  Final biopsy results were pending at 
discharge, but preliminary results were consistent with a 
hypersensitivity reaction (not convincing for vasculitis).  They 
recommended triamcinalone ointment 0.1% to affected areas daily, 
under occlusion (seran wrap) for one hour as well as colchicine 
0.6 mg po BID until seen in follow up next week.  A follow up 
appt needs to be arranged within one week.  The family was 
notified of how to make the appointment (as he was discharged on 
___ and the office was not available for appointments at the 
time of discharge).  
.
Dermatology consult note ___ by Drs. ___.
"Assessment/Plan:
___ with MMPs presents with 3 weeks of a progressive purpuric
rash that is clinically consistent with a leukocytoclastic
vasculitis (LCV). Differential diagnosis includes drug rash with
purpura ___ coumadin, but the eruption seems more florid than
this. Fortunately, his urinalysis was normal which goes against
renal involvement. Skin biopsy was performed for
clinico-pathologic correlation. Skin biopsy was performed for
clinico-pathologic correlation.
  Unfortunately, no etiology can be found for LCV in up to one
half of all cases. LCV can be associated with drugs, infection,
CTD and malignancy. The most common drugs that can cause
cutaneous vasculitis are antibiotics, particularly beta-lactam
drugs, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and diuretics. 
 Various infections may be associated with vasculitis. Upper
respiratory tract infections, particularly with beta-hemolytic
streptococci, and viral hepatitis are implicated most often.
Perhaps this rash was preceded by an infection for which he was
given Bactrim?
  Malignancy accounts for less than 1% of cases of cutaneous
vasculitis. Perhaps lymphoproliferative diseases are more 
common.
Given his new leukopenia and his weight loss, a work up 
including
SPEP and UPEP seems warranted. 
  Given the progressive nature of the rash, the fact that it is
ulcerating and the fact that it is painful, I recommend the
following:
 - f/u RUSH bx results (they should be back tomorrow)
 - check SPEP, UPEP
 - apply Bactroban ointment BID to all open areas
 - triamcinolone 0.1% cream BID to rash, avoid open areas (wrap
legs with Kerlix after treatment)
 - if biopsy consistent with vasculitis would consider systemic
treatment. Given his CHF and the fact that he is on coumadin
would avoid prednisone. Colchicine is a good option.
 - cont to list Bactrim as allergy
** at time of discharge please talk with dermatology consult
resident to arrange outpt follow up**
 
--Please arrange for suture removal in ___ days."

.
# Chronic systolic CHF:  No apparent active issues clinically.  
Continued outpatient dig, lisinopril, coumadin, metoprolol.  
Chest x-ray findings as below.
.
# Atrial Fibrillation:  Continued dig, coumadin, metoprolol.  
His INR level was subtherapeutic, so his coumadin was increased 
from 2.5mg daily to 5mg daily.  He was discharged on this 
elevated dose with instructions to moniter his INR and adjust 
his coumadin as needed for goal INR of 2 to 3.
.
# Chest x-ray findings:  Noted left sided hiatal hernia versus 
pleural effusion.  Did not pursue as would not change management 
(given his history of extensive CHF, if it is a pleural 
effusion, is likely from this, and currently is not 
symptomatic).
.
# BPH:  Continued finasteride.
.
# Code: Full
.

# Rash: Visually appears as a hypersensitivity vasculitis,
possibly from recent bactrim use. His other medications were
reviewed without finding other possible culprit medication.
He clinically appeared well aside from the rash, was non-toxic
appearing, stable vitals signs, stable renal and liver function
and other laboratory values.
ESR was measured at 40, CRP was measured at 31, C3 was measured
at 100, and C4 was measured at 19.
Dermatology was consulted and performed a skin biopsy. Their
note is attached to below. Final biopsy results were pending at
discharge, but preliminary results were consistent with a
hypersensitivity reaction (not convincing for vasculitis). They
recommended triamcinalone ointment 0.1% to affected areas daily,
under occlusion (seran wrap) for one hour as well as colchicine
0.6 mg po BID until seen in follow up next week. A follow up
appt needs to be arranged within one week. The family was
notified of how to make the appointment (as he was discharged on
___ and the office was not available for appointments at the
time of discharge).
.
Dermatology consult note ___ by Drs. ___.
"Assessment/Plan:
___ with MMPs presents with 3 weeks of a progressive purpuric
rash that is clinically consistent with a leukocytoclastic
vasculitis (LCV). Differential diagnosis includes drug rash with
purpura ___ coumadin, but the eruption seems more florid than
this. Fortunately, his urinalysis was normal which goes against
renal involvement. Skin biopsy was performed for
clinico-pathologic correlation. Skin biopsy was performed for
clinico-pathologic correlation.
Unfortunately, no etiology can be found for LCV in up to one
half of all cases. LCV can be associated with drugs, infection,
CTD and malignancy. The most common drugs that can cause
cutaneous vasculitis are antibiotics, particularly beta-lactam
drugs, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and diuretics. Various infections may be associated with vasculitis. Upper
respiratory tract infections, particularly with beta-hemolytic
streptococci, and viral hepatitis are implicated most often.
Perhaps this rash was preceded by an infection for which he was
given Bactrim?
Malignancy accounts for less than 1% of cases of cutaneous
vasculitis. Perhaps lymphoproliferative diseases are more
common.
Given his new leukopenia and his weight loss, a work up
including
SPEP and UPEP seems warranted. Given the progressive nature of the rash, the fact that it is
ulcerating and the fact that it is painful, I recommend the
following:
- f/u RUSH bx results (they should be back tomorrow)
- check SPEP, UPEP
- apply Bactroban ointment BID to all open areas
- triamcinolone 0.1% cream BID to rash, avoid open areas (wrap
legs with Kerlix after treatment)
- if biopsy consistent with vasculitis would consider systemic
treatment. Given his CHF and the fact that he is on coumadin
would avoid prednisone. Colchicine is a good option.
- cont to list Bactrim as allergy
** at time of discharge please talk with dermatology consult
resident to arrange outpt follow up**
--Please arrange for suture removal in ___ days."
.
# Chronic systolic CHF: No apparent active issues clinically.
Continued outpatient dig, lisinopril, coumadin, metoprolol.
Chest x-ray findings as below.
.
# Atrial Fibrillation: Continued dig, coumadin, metoprolol.
His INR level was subtherapeutic, so his coumadin was increased
from 2.5mg daily to 5mg daily. He was discharged on this
elevated dose with instructions to moniter his INR and adjust
his coumadin as needed for goal INR of 2 to 3.
.
# Chest x-ray findings: Noted left sided hiatal hernia versus
pleural effusion. Did not pursue as would not change management
(given his history of extensive CHF, if it is a pleural
effusion, is likely from this, and currently is not
symptomatic).
.
# BPH: Continued finasteride.
.

.

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY/ASSESSMENT: Ms. ___ is a ___ female with 
the past medical history of myeloproliferative disorder, 
Afib/flutter, dementia who presents with SOB, found to have 
pneumonia and worsening leukocytosis. 

ACUTE/ACTIVE: 

# Acute on Chronic HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE, due to 
# CAP, Atypical Pneumonia # COPD with acute exacerbation
Pt presented with 2 weeks of cough and was found to be hypoxic. 
CXR with right basilar opacity concerning for pneumonia. Sputum 
cx growing GPCs, GNRs, GPRs. Flu neg. Her respiratory viral 
sample was insufficient and could not be performed. However she 
has been improving on antibiotic therapy with overall 
improvement
in O2 requirement. Treated with levofloxacin x 5 d given PCN 
allergy. Was also on vancomycin; however, this was stopped given 
negative MRSA swab. Given persistent O2 requirement, pulm was 
consulted. CT suggestive of underlying COPD and likely explains
persistent O2 requirement in the setting of recent pulmonary 
infection. Ultimately decision made to treat with 5 days of 
azithromycin for suspected atypical pneumonia (ECG repeated and 
QTc improved to 440's). She will complete her course on ___. 
She was also discharged home with supplemental oxygen and will 
follow up with pulmonary in clinic with plan for PFTs and repeat 
imaging in the outpatient setting. 

#Orthostatic hypotension - persistent despite adequate fluid 
challenge (though overall improved since admission), minimal 
postural symptoms now so will not attempt to correct this, 
suspect chronic component to this though can't be sure.  

#Acute on chronic LEUKOCYTOSIS #Myelodysplastic Syndrome 
#Leukemoid Reaction: Given history of myeloproliferative 
disorder with worsening leukocytosis over last ___ months, 
initial concern for possible transformation to acute leukemia. 
Pt was evaluted by heme/onc and her peripheral blood smear was 
reviewed, which did not show immature WBCs on peripheral blood 
smear. Instead, smear was consistent with underlying MPN given 
increased number of mature appearing WBCs. Given this, 
leukocytosis most likely stress reaction to underlying illness 
(PNA, see below) in setting of chronic underlying MPN.
- f/u heme/onc recs, given stable leukocytosis over the 
remainder of her hospital course with interval resolution of 
bandemia, no further interventions were made in-house and she 
will follow up with hematology after discharge for further 
management and likely bone marrow biopsy. Given plans to be here 
___) until the end ___ she will need referral to our 
Heme department (her hematologist is in ___).  
- continued hydrea 500mg, increased from 3x/week to once daily 

# ANEMIA: Baseline Hgb ___, currently close to baseline. 
Macrocytosis likely related to hydrea. No evidence of hemolysis. 
Stable on discharge.

# AFIB/FLUTTER: As outpatient was on 15mg Xarelto as she had 
been on Plavix as well. Plavix was recently discontinued but 
Xarelto dose was not adjusted. Rivaroxaban dose has been 
increased here to 20 mg.
- continued rivaroxaban 20 mg daily
- continued amiodarone, back to home dose of 200mg daily
- of note, patient with bradycardia to ___ but hemodynamically 
stable (with exception of orthostatic hypotension as above). 
suspect chronic, will continue to monitor. 

CHRONIC/STABLE:
 
# DM2: Not on any home meds, diet controlled per husband. On 
___. FSBS ranged 130s-230s over the past 24 hours. Treated with 
Humalog sliding scale while in-house. 

# HLD: on home statin
# Osteoporosis: continued on home alendronate
# Dementia: continued donepezil

RESOLVED: 
# NAUSEA: Resolved.
- avoiding QTc prolonging agents given prolonged QTc
- cont tums PRN and ranitidine
- bowel regimen

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- lung nodules seen on CT scan will need follow up 
- patient has had interval progression of her MDS with worsening 
leukocytosis, she will need outpatient Bone Marrow Biopsy and 
will follow up with Hematology at ___ while in ___ for the summer
- Outpatient Pulmonary follow up has also been arranged with

Pt presented with 2 weeks of cough and was found to be hypoxic.
CXR with right basilar opacity concerning for pneumonia. Sputum
cx growing GPCs, GNRs, GPRs. Flu neg. Her respiratory viral
sample was insufficient and could not be performed. However she

in O2 requirement. Treated with levofloxacin x 5 d given PCN
allergy. Was also on vancomycin; however, this was stopped given
negative MRSA swab. Given persistent O2 requirement, pulm was
consulted. CT suggestive of underlying COPD and likely explains
persistent O2 requirement in the setting of recent pulmonary
infection. Ultimately decision made to treat with 5 days of
azithromycin for suspected atypical pneumonia (ECG repeated and
QTc improved to 440's). She will complete her course on ___.

follow up with pulmonary in clinic with plan for PFTs and repeat
imaging in the outpatient setting.

#Leukemoid Reaction: Given history of myeloproliferative
disorder with worsening leukocytosis over last ___ months,
initial concern for possible transformation to acute leukemia.

reviewed, which did not show immature WBCs on peripheral blood
smear. Instead, smear was consistent with underlying MPN given
increased number of mature appearing WBCs. Given this,
leukocytosis most likely stress reaction to underlying illness
(PNA, see below) in setting of chronic underlying MPN.
- f/u heme/onc recs, given stable leukocytosis over the
remainder of her hospital course with interval resolution of
bandemia, no further interventions were made in-house and she
will follow up with hematology after discharge for further

___) until the end ___ she will need referral to our

Patient has long-standing ILD and uses O2 at home. 10 days ago,
he began to feel increasingly unwell, developed a cough
productive of sputum, and felt that he had increased WOB,
requiring him to use his home O2 more often. For the last 
several
days, his O2 sat has dropped to the mid 80's with walking, which
is unusual for him. 4 days ago (___), he saw his CHA
pulmonologist who prescribed azithromycin. 

Within the last 48 hours, he developed such severe weakness and
difficulty breathing that he could not stand independently. His
wife also reports that he had a fever (temperature unknown) with
shaking chills last night (___), resolved with 2 tylenol. For
the last two days, his sputum has been brown/black with some
epistaxis upon blowing his nose. His wife also noted 2 large
abdominal ecchymoses one day ago but the patient is unaware of
how or when they first occurred. The patient and family report
that he has intermittently had easy bruising initially 
attributed
to his chronic prednisone, but this seems to have worsened in 
the
past several months since he started MMF.

Denies sick contacts, pain on inspiration. Endorses occasional
chest pain with cough, but no other chest pain, nausea.
Subjective fever last night, but has not taken temperature in 
the
last 10 days while sick. Due to worsening condition, referred to
ED by his pulmonologist for CT of chest and admit to medicine w/
pulm consult.

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY STATEMENT:
==================
The patient is a ___ man with history of HFpEF, severe 
MR, IOD (UIP/NSI P), A. fib on apixaban, prior CVA on 3 L of 
home oxygen presenting with 10 days of worsening dyspnea, cough, 
and increasing O2 requirement with accompanying fatigue and 
weakness.  He had pulmonary edema secondary to hypervolemia and 
was diuresed with IV Lasix with significant improvement in 
oxygen requirement.  On transition to po diuretics, oxygen 
requirement once again increased.  Repeat CT scan showed some 
worsening ground glass opacities concerning for infection versus 
ILD flare, so patient was initiated on broad-spectrum 
antibiotics as well as IV methylprednisolone.  Due to increasing 
oxygen requirement not improving with diuresis he was 
transferred to the ICU. While in the ICU he was diuresed 
extensively, continued on steroids and treated for HAP. Invasive 
cardiac testing showed no CAD and pulmonary pressures consistent 
with euvolemia. He had worsening renal failure, MSOF and hence, 
family made decision to make patient CMO on ___.

#Acute on chronic hypoxemic respiratory failure
#Acute on chronic heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
#Acute flare of chronic interstitial lung disease
#Mitral regurgitation
#Concern for pneumonia
On admission, it was determined the patient was likely suffering 
from pulmonary edema due to hypervolemia.  He was diuresed with 
IV Lasix with significant improvement in his symptoms as well as 
oxygen requirement to below baseline (0.5-1 L, ambulating 
without symptoms).  He had a small ___ bump as well as 
contraction alkalosis, so he was switched to oral diuretic with 
torsemide.  There his oxygen requirement started to worsen, and 
he was placed back on IV diuresis with Lasix as well as 
initiating vancomycin and cefepime due to worsening groundglass 
opacities seen on repeat CT scan.  CTA ruled out pulmonary 
embolus.  Given the CT findings he was also started on IV 
steroids for possible ILD flare.  On ___, he had worsening 
oxygen requirements not improving with diuresis, likely 
secondary to flash pulmonary edema from his mitral 
regurgitation.  He was transferred to the ICU for higher oxygen 
supply and close monitoring. While in the MICU he was diuresed, 
continued on steroids and treated for HAP. Given no improvement 
he was taken for invasive cardiac testing that showed no CAD and 
pulmonary pressures consistent with euvolemia. He was electively 
intubated for invasive cardiac testing but overall condition 
worsened with acute renal failure, liver failure and MSOF. He 
was made CMO on ___ after family meeting.

DEATH NOTE
==========
Paged by the patient's nurse at approximately 1200 that the 
patient had expired. He had been transitioned to comfort 
measures at approximately 1115 this morning. On exam, the 
patient demonstrated fixed and dilated pupils, absent heart and 
lung
sounds, and no withdrawal from painful stimuli. Time of death 
was called at 1208. Attending of record and patient's PCP were 
notified. Family was notified and requested autopsy.

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY STATEMENT:
==================
The patient is a ___ man with history of HFpEF, severe
MR, IOD (UIP/NSI P), A. fib on apixaban, prior CVA on 3 L of
home oxygen presenting with 10 days of worsening dyspnea, cough,
and increasing O2 requirement with accompanying fatigue and
weakness. He had pulmonary edema secondary to hypervolemia and
was diuresed with IV Lasix with significant improvement in
oxygen requirement. On transition to po diuretics, oxygen
requirement once again increased. Repeat CT scan showed some
worsening ground glass opacities concerning for infection versus
ILD flare, so patient was initiated on broad-spectrum
antibiotics as well as IV methylprednisolone. Due to increasing
oxygen requirement not improving with diuresis he was
transferred to the ICU. While in the ICU he was diuresed
extensively, continued on steroids and treated for HAP. Invasive
cardiac testing showed no CAD and pulmonary pressures consistent
with euvolemia. He had worsening renal failure, MSOF and hence,
family made decision to make patient CMO on ___.
#Acute on chronic hypoxemic respiratory failure
#Acute on chronic heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
#Acute flare of chronic interstitial lung disease
#Mitral regurgitation
#Concern for pneumonia
On admission, it was determined the patient was likely suffering
from pulmonary edema due to hypervolemia. He was diuresed with
IV Lasix with significant improvement in his symptoms as well as
oxygen requirement to below baseline (0.5-1 L, ambulating
without symptoms). He had a small ___ bump as well as
contraction alkalosis, so he was switched to oral diuretic with
torsemide. There his oxygen requirement started to worsen, and
he was placed back on IV diuresis with Lasix as well as
initiating vancomycin and cefepime due to worsening groundglass
opacities seen on repeat CT scan. CTA ruled out pulmonary
embolus. Given the CT findings he was also started on IV
steroids for possible ILD flare. On ___, he had worsening
oxygen requirements not improving with diuresis, likely
secondary to flash pulmonary edema from his mitral
regurgitation. He was transferred to the ICU for higher oxygen
supply and close monitoring. While in the MICU he was diuresed,
continued on steroids and treated for HAP. Given no improvement
he was taken for invasive cardiac testing that showed no CAD and
pulmonary pressures consistent with euvolemia. He was electively
intubated for invasive cardiac testing but overall condition
worsened with acute renal failure, liver failure and MSOF. He
was made CMO on ___ after family meeting.
DEATH NOTE
==========
Paged by the patient's nurse at approximately 1200 that the
patient had expired. He had been transitioned to comfort
measures at approximately 1115 this morning. On exam, the
patient demonstrated fixed and dilated pupils, absent heart and
lung
sounds, and no withdrawal from painful stimuli. Time of death
was called at 1208. Attending of record and patient's PCP were
notified. Family was notified and requested autopsy.

11. Mycophenolate Mofetil 1500 mg PO BID
12. Nystatin Oral Suspension 5 mL PO QID:PRN thrush
13. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY
14. PredniSONE 30 mg PO DAILY
15. Albuterol Inhaler 2 PUFF IH Q4H:PRN wheezing
16. Pyridoxine 50 mg PO DAILY
17. Sertraline 50 mg PO DAILY
18. Vesicare (solifenacin) 10 mg oral DAILY
19. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 1 TAB PO 3X/WEEK (___)
20. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO QHS

text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Anemia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
EGD
Blood transfusion
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o gentleman without any significant 
medical history who presented to the ED from his PCP's office 
for a Hgb of 6.

He was in his normal state of health until five months ago when 
he started to feel as if his 'stomach was bubbling'.  He 
attributed the sensation to excessive caffeine use, as he was 
drinking several soft and energy drinks every day.  As a result, 
he stopped drinking caffeine and experienced severe caffeine 
withdrawal headaches.  To self-treat his withdrawal headaches he 
was taking approximately 9 regular aspirin a day for about a 
week, and then continued to take numerous aspirin after that 
weeks.  

In the setting of his excessive aspirin intake, he began to 
notice dark tarry stools and increasing fatigue.  He appoximates 
that he's had about one melanic stool per day, although in the 
past few days it has been more frequent.  No other symptoms of 
diarrhea or bright red blood in his stool.  He had a couple 
episodes of nonbilious, nonbloody vomiting approximately two 
weeks ago. 

As the month progressed, he noted increasing fatigue, especially 
as his job as the ___ ___ requires a great deal of 
energy.  He notes increasing muscle weakness, a heart that 'was 
working hard' and the sensation of 'seeing bright lights' with 
exertion.  A few weeks ago, he had a episode of left arm and 
chest pain that resolved over the day, was not associated with 
exertion, and changed with movement, which the patient 
attributed to an uncomfortable sleeping position.  He also noted 
that his skin appeared more pale. 

 He initially attributed his symptoms to dehydration and thus, 
drank a great deal of gatorade and water to compensate.  When 
this did not relieve his symptoms, he visited his PCP.  Labs 
done by his primary care physician ___ ___ were notable for 
severe ___ deficiency anemia with Hg 6.0, Hct 19.9, MCV 68.3, 
Plt 446, Serum Fe 27, TIBC 479, Tfn ___ 5.6 and Transferrin 342. 
 Due to his severe anemia and suggestive symptoms, his PCP 
suggested he present to the ___ ED.  At the advice of his PCP, 
he presented to the ___ ED.

He does not report any fevers, chills, dyspnea, pain, chemical 
exposures, travel history or trauma.  

In the ED, initial vitals:  98.8 98 131/58 16 100% RA.  He had 
guiaic positive stools and GI was consulted.  They suggested an 
EGD tomorrow morning, and starting a PPI tonight.  

Vitals prior to transfer: 98.1 79 93/61 18 100%RA
 
Currently, he feels slightly fatigued, but has no other 
symptoms, including no pain, no dizziness, no lightheadedness 
and no palpitations.  He is comfortable laying in bed.
 
ROS:  
No fevers, chills, night sweats.  Has gained 3 lbs over the last 
month. 
No changes in hearing, no changes in balance. 
No cough, no shortness of breath. 
No chest pain. 
No dysuria or hematuria. 
No numbness or weakness, no focal deficits.  

 
Past Medical History:
Oral surgery when a teenager. 

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Maternal grandmother- multiple brain aneurysms
Maternal grandfather- ___ disease
Paternal grandmother- throat cancer
___ grandfather- throat and stomach cancer
Mother- ___ deficiency anemia
Father- hyperlipidemia 
Brother- ___ years old in good health 

 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM
Vitals-  98.3 106/58 78 20 100% RA
General- Alert, oriented, no acute distress  
HEENT- Sclerae anicteric/pale, MMM, oropharynx clear  
Neck- Supple, JVP at 8cm, no LAD  
Lungs- CTAB no wheezes, rales, rhonchi  
CV- RRR, Nl S1, S2, No MRG  
Abdomen- Soft, normoactive bowel sounds, NT/ND, no rebound 
tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly, liver felt 1cm below 
the rib cage. 
GU- no foley  
Ext- Warm, well perfused, 2+ radial and DP pulses, no clubbing, 
cyanosis or edema, 2x 18G IVs, one in each arm.
Neuro- CNs2-12 intact, motor function grossly normal 
Skin- Extremely pale.

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM
Vitals: 98.1 99/51(80-100/40-60s) 77(50-80s) 20 100%RA 
Exam:  
General- Alert, oriented, no acute distress  
HEENT- No conjunctiva pallor, MMM, oropharynx clear  
Neck- Supple
Lungs- CTAB no wheezes, rales, rhonchi  
CV- RRR, Nl S1, S2, No MRG  
Abdomen- Soft, normoactive bowel sounds, NT/ND, no rebound 
tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly. 
GU- no foley  
Ext- Warm, well perfused, 2+ DP pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or 
edema, 2x 18G IVs, one in each arm.
Neuro- CNs2-12 intact, motor function grossly normal 
Skin- pale.
 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:
___ 02:05PM BLOOD WBC-4.0 RBC-2.65* Hgb-5.1* Hct-20.1* 
MCV-76* MCH-19.4* MCHC-25.5* RDW-18.5* Plt ___
___ 02:05PM BLOOD Neuts-68.6 ___ Monos-6.4 Eos-0.9 
Baso-0.4
___ 02:05PM BLOOD Plt ___
___ 02:05PM BLOOD ___ PTT-30.0 ___
___ 02:05PM BLOOD Ret Man-5.2*
___ 12:25PM BLOOD Glucose-88 UreaN-16 Creat-1.1 Na-138 
K-3.7 Cl-106 HCO3-24 AnGap-12

DISCHARGE LABS:
___ 07:55AM BLOOD WBC-6.5 RBC-3.67* Hgb-8.7* Hct-28.7* 
MCV-78* MCH-23.8* MCHC-30.4* RDW-19.2* Plt ___

RELEVANT INTERIM LABS:
H.pylori negative

EGD ___
Irregular z-line (biopsy)
Mild gastritis and erosion of the antrum. This does not 
necessarily explain the patients severe anemia. (biopsy)
Normal mucosa in the whole duodenum (biopsy)
Otherwise normal EGD to third part of the duodenum

IMAGING:
CT A/P ___
IMPRESSION:  
 
1.  No imaging features to suggest small bowel lymphoma.  
 
2.  Multiple abnormal appearing segments of small bowel are 
identified, some with apparent wall thickening and other with 
fecalization as described above which may be related to 
processes such as Crohn disease. Assessment is limited given the 
static nature of CT enterography, and as the majority of enteric 
contrast was in the colon.  MR-Enterography is recommended for 
further evaluation. 

PATHOLOGY
-Upper GI biopsy pending at time of discharge

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o gentleman with approximately one 
month of melenic stools, excessive aspirin use and labs 
suggestive of ___ deficiency anemia suggestive for upper 
gastrointestinal bleeding.

ACTIVE ISSUES:
# Anemia:  He presented with lab values consistent with ___ 
deficiency anemia with Hgb of 5.1, melena history consistent 
with upper gastroinstestinal bleed.  He received 3U PRBC which 
stabilized his Hgb at 8.  GI was consulted and preformed a EGD, 
which showed no source of bleeding, but did show mild gastritis. 
 He was started on po pantoprazole. He also received a CT scan 
to evaluate for possible source of bleed in small intestine (eg, 
small intestinal lymphoma given h/o night sweats), which showed 
some changes which might be consistent with inflammatory process 
such as Crohn's disease, but no masses. H. Pylori serology and 
hemolysis labs were negative.  At the time of discharge, he was 
hemodynamically stable with a Hgb/Hct of 8.7/28.7.  He was 
recommended by GI to have an outpatient colonoscopy.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- Will need CBC rechecked at appointment with PCP to ensure 
stability
- Will need outpatient colonoscopy, and given evidence of 
changes possibly consistent with Crohn's on CT enterography, 
will need referral to GI (in Atrius system)
- Pathology from biopsy from EGD pending at time of discharge

 
Medications on Admission:
None.  Some aspirin use, as detailed in the HPI.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO BID 
RX *ferrous sulfate 325 mg (65 mg ___ 1 tablet(s) by mouth 
twice daily Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY 
RX *omeprazole 40 mg 1 capsule,delayed ___ by 
mouth daily Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
___ deficiency anemia.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure to take part in your care during your stay at 
the ___.  As you know, you were 
admitted to the hospital to receive a blood transfusion and 
investigate the cause of your anemia (low blood counts).  You 
received a Esophagogastroduodenoscopy or EGD in which a camera 
took pictures of your esophagus, stomach and the upper part of 
your small intestine.  There was no site of bleeding identified 
during the EGD.  

You also received a CT scan to look for changes in your 
intestine that might be bleeding and could also result in a low 
blood count.  The results of this test were pending at the time 
of discharge. 

We have made you an appointment with your primary doctor who you 
should ___ with so that he can help get you scheduled for 
an outpatient colonoscopy.  You may also need a capsule study 
(which looks at your small intestine), but only if the other 
tests are negative.

We wish you good health in the future.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
acetaminophen overdose 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Intubation
 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year old female with history of IVDU (clean since 
___ on maintenance methadone) who was found down on ___ in 
a pool ov emesis with ___ bottles of 
acetaminophen/diphenhydramine as well as with empty wine and 
vodka bottles.  She was discovered after she failed to show up 
for a mental health provider appointment and the police were 
called to check on her.  She was intubated in the field then 
taken to OSH where ___ Coma scale of 3. Tox screen neg for 
everything but APAP (initial APAP level was 497) & methadone. 
Initial ABG showed metabolic acidosis (pH=7.12). LFT's: AST=400 
ALT=200, normal bili, INR normal. Head CT neg. QTc of .7 so Mg 
given. She received oral NAC load.  After several hours at OSH 
pt's MS improved so she sat up and tried to remove ET tube and 
thus was extubated and able to follow commands.  
.  
She was transferred here and admitted to the SICU overnight 
given acidosis and concern she would need liver transplant.  
Major active issues have been persistent confusion, which 
improved as of this morning, as well as opiate withdrawal and 
pain prior to having her methadone restarted today.  She has

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. with acetaminophen/diphenhydramine overdose from a 
suicide attempt found down and was admitted to the hospital with 
rhabdomyolysis and acute hepatitis.  
  
1) Acetaminophen overdose: The patient was started on 
N-acetylcysteine, and her LFTs initially remained stable.  
However, on Day 3 of hospitalization, the patient's LFTs 
markedly increased with ALT peaking in the 9000s and AST in the 
8000s.  The patient's liver synthetic dysfunction also was 
impacted with her INR increasing to a peak of 4.2.  The patient 
responded to NAC therapy and IVF and by the time of discharge 
her LFTs had been downtrending significantly.  Her INR was 1.7 
on ___ (Day 7 of hospitalization) and her NAC was 
discontinued.  

2) Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury: The patient developed 
acute kidney injury with creatinine elevating to a peak of 2.5.  
The patient was placed on IV fluids and by the time of 
discharge, her creatinine had improved to baseline at 0.7.  Her 
CK peaked at 9667 but was in the 100s at discharge.

3) Suicide attempt: The patient's attempt was determined to be a 
serious attempt with low chance of rescue and premeditation.  
Psychiatry evaluated the patient and felt that she was a danger 
to herself and a ___ form was initiated.  She was kept 
under 24 hour 1:1 monitoring.

4) Urinary tract infection: The patient developed a fever on Day 
5 of her admission and was found to have a urinary tract 
infection by E-coli.  The patient was started on ciprofloxacin 
for a ___) Anemia: The patient's hematocrit dropped from 45 to 24.6 in 
the setting of large volume IV fluids. The patient endorsed 
having a bowel movement with blood; this was evaluated by 
flexible sigmoidoscopy, and the patient was noted to have 
hemorrhoids. A repeat hematocrit was performed on the same day 
of the bowel movement which contained blood, and showed a stable 
hematocrit at the time of discharge. Iron studies did not show 
an iron deficiency anemia, and a reticulocyte index was low; it 
was thought that the damage sustained to the kidneys may have 
temporarily decreased the amount of Erythropoietin produced, but 
that with further kidney recovery, the hematocrit would also 
improve.

6) Respiratory distress: The patient developed mild pulmonary 
edema and tachypnea during her hospitalization secondary to IV 
fluids for her acute kidney injury.  This had resolved by the 
time of discharge with the aid of PO Furosemide.

7) History of hepatitis C: Patient's viral load on this 
admission zero, therefore she had cleared her hep C.

8) Substance abuse: The patient came in on 75mg methadone daily 
for history of IVDU; this was decreased to 45mg in the setting 
of liver failure, but had been returned to her home dose by time 
of discharge.

9) Code: Full
 
Medications on Admission:
methadone 75 mg daily

 
Discharge Medications:
1. methadone 10 mg Tablet Sig: 7.5 Tablets PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. ondansetron 4 mg Tablet, Rapid Dissolve Sig: One (1) Tablet, 
Rapid Dissolve PO every eight (8) hours as needed for nausea.  
3. omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: Two (2) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
4. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
5. prochlorperazine maleate 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for nausea.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acetaminophen overdose
Rhabdomyelysis
Acute kidney injury
Urinary tract infection

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital because you overdosed on 
benadryl and tylenol.  This caused massive liver injury and you 
were given the antidote to tylenol.  With treatment, your liver 
slowly improved.  Your kidneys also were damaged at the same 
time, but this resolved as well.  You also had a urinary tract 
infection which were treated with antibiotics.

You were seen by our psychiatrists who were concerned about this 
being a suicide attempt.  You are being discharged to a 
psychiatric facility to help manage your depression.

You have had the following changes to your medication:
START zofran - 4mg every 8 hours as needed for nausea
START prochlopherazine 10mg every 8 hours as needed for nausea
START omeprazole 40mg daily

 
Followup Instructions:
___

CXR: Cardiomegaly and findings suggesting mild pulmonary 
vascular 
hypertension; otherwise unremarkable. 

STRESS: No anginal type symptoms or ischemic EKG changes. 
Nuclear 
report sent separately. 

PERFUSION: 1. Normal myocardial perfusion. 2. Normal left 
ventricular size 
and function with preserved LVEF of 59%. 

ECHO: Suboptimal image quality due to body habitus. Left 
ventricular systolic function is probably normal, a focal wall 
motion abnormality cannot be excluded. Probable diastolic 
dysfunction. The right ventricle is not well seen but appears 
dilated with mild hypokinesis. Mild mitral regurgitation. 
Moderate tricuspid regurgitation with moderate elevation of 
pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with diastolic CHF, HTN, DLP, h/o CVA/TIA, DM, COPD, and 
morbid obesity presenting with lightheadedness and jaw pain and 
new onset atrial fibrillation.  
  
ACUTE ISSUES:
# Arm/Jaw Pain: History was concerning for unstable angina so 
patient was started on heparin gtt the evening of admission 
while ruled out for ACS. Troponins neg x 3. EKG showed new onset 
afib but no evidence of ischemia compared to priors. Nuclear 
stress showed normal cardiac perfusion, no ischemic EKG changes, 
and no anginal symptoms.  TTE was suboptimal due to body habitus 
but was significant for probable diastolic dysfunction, RV 
dilation with mild hypokinesis, moderate TR, and moderate 
pulmonary HTN.  Unsure what cause of patient's jaw pain is, but 
it does not appear to be cardiac in nature. However, the RV 
dilatation and pulm HTN are suggestive of possible sleep apnea, 
so the attending recommended sleep study as an outpatient for 
further evaluation.  
  
# Atrial Fibrillation: The patient was found to be in new onset 
atrial fibrillation. She was asymptomatic at the time of 
admission but reports history of lightheadedness on minimal 
exertion which may be related to afib with RVR.  She was placed 
on a heparin gtt given her CHADS2 score of ___.  TTE and stress 
test results as above.  TSH within normal limits. No evidence of 
infection. patient was started on metoprolol for rate control 
and it was titrated up to metoprolol succinate 75mg po daily at 
the time of discharge. She was started on coumadin and bridged 
with lovenox 1mg/kg BID due to her high chads2 score and heparin 
drip was stopped prior to this.  Her aggrenox was stopped and 
she was continued on baby aspirin only. She will continue 
anticoagulation with plan for possible DC cardioversion in ___ 
weeks.
  
CHRONIC ISSUES:
# Diastolic CHF: The patient appeared to be near euvolemia 
throughout admission. continued her on home lasix 20 mg daily  
# Diabetes: Held Metformin and Glimepiride while in house and 
used SSI. restarted home meds on discharge.
# Hypertension: continued home Losartan  
# Dyslipidemia: Converted home Pravastatin statin to high dose 
Atorvastatin 80 mg daily while in house during ___.  Switched 
pt back to home pravastatin on discharge.
# Osteoporosis: Continued Vitamin D/Calcium per home regimen.
# GERD: Continued home Omeprazole, Ranitidine
# COPD: No evidence of acute exacerbation. Continued home 
Albuterol, Fluticasone inhalers
# Depression: Continued home Citalopram 30 mg daily.  
  
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
1. Please consider sleep study to rule out sleep apnea (pt has 
dilated right ventricle on echo and pulmonary hypertension).
2. INR check on ___ and titrate warfarin as needed.
3. Stop lovenox once warfarin therapeutic.
4. Consider cardioversion for afib after ___ weeks of 
anticoagulation.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Atrial Fibrillation

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You came to the hospital because you were having light 
headedness and shortness of breath.  You also were having 
intermittant jaw pain.  You were found to have an irregular 
heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation.  You were started on a 
medication to help slow down your heart (Metoprolol) and you 
will need to continue to take this.  Patients with atrial 
fibrillation have a higher risk of developing a stroke.  You 
were started on a new blood thinner called Warfarin to decrease 
the risk of having a stroke.  You will need to also take the 
injection blood thinner (Enoxaparin AKA "Lovenox") for a few 
days until the warfarin levels are right.  You were taught how 
to give yourself these injections.

In addition, you had a stress test to see if your jaw pain was 
from angina (decreased blood flow to the heart).  Your stress 
test did not show any evidence of this, so we think your jaw 
pain was not from your heart.

We have made a few other changes to your medications:
**Stop Aggrenox (Dipyridamole)
**Begin taking a baby aspirin 81 mg daily
** Start Warfarin 5 mg a day (this may need to be adjusted based 
on the level in your blood)
** Start Enoxaparin (Lovenox) injections until your INR level is 
between ___
** Start Metoprolol XL 75 mg once a day

Please continue to take the rest of your medications as 
prescribed
Please follow up with your primary care doctor and your 
cardiologist (see appointments below).

You will need to have your blood drawn by your home nurse ___ 
level). Please have the results faxed to your primary care 
doctor ___ number ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

alcoholic cirrhosis (compensated), who presents as a transfer 
from ___ with concern for seizure in the setting of alcohol 
withdrawal.

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS: 
====================== 
# EtOH use disorder 
# EtOH withdrawal
# Seizure: 
Patient presented with episode of loss of consciousness after 
abrupt decrease in alcohol consumption. S/p 15 mg/kg 
phenobarbital load on ___, self-tapering. Intermittently 
required benzodiazepines, clonidine, and quetiapine post 
phenobarbital load. Started MVI, folic acid, and high dose 
thiamine repletion (D1 = ___. SW consulted for alcohol 
cessation resources. Started Naltrexone 50 mg PO DAILY started 
for EtOH cravings. 

# EtOH cirrhosis: 
Per ___ Atrius records, patient visited GI and was diagnosed 
with compensated alcoholic cirrhosis. Evidence of synthetic 
dysfunction with elevated INR, thrombocytopenia. Currently no 
sign of decompensation (ascites, HE, bleed,
infection). RUQUS showed e/o steatosis, but cannot exclude 
cirrhosis. 

# UTI
Patient noted dysuria and foul-smelling urine. UCx from BI-M 
growing E.coli ___ to nitrofurantoin). S/p one dose of 
ceftriaxone in ED. Nitrofurantoin ___ for total 3 day 
course. 

#Generalized anxiety disorder
Patient describes significant worry about many things in her 
life (her health issues, dentist, living situation, etc.). This 
is sometimes a trigger for alcohol use. Started sertraline 25 mg 
daily. 

CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS: 
======================== 
# Psoriasis 
Held ammonium lactate 12 % topical DAILY. Started Clobetasol 
Propionate 0.05% Ointment 1 Appl TP BID 

# Diabetes
HbA1c 6.3. ISS while inpatient. 

# Hypertension
Lisinopril 10 mg daily while inpatient (home benazepril 10 mg 
oral DAILY not formulary) 

# Neuropathy
Increased gabapentin to 300 mg PO BID and 600 QHS given 
persistent pain and paresethesia. 

# Lower extremity edema
Home Furosemide 40 mg PO DAILY

# GERD
Continue Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 

# CONTACT: Room ___, ___

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
[]Patient has evidence of cirrhosis. Please continue to 
emphasize the importance of alcohol cessation. 
[]Started naltrexone to help with alcohol cravings 
[]Please ensure Hepatology follow up for fibroscan and 
management of likely cirrhosis. 
[]Patient describes significant generalized anxiety. Started 
sertraline 25 mg daily. Please monitor anxiety and titrate 
sertraline. Consider psychiatry follow up for anxiety and 
substance use. 
[]Started betamethasone Ointment for psoriasis.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You came into the hospital because you had a seizure in the 
setting of alcohol withdrawal. You were given medicines to help 
with the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal. You were started on a 
medication to help prevent alcohol craving (naltrexone) and a 
medication for anxiety (sertraline). 

When you leave the hospital you should:
- Take all of your medications as prescribed.
- Attend all clinic appointments.
- It is very important that you attempt to stop drinking 
alcohol. If you continue to drink, you may continue to have 
seizures and your liver will continue to get worse, which can 
lead to death.
- You should see a liver specialist for your liver cirrhosis. 
Please call to make an appointment (___) 

It was a pleasure taking care of you, 
Your ___ Care Team

Brief Hospital Course:
Hospitalization Summary (ED Admit)
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have right ankle fracture and was admitted to the orthopedic 
surgery service. The patient was taken to the operating room on 
___ for a right ankle ORIF, which the patient tolerated well. 
For full details of the procedure please see the separately 
dictated operative report. The patient was taken from the OR to 
the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery 
from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was 
initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and 
progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The 
patient was given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation 
per routine. The patient's home medications were continued 
throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who 
determined that discharge to home with ___ for ___ was 
appropriate. The ___ hospital course was otherwise 
unremarkable.

Discharge Diagnosis:
right ankle fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid 

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- nonweightbearing right lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take lovenox daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:
- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling

to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener
(colace) to prevent this side effect.
ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take lovenox daily for 4 weeks
WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.

visibly soaked or falling off.

___ year old gentleman with cardiomyopathy, LVEF 25%, prior CABG 
and atrial fibrillation who was admitted to ___

outside hospital, he was hypoxic with SaO2 at 70-88%% on 6 L.  
He was treated with lasix IV, NTP, enalaprilat, and biPAP with 
improvement in dyspnea.  After he improved clinically he

while sleeping, with pauses ___ seconds in atrial fibrillation.  
He reports that he had two unsuccessful cardioversion attempts 
within the past month due to atrial fibrillation.  Due to the 
ongoing rhythm disturbances, he was transfered for further 
cardiac evaluation.

aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good 
leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic 
regurgitation. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen.    
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Transferred in from outside hospital with bradycardia and was 
evaluated by electrophysiology and decision was made to place 
ICD/pacer due to heart failure.  On ___ he was taken to the 
cardiac lab for placement and generator was placed however they 
were unable to advance leads. See procedure note for further 
details.  He was then referred to cardiac surgery for epicardial 
lead placement.  He underwent preoperative workup and continued 
to be treated with lasix for volume overloaded and beta blockers 
continued to be held due to slow ventricular rhythm.  On ___ he 
was brought to the operating room for epicardial lead placement 
via throacotomy.  See operative report for further details.  He 
was transferred to the intensive care unit for post operative 
management.  That evening he was weaned from sedation, awoke 
neurologically intact and was extubated without complications. 
On post operative day one he had decreased urine output with 
increased creatinine and was started on dopamine with improved 
output however creatinine continued to climb with peak 3.2, 
acute kidney injury, but then progressively decreased.  He was 
started on coumadin for anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation. 
 He remained in the intensive care unit on dopamine.  On post 
operative day 5 he was weaned off the dopamine, creatinine 
continued to improve and he was transferred to the floor.  
Physical therapy worked with him on strength and mobility.  He 
continued to progress and was ready for discharge home with 
services on ___ with creatinine back down to 1.8 and plan for 
INR check ___ with further dosing by primary care.  Additionally 
due to blood pressure he was unable to be started on carvedilol 
and valsartan.  His diuretic was stopped due to fluid balance 
negative and no evidence of overload.  Discussed with Dr 
___ to re evaluate as outpatient.

Brief Hospital Course:
Transferred in from outside hospital with bradycardia and was
evaluated by electrophysiology and decision was made to place
ICD/pacer due to heart failure. On ___ he was taken to the
cardiac lab for placement and generator was placed however they
were unable to advance leads. See procedure note for further
details. He was then referred to cardiac surgery for epicardial
lead placement. He underwent preoperative workup and continued
to be treated with lasix for volume overloaded and beta blockers
continued to be held due to slow ventricular rhythm. On ___ he
was brought to the operating room for epicardial lead placement
via throacotomy. See operative report for further details. He
was transferred to the intensive care unit for post operative
management. That evening he was weaned from sedation, awoke
neurologically intact and was extubated without complications.
On post operative day one he had decreased urine output with
increased creatinine and was started on dopamine with improved
output however creatinine continued to climb with peak 3.2,
acute kidney injury, but then progressively decreased. He was
started on coumadin for anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation. He remained in the intensive care unit on dopamine. On post
operative day 5 he was weaned off the dopamine, creatinine
continued to improve and he was transferred to the floor.
Physical therapy worked with him on strength and mobility. He
continued to progress and was ready for discharge home with
services on ___ with creatinine back down to 1.8 and plan for
INR check ___ with further dosing by primary care. Additionally
due to blood pressure he was unable to be started on carvedilol
and valsartan. His diuretic was stopped due to fluid balance
negative and no evidence of overload. Discussed with Dr
___ to re evaluate as outpatient.

.
On initial interview, patient reports she has been hearing 
voices telling her to kill and hurt herself and that her 
depression has been getting worse. She states that she is

some pills to overdose at her sister's house on ___ of 
presentation. However, she thought more about it, "put them 
down" and then prayed. Does not know what medications she was

her sister's house. States she told her sister how she was 
feeling and her sister called the ambulance. States that things

___. States she wants to be dead, and feels depressed because

sometimes sees this girl and "that's why I close my eyes so 
much". States she prays to get the voices to go away, but if 
does not work. States that they tell her to kill herself because 
"I talk back to them, so they want me dead". States she hears 
them while speaking to this writer, "they tell me not to listen 
to you, because you want to help me". 
. 
Reports getting ___ hours of sleep per night, poor appetite "I 
nibble", poor concentration, poor memory, anhedonia, and

because of the voices, but cannot elaborate. Denies episodes of 
hypomania/mania, states "I'm always depressed". Denies homicidal

patient uses drugs or not, but wouldn't be surprised. Doesn't 
believe she is a heavy drinker, "might have a few beers mixed 
with ___ Aid, but she's not a drunk." 
.
