Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old ___ woman, currently  
homeless, unemployed, reported history of schizophrenia, cocaine 
use disorder, alcohol use disorder, s/p numerous prior  
psychiatric hospitalizations and reported suicide attempt via  
cutting wrists, who presented to ___ reporting worsening 
depression and suicidal ideation with plan to overdose on  
medications.
. 
History obtained from the patient, who was a somewhat unreliable 
historian, significant for ongoing depression with auditory 
hallucinations of voices telling her to kill herself in the 
setting of medication noncompliance, significant alcohol and 
cocaine use, and homelessness. Patient also reporting poor 
sleep, poor appetite, anhedonia, feelings of homelessness. 
Mental status examination during beginning of hospitalization 
notable for a irritable woman with reactive affect, "depressed" 
mood, labile mood, suicidal ideation that intensified when 
discussing discharge options, reported auditory hallucinations 
although she did not appear to be responding to internal 
stimuli. 
. 
Diagnostically, etiology of presentation is likely 
multifactorial with significant substance use, possibly 
underlying neurocognitive deficits in the setting of years of 
substance abuse and numerous vascular risk factors, and perhaps 
underlying primary psychotic disorder all contributing. In 
addition, I cannot rule out underlying character pathology 
contributing to her presentation with chronic maladaptive coping 
mechanisms. 

#. Legal/Safety: Patient was admitted on a ___, upon 
admission, she refused to sign a CV. However, on ___, patient 
signed a CV, which was accepted. She maintained her safety 
throughout her psychiatric hospitalization on 15 minute checks. 
Although irritable at times with staff, she maintained adequate 
behavioral control and did not require physical or chemical 
restraints. 

#. Unspecified Psychotic Disorder: likely multifactorial in 
etiology as noted above
- ___ workup including lipid panel, TSH, HbA1c, B12, folate, 
RPR, and LFTs were all within normal limits. 
- Patient was encouraged to attend groups, but declined to 
attend throughout her hospitalization. 
- Although patient's did complain of some depressive symptoms, 
there seemed to be limited benefit of Zoloft and so this 
medication was not restarted in favor of targeting mood symptoms 
including irritability with a second generation antipsychotic. 
- After discussion of the risks and benefits, patient was 
initially started on Risperidone titrated to 2 mg po bid in 
addition to 1 mg po q4h prn agitation. Patient did not believe 
this medication was effective and expressed concern regarding 
the metabolic side effects of risperidone. 
- After discussion of the risks and benefits, we started Geodon 
60 mg po bid. She tolerated this medication well without side 
effects. Her mood improved during her hospitalization; her 
depression improved; her voices were lessened. She did endorse 
conditional suicidality initially when discussing discharge 
several days prior. However, after learning she could live with 
her daughter following discharge, her suicidality improved 
significantly as did her mood. At time of discharge she had been 
consistently denying suicidal ideation or thoughts of self harm 
with thought process that was notably linear, goal and future 
oriented. She was notably less irritable with her treatment team
- For complaints of insomnia, we restarted Trazodone 100 mg po 
qhs for insomnia which she tolerated well with no complaints of 
side effects 
- Of note, collateral was obtained from her outpatient treaters, 
who agreed with our above assessment and plan for patient to 
follow up with them following discharge. 
- In addition, prior medical records from hospitalizations at 
___ in ___ was obtained that revealed history and 
presentation similar to above with patient complaining of 
suicidal ideation in the setting of homelessness and cocaine 
use. 
- Patient declined to allow us to have a family meeting prior to 
discharge. However, she was amenable to referral to a ___ 
worker, who will continue to work with the patient as per 
discharge worksheet. 
.
#. Polysubstance Use Disorder: 
- Patient was encouraged to attend AA/NA during her 
hospitalization, which she mostly declined. 
- Discussed the risks and benefits of avoiding alcohol and 
illicit drug use and at time of discharge she did show some 
interest in maintaining her sobriety-- she did call numerous 
substance abuse programs, but was unable to find a match prior 
to discharge. Patient expressed interest in following up with 
her psychiatric providers regarding her substance use. 

#. Hypertension: ___ has a history of hypertension and has 
never before been on medications. During her stay, we began 
lisinopril 10 mg QD, which she tolerated well. Her blood 
pressures were labile but were maintained in the 
120s-150s/60-90s on lisinopril. She will follow up with her PCP 
for continued management.  

#. Eczema: While ___ was inpatient, her eczema flared behind 
her knees and in her elbow creases. We provided her with 
diphenhydramine 50mg BID as needed, hydrocortisone ointment BID, 
and Vaseline for moisturization. 

#. Muscle Spasm: On ___, ___ woke up with back and left 
shoulder pain after sleeping improperly on her arm. She had no 
concerning symptoms (weakness, decreased sensation) and had full 
range of motion on her left arm and shoulder. We encouraged 
stretching, heat packs, and ibuprofen as management of this 
presumed muscle spasm. She improved over several days. 

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. RisperiDONE 2 mg PO DAILY 
2. Sertraline 50 mg PO DAILY 
3. TraZODone 100 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia 
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  DiphenhydrAMINE 50 mg PO BID:PRN rash/pruritis  
2.  FoLIC Acid 1 mg PO DAILY  
3.  Hydrocortisone Oint 2.5% 1 Appl TP BID PRN Itch/irritation   

4.  Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY  
5.  Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY  
6.  Nicotine Patch 21 mg TD DAILY  
7.  Thiamine 100 mg PO DAILY  
8.  ZIPRASidone Hydrochloride 60 mg PO BID  
9.  TraZODone 100 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cocaine use disorder 
Unspecified psychotic disorder 

 
Discharge Condition:
VS:  97.9    153/100    82   18   96%RA 
A/B: Appears stated age, dressed casually with adequate hygiene 
and grooming, calm, cooperative with interviewer, good eye 
contact, no psychomotor agitation or retardation noted
S: normal rate, volume, prosody 
M: 'fine' 
A: euthymic, mood congruent, appropriate
TC: denies SI/HI, AVH 
TP: linear, goal and future oriented
C: awake, alert and oriented x3 
I/J: fair/fair 

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Please follow up with all outpatient appointments as listed - 
take this discharge paperwork to your appointments.
-Unless a limited duration is specified in the prescription, 
please continue all medications as directed until your 
prescriber tells you to stop or change.
-Please avoid abusing alcohol and any drugs--whether 
prescription drugs or illegal drugs--as this can further worsen 
your medical and psychiatric illnesses.
-Please contact your outpatient psychiatrist or other providers 
if you have any concerns.
-Please call ___ or go to your nearest emergency room if you 
feel unsafe in any way and are unable to immediately reach your 
health care providers.
It was a pleasure to have worked with you, and we wish you the 
best of health.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old ___ woman, currently
homeless, unemployed, reported history of schizophrenia, cocaine
use disorder, alcohol use disorder, s/p numerous prior
psychiatric hospitalizations and reported suicide attempt via
cutting wrists, who presented to ___ reporting worsening
depression and suicidal ideation with plan to overdose on
medications.
.
History obtained from the patient, who was a somewhat unreliable
historian, significant for ongoing depression with auditory
hallucinations of voices telling her to kill herself in the
setting of medication noncompliance, significant alcohol and
cocaine use, and homelessness. Patient also reporting poor
sleep, poor appetite, anhedonia, feelings of homelessness.
Mental status examination during beginning of hospitalization
notable for a irritable woman with reactive affect, "depressed"
mood, labile mood, suicidal ideation that intensified when
discussing discharge options, reported auditory hallucinations
although she did not appear to be responding to internal
stimuli.
.
Diagnostically, etiology of presentation is likely
multifactorial with significant substance use, possibly
underlying neurocognitive deficits in the setting of years of
substance abuse and numerous vascular risk factors, and perhaps
underlying primary psychotic disorder all contributing. In
addition, I cannot rule out underlying character pathology
contributing to her presentation with chronic maladaptive coping
mechanisms.
#. Legal/Safety: Patient was admitted on a ___, upon
admission, she refused to sign a CV. However, on ___, patient
signed a CV, which was accepted. She maintained her safety
throughout her psychiatric hospitalization on 15 minute checks.
Although irritable at times with staff, she maintained adequate
behavioral control and did not require physical or chemical
restraints.
#. Unspecified Psychotic Disorder: likely multifactorial in
etiology as noted above
- ___ workup including lipid panel, TSH, HbA1c, B12, folate,
RPR, and LFTs were all within normal limits.
- Patient was encouraged to attend groups, but declined to
attend throughout her hospitalization.
- Although patient's did complain of some depressive symptoms,
there seemed to be limited benefit of Zoloft and so this
medication was not restarted in favor of targeting mood symptoms
including irritability with a second generation antipsychotic.
- After discussion of the risks and benefits, patient was
initially started on Risperidone titrated to 2 mg po bid in
addition to 1 mg po q4h prn agitation. Patient did not believe
this medication was effective and expressed concern regarding
the metabolic side effects of risperidone.
- After discussion of the risks and benefits, we started Geodon
60 mg po bid. She tolerated this medication well without side
effects. Her mood improved during her hospitalization; her
depression improved; her voices were lessened. She did endorse
conditional suicidality initially when discussing discharge
several days prior. However, after learning she could live with
her daughter following discharge, her suicidality improved
significantly as did her mood. At time of discharge she had been
consistently denying suicidal ideation or thoughts of self harm
with thought process that was notably linear, goal and future
oriented. She was notably less irritable with her treatment team
- For complaints of insomnia, we restarted Trazodone 100 mg po
qhs for insomnia which she tolerated well with no complaints of
side effects
- Of note, collateral was obtained from her outpatient treaters,
who agreed with our above assessment and plan for patient to
follow up with them following discharge.
- In addition, prior medical records from hospitalizations at
___ in ___ was obtained that revealed history and
presentation similar to above with patient complaining of
suicidal ideation in the setting of homelessness and cocaine
use.
- Patient declined to allow us to have a family meeting prior to
discharge. However, she was amenable to referral to a ___
worker, who will continue to work with the patient as per
discharge worksheet.
.
#. Polysubstance Use Disorder:
- Patient was encouraged to attend AA/NA during her
hospitalization, which she mostly declined.
- Discussed the risks and benefits of avoiding alcohol and
illicit drug use and at time of discharge she did show some
interest in maintaining her sobriety-- she did call numerous
substance abuse programs, but was unable to find a match prior
to discharge. Patient expressed interest in following up with
her psychiatric providers regarding her substance use.
#. Hypertension: ___ has a history of hypertension and has
never before been on medications. During her stay, we began
lisinopril 10 mg QD, which she tolerated well. Her blood
pressures were labile but were maintained in the
120s-150s/60-90s on lisinopril. She will follow up with her PCP
for continued management.
#. Eczema: While ___ was inpatient, her eczema flared behind
her knees and in her elbow creases. We provided her with
diphenhydramine 50mg BID as needed, hydrocortisone ointment BID,
and Vaseline for moisturization.
#. Muscle Spasm: On ___, ___ woke up with back and left
shoulder pain after sleeping improperly on her arm. She had no
concerning symptoms (weakness, decreased sensation) and had full
range of motion on her left arm and shoulder. We encouraged
stretching, heat packs, and ibuprofen as management of this
presumed muscle spasm. She improved over several days.

Ms. ___ is a ___ female with ADD, depression,

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
[ ] Prescribed OxyContin 10mg Q8H, as well as PO Dilaudid 2mg 
Q6H:PRN (breakthrough pain), on discharge (1 week supply given 
for both medications). Please continue to assess pain in 
outpatient setting, to ensure adequate pain control.
[ ] Planned Lenalidomide schedule: continue taking daily until 
___, then stop medication for 7 days (___), resume on 
___ 

# Cancer-Related Pain
Patient presented with severe back and shoulder pain, secondary 
to known myeloma lesions throughout spine and bone marrow 
expansion, as well as side effect of chemotherapy. No 
signs/symptoms of cord compression. Pain was initially 
controlled with PO oxycodone, IV Dilaudid, standing Tylenol TID, 
and dexamethasone 20mg daily on ___. Weaned to oral regimen 
on ___. Due to persistent refractory pain, Ortho spin saw the 
patient, and recommended a repeat lumbar spine MRI to look for 
evidence of a compression fracture; no fracture was noted, and 
the MRI was otherwise stable and unchanged form her last study 
in ___ (had persistent neural-foraminal narrowing at 
L4/L5, as well as degenerative changes and heterogeneous bone 
marrow consistent with her diagnosis of multiple myeloma). On 
discharge, she was prescribed OxyContin 10mg Q8H, as well as PO 
Dilaudid 2mg Q6H:PRN (she was given a 1-week supply of both 
medications). She was maintained on a bowel regimen, and was 
having regular BMs prior to discharge. 

# Multiple Myeloma

iso poor PO intake from severe pain. Improved to baseline

on the aortic valve. No aortic valve abscess is seen. No aortic

phalanx, measuring 8 mm, with a thin sclerotic border, likely 
representing a large subchondral cyst. Additional lucency 
projects over the base of the third toe proximal phalanx however 
this is remote from the articular surface. This measures 5 mm 
and is seen on the oblique view only. Minimal degenerative

Mandible Panorex ___: Several missing teeth.  The mandible

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with a history of IVDU (heroin) and 
untreated hepatitis C who was transferred from ___ 
for further evaluation of fevers found to have multifocal 
pneumonia on CT chest and ?septic emboli in lungs and staph 
aureus in urine rising concern for more systemic process.

# Pneumonia: Patient with fevers and leukocytosis on admission. 
CXR suspicious for bibasilar opacities. CT chest obtained which 
showed diffuse ground glass opacities and more consolidative 
opacities bilaterally in posterior portions of the lungs. Likely 
related to aspiration pneumonia in setting of intoxication. Also 
question of possible septic emboli vs scarring from previous 
infection. TTE without any signs of endocarditis and TEE 
obtained which confirmed no endocarditis. He was treated with 
levofloxacin and flagyl. Additionally, MSSA covered as below 
(initially with vancomycin and changed to cefazolin). Ultimately 
narrowed to cefazolin alone and discharged off treatment after 
completing an 8 day course of antibiotics for UTI. The patient 
will need repeat chest CT in about ___ weeks to evaluate the 
lung process for stability or improvement.

# MSSA in Urine: Patient is without urinary symptoms, however is 
growing MSSA. This rasises concern for transient bacteremia 
though all blood cultures were no growth. He was initially 
treated with vancomycin which was changed to cefazolin when 
culture data returned. ID was consulted. CT abd/pelvis obtained 
that showed thickened bladder wall but no other abnormalities. 
Panorex preformed that also did not reveal a source. Ultimately 
the patient reported a previous erythematous lesion over right 
bicep from previous injection site that had resolved but 
potentially a source. Despite first negative TEE, ID recommended 
repeat imaging to increase likelihood of picking up a 
vegetation. Cardiology did not think this was appropriate. 
Cardiology input combined with the fact that the patient refused 
repeat TEE led to a repeat TEE not being performed. In addition, 
patient refused to be discharged to a state facility for IV 
antibiotics (this being the only option given IVDA and lack of 
insurance) and threatened to leave AMA if this was his discharge 
plan. Because of this, PICC line could not be inserted safely. 
Ultimately, due to low likelihood of endocarditis with negative 
TEE while blood cultures were sterile, proof of MSSA infection 
only in the urine and not in the blood, and patient's difficult 
disposition, it was decided to either discharge him on oral 
antibiotics or no antibiotics with close follow up, both of 
which were viable options. The latter was decided on (discharge 
without antibiotics) given completion of course for MSSA in the 
urine. Patient was counseled extensively on warning signs and 
knows to return with fever, sweats, chest pain or other 
concerning symptoms.

# Sternal Tenderness: Initially rising concerns for osteo. 
Likely related to trauma as per report girlfriend and EMS 
rubbing on chest. ESR/CRP negative at OSH on ___. Monitored and 
improved during course.

# Left Wrist Edema and Pain: Reports no trauma. Xray without 
injury. Plastics Hand surgery consulted and felt no 
intervention. Edema and pain improved.

# Left Foot Pain: Across MCPs. Xray showed no acute process. He 
was given 1x dose of colchicine empirically for gout with 
complete resolution of pain. There after treated with Aleve prn.

# Hepatitis C: Untreated. LFTs trending down, likely elevated in 
setting of being found down and substance abuse. Hepatitis 
serologies show not immune to hep A or hep B. Per history 
patient may have received ___ hep B injections a few years ago.
One dose of hep B and hep A vaccination given on ___.
- Transitional:
---Patient will need Hep A #2 
---Consider rechecking hep B serologies to determine immunity 
now that may have received #3 here

# Hypertension: reports remote history of taking anti-HTN 
regimen and SBPs elevated during hospitalization. He was started 
on amlodipine 5mg daily.

# Benzo Withdrawal: Patient reported symptoms of withdrawl and 
was treated with diazapam per CIWA. He was also monitored for 
heroin withdrawl but did not require treatment for this.

# Drug Abuse: SW consulted and patient interested in remaining 
sober. HIV test sent and negative.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
-Repeat CT chest in ___ weeks to evaluate for stability or 
improvement in lung lesions. If worsening may have to consider 
lung abscess and treat for prolonged course.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. This patient is not taking any preadmission medications

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Amlodipine 5 mg PO DAILY 
RX *amlodipine 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary:
- Polysubstance abuse and overdose
- Aspiration pneumonia
- Possible MSSA blood stream infection
- Acute gout
- Hypertension
- Hepatitis C

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your 
hospitalization. You were admitted with fevers and bacteria in 
your urine that was suggestive of bacteria in your blood. 
Ultrasound of your heart did not show bacteria on your heart 
valves. You were treated with antibiotics but will not require 
any after discharge. It is very important that you follow up 
with your new PCP and return to the hospital if you have any 
fevers. It is critical that you stop using drugs because this 
can result in significant infection and death.

No changes were made to your medications.

Your ___ Team
 
Followup Instructions:

.

dome, which may represent a hemangioma. No focal lesion 
identified elsewhere. The patient is status post

gallbladder fossa. A biliary stent and subhepatic drain is in 
place. Pneumobilia is present.

The pancreas enhances homogeneously. Fat stranding and fluid is 
seen surrounding the pancreas and extending into the transverse 
mesocolon consistent with history of pancreatitis. The spleen, 
adrenal glands, and kidneys are within normal limits. The 
intra-abdominal loops of large and small bowel maintain a normal 
caliber without evidence of obstruction. No free air or 
lymphadenopathy is appreciated. Small amount of free fluid 
tracks along the mesentery. The abdominal aorta maintains a 
normal contour. The celiac, SMA, and ___ are patent.

limits. No free fluid or lymphadenopathy is appreciated.

pancreatitis. The pancreas enhances homogeneously without 
evidence of necrosis.

subhepatic drain remains in place.

which may represent a hemangioma

 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year-old man s/p cholecystectomy ___ at ___ 
___ complicated by cystic duct leak, ERCP on ___ with 
sphincterotomy, placement of common bile duct stent who returns 
___ with abdominal pain and found to have post-ERCP 
pancreatitis.

1) Acute Pancreatitis
Kept NPO.  Maintained on IVF.  Given dilaudid IV for pain 
control (initially PCA, later changed to IV push).  Pancreatic 
enzymes trended down during course of hospitaliation and 
abdominal pain gradually improved, then pain and fevers 
recurred, all cx. negative, ultimately thought due to irritation 
from stent and retained stone, repeat ERCP removed both with 
improvement.  At time of d/c, eating, afebrile, cx. neg.
.
2) Trasaminitis
Associated with #1.  Also improved during course of 
hospitalization.
.
3) GERD
Continued on PPI - will take omeprazole for two weeks at d.c
.
4) Cholecystitis s/p cholecystectomy
JP drain in place with only minimal drainage.  Ultimately, this 
was removed by surgery team (after consultation with operating 
surgeon Dr. ___ when small fluid sent showed yeast in 
culture (likely contaminant/colonization of drain), as well as 
streptococcus (also felt to be colonizer) - this discussed with 
ID team and in formal consultation.
.
5) Hyperlipidemia
On Lovastatin, however this was held given acute GI issues.  
Will restart in two weeks via pcp if labs stable.
.
6) Fever/Leukocytosis
Despite therapy with Levaquin post-ERCP, the patient remained 
persistently febrile each day with elevated WBC count and 
inflammatory markers (as above).  Coverage broadened with 
addition of Flagyl.  Had repeat CT as above, which essentially 
showed active pancreatitis.  Given persistence of fevers and 
leukocytosis as well as fungus seen in JP drain, ID team 
consulted.  Felt that these findings were all due to 
pancreatitis.  Recommended stopping flagyl and stopping Levaquin 
after 7-day post-ERCP course (last dose ___.  Fevers 
ultimately resolved only after second ercp with removal of 
retained stone and stent.  
.
7) Anxiety
Was maintained on celexa.

 
Medications on Admission:
lovastatin 40mg daily
celexa 10mg daily
levoquin 750mg daily x 7 days from ERCP
omeprazole dose unknown
zofran prn
 
Discharge Medications:
No changes to above - discusssed with pt. and wife that he 
should continue omeprazole, and restart lovastatin after two 
weeks if his pcp recommends, after confirmation that his liver 
studies have returned to normal.
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Post-ERCP Pancreatitis
Cholecystitis s/p Cholecystectomy with cystic duct leak and CBD 
stone (s/p extraction and stent; and stent removal via ERCP 
times two)
Anxiety
Depression

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable, afebrile, no pain, cx. negative including c. diff times 
4 (all neg), tolerating po diet, ambulatory.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please return to the emergency room or call your primary doctor 
if you should have increased abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting, or 
high fever.

___

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were hospitalized due to symptoms of weakness on the left 
side of your body resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a 
condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to 
the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your 
body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, 
so damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply 
can result in a variety of symptoms.  

Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors include:  
 - Atrial fibrillation
 - High blood pressure
 - Mildly elevated cholesterol
  
We are changing your medications as follows:  
 - ADD aspirin 81 mg by mouth daily
 - ADD atorvastatin 40 mg by mouth in the evening

Your aspirin will be changed to a blood thinning medication 
(rivaroxaban) a few days after leaving the hospital. Please take 
your other medications as prescribed.

as listed below.

scans revealed stable right MCA infarct with two small foci of
hemorrhage, near complete effacement of right lateral ventricle
anterior horn. MRI ___ showed multiple ischemic infarcts in the
right basal ganglia, right temporal lobe, left posterior
temporal lobe, and bilateral right>L cerebellum. Given multiple
areas of ischemia on imaging, history of atrial fibrillation and
subtherapeutic INR on admission, strokes felt to be
cardioembolic in origin. Accordingly, to improve adherence,
favor switching anticoagulation to rivaroxaban following
discharge. High-intensity statin therapy also initiated for LDL
of 73.

repeat swallow study, and recommendation was made for close SLP
follow-up after discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were hospitalized due to symptoms of weakness on the left
side of your body resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a
condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to
the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your
body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body,
so damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply
can result in a variety of symptoms.
Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke.
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk
factors. Your risk factors include: - Atrial fibrillation
- High blood pressure
- Mildly elevated cholesterol
We are changing your medications as follows: - ADD aspirin 81 mg by mouth daily
- ADD atorvastatin 40 mg by mouth in the evening
Your aspirin will be changed to a blood thinning medication
(rivaroxaban) a few days after leaving the hospital. Please take
your other medications as prescribed.
Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician
as listed below.
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur,
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of
these symptoms: - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to
you - Sudden weakness of one side of the body - Sudden drooping of one side of the face - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body

Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with a history of migraines,

first started 1 week ago. 1 week ago he developed a left sided, 
piercing headache associated with aura of seeing black spots, 
photophobia and nausea. This is different than his typical 
migraines, which he describes as bilateral and improved with ice 
packs and excedrin. Over the next few days, the headaches 
persisted and he developed nausea, nonbloody diarrhea, emesisx1, 
subjective fever and chills, diffuse myalgias and arthalgias, 
and neck stiffness. Symptoms persisted until yesterday, when he 
had an appt with his PCP. Per pt, he was afebrile at his PCPs, 
given ___ shot of toradol, his headache greatly improved. Then 
later in the evening he developed a temp of 101.7, vertigo, and 
felt hearing "go out" in his right ear. 

He experienced no mental status changes, no focal neurologic 
changes, no loss of consciousness. No new rashes. He has had no 
recent travel, but reports hiking/running through wooded areas. 
He has seen no ticks on him or his dog, and has never had a tick 
borne illness in the past. He has had no penile, anus, or oral 
lesions, and no history of HSV. Last negative HIV test was ___ 
year ago.

block.

Patient was given: 1 g vancomycin, 2 g ceftriaxone, and 
acyclovir was ordered but does not appear to have been given. He 
was given toradol, zofran, reglan, and 2 L NS.

has some neck stiffness, myalgias and arthralgias, although all

IMAGING AND DIAGNOSTICS
====================================
___ ECG:
Normal sinus rhythm. Tracing is within normal limits. No 
previous tracing
available for comparison.

___ CXR:
IMPRESSION: 
No acute cardiopulmonary abnormality.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with no significant past 
medical history, who presents with symptomatology and CSF 
consistent with acute meningitis.

Mr. ___ presented with five days of headache, photophobia, 
myalgias, nausea, vomiting, and two days of fevers and chills, 
no rashes or skin lesions. He presented to the ED, and a lumbar 
puncture was done, he was given vancomycin, ceftriaxone, 
acyclovir. The patient's symptoms and CSF were consistent with 
acute meningitis, viral vs lyme. Team was not concerned for 
other bacterial causes as CSF was not consistent with that 
(glucose normal, neg gram stain, primary lymphocytes). TB was 
not a concern because patient was low risk, had no cough, no 
night sweats. Team was also not concerned for foreign associated 
diseases, as patient did not have any recent travels. He had not 
had any drug-exposure to suggest drug-induced meningitis. For 
this reason, patient was only continued on ceftriaxone and 
acyclovir. Headaches were controlled with toradol and nausea 
with zofran. In addition, encephalitis was lower on the 
differential because the patient was mentating well and had no 
neurological changes or deficits. 

HIV, HSV 1 and 2, Lyme, and enterovirus returned negative. The 
patient improved with supportive treatment. He was diagnosed 
with viral meningitis, as viral meningitis may often not grow 
anything in the CSF and treatment is supportive therapy.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
#FULL CODE
#CONTACT: ___, partner, ___ ___, 
___
# PAtient to follow up with PCP in one week
# Patient d/ced in stable condition with no focal neurological 
deficits. He was instructed to return to ED or call PCP if his 
symptoms worsened, he had worsening headaches, blurry vision, 
any fevers or chills 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS
Acute viral meningitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization 
at ___. You were admitted with 
symptoms and laboratory tests concerning for meningitis. From 
your symptoms and the results of your lumbar puncture, the cause 
is likely a virus. While you were hospitalized, we treated you 
with an antibiotic and antiviral to cover for different bacteria 
and viruses until the official results came back. You improved, 
and further antibiotic and antiviral treatment were no longer 
needed.

Please drinks lots of fluids and take tylenol as needed (no more 
than 3000 mg a day) for your symptoms. Try to avoid NSAIDS until 
your symptoms resolve (motrin, advil, ibuprofen).

If your symptoms return, worsen, or you notice any changes in 
your mental status or function, please seek medical attention 
immediately.

We wish you the best of luck in your health!

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

IMAGING AND DIAGNOSTICS
====================================
___ ECG:
Normal sinus rhythm. Tracing is within normal limits. No
previous tracing
available for comparison.
___ CXR:
IMPRESSION:
No acute cardiopulmonary abnormality.
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with no significant past
medical history, who presents with symptomatology and CSF
consistent with acute meningitis.
Mr. ___ presented with five days of headache, photophobia,
myalgias, nausea, vomiting, and two days of fevers and chills,
no rashes or skin lesions. He presented to the ED, and a lumbar
puncture was done, he was given vancomycin, ceftriaxone,
acyclovir. The patient's symptoms and CSF were consistent with
acute meningitis, viral vs lyme. Team was not concerned for
other bacterial causes as CSF was not consistent with that
(glucose normal, neg gram stain, primary lymphocytes). TB was
not a concern because patient was low risk, had no cough, no
night sweats. Team was also not concerned for foreign associated
diseases, as patient did not have any recent travels. He had not
had any drug-exposure to suggest drug-induced meningitis. For
this reason, patient was only continued on ceftriaxone and
acyclovir. Headaches were controlled with toradol and nausea
with zofran. In addition, encephalitis was lower on the
differential because the patient was mentating well and had no
neurological changes or deficits.
HIV, HSV 1 and 2, Lyme, and enterovirus returned negative. The
patient improved with supportive treatment. He was diagnosed
with viral meningitis, as viral meningitis may often not grow
anything in the CSF and treatment is supportive therapy.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
#FULL CODE
#CONTACT: ___, partner, ___ ___,
___
# PAtient to follow up with PCP in one week
# Patient d/ced in stable condition with no focal neurological
deficits. He was instructed to return to ED or call PCP if his
symptoms worsened, he had worsening headaches, blurry vision,
any fevers or chills
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY
Discharge Medications:
1. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS
Acute viral meningitis
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization
at ___. You were admitted with
symptoms and laboratory tests concerning for meningitis. From
your symptoms and the results of your lumbar puncture, the cause
is likely a virus. While you were hospitalized, we treated you
with an antibiotic and antiviral to cover for different bacteria
and viruses until the official results came back. You improved,
and further antibiotic and antiviral treatment were no longer
needed.
Please drinks lots of fluids and take tylenol as needed (no more
than 3000 mg a day) for your symptoms. Try to avoid NSAIDS until
your symptoms resolve (motrin, advil, ibuprofen).
If your symptoms return, worsen, or you notice any changes in
your mental status or function, please seek medical attention
immediately.
We wish you the best of luck in your health!
Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
CT contrast
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal distension and abnormal LFTs 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Therapeutic paracentesis, ___
Percutaneous liver biopsy, ___ 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M w/ hx of bipolar disorder, polysubstance abuse (EtOH, 
cocaine, heroin) referred by his gastroenterologist for new 
onset ascites in the setting of worsening LFTs.

Although he has a longstanding history of EtOH use (pint daily x 
___ years) and IV drug use (heroin), he was relatively well and 
without known liver disease until seven months ago.  In ___ 
he developed severe fatigue; labs drawn by his PCP showed an 
acute, ALT-predominant transaminitis (AST 1188/ALT 1888; LFTs 
normal as of one month prior, ___ and he was found to have 
hepatitis C with a VL of 12 million (per his report, prior 
testing had found him Hep C negative; Hep B and A both negative 
on OSH labs).  Further workup included testing for underlying 
causes of liver disease and was notable primarily for markedly 
elevated Fe indices (ferritin 15,223, Fe 267, TIBC 2168; ___ 
with HFA heterozygosity and screening ___ negative. His LFTs 
continued to deterioriate, peaking in ___ with transaminases 
of AST 967/ ALT 1435, TBili 7.7 (although w/ relatively 
preserved synthetic function - INR ~1.4 - and without 
encephalopathy.  

He came to ___ for outpatient consultation with Dr. ___ in 
___, at which time his LFTs were slowly downtrending but he 
continued to suffer from severe fatigue.  The impression was one 
of multifactorial liver disease: acute hepatitis C superimposed 
on presumed chronic alcoholic liver disease w/ likely 
contribution from Fe-deposition related disease. Expedited 
evaluation as an inpatient was recommended, which he declined at 
that time.  He underwent liver biopsy to elucidate both acute 
and chronic causes of liver injury on ___ this showed 
mild-moderated lymphocytic infiltrate, the absence of overt 
fibrosis and mild Fe deposition and was interpreted as being 
consistent with acute viral hepatitis.  

In subsequent months his LFTs were followed by his local 
gastroenterologist and trended toward normalization, nadiring at 
transaminases in the 300s one month ago (mid ___.  He now 
presents at the urging of his GI doctor as labs drawn yesterday 
showed recurrence of hepatitis with transaminases in the 1000s.  
This is in the setting of 8lb weight gain in the past week with 
increased abdominal distension.

On my interview, he is without acute complaints save the rapid 
onset of abdominal distension. He is on a steady home medication 
regimen including anti-epileptics and anti-depressants but 
denies and new medications, changes to his medications, OTC meds 
or supplements.  He endorses significant fatigue without fever, 
night sweats or adenopathy.  He confirms that he has not drank 
alcohol or used drug since ___. He does not have any 
information about his family history, as he is adopted.  

 
Past Medical History:
#HCV (Dx ___
#EtOH abuse (last drink ___
#Polysubstanec abuse (heroin, crack; last use ___
#Bipolar disorder
#Seizure disorder (none in >decade)
#MI w/ stenting (___)

___
Family History:
Not known; patient is adopted.
 
Physical Exam:
DISCHARGE EXAM, ___: 
VS - AFeb, 133/77, 76, 18, 97% on RA 
Gen: overweight middle-aged M, sitting in bed in no distress
HEENT: anicteric, MMM, no OP lesions
Neck: no cervical adenopathy
Cor: systolic murmur best appreciated at LUSB
Pulm: diminished at bilateral bases; no adventitious sounds
Abd: obese, soft, non-tender, mildly distended, no appreciable 
fluid wave 
Extrem: no edema, warm 
Misc: no stigmata of chronic liver disease except spider 
angiomata on LLE
Psych: anxious-appearing 

 
Pertinent Results:
LFTs: 
___: AST 1016/ ALT 646 / AP 171 / TB 2.9
___: AST 939/ ALT 523 / AP 109 / TB 4.4 
INR: 1.5
HCV VL (___): 1,550,000 
HBsAg neg; HBsAb neg; HBcAb neg, HAV IgM neg (___)
Hep E IgG/M PENDING (___): PENDING 
CMV PCR neg, EBV PCR neg; VZV IgM neg; Adeno PCR neg; Parvo 
IgG/M PENDING 
Fe: 246 / Ferritin ___ / TIBC 272 (___)
GGT (___): 206 (nl ___
AMA: neg, Smooth: neg, ___: neg (___)
Tox (___): pan-negative 
HIV: Negative (___)
Fibrinogen (___): 223
D-dimer (___): 1,222 (nl <500)
Ascites (___): WBCs 190; 1% polys; TP 1.0 

STUDIES:
Abd U/S (___): Splenomegaly (15cm), small-mod ascite, patent 
portal vein.

PATH:
Liver Bx (___): PENDING 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M w/ hx of bipolar disorder, polysubstance abuse (EtOH, 
cocaine, heroin) presenting with new onset ascites in the 
setting of recurrent hepatitis (transaminases had nadired in the 
300s around ___ one month later he presented w/ AST 1100/ALT 
600). ___ extensive work-up was undertaken this admission, it 
revealed no definitive etiology of his acute hepatitis; his 
chronic liver disease remains similarly poorly understood, 
however both will be further characterized by the liver biopsy 
obtained ___.  

#Acute-on-chronic hepatitis:
- ___ he is known to have hepatitis C (and it is thoguht that 
acute hep C accounted for his ___ episode of acute 
hepatitis), his current hepatic inflammation is unexplained by 
either hepatitis C or his presumed alcoholic liver disease.  Of 
note, HCV VL (12million in ___ was down to 1.5 million this 
admission.
- Thorough laboratory search undertaken this admission for 
causes of acute hepatitis, ultimately unrevealing.  DDx includes 
drug-induced liver injury (on several culprit meds chronically, 
but denies recent ingestion of OTC/prescription 
meds/supplements/illicits and w/ negative tox screen), viral 
hepatitis (Hep A and B negative; Hep E pending; other viral 
studies negative), ischemic hepatitis/shock liver (for which he 
is without apparent precipitant)and autoimmune hepatitis ___ 
negative).
- Percutaneous liver biopsy obtained ___ results are pending 
at the time of discharge, but will be finalized by the time of 
his outpatient hepatology appointment next week. 
- Pt to obtain LFTs in one week; results to be faxed to Dr. ___ 
___, these are visible through the Atrius system) 

#Chronic liver disease:  It is furthermore unclear what his 
underlying liver disease is; he is at high risk for alcoholic 
liver disease by history, and HFA heterozygosity in the presence 
of another hepatotoxic disease puts him at risk for cirrhosis 
(which, if present, is not advanced or would not produce 
transaminitis of this magnitude). His current decompensation, 
with evidence of new portal hypertension as evidence by mild 
ascites and splenomegaly, is likely driven by hepatic 
inflammation (no e/o SBP or PVT).  
- Liver biopsy obtained to stage underlying liver disease; 
additionally sent for Fe quantification 
- Ascites was minimal; therapeutic paracentesis performed prior 
to liver bx drained only 1L. Discharged without diuretic on Na 
restricted diet w/ suggested fluid restriction of 2L. 

#Bipolar disorder: continued on effexor, seroquel, and 
lamotrigine at home doses 

#CAD s/p remote stent: continue home metoprolol; ASA held 
___

The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires 
futher investigation.

2. QUEtiapine Fumarate 25 mg PO QAM 
3. QUEtiapine Fumarate 100 mg PO QHS 
4. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg PO BID 
5. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
6. Venlafaxine XR 75 mg PO DAILY

5. Venlafaxine XR 75 mg PO DAILY 
6. Outpatient Lab Work
Hepatic function panel
___ 
Fax results to Dr. ___ at ___

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY 
Acute-on-chronic hepatitis 

SECONDARY
Hepatitis C
Presumed Alcohol-related Liver Disease 
History of Alcohol Abuse
History of Polysubstance Abuse
Bipolar Disorder 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental status: alert and oriented 
Ambulatory status: independent 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization 
at ___.
You were admitted to the hospital with abnormal liver tests 
(indicating liver inflammation) and because of new onset of 
swelling in your belly.  We did many blood tests in order to try 
to figure out the cause of your liver inflammation.  In 
addition, we performed a liver biopsy which will help us in 
making a diagnosis.
Unfortunately, we were not able to reach a diagnosis during the 
time you were in the hospital. Hopefully we will be able to find 
a definite diagnosis in the coming weeks as you continue to meet 
with our liver doctors. ___ we know that you have hepatitis C, 
as well as likely have some degree of liver disease from 
drinking alcohol, we are still not sure why your liver tests 
have fluctuated to very high levels over the past several 
months.  
The staff at the ___ (where you previously saw 
Dr. ___ will contact you to arrange follow-up with Dr. ___ 
___ or one of our other hepatologists.  If you do not hear from 
them by ___ morning (___), please call them at 
___.
You will continue taking the same medications that you took 
previously with one exception: please do not take aspirin for 
the next ___ (resume it on ___ morning).  
In addition to having the liver biopsy, you also had one liter 
of fluid drained from your belly on ___.  This fluid 
accumulates as a result of liver disease. In order to prevent 
fluid from building up, try to restrict your total fluid intake 
to around 2 liters daily, and limit the amount of salt in your 
diet.  
Please obtain liver function tests (prescription provided) at 
your primary care appointment next ___ 
(alternatively, obtain liver function tests one day prior to 
your appointment at the ___ so that these will be 
available for Dr. ___.  

We wish you all the best.
Sincerely,
Your ___ Phsycians   
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Thalamic ICH
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
The pt is a ___ year-old M w/ hx of HTN, HLD, CAD, COPD, and 
prior
L parietal CVA c/b residual RUE paresis and dysarthria who
presents with findings of thalamic bleed on NCHCT. 

Pt reports that earlier today he went to coffee shop to get a
snack when he began to "feel funny". He immediately vomited up
his food and drink and felt lousy. He sat inside the shop for a
period of time hoping to improve but continued to feel fatigued.
He walked outside for a breath of fresh air but ultimately 
called
EMS to be brought to OSH. While there, underwent lab w/u and
NCHCT which demonstrated a R thalamic ICH. Pt was subsequently
transferred to ___ for intervention.

Pt denies any headaches, n/v, or fatigue prior to current
episode. No associated CP, palpitations, SOB, or diaphoresis.

___ year-old M w/ hx of HTN, HLD, CAD, COPD, and prior L parietal 
CVA c/b residual RUE paresis and dysarthria who presents with 
findings of thalamic bleed on ___

#Thalamic Hemorrhage: Small thalamic hemorrhage was found on CT 
___ for which ___ was transferred. He had CTA that showed 
stable hemorrhage, extensive chronic microangiopathic disease, 
diffuse atherosclerotic disease. MRI showed hemorrhage with mild 
surrounding edema without evidence of underlying mass or lesion, 
no acute ischemic strokes but re-demonstrated extensive white 
matter changes. He was re-started on ASA 81mg given stable 
bleed. CTA also showed extensive atherosclerotic disease and he 
was re-started on his home atorvastatin 80mg. During admission 
blood pressure ranged from SBP 100s-150s on home blood pressure 
regimen, though ___ reports difficult to control BP as an 
outpatient and having very labile blood pressures in past. 
Etiology of bleed was felt to be likely hypertensive in nature 
given report of labile blood pressures. 

#Subclavian stenosis
#Aortic Aneurysm: ___ was noted to have asymmetric blood 
pressures without any chest pain, SOB, or arm pain. CTA showed 
significant left subclavian stenosis in addition to aortic 
aneurysm. We discussed findings with vascular surgery who said 
there was no urgent indication for inpatient surgery. They felt 
that ___ could follow up with vascular as an outpatient for 
evaluation of possible stenting in the future. Discussed this 
with ___ and he was in agreement. 

#HTN: ___ was continued on his home medications. Of note, he 
had very asymmetric blood pressures which likely due to 
subclavian seen on CTA for which he was referred to vascular 
surgery. 

#COPD: Continued home inhalers. 

#CKD: In review of outpatient labs, Cr baseline around 1.4. Cr 
upon admission 1.4 and trended up to 1.6, slightly above 
baseline. Stable after CTA. 

#Smoking Cessation: ___ counseled to quit smoking. He is not 
interested in quitting smoking and despite counseling about 
risks of vascular disease and recurrent ischemic strokes. 

#Social: ___ family expressed concern about ___ 
safety at home with medical needs. He was seen by social work 
and after discussion with family and ___ felt safe for 
discharge home with skilled nursing.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,  

You were hospitalized due to symptoms of nausea and vomiting and 
found to have an acute hemorrhagic stroke, or small area of 
bleeding in your brain.  The brain is the part of your body that 
controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage 
to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result 
in a variety of symptoms.  

You were found to have narrowing of the arteries to goes to your 
left arm, likely the cause of your different blood pressure 
readings in each arm. You also had an aneurysm (out pouching of 
artery) in your aorta. You will need to follow up with vascular 
surgery for this. 

Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:  
 - Hyperlipidemia 
 - Hypertension 
 - Active smoking 
 
Please take your other medications as prescribed. 
 
Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.  You will also need to follow up with Vascular 
surgery to evaluate the vascular stenosis found in your left 
arm. 

If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:  
 - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
 - Sudden weakness of one side of the body  
 - Sudden drooping of one side of the face  
 - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body 
 
 Sincerely,  
 Your ___ Neurology Team

Atherosclerotic changes of the carotid bifurcations are seen
with 50% right and 40% left narrowing of the internal carotid
arteries, by NASCET criteria.
The vertebral arteries appear normal with no evidence of
stenosis or
occlusion.
OTHER:
A small right pleural effusion is seen. Biapical emphysematous
changes are seen. The visualized portion of the thyroid gland
is within normal limits. There is no lymphadenopathy by CT size
criteria. Degenerative changes of the cervical spine are seen
IMPRESSION:
1. Unchanged right thalamic intraparenchymal hematoma with
minimal surrounding vasogenic edema. No acute large territory
infarct.
2. Extensive chronic microangiopathy changes.
3. Moderate narrowing of the cavernous ICAs secondary to
atheromatous changes with patent distal flow. Otherwise patent
circle of ___.
4. Atherosclerotic changes of the carotid bifurcations with 50%
right and 40% left narrowing of the ICAs, by NASCET criteria.
5. Patent cervical vertebral arteries.
6. Large focal fusiform aneurysm of the mid aortic arch,
measuring 3.7 cm.
7. Severe narrowing of the proximal left subclavian artery with
patent distal flow.
8. Small right pleural effusion.
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year-old M w/ hx of HTN, HLD, CAD, COPD, and prior L parietal
CVA c/b residual RUE paresis and dysarthria who presents with
findings of thalamic bleed on ___
#Thalamic Hemorrhage: Small thalamic hemorrhage was found on CT
___ for which ___ was transferred. He had CTA that showed
stable hemorrhage, extensive chronic microangiopathic disease,
diffuse atherosclerotic disease. MRI showed hemorrhage with mild
surrounding edema without evidence of underlying mass or lesion,
no acute ischemic strokes but re-demonstrated extensive white
matter changes. He was re-started on ASA 81mg given stable
bleed. CTA also showed extensive atherosclerotic disease and he
was re-started on his home atorvastatin 80mg. During admission
blood pressure ranged from SBP 100s-150s on home blood pressure
regimen, though ___ reports difficult to control BP as an
outpatient and having very labile blood pressures in past.
Etiology of bleed was felt to be likely hypertensive in nature
given report of labile blood pressures.
#Subclavian stenosis
#Aortic Aneurysm: ___ was noted to have asymmetric blood
pressures without any chest pain, SOB, or arm pain. CTA showed
significant left subclavian stenosis in addition to aortic
aneurysm. We discussed findings with vascular surgery who said
there was no urgent indication for inpatient surgery. They felt
that ___ could follow up with vascular as an outpatient for
evaluation of possible stenting in the future. Discussed this
with ___ and he was in agreement.
#HTN: ___ was continued on his home medications. Of note, he
had very asymmetric blood pressures which likely due to
subclavian seen on CTA for which he was referred to vascular
surgery.
#COPD: Continued home inhalers.
#CKD: In review of outpatient labs, Cr baseline around 1.4. Cr
upon admission 1.4 and trended up to 1.6, slightly above
baseline. Stable after CTA.
#Smoking Cessation: ___ counseled to quit smoking. He is not
interested in quitting smoking and despite counseling about
risks of vascular disease and recurrent ischemic strokes.
#Social: ___ family expressed concern about ___
safety at home with medical needs. He was seen by social work
and after discussion with family and ___ felt safe for
discharge home with skilled nursing.
Transitional Issues
====================
[]PCP: ___ follow up Cr to ensure at baseline
[]PCP: ___ discharged with ___ services at home
[]PCP: please continue to monitor blood pressure
[]Follow up with Neurology
[]Follow up with Vascular Surgery for subclavian stenosis and
aortic aneurysm

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were hospitalized due to symptoms of nausea and vomiting and
found to have an acute hemorrhagic stroke, or small area of
bleeding in your brain. The brain is the part of your body that
controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage
to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result
in a variety of symptoms.
You were found to have narrowing of the arteries to goes to your
left arm, likely the cause of your different blood pressure
readings in each arm. You also had an aneurysm (out pouching of
artery) in your aorta. You will need to follow up with vascular
surgery for this.
Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke.
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk
factors. Your risk factors are: - Hyperlipidemia - Hypertension - Active smoking
Please take your other medications as prescribed.
Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician
as listed below. You will also need to follow up with Vascular
surgery to evaluate the vascular stenosis found in your left
arm.
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur,
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of
these symptoms: - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to
you - Sudden weakness of one side of the body - Sudden drooping of one side of the face - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body Sincerely, Your ___ Neurology Team

*****TRANSITIONAL ISSUES*****
#Discharged with oral pain medications (acetaminophen and 
tramadol) as a bridge to next Remicade infusion. Patient 
instructed not to take any NSAIDs given concern for GI bleeding.

pressures

# ___ need outpatient ___ to look for source. 

___ year old female with history of ankylosing spondylitis who 
was taking NSAIDs in the setting of missing a Remicade infusion 
who presented with hypotension in the setting of melana x 1 week 
complicated by EKG changes, minimal troponin elevation, and 
acute renal failure. 

#Melana: Upon admission, her blood pressure and anticoagulant 
medications were held given concern for potential ongoing GI 
bleeding. During the stay her vital signs and CBC remained 
stable. She did not have any ongoing melena. We restarted her 
beta blocker in the hospital because she started to have 
asymptomatic atrial fibrillation with RVR. Her anticoagulation 
was restarted once it was determined she was not having a 
clinically significant, active GI bleed. We did not re-start her 
valsartan since her BP was soft, but stable, at the time of 
discharge. Aspirin continued to be held at discharge

#EKG changes: Seen by cardiology for T wave inversions in the 
setting of hypotension, troponin peaked at 0.03, likely in the 
setting of hypotension.  Recommended a non urgent stress test as 
an outpatient. 
- Outpatient p-MIBI once stable

___: Likely pre-renal,  responded to IVF and resolved at 
discharge. 

#Atrial Fibrillation: In the setting of discontinuing her beta 
blocker there was a short period of asymptomatic RVR. 
- Rate control: Toprol XL 200mg 
- Rhythm control: none
- PPX: apixaban 5mg BID

Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary diagnosis: Gastrointestinal bleeding 

Secondary diagnosis: acute kidney failure, abnormal 
electrocardiogram, atrial fibrillation, anemia, ankylosing 
spondylitis, hypothyroidism 
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You came to the hospital because your blood pressure was low.

Given your black stools, we think the source of bleeding is 
somewhere in your stomach or intestines.  This is likely given 
all of the anti-inflammatory pain medications you were taking 
recently.  

During the hospitalization your blood counts were stable and 
there were no signs or symptoms of continued active bleeding.  
You can discuss with your primary care doctor the need for 
further evaluation for this problem. 

You were also seen by cardiology because the EKG (a way to 
monitor the electrical activity of your heart) was concerning.  
They believe that this was most likely caused by the stress 
placed on your heart by the bleeding.  Please follow up with 
your outpatient cardiologist for further evaluation, which may 
include stress testing. 

Please call your rheumatologist to schedule another infusion. 

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay. 

Sincerely, 

Your ___ team 
 
Followup Instructions:

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
unresponsive
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year old female with PMHx significant for 
hypertension, migraines, IBS who had a witness syncopal event at 
home. 

 Patient's family states that she has been battling a viral 
illness for the last month. Initially she had a sinus infection 
in ___, and possibly upper respiratory infection. Per family, 
she was treated with a course of antibiotics, however, given no 
improvement, she was treated with a second course of antibiotics 
and a course of prednisone. The family is unable to comment what 
antibiotics were given, however per medication history, it 
appears to be erythromycin x 7 day course (___) followed by 
levofloxacin and seven day burst of prednisone. She was also 
treated with doxycycline ___. Per her family about two 
weeks ago she started having sore throat, nonproductive cough, 
and continued to have rhinorrhea with purulent drainage. At this 
time she developed a red rash on her cheeks bilaterally, on the 
dorsal surfaces of her arms b/l. This did improve over time. Per 
her PCP, she called her PCP ___ complaining about the itchy 
rash, and thought it was drug induced from a new medication 
valsartan, and subsequently changed to losartan. She sought 
evaluation from outpatient infectious disease clinic, and 
received diagnosis of "hand foot mouth disease". Per PCP, had 
mild leukocytosis, +EBV, +Parvo IgG. The patient's family state 
that she has had symptoms of exhaustion and fatigue, also c/o 
joint pains. Otherwise they say that she was not forthcoming 
with her symptoms, and cannot comment on urinary discomfort, 
abdominal pain or other symptoms. They do state that she had 
been having subjective fevers at home. 

 They state that the day before the event, she was feeling 
better and knitting. On the day of the event, she had a sudden 
sudden witnessed event with questional LOC at home. Bystander 
CPR for very brief period. EMS on arrival found the patient with 
a pulse, following commands, non verbal but able to squeeze 
hand; she developed irregular agonal breathing, and was 
intubated on the scene. EKG reportedly on arrival with Atrial 
fibrillation in ___. Subsequent EKG with anterior/lateral 
elevation with reciprocal changes. 

In the ED, initial vitals were:  variable lack of pulses, 
difficult to palpate BP ___- 100s SBP. Started on levophed with 
multiple phenylephrine pushes. 

EKG on arrival with STEMI V2-V5; Bedside echo c/w anterior 
STEMI, EF 30% and RWMA. 

Arterial line and CVL placed emergently in the ED. Patient taken 
directly to cath lab.

In cath lab, patient started on lidocaine and amiodarone. IABP 
placed at bedside given BPs 90/50. She had >10 VF arrests in the 
cath labs, with ROSC after cardioversion. She was started on 
dopamine and vasopressin in addition to norephinphrine. She was 
given multiple doses of sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, 
and magnesium bolus. LHC with mild disease, no intervention. RHC 
with elevated filling pressures. Patient transferred to the ICU. 
 

On arrival to the ICU, she had multiple brief episodes of VF 
arrest requiring cardioversion despite amiodarone and lidocaine 
gtt. She was given 1.25 Lopressor IV with improvement of ectopy 
and briefly on esmolol. Patient dyssynchronous on the vent -- 
required 60 mg rocuronium, sedated with fentanyl and midazolam. 
Patient started on Artic Sun for cooling protocol. CVL exchanged 
sterilely. Patient started on broad spectrum antibiotics given 
bandemia; stress dose hydrocortisone administered given 
eosinophilia and h/o steroid use. 

Given concern for RLE pallor, lack of dopplerable pulses, 
Vascular surgery assessed at bedside. No acute pathology per 
their evaluation, IV heparin if able to tolerate.

Portable CTH completed at bedside, c/f R cerebral edema 
involving MCA +/- ACA, PCA territory and midline shift. 
Neurosurgery and Neurology evaluated at bedside, consistent with 
anoxic brain injury, no intervention noted at this time. 

Met with family that endorsed the above history. PCP contacted 
overnight, verified above history, will given further details in 
AM.  Patient intubated and sedated, unable to provide history. 
 
Past Medical History:
Migraines
Hypertension
Irritable Bowel Syndrome 
GERD
Migraines
Deviated septum
Lost vision in her eyes ___ years ago at ___ -- unclear 
etiology, regained 
recurrent sinus infections 

h/o CCY
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Endorses history of multiple sclerosis 
Denies history of rheumatologic disorders 
 No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or 
sudden cardiac death.  
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  
VS:   34.5  79  97/53  18  91% 100% CMV FiO2 5 PEEP
GEN: intubated, sedated 
HEENT: No conjunctival pallor. No icterus. MMM. 
NECK: shotty anterior cervical LAD. No LAD. JVP unable to be 
appreciated. Normal carotid upstroke without bruits. No 
thyromegaly.  
CV: PMI in ___ intercostal space, mid clavicular line. 
bradycardic, regular. normal S1,S2. No murmurs, rubs, clicks, or 
gallops  
LUNGS: mechanically ventilated breath sounds.  
ABD: soft but firm, +BS. + IABP appreciated. 
EXT: Cold extremities bilaterally. LLE unable to be dopplered. 
Pale LLE. R femoral sheath in place with IABP.  
SKIN: faint maculopapular rash on dorsum of arms 
NEURO: pinpoint pupils, sluggish. Unable to complete other exam

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female with no significant PMHx presenting to the 
CCU after witnessed syncopal event, multiple episodes of VF 
arrest, now with hypoxic respiratory failure and shock of 
unknown etiology. On HD3, patient was found to have R pupil 
fixation/dilation. Repeat NCHCT was concerning for worsening of 
edema and herniation. Neurology examined patient and determined 
she had undergone a catastrophic neurological event with CT 
imaging concerning for uncal herniation and fixed dilated R 
pupil. The family including husband/HCP requested that patient 
be terminally extubated with comfort measures only. The patient 
died shortly thereafter.

# CORONARIES:  no obstructive disease 
# PUMP:  no formal TTE. Bedside echo with EF ___ gloval 
hypokinesis
# RHYTHM:  NSR

# VENTRICULAR FIBRILLATION ARREST: Patient with witnessed 
syncopal event, responded to bystander CPR. Patient required >10 
defibrillations on arrival to ___. Likely due to metabolic 
derangements. UTox negative. Cath excludes acute plaque rupture. 
Consider PE given high RHC measurements. She was cooled by 
___ Sun protocol. Started on heparin when head CT showed no 
evidence of intraparenchymal hemorrhage.
 
# SHOCK: Patient presents with two to three pressor (+neo) shock 
of unclear etiology. Likely mixed cardiogenic and distributive 
shock given bedside echocardiogram findings and septic 
physiology. Patient with high bandemia, eosinophils (Abs Eos 
880), appeared volume responsive. Pressors were discontinued 
when patient's goals of care were transitioned to comfort 
measures only.

# HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Patient with hypoxic respiratory 
failure after post-cardiac arrest. High pulmonary wedge 
pressures c/w cardiogenic cause, although cannot completely r/o 
ARDs. 

#) ST ELEVATIONS/TROPONINEMIA: Patient presented with diffuse 
STE concerning for STEMI. ___ also have diffuse PR depression, 
preceding viral prodrome c/w myopericarditis. CTH excluded SAH. 
Aortic dissection not found on cath
 
#) R MCA STROKE: Patient with R cerebral edema with complete 
effacement of sulci, L midshift. Neurosurgery and Neurology 
consulted overnight -- likely ___ to anoxic brain injury. No 
acute intervention. 3mm SDH noted per NSGY, thought to be 
artifactual. 
 
#) ACUTE SYSTOLIC DYSFUNCTION: Patient with depressed EF on 
arrival ___. Cath excluded. BNP WNL, may be falsely negative 
given CXR c/w pulmonary edema. 

# OLIGURIC RENAL FAILURE: Patient initially anuric x several 
hours. Appears to have responded to 2 L volume resuscitation 
with increased output

# INTRAABDOMINAL HYPERTENSION: Elevated bladder pressure at 15. 

# COAGULOPATHY: Likely ___ to cooling protocol. Required 1 pack 
of cryoprecipitate on admission for fibrinogen 54. High risk of 
DIC if underlying sepsis

# TRANSAMINITIS: Likely shock liver in setting of multiple VFib 
arrests. ___ also consider viral etiology v. inflammatory 
etiology

# NON-ANION GAP METABOLIC ACIDOSIS: Patient with normal osm gap; 
Nl AG despite high lactates, normal globulin gap which is 
unusual. Consider RTA -- s/p 4 amps bicarbonate overnight with 
improvement  

# HYPERGLYCEMIA: Not c/w DKA given no ketones on urinalysis. 
Initially presented in 400s, therefore now high enough to be 
considered hyperosmolar hypoketotic. Likely stress response, 
persisted in setting of stress dose steroids. She was treated 
with insulin gtt followed by sliding scale.

# THROMBOCYTOPENIA: Likely d/t reactive in setting of bone 
marrow suppression. Considered HITT, although no recent 
hospitalization or heparin exposure making this less likely. 

 CHRONIC ISSUES:  
# h/o HTN: hold antihypertensives
# ? chronic pain: gabapentin held on arrival given sedation
 
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
# decreased
# CONTACT:  ___, husband ___ ___, daughter

History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year old female with PMHx significant for
hypertension, migraines, IBS who had a witness syncopal event at
home. Patient's family states that she has been battling a viral
illness for the last month. Initially she had a sinus infection
in ___, and possibly upper respiratory infection. Per family,
she was treated with a course of antibiotics, however, given no
improvement, she was treated with a second course of antibiotics
and a course of prednisone. The family is unable to comment what
antibiotics were given, however per medication history, it
appears to be erythromycin x 7 day course (___) followed by
levofloxacin and seven day burst of prednisone. She was also
treated with doxycycline ___. Per her family about two
weeks ago she started having sore throat, nonproductive cough,
and continued to have rhinorrhea with purulent drainage. At this
time she developed a red rash on her cheeks bilaterally, on the
dorsal surfaces of her arms b/l. This did improve over time. Per
her PCP, she called her PCP ___ complaining about the itchy
rash, and thought it was drug induced from a new medication
valsartan, and subsequently changed to losartan. She sought
evaluation from outpatient infectious disease clinic, and
received diagnosis of "hand foot mouth disease". Per PCP, had
mild leukocytosis, +EBV, +Parvo IgG. The patient's family state
that she has had symptoms of exhaustion and fatigue, also c/o
joint pains. Otherwise they say that she was not forthcoming
with her symptoms, and cannot comment on urinary discomfort,
abdominal pain or other symptoms. They do state that she had
been having subjective fevers at home. They state that the day before the event, she was feeling
better and knitting. On the day of the event, she had a sudden
sudden witnessed event with questional LOC at home. Bystander
CPR for very brief period. EMS on arrival found the patient with
a pulse, following commands, non verbal but able to squeeze
hand; she developed irregular agonal breathing, and was
intubated on the scene. EKG reportedly on arrival with Atrial
fibrillation in ___. Subsequent EKG with anterior/lateral
elevation with reciprocal changes.
In the ED, initial vitals were: variable lack of pulses,
difficult to palpate BP ___- 100s SBP. Started on levophed with
multiple phenylephrine pushes.
EKG on arrival with STEMI V2-V5; Bedside echo c/w anterior
STEMI, EF 30% and RWMA.
Arterial line and CVL placed emergently in the ED. Patient taken
directly to cath lab.
In cath lab, patient started on lidocaine and amiodarone. IABP
placed at bedside given BPs 90/50. She had >10 VF arrests in the
cath labs, with ROSC after cardioversion. She was started on
dopamine and vasopressin in addition to norephinphrine. She was
given multiple doses of sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate,
and magnesium bolus. LHC with mild disease, no intervention. RHC
with elevated filling pressures. Patient transferred to the ICU.
On arrival to the ICU, she had multiple brief episodes of VF
arrest requiring cardioversion despite amiodarone and lidocaine
gtt. She was given 1.25 Lopressor IV with improvement of ectopy
and briefly on esmolol. Patient dyssynchronous on the vent --
required 60 mg rocuronium, sedated with fentanyl and midazolam.
Patient started on Artic Sun for cooling protocol. CVL exchanged
sterilely. Patient started on broad spectrum antibiotics given
bandemia; stress dose hydrocortisone administered given
eosinophilia and h/o steroid use.
Given concern for RLE pallor, lack of dopplerable pulses,
Vascular surgery assessed at bedside. No acute pathology per
their evaluation, IV heparin if able to tolerate.
Portable CTH completed at bedside, c/f R cerebral edema
involving MCA +/- ACA, PCA territory and midline shift.
Neurosurgery and Neurology evaluated at bedside, consistent with
anoxic brain injury, no intervention noted at this time.
Met with family that endorsed the above history. PCP contacted
overnight, verified above history, will given further details in
AM. Patient intubated and sedated, unable to provide history.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female with no significant PMHx presenting to the
CCU after witnessed syncopal event, multiple episodes of VF
arrest, now with hypoxic respiratory failure and shock of
unknown etiology. On HD3, patient was found to have R pupil
fixation/dilation. Repeat NCHCT was concerning for worsening of
edema and herniation. Neurology examined patient and determined
she had undergone a catastrophic neurological event with CT
imaging concerning for uncal herniation and fixed dilated R
pupil. The family including husband/HCP requested that patient
be terminally extubated with comfort measures only. The patient
died shortly thereafter.
# CORONARIES: no obstructive disease
# PUMP: no formal TTE. Bedside echo with EF ___ gloval
hypokinesis
# RHYTHM: NSR
# VENTRICULAR FIBRILLATION ARREST: Patient with witnessed
syncopal event, responded to bystander CPR. Patient required >10
defibrillations on arrival to ___. Likely due to metabolic
derangements. UTox negative. Cath excludes acute plaque rupture.
Consider PE given high RHC measurements. She was cooled by
___ Sun protocol. Started on heparin when head CT showed no
evidence of intraparenchymal hemorrhage.
# SHOCK: Patient presents with two to three pressor (+neo) shock
of unclear etiology. Likely mixed cardiogenic and distributive
shock given bedside echocardiogram findings and septic
physiology. Patient with high bandemia, eosinophils (Abs Eos
880), appeared volume responsive. Pressors were discontinued
when patient's goals of care were transitioned to comfort
measures only.
# HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Patient with hypoxic respiratory
failure after post-cardiac arrest. High pulmonary wedge
pressures c/w cardiogenic cause, although cannot completely r/o
ARDs.
#) ST ELEVATIONS/TROPONINEMIA: Patient presented with diffuse
STE concerning for STEMI. ___ also have diffuse PR depression,
preceding viral prodrome c/w myopericarditis. CTH excluded SAH.
Aortic dissection not found on cath
#) R MCA STROKE: Patient with R cerebral edema with complete
effacement of sulci, L midshift. Neurosurgery and Neurology
consulted overnight -- likely ___ to anoxic brain injury. No
acute intervention. 3mm SDH noted per NSGY, thought to be
artifactual.
#) ACUTE SYSTOLIC DYSFUNCTION: Patient with depressed EF on
arrival ___. Cath excluded. BNP WNL, may be falsely negative
given CXR c/w pulmonary edema.
# OLIGURIC RENAL FAILURE: Patient initially anuric x several
hours. Appears to have responded to 2 L volume resuscitation
with increased output
# INTRAABDOMINAL HYPERTENSION: Elevated bladder pressure at 15.
# COAGULOPATHY: Likely ___ to cooling protocol. Required 1 pack
of cryoprecipitate on admission for fibrinogen 54. High risk of
DIC if underlying sepsis
# TRANSAMINITIS: Likely shock liver in setting of multiple VFib
arrests. ___ also consider viral etiology v. inflammatory
etiology
# NON-ANION GAP METABOLIC ACIDOSIS: Patient with normal osm gap;
Nl AG despite high lactates, normal globulin gap which is
unusual. Consider RTA -- s/p 4 amps bicarbonate overnight with
improvement
# HYPERGLYCEMIA: Not c/w DKA given no ketones on urinalysis.
Initially presented in 400s, therefore now high enough to be
considered hyperosmolar hypoketotic. Likely stress response,
persisted in setting of stress dose steroids. She was treated
with insulin gtt followed by sliding scale.
# THROMBOCYTOPENIA: Likely d/t reactive in setting of bone
marrow suppression. Considered HITT, although no recent
hospitalization or heparin exposure making this less likely. CHRONIC ISSUES:
# h/o HTN: hold antihypertensives
# ? chronic pain: gabapentin held on arrival given sedation
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
# decreased
# CONTACT: ___, husband ___ ___, daughter
___

4. HydrOXYzine 25 mg PO TID
5. Acetaminophen-Caff-Butalbital ___ TAB PO Frequency is Unknown
6. Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY
