Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___               Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
___
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Fever, headache
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is an ___ year old man with history of OCD and autism 
spectrum disorder who presents as a transfer from ___ with 
2 days of fevers and headache concerning for CNS infection.

The patient originally presented to ___ with 48 hours of 
fevers and bifrontal headache. He also reported one day of 
chills, nausea and vomiting, but denied neck pain or visual 
disturbance. Of note he says that multiple people in his summer 
camp program at ___ have recently had the same 
symptoms (fevers, headache, and nausea/vomiting) which improved 
on their own. He underwent CT head at ___ as part of 
workup for meningitis which showed multiple punctate parenchymal 
hyperdensities and hypodensities suspicious for punctate 
hemorrhages and microabscesses. He was started on ceftriaxone, 
vancomycin, and flagyl. LP was deferred given concern for 
microabscesses, and he was transferred to ___ for further 
work-up and neurology/neurosurgery evaluation.

In the ED, initial vitals were: T 98.9, HR 84, BP 109/62, RR 16, 
SPO2 98% RA. While in the ED he fevered to 100.8. Exam was 
notable for a nonfocal neurologic exam and a II/VI systolic 
ejection murmur. Labs were notable for WBC 17.4 with 
neutrophilic predominance, Hgb 13.1, and CRP 39.2. Neurosurgery 
was consulted
in the ED who said no urgent or emergent NSGY intervention is 
indicated. Neurology was consulted who recommended brain MRI 
given that the superficial location of the largest parenchymal 
hyperdensity raised question of associated cortical vein 
thrombosis. MRI brain was obtained and was essentially normal 
with no hemorrhage, masses, or thrombosis. LP was performed and 
fluid studies were not consistent with meningitis. While in the 
ED he received dexamethasone 4mg IV and ceftriaxone 2gm. He was 
admitted to medicine for an infectious workup.

On arrival to the floor, he reports that his headache is 
currently barely there, and he only notices it when he sits up. 
He is not currently nauseous, and says that he only threw up 
after taking medications on an empty stomach. He denies rashes, 
dysuria or other urinary symptoms, abdominal pain, diarrhea,
congestion, coughing, or shortness of breath. He denies tick 
exposures but has been hiking in the woods recently. He denies 
recreational drug use or sexual activity. He recently traveled 
to ___ and ___.

Autism spectrum disorder

2+
bilaterally.

spontaneously. ___ strength throughout. Normal sensation.

AbsEos-0.10 AbsBaso-0.___RIEF HOSPITAL COURSE: 
==================== 
Mr. ___ is an ___ year old man with history of OCD and autism
spectrum disorder who presents as a transfer from ___ with
2 days of fevers and headache originally concerning for CNS
infection. OSH CT was initially read as cf microabscesses but
final read was updated to concerns of SAH, now with reassuring 
LP
with low RBC count without xanthochromia. Infectious workup 
negative with repeat MRI negative for any intracranial process - 
given remarkable improvement and negative workup, ultimately 
diagnosed with viral syndrome and discharged home.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
- Patient and parents notified to return to ED if any concerning 
symptoms/signs such as fever, chills, return of moderate/severe 
headache. Otherwise no follow-up required. 
- NO follow up imaging recommended from neurosurgery or 
neurology

ACUTE ISSUES:
================
# Fever
# Leukocytosis
# Headache
# Nausea and vomiting
The patient presented with 2 days of bifrontal headache and 
fevers, and one day of chills, nausea, and emesis. Labs notable 
for leukocytosis with neutrophilic predominance and bandemia. 
Head CT at ___ showed left frontal hyperdensity cf acute 
subarachnoid hemorrhage (this was initially read as cf 
microabscesses but was revised as documented above).  both 
neurology and neurosurgery were consulted and reviewed this -  
However, brain MRI here was normal, and most importantly LP was 
clear and colorless with RBCs of 80 and 17 (likely from 
hemorrhagic tap). Given low RBC count and negative MRI, ___ was 
felt unlikely by both neurology and neurosurgery and they 
recommended no further evaluation was necessary. There was 
initial concern for meningitis due to his headache and fevers, 
but this is unlikely reassuring LP, no nuchal rigidity, no AMS. 
There was no evidence of endocarditis on TTE. Blood cultures 
have had NGTD. On the day of discharge pt feels much improved 
with fevers, HA, and chills all resolved, downtrending WBC. 
Patient received dexamethasone 4mg IV in the ED and was 
continued on Ceftriaxone and Vancomycin until blood cultures 
were negative for 48h hours and patient's symptoms had resolved. 
UTI and pulm infection also unlikely without symptoms and 
negative UA/CXR. Tick-borne illness panel checked at ___ 
and was negative. 

CHRONIC/STABLE ISSUES:
======================
# OCD
# Autism spectrum disorder
- continued home buspirone
- continued home guanfacine

1. BusPIRone 15 mg PO BID 
2. guanFACINE 1 mg oral QID

1.  BusPIRone 15 mg PO BID  
2.  guanFACINE 1 mg oral QID  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Viral syndrome

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,  

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___ 
___.  

WHY WERE YOU IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- You were admitted to the hospital for fevers and headache with 
concern for an infection

WHAT HAPPENED WHEN YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- We checked your blood cultures and cell counts for infection.
- We had initially started you on antibiotics, but we were able 
to stop these once your laboratory tests all came back as 
reassuring and you were feeling better.

WHAT SHOULD YOU DO AFTER YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?  
- Continue to take all your medicines as prescribed below. 
- Show up to your appointments as listed below.
- If you develop another headache, fever or any other concerning 
symptoms PLEASE return to the ___ emergency department.

We wish you the best!  

Sincerely,  

Your ___ Team

 
Followup Instructions:
___

- Show up to your appointments as listed below.
- If you develop another headache, fever or any other concerning
symptoms PLEASE return to the ___ emergency department.
We wish you the best!
Sincerely,
Your ___ Team
Followup Instructions:
___

presented to an OSH after being found at home by family in a
disheveled manner. OSH ordered a CT head and found ICH and
subsequently sent him here for neuro-surg evaluation. 
Per report he had a series of falls lately. Family not at 
bedside
yet. I tried called emergency contact ___ at ___
and ___, both of these numbers do not work.
The patient himself states he has had falls but none today. He
does not know exactly  he is here, but states he is here " to 
get
better", to "fix my medical needs". I told him he was here
because of bleeding in his brain. He states that he had a
headache earlier but not currently, he notes no weakness or
numbness. Denies diplopia as well.

Atrial fibrillation with moderately rapid ventricular response. 
Diffuse 
non-specific ST segment abnormality. Possible left ventricular 
hypertrophy. 
No previous tracing available for comparison.  
  Intervals Axes 
Rate PR QRS QT/QTc P QRS T 
94 0 82 364/423 0 33 51 
 
CXR 1 view:
SUPINE AP VIEW OF THE CHEST: The heart size is mildly enlarged. 
The aorta is 
slightly tortuous. There is fullness of the hila bilaterally and 
there is 
mild pulmonary vascular congestion. Linear opacities within the 
right upper 
lobe may reflect scarring and chronic changes. There is likely 
mild streaky 
opacity in left lung base, reflective of atelectasis. No focal 
consolidation, 
pleural effusion, or pneumothorax is visualized. No definite 
displaced rib 
fractures are seen; however, the left lateral ribs are not 
completely included 
in the field of view. 
  
IMPRESSION: Mild pulmonary vascular congestion. Probable left 
basilar 
atelectasis and chronic changes within the right upper lobe. 

Pelvis Xray - 1 view:
AP VIEW OF THE PELVIS, TWO VIEWS OF THE RIGHT FEMUR: No definite 
fracture or 
dislocation is present. There is diffuse demineralization of the 
osseous 
structures which limits the detection for subtle fractures. The 
right leg is 
rotated, though no distinct fracture line is visible. There are 
mild 
degenerative changes in both hips with joint space narrowing. No 
diastasis of 
the pubic symphysis or sacroiliac joints is seen. There are 
diffuse vascular 
calcifications. Extensive degenerative changes are noted within 
the imaged 
aspect of the right knee with joint space narrowing, subchondral 
sclerosis and 
osteophyte formation. A moderate-sized suprapatellar joint 
effusion is also 
noted. 
  
IMPRESSION: Rotation of the right femur, but no definite 
fracture or 
dislocation. If there is continued clinical concern for an 
occult fracture, a 
CT is recommended for further evaluation. 

Femur Xray - 2view:
AP VIEW OF THE PELVIS, TWO VIEWS OF THE RIGHT FEMUR: No definite 
fracture or 
dislocation is present. There is diffuse demineralization of the 
osseous 
structures which limits the detection for subtle fractures. The 
right leg is 
rotated, though no distinct fracture line is visible. There are 
mild 
degenerative changes in both hips with joint space narrowing. No 
diastasis of

calcifications. Extensive degenerative changes are noted within 
the imaged 
aspect of the right knee with joint space narrowing, subchondral

osteophyte formation. A moderate-sized suprapatellar joint

noted. 
  
IMPRESSION: Rotation of the right femur, but no definite

CT is recommended for further evaluation. 

Hip Xray: 2 view
AP VIEW OF THE PELVIS, TWO VIEWS OF THE RIGHT FEMUR: No definite 
fracture or 
dislocation is present. There is diffuse demineralization of the 
osseous 
structures which limits the detection for subtle fractures. The 
right leg is 
rotated, though no distinct fracture line is visible. There are 
mild 
degenerative changes in both hips with joint space narrowing. No 
diastasis of

calcifications. Extensive degenerative changes are noted within 
the imaged 
aspect of the right knee with joint space narrowing, subchondral 
sclerosis and 
osteophyte formation. A moderate-sized suprapatellar joint 
effusion is also 
noted. 
  
IMPRESSION: Rotation of the right femur, but no definite 
fracture or 
dislocation. If there is continued clinical concern for an 
occult fracture, a 
CT is recommended for further evaluation. 

CT C-spine without contrast:
FINDINGS: Non-displaced fractures are present at the left 
transverse 
processes of T1 and T2 (601B:32). No acute vertebral body 
fractures are seen. 
There is a chronic wedge compression deformity of T2 (602B:36). 
Severe 
multilevel degenerative changes are seen throughout the cervical 
spine, worst 
at C3/4 and the C6/7, there is loss of intervertebral disc space 
with endplate 
sclerosis and subchondral cystic changes. Subluxation of 
multiple facets are 
compatible with severe osteoarthropathy. Included views of the 
lung apices 
demonstrate scarring and pleural calcifications, as seen on the 
prior chest 
radiograph (5:61). 
  
IMPRESSION: 
1. Non-displaced fractures of the left T1 and T2 transverse 
processes. 
2. Chronic wedge compression deformity at T2. 
3. Severe multilevel degenerative changes throughout the 
cervical spine. 

CT Head noncontrast ___:
IMPRESSION:  
  
1. Numerous bifrontal and left temporal intraparenchymal 
hematomas, unchanged 
in appearance since the 1:01 p.m. study, with new trace 
intraventricular 
extension. Findings are most compatible with traumatic contusion 
injuries. If 
the diagnosis is in doubt and amyloid angiopathy is being 
entertained as a 
potential diagnosis, then MR may be of potential value in 
further assessment.  
  
  
2. Very small subdural hygromas, not significantly changed and 
also 
supporting the probability of a traumatic etiology. 

Head Ct noncontrast ___:
IMPRESSION:  
1. Bifrontal and left temporal horn parenchymal hemorrhage, 
largely unchanged 
in distribution compared to the prior with some likely 
evolution- i.e. 
slightly increased focus of hemorrhage at left frontal lobe 
(2,20) and 
slightly less prominent foci at the left frontal lobe at the 
vertex (2, 
23)when compared to the comparable level and allowing for 
differences in 
technique. 2. Small subdural hygromas stable.  
3. Minimally increased vasogenic edema particularly at the level 
of the the 
left frontal lobe at the vertex (2, 23).  
4. Stable layering blood in the occipital horns bilaterally. 

MRI Head without contrast:
FINDINGS: Multiple foci of blood products are seen in both 
frontal lobes, 
left temporal lobe and intraventricular blood is also 
identified. There are 
bilateral small subdural collections seen extending from frontal 
to the 
occipital region with a maximum width of approximately 6 mm on 
the left and 5 
mm on the right side. There is mild indentation on the adjacent 
sulci seen. 
  
On the susceptibility images, the areas of blood products 
corresponding to the 
CT abnormality are identified. There are no additional foci seen 
to indicate 
underlying microhemorrhages. 
  
There is no mass effect or midline shift seen. Mild changes of 
small vessel 
disease are noted. 
  
IMPRESSION: Blood products in both frontal and left temporal 
region likely 
due to hemorrhagic contusions, although the locations of the 
abnormalities are 
somewhat atypical. No evidence of chronic microhemorrhages seen 
in other 
parts of the brain to suggest underlying abnormality. Small 
bilateral 
subdural collections are seen. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Neurology Service at ___ on 
___ after sustaining multiple falls with confusion. Imaging 
of his head showed several areas of hemorrhage in bifrontal and 
left temporal areas.
.
The patient was kept in the ICU for several days for close 
observation and then transferred to the floor. He was cleared 
from his c-collar medically while in the ICU. His coumadin was 
held during his stay and his goal SBP was <160. Hydralazine was 
given as necessary to keep within these parameters, although the 
patient autoregulated well during his stay. He was started on 
Keppra for seizure prophylaxis.
.
The patient also had an issue with hypernatremia and was started 
on normal saline at 70 cc/hr for treatment. He should get labs 
daily at rehab, and may need further treamtent for his 
hypernatremia.
.
One of the major issues during his stay was his mental status. 
The majority of his stay he was not oriented to person, place, 
or time. On discharge he is oriented to place and year.
.
He was not able to pass a speech and swallow evaluation until 
___ as he would not swallow, but was cleared for pureed solids 
and thin liquids with meds given crushed in puree. The patient 
should be under observation when eating. This should be 
re-evaluated at rehab to see if diet can be advanced.
. 
Once leaving rehab, the patient will need to followup with his 
PCP, ___ in reference to restarting warfarin. He was 
stopped due to intracranial hemorrhages. Having atrial 
fibrillation puts him at risk for embolic strokes. Since he has 
a history of falls, his primary care physician should assess him 
as an outpatient to evaluate the risks and benefits of 
restarting coumadin. His simvastatin and lopressor doses were 
not known, and he will not go to rehab on either medication. He 
should followup with his PCP about restarting these medications 
after rehab.
.
He will need followup with Dr. ___ on ___ and get a head 
CT one week before this appointment. He will need followup with 
his PCP, ___ one week of leaving rehab. 
 

 
Medications on Admission:
Coumadin
Lopressor
simvastatin
(unknown dosage)

 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.  
2. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed for constipation.  
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
4. insulin regular human 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: One (1)  
Injection ASDIR (AS DIRECTED).  
5. glucagon (human recombinant) 1 mg Recon Soln Sig: One (1) 
Recon Soln Injection Q15MIN () as needed for hypoglycemia 
protocol.  
6. ondansetron HCl (PF) 4 mg/2 mL Solution Sig: One (1)  
Injection Q8H (every 8 hours) as needed for nausea.  
7. dextrose 50% in water (D50W)     Syringe Sig: One (1)  
Intravenous PRN (as needed) as needed for hypoglycemia protocol. 
 
8. Keppra 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day.  
9. hydralazine 20 mg/mL Solution Sig: 0.5  Injection Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for PRN SBP >160.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
bifrontal and left temporal hemorrhages

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - sometimes.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted to the Neurology Service at ___ on ___ 
after sustaining multiple falls with confusion. Imaging of your 
head showed several areas of hemorrhage in your brain.
.
You were taking coumadin for your atrial fibrillation. This 
medication was held during your stay as it can increase 
hemorrhages in your brain. Your blood pressure was also kept 
below a certain level for treatment. 
. 
You were initially in the ICU for close monitoring, and then 
transferred to the floor once stable.
. 
You were started on keppra for seizure prophylaxis which you 
will go to rehab on and continue until your appointment with Dr. 
___ on ___. Once leaving rehab, you will need to followup 
with your PCP, ___ in reference to restarting your 
warfarin. You were stopped due to the hemorrhages in your brain. 
Having atrial fibrillation puts you at risk for blood clots 
which can cause strokes. Since you have a history of falls, your 
primary care physician should assess you as an outpatient to 
evaluate the risks and benefits of restarting coumadin. Your 
simvastatin and lopressor doses were not known, and you will not 
go to rehab on either medication. You should followup with your 
PCP about restarting these medications after rehab.
.
You were not able to pass a speech and swallow evaluation until 
___, and they then cleared you for pureed solids and thin 
liquids.
.
Please followup with Dr. ___ on ___ and get a CT scan of 
your head one week before this appointment. Please followup with 
your PCP, ___ one week of leaving rehab. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

1. Numerous bifrontal and left temporal intraparenchymal
hematomas, unchanged
in appearance since the 1:01 p.m. study, with new trace
intraventricular
extension. Findings are most compatible with traumatic contusion
injuries. If
the diagnosis is in doubt and amyloid angiopathy is being
entertained as a
potential diagnosis, then MR may be of potential value in
further assessment.
2. Very small subdural hygromas, not significantly changed and
also
supporting the probability of a traumatic etiology.
Head Ct noncontrast ___:
IMPRESSION:
1. Bifrontal and left temporal horn parenchymal hemorrhage,
largely unchanged
in distribution compared to the prior with some likely
evolution- i.e.
slightly increased focus of hemorrhage at left frontal lobe
(2,20) and
slightly less prominent foci at the left frontal lobe at the
vertex (2,
23)when compared to the comparable level and allowing for
differences in
technique. 2. Small subdural hygromas stable.
3. Minimally increased vasogenic edema particularly at the level
of the the
left frontal lobe at the vertex (2, 23).
4. Stable layering blood in the occipital horns bilaterally.
MRI Head without contrast:
FINDINGS: Multiple foci of blood products are seen in both
frontal lobes,
left temporal lobe and intraventricular blood is also
identified. There are
bilateral small subdural collections seen extending from frontal
to the
occipital region with a maximum width of approximately 6 mm on
the left and 5
mm on the right side. There is mild indentation on the adjacent
sulci seen.
On the susceptibility images, the areas of blood products
corresponding to the
CT abnormality are identified. There are no additional foci seen
to indicate
underlying microhemorrhages.
There is no mass effect or midline shift seen. Mild changes of
small vessel
disease are noted.
IMPRESSION: Blood products in both frontal and left temporal
region likely
due to hemorrhagic contusions, although the locations of the
abnormalities are
somewhat atypical. No evidence of chronic microhemorrhages seen
in other
parts of the brain to suggest underlying abnormality. Small
bilateral
subdural collections are seen.
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Neurology Service at ___ on
___ after sustaining multiple falls with confusion. Imaging
of his head showed several areas of hemorrhage in bifrontal and
left temporal areas.
.
The patient was kept in the ICU for several days for close
observation and then transferred to the floor. He was cleared
from his c-collar medically while in the ICU. His coumadin was
held during his stay and his goal SBP was <160. Hydralazine was
given as necessary to keep within these parameters, although the
patient autoregulated well during his stay. He was started on
Keppra for seizure prophylaxis.
.
The patient also had an issue with hypernatremia and was started
on normal saline at 70 cc/hr for treatment. He should get labs
daily at rehab, and may need further treamtent for his
hypernatremia.
.
One of the major issues during his stay was his mental status.
The majority of his stay he was not oriented to person, place,
or time. On discharge he is oriented to place and year.
.
He was not able to pass a speech and swallow evaluation until
___ as he would not swallow, but was cleared for pureed solids
and thin liquids with meds given crushed in puree. The patient
should be under observation when eating. This should be
re-evaluated at rehab to see if diet can be advanced.
.
Once leaving rehab, the patient will need to followup with his
PCP, ___ in reference to restarting warfarin. He was
stopped due to intracranial hemorrhages. Having atrial
fibrillation puts him at risk for embolic strokes. Since he has
a history of falls, his primary care physician should assess him
as an outpatient to evaluate the risks and benefits of
restarting coumadin. His simvastatin and lopressor doses were
not known, and he will not go to rehab on either medication. He
should followup with his PCP about restarting these medications
after rehab.
.
He will need followup with Dr. ___ on ___ and get a head
CT one week before this appointment. He will need followup with
his PCP, ___ one week of leaving rehab.
Medications on Admission:
Coumadin
Lopressor
simvastatin
(unknown dosage)
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every
6 hours) as needed for pain.
2. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a
day) as needed for constipation.
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2
times a day).
4. insulin regular human 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: One (1)
Injection ASDIR (AS DIRECTED).
5. glucagon (human recombinant) 1 mg Recon Soln Sig: One (1)
Recon Soln Injection Q15MIN () as needed for hypoglycemia
protocol.
6. ondansetron HCl (PF) 4 mg/2 mL Solution Sig: One (1)
Injection Q8H (every 8 hours) as needed for nausea.
7. dextrose 50% in water (D50W) Syringe Sig: One (1)
Intravenous PRN (as needed) as needed for hypoglycemia protocol.
8. Keppra 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day.
9. hydralazine 20 mg/mL Solution Sig: 0.5 Injection Q6H (every
6 hours) as needed for PRN SBP >160.
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
bifrontal and left temporal hemorrhages
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - sometimes.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or
wheelchair.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted to the Neurology Service at ___ on ___
after sustaining multiple falls with confusion. Imaging of your
head showed several areas of hemorrhage in your brain.
.
You were taking coumadin for your atrial fibrillation. This
medication was held during your stay as it can increase
hemorrhages in your brain. Your blood pressure was also kept
below a certain level for treatment.
.
You were initially in the ICU for close monitoring, and then
transferred to the floor once stable.
.
You were started on keppra for seizure prophylaxis which you
will go to rehab on and continue until your appointment with Dr.
___ on ___. Once leaving rehab, you will need to followup
with your PCP, ___ in reference to restarting your
warfarin. You were stopped due to the hemorrhages in your brain.
Having atrial fibrillation puts you at risk for blood clots
which can cause strokes. Since you have a history of falls, your
primary care physician should assess you as an outpatient to
evaluate the risks and benefits of restarting coumadin. Your
simvastatin and lopressor doses were not known, and you will not
go to rehab on either medication. You should followup with your
PCP about restarting these medications after rehab.
.
You were not able to pass a speech and swallow evaluation until
___, and they then cleared you for pureed solids and thin
liquids.
.
Please followup with Dr. ___ on ___ and get a CT scan of
your head one week before this appointment. Please followup with
your PCP, ___ one week of leaving rehab.
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
fevers/rash/chest pressure
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Cardiac Catheterization on ___, showing no coronary artery 
disease.

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year-old caucasian male no significant PMH who 
presents from OSH after he presented there complaining of rash, 
fever and chest pain. Pt was in his usual state of health unitl 
1 week prior on ___ Day when he was cutting his lawn and 
noticed an insect (not sure what kind) bit him in the Left 
elbow.  He lives in a wooded area where deer live.  The next day 
he began to have symptoms of diffuse myalgias and fevers to 
103.7.  At the same time he noted an erythematous 2 cm circulair 
rash on his Right elbow at the site of the insect bite.  In 
addition to myalgias he also noted headaches, left testicle 
tenderness and photosensitivity.  He went to an OSH ER who 
diagnosed epididimitis and prescribed levoquin and discharged 
him to home.  Pt took 3 days of levaquin, tylenol, and ibuprofen 
with little relief of symptoms.  Then on the day prior to 
admission he began to note ___ chest pressure on the left side. 
 He reports associted dysnpea.  He was not exerting himself due 
to generalized myalgias, but he dis not note any exertional 
component.  The pressure and dyspnea varied with possition, and 
he stated "it was difficult to get into a comfortable position." 
 He stated that he was only comfortable when lying on his side, 
or when propped up with 3 pillows; pain was worse when sitting 
completely upright or when lying flat.  Then on ___ evening 
he noted that pain radiated to the left jaw.  Also on ___ 
he noted nausea and vomitted x2, and has had decreased PO intake 
since ___.  He denies PND, lightheadedness, presyncope, 
syncope, and palpitiations.  
.
Because of these symptoms he presented to OSH ED.  At the OSH ED 
he was noted to have chest pressure, his troponin was elevated 
to 25.86, cK 975, MB 8.7, EKG demonstrated ___levations in 
V4, I, II, avL, and echo at OSH reportedly with mild global 
hypokinesis (45-50%), apical akinesis, and no effusion.  He was 
given vancomycin, gentamycin, fentanyl.  He was transferred to 
___ for Cardiac Cath.    
.
In the ED, initial vitals were T: 99.3 HR:89 BP:111/60 RR:11 
O2Sat:96%RA. Patient complaining of chest heaviness and noted to 
have a 1 cm circular abrasion on the R elbow with overlying "red 
cellulitic area."  He was then sent to the Cath lab for C Cath.  

.
C Cath showed no obstructive disease, CO of 5 L/min with no 
signs of tamponade or constriction.  He was then transferred to 
the floor.  On the floor he complains of continued ___ chest 
pressure, diaphoresis, and diffuse myalgias.
. 
Of note, 1 week prior he was cutting his lawn and developed a 
rash on bilateral lower extremities.  He went to his doctor ___ 
___ and prescribed a 5 day course of 
prednisone, which he completed 1 week prior to presentation.

 
Past Medical History:
H/O epididimitis
Seasonal Allergies
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
There is no family history of premature coronary artery disease 
or sudden death.  
 
Physical Exam:
VS: T:99.7, 90/54 (87-96/54-62), HR 90 (80-90), RR 18, 100%RA.
Gen: WDWN middle aged male in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect 
appropriate.  
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were 
pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.  

Neck: Supple with no JVP elevation, +LAD
CV: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. 
RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4.  
Chest: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp 
were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, 
wheezes or rhonchi.  
Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by 
palpation. No abdominial bruits.  
Ext: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits.  Right cath site with clean 
dressing, no hematoma.
Skin: Erythematous 3 cm circular lesion over Right elbow with 
blanchable, edges and dark nonblanchable ___rythematous ___ rash on posterior aspect of 
bilateral knees.
.  
Pulses:  
Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 09:35AM URINE  HOURS-RANDOM
___ 09:35AM URINE  HOURS-RANDOM
___ 09:35AM URINE  GR HOLD-HOLD
___ 09:35AM URINE  bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG opiates-NEG 
cocaine-NEG amphetmn-NEG mthdone-NEG
___ 09:35AM URINE  COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Clear SP ___
___ 09:35AM URINE  ___ NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG 
GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-50 BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-6.5 
LEUK-NEG
___ 09:20AM   ___ PTT-24.6 ___
___ 09:12AM   COMMENTS-GREEN TOP
___ 09:12AM   LACTATE-1.0
___ 09:04AM   GLUCOSE-111* UREA N-11 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-140 
POTASSIUM-4.1 CHLORIDE-105 TOTAL CO2-28 ANION GAP-11
___ 09:04AM   estGFR-Using this
___ 09:04AM   ALT(SGPT)-136* AST(SGOT)-164* LD(LDH)-373* 
CK(CPK)-1019* ALK PHOS-81 TOT BILI-0.5
___ 09:04AM   cTropnT-1.97*
___ 09:04AM   CK-MB-59* MB INDX-5.8

bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG tricyclic-NEG
___ 09:04AM   WBC-6.2 RBC-4.45* HGB-12.9* HCT-37.0* MCV-83 
MCH-29.0 MCHC-34.9 RDW-13.1
___ 09:04AM   PLT COUNT-132*
___ 09:04AM   PARST SMR-NEGATIVE
.
.
EKG demonstrated NSR at 86. nml axis, nml intervals.  TW 
flattening in II, III, aVF. ___levation in V2-V6.
.
C.CATH Study Date of ___:
1.  Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system 

demonstrated no angiographically significant coronary artery 
disease. 
2.  LV Ventriculography was deferred. 
3.  Limited resting hemodynamics demonstrated a low central 
aortic 
pressure (87/63 mm Hg).  The right (RVEDP 9 mm Hg) and left 
(mean PCWP 
16 mm Hg) were mildly elevated.  The cardiac output / index 
measured by 
the Fick equation were preserved at 5.4 L/min and 2.64 L/min/m2. 

FINAL DIAGNOSIS:     
1. Coronary arteries are normal. 
.
Portable TTE (Complete) Done ___:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. The estimated right atrial 
pressure is ___. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are 
normal. The left ventricular cavity size is top 
normal/borderline dilated. There is moderate global left 
ventricular hypokinesis (LVEF = ___ %). There is no 
ventricular septal defect. The right ventricular cavity is 
borderline dilated with borderline normal free wall function. 
The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with 
good leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. No masses or 
vegetations are seen on the aortic valve. The mitral valve 
appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. 
There is no mitral valve prolapse. No mass or vegetation is seen 
on the mitral valve. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic 
pressure is normal. No vegetation/mass is seen on the pulmonic 
valve. There is no pericardial effusion. 
IMPRESSION: cardiomyopathy  
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Assessment: ___ year-old caucasian male no significant PMH who 
presents from OSH after he presented there complaining of rash, 
fever and chest pain found to have positive biomarkers and ST 
elevations. C Cath with clean coronaries.  Most likely 
infectious mycarditis.
.  
#. CAD: No evidence of CAD on C Cath.
.  
#. Pump: EF ___ on ___ echo with global hypokinesis.  
Therefore, this is a non-ischemic cardiomyopathy.  Due to 
history of insect bite and rash with transaminitis 
lyme/ehrlichia is of concern.  Other infections to consider 
include babesia and viral causes.  Babesia has been ruled out 
with negative parasite smear.  Lyme serologies were negative, 
however acute infection could not be ruled out so PCR was sent.  
Lyme PCR results were pending at the time of discharge.  Other 
serolgies were pending at the time of discharge. 
- scheduled for ID follow-up, where serologies will be 
followed-up
- treated with doxycycline for empiric treatment of lyme and 
ehrlichia.  He was discharged on a 4 week course.
- Was started on captopril in house to prevent remodeling.  This 
was changed to lisinopril on discharge.
- Started on a Beta Blocker given scattered ___ beat runs of 
NSVT on telemetry.
- cardiology follow up arranged with cardiologist in ___'s 
geographic region (dr. ___.
- Cardiac MRI was obtained.  The official read was pending at 
the time of discharge.  The result should be followed up by pt's 
cardiologist (result can be obtained by calling the radiology 
department (___).
.  
#. Rhythm: ___ episodes of ___ beat runs of NSVT on telemetry.  
No evidence of conduction abnormalities which would argue more 
in favor of lyme. 
- monitored on telemetry while admitted, and treated with B 
Blocker
.  
#. Fevers/rash: As described above, this is concerning for viral 
illness, lyme, erlichia.
- treated with doxycycline for empiric treatment of lyme and 
ehrlichia.  He was discharged on a 4 week course.
- ID appointment scheduled, where serologies will be followed up
- treated supportivly with tylenol and ibuprofen
.
#.  Transaminitis: This is likely related to infection. 
- LFTs should be rechecked during follow-up to verify resolution 

.
.
****FAXED TO Dr. ___ office at ___
 
Medications on Admission:
(on transfer)
Zyrtek OTC
Vancomycon 1 gm Qday
Levaquin 500 mg QDay (had taken 3 days)
Tylenol ___ mg 
Ibuprofen 800 mg
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4H (every 
4 hours) as needed.  
2. Ibuprofen 400 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for fever or pain.  
3. Lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Metoprolol Succinate 25 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr 
Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Doxycycline Hyclate 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
Q12H (every 12 hours) for 26 days: last dose on ___.
Disp:*52 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Infectious Myocarditis.

 
Discharge Condition:
Vital signs stable, ambulating without difficulty, afebrile, 
chest pain free.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with symptoms of chest pain 
and fevers after an insect bite.  Cardiac catheterization was 
performed and showed that you have no coronary artery disease.  
The most likely cause of your heart disease is an infectius 
myocarditis, and infection of the muscle of the heart.  You 
should schedule follow up appointments with your PCP, ___ 
___ (listed below), and an infectious disease doctor 
___ below).  
.
Please weigh yourself daily, if you gain more than 3 pounds, 
have lower extremity swelling, difficulty breathing please call 
your primary care physician or your cardiologist. Please follow 
a low sodium diet. Information was given to you at discharge 
regarding this.
.
Please take your medications as prescribed below.  You were 
started on two new medications, toprol and lisinopril, and you 
should continue to take tylenol and ibuprofen as needed.  You 
will also take an antibiotic called doxycycline.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Lyme PCR results were pending at the time of discharge. Other
serolgies were pending at the time of discharge.
- scheduled for ID follow-up, where serologies will be
followed-up
- treated with doxycycline for empiric treatment of lyme and
ehrlichia. He was discharged on a 4 week course.
- Was started on captopril in house to prevent remodeling. This
was changed to lisinopril on discharge.
- Started on a Beta Blocker given scattered ___ beat runs of
NSVT on telemetry.
- cardiology follow up arranged with cardiologist in ___'s
geographic region (dr. ___.
- Cardiac MRI was obtained. The official read was pending at
the time of discharge. The result should be followed up by pt's
cardiologist (result can be obtained by calling the radiology
department (___).
.
#. Rhythm: ___ episodes of ___ beat runs of NSVT on telemetry.
No evidence of conduction abnormalities which would argue more
in favor of lyme.
- monitored on telemetry while admitted, and treated with B
Blocker
.
#. Fevers/rash: As described above, this is concerning for viral
illness, lyme, erlichia.
- treated with doxycycline for empiric treatment of lyme and
ehrlichia. He was discharged on a 4 week course.
- ID appointment scheduled, where serologies will be followed up
- treated supportivly with tylenol and ibuprofen
.
#. Transaminitis: This is likely related to infection.
- LFTs should be rechecked during follow-up to verify resolution
.
.
****FAXED TO Dr. ___ office at ___
Medications on Admission:
(on transfer)
Zyrtek OTC
Vancomycon 1 gm Qday
Levaquin 500 mg QDay (had taken 3 days)
Tylenol ___ mg
Ibuprofen 800 mg
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4H (every
4 hours) as needed.
2. Ibuprofen 400 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6
hours) as needed for fever or pain.
3. Lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Metoprolol Succinate 25 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr
Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Doxycycline Hyclate 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO
Q12H (every 12 hours) for 26 days: last dose on ___.
Disp:*52 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Infectious Myocarditis.
Discharge Condition:
Vital signs stable, ambulating without difficulty, afebrile,
chest pain free.
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with symptoms of chest pain
and fevers after an insect bite. Cardiac catheterization was
performed and showed that you have no coronary artery disease.
The most likely cause of your heart disease is an infectius
myocarditis, and infection of the muscle of the heart. You
should schedule follow up appointments with your PCP, ___
___ (listed below), and an infectious disease doctor
___ below).
.
Please weigh yourself daily, if you gain more than 3 pounds,
have lower extremity swelling, difficulty breathing please call
your primary care physician or your cardiologist. Please follow
a low sodium diet. Information was given to you at discharge
regarding this.
.
Please take your medications as prescribed below. You were
started on two new medications, toprol and lisinopril, and you
should continue to take tylenol and ibuprofen as needed. You
will also take an antibiotic called doxycycline.

his PCP ___ few days prior to transfer, who, in consultation with

Pre-bypass Exam
 rhythm: sinus bradycardia
 infusions: phenylephrine

 1. The left atrium is normal in size. No spontaneous echo 
contrast is seen in the body of the left atrium or left atrial 
appendage.
 2. A small patent foramen ovale is present. A left-to-right 
shunt across the interatrial septum is seen at rest.
 3. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. 
Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). 

 4. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are 
normal. 
 5. There are three aortic valve leaflets. The aortic valve 
leaflets are severely thickened/deformed. There is severe aortic 
valve stenosis (valve area <1.0cm2). Area is 0.7 by 2D 
planimetry. Dimensionless Index <0.25 consistent with severe AS. 
Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. 
 6. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild (1+) 
mitral regurgitation is seen. The jet is central. The P2 portion 
of the postrior leaflet is billowing and borderline prolapsing.

 Post Bypass Exam
 rhythm: atrial pacing
 infusions: phenylephrine

 1. Aortic valve bioprosthesis visualized, well seated. No 
significant paravaulvular or intravalvular regurgitation is 
seen. The mean gradient is 6mmHg
 2. Other valvular function is intact and unchanged from 
pre-byass
 3. Left ventricular function is intact LVEF >65%
 4. Right ventricular function is intact and unchanged
 5. Aorta intact, no evidence of dissection

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was brought to the Operating Room on ___ where 
the patient underwent  CABG x2 (SVG-PDA, SVG-OM2), AVR tissue 
(25mm Magna Ease).  Overall the patient tolerated the procedure 
well and post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable 
condition for recovery and invasive monitoring.  

 POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and 
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact 
and hemodynamically stable.  Beta blocker was initiated and the 
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  The 
patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further 
recovery. The patient developed post-operative atrial 
fibrillation that corrected with amiodarone. The duration of the 
AF was short and he will not require anticoagulation at 
discharge. He will be discharged on the typical 1 month course 
of amiodarone. Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued 
without complication.  The patient was evaluated by the Physical 
Therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility. On 
POD 4 the patient had a self-limiting episode of diplopia. The 
patient states he had no other symptoms and his diplopia 
resolved in 15 seconds. The patient had no further episodes and 
no further work up was indicated given the short duration of his 
symptoms.  By the time of discharge on POD 5 the patient was 
ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain was controlled 
with oral analgesics.  The patient was discharged to home in 
good condition with appropriate follow up instructions.

Hct 23 --> 2 units pRBCs --> 31

___ Portable CXR 
Edema-like pattern, presence of atypical infection not excluded. 
 
Correlate clinically. If diuresed, consider repeat radiography 
to assess for underlying infection. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ male with history of aortic stenosis, coronary artery 
disease s/p MI, and prostate cancer s/p XRT complicated by 
radiation proctitis was admitted with chest pain and 
hematochezia. 

1. Hematochezia
Patient appears to have had acute blood loss anemia in the 
setting of rectal bleeding related to radiation proctitis. 
Patient and family were not interested in further 
gastroenterology evaluation with colonoscopy as patient has 
undergone ineffective cautery in the past. Patient was 
transfused 2 units pRBCs with an appropriate improvement in his 
hematocrit from 23 to 31. He had no further episodes of bleeding 
as an outpatient. 

2. NSTEMI
Patient appears to have had an acute GI bleed ___ days prior to 
admission at which time he experienced chest pain. This likely 
represented an MI in the setting of demand ischemia. His cardiac 
enzymes were elevated on presentation and then declined during 
his admission. His aspirin was held during this admission due to 
the GI bleeding. Likewise, lisinopril and metoprolol were also 
held in the setting of hypotension with systolic blood pressures 
primarily in the ___. He was recommended to have these 
medications restarted as an outpatient. His simvastatin was 
increased to 80mg from 20mg in the setting of his NSTEMI. 

3. Acute Exacerbation of Chronic Systolic Heart Failure
Shortly after receiving 2 units of pRBCs for his GI bleeding, he 
developed an oxygen requirement after being found to be 89% on 
room air. As his blood pressure allowed, he was gently diuresed 
with lasix and then restarted on his home dose of lasix. He was 
stable on room air upon discharge from the hospital. As 
described below, his ACEI and beta blocker were held during this 
admission due to hypotension. These should be restarted as an 
outpatient as blood pressure allows. 

4. Hypotension
Shortly after arriving to the floor, patient triggered with 
hypotension with systolic blood pressure of 80. His blood 
pressure improved with transfusions and holding his home 
medications of lisinopril and metoprolol. These should be 
restarted as an outpatient as blood pressure allows. 

His code status was confirmed to be DNR/DNI with patient's 
daughter. 
 
 
Medications on Admission:
Lisinopril 2.5 mg po 
Simvastatin 20 mg qd
ASA 81 mg qd
Lopressor 25 mg po bid
Alprazolam 0.5 mg qhs - 
Erythromycin ointment R eye
Metamucil 
Alprazolam 0.25 mg q 6 hours
SLNG
Iron sulfate 325 mg po qd
Lasix 40 mg po qd
Potassium chloride 20 meq ER 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Simvastatin 40 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
2. Alprazolam 0.25 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO QHS (once a 
day (at bedtime)).  
3. Alprazolam 0.25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO four times a 
day as needed for anxiety.  
4. Erythromycin 5 mg/g Ointment Sig: One (1)  Ophthalmic QID (4 
times a day).  
5. Lasix 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
6. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg (65 mg Iron) Capsule, Sustained 
Release Sig: One (1) Capsule, Sustained Release PO once a day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home with Service
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS: 
1. Gastrointestinal Bleeding
2. Acute Exacerbation of Chronic Systolic Heart Failure
3. Radiation Proctitis
4. Coronary Artery Disease

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable. Patient is tolerating oral intake and ambulating. 

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for treatment of your bleeding 
and low blood count. Your bleeding is most likely related to 
complications and side effects from your radiation therapy. You 
also likely had a heart attack due to the stress on your heart. 

Please continue to take all of your medications. We have made 
the following changes to your medications: 
- Lisinopril - We have discontinued this medication because your 
blood pressure was slightly low. 
- Metoprolol - We have discontinued this medication because your 
blood pressure was slightly low. 
- Aspirin - We have discontinued this medication due to your 
bleeding. 
- Simvastatin - We have increased this medication from 20mg to 
80mg once daily. 

Please seek immediate medical attention if you develop fevers, 
shaking chills, night sweats, bleeding from your bottom, nausea, 
vomiting, bloody vomitus, shortness of breath, or chest pain. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

PSYCHIATRIC:
#Pyschosis:
Patient presented with flat affect, severe paranoia, 
disorganized thought process, and possible catatonia. Patient 
was very reluctant to speak to staff, but would intermittently 
talk to staff. Patient was started on Lorazepam 2mg TID for 
catatonia but refused to take them. After further evaluation, 
she was determined not to be catatonic and the lorazepam was 
stopped and she was started on Zyprexa Zydis 10mg BID with 
Zyprexa Zydis 5mg BID:PRN. Patient initially refused these. On 
the night of ___, patient attempted to elope and became very 
agitated and assaultive towards staff and had to be put in 
seclusion for safety of self and concern for safety for staff. 
Patient was then started on Zyprexa 10mg IM.  However, she did 
not respond well to this and was violent to staff on multiple 
occasions.  She was transitioned to thorazine standing.  This 
was too sedating and she was then transitioned to haldol with 
intermittent ativan prn agitation. After the ___ was granted on 
___, patient was started on Haldol Deconoate IM with Haldol PO 
as a bridge and tolerated it well. Patient was also only 
intermittently eating and there was a concern for her medical 
health due to malnutrition. Patient was able to be reassured 
that eating was beneficial to her and started eating again. 
Patient started to improve on haldol evidenced by lessening 
paranoia, becoming more visible in the milieu and interacting 
with other patients and her family. Patient was given a series 
of 2 Haldol Deconoate 100mg IM shots and a ___ shot of 75mg 
Haldol deconoate and tolerated them well without side effects. 
Patient was also titrated off Oral Haldol by discharge and was 
only requiring 75mg Haldol Deconoate IM every 2 weeks.  Patient 
was also put on Cogentin 1mg BID to prevent EPS and has 
tolerated it well. Patient was discharged on Cogentin 1mg BID as 
well. 

GENERAL MEDICAL CONDITIONS:

hypo/hyperglycemia.

stay on the unit. Her heart rate would reach up to 110's 
consistently. She was started on Nadolol 20mg BID which she 
tolerated well. Patient's HR was in ___'s towards end of stay and 
did not require nadolol anymore.

in the treatment and discussing any  questions about medications 
with the treatment team, and I  answered the patient's

consented to begin the medication.

-Long standing mental illness

-Medication non compliance

- No current outpatient providers

- Strong family support

The patient presented to ___ at ___ on ___ due to 
SOB and audible wheezes. The patient has a h/o COPD and is on 2 
L NC at home. During this episode of dyspnea, the patient was 
96% on his baseline 2L. The patient also c/o slurred speech, 
which he attributed to a swollen tongue. According to the notes, 
the patient recently started a new medication, which he said was 
Chantix three days prior. The patient was also recently 
diagnosed with Parkinsonism and is on Sinemet at home. The 
patient was also complaining of increased visual hallucinations 
at home prior to presentation. At ___, the patient had an ABG 
that was 7.36/47/142/26 on 4L NC. He was given 125mg Solumedrol, 
Duoneb, Levaquin 750mg. His saturations remained in the high ___ 
on 2L NC. During the ED stay at ___, the patient took off all 
of his EKG leads and wanted to leave, but was easily redirected. 
By ___, it was reported that the patient's tongue swelling had 
improved. The patient was transfered to ___ due to altered 
mental status and neurology consult. During transport, the 
patient continued to have visual hallucinations and was 
repsonding to internal stimuli, which the patient says was 
baseline for him. He was not distressed by these.
.
At ___, initial VS were 98.8, 112/71, 79, 20, 96% RA. He 
triggered for 2 episodes of unresponsiveness even to sternal 
rub. On exam, at first incredibly somnolent, slurred speech, 
tongue fasciculations, otherwise CN II-XII intact; strength ___ 
throughout w/e/o L leg foot drop; lungs exp wheezing bilat. ? 
myoclonic jerks. Awoke spontaneously after minutes. Lactate 
normal, ABG 7.37/46/62/28. Normal head CT. Utox negative. Given 
narcan with no change in mental status.
.  
On arrival to the MICU, the patient was initially difficult to 
arouse. Once awoken, the patient was appropriate, following 
commands, and logical. The patient says that he doesn't remember 
much of what happened today, but notes that it started this AM 
with some SOB and then increasing visual hallucinations. He says 
that he has had these hallucinations for ___ weeks, which he 
describes as seeing people whom he knows and he has 
conversations with. These are nonthreatening hallucinations. The 
patient also notes some orthostasis, especially dizziness when 
he arises from bed in the AM. He complains of tremor, both at 
rest and with movement, which he says has gotten better since 
starting Sinimet. He denies rigidity or gait disturbance. No 
urinary symptoms. He notes dry mouth, but little tongue swelling 
now.

Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ because you were confused and having 
hallucinations.  We believe this happened as a side effect of 
multiple medications you were taking, including Sinimet, 
Chantix, Citalopram, ropinirole, and percocet.  We stopped these 
medications while you were in the hospital, and your confusion 
improved.

You were also evaluated by our neurologists while you were in 
the hospital.  The neurologists do not feel that you have 
___ disease and recommend that you stop taking Sinimet 
as it could be contributing to your hallucinations.  We 
recommend that you follow up with a neurologist as an 
outpatient.  Please talk to your primary care provider about 
setting up an appointment with a neurologist near you.

We recommend that you stop the following medications:
-STOP Sinimet
-STOP Chantix - we recommend you continue using your nicotine 
patch for smoking cessation
-STOP Ropinirole
-STOP Citalopram
-STOP alprazolam
-STOP percocet
-STOP amitriptyline

We made no other changes to your medications while you were in 
the hospital.  Please continue taking the rest of your 
medications as prescribed by your outpatient providers.

We have scheduled an appointment for you to follow up with your 
primary care provider.  Please see below for your appointment 
time.

It has been a pleasure taking care of you at ___ and we wish 
you a speedy recovery.

throughout w/e/o L leg foot drop; lungs exp wheezing bilat. ?
myoclonic jerks. Awoke spontaneously after minutes. Lactate
normal, ABG 7.37/46/62/28. Normal head CT. Utox negative. Given
narcan with no change in mental status.
.
On arrival to the MICU, the patient was initially difficult to
arouse. Once awoken, the patient was appropriate, following
commands, and logical. The patient says that he doesn't remember
much of what happened today, but notes that it started this AM
with some SOB and then increasing visual hallucinations. He says
that he has had these hallucinations for ___ weeks, which he
describes as seeing people whom he knows and he has
conversations with. These are nonthreatening hallucinations. The
patient also notes some orthostasis, especially dizziness when
he arises from bed in the AM. He complains of tremor, both at
rest and with movement, which he says has gotten better since
starting Sinimet. He denies rigidity or gait disturbance. No
urinary symptoms. He notes dry mouth, but little tongue swelling
now.
.

admission with non-threatening hallucinations could be c/w a

not have the characteristic motor findings. The neurology
service was consulted and felt his hallucinations were most
likely ___ polypharmacy vs hypoxia from his underlying lung
disease. His sinemet was discontinued as neurology felt he had
no s/sx ___ disease. His alprazolam, loratidine,
oxycodone, amitriptyline, and gabapentin were held. His
hallucinations resolved and mental status cleared. On
discharge, it was recommended that he continue to hold these
medications and follow up with his PCP and an outpatient
neurologist for further evaluation.

smoker. He remained at his baseline O2 requirement of 2L
throughout hospitalization, and ABG was wnl. he was continued
on his home inhalers.

# HTN: He was continued on his home lisinopril and nifedipine.

- The following medications were discontinued: Sinimet, chantix,
ropinirole, alprazolam, loratidine, oxycodone, amitriptyline,
and gabapentin.
- He was scheduled to follow up with his PCP after discharge.

neurologist in his area.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted to ___ because you were confused and having
hallucinations. We believe this happened as a side effect of
multiple medications you were taking, including Sinimet,
Chantix, Citalopram, ropinirole, and percocet. We stopped these
medications while you were in the hospital, and your confusion
improved.
You were also evaluated by our neurologists while you were in
the hospital. The neurologists do not feel that you have
___ disease and recommend that you stop taking Sinimet
as it could be contributing to your hallucinations. We
recommend that you follow up with a neurologist as an
outpatient. Please talk to your primary care provider about
setting up an appointment with a neurologist near you.

patch for smoking cessation

-STOP amitriptyline

the hospital. Please continue taking the rest of your
medications as prescribed by your outpatient providers.

primary care provider. Please see below for your appointment
time.
It has been a pleasure taking care of you at ___ and we wish
you a speedy recovery.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman with Hx of IBS, Diverticulosis, and CAD, 
presenting with 5 days of watery diarrhea and found to have 
guaiac + stools with 5 pt Hct drop
.
# Normocytic Anemia: Patient had 5 pt Hct drop on labs from the 
ED. In setting of guaiac + stools, this was concerning for a GI 
source of acute blood loss. She has known diverticulosis and 
hemorrhoids, and was currently experiencing diarrhea. She denied 
black stools and had none during this admission. She declined NG 
lavage in the ED, and declined any additional inpatient 
procedures to further investigate a potential GI source of blood 
loss. We maintained an active T&S and two large-bore peripheral 
IVs for access. She was monitored on telemetry and her vitals 
remained hemodynamically stable. Her repeat hematocrit was also 
stable. Given the low suspicion of an acute large-volume GI 
bleed, the patient was discharged home with instructions to 
follow up with her Gastroenterologist, Dr. ___ was also in 
agreement with this plan. It is more likely that she presented 
with an elevated hematocrit secondary to hemoconcentration in 
the setting of diarrhea, which fell by 5 pts after rehydration.
.  
# Diarrhea: In setting of chills, weakness, and a recent 
laryngitis, her diarrhea was likely infectious in etiology. 
Given lack of fever or leukocytosis, a viral etiology was 
suspected over an acute bacterial infection. She denied recent 
antibiotic use and had only one episode of vomiting. Stool 
studies were sent and most are still pending. These will need to 
be followed up by her Gastroenterologist. No abdominal imaging 
was performed; however, her exam was reassuring with no 
tenderness to palpation, rebound, or guarding. Given the low 
likelihood of a bacterial infection with toxin production, she 
was given Loperamide to take to as needed to control her 
diarrhea. She was additionally given IV hydration and her 
electrolytes were repleted as needed. 
.
# Hypokalemia: Likely secondary to diarrhea. Repleted as needed. 

.  
# Coronary Artery Disease: Has a history of a myocardial 
infarction in ___ without any further events. Denies stent 
placement. Presented on Aspirin 81 and ___ 75 mg daily. After 
discussion with her Primary Care Physician, ___ was held at 
discharge given no clear current indication and possible 
near-future procedure (colonoscopy). 
.  
# Hypertension: Currently normotensive. Continued on Atenolol 75 
mg at discharge. 
.  
# HLD: Continued on Atorvastatin 80 mg at discharge. 
.
# GERD: Continued on Nexium 40 mg at discharge. 
.
# Full Code
.
# To Do:
-Follow up pending stool studies
-Given guaiac positive stools, consider additional procedures to 
evaluate for GI source of anemia
 
Medications on Admission:
1. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. ergocalciferol (vitamin D2)  Oral
3. Estrace 0.01 % (0.1 mg/g) Cream Vaginal
4. atenolol 50 mg Tablet Sig: 1.5 Tablets PO once a day.  
5. cyanocobalamin (vitamin B-12) 1,000 mcg Tablet Extended 
Release Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release PO once a day.  
6. Lipitor 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
7. Nexium 40 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO once a day.  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. ergocalciferol (vitamin D2)  Oral
3. Estrace 0.01 % (0.1 mg/g) Cream Vaginal
4. atenolol 50 mg Tablet Sig: 1.5 Tablets PO once a day.  
5. cyanocobalamin (vitamin B-12) 1,000 mcg Tablet Extended 
Release Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release PO once a day.  
6. Lipitor 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
7. Nexium 40 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO once a day.  
8. loperamide 2 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO QID (4 times 
a day) as needed for diarrhea: ___ may buy this over the 
counter.
Disp:*20 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
diarrhea likely secondary to viral gastroenteritis
guaiac positive stools
anemia
hypertension

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

___ were admitted to the ___ Medicine service for evaluation 
of your anemia and diarrhea. ___ are likely experiencing a viral 
gastroenteritis. ___ will need to contact your 
Gastroenterologist tomorrow to discuss additional evaluation of 
the blood in your stools, which may include a colonoscopy. He 
will also follow up on the pending lab work ___ had done while 
in the hospital. We gave ___ fluids and ___ improved. ___ are 
stable and safe to go home. 
.
We are making the following change to your medications:
-Please STOP ___ for now. This may be restarted in the future 
by your physicians. 
-Please START Immodium as directed for management of your 
diarrhea. ___ may buy this over the counter. We are providing 
___ a prescription for convenience.
.
Please remember to eat and drink to keep yourself well hydrated.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

.

infarction in ___ without any further events. Denies stent
placement. Presented on Aspirin 81 and ___ 75 mg daily. After
discussion with her Primary Care Physician, ___ was held at
discharge given no clear current indication and possible
near-future procedure (colonoscopy).
.
# Hypertension: Currently normotensive. Continued on Atenolol 75
mg at discharge.
.
# HLD: Continued on Atorvastatin 80 mg at discharge.
.
# GERD: Continued on Nexium 40 mg at discharge.
.
# Full Code
.
# To Do:
-Follow up pending stool studies
-Given guaiac positive stools, consider additional procedures to
evaluate for GI source of anemia

Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right buttocks pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Incision and Drainage, Perirectal Abcess 
___ Exam under anesthesia, debridement of perirectal 
abscess cavity
___ Exam under anesthesia, debridement of perirectal 
abscess cavity

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M with history of chronic anal fissures x ___ years 
diagnosed as lichen simplex on biopsy, and thrombocytopenia of 
unknown etiology, who presents with R buttock pain and fevers 
for the past ___ days after picking at a "zit" deep in his 
buttocks. Per pt, he was in his usual state of health, believing 
his fissures were fully healed, when he noticed a zit in his 
buttocks on ___.  He tried to pop it with his 
finger. The next day he had subjective fevers and chills that 
were unresponsive to tylenol.  On ___ he noticed pinpoint 
rectal pain, ___ in severity, at the site of the zit.  This 
progressed over the next few days to ___ throbbing pain over 
a larger area encompassing most of his right buttock, with 
overlying warmth and drops of bright red bloody discharge (no 
pus). When he sits on his buttocks, the pain increases to 
___.  He denies accompanying diarrhea or constipation.  He 
continues to have bowel movements that increase his buttock 
pain.  He denies tenesmus, or changes in his stool.  He is 
sexually active with anal sex, but reports last activity was in 
___.
.
Of note, pt had excision in ___ for biopsy of chronic 
fissures, which showed lichen chronicus simplex.  This was 
treated with steroid cream for 2 months to little effect, and 
then with zinc ointment also to little effect.  The area of 
excised fissure was noted to be healing slowly, but per pt he 
was fully self-healed before current presentation.  In ___, he visited his PCP with diarrhea and bloody stools, some 
tenesmus, and proctitis-type symptoms in the context of recnt 
abx use, but no fevers/chills.  He received metronidazole 500 mg 
Q8 x 10 days. C. diff was negative, and stool cx negative for 
shigella, salmonella, campylobacter.  Pt reports diarrhea 
self-resolved within a few days.  Pt also had a colonoscopy in 
___ for his chronic history of fissure, which noted a 
small polyp that was excised.  Per report, the colon appeared 
normal.  Per pt, the polyp pathology was unremarkable.  There is 
no family history of colon cancer or IBD that pt is aware of.
.  
In the ED, initial VS were: 100.2 109 130/66 22 98% RA. Exam was 
notable for large erythematous area of right buttocks w/ 
drainage at the site. Labs notable for WBC of 11.1 with 90% 
neutrophils and platelets of 79. Patient underwent CT which was 
initially read as negative for perirectal/perianal fistula. He 
was give vancomycin 1 g and 4L NS and admitted to medicine for 
further management. Pt received IV morphine and IV dilaudid for 
pain control, to good effect. 
.  
ROS: Denies urinary symptoms, dysuria, or pain anywhere else.  
Otherwise noncontributory.
 
Past Medical History:
-lichen chronicus simplex of anus
-Thrombocytopenia, diagnosed as ITP with splenomegaly ___, 
___, records not yet found), not currently 
treated
-Syphilis in ___ (s/p PCN)
-Bilateral knee arthroscopies 
-Postnasal drip
-Erectile dysfunction

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Negative for colon cancer, IBD.

 
Physical Exam:
EXAM ON ADMISSION:
VS:  99.9 --> 102.3, 104/60, 103, 16, 98% RA
GENERAL: Well-appearing man in NAD lying on his L side, 
occasionally shaking under the blankets.  
HEENT: NC/AT, PERRLA, EOMI, sclerae anicteric, MMM, OP clear.  
NECK: Supple, no JVD, no LAD.  
HEART: RRR, no MRG, nl S1-S2.  
LUNGS: CTA bilat, no r/rh/wh, good air movement, resp unlabored. 
 
ABDOMEN: Soft/NT/ND, +BS, no rebound/guarding.  
EXTREMITIES: WWP, no c/c/e, 2+ peripheral pulses.  
SKIN: R buttock with large (appx 4 x 5 in) area of erythema and 
induration, with overlying warmth.  No fluctuance or apparent 
discharge.
NEURO: Awake, A&Ox3, CNs II-XII grossly intact, muscle strength 
___ throughout, sensation grossly intact throughout. 

 
Pertinent Results:
LABS ON ADMISSION:

___ 09:47PM BLOOD WBC-11.1* RBC-5.30 Hgb-16.1 Hct-43.8 
MCV-83 MCH-30.4 MCHC-36.8* RDW-13.4 Plt Ct-79*
___ 09:47PM BLOOD Neuts-91.1* Lymphs-5.9* Monos-2.6 Eos-0.3 
Baso-0.1

___ 09:47PM BLOOD Glucose-144* UreaN-14 Creat-1.2 Na-135 
K-3.7 Cl-99 HCO3-25 AnGap-15
___ 09:45AM BLOOD Calcium-7.5* Phos-1.0* Mg-1.5*
___ 01:15AM BLOOD Lactate-1.6
.
MICROBIOLOGY
___ 4:45 pm BLOOD CULTUREx4, Blood Culture, Routine 
(Pending): 
.
DIAGNOSTICS:
___ Chest Xray:
FINDINGS: Low lung volumes are seen which give the appearance of 

bronchovascular crowding. Otherwise, there is no focal 
consolidation, pleural 
effusion, or pneumothorax. The heart is normal in size, normal 
cardiomediastinal silhouette. 
  
IMPRESSION: No acute intrathoracic process. 
.
___ CT Pelvis with contrast:
FINDINGS: Large and small bowel within the abdomen is 
unremarkable aside from 
sigmoid diverticular disease without active inflammatory process 
changes.  
There is no free air or free fluid in the pelvis. There is no 
pelvic or 
inguinal adenopathy. The bladder, prostate and rectum are 
unremarkable. 
  
OSSEOUS AND SOFT TISSUE STRUCTURES: There is no lytic or 
sclerotic bony 
lesion concerning for osseous malignant process.  
  
Soft tissue stranding and skin thickening is seen along the 
right gluteal fold 
with subcutaneous edema. There is a focal area along the gluteal 
fold that 
appears slightly more dense though without discrete fluid 
collection that 
could reflect a poorly-visualized tract or phlegmonous change 
measuring 33 x 
11mm.  
  
IMPRESSION: No discrete fluid collection with extensive right 
medial gluteal 
subcutaneous stranding and skin thickening with focal, slightly 
more organized 
area which could reflect a tract or area of phlegmonous change 
below the 
resolution of CT. Further evaluation by Pelvic MRI is 
recommended.  
.
___ MRI Pelvis with and without contrast:
.
PERTINENT LABS ON DISCHARGE:

___ 04:45AM BLOOD Plt Ct-83*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
He was initially admitted to the medicine service and his care 
was transferred to the Acute Care Surgery team for further 
management of his ___ abscess. 

His presentation of right buttock erythema with overlying 
warmth, fevers/chills, and lack of fluctuance or fluid 
collection on CT was initially concerning for a superficial 
infection, most likely cellulitis given his recent history of 
picking at the area with his fingers. Initially, there was no 
clear sign of abscess or inflamed fistula on CT.  He was started 
on IV vancomycin 1.2 g Q12h for gram positive coverage (day 1 
___, and received IV Dilaudid for pain control.  Surgery 
consult on the first day of admission concluded low suspicion 
for abscess at the time.  Later that afternoon, however, patient 
continued to have fevers (Tmax 103) despite receiving vancomycin 
and Tylenol.  He received IVF NS boluses for SBP to 100s and HR 
to 100s-120s.  MRI pelvis was again equivocal.  The next morning 
he complained of new bilateral scrotal swelling and erythema, 
with dysuria that was concerning for postrenal/obstructive 
symptoms.  He was then taken to OR for surgical incision and 
drainage of a ___ abscess. 

Postoperatively he was continued on the IV antibiotics and on 
POD #2 ___ baths were ordered. His ___ was left for another 
couple of days and then removed. His pain persisted 
postoperatively along with increasing in erythema and he was 
taken back to the operating room on ___ and ___ for 
further irrigation and debridement. Both his pain and erythema 
diminished significantly although he was still requiring 
narcotics for pain control. ___ baths and BID dressing changes 
were resumed.

He did have significant pain control issues requiring several 
adjustments of his pain regimen. At time of discharge he is on 
an oral regimen which includes both long and short acting 
narcotics with adequate control. A bowel regimen was initiated 
early on as well.

His antibiotics were stopped and his WBC and temperature were 
followed closely 48 hours after stopping therapy. Both his white 
count and temperature remained stable.
 
Of note on admission his platelet count of 79, slightly down 
from his baseline of 90-110s. Per PCP notes, this was worked up 
at ___ to be ITP, although it is unclear what 
studies were performed. His platelet count remained stable at 83 
at time of discharge.

He will also need to follow up with his primary provider ___ 
___ weeks after discharge for ongoing management of his 
pre-hospital issues.

He was discharged home with nursing services for wound care and 
will follow up in ___ clinic in about a week for evaluation of 
his wound.
 
Medications on Admission:
- Vardenafil (LEVITRA) 10 mg PRN
- FLUTICASONE 50 MCG/ACTUATION NASAL spray, 1 spray in each 
nostril once daily 
- MULTIVITAMIN TAB (MULTIVITAMINS) One tablet daily; available 
over the counter 

 
Discharge Medications:
  

1. fluticasone 50 mcg/Actuation Spray, Suspension Sig: One (1) 
Spray Nasal DAILY (Daily).  
2. multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
3. trazodone 50 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO HS (at bedtime) as 
needed for insomnia.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
5. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
6. tramadol 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QID (4 times a 
day).
Disp:*120 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
7. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.  
8. polyethylene glycol 3350 17 gram/dose Powder Sig: Seventeen 
(17) GM's PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for constipation.  
9. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed for breakthrough pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
10. OxyContin 10 mg Tablet Extended Release 12 hr Sig: One (1) 
Tablet Extended Release 12 hr PO every twelve (12) hours: take 1 
tablet every 12 hours for 3 days and then 1 tablet daily for 3 
days then discontinue.
Disp:*10 Tablet Extended Release 12 hr(s)* Refills:*0*
11. mineral oil     Oil Sig: Thirty (30) ML PO DAILY (Daily) as 
needed for constipation.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
___ abscess

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for ___ skin infection with underlying 
bacterial fluid collection.  You were treated with antibiotics 
and surgical drainage of the fluid collection. You also were 
given narcotic pain medications for pain control so it is very 
important for you to prevent constipation by taking a stool 
softener and laxative to everyday unless you are having loose 
bowel movements.

We are recommending that you ___ baths 2x/day prior to your 
dressing changes. A visiting nurse is being arranged to come 
into your home to assess your wound and perform the dressing 
changes.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
___ F w/ PMH of HTN, recent dx of paroxysmal afib, CHF p/w

and progressively worsening weakness over the last ___. Woke 
up this AM feeling extremely tired; required walker to ambulate

Brief Hospital Course:
#. Bradycardia - pt has known AFib, rhythm-controlled on 
Diltiazem and Norpace since ___. Bradycardia likely ___ 
nodal-blocking properties of these meds in the setting of 
underlying conduction disease. Pt was given Atropine x2 and 
Calcium; BP and HR increased in response. Pt converted to sinus 
rhythm in the ED. Per discussion with patient and daughter, 
prefers medication management and refuses PPM at this time. A 
TTE was obtained and showed normal ventricular systolic 
function, moderate aortic valve stenosis and regurgitation, mild 
pulmonary HTN, and mild post-stenotic dilation of the ascending 
aorta. We have stopped her home Norpace 100mg TID and Diltiazem 
120mg BID. We have started her on Norpace CR 100mg BID for 
rhythm control. No other medication changes were made. She 
should continue home ASA. Of note, she was noted to have high 
TSH (7.9) and normal free T4 (1.1). TSH elevation likely to 
non-thyroid processes in the setting of bradycardia and 
conduction abnormalities. Recommend re-checking TSH in ___ 
to rule out hypothyroidism. 
.
#. HTN - on presentation, pt was found to be hypotensive w/ SBP 
of 80-90s. Home Diltiazem was stopped, pt was given IV Fluids. 
BP improved overnight and pt was found to be hypertensive 
(150-170s/40-60s) on day of discharge. No antihypertensive 
medications were started to avoid dysrymias and worsening 
conduction abnormalities. We recommend that the subject of HTN 
be revisited on her ___ appt with PCP or ___ as she might 
benefit from ACE-inhibitor for pressure control. Would recommend 
avoiding any nodal blocking agents given underlying conduction 
disease. 
.  
# Delirium - on presentation to the floor, pt was noted to be 
disoriented and delirious likely ___ medications (?Atropine). 
Mental status markedly improved within ___ hours. on 
discharge, pt was AOx3 and close to her baseline.
.  
# Vertigo/Emesis - Pt developed spells of vertigo and/or 
sensation of falling down; additionally, she had two episodes of 
emesis, associated w/ vertigo. These symptoms, too, were ikely a 
side effect of Atropine. Pt given Zofran and IV Fluids w/ 
complete relief. On discharge, denies nausea, dizziness, 
vertigo.   
.  
# Acute renal failure: On initial labs, it was noted that pt's 
creatinine was 1.2. Unknown baseline. Possibly from either 
dehydration or from poor forward flow in the setting of brief 
episodes of hypotension. Pt was given IV Fluids. Creatinine 
improved to .8 on day of discharge.
.  
#. Coagulopathy: INR 1.4. Likely from nutritional status.  
Recommend re-checking on PCP ___.  
.  
#. FEN: Soft regular diet w/ thin liquids.  
.  
#. Gait instability: ___ consult was obtained and she went home 
w/ home ___ and 24 hr supervision.
.  
#. Communication:  
Daughter - ___ ___  
.  
#. Code: Full code
 
Medications on Admission:
Disopyramide 100mg TID
Diltiazem 120mg BID
Aspirin 81mg BID
Travatan .004% QHS
Combigan .2-.5% BID
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO every twelve (12) hours.  
2. Travoprost 0.004 % Drops Sig: One (1) drop Ophthalmic QHS 
(once a day (at bedtime)).  
3. Combigan 0.2-0.5 % Drops Sig: One (1) drop Ophthalmic twice a 
day.  
4. Disopyramide 150 mg Capsule, Sustained Release Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sustained Release PO twice a day.

Home With Service

Bradycardia

Secondary:
Glaucoma

Left Ventricular Hypertrophy
Hypertension

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable vital signs: afebrile, systolic hypertension 
(150-170s/40-60s), pulse 60-70s. 

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to ___ for 
worsening weakness and slow pulse (30s). You were treated with 
Atropine, which helped increase your heart rate to ___. As you 
know, you were recently diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and 
congestive heart failure and were treated with Diltiazem and 
Norpace at home. 

The following medication changes were made:
Stop Diltiazem 120mg twice a day
Stop Norpace 100mg three times a day
Start Norpace CR 100mg twice a day
Continue Aspirin 81mg twice daily
Continue Travatan and Combigan eye drops

No other medication changes were made, you should continue all 
your other home medications as directed.

Please follow up with your Primary Care Doctor in the next 
several weeks.

If you lose consciousness, have chest pain, shortness of breath, 
lightheadedness or dizziness, high fever, severe abdominal pain 
or any other concerning symptoms, please seek medical care 
immediately.
