text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
OSH transfer for treatment of babesia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None.

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ PMH HTN, asplenia, SVT s/p ablation who 
presents as a transfer from ___ after a smear 
was concerning for babesiosis. He says the current presentation 
started 3 weeks ago. He first noticed he wasn't feeling well 
when he ate a burger at Five Guys with some friends and it felt 
like it took 2d to digest. He then developed a cough so a friend 
prescribed him a Z-pack. His symptoms did not resolve and he 
started developing fevers ranging from 100.4 to 103.3. He was 
also having such severe chills that at times he had to shut the 
AC off and turned the heat up to ___. 2d ago he presented to his 
PCP for the persistent cough and was prescribed Levofloxacin, 
and was told that if his symptoms did not improve by ___ 
he should get a CXR. The night prior to presentation he had 
drenching night sweats so he came to the ___ ED.  
 In the ___ ED he was found to be hyponatremic (128) 
with smear concerning for intracellular parasites so he was seen 
by ID. Parasite count and legionella antigen from OSH are 
pending. He was given CTX, atovaquone, and doxycycline. 
Initially he was afebrile on arrival but then spiked a fever to 
103.0 and was given APAP. He was also desaturating and requiring

Dear ___,

You were transferred to ___ with concern for a 
babesia infection. You were also found to have Lyme disease. 
This was causing fever, sweating, and cough.

You were seen here by our infectious disease specialists. You 
were started on several strong antibiotics that you will 
continue taking for several weeks. 

Because you don't have a spleen, you are at higher risk for 
infection. You should see your PCP for vaccinations to make sure 
you're up to date. If you EVER develop a fever over 100.4 or 
severe shaking chills, you should take an antibiotic pill 
(Augmentin) and see your doctor as soon as possible. We also 
recommend that you wear a medical alert bracelet explaining your 
asplenia.

work to ensure the infection is controlled.

you all the best.

Your ___ Health Team

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo LHW with h/o HTN and prior CVA with residual left sided 
weakness presents with acute right facial droop, N/V and 
nystagmus.

NEURO:
Patient presented to ED and code stroke called. NIHSS was 6, 
however 3 points were from prior CVA. This was considered a low 
score and t-PA was not indicated. CT, CTA and CTP showed no 
acute abnormalities, only evidence of old lacunar infarcts and 
atrophy. Patient's neurologic exam was significant for 
dysarthria, right facial droop, left gaze preference with 
inability to cross midline toward right side, with nystagmus on 
attempts to look right, left sided hemiparesis and hemisensory 
loss. She was also profusely vomiting despite receiving Zofran. 
Given multiple cranial nerve involvement, localization was 
thought to be brainstem, specifically pons. 
BP was allowed to autoregulate, and patient was started on ASA 
325mg. Home dose of statin was increased, and atenolol was 
halved during acute period. 
MRI showed a right lateral medullary/pontine-meduallary junction 
infarct on diffusion weighted imaging. The etiology was presumed 
to be ___. There was diffuse calcification of intracranial 
vessels, and it was thought that an artery-to-artery embolism 
could have originated from the right vertebral. 
TTE demonstrated an EF of 80% with normal wall motion. Telemetry 
revealed sinus rhythm with PACs. 
Further workup for embolic source was not completed given 
patient's age and comorbidites (ie baseline left hemiparesis), 
which make her a less than ideal candidate for coumadin. 
She had not been taking ASA, for unclear reasons, so this will 
be a good starting point. 

RESP:
Patient developed respiratory distress ___ the ED after several 
episodes of vomiting. She had impaired gag reflex, and likely 
aspirated. She required nonrebreather, and it was felt that she 
could not support breathing independently. The situation was 
discussed with patient and her son, and decision was made to 
intubate. 
CXR showed RML infiltrate c/w aspiration pneumonitis. Patient 
then had low grade fever and elevated WBC on day 2. She failed 
extubation ___ RR ___ and hypercarbia (pH 7.15). She was started 
on broad spectrum antibiotics.Treated with Cefepime for 4+ E. 
Coli starting ___ with stop date scheduled for ___. 

Due to concerns over inability to protect her airway the patient 
underwent tracheostomy and PEG placement on ___ with no 
complications.

Bronchoscopy performed on ___.  Showed purulence ___ RUL, all 
other lung fields clear.  Coverage initally broadened to 
Vancomycin but subsequently narrowed on ___ when results of 
BAL showed only 1+ GNR. 
   
On day of transfer out of the unit, pt had shown to be able to 
tolerate trach collar oxygen flow and was said to not be 
ventilator dependent.   

CV:
BP not well controlled with home meds atenolol and lisinopril, 
amlodipine 5mg QD started ___ addition on ___. 

ID:
Developed aspiration PNA as above.  Stop date for AB therapy 
(Cefepime) was ___. There was PSEUDOMONAS AERUGINOSA by BAL on 
___ that was pan-sensitive. Subsequently you were started on 
ceftriaxone for and a repaet U/A with culture and sensitivity 
are currently pending.

GI: recevied iv famotidine while ___ unit.  Pt given tube feeds

50cc/hr.

discontinued as blood sugars were consistenly  below 150.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admiited after presenting with nausea, vomiting,
dizzynes and double vision. A code stroke was called on you
after developing new right facial droop with slurred speech.
Upon evaluaiton here you had a NIHSS score of 2 and you were not
given t-PA. Your respiratory status quickly decompensated after
aspiration and you were intubated after DNI status was waived by
your son. You were found to have a new right medullary infarct.
You were not able to come off ventilator support and you
subsequently recieved a tracheostomy and PEG tube. You were
transfered to the floor for further care. Your course was
complicated by infection. You had a BAL that was significant for
pseudomonas that was pan sensitive. You had an 8 day course of
cefepime. Your WBC count rose on ___. You were started on
ceftriaxone 1g qday on ___. You had a U/A and a culture of
your tracheostomy site done. You had hypertension and a
titration of your anti-hypertensives were made. You are on
norvasc 10mg and lisinopril 40mg daily You are to be transferred
to ___. You have ongoing tube feeds and have pending
urinealysis.

Physical Exam:
On exam, the patient is a well appearing female with no cervical
or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.  Abdomen is soft, NT with no
hernias.  No prior abdominal incisions.  ___ are warm and well
perfused without edema.  

Breast: Bilateral pectoralis and latissimus muscle functioning
normally; left breast with 4cm transverse incision at the 2
o'clock position

Parameters
               Right     Left
SN-N               24            24.5
NAC               5x5           5x5       
Breast width       12.5          12.5            
Nipple to IMF       9.5           9.5                          
Grade ptosis       3             3              

ASSESSMENT/PLAN:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with a newly diagnosed left
breast cancer in the setting of prior BCT to the same breast. 

Today, I reviewed the entire spectrum of breast reconstructive
therapy including immediate, delayed, and delayed immediate
reconstruction and delayed.  Similarly, we discussed implant
(tissue expander/implant) versus autologous (pedicled TRAM, free
TRAM, ___, Latissimus) reconstructive options as well as hybrid
procedures (latissimus with implant).  We discussed the
trade-offs of each school of reconstruction including the 
shorter
operative times with implant based reconstruction although the
implants themselves have a limited life span and are not as
natural when palpated.   With autologous reconstruction, longer
operative times are balanced with more natural tissues though 
the
patient ___ have additional donor sites and recovery.  

The patient understands the operations, the options, the 
expected
outcomes and the potential risks and complications that include,
but are not limited to: infection, scarring, bleeding, unsightly
scarring, wound separation and delayed healing, fluid
collections, hematomas, need for repeated aspirations, partial 
or
complete skin flap necrosis and loss, expander
extrusion/leak/infection, implant leak and deflation/silicone
extrusion, implant infection, capsular contracture formation 
with
hardening of the breast or change in shape, asymmetry, contour
irregularities, need for further surgery, loss of flap including
potential emergent surgery.

Lastly, there are serious but extremely uncommon complications
related to receiving an anesthetic. Furthermore, I explained 
that
there are so many variables that exist in the healing process
that affect the final outcome.  These are not entirely
predictable and that final results may be disappointing despite
all surgery and care being done appropriately.  The patient
understands these risks and all of her questions were answered. 

The patient is strongly interested in an autologous based
reconstruction and, given her prior BCT, this would be ideal. 
The patient is strongly interested in pursuing an immediate ___
flap reconstruction which is also very appropriate.  ___ d/w 
Dr.
___.  ___ obtain a pre-operative CTA of the abdomen.

Thank you for this kind referral.

I have spent 60 total minutes face-to-face with this patient.
Over half of that time was spent in counseling the patient on 
her
anticipated breast defects. We discussed reconstructive options.

COLON POLYP                                                     
DCIS                                                            
DCIS                                                            
HYPERLIPIDEMIA                                                  
HYPERTENSION                                                    
MELANOMA

drains in place holding suction serosanguinous output present
Abdominal incisions all c,d,i

Unremarkable post operative course

Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left Breast Cancer
 
Discharge Condition:
Excellent

 
Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care:
1. You may keep your incisions open to air or covered with a 
clean, sterile gauze that you change daily. If any areas develop 

blistering, you ___ need to apply Bactroban cream twice a day. 
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with soap and water. 
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day. 
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. Your drains ___ be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount. 
5. DO NOT wear a normal bra for 3 weeks. You may wear a soft, 
loose camisole for comfort. 
6. You may shower daily with assistance as needed. Be sure to 
secure your upper drains to a lanyard that hangs down from your 
neck so they don't hang down and pull out. You may secure your 
lower drains to a fabric belt tied around your waist.
7. The Dermabond skin glue ___ begin to flake off in about ___ 

days. 
8. No pressure on your chest or abdomen 
9. Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your 
doctor. 
. 
Activity: 
1. You may resume your regular diet. 
2. Keep hips flexed at all times, and then gradually stand 
upright as tolerated. 
3. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity for 6 weeks following surgery. 
. 
Medications: 
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered . 
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 

for mild pain as directed on the packaging. 
3. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol. 
4. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish. 
5. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber. 
. 
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following: 
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 
. 
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
. 
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS 
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Endotracheal intubation
 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old gentleman found by police outside ___ 
agitated and running around naked, stating he had taken ___. 
En route to the ED, pt had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure 
and received 1mg Ativan. Patient had a urine tox positive for 
cocaine.  

In the ED the patient remained agitated, diaphoretic, with 
dilated pupils. Initial vitals were: T 38.3 HR 160 BP 170s/80s 
O2 sat 100% in RA. The patient was intubated for agitation and 
sedated with propofol and versed. Per MICU note, after 
intubation, patient's vitals improved to SBP of 110s-120s, HR to 
110s, and Temperature of 37.1. Initial labs were notable for Na: 
154, Cl. 109, Cr. 1.4 pH initially 6.96 on VBG, then 7.06 on ABG 
and then 7.41 on ABG, lactate of 16.7, CPK 1065, ___: 12.8, INR: 
1.2 Serum tox negative. He was given 2 amps of sodium bicarb and 
started on sodium bicarb gtt at 150 ml/hr. Pt also given 4 mg of

___ CXR

FINDINGS: Single AP view of the chest was reviewed. The 
endotracheal tube is
present 9.2 cm above the carina. The enteric tube is present 
with distal tip
and sideholes in the stomach. Cardiomediastinal and hilar 
contours are stable.
There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Lungs are well 
expanded and
clear.  There is no focal consolidation concerning for 
pneumonia.  
 
IMPRESSION: Endotracheal tube malpositioned. Advancement by 
several
centimeters is recommended. No acute cardiopulmonary process.

___ C-spine CT noncon
FINDINGS:  There is no fracture or malalignment of the cervical 
spine.  The
atlanto-occipital and -axial articulations are intact.  There is 
no
prevertebral soft tissue edema, though there are NG and ET tubes 
coursing
through the visualized pharynx.  There is no cervical 
lymphadenopathy.  The
thyroid gland is normal.  The visualized lung apices are clear.
 
IMPRESSION:  No acute fracture or malalignment of the cervical 
spine.

___ Head CT Noncon
IMPRESSION:
1.  No acute intracranial abnormality.
2.  2.7 cm mass partially imaged within the right maxillary 
sinus compatible
with a juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).  Further 
imaging with
dedicated MR is recommended.
 
NOTE ADDED IN ATTENDING REVIEW:  In overall appearance, the 
maxillary mass
would be quite atypical for JNA, which generally show present as 
a soft-tissue
mass in the nasopharynx or nasal cavity, a mass in the 
pterygopalatine fossa,
or erosion of posterior osseous margin of the sphenopalantine 
foramen
extending to the base of the medial pterygoid plate.  Rarely, 
JNA may be
limited to the maxillary sinus.
 
Other entities such as inflammatory polyp (particularly given 
the history) and
even malignant sinus tumor should be considered, and biopsy may 
be considered,
depending on the clinical context.

possible wandering
atrial pacemaker. Right ventricular conduction delay with 
vertical QRS axis.
Slightly peaked sinus P waves raising consideration of right 
atrial overload.
Prominent R wave in lead V4 may be a physiologic variant. 
Compared to the
previous tracing of ___ varying atrial pacemaker is now 
seen.

Extremely marked supraventricular tachycardia which is probably 
sinus, although
atrial tachcyardia is not excluded. P-R interval is about 120 
milliseconds.
Right bundle-branch block. Non-specific ST-T wave changes. 
Exclude an
right ventricular overload syndrome, if clinically indicated. No 
previous
tracing available for comparison. Clinical correlation is 
suggested.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ is an ___ male with pmh of marijuana, 
alcohol, and occasional cocaine presented w/ agitation who was 
admitted after being found agitated with hypertension, 
tachycardia, dilated pupils and a tonic-clonic seizure requiring 
intubation and found to have cocaine toxicity.

# Overdose:  Patient's utox was positive for cocaine with no 
other positives on urine or serum tox screen though unclear if 
the patient also ingested ___, a pure form of NMDA (which he 
had admitted to when he was picked up by the police). On further 
discussions with the patient and family members, he had ingested 
a combination of Adderall, cocaine and LSD. His presentation of 
extreme tachycardia, hypertension and hyperthermia was likely 
more consistent with cocaine toxicity than ___ per discussion 
with toxicology. He was maintained on a D5W drip with 
bicarbonate for pH target range between 7.45-7.55 especially 
given the QRS prolongation seen on ECG in the ED. ECGs were 
obtained q6h for QRS monitoring and his intervals did normalize 
over his course in the ICU. At time of transfer to the floor, 
comprehensive urine and serum toxicology panels had been sent to 
___ for further analysis. Pt was stable on floor and mentating 
normally but held overnight per toxicology given concern for 
continued sympathomimetic effect as he was tachycardic with even 
slight exertion despite fluid bolus. F/u EKGs showed narrowing 
of QRS and return to baseline. He was discharged with stable 
vital signs after improved hydration and waning sympathomimetic 
effect.

# Airway compromise: The patient was intubated for non-secure 
airway secondary to agitation and tonic-clonic seizures. He was 
initially sedated with a combination of propofol and midazolam. 
These medications were weaned when the patient's vitals 
normalized and he was extubated without complications on HD#1.

# Elevated CK: Likely secondary to tonic-clonic seizures. The 
patient was initially given IVF rehydration, however his CK 
never reached a level >5,000 decreasing our suspicion for renal 
impairment. CK trended down daily from 1600s to 300s by day of 
discharge without intervention. 

# Lactic acidosis:  Likely explained by the seizure en route to 
the hospital as it rapidly returned to normal with fluids. 

Transitional issues:
-Patient will likely leave school this semester and return home 
to ___ where he will enter drug rehab facility
-Per pt's mother, will need psychiatric care as he has 
underlying emotional problems
-Will need PCP follow up, currently booked for appointment with 
___ ___
-Incidental finding requiring follow-up:
CT head on ___ visualized a "2.7 cm mass partially imaged 
within
the right maxillary sinus" - the differential diagnosis includes
juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), inflammatory polyp,
and even malignant sinus tumor.
Consider dedicated MRI and/or biopsy.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. ALPRAZolam 0.25 mg PO TID:PRN anxiety 
2. Minocycline 100 mg PO Q12H 
3. Loratadine Dose is Unknown  PO DAILY 
4. DiphenhydrAMINE 50-75 mg PO HS 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. DiphenhydrAMINE 50-75 mg PO HS 
2. Minocycline 100 mg PO Q12H 
3. ALPRAZolam 0.25 mg PO TID:PRN anxiety 
4. Loratadine 10 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cocaine overdose
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___:

As you know you were admitted here for agitation after a cocaine 
overdose. You were initially cared for in the ICU where you were 
intubated to help you breathe and your heart was monitored 
closely. You were soon transferred to the medicine floor where 
the activity of your heart was again monitored closely. You 
heart rate was too fast during much of your stay but slowed 
before discharge. During your admission, you denied any 
discomfort and after close observation the team felt that it was 
safe for you to return home. 

We highly encourage you to avoid using illicit drugs. It is very 
dangerous to your health and their effects can be life 
threatening. Additionally, using drugs may jeopardize your 
education which we know is very important to you.

Please make sure to follow up with your new primary care doctor.

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___ 
___, 

Your ___ Doctors
 
___ Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Bactrim
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
hypoxia, hypotension

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
You were transferred to ___ intubated and mechanically 
ventialted.
___ - Extubation and discontinuation of mechanical 
ventilation
___ - Bedside bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year-old Female with oxygen-dependent COPD, CAD, 
diastolic CHF, mitral stenosis, IDDM, HTN, HLD who presented to 
an ___ ED on ___ with acute hypoxic 
respiratory failure with oxygen saturations in the 81-85% on 2L 
NC and hypotension.
.
Her partner states that she had been feeling unwell for several 
days prior to this with fatigue, chills, one an episode of 
non-bloody emesis, "indigestion," decreased urine output, and 
back pain. She had completed a course of antibiotics and 
Prednisone as an outpatient earlier this month for presumed 
pneumonia. 
.
In the OSH ED, she was found to have acute renal failure with a 
creatinine of 1.9 (baseline 0.6). A CXR showed a right lower 
lobe infiltrate. Given her recent hospitalization 1-month prior, 
she was started on atypical coverage with Azithromycin as well 
as HCAP PNA coverage with Vancomycin and Zosyn. Her previous 
hospital course was complicated by an episode of hypercarbic 
respiratory failure requiring intubation, and she was intubated 
on ___ prior to bronchoscopy. She underwent a fiber-optic 
bronchscopy on ___ which showed clear tenacious secretions in 
the left mainstem, persistent bronchomalacia of the left 
mainsten, a stenosis of right middle lobe oriface. Biopsies 
showed acute inflammation and revealed no malignancy.  
.  
The patient was extubated to BiPAP following her bronchoscopy. 
She had an asystolic event with CPR and ROSC on ___ thought to 
be due to mucous plugging, resulting in re-intubation (___). 
Of note, the patient has had a similar event on a prior 
hospitalization. The etiology of this event was thought to be 
pulmonary in origin. 
.
She also underwent CT abdominal imaging on ___ given her 
back pain complaints on admission and known cardiovascular 
disease, which showed bilateral lower lobe infiltrates and a 
left adrenal adenoma without AAA. CT chest imaging showed no 
pulmonary embolism, no aortic dissection, but was notable for 
bilateral pleural effusions. There was high grade stenosis at 
the level of the SMA. 
.
She was transferred to ___ on ___ for involvement of 
interventional pulmonology given her bronchiomalacia and 
cardiology consult for her worsening mitral stenosis, and 
further work-up of of her renal failure.  
.  
On arrival to the MICU, the patient was intubated and sedated 
with Fentanyl and Versed. Patient has received intermittent IV 
Lasix dosing with adequate diuresis. A 2D-Echo demonstrated 
severe mitral annular calcification with mild stenosis and 
regurgitation, moderate to severe pulmonary HTN (PASP 58 mmHg) 
with a preserved LVEF of 55%. A bronchoscopy was performed on 
___ showing COPD, accessory cardiac bronchus, no focal 
stenosis. BAL showed 3+ PMNs, 1+ GPCs in pairs and clusters with 
commensal respiratory flora speciated. Her antibiotic coverage 
was focused to IV Vanc and she was maintained on Prednisone 40 
mg PO daily. She was successfully extubated on ___. Cardiac 
biomakers revealed a mild Troponin leak with flat CK-MBs. She 
received Lasix 40 mg IV x 1 prior to transfer and has been -5.7L 
for length-of-stay fluid balance. Of note, has intermittent 
episodes of discomfort, anxiety and bronchospasm with a history 
of mucus plugging. Prior to transfer, she was weaned from high 
flow oxygen fask mask to ___ NC.
.
On transfer to the floor, the patient appears fatigued but 
comfortable and is speaking in short sentences.
 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL & SURGICAL HISTORY:
1. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (baseline on ___ NC 
with baseline saturations in the 90-93% range; has had episodes 
of hypercarbic and hypoxic respiratory failure requiring 
intubation in the past) - question of bronchomalacia
2. Moderate mitral stenosis (severe annular mitral valve 
calcification with LAE; last 2D-Echo ___, MV gradient 8 mmHg, 
1+ MR, functional MS)
3. Congestive heart failure with preserved EF (attributed to 
mitral stenosis, diastolic dysfunction)
4. Coronary artery disease (question of prior anterior and 
inferior MI)
5. Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (on Levemir and Novolog)
6. Irritable bowel syndrome
7. Hypertension
8. Hypercholesterolemia
9. Peripheral vascular disease (s/p aortofemoral bypass, ___
10. s/p cholecystectomy
___. s/p hysterectomy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION EXAMINATION:
.
Vitals: T:98.0F BP:121/54 P:77 R:13 O2: 93% on vent  
General: intubated, sedated, responsive to voice  
HEENT: Sclera anicteric, OG tube in place,  
Neck: supple, JVP not elevated, right subclavian CVL in place  
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, ___ diastolic 
murmur, no rubs, gallops  
Lungs: Faint bibasilar crackles, no wheezes, rales, ronchi  
Abdomen: soft, obese, slightly distended, non-tender, bowel 
sounds present, no organomegaly  
GU: foley in place  
Ext: warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, slight nonpitting edema 
edema  
Neuro: sedated, reponsive to voice  
.
DISCHARGE EXAMINATION:
.
VITALS: 97.5  97.5  118/60  63  20  94% 3L NC    BG: 154-212 
mg/dL
I/Os: 1080 | 4375 (-3.2L/day, ___   weight: 74.3 kg
GENERAL: Appears in no acute distress. Alert and interactive.
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. EOMI. PERRL. Nares clear. 
Mucous membranes moist. 
NECK: supple without lymphadenopathy. JVD just above clavicle at 
90-degrees.
___: Regular rate and rhythm, without murmurs, rubs or gallops. 
S1 and S2 normal.
RESP: Decreased breath sounds bilaterally throughout with faint 
inspiratory crackles at bases. No wheezing, no rhonchi. Stable 
inspiratory effort.
ABD: soft, non-tender, mildly distended, with normoactive bowel 
sounds. No palpable masses or peritoneal signs. No CVA 
tenderness.
EXTR: no cyanosis, clubbing; 1+ pitting edema to dorsal ankles, 
2+ peripheral pulses
NEURO: CN II-XII intact throughout. Alert and oriented x 3. 
Strength ___ bilaterally (limited by effort), sensation grossly 
intact. Gait deferred.
 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:
.
___ 10:25PM BLOOD WBC-6.1 RBC-3.73* Hgb-11.3* Hct-33.8* 
MCV-91 MCH-30.3 MCHC-33.5 RDW-14.6 Plt ___
___ 10:25PM BLOOD ___ PTT-31.1 ___
___ 10:25PM BLOOD Glucose-260* UreaN-41* Creat-0.8 Na-143 
K-4.7 Cl-108 HCO3-30 AnGap-10
___ 04:27AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-17*
___ 10:25PM BLOOD CK-MB-1 cTropnT-0.04* proBNP-3293*
___ 04:27AM BLOOD CK-MB-1 cTropnT-0.06*
___ 08:02PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.04*
___ 10:25PM BLOOD Calcium-8.6 Phos-4.0 Mg-2.3
___ 10:29PM BLOOD Type-ART pO2-74* pCO2-55* pH-7.39 
calTCO2-35* Base XS-6
.
DISCHARGE LABS:
___ 05:40AM BLOOD WBC-9.0 RBC-3.95* Hgb-11.6* Hct-34.8* 
MCV-88 MCH-29.5 MCHC-33.4 RDW-14.8 Plt ___
___ 04:27AM BLOOD ___ PTT-28.8 ___
___ 05:45AM BLOOD Glucose-92 UreaN-36* Creat-1.1 Na-143 
K-3.8 Cl-96 HCO3-41* AnGap-10
___ 05:45AM BLOOD Calcium-10.0 Phos-5.0* Mg-2.0
.
URINALYSIS: None
.
MICROBIOLOGY DATA:
___ Blood culture - negative
___ MRSA screen - negative
___ Bronchoalveolar lavage - 3+ PMNs, 1+ GPC pairs, cluster, 
> 100K commensal respiratory flora
___ Bronchial washings - negative for malignant cells
.
IMAGING:
___ 2D-ECHO - The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is 
mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity 
size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF > 55%). The 
right ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with normal free 
wall contractility. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. There is 
severe mitral annular calcification. There is mild functional 
mitral stenosis (mean gradient 7 mmHg) due to mitral annular 
calcification. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to 
acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation may be 
significantly underestimated.] There is moderate to severe 
pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial 
effusion. Calcific mitral valve disease with mild stenosis and 
at least mild regurgitation. Mild symmetric LVH with normal 
global and regional systolic function. Dilated right ventricle 
with preserved systolic function. Moderate to severe pulmonary 
hypertension.  
.
___ CHEST (PORTABLE AP) - In comparison with the study of 
___, the monitoring and support devices are essentially 
unchanged. There is continued substantial enlargement of the 
cardiac silhouette with pulmonary edema and bilateral effusions 
with compressive atelectasis at the bases. An area of increased 
opacification that is more confluent in the mid-lung on the 
right could reflect atelectasis or 
pneumonia.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with a PMH significant for oxygen-dependent chronic 
obstructive pulmonary disease (2L NC at home), coronary artery 
disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, type 2 diabetes 
mellitus on insulin, and hypertension admitted to OSH with 
hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation. She was 
transferred to ___ for concern for bronchomalacia requiring 
stenting. However, she improved with treatment for health care 
associated pneumonia, acute on chronic diastolic heart failure, 
and COPD, and did not require bronchial stenting. 
.
#ACUTE HYPOXEMIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE/CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE 
PULMONARY DISEASE EXACERBATION/ACUTE-on-CHRONIC DIASTOLIC HEART 
FAILURE/PNEUMONIA:
Patient was transferred from ___ following 
intubation for respiratory failure and concern for 
bronchomalacia as significant contributor (bronch there showed 
clear tenacious secretions in the left mainstem, persistent 
bronchomalacia of the left mainsten, and stenosis of right 
middle lobe oriface - biopsies revealed no malignancy). At ___ 
she was continued on treatment for HCAP with Vancomycin and 
Zosyn was aggressively diuresed with improvement. She underwent 
bronchoscopy just prior to extubation which did not show 
stenosis and BAL fluid grew only commensal flora after abx. She 
was extubated and completed treatement with a course of 
Vancomycin for ___s started on a prednisone taper 
given likely exacerbation of COPD as a contributor to 
respiratory failure. She was discharged to continue a prolonged 
taper as recommended by her outpatient pulmonologist. She also 
endorsed increased lower extremity swelling and increased 
abdominal girth in the month leading up to hospitalization along 
with weight gain and it was felt that worsening diastolic heart 
failure was a significant contributor to her respiratory 
symptoms. A repeat 2D-Echo showed preserved EF with mild 
symmetric LVH and severe mitral annulus calcification but only 
mild mitral stenosis and 1+ MR and pulmonary HTN. She was 
diuresed aggressively to a weight of 74kg on discharge with 
improvement in her respiratory symptoms (although not completely 
back to her baseline respiratory function-on 3L O2 by NC instead 
of usual 2L). She was continued on her home BB/ACEI as well as 
COPD bronchodilators and inhaled steroid. She was discharged to 
follow up with her Cardiologist, PCP, and ___ for f/u 
of her COPD, heart failure, and renal function and to assess the 
need for any changes to her diuretic and COPD regimen.
.
# CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE, HYPERLIPIDEMIA, Hypertension:
Patient was continued on home aspirin, statin, Carvedilol, ACEI, 
long acting nitrate. 
.
#Type 2 DIABETES MELLITUS ON INSULIN - The patient has known 
IDDM and her home glucose range is noted to be 60-180s mg/dL, 
per the patient. She is controlled with Levemir 72 units SC QHS 
and Novolog sliding scale prior to meals. She was treated with 
Lantus +SSI during admission and transitioned back to her home 
Levemir on discharge.
.
TRANSITION OF CARE ISSUES:
1. Consider outpatient evaluation of MR, MS, diastolic heart 
failure and CAD with Cardiology - no acute indications for 
balloon valvuloplasty at this time (prefers to see ___, 
MD)
2. Monitoring oxygen saturations. Patient will continue on home 
oxygen therapy with goal oxygen saturation of 88-93% on 2.5-3L 
of oxygen via nasal cannula
3. Pulmonary rehabilitation is recommeneded and a prescription 
was provided
4. Patient will continue on steroid taper, as follows: Take 30 
mg by mouth for 3-days ___ to ___. Take 20 mg by mouth 
for 3-days ___ to ___. Take 10 mg thereafter until 
follow-up.
5. Patient will be discharged on low dose narcotic for pain 
control and Flexeril for muscle spasm given her lower back 
complaints. AVOID taking this medication if you anticipate 
driving, or while consuming alcohol.
6. Patient should have her electrolytes checked (sodium, 
potassium, chloride, bicarbonate, BUN, creatinine and magnesium) 
on ___ - to help in determining appropriate 
home diuretic regimen. These results should be faxed to her 
primary care physician's office. She was discharged on Lasix 
80mg po BID to maintain goal weight of 74kg.
7. Please check daily weights. Her DRY WEIGHT is estimated at 
74-kg. Please check daily weight and HOLD Lasix dose in the 
evening if her weight is dropping. 
8. Please provide teaching regarding low sodium and cardiac 
healthy diet strategies.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Albuterol/ipratropium (Combivent) nebulizers Q4-6H PRN 
wheezing
2. Fluticasone-salmeterol 500-50 1 puff INH BID
3. Tiotropium 18 mcg INH daily
4. Ambien 10 mg PO QHS
5. Lisinopril 10 mg PO daily
6. Isosorbide 30 mg PO daily
7. Rosuvastatin 20 mg PO QHS
8. Carvedilol 6.25 mg PO BID
9. Lasix 60 mg PO daily
10. Aspirin 81 mg PO daily
11. Levemir 72 units SC QHS
12. Novolog ___ units pre-prandial with meals
13. Vitamin Co-Q10 1 tablet PO daily
14. Iron 198 mg PO daily
15. Magnesium 250 mg PO QHS
16. Vitamin C
17. Vitamin D-calcium supplement
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Combivent ___ mcg/actuation Aerosol Sig: One (1) nebulizer 
Inhalation every ___ hours as needed for shortness of breath or 
wheezing.  
2. fluticasone-salmeterol 500-50 mcg/dose Disk with Device Sig: 
One (1) puff Inhalation twice a day.  
3. tiotropium bromide 18 mcg Capsule, w/Inhalation Device Sig: 
One (1) capsule Inhalation once a day.  
4. Ambien 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO at bedtime.  
5. lisinopril 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
6. isosorbide mononitrate 30 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr 
Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO once a day.  
7. rosuvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO at bedtime.  

8. carvedilol 3.125 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO BID (2 
times a day).  
9. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
10. Levemir 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: ___ (72) units 
Subcutaneous at bedtime.  
11. Novolog 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: ___ units Subcutaneous 
TID with meals.  
12. Co Q-10  Oral
13. iron  Oral
14. magnesium 250 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO at bedtime.  
15. Vitamin C  Oral
16. Calcium-Vitamin D  Oral
17. prednisone 20 mg Tablet Sig: see taper Tablet PO once a day: 
Take 30 mg by mouth for 3-days ___ to ___. Take 20 mg 
by mouth for 3-days ___ to ___. Take 10 mg thereafter 
until follow-up.
Disp:*6 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
18. prednisone 10 mg Tablet Sig: see taper Tablet PO once a day: 
Take 30 mg by mouth for 3-days ___ to ___. Take 20 mg 
by mouth for 3-days ___ to ___. Take 10 mg thereafter 
until follow-up.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
19. cyclobenzaprine 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at 
bedtime).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
20. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every ___ hours 
as needed for pain: AVOID taking this medication if you 
anticipate driving, or while consuming alcohol.
Disp:*25 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
21. Outpatient Physical Therapy
Patient needs pulmonary rehabilitation given her chronic 
obstructive pulmonary disease.
22. Outpatient Lab Work
Patient should have her electrolytes checked (sodium, potassium, 
chloride, bicarbonate, BUN, creatinine and magnesium) on 
___ - while on aggressive diuretic therapy. 
These results should be faxed to her primary care physician's 
office. FAX NUMBER: ___ (Dr. ___

23. Lasix 40 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO twice a day.
Disp:*120 Tablet(s)* Refills:*1*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnoses:
1. Acute on chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbation
2. Acute diastolic heart dysfunction
.
Secondary Diagnoses:
1. Moderate mitral stenosis
2. Mild mitral regurgitation
3. Coronary artery disease
4. Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (on Levemir and Novolog)
5. Hypertension
6. Hypercholesterolemia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Patient Discharge Instructions:
.
You were admitted to the Internal Medicine service at ___ 
___ on ___ regarding management of 
your acute respiratory issues. You were initially treated at 
___ and transferred to ___ with a 
breathing tube and requiring mechanical ventilation. The 
breathing tube was removed after aggressive diuresis and you 
were treated with steroids as well as antibiotics for pneumonia. 
You will be discharged with a steroid taper in discussion with 
Dr. ___, your outpatient pulmonologist. You improved 
and were able to wean back to your home oxygen requirement. 
Overall, your worsening clinical picture was likely related to 
an exacerbation in both respiratory and cardiac function. You 
will be discharged to a rehabilitation facility where you will 
improve your strength.
. 
Please call your doctor or go to the emergency department if:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* You develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or 
wheezing.
* You are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids, or your 
medications.
* If you are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea, or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include: dry 
mouth, rapid heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit, or have a 
bowel movement.
* You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience an unusual discharge.
* Your pain is not improving within 12 hours or is not under 
control within 24 hours.
* Your pain worsens or changes location.
* You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
* You develop any other concerning symptoms.
.
CHANGES IN YOUR MEDICATION RECONCILIATION:
.
* Upon admission, we ADDED: 
START: Prednisone taper, as directed (Take 30 mg by mouth for 
3-days ___ to ___. Take 20 mg by mouth for 3-days 
___ to ___. Take 10 mg thereafter until follow-up)
START: Cyclobenzaprine 10 mg by mouth at nighttime as needed for 
back spasm
START: Oxycodone 5 mg by mouth every ___ hours as needed for 
severe pain  
.
* Upon admission, we CHANGED:
We CHANGED: Lasix from 60 mg by mouth daily to 80 mg by mouth 
twice daily (with dose adjustment based on any evidence of leg 
swelling, shortness of breath)
.
* The following medications were DISCONTINUED on admission and 
you should NOT resume: NONE
.
* You should continue all of your other home medications as 
prescribed, unless otherwise directed above.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ 05:45AM BLOOD Glucose-92 UreaN-36* Creat-1.1 Na-143
K-3.8 Cl-96 HCO3-41* AnGap-10
___ 05:45AM BLOOD Calcium-10.0 Phos-5.0* Mg-2.0
.
URINALYSIS: None
.
MICROBIOLOGY DATA:
___ Blood culture - negative
___ MRSA screen - negative
___ Bronchoalveolar lavage - 3+ PMNs, 1+ GPC pairs, cluster,
> 100K commensal respiratory flora
___ Bronchial washings - negative for malignant cells
.
IMAGING:
___ 2D-ECHO - The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is
mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity
size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF > 55%). The
right ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with normal free
wall contractility. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. There is
severe mitral annular calcification. There is mild functional
mitral stenosis (mean gradient 7 mmHg) due to mitral annular
calcification. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to
acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation may be
significantly underestimated.] There is moderate to severe
pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial
effusion. Calcific mitral valve disease with mild stenosis and
at least mild regurgitation. Mild symmetric LVH with normal
global and regional systolic function. Dilated right ventricle
with preserved systolic function. Moderate to severe pulmonary
hypertension.
.
___ CHEST (PORTABLE AP) - In comparison with the study of
___, the monitoring and support devices are essentially
unchanged. There is continued substantial enlargement of the
cardiac silhouette with pulmonary edema and bilateral effusions
with compressive atelectasis at the bases. An area of increased
opacification that is more confluent in the mid-lung on the
right could reflect atelectasis or
pneumonia.
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with a PMH significant for oxygen-dependent chronic
obstructive pulmonary disease (2L NC at home), coronary artery
disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, type 2 diabetes
mellitus on insulin, and hypertension admitted to OSH with
hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation. She was
transferred to ___ for concern for bronchomalacia requiring
stenting. However, she improved with treatment for health care
associated pneumonia, acute on chronic diastolic heart failure,
and COPD, and did not require bronchial stenting.
.
#ACUTE HYPOXEMIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE/CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE
PULMONARY DISEASE EXACERBATION/ACUTE-on-CHRONIC DIASTOLIC HEART
FAILURE/PNEUMONIA:
Patient was transferred from ___ following
intubation for respiratory failure and concern for
bronchomalacia as significant contributor (bronch there showed
clear tenacious secretions in the left mainstem, persistent
bronchomalacia of the left mainsten, and stenosis of right
middle lobe oriface - biopsies revealed no malignancy). At ___
she was continued on treatment for HCAP with Vancomycin and
Zosyn was aggressively diuresed with improvement. She underwent
bronchoscopy just prior to extubation which did not show
stenosis and BAL fluid grew only commensal flora after abx. She
was extubated and completed treatement with a course of
Vancomycin for ___s started on a prednisone taper
given likely exacerbation of COPD as a contributor to
respiratory failure. She was discharged to continue a prolonged
taper as recommended by her outpatient pulmonologist. She also
endorsed increased lower extremity swelling and increased
abdominal girth in the month leading up to hospitalization along
with weight gain and it was felt that worsening diastolic heart
failure was a significant contributor to her respiratory
symptoms. A repeat 2D-Echo showed preserved EF with mild
symmetric LVH and severe mitral annulus calcification but only
mild mitral stenosis and 1+ MR and pulmonary HTN. She was
diuresed aggressively to a weight of 74kg on discharge with
improvement in her respiratory symptoms (although not completely
back to her baseline respiratory function-on 3L O2 by NC instead
of usual 2L). She was continued on her home BB/ACEI as well as
COPD bronchodilators and inhaled steroid. She was discharged to
follow up with her Cardiologist, PCP, and ___ for f/u
of her COPD, heart failure, and renal function and to assess the
need for any changes to her diuretic and COPD regimen.
.
# CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE, HYPERLIPIDEMIA, Hypertension:
Patient was continued on home aspirin, statin, Carvedilol, ACEI,
long acting nitrate.
.
#Type 2 DIABETES MELLITUS ON INSULIN - The patient has known
IDDM and her home glucose range is noted to be 60-180s mg/dL,
per the patient. She is controlled with Levemir 72 units SC QHS
and Novolog sliding scale prior to meals. She was treated with
Lantus +SSI during admission and transitioned back to her home
Levemir on discharge.
.
TRANSITION OF CARE ISSUES:
1. Consider outpatient evaluation of MR, MS, diastolic heart
failure and CAD with Cardiology - no acute indications for
balloon valvuloplasty at this time (prefers to see ___,
MD)
2. Monitoring oxygen saturations. Patient will continue on home
oxygen therapy with goal oxygen saturation of 88-93% on 2.5-3L
of oxygen via nasal cannula
3. Pulmonary rehabilitation is recommeneded and a prescription
was provided
4. Patient will continue on steroid taper, as follows: Take 30
mg by mouth for 3-days ___ to ___. Take 20 mg by mouth
for 3-days ___ to ___. Take 10 mg thereafter until
follow-up.
5. Patient will be discharged on low dose narcotic for pain
control and Flexeril for muscle spasm given her lower back
complaints. AVOID taking this medication if you anticipate
driving, or while consuming alcohol.
6. Patient should have her electrolytes checked (sodium,
potassium, chloride, bicarbonate, BUN, creatinine and magnesium)
on ___ - to help in determining appropriate
home diuretic regimen. These results should be faxed to her
primary care physician's office. She was discharged on Lasix
80mg po BID to maintain goal weight of 74kg.
7. Please check daily weights. Her DRY WEIGHT is estimated at
74-kg. Please check daily weight and HOLD Lasix dose in the
evening if her weight is dropping.
8. Please provide teaching regarding low sodium and cardiac
healthy diet strategies.

Discharge Instructions:
Patient Discharge Instructions:
.
You were admitted to the Internal Medicine service at ___
___ on ___ regarding management of
your acute respiratory issues. You were initially treated at
___ and transferred to ___ with a
breathing tube and requiring mechanical ventilation. The
breathing tube was removed after aggressive diuresis and you
were treated with steroids as well as antibiotics for pneumonia.
You will be discharged with a steroid taper in discussion with
Dr. ___, your outpatient pulmonologist. You improved
and were able to wean back to your home oxygen requirement.
Overall, your worsening clinical picture was likely related to
an exacerbation in both respiratory and cardiac function. You
will be discharged to a rehabilitation facility where you will
improve your strength.
.
Please call your doctor or go to the emergency department if:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or
tightness.
* You develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or
wheezing.
* You are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids, or your
medications.
* If you are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting,
diarrhea, or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include: dry
mouth, rapid heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit, or have a
bowel movement.
* You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your
urine, or experience an unusual discharge.
* Your pain is not improving within 12 hours or is not under
control within 24 hours.
* Your pain worsens or changes location.
* You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
* You develop any other concerning symptoms.
.
CHANGES IN YOUR MEDICATION RECONCILIATION:
.
* Upon admission, we ADDED:
START: Prednisone taper, as directed (Take 30 mg by mouth for
3-days ___ to ___. Take 20 mg by mouth for 3-days
___ to ___. Take 10 mg thereafter until follow-up)
START: Cyclobenzaprine 10 mg by mouth at nighttime as needed for
back spasm
START: Oxycodone 5 mg by mouth every ___ hours as needed for
severe pain
.
* Upon admission, we CHANGED:
We CHANGED: Lasix from 60 mg by mouth daily to 80 mg by mouth
twice daily (with dose adjustment based on any evidence of leg
swelling, shortness of breath)
.
* The following medications were DISCONTINUED on admission and
you should NOT resume: NONE
.
* You should continue all of your other home medications as
prescribed, unless otherwise directed above.
Followup Instructions:
___

yesterday with weight of 67 pounds. Her weight this AM was 64.8

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with history of 
anorexia nervosa (admit BMI 10.7, 51.2% IBW), depression with 
recent suicide attempt, and anxiety who presents from ___ 
___ for anorexia, severe malnutrition, and 
weight loss.
  
# Severe Malnutrition
# Anorexia Nervosa: 
Patient was maintained on an eating disorder refeading protocol 
as below. Most recently, patient failed breakfast on ___, was 
informed after lunch, mother and patient upset that she was 
informed "late". Exam with stable hypotension and bradycardia. 
Orthostasis stable. 
-By discharge, we were checking Chem-10 QOD and they remained 
stable. Would recommend approximately weekly Chem-10 checks once 
at ___ EDU, to be determined by medical director there.
    
EATING DISORDER PROTOCOL:
- Daily weights at 5AM and strict I/Os
- Daily orthostatics 
- Chem 10 every other day (check ___
- Social Work, psychiatry, and nutrition consults
- Monitor electrolytes for refeeding syndrome

# Bradycardia: Secondary to anorexia and resolved prior to 
discharge.

# Anxiety and Depression: Denied suicidal ideation during 
admission, and has come to terms with the stimuli that 
precipitated her previous attempt. She is exhibiting future 
planning and has no suicide plan. Psych followed in house and 
there were no high risk features. Sitter remained with patient 
only during meals. Continued home medications (temazepam, 
clonazepam, gabapentin)
   
# CODE: Full
# CONTACT: Mother ___ (___)

Bradycardia

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

It was a pleasure being a part of your care during your 
admission to ___.  You were 
transferred from ___ due to vital sign instability in the 
setting of extremely low weight. You were placed on the eating 
disorder protocol and closely monitored.

After stability was confirmed and adequate parameters were met, 
you were discharged into your mother's care with the plan of 
going to the ___ EDU the morning after discharge.

We wish you well on your recovery.

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team

IMAGING
========
CXR ___  
Standard positioning of the endotracheal and enteric tubes.  
Mild bibasilar 
atelectasis. 

NCHCT ___
No acute intracranial process.

Cath ___
- Elevated left and right heart filling pressures.
Â Cardiogenic shock.
Â Three vessel coronary artery disease.
Â Successful primary PCI for STEMI of the LAD coronary artery.

TTE ___
Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity 
size and extensive
regional systolic dysfunction c/w multivessel CAD or other 
diffuse process. Likely apical aneurysm
with mural thrombus. Appropriately positioned Impella catheter. 
Moderate tricuspid regurgitation.
Mild mitral regurgitation with normal valve morphology.
Compared with the prior TTE (images reviewed) of ___ , an 
apical thrombus is now seen (prior
study was not performed with Lumason and this may explain the 
difference as thrombus not seen in native
imaging/without Lumason).
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with hx of HTN, ___ disease, and HLD who 
presented to ED from ___ with altered mental status and 
seizure and was found to have EKG changes concerning for an 
anterior STEMI. The patient had a cath showing 100% stenosis 
pLAD, OM1 100% stenosis, RCA 100% stenosis proximal, mid, distal 
s/p DESx2 to LAD. Impella was placed for support. Overnight from 
___, the patient went into VT storm leading to a code 
with multiple shocks. He continued to have hemodynamic 
decompensation following this with poor mental status. He was 
eventually made CMO and passed away on ___.

#STEMI s/p POBA, DES x2 to LAD
#Cardiogenic shock s/p impella placement
#Elevated lactate
STEMI ___ 100% proximal LAD occlusion, 100% proximal OM1, 100%
RCA occlusion leading to decreased EF and poor cardiac output.
Extremities are remained cool. Urine output decreased and he was 
started on CRRT as below. Impella was placed during the cath but 
the patient continued to have worsening hemodynamics requiring 
pressors despite impella support. There were issues with suction 
events as well as VT storm as below. He was eventually made CMO, 
Impella was turned off and the patient passed away quickly 
after.

# VT storm
Pt with VT storm overnight ___, requiring multiple 
shocks, later
stabilized on lidocaine and amio drip.

#apical thrombus
Apical thrombus visualized on TTE on ___. Potentially occluding
the impella inflow. He received systemic AC with heparin

#HFrEF (___)
TTE with EF ~20%. Extensive regional systolic dysfunction c/w
multivessel CAD. Likely ___ ischemic cardiomyopathy.
PRELOAD:    CVP elevated, with evidence of increased right sided
filling pressures, PCWP elevated, was on CRRT, inotropy with
dobutamine
AFTERLOAD: dobutamine with uptrending SVRs. 
NHBK: held iso shock
INOTROPE:  dobutamine, levophed 
MECH SUPPORT: Impella CP

#Intubation
Encephalopathy likely due to cardiogenic shock and poor cerebral
perfusion. Intubated for airway protection due to altered mental
status.

#Seizure
Reported seizure at ___. Per daughter, pt was noted to be
talking, interactive and then started to stare into space, then
body became rigid and he started to shake. Was given Keppra in
the ED.

# ___ on CKD
Pt baseline Cr 1.16 (___). Likely ischemic ATN. Cr slightly
improved on CRRT.

# transaminases
Secondary to shock liver iso cardiogenic shock. 

# thrombocytopenia
236 downtrending to 93 this morning. thrombus, the device and
liver dysfunction, critical illness all potential etiologies

#HTN
Held anti-hypertensives iso cardiogenic shock

#HLD
Atorvastatin 80 mg 

___ disease
home sinemet

regional systolic dysfunction c/w multivessel CAD or other

with mural thrombus. Appropriately positioned Impella catheter.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with hx of HTN, ___ disease, and HLD who
presented to ED from ___ with altered mental status and
seizure and was found to have EKG changes concerning for an
anterior STEMI. The patient had a cath showing 100% stenosis
pLAD, OM1 100% stenosis, RCA 100% stenosis proximal, mid, distal
s/p DESx2 to LAD. Impella was placed for support. Overnight from

with multiple shocks. He continued to have hemodynamic
decompensation following this with poor mental status. He was
eventually made CMO and passed away on ___.

RCA occlusion leading to decreased EF and poor cardiac output.
Extremities are remained cool. Urine output decreased and he was
started on CRRT as below. Impella was placed during the cath but
the patient continued to have worsening hemodynamics requiring
pressors despite impella support. There were issues with suction
events as well as VT storm as below. He was eventually made CMO,
Impella was turned off and the patient passed away quickly
after.

shocks, later
stabilized on lidocaine and amio drip.

(LIMA-LAD and SVG-Ramus), hypertension, hyperlipidemia, CRI, 
unilateral vocal cord paralysis after CABG in ___, and 
sarcoidosis who presents now with exertional dyspnea and chest 
pain concerning for unstable angina.  

Mr. ___ did well s/p CABG in ___, though had recurrent chest 
pain ___ years later. Exercise thallium test ___ showed 
mild anteroapical ischemia, but given patient did not want to 
procede with repeat cath, he was continued on medical management 
of CAD. However, over the past several months he has had 
increasing exertional dyspnea, prompting repeat exercise 
thallium stess test on ___. This study showed no ischemia, 
but did show evidence of a borderline increase in LV filling 
pressure during exercise. Had echo ___, which showed mild 
concentric LVH, decreased LV diastolic compliance, and 
borderline pulmonary hypertension. LVEF was preserved.  
 
Patient had been started on furosemide 20mg daily by his 
cardiologist in late ___, given concern that exertional 
dyspnea may be secondary to ___. Patient's symptoms did not 
improve, and he also began to develop exertional chest pain. He 
describes the pain as a pressure-like sensation across his chest 
which is non-radiating and comes on after walking a short 
distance. The pressure is associated with mild dyspnea, but no 
dizziness, nausea, or diaphoresis. The pain resolves within one 
minute if he stops to rest. Over the past ___ days, he has also 
had similar chest pressure with minimal activity such as washing 
dishes. He saw his cardiologist for follow-up in clinic 
yesterday, who was concerned that his symptoms are due to 
recurrent ischemia. Cardiologist recommended right and left 
heart cath for further evaluation, and patient is admitted now 
for pre-cath hydration given CRI, with plans for cath early 
tomorrow morning.  

On arrival to the floor, patient is comfortable and denies any 
dyspnea or chest pain. Denies any HA, dizziness/lightheadedness. 
 

On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, 
TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the 
time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, hemoptysis, black stools 
or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He 
denies exertional buttock or calf pain. Does report chronic 
non-productive cough, chronic right-sided leg cramps at night. 
All of the other review of systems were negative.  

Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of PND, 
orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. 
Patient does report ___ pound weight gain over past several 
months.

IMAGING:
ECG ___: Normal sinus rhythm. Left atrial abnormality. 
Otherwise, tracing is within normal limits. No previous tracing 
available for comparison.  

CXR ___: 
1. Scattered interstitial and alveolar opacities. Differential 
diagnosis 
includes pulmonary sarcoidois, however, basilar changes suggest 
an additional interstial lung disease or superimposed pulmonary 
edema.  
2. Pleural irregularity, possible asbestos exposure.  

TTE ___: Regional left ventricular wall motion is normal. 
Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). 
Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. 
No thoracic aortic dissection is seen. Mild (1+) aortic 
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary 
artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no 
pericardial effusion.   

CTA Chest ___: 
1. No aortic dissection. 
2. Extensive moderately severe atherosclerosis of the aorta and 
its branches, including thoracic aortic arch ulcers as 
described, and ulcerated mixed plaque in the proximal left 
subclavian artery, of undetermined age. There is no periaortic 
bleeding. 
3. Occlusion of the left vertebral artery from its origin, of 
undetermined 
age. 
4. Extensive scarring in both apices and lung bases consistent 
with the given history of sarcoidosis, comparison with prior 
imaging is suggested to determine disease activity. 
5. Very mild pulmonary edema.  
6. Solid left renal lesion, possible renal cell carcinoma. 
7. Chronic mild scarring and traction bronchiectasis, right 
lower lobe. 

CARDIAC CATH ___ (Prelim):
Right dominant
LMCA 30% tapering distally
LAD 90% ostial stenosis
LCX 70% ostial stenosis
RCA 95% proximal stenosis
SVG-OM1 patent
LIMA-LAD unable to engage for selective injection because of 
tortuosity of left subclavian
Ascending aorta and arch - no obvious dissection

CARDIAC CATH ___: report pending
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ male with history of CAD s/p CABG, HTN, HL, CRI and 
sarcoidosis who presented for cardiac catheterization in setting 
of progressive dyspnea on exertion and new onset exertional 
chest pain, concerning for unstable angina.  

# Exertional Dyspnea/Chest Pain/CAD: Exertional dyspnea and 
chest pain prior to admission were concerning for unstable 
angina.  Patient underwent right and left heart cath on ___, 
which revealed patent SVG-OM1 graft, presumed patent LIMA-LAD 
graft, and new proximal 95% RCA stenosis.  Patient developed 
severe, non-pleuritic pain across his chest during the procedure 
and had vagal response, requiring administration of atropine and 
increased IVF.  He did not have any acute ST changes on ECG, and 
CTA chest was negative for dissection or PE.  Had slight 
troponin bump, which was felt to be secondary to demand ischemia 
in setting of hypotension from vagal response.  Patient was 
transferred to CCU for close BP monitoring, and later became 
hypertensive requiring nitro gtt.  Went back to cath lab on 
___ for repeat cath with DES placed to RCA.  Patient 
tolerated procedure well and did not have further CP during the 
admission.  He remained hemodynamically stable, and was weaned 
off nitro gtt.  Was discharged on regimen of aspirin 325mg 
daily, plavix 75mg daily, simvastatin, and metoprolol.  ACE 
inhibitor was not started given Cr slightly elevated above 
baseline, though patient would likely benefit from addition of 
ACEi if Cr remains stable in outpatient setting.  Patient will 
follow-up with his cardiologist within 1 week of discharge.

# Acute dCHF: Recent echo ___ showed preserved LVEF but 
evidence of diastolic dysfunction, and diastolic dysfunction 
also present on recent exercise thallium test.  TTE ___ 
showed EF >55%.  Cardiac cath revealed mildly increased right 
and left heart filling pressures, again consistent with 
diastolic dysfunction.  Patient's exam was suggestive of volume 
overload, and HTN was likely contributing to acute exacerbation 
of dCHF.  Patient's home furosemide dose increased from 20mg 
daily to 40mg daily on discharge.  He was continued on a beta 
blocker, though atenolol changed to metoprolol given underlying 
CKD.  Patient will likely benefit from an ACE inhibitor, though 
this was deferred to outpatient setting given Cr slightly above 
baseline during this admission.  

# Hypertension: Patient hypertensive on admission, and of note 
briefly required nitro gtt during his hospital course for 
management of hypertension.  His nifedipine dose was increased 
from 30mg daily to 60mg daily, and atenolol was changed to 
metoprolol given underlying CKD.  Patient will need BP monitored 
in follow-up, and may need further adjustment to 
anti-hypertensive regimen.  ___ benefit from ACE inhibitor, 
though this was deferred to outpatient provider given ___ 
elevated above baseline this admission.
 
# CKD: Baseline Cr 1.9, and Cr ranged 1.9-2.2 this admission.  
Patient received pre-cath hydration, as he is at higher risk for 
contrast-induced nephropathy given low GFR.  His Cr was stable 
during the admission, but should be rechecked in follow-up the 
week of ___.  As above, if Cr stable, patient will likely 
benefit from ACE inhibitor. 

# Hyperlipidemia: Continued simvastatin 20mg daily.  

# Sarcoidosis: CXR this admission revealed scattered 
interstitial and alveolar opacities, which could represent 
pulmonary sarcoidosis.  Patient will follow-up with his PCP.

# Left renal mass: CTA chest revealed incidental finding of 38 x 
37mm peripherally enhancing solid left renal lesion, concerning 
for a renal cell carcinoma.  Patient will follow-up with PCP 
within one week of discharge, and will likely need MRI for 
further evaluation based on radiology recommendations.  Pending 
MRI results, patient may require biopsy or resection, as well as 
referral to heme/onc if mass determined to be malignant.

PENDING AT TIME OF DISCHARGE:
-final cardiac catheterization report from ___

TRANSITIONAL CARE ISSUES:
-Patient's code status was DNR/DNI this admission
-Patient will likely need outpatient MRI for further evaluation 
of left renal mass, and may eventually need biopsy or resection 
of mass as well as referral to hematology/oncology if mass 
determined to be malignant
-Patient will need renal function checked at follow-up 
appointment week of ___
-Patient will need to be on aspirin 325mg daily, plavix 75mg 
daily x12 months
 
Medications on Admission:
Furosemide 20 mg daily (stopped yesterday)  
Atenolol 50 mg daily  
Simvastatin 20 mg daily  
Nifedipine 30 mg ER tablet daily  
Aspirin 325mg daily (dose increased ___  
MVI daily

Extended Release PO DAILY (Daily).

as needed for CAD: RCA DES.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis:
Coronary artery disease
Hypertension
Acute on chronic diastolic heart failure

Seconary Diagnoses:
Dyslipidemia
Chronic kidney disease
Sarcoidosis
Renal mass

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital for a cardiac catheterization, 
for further evaluation of your shortness of breath and chest 
pressure.  During your catheterization on ___, you developed 
the sudden onset of chest pain.  This was likely caused by 
having decreased blood flow to the heart because your blood 
pressure was low.  

You were briefly admitted to the ICU for close monitoring of 
your blood pressure, which improved.  You had a repeat cardiac 
catheterization on ___, and had a stent placed into one of 
the coronary arteries.  You will need to continue taking 
aspirin, and will also need to take a new medication called 
clopidogrel (plavix) daily for the next ___ months.  It is very 
important that you take this medication daily, and that you 
speak with Dr. ___ stopping it for any reason.

Your CT scan revealed that there is a mass on your left kidney, 
which could represent a cancer.  We will let Dr. ___ about 
this lesion.  You may need to have an MRI to look more closely 
at the kidney, and ultimately they may decide to either biopsy 
the lesion or remove it.

We made the following changes to your medications while you were 
here:
1. STARTED clopidogrel (plavix) 75mg daily
2. STOPPED atenolol
3. STARTED metoprolol tartrate 25mg twice daily
4. INCREASED furosemide to 40mg daily
5. INCREASED nifedipine to 60mg daily

Weigh yourself every morning, call your doctor if your weight 
goes up more than 3 lbs.

SVG-OM1 patent
LIMA-LAD unable to engage for selective injection because of
tortuosity of left subclavian
Ascending aorta and arch - no obvious dissection
CARDIAC CATH ___: report pending
Brief Hospital Course:
___ male with history of CAD s/p CABG, HTN, HL, CRI and
sarcoidosis who presented for cardiac catheterization in setting
of progressive dyspnea on exertion and new onset exertional
chest pain, concerning for unstable angina.
# Exertional Dyspnea/Chest Pain/CAD: Exertional dyspnea and
chest pain prior to admission were concerning for unstable
angina. Patient underwent right and left heart cath on ___,
which revealed patent SVG-OM1 graft, presumed patent LIMA-LAD
graft, and new proximal 95% RCA stenosis. Patient developed
severe, non-pleuritic pain across his chest during the procedure
and had vagal response, requiring administration of atropine and
increased IVF. He did not have any acute ST changes on ECG, and
CTA chest was negative for dissection or PE. Had slight
troponin bump, which was felt to be secondary to demand ischemia
in setting of hypotension from vagal response. Patient was
transferred to CCU for close BP monitoring, and later became
hypertensive requiring nitro gtt. Went back to cath lab on
___ for repeat cath with DES placed to RCA. Patient
tolerated procedure well and did not have further CP during the
admission. He remained hemodynamically stable, and was weaned
off nitro gtt. Was discharged on regimen of aspirin 325mg
daily, plavix 75mg daily, simvastatin, and metoprolol. ACE
inhibitor was not started given Cr slightly elevated above
baseline, though patient would likely benefit from addition of
ACEi if Cr remains stable in outpatient setting. Patient will
follow-up with his cardiologist within 1 week of discharge.
# Acute dCHF: Recent echo ___ showed preserved LVEF but
evidence of diastolic dysfunction, and diastolic dysfunction
also present on recent exercise thallium test. TTE ___
showed EF >55%. Cardiac cath revealed mildly increased right
and left heart filling pressures, again consistent with
diastolic dysfunction. Patient's exam was suggestive of volume
overload, and HTN was likely contributing to acute exacerbation
of dCHF. Patient's home furosemide dose increased from 20mg
daily to 40mg daily on discharge. He was continued on a beta
blocker, though atenolol changed to metoprolol given underlying
CKD. Patient will likely benefit from an ACE inhibitor, though
this was deferred to outpatient setting given Cr slightly above
baseline during this admission.
# Hypertension: Patient hypertensive on admission, and of note
briefly required nitro gtt during his hospital course for
management of hypertension. His nifedipine dose was increased
from 30mg daily to 60mg daily, and atenolol was changed to
metoprolol given underlying CKD. Patient will need BP monitored
in follow-up, and may need further adjustment to
anti-hypertensive regimen. ___ benefit from ACE inhibitor,
though this was deferred to outpatient provider given ___
elevated above baseline this admission.
# CKD: Baseline Cr 1.9, and Cr ranged 1.9-2.2 this admission.
Patient received pre-cath hydration, as he is at higher risk for
contrast-induced nephropathy given low GFR. His Cr was stable
during the admission, but should be rechecked in follow-up the
week of ___. As above, if Cr stable, patient will likely
benefit from ACE inhibitor.
# Hyperlipidemia: Continued simvastatin 20mg daily.
# Sarcoidosis: CXR this admission revealed scattered
interstitial and alveolar opacities, which could represent
pulmonary sarcoidosis. Patient will follow-up with his PCP.
# Left renal mass: CTA chest revealed incidental finding of 38 x
37mm peripherally enhancing solid left renal lesion, concerning
for a renal cell carcinoma. Patient will follow-up with PCP
within one week of discharge, and will likely need MRI for
further evaluation based on radiology recommendations. Pending
MRI results, patient may require biopsy or resection, as well as
referral to heme/onc if mass determined to be malignant.
PENDING AT TIME OF DISCHARGE:
-final cardiac catheterization report from ___
TRANSITIONAL CARE ISSUES:
-Patient's code status was DNR/DNI this admission
-Patient will likely need outpatient MRI for further evaluation
of left renal mass, and may eventually need biopsy or resection
of mass as well as referral to hematology/oncology if mass
determined to be malignant
-Patient will need renal function checked at follow-up
appointment week of ___
-Patient will need to be on aspirin 325mg daily, plavix 75mg
daily x12 months
Medications on Admission:
Furosemide 20 mg daily (stopped yesterday)
Atenolol 50 mg daily
Simvastatin 20 mg daily
Nifedipine 30 mg ER tablet daily
Aspirin 325mg daily (dose increased ___
MVI daily
Discharge Medications:
1. furosemide 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO once a day.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. simvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.
3. nifedipine 60 mg Tablet Extended Release Sig: One (1) Tablet
Extended Release PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet Extended Release(s)* Refills:*2*
4. aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
5. multivitamin Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
6. clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily)
as needed for CAD: RCA DES.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
7. metoprolol tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice
a day.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis:
Coronary artery disease
Hypertension
Acute on chronic diastolic heart failure
Seconary Diagnoses:
Dyslipidemia
Chronic kidney disease
Sarcoidosis
Renal mass
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted to the hospital for a cardiac catheterization,
for further evaluation of your shortness of breath and chest
pressure. During your catheterization on ___, you developed
the sudden onset of chest pain. This was likely caused by
having decreased blood flow to the heart because your blood
pressure was low.
You were briefly admitted to the ICU for close monitoring of
your blood pressure, which improved. You had a repeat cardiac
catheterization on ___, and had a stent placed into one of
the coronary arteries. You will need to continue taking
aspirin, and will also need to take a new medication called
clopidogrel (plavix) daily for the next ___ months. It is very
important that you take this medication daily, and that you
speak with Dr. ___ stopping it for any reason.
Your CT scan revealed that there is a mass on your left kidney,
which could represent a cancer. We will let Dr. ___ about
this lesion. You may need to have an MRI to look more closely
at the kidney, and ultimately they may decide to either biopsy
the lesion or remove it.
We made the following changes to your medications while you were
here:
1. STARTED clopidogrel (plavix) 75mg daily
2. STOPPED atenolol
3. STARTED metoprolol tartrate 25mg twice daily
4. INCREASED furosemide to 40mg daily
5. INCREASED nifedipine to 60mg daily
Weigh yourself every morning, call your doctor if your weight
goes up more than 3 lbs.
Followup Instructions:
___

Name: ___. Unit No: ___ Admission Date: ___ Discharge Date: ___ Date of Birth: ___ Sex: M Service: MEDICINE Allergies: No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions Attending: ___. Chief Complaint: Chest Pain, Hypoglycemia, Weakness Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: NONE History of Present Illness: ___ w/ hx IDDM, HTN, HLD, CKD who presents with weakness and chest pain. Patient reports that for the past two weeks he has felt fatigued. Patient states that he was feeling mildly weak this morning, and went to his outpatient nephrology appointment, and felt extremely weak and short of breath upon entering the building. He was pushed in a wheelchair, which when he felt lightheaded and started seeing floaters. He was noted to have a sugar of 29, was given juice with sugar improvement to 58, and then transferred to the emergency department. He denied any sweating, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, shortness of breath at the time. Of note he does note an episode of chest pain last night, which he describes as sharp, radiating up to the neck, lasting 30 minutes, associated with mild nausea, not associated with vomiting, shortness of breath, sweating. He says that this does feel similar to when he went into a. fib with RVR and developed chest pain. He took a lorazepam and the pain went away. Denies any fevers, chills, changes in urination, headaches, new changes in vision, recent travel, recent illness. Has been taking his insulin as prescribed, 15 units NovoLog twice a day in the morning and afternoon, and 20 units Lantus at night. This AM, the patient just ate an apple and ate no other food that day but still took his novolog twice that day. In regards to his cardiac history, the patient went to ___ last year after he developed chest pain. He was found to be in a. fib with RVR and then had a chemical stress test which was supposedly normal. He had another chemical stress test six months ago and was told that this was normal. He does not believe he has had a catherization. He just quit smoking 10 weeks ago. He has had some issues with intermittent diarrhea He recently underwent a right total hip replacement about two months ago and has limited mobility and ambulates with a cane. His only complaint is constipation that occurred today. He had diarrhea yesterday. This has been going on for over a year.
