Brief Hospital Course: Mr. ___ is a ___ w/ hx IDDM, HTN, HLD, CKD who presents with weakness secondary to hypoglycemia. ACUTE ISSUES: ============= #Hypoglycemia #Type ___ Diabetes Mellitus: Patient presented after feeling weak in his outpatient nephrologist's office and found to have a blood glucose of 29. Patient was given juice and brought to the ED with improvement in blood glucose. Of note, patient's home insulin regimen was recently changed to standing Novolog 15U BID and glargine 20U QHS and takes Novolog without regard to whether he is eating or not. Patient also has only been checking blood glucose ~1x per week and notes that it has been relatively well controlled. Patient's Novolog was discontinued after presentation and he received 10U glargine overnight. Patient is amenable to more frequent glucose checks (prior to each meal) and starting a sliding scale to help prevent hypoglycemic episodes. He also understands that he only needs to take Novolog if he is going to have a meal. He was discharged on home glargine 20U QHS and Novolog ISS. He agrees to have close follow up with his primary care physician to adjust dosage for better glucose control. #NSTEMI Patient found to have elevated troponins and CK-MB to 0.08 and 15, respectively, at time of presentation. EKG was similar to prior EKG in ___. Denied any symptoms of chest pain or shortness of breath. Repeat enzymes were downtrending, with Trop-T of 0.07 and CK-MB of 13. Suspect that patient had type ___ NSTEMI with underlying stable plaque and associated troponin leak in setting of acute stress related to hypoglycemia. Per patient, he had a normal stress test last year at ___. Given troponin leak, P-MIBI was not pursued but patient would likely benefit from stress test as outpatient. Patient was started on atorvastatin 80mg daily. He was kept on his home aspirin 81mg daily, carvedilol 12.5mg po BID, HCTZ 25mg po daily, and lisinopril 40mg daily. #Hyperkalemia Potassium elevated to 5.3 at presentation, unchanged from K on ___. Patient has history of CKD stage III and is on lisinopril as outpatient. EKG without peaked T waves. Given diabetes and proteinuria, patient was kept on lisinopril. His potassium remained stable at 5.2 at time of discharge. # Normocytic Anemia: Suspect to be related to underlying CKD. Up to date on colonoscopies and denying any melena or hematochezia. Hb stable during hospitalization, at 9.9 at discharge. Iron studies pending at time of discharge. CHRONIC ISSUES: =============== #CKD: Cr remained around 2, at baseline. #Hypertension: Continue anti-hypertensives as above #Insomnia: Continue trazodone #Anxiety: Continue sertraline TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ==================== New Medications: - Atorvastatin 80 mg PO/NG QPM Changed Medications: - Insulin Novolog 15U BID changed to sliding scale [] Diabetes - insulin regimen changed to glargine 20U QHS and Novolog ISS. Adjust as needed for better glucose control. [] Hyperkalemia - consider decreasing lisinopril or increasing HCTZ depending on BP [] Type ___ NSTEMI - consider outpatient P-MIBI for further evaluation [] Anemia - follow up iron studies #CODE: FULL, presumed #CONTACT: ___ (son) Medications on Admission: The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 2. Carvedilol 12.5 mg PO BID 3. Glargine 20 Units Bedtime
novolog 14 Units Q12H 4. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 5. Sertraline 75 mg PO DAILY 6. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 7. LORazepam 1 mg PO DAILY:PRN anxiety 8. TraZODone 150 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia Discharge Medications: 1. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM RX *atorvastatin 80 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth at bedtime Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0 2. FreeStyle Lite Meter (blood-glucose meter) 1 device miscellaneous ONCE RX *blood-glucose meter one Disp #*1 Kit Refills:*0 3. FreeStyle Lite Strips (blood sugar diagnostic) miscellaneous TID W/MEALS RX *blood sugar diagnostic [FreeStyle Lite Strips] TID w/ MEALS Disp #*100 Strip Refills:*0 4. Glargine 20 Units Bedtime Insulin SC Sliding Scale using HUM Insulin 5. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 6. Carvedilol 12.5 mg PO BID 7. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 8. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 9. LORazepam 1 mg PO DAILY:PRN anxiety 10. Sertraline 75 mg PO DAILY 11. TraZODone 150 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia Discharge Disposition: Home Discharge Diagnosis: PRIMARY DIAGNOSES: Type ___ Diabetes Mellitus Hypoglycemia Type ___ NSTEMI SECONDARY DIAGNOSES: Anemia Hypertension Discharge Condition: Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. Discharge Instructions: Dear Mr. ___, Thank you for choosing ___ for your site of care! Why was I admitted to the hospital? -You were admitted because you were found to have a low blood sugar. What was done for me while I was in the hospital? -You were given juice with improvement in your blood sugar. -Your home Novolog dosing was changed from 15U twice a day to sliding scale based on glucose value prior to meals. -Your blood work showed that your heart enzymes were elevated. We suspect this occurred due to the low blood glucose. You were monitored and had no chest pain. You will need further heart work up as an outpatient. What should I do when I leave the hospital? -You will need to have a cardiac stress test as an outpatient. -You will need to check your blood sugar before each meal and only take Novolog based on the sliding scale provided to you. -You need to keep track of your blood sugars and work with Dr. ___ to adjust your insulin dosing in the future. -Please continue to take all of your medications as prescribed. -Please follow up with the listed providers below. ** We changed your insulin. Please follow the instructions below and call Dr. ___ your blood sugar is less than 70 or greater than 400 before taking any sliding scale insulin. Again, please check your blood sugars three times per day and only take your Novolog if you are having a meal. At bedtime, check your blood sugar and if greater than 100, take your nightly dose of 20U Lantus. If less than 100, call your doctor before injecting the insulin. Before each meal, check your blood glucose. Only if you are planning on eating a meal, please inject Novolog at the following doses based on your blood sugar: - Blood sugar: less than 70 - drink juice and call your doctor - Blood sugar: 71-150 - none - Blood sugar: 151-200 - 2U Novolog - Blood sugar: 201-250 - 4U Novolog - Blood sugar: 251-300 - 6U Novolog - Blood sugar: 301-350 - 8U Novolog - Blood sugar: 351-400 - 10U Novol - Blood sugar: greater than 400 - call your doctor ___ wish you the best! Your ___ treatment team Followup Instructions: ___

Suspect that patient had type ___ NSTEMI with underlying stable plaque and associated troponin leak in setting of acute stress related to hypoglycemia. Per patient, he had a normal stress test last year at ___. Given troponin leak, P-MIBI was not pursued but patient would likely benefit from stress test as outpatient. Patient was started on atorvastatin 80mg daily. He was kept on his home aspirin 81mg daily, carvedilol 12.5mg po BID, HCTZ 25mg po daily, and lisinopril 40mg daily. #Hyperkalemia Potassium elevated to 5.3 at presentation, unchanged from K on ___. Patient has history of CKD stage III and is on lisinopril as outpatient. EKG without peaked T waves. Given diabetes and proteinuria, patient was kept on lisinopril. His potassium remained stable at 5.2 at time of discharge. # Normocytic Anemia: Suspect to be related to underlying CKD. Up to date on colonoscopies and denying any melena or hematochezia. Hb stable during hospitalization, at 9.9 at discharge. Iron studies pending at time of discharge. CHRONIC ISSUES: =============== #CKD: Cr remained around 2, at baseline. #Hypertension: Continue anti-hypertensives as above #Insomnia: Continue trazodone #Anxiety: Continue sertraline TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ==================== New Medications: - Atorvastatin 80 mg PO/NG QPM Changed Medications: - Insulin Novolog 15U BID changed to sliding scale [] Diabetes - insulin regimen changed to glargine 20U QHS and Novolog ISS. Adjust as needed for better glucose control. [] Hyperkalemia - consider decreasing lisinopril or increasing HCTZ depending on BP [] Type ___ NSTEMI - consider outpatient P-MIBI for further evaluation [] Anemia - follow up iron studies #CODE: FULL, presumed #CONTACT: ___ (son) Medications on Admission: The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 2. Carvedilol 12.5 mg PO BID 3. Glargine 20 Units Bedtime
novolog 14 Units Q12H 4. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 5. Sertraline 75 mg PO DAILY 6. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 7. LORazepam 1 mg PO DAILY:PRN anxiety 8. TraZODone 150 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia Discharge Medications: 1. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM RX *atorvastatin 80 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth at bedtime Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0 2. FreeStyle Lite Meter (blood-glucose meter) 1 device miscellaneous ONCE RX *blood-glucose meter one Disp #*1 Kit Refills:*0 3. FreeStyle Lite Strips (blood sugar diagnostic) miscellaneous TID W/MEALS RX *blood sugar diagnostic [FreeStyle Lite Strips] TID w/ MEALS Disp #*100 Strip Refills:*0 4. Glargine 20 Units Bedtime Insulin SC Sliding Scale using HUM Insulin 5. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 6. Carvedilol 12.5 mg PO BID 7. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 8. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 9. LORazepam 1 mg PO DAILY:PRN anxiety 10. Sertraline 75 mg PO DAILY 11. TraZODone 150 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia Discharge Disposition: Home Discharge Diagnosis: PRIMARY DIAGNOSES: Type ___ Diabetes Mellitus Hypoglycemia Type ___ NSTEMI SECONDARY DIAGNOSES: Anemia Hypertension Discharge Condition: Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. Discharge Instructions: Dear Mr. ___, Thank you for choosing ___ for your site of care! Why was I admitted to the hospital? -You were admitted because you were found to have a low blood sugar. What was done for me while I was in the hospital? -You were given juice with improvement in your blood sugar. -Your home Novolog dosing was changed from 15U twice a day to sliding scale based on glucose value prior to meals. -Your blood work showed that your heart enzymes were elevated. We suspect this occurred due to the low blood glucose. You were monitored and had no chest pain. You will need further heart work up as an outpatient. What should I do when I leave the hospital? -You will need to have a cardiac stress test as an outpatient. -You will need to check your blood sugar before each meal and only take Novolog based on the sliding scale provided to you. -You need to keep track of your blood sugars and work with Dr. ___ to adjust your insulin dosing in the future. -Please continue to take all of your medications as prescribed. -Please follow up with the listed providers below. ** We changed your insulin. Please follow the instructions below and call Dr. ___ your blood sugar is less than 70 or greater than 400 before taking any sliding scale insulin. Again, please check your blood sugars three times per day and only take your Novolog if you are having a meal. At bedtime, check your blood sugar and if greater than 100, take your nightly dose of 20U Lantus. If less than 100, call your doctor before injecting the insulin. Before each meal, check your blood glucose. Only if you are planning on eating a meal, please inject Novolog at the following doses based on your blood sugar: - Blood sugar: less than 70 - drink juice and call your doctor - Blood sugar: 71-150 - none - Blood sugar: 151-200 - 2U Novolog - Blood sugar: 201-250 - 4U Novolog - Blood sugar: 251-300 - 6U Novolog - Blood sugar: 301-350 - 8U Novolog - Blood sugar: 351-400 - 10U Novol - Blood sugar: greater than 400 - call your doctor ___ wish you the best! Your ___ treatment team Followup Instructions: ___

History of Present Illness:
Eu Critical, ___, aka ___, was last seen normal by 
her daughter at ___ on ___. She had been complaining of a 
headache for the past day, after being hit in the head with a 
box while at work at ___. She told her daughter that she 
could not go to work as she did not feel well and was dizzy, and 
laid on the ground where she was noted to have a facial droop 
and started to slur her speech. Her daughter called ___ where 
EMS noted to her to be flaccid on the right and a decreasing 
mental status en route. She was brought to ___ 
where she was intubated and a CT head showed a large left sided
intraparenchymal hemorrhage. She was then sent to ___ for 
further neurosurgical management. Upon arrival at ___, her 
pupils were non-reactive and anisocoric and she had extensor 
posturing in all four extremities. She was given 100g Mannitol 
and 1000mg Keppra. A Nicardipine gtt was initiated to maintain 
SBP<140.                                             

 
Past Medical History:
Hypertension

___

Non contributory.

Pertinent recent imaging:

Bilateral ___ US ___
IMPRESSION:    
No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the right or left lower 
extremity 
veins. 

CTA Chest ___
IMPRESSION:   
1. There is a re-demonstrated nonocclusive pulmonary embolism in 
the segmental branches of the left upper lobe as seen on the 
head and neck CTA performed earlier today.  No additional 
pulmonary emboli are visualized.  No imaging evidence of right 
heart strain. 
2. Emphysema. 
3. Additional findings above. 

CTA Head and Neck ___
IMPRESSION:   
1. Acute pulmonary embolus left upper lobe. 
2. Multifocal areas of intracranial arterial narrowing, may 
represent 
vasospasm,, differential diagnosis is vasculopathy. 
3. Grossly stable appearance following left craniotomy and 
decompression with persistent extracranial brain herniation.  
Minimal interval decreased size of rim enhancing left 
parenchymal subacute hematoma.  Follow-up recommended to 
document resolution. 
4. Stable mass effect, hydrocephalus. 
5. Multiple punctate infarcts are stable. 
6. Transverse sinuses better evaluated on prior MRI. 
7. No significant narrowing CTA neck. 
8. Diffusely enlarged thyroid gland, consider thyroiditis. 

MRI Head ___
IMPRESSION:    
Multiple punctate areas of restricted diffusion in the right 
temporal, 
parietal and frontal lobes in keeping with acute embolic 
infarcts.   
Filling defect in the left transverse sinus suggestive of dural 
venous sinus thrombosis, which is new compared to prior.   
The patient is status post left frontotemporoparietal 
decompressive surgery.  The hematoma is decreased in size and 
there is decreased mass effect.  The amount of transcranial 
herniated brain tissue is slightly increased compared to prior. 
There is two small rim enhancing extracranial collections 
anterior to the 
transcranial herniated brain tissue as described above.  These 
are nonspecific and may represent rim enhancing hematomas, but 
infection/abscesses should be considered in the differential 
diagnosis. 

Abominal US ___
IMPRESSION:    
Normal abdominal ultrasound. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ year-old woman with HTN who presents 
with acute onset dizziness followed by fall found to have large 
left temporoparietal ICH at OSH that increased on repeat imaging 
here at ___ with rightward midline shift and subfalcine 
herniation, s/p decompressive craniectomy on the left ___. 

#Left Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage
The patient was transferred intubated from OSH with a left sided 
intraparenchymal hemorrhage with surrounding edema. A repeat 
head CT was obtained upon arrival to ___ that showed worsening 
hemorrhage with increasing midline shift and herniation. A 
meeting was had with the family offering a surgical 
decompressive craniectomy as well as discussing her poor 
prognosis. It was decided to proceed with surgical intervention. 
She underwent an emergent left sided decompressive 
hemicraniectomy on ___ and was admitted to the Neuro ICU 
post-operatively for close neurologic monitoring. She was 
started on Keppra x7 days postop for seizure prophylaxis. Postop 
head CT showed minimal increase in IPH, with improved uncal 
herniation and MLS. She was started on 3% hypertonic saline for 
cerebral edema. She was maintained on hypertonic saline. 
Hypertonic saline d/c'd ___. CT torso was done to look for 
underlying malignancy, which was negative. MRI performed to look 
for underlying etiology of bleed, but was unrevealing. On ___, 
the patient underwent a NCHCT and a family meeting was held in 
the afternoon, in which patient's prognosis at this point was 
discussed. Repeat CT on ___ was stable. On ___, the staples 
from the incision were removed. On ___ patient was noted to 
have left arm, left shoulder twitching and was restarted on 
Keppra 1gm BID. She was placed on continuous EEG for 24 hours 
which showed continuous focal slowing over entire left 
hemisphere, no seizure activity. On ___, she was again noted 
to have facial twitching and left shoulder twitching, concerning 
for seizure activity. Keppra was increased to 1250mg BID and 
restarted on continuous EEG, which was negative for seizure 
activity. EEG was again DC'd on ___ and she was maintained on 
Keppra 1250mg BID. Patient's neurologic exam remained stable. 

#Embolic Infarcts /Dural venous sinus thrombosis
Neurology was consulted for new right MCA territory 
embolic-appearing infarcts and developing venous sinus 
thrombosis on MRI ___. Neurology recommended TTE with bubble, 
which identified no cardiac source of embolism.  Left transverse 
sinus VST is small and now flow limiting, thought to be related 
to pressure due to IPH and swelling. Anticoagulation was 
deferred. CTA Head/Neck from ___ showed multifocal cerebral 
arterial narrowing concerning for vasospasm vs vasculopathy. 
Cardiology was contacted regarding optimality of TTE study, who 
recommended obtaining a TEE, which would be a better study to 
further evaluate for possible source of emboli. Family 
discussion determined to not proceed with further workup of 
infarcts. 

#PE
The same CTA head/neck on ___ discussed above also showed a 
small PE in the left upper lobe. A CTA chest confirmed 
non-occlusive PE in left upper lobe, for which anticoagulation 
was deferred because of the IPH and the patient's respiratory 
status remained stable. LENIs were negative for DVT. She was 
closely monitored for physiologic signs of worsening of PE.

#Hypertension /Intermittent SVT 
SBP into the 170s, requiring nicardipine drip intermittently. 
Intermittently tachycardic, so given fentanyl boluses for 
discomfort and started on metoprolol 25mg Q8H for both blood 
pressure control and intermittent SVT. Lopressor was increased 
on ___ due to persistent tachycardia. Cardiology was consulted 
for recommendations regarding rate control; metoprolol was 
adjusted. 

#Respiratory Failure 
The patient was intubated on arrival and remained intubated 
during her ICU stay.  Mini BAL was performed on ___ gram stain 
grew GNR's. Cultures grew H flu, antibiotics narrowed to 
ceftriaxone completed on ___. She failed to be weaned from the 
ventilator and tracheostomy was placed on ___ and weaned off 
vent. On ___ patient required increased in secretions and 
required frequent suctioning. She was started on Glycopyrrolate 
with much improvement in secretions. She was noted to have 
yellow secretions on ___, sputum culture was collected. Final 
results were still pending on discharge however the patient's 
respiratory status was stable, WBC WNL, and patient afebrile. 
Repeat cultures may be followed-up on as an outpatient if 
needed.

#Thrombocytopenia 
Per PMD documentation, patient had recent weight loss; could not 
obtain recent bloodwork from PCP. Some hematologic abnormalities 
were noted, including thrombocytopenia. On admission platelets 
100, trended down to ___. She did not require transfusion and 
platelet count improved. Outpatient heme records received, show 
mild baseline elevation of MCV and thrombocytopenia which was 
being monitored outpatient.

#Nutrition
OGT was placed. Tube feeds were at goal, and on ___ she was 
noted to have hypophosphatemia; concern for refeeding syndrome 
so decreased rate of tube feeds and repleted electrolytes, 
contact dietary for tube feeding recommendations. They 
recommended titrating up on tube feeds very slowly and repleting 
electrolytes as needed. Thiamine and folate were added. On 
___, the patient underwent placement of a PEG tube. Tube feeds 
were restarted Jevity 1.2 cal. Due to an uptrending serum 
calcium level, tube feeds were changed to Glucerna 1.2 cal on 
___. She was noted to have skin breakdown at the PEG site with 
ulceration and ACS was made aware on ___ and they placed a 2x2 
gauze under the bumper. ACS was paged again to re-evaluate the 
PEG site as 2 sutures remained in place on ___ and patient 
continued with skin breakdown despite 2x2 gauze. 2 sutures were 
removed and the bumper to the PEG was rotated. It was 
recommended to leave open to air or use a thin gauze if a 
dressing was indicated. 

#Fever
The patient was febrile intermittently during her ICU stay and 
was pancultured.  Mini BAL on ___ with GNR's on gram stain. She 
was started empirically on vanc/cefepime on ___. Patient with 
sputum cultures grew H.influenzae and completed course of 
ceftriaxone on ___. On ___ patient was febrile up to 102.4, 
urinalysis, chest xray and LENIs were negative. Obtained blood 
cultures, PICC line removed and tip of catheter was cultured. On 
___ patient persisted with fevers up to 101.9. Infectious 
disease was consulted for further management, Vancomycin and 
cefepime was started. Two Sputum cultures was obtained, which 
were both contaminated with respiratory flora. An induced sputum 
culture, suctioned from trach site was obtained, which... She 
was febrile again on ___, and UA/CXR were ordered, both 
negative for acute process. On ___ ID recommended 
discontinuation of antibiotics with close monitoring, for 
possible drug fever. She continued to be febrile after 
antibiotics discontinued. MRI was obtained ___ which was 
negative for infection but showed right embolic infarcts and a 
developing dural venous sinus thrombosis. Once PE identified, it 
was determined that is the likely cause of her intermittent 
fevers. No further fever workup obtained. 

#Mucous Plug 
Patient underwent a CTA Chest to rule out pulmonary embolism on 
___ which revealed no evidence of pulmonary embolism and new 
focally dilated subsegmental bronchus in the right lower lobe 
with distal nodular opacification possibly reflecting mucous 
plugging within the distal airway and upstream dilatation. Chest 
physiotherapy and aggressive suctioning ordered, the patients 
respiratory status remained stable on discharge. 

#Elevated LFTs
Medicine was consulted for elevated ALT/Lipase/Amylase in the 
setting of fever on ___, who recommended Hepatitis B/C 
serology, Fe/Ferritin/TIBC, TSH/Free T4, and a RUQ ultrasound as 
workup. Aside from a slightly elevated Ferritin, this workup was 
overall negative for any acute/subacute hepatic process, and the 
elevated LFTs were stable on ___. This was attributed to a 
medication effect, likely either beta-blocker or cephalosporin.

#Dispo
Patient was evaluated by ___ and OT who recommended rehab. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Medications prior to admission:
Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg PO daily
Folic Acid 1mg PO Daily 
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild/Fever 
Do not exceed 4GM acetaminophen in 24 hours.   
2.  Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY:PRN constipation   
3.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
4.  Famotidine 20 mg PO BID  
5.  Glycopyrrolate 1 mg PO BID  
6.  Heparin 5000 UNIT SC BID  
7.  LevETIRAcetam 1250 mg PO BID  
8.  Metoprolol Tartrate 50 mg PO Q6H  
9.  Multivitamins W/minerals Liquid 15 mL PO DAILY  
10.  Nystatin Oral Suspension 5 mL PO QID  
11.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID constipation   
12.  Thiamine 100 mg PO DAILY  
13.  Vitamin D 1000 UNIT PO DAILY  
14.  FoLIC Acid 1 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:

Venous Sinus Thrombosis
Tachycardia

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Nonverbal
Level of Consciousness: Lethargic but arousable.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Brain Hemorrhage with Surgery

Surgery
ÂYou underwent a surgery called a craniectomy. A portion of 
your skull was removed to allow your brain to swell. You must 
wear a helmet when out of bed at all times.
ÂIt is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
ÂCall your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
ÂWe recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
ÂYou make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
ÂNo driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
ÂIf you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
ÂNo contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
ÂPlease do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
ÂYou have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This 
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is 
important that you take this medication consistently and on 
time. 
ÂYou may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
ÂYou may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and 
remembering new information.
ÂEmotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. 
ÂFeeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood 
swings are also common.
ÂYou may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
ÂConstipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

Headaches:
ÂHeadache is one of the most common symptoms after a brain 
bleed. 
ÂMost headaches are not dangerous but you should call your 
doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, 
increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a 
headache. 
ÂMild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches but 
avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed 
by your doctor. 
ÂThere are other things that can be done to help with your 
headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, 
relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. 


When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
ÂSevere pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
ÂFever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
ÂNausea and/or vomiting
ÂExtreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
ÂSevere headaches not relieved by pain relievers
ÂSeizures
ÂAny new problems with your vision or ability to speak
ÂWeakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
ÂSudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
ÂSudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
ÂSudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
ÂSudden severe headaches with no known reason

Keppra 1gm BID. She was placed on continuous EEG for 24 hours
which showed continuous focal slowing over entire left
hemisphere, no seizure activity. On ___, she was again noted
to have facial twitching and left shoulder twitching, concerning
for seizure activity. Keppra was increased to 1250mg BID and
restarted on continuous EEG, which was negative for seizure
activity. EEG was again DC'd on ___ and she was maintained on
Keppra 1250mg BID. Patient's neurologic exam remained stable.
#Embolic Infarcts /Dural venous sinus thrombosis
Neurology was consulted for new right MCA territory
embolic-appearing infarcts and developing venous sinus
thrombosis on MRI ___. Neurology recommended TTE with bubble,
which identified no cardiac source of embolism. Left transverse
sinus VST is small and now flow limiting, thought to be related
to pressure due to IPH and swelling. Anticoagulation was
deferred. CTA Head/Neck from ___ showed multifocal cerebral
arterial narrowing concerning for vasospasm vs vasculopathy.
Cardiology was contacted regarding optimality of TTE study, who
recommended obtaining a TEE, which would be a better study to
further evaluate for possible source of emboli. Family
discussion determined to not proceed with further workup of
infarcts.
#PE
The same CTA head/neck on ___ discussed above also showed a
small PE in the left upper lobe. A CTA chest confirmed
non-occlusive PE in left upper lobe, for which anticoagulation
was deferred because of the IPH and the patient's respiratory
status remained stable. LENIs were negative for DVT. She was
closely monitored for physiologic signs of worsening of PE.
#Hypertension /Intermittent SVT
SBP into the 170s, requiring nicardipine drip intermittently.
Intermittently tachycardic, so given fentanyl boluses for
discomfort and started on metoprolol 25mg Q8H for both blood
pressure control and intermittent SVT. Lopressor was increased
on ___ due to persistent tachycardia. Cardiology was consulted
for recommendations regarding rate control; metoprolol was
adjusted.
#Respiratory Failure
The patient was intubated on arrival and remained intubated
during her ICU stay. Mini BAL was performed on ___ gram stain
grew GNR's. Cultures grew H flu, antibiotics narrowed to
ceftriaxone completed on ___. She failed to be weaned from the
ventilator and tracheostomy was placed on ___ and weaned off
vent. On ___ patient required increased in secretions and
required frequent suctioning. She was started on Glycopyrrolate
with much improvement in secretions. She was noted to have
yellow secretions on ___, sputum culture was collected. Final
results were still pending on discharge however the patient's
respiratory status was stable, WBC WNL, and patient afebrile.
Repeat cultures may be followed-up on as an outpatient if
needed.
#Thrombocytopenia
Per PMD documentation, patient had recent weight loss; could not
obtain recent bloodwork from PCP. Some hematologic abnormalities
were noted, including thrombocytopenia. On admission platelets
100, trended down to ___. She did not require transfusion and
platelet count improved. Outpatient heme records received, show
mild baseline elevation of MCV and thrombocytopenia which was
being monitored outpatient.
#Nutrition
OGT was placed. Tube feeds were at goal, and on ___ she was
noted to have hypophosphatemia; concern for refeeding syndrome
so decreased rate of tube feeds and repleted electrolytes,
contact dietary for tube feeding recommendations. They
recommended titrating up on tube feeds very slowly and repleting
electrolytes as needed. Thiamine and folate were added. On
___, the patient underwent placement of a PEG tube. Tube feeds
were restarted Jevity 1.2 cal. Due to an uptrending serum
calcium level, tube feeds were changed to Glucerna 1.2 cal on
___. She was noted to have skin breakdown at the PEG site with
ulceration and ACS was made aware on ___ and they placed a 2x2
gauze under the bumper. ACS was paged again to re-evaluate the
PEG site as 2 sutures remained in place on ___ and patient
continued with skin breakdown despite 2x2 gauze. 2 sutures were
removed and the bumper to the PEG was rotated. It was
recommended to leave open to air or use a thin gauze if a
dressing was indicated.
#Fever
The patient was febrile intermittently during her ICU stay and
was pancultured. Mini BAL on ___ with GNR's on gram stain. She
was started empirically on vanc/cefepime on ___. Patient with
sputum cultures grew H.influenzae and completed course of
ceftriaxone on ___. On ___ patient was febrile up to 102.4,
urinalysis, chest xray and LENIs were negative. Obtained blood
cultures, PICC line removed and tip of catheter was cultured. On
___ patient persisted with fevers up to 101.9. Infectious
disease was consulted for further management, Vancomycin and
cefepime was started. Two Sputum cultures was obtained, which
were both contaminated with respiratory flora. An induced sputum
culture, suctioned from trach site was obtained, which... She
was febrile again on ___, and UA/CXR were ordered, both
negative for acute process. On ___ ID recommended
discontinuation of antibiotics with close monitoring, for
possible drug fever. She continued to be febrile after
antibiotics discontinued. MRI was obtained ___ which was
negative for infection but showed right embolic infarcts and a
developing dural venous sinus thrombosis. Once PE identified, it
was determined that is the likely cause of her intermittent
fevers. No further fever workup obtained.
#Mucous Plug
Patient underwent a CTA Chest to rule out pulmonary embolism on
___ which revealed no evidence of pulmonary embolism and new
focally dilated subsegmental bronchus in the right lower lobe
with distal nodular opacification possibly reflecting mucous
plugging within the distal airway and upstream dilatation. Chest
physiotherapy and aggressive suctioning ordered, the patients
respiratory status remained stable on discharge.
#Elevated LFTs
Medicine was consulted for elevated ALT/Lipase/Amylase in the
setting of fever on ___, who recommended Hepatitis B/C
serology, Fe/Ferritin/TIBC, TSH/Free T4, and a RUQ ultrasound as
workup. Aside from a slightly elevated Ferritin, this workup was
overall negative for any acute/subacute hepatic process, and the
elevated LFTs were stable on ___. This was attributed to a
medication effect, likely either beta-blocker or cephalosporin.
#Dispo
Patient was evaluated by ___ and OT who recommended rehab.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Brain Hemorrhage with Surgery
Surgery
ÂYou underwent a surgery called a craniectomy. A portion of
your skull was removed to allow your brain to swell. You must
wear a helmet when out of bed at all times.
ÂIt is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to
cover it when outside.
ÂCall your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like
redness, fever, or drainage.
Activity
ÂWe recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing,
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
ÂYou make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest.
___ try to do too much all at once.
ÂNo driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication.
ÂIf you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT
allowed to drive by law.
ÂNo contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You
should avoid contact sports for 6 months.
Medications
ÂPlease do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin,
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon.
ÂYou have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this
medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is
important that you take this medication consistently and on
time.
ÂYou may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
What You ___ Experience:
ÂYou may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and
remembering new information.
ÂEmotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common.
ÂFeeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood
swings are also common.
ÂYou may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be
easier during this time.
ÂConstipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.
Headaches:
ÂHeadache is one of the most common symptoms after a brain
bleed.
ÂMost headaches are not dangerous but you should call your
doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness,
increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a
headache.
ÂMild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches but
avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed
by your doctor.
ÂThere are other things that can be done to help with your
headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise,
relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs.
When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
ÂSevere pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision
site.
ÂFever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
ÂNausea and/or vomiting
ÂExtreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
ÂSevere headaches not relieved by pain relievers
ÂSeizures
ÂAny new problems with your vision or ability to speak
ÂWeakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg
Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience
any of the following:
ÂSudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
ÂSudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
ÂSudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or
coordination
ÂSudden severe headaches with no known reason

PA/LATERAL CHEST X-RAY (___): As compared to the previous 
radiograph on ___, the patient has developed a left lower 
lobe opacity with air bronchograms, located in the lower lobe 
and better appreciated on the frontal than on the lateral 
radiograph. In the appropriate clinical context, this change 
represents pneumonia. At the time of observation, 11:02 on ___, the referring physician, ___, was 
contacted by telephone and the findings were subsequently 
discussed. Otherwise, there is no relevant change. Constant mild 
cardiomegaly with tortuosity of the thoracic aorta but without 
pulmonary edema.  No pleural effusions. Unchanged mild 
mediastinal widening, potentially caused by a retrosternal

.
AP PORTABLE CHEST X-RAY (___): As compared to the previous

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with h/o mental retardation, HTN, prostate and colon ca, 
DM2, CKD (bl Cr 1.5) p/w shortness of breath, hypoxia, cough and 
e/o pneumonia on CXR.
.  
# DYSPNEA, HYPOXIA, COUGH: CXR on admission showed new LLL 
opacity with air bronchograms, making pneumonia most likely 
diagnosis. Patient was started on vancomycin and cefepime for 
coverage of HCAP, and albuterol + tiotropium given wheezing on 
exam. Initially he improved clinically and was afebrile; however 
on HD #3 he became febrile to 100.4 and clinically worsened with 
increasing dyspnea and lethargy and rising pCO2 on ABG. There 
was concern by team that he was aspirating given his lethargy 
while on regular diet. Therefore IV Flagyl was added to regimen 
to cover for aspiration pneumonia. He was also started on 
humidified O2 and frequent suctioning. With these interventions, 
he improved clinically with less hypoxia and decreased lethargy, 
and no longer spiked any fevers. Blood, urine and sputum 
cultures were all negative. Given negative sputum, Vancomycin 
was discontinued. Once he remained stable, he was transitioned 
to PO Levoquin and PO Flagyl to complete total 7-day antibiotic 
course on ___. 
.
# LETHARGY: Patient's mental status extremely difficult to 
assess given underlying mental retardation, blindness and 
deafness; obtained collateral from caregiver who felt he was 
worse than baseline. was likely in setting of infection (per 
above), but patient was also quite constipated which likely also 
contributed. He was started on aggressive bowel regimen and did 
start having BMs during hospitalization. With treatment of 
infection, hypoxia and constipation, patient's mental status 
steadily improved during hospitalization and he was back to 
baseline on discharge. 
.
# CONSTIPATION: on admission, abdomen distended (with ventral 
hernia) but nontender, pt reportedly had not had BM in several 
days. He was started on aggressive bowel reg with Colace, Senna, 
Miralax and Bisacodyl, and had a bowel movement. Should continue 
monitoring at rehab and uptitrate bowel reg if no BMs in >2 
days.  
.
# CKD: On admission, patient's creatinine was elevated to 1.7 
(baseline 1.1-1.4). He was given IV fluids and his creatinine 
returned to baseline, supporting pre-renal insufficiency due to 
fluid loss and poor PO intake as diagnosis. 
.
# HTN: Normotensive throughout hospitalization on home regimen 
(amlodipine, lisinopril, metoprolol). 
.
# Hypothyroidism: Continued home levothyroxine.
.
# Anemia: chronic, normocytic, stable, baseline HCT ___. 
.
# Conjunctivitis: Has chronic right eye conjunctivitis, on 
chronic bacitracin ointment BID. Appeared to have bilateral 
conjunctivitis on admission. Treated with bacitracin to both 
eyes BID throughout hospitalization. Did not worsen clinically.
.
# Prostate cancer: on Lupron as outpatient. 
.
# BPH: continued home doxazosin. 
. 
# CODE STATUS: full code, confirmed with caregiver ___ 
___ (cell ___, home ___ 
.

Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure participating in your care at ___ 
___. You were admitted to the hospital with 
cough, hypoxia and shortness of breath. You were found to have 
pneumonia. You were treated with IV antibiotics and inhalers and 
your symptoms improved. 
.

.

continued until current symptoms resolve)

CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs,
gallops
Abdomen: Softly distended. +large ventral hernia. Diffusely TTP
with +voluntary guarding. +BS. No rebound. Unable to palpate
liver/spleen.
Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or
edema
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:
___ 12:20PM BLOOD WBC-5.9 RBC-3.96* Hgb-10.1* Hct-32.9*
MCV-83 MCH-25.6* MCHC-30.7* RDW-15.7* Plt ___
___ 12:20PM BLOOD Neuts-73.3* Lymphs-13.6* Monos-7.7
Eos-4.6* Baso-0.8
___ 12:20PM BLOOD ___ PTT-27.9 ___
___ 10:40AM BLOOD UreaN-29* Creat-1.6* Na-138 K-4.3 Cl-101
HCO3-28 AnGap-13
___ 07:20AM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-3.0 Mg-2.2
.
PA/LATERAL CHEST X-RAY (___): As compared to the previous
radiograph on ___, the patient has developed a left lower
lobe opacity with air bronchograms, located in the lower lobe
and better appreciated on the frontal than on the lateral
radiograph. In the appropriate clinical context, this change
represents pneumonia. At the time of observation, 11:02 on ___, the referring physician, ___, was
contacted by telephone and the findings were subsequently
discussed. Otherwise, there is no relevant change. Constant mild
cardiomegaly with tortuosity of the thoracic aorta but without
pulmonary edema. No pleural effusions. Unchanged mild
mediastinal widening, potentially caused by a retrosternal
goiter.
.
AP PORTABLE CHEST X-RAY (___): As compared to the previous
radiograph, there is evidence of newly appeared parenchymal
opacities at the lung bases, left more than right. The
distribution suggests aspiration or pneumonia. No other changes.
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with h/o mental retardation, HTN, prostate and colon ca,
DM2, CKD (bl Cr 1.5) p/w shortness of breath, hypoxia, cough and
e/o pneumonia on CXR.
.
# DYSPNEA, HYPOXIA, COUGH: CXR on admission showed new LLL
opacity with air bronchograms, making pneumonia most likely
diagnosis. Patient was started on vancomycin and cefepime for
coverage of HCAP, and albuterol + tiotropium given wheezing on
exam. Initially he improved clinically and was afebrile; however
on HD #3 he became febrile to 100.4 and clinically worsened with
increasing dyspnea and lethargy and rising pCO2 on ABG. There
was concern by team that he was aspirating given his lethargy
while on regular diet. Therefore IV Flagyl was added to regimen
to cover for aspiration pneumonia. He was also started on
humidified O2 and frequent suctioning. With these interventions,
he improved clinically with less hypoxia and decreased lethargy,
and no longer spiked any fevers. Blood, urine and sputum
cultures were all negative. Given negative sputum, Vancomycin
was discontinued. Once he remained stable, he was transitioned
to PO Levoquin and PO Flagyl to complete total 7-day antibiotic
course on ___.
.
# LETHARGY: Patient's mental status extremely difficult to
assess given underlying mental retardation, blindness and
deafness; obtained collateral from caregiver who felt he was
worse than baseline. was likely in setting of infection (per
above), but patient was also quite constipated which likely also
contributed. He was started on aggressive bowel regimen and did
start having BMs during hospitalization. With treatment of
infection, hypoxia and constipation, patient's mental status
steadily improved during hospitalization and he was back to
baseline on discharge.
.
# CONSTIPATION: on admission, abdomen distended (with ventral
hernia) but nontender, pt reportedly had not had BM in several
days. He was started on aggressive bowel reg with Colace, Senna,
Miralax and Bisacodyl, and had a bowel movement. Should continue
monitoring at rehab and uptitrate bowel reg if no BMs in >2
days.
.
# CKD: On admission, patient's creatinine was elevated to 1.7
(baseline 1.1-1.4). He was given IV fluids and his creatinine
returned to baseline, supporting pre-renal insufficiency due to
fluid loss and poor PO intake as diagnosis.
.
# HTN: Normotensive throughout hospitalization on home regimen
(amlodipine, lisinopril, metoprolol).
.
# Hypothyroidism: Continued home levothyroxine.
.
# Anemia: chronic, normocytic, stable, baseline HCT ___.
.
# Conjunctivitis: Has chronic right eye conjunctivitis, on
chronic bacitracin ointment BID. Appeared to have bilateral
conjunctivitis on admission. Treated with bacitracin to both
eyes BID throughout hospitalization. Did not worsen clinically.
.
# Prostate cancer: on Lupron as outpatient.
.
# BPH: continued home doxazosin.
.
# CODE STATUS: full code, confirmed with caregiver ___
___ (cell ___, home ___
.
Medications on Admission:
amlodipine 10 mg daily
bacitracin 1.25 inches L eye BID
vitamin B12 1000 mcg/mL IM qmonth
doxazosin 2 mg daily
leuprolide 7.5 mg IM monthly
levothyroxine 137 mcg daily
lisinopril 10 mg daily
metoprolol succinate 50 mg daily
triamcinolone acetonide 0.1% ointment 3x/week
zolpidem 5 mg HS
aspirin 81 mg daily
senna PRN
diphenhydramine cream PRN
colace PRN
ferrous gluconate 324 mg daily

cough, hypoxia and shortness of breath. You were found to have

.
Once you are discharged from rehab, you should schedule a

.

K-3.8 Cl-101 HCO3-25 AnGap-___ year old Male with a history of chronic stable Asthma  who 
presents with 24 hours of progressive dyspnea and wheezing 
consistent with an asthma exacerbation.

Assessment and Plan:
# Chronic Stable Asthma with severe acute exacerbation: Patient 
presents with shortness of breath, and significant wheezing with 
accessory muscle use consistent with an acute asthma 
exacerbation. Patient meets criteria for a severe exacerbation 
due to RR>30 in the ED, and patient required a 100% NRB mask 
during transport.  Given the patient's symptoms likely 
represents a viral bronchitis type trigger. He was started on 
Prednisone 60 mg p.o. daily and standing nebs until his 
breathing improved and will taper his predniosone 10mg every 
other day on discharge. HIs peakflows improved to 220-285 (at or 
above baseline per patient) and he had spirometry while in the 
hospital as well. He will follow up with his pulmonologist and 
PCP as an outpatient. 

# HTN: 
- Continued amlodipine

# Atrial Fibrillation: Patient is not on a rate control agent. 
He presented with RVR in the setting of nebs but that resolved 
with improved respiroaty status. Continued rivoroxaban

# Hyperlipidemia
- Continued Pravachol

# QT Prolongation: Resolved. Note patient has a QTc > 500 on EKG 
in ED. His baseline on prior EKGs is normal at 430.  He was 
monitored on telemetry and repeat EKGs over the following 2 days 
showed a reduction in his QTC down to 450. Bupropion is a QT
prolonging agent, but wish to avoid stopping this in the setting 
of increased anxiety with steroids.  He should have follow-up 
EKGs as an outpatient to continue to monitor his QTC but 
discharge QTc 450. 

Transitional Issues:
[] Follow up QTc on EKG as an outpatient. 
[] Evaluate for the need to prolong his steroid course. 

Greater than 30 minutes spent in care coordination and 
counseling on the day of discharge. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. EPINEPHrine (EpiPEN) 0.3 mg IM ONCE MR1 anaphylaxis 
2. mepolizumab 100 mg subcutaneous Q28 Days 
3. BuPROPion XL (Once Daily) 450 mg PO DAILY 
4. ClonazePAM 0.5 mg PO BID:PRN anxiety 
5. amLODIPine 5 mg PO DAILY 
6. Rivaroxaban 20 mg PO DAILY 
7. Pravastatin 40 mg PO QPM 
8. Montelukast 10 mg PO DAILY 
9. budesonide-formoterol 160-4.5 mcg/actuation inhalation DAILY 
10. Omeprazole 20 mg PO BID 
11. albuterol sulfate 90 mcg/actuation inhalation TID:PRN 
dyspnea 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  PredniSONE 60 mg PO DAILY 
Than taper down 10mg every 2 days.
60mg x2 day then
50mg x2 days ect until complete.  
Tapered dose - DOWN

dyspnea

4.  budesonide-formoterol 160-4.5 mcg/actuation inhalation DAILY 
 
5.  BuPROPion XL (Once Daily) 450 mg PO DAILY

8.  Montelukast 10 mg PO DAILY  
9.  Pravastatin 40 mg PO QPM  
10.  Rivaroxaban 20 mg PO DAILY

Home

Acute Asthma Exacerbation

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.

Mr ___,

hosptial. You were admitted with shortness of breath and found 
to have an asthma exacerbation. You were treated with steroids 
and nebulizers and your breathing slowly improved. Please take 
your medications as directed and follow up as noted below.

Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs

Chief Complaint:
In and out of atrial fibrillation
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ gentleman with h/o recurrent atrial 
fibrillation, CAD, hyperlipidemia, who was admitted to ___ 
___ on ___ after waking up in atrial fib with 
palpitations and having substernal chest pressure (last 1 hr and 
relieved by the time he was in the ED) with no other sx. He had 
a nuclear stress test there on ___ and was discharged home. 
He had a second episode on ___ occuring early in the am 
feeling palpitations and light headedness possibly precipitated 
by sleep apnea. He has a history of an old infarct on stress 
testing which showed no evidence of ischemia. He took a 
cardiazem on ___ and was back in sinus rhythm with in 20min 
but felt weak and lightheaded and went to ___'s office. From 
___'s office, he was admitted to ___ for initiation 
of antiarrythmic therapy. There he was started on sotalol but 
was unable to tolerate the medication with episodes of 
bradycardia and non sustained VT. He is now being transferred to 
___ for induction on dofetilide.
.
Per OSH notes, he had an episode of nonsymptomatic VT yesterday 
that was not treated. He is awake alert and oriented up and 
walking around. Vitals at OSH prior to transfer were Temp 97.2 
BP 133/79 HR 97.2 RR20, 95% on RA.
.
On arrival to ___, patient had stable vs 97.5 151/85 61 18 
96%. He has no cp, arm pain, jaw pain, palpitations, SOB, or 
lightheadedness. He is feeling fine.
. 
On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, 
TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the 
time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black 
stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. 
He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other 
review of systems were negative.
Cardiac review of systems is notable for + lightheadedness if he 
gets out of a chair too quickly, + feeling strain on chest at 
sternum that was secondary to lifting weights, + dyspnea on 
exertion when walking up a hill, + for L leg swelling secondary 
to vein stripping, absence of other chest pain, paroxysmal 
nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea. 
 
Past Medical History:
CAD
atrial fibrillation
Prostate cancer s/p radiation and chemotherapy
HTN
Hyperlipidemia
Anxiety and depression
Known RBBB
Abdominal aortic aneurysm s/p repair- ___ Dacron patch 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
The pt reports his father had CAD and strokes. His brother had 
MIs starting at age ___ had a bypass surgery and died of an MI in 
his ___. 
 
Physical Exam:
VS: T97.5, BP151/84, HR61, RR18, 96% on RA
Gen: WDWN middle aged male in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect 
appropriate.
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were 
pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.
Neck: No JVD.
CV: RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No S3 or S4.
Chest: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp 
were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, 
wheezes or rhonchi.
Abd: +bs, Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not 
enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits.
Ext: + LLE swollen compared to left but no pitting edema on 
either leg. No femoral bruits.
Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.
.

MCV-89 MCH-31.8 MCHC-35.6* RDW-13.5 Plt ___

MCV-87 MCH-31.1 MCHC-35.6* RDW-13.2 Plt ___

K-4.4 Cl-101 HCO3-33* AnGap-11

.
ECG ___:
Sinus bradycardia. Consider left atrial abnormality. Right 
bundle-branch block. Left axis deviation suggests left anterior 
fascicular block and consider possible prior inferior myocardial 
infarction. Clinical correlation
is suggested. No previous tracing available for comparison. 
QT/QTC 442/429
.
ECG ___:
QT/QTC 470/___SSESSMENT AND PLAN, AS REVIEWED AND DISCUSSED IN 
MULTIDISCIPLINARY ROUNDS
___ with h/o recurrent atrial fibrillation, CAD, hyperlipidemia, 
who was transferred from ___ for possible dofetilide 
induction vs ablation after bradycardia on sotalol.
.
#. Rhythm: The patient was admitted after recurrent and 
increasing episodes of afib brought him to OSH for antiarrythmic 
therapy. The patient was trialed on initiation of sotalol at the 
OSH but this was discontinued ___ bradycardia. The patient was 
in NSR during his whole hospitalization at ___.  He was initiated 
on dofetilide and received 6 doses while at the hospital. His 
QTC was monitored.  Of note he has a widened QRS and this was 
allowed a QTC up to 520.  His maximum QTC during the admission 
was 486.  The patient was stopped on HCTZ due to receiving the 
dofetilide. His INR was subtherapeutic due to being given the 
incorrect dosing of coumadin.  This error was fixed and he was 
discharged on his home dose of coumadin with close INR follow 
up.  
.
#. CAD: Patient with known history of CAD. A recent pMIBI showed 
fixed defect of inferior wall perfusion c/w old 
infarct/myocardial scar. It also showed mild septal & inferior 
wall hypokinesis. EF 51%.  He was continued on his ASA and 
statin.  He was not on ASA when he was admitted as this was 
stopped when he started coumadin. We were unable to start a 
b-blocker given the patient's bradycardia.
.
#. Pump: His LVEF 2as 51% on his recent pMIBI was 51%. He was 
euvolemic on exam.
.
#. HTN: The patient was stopped on HCTZ when dofetilide was 
started.  He was continued on his ACE for BP control.
.
#. Hyperlipidemia: he was continued on his statin and niacin.
.
#. Prostate cancer s/p XRT: he was continued on his casodex
.
#. Depression/anxiety: he was continued on Paxil.
.
#. FEN: he was on a cardiac diet and his K+ and Mg2+ were 
aggressively repleated.
.
#. PPx: The patient did not need SC heparin as he was 
ambulating.  He was on a bowel regimen.
.
#. Code: Full code

Niacin 500mg PO QHS
Coumadin as directed (normally 2.5 ___ and wed and 5 the 
other days of the week)
Prilosec 20mg PO daily
Lupron q3months
L leg veins striped
.

Coumadin 2.5mg PO
Zocor 80mg QHS

Casodex ___ PO daily

Tylenol prn
Colace prn

___ and ___.

___.

6. Niacin 500 mg Capsule, Sustained Release Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sustained Release PO QHS (once a day (at bedtime)).  
7. Bicalutamide 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
8. Paroxetine HCl 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
9. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One 
(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours).  
10. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID 
(2 times a day) as needed for constipation.

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Codeine / topiramate / amitriptyline / ceftriaxone
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Headache
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Lumbar puncture
 
History of Present Illness:
HPI: Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with history of Crohn's
disease and migraine headaches presenting with fever and neck
pain.

The patient reports that she was in her usual state of health
until ___, when she noticed a targetoid, erythematous rash on 
her
left anterior thigh. She denies any known tick bites, no hiking,
no recent travel outside ___ or to the ___. She had no 
fevers
or chills. No other complaints. She presented to urgent care for
evaluation of this, and based on the appearance of her lesion 
was
prescribed doxycycline for presumed Lyme disease; Lyme Ab were
sent and have now returned negative. 

She reports that she took the doxycycline at home, but developed
nausea in the mornings after taking the medicine. She reports
that the rash completely abated with the antibiotics. However, 
on
___, she developed a posterior headache, neck stiffness, and
fevers up to Tmax 100. She states that the headache was unique
from her migraines, which are usually frontal and debilitating.
She denies any sick contacts. No cough or shortness of breath. 
No
bowel changes.

In the ED, vitals: 97.5 89 113/81 18 100% RA 
Exam notable for: mild tenderness to palpation along L neck and
shoulder
Labs notable for: WBC 12.7
Imaging: CXR, CTA head
Patient given: 1L LR, lorazepam 0.5 mg, ceftriaxone 2 g,
methylpred 80 mg IV, Benadryl 50 mg IV, famotidine 20 mg IV,
EpiPen 0.3 mg; vancomycin was ordered but not administered

In the ED, multiple attempts were made at LP without success.
Patient was empirically treated for meningitis. Upon
administration of ceftriaxone, the patient developed a rash on
her chest and face, and reported sensation of throat closing. 
She
was treated as above for allergic reaction; no further
antibiotics were administered. ID was curbsided, and recommended
moxifloxacin as alternative for ceftriaxone, however, this is
non-formulary.

On arrival to the floor, the patient reports that her headache 
is
improved. She denies any shortness of breath. No other
complaints.

ROS: Pertinent positives and negatives as noted in the HPI. All
other systems were reviewed and are negative.

- Crohn's disease
- Irritable bowel syndrome
- Migraine headaches
- GERD

disease

Ms ___ was admitted after recent left thigh rash that had 
resolved prior to hospitalization. Outpatient lyme serologies 
negative. Worsening HA at home and c/f neck stiffness prompted 
presentation. Reports HA distinct from migraines. On arrival, 
she received CTX that was c/b allergic reaction requiring epi 
pen as well as vanco and acyclovir for empiric coverage of 
meningitis. On hospital day 1, she underwent LP that showed 2 
total nucleated cells, ruling out meningitis. ID was consulted 
and felt her presentation could still be consistent with early 
CNS Lyme disease inspite of negative serologies outpatient. 
Recommended continued doxycycline with meals to reduce 
nausea/vomiting patient was experiencing at home with 
medication. CSF studies for lyme, eneterovirus and arbovirus 
pending at time of discharge. 

# Headache/Neck pain: Patient presenting with headache and 
posterior neck pain, as well as reported subjective fevers at 
home, although she is afebrile here. Patient does have history 
of migraines, although she describes her current headache as
distinct from typical migraine phenotype. patient with 
tenderness to palpation over paraspinal muscles also suggesting 
possible muscle spasm as etiology. CTA head without acute 
process. Meningitis is possible, although she is well-appearing, 
afebrile, and has equivocal meningismus on exam; LP could not be 
obtained
in ED. Pt initially started on vanc/acyclovir after CTX 
reaction, however, given low concern for meningitis on exam 
(unilateral neck pain more c/w MSK, oriented x3, full ROM of 
neck), antibiotics were discontinued and she was placed back on 
PO doxycycline. 

# Rash: Resolved. Patient with rash on left thigh, now resolved. 
Lyme serologies negative. Lyme serologies were resent and 
pending at time of discharge as false negatives are possible. 
Restarted and discharged on PO doxycycline.

================================
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES

early CNS lyme given concern that she did not absorb previously 
prescribed doxycycline due to nausea/vomiting

doxycycline and to take it with meals to reduce nausea/vomiting
[ ] Lyme serologies from blood and CSF studies for lyme, 
eneterovirus and arbovirus all pending at time of discharge

please consider autoimmune workup

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
left chest pain s/p mechanical fall
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ man with history of NIDDM who
presents as transfer from ___ with left chest pain 5 
days
after a fall with CT findings notable for L rib fractures and
small L pneumothorax.  

Patient reports that 5 days prior to presentation, he was 
tilling
the soil ("dethatching") of his son's lawn and walking backward
in doing so when he tripped over one granite block and fell on
another, striking the left side of his body. He denies 
headstrike
and denies LOC and has complete recall of the event.  He had
severe immediate left chest pain and shortness of breath, and
states that he took approximately 5 minutes to catch his breath. 

Following this, however, he was able to get up and states that 
he
actually continued dethatching the lawn for the next 4 hours.  

His pain persisted for the next 5 days and ultimately his wife
convinced him to come into urgent care today, whereupon he was
referred to ___ and underwent imaging with left chest
findings as stated above (also see CT reports below).  He was
then referred to ___ for further evaluation.  

On presentation, he states that he is feeling generally well and
has no shortness of breath. He denies any fevers / chills /
nausea / emesis.  His pain is currently minimal but becomes 
worse
with movement.  He does also feel a twinge of pain with 
extremely
deep inspiration.  He was provided in the ED with an incentive
spirometer and is managing to inhale volumes in excess of 2
liters with minimal difficulty.  

 
Past Medical History:
PMH:  
- NIDDM
- BPH
- OA
- HLD
- Chronic neck pain

PSH: 
- Tonsillectomy (pediatric)
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
Physical exam:  
VS:  98.6  85  177/91  18  94% RA
Gen:  NAD, AAOx3, pleasant, wearing glasses
HEENT:  Grossly NC/AT, PERRL, EOMI
CV:  RRR
Pulm:  No respiratory distress, grossly CTAB. +mild anterior L
chest crepitus, +tenderness to palpation about left lateral
mid-chest. No visible ecchymosis, no wounds. 
Abd:  Soft, NT/ND
Ext:  WWP no c/c/e

Discharge Physical Exam:
VS: 98.4, 126/69, 86, 18, 93 Ra 
Gen: A&O x3 NAD RR even / unlabored
CV: HRR
Pulm: Diminished breath sounds to the left side 
Abd: soft NT/ND
Ext: No edema

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 08:45PM BLOOD WBC-7.2 RBC-4.04* Hgb-11.8* Hct-36.1* 
MCV-89 MCH-29.2 MCHC-32.7 RDW-13.0 RDWSD-42.5 Plt ___
___ 03:05PM BLOOD Glucose-176* UreaN-17 Creat-1.1 Na-142 
K-4.9 Cl-103 HCO3-29 AnGap-10
___ 08:45PM BLOOD Glucose-106* UreaN-17 Creat-0.9 Na-142 
K-4.3 Cl-105 HCO3-22 AnGap-15
___ 03:05PM BLOOD Calcium-9.1 Phos-4.4 Mg-1.5*

Chest CT with contrast
___: ___
IV CONTRAST:  75 cc of Omnipaque 350.
COMPARISON: Chest radiograph from earlier in the day
FINDINGS:
- HEART: The heart is normal in size. There is coronary
calcification consistent with an element of coronary artery
disease.
- AORTA: The aorta is not dilated. No dissection is identified.
- PULMONARY VESSELS: No filling defects are identified in the
pulmonary arteries to indicate pulmonary emboli.
- NODES: No significant mediastinal or hilar adenopathy is
identified.
- ESOPHAGUS: Unremarkable.
- THYROID: Unremarkable.
- BRONCHI: The central bronchial tree is unremarkable.
- LUNGS: No generalized interstitial disease is identified. No
edema is identified. There is partial atelectasis of the basilar
segments of the left lower lobe.
- LUNG NODULES: There is a 5 mm nodule in the left apex. There
are benign calcified granulomas in the right lung.
- PLEURAL SURFACES: There is a moderate left pneumothorax. There
is a small associated left pleural effusion.
- UPPER ABDOMEN: There is an incidental left upper pole renal
cyst. The spleen, kidneys, liver, pancreas, and adrenals are
otherwise unremarkable.
- AXILLAE: No axillary adenopathy is identified.
- MUSCULOSKELETAL: There are degenerative findings in the spine.
There is calcification along the anterior longitudinal ligament.
There is a 8mm area of dense sclerosis in the T4 vertebral body,
likely representing a bone island. There are fractures of the
posterior left sixth through 10th ribs. There is also a fracture
of the 11th rib at its articulation with the spine.
- ADDITIONAL FINDINGS: There is chest wall emphysema associated
with the rib fractures.

IMPRESSION:
1. Fractures of the posterior left sixth through 10th ribs.
2. Moderate left pneumothorax.
3. Left chest wall emphysema.
4. Partial collapse of the basilar segments left lower lobe.
There is a 5 mm left upper lobe nodule.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ male status post fall 5 days ago. CT scan notable 
for multiple left-sided rib fractures and moderately sized but 
potentially loculated pneumothorax. Patient evaluated by trauma 
surgery, admitted to their service for further monitoring, no 
chest tube recommended. The patient was hemodynamically stable. 

Pain was well controlled. During this hospitalization, the 
patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with 
respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively 
participated in the plan of care. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay. He was pulling ___ on the IS and oxygen was 93% on room 
air. On HD2, repeat CXR showed moderate to large left 
hydropneumothorax, unchanged from the prior study.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged home without services. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

 
Medications on Admission:
Meds at home:  
- Citalopram 20'
- Colace 100''' PRN
- Flurbiprofen 100''
- Iron
- Simvastatin 80'
- Tamsulosn 0.4'
- Vit D
- Metformin 1000''
- Baclofen, strength unknown 1 tab QHS

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H 
RX *acetaminophen 325 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) 
hours Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
3.  Lidocaine 5% Patch 1 PTCH TD QAM L rib fx's 
RX *lidocaine-menthol [LidoPatch] 4 %-1 % 1 patch daily Disp 
#*14 Patch Refills:*0 
4.  TraMADol 50 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - Moderate 
RX *tramadol 50 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*20 Tablet Refills:*0 
5.  Baclofen 10 mg PO QHS  
6.  Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY  
7.  MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 1000 mg PO BID  
8.  Simvastatin 80 mg PO QPM  
9.  Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
[] Fractures of the posterior left sixth through 10th ribs. 
There is also a fracture of the 11th rib at its articulation 
with the spine.

[] Moderate left pneumothorax

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to ___ after a fall. Your chest x-ray and CT 
scan showed several fractured ribs on the left side and a 
partial lung collapse, from air collecting around the space of 
the lung (pneumothorax). You were monitored closely and a repeat 
x-ray showed the lung injury was stable and not expanding. Your 
pain is well controlled and you are breathing comfortably. You 
are cleared for discharge home to continue your recovery. You 
should get a repeat chest x-ray at your follow-up appointment 
with your PCP next ___.

*Please restart your metformin tomorrow ___. 

Your injury caused 6 rib fractures which can cause severe pain 
and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths because of 
the pain.
 
* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead 
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If 
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and 
notify your physician.
 
* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.
 
* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold 
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and 
deep breathing.
 
* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.
 
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.
 
* Do NOT smoke
 
* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
 
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs (crepitus).

 
Followup Instructions:
___

- LUNG NODULES: There is a 5 mm nodule in the left apex. There
are benign calcified granulomas in the right lung.
- PLEURAL SURFACES: There is a moderate left pneumothorax. There
is a small associated left pleural effusion.
- UPPER ABDOMEN: There is an incidental left upper pole renal
cyst. The spleen, kidneys, liver, pancreas, and adrenals are
otherwise unremarkable.
- AXILLAE: No axillary adenopathy is identified.
- MUSCULOSKELETAL: There are degenerative findings in the spine.
There is calcification along the anterior longitudinal ligament.
There is a 8mm area of dense sclerosis in the T4 vertebral body,
likely representing a bone island. There are fractures of the
posterior left sixth through 10th ribs. There is also a fracture
of the 11th rib at its articulation with the spine.
- ADDITIONAL FINDINGS: There is chest wall emphysema associated
with the rib fractures.
IMPRESSION:
1. Fractures of the posterior left sixth through 10th ribs.
2. Moderate left pneumothorax.
3. Left chest wall emphysema.
4. Partial collapse of the basilar segments left lower lobe.
There is a 5 mm left upper lobe nodule.
Brief Hospital Course:
___ male status post fall 5 days ago. CT scan notable
for multiple left-sided rib fractures and moderately sized but
potentially loculated pneumothorax. Patient evaluated by trauma
surgery, admitted to their service for further monitoring, no
chest tube recommended. The patient was hemodynamically stable.
Pain was well controlled. During this hospitalization, the
patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with
respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively
participated in the plan of care. The patient received
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this
stay. He was pulling ___ on the IS and oxygen was 93% on room
air. On HD2, repeat CXR showed moderate to large left
hydropneumothorax, unchanged from the prior study.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well
controlled. The patient was discharged home without services.
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with
the discharge plan.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to ___ after a fall. Your chest x-ray and CT
scan showed several fractured ribs on the left side and a
partial lung collapse, from air collecting around the space of
the lung (pneumothorax). You were monitored closely and a repeat
x-ray showed the lung injury was stable and not expanding. Your
pain is well controlled and you are breathing comfortably. You
are cleared for discharge home to continue your recovery. You
should get a repeat chest x-ray at your follow-up appointment
with your PCP next ___.
*Please restart your metformin tomorrow ___.
Your injury caused 6 rib fractures which can cause severe pain
and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths because of
the pain.
* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and
notify your physician.
* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures. In order to
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4
times every hour while awake. This will help expand the small
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that
pool in the lungs.
* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and
deep breathing.
* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short
periods may ease the pain.
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid
and fiber intake if possible.
* Do NOT smoke
* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin,
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation
around your ribs (crepitus).
Followup Instructions:
___

Chief Complaint:
Chest pain

None
 
History of Present Illness:
This patient is a ___ year old female with past medical
history of recently diagnosed Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, CHF,
GERD, and hypertension who was brought in by EMS with chest
pain.
 
The patient was laying in bed late last evening when she
began feeling pressure in her chest accompanied by
diaphoresis and lightheadedness. These symptoms were unremitting 
for a few hours, with no aggravating or relieving factors. She 
did not have radiation of her discomfort. This pressure was also 
giving her shortness of breath. She denies recent DOE, 
orthopnea, or PND. She has had no nausea or vomiting. 

She called EMS and was given sublingual nitroglycerine and 
aspirin by EMS in the ambulance with some relief of her 
symptoms. By the time she arrived at the ED, she was pain-free. 
She had troponins drawn that were negative, and an EKG showing 
t-wave inversions in all leads, otherwise no ST segment changes.

Of note, patient experienced similar pain last week while 
vacationing in ___. The patient reports that she was canoeing 
when she had chest pain and presented for evaluation at
___. She was found to have Takotsubo
cardiomyopathy and was anticoagulated and discharged home
after a clean cardiac catherization and an echo showing apical 
ballooning.

Patient is usually very active and has had a slight decrease in 
activity due to dyspnea; however, she can still walk many blocks 
before this happens.

___ 04:30PM BLOOD Osmolal-286

ECHO:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. Left ventricular wall 
thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional 
left ventricular systolic dysfunction with mild hypokinesis of 
the distal septum and anterior walls and apex. The apex is not 
aneurysmal. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 55 
%). There is no left ventricular outflow obstruction at rest or 
with Valsalva. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The 
aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good 
leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis. Trace aortic 
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild 
(1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Normal left ventricular cavity size with mild 
regional systolic dysfunction c/w distal LAD distribution. Mild 
mitral regurgitation with normal valve morphology. Mild 
pulmonary artery hypertension. Trace aortic regurgitation. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman with Takotsubo CM ddx'd last week who presents with 
chest pain, negative trops and no specific EKG chagnes.

#chest pain: given her clean coronary angiogram the week before 
admission, and the fact that the pain was unremitting for four 
hours, not associated with exertion, and associated with diffuse 
T wave inversions without troponin elevations make this less 
likely for an ACS picture. This chest pressure likely represents 
a recurrence of her Takotsubo cardiomyopathy with some evidence 
of heart failure, with vascular congestion on CXR. 
Patient was given a 10ml IV dose of lasix, to which she diuresed 
about 2 liters of fluid. She denied any further chest pain in 
the hospital and did not have any symptoms of dyspnea, 
orthopnea, or PND.
An echo taken showed continued wall-motion abnormalities in the 
anterior and inferior walls of the left ventricle, with an EF of 
55%.
On discharge, she had no further pain or dyspnea, patient was 
given nitroglycerin for any further chest pain, as well as lasix 
to take to avoid further volume overload. Her lisinopril was 
increased to 10mg daily for afterload reduction. She was 
counseled to continue taking her coumadin and to follow up with 
her outpatient cardiologist.

#hyponatremia: likely representing hypervolemic hyponatremia; 
resolved spontaneously without any specific treatment. She did 
not have any symptoms from her hyponatremia.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY 
2. Lisinopril 2.5 mg PO DAILY 
3. Warfarin 2.5 mg PO DAILY16 
4. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
5. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
6. Ipratropium Bromide MDI 2 PUFF IH Q6H:PRN wheezing 
7. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 2 SPRY NU BID:PRN congestion 

 
Discharge Medications:

2. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 2 SPRY NU BID:PRN congestion
