Refills:*0
4. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
5. Warfarin 2.5 mg PO DAILY16 
6. Ipratropium Bromide MDI 2 PUFF IH Q6H:PRN wheezing 
7. Metoprolol Succinate XL 50 mg PO DAILY 
RX *metoprolol succinate 50 mg 1 tablet extended release 24 
hr(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0
8. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 
RX *furosemide 20 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Daily Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*0
9. Nitroglycerin SL 0.4 mg SL PRN chest pain 
can take one every 5 minutes up to 3 times. If chest pain is not 
resolved, call ___. 
RX *nitroglycerin 0.4 mg 1 tablet sublingually q5 min x3 Disp 
#*20 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute heart failure 
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
Hyponatremia
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted for chest pain. After some tests we did, we 
determined that this is likely due to your takotsubo 
cardiomyopathy. You also had a bit of extra fluid in your body 
that we removed with the lasix medication.

If you have further episodes of chest pain, try nitroglycerin. 
If it continues, or if you have weight gain >3 lbs (current 
weight 120lbs) or shortness of breath, please call your doctor 
or return to the E.R.
 
Followup Instructions:

# Severe Aortic Regurgitation
# Culture Negative Endocarditis w/ AV vegetations
Patient presented with acute respiratory failure with acute 
heart failure exacerbation without any prior history. Work up 
included echocardiogram that showed 
moderate and small vegetations on noncoronary and right coronary 
leaflets respectively with severe aortic regurgitation. No 
perivalvular abscess identified. Patient underwent cardiac 
surgery evaluation with plan for AVR. Cardiac cath prior to AVR 
showed no significant coronary disease. Work up for culture 
negative endocarditis with evaluation for brucella, bartonalla, 
cockasackie ABs and HIV sent and all negative. Patient placed on 
vanc/unasyn (D1 on ___ per infectious disease recommendations 
for culture negative endocarditis with plan for #############
  
# Diastolic HF Exacerbation
Patient found to be in initial respiratory failure requiring 
BiPAP with mild troponin elevation and BNP elevation. Patient 
was diuresed with IV Lasix and BIPAP quickly weaned to RA. 
Cardiac cath did not show evidence of significant coronary 
disease. 

# Ascending Aortic Aneurysm: 
Patient underwent CTA that showed aneurysm most prominent at the 
aortic root/sinuses of Valsalva measuring 52 x 47 mm in 
diameter. The sino-tubular junction measures 42 x 46 mm.  The 
mid ascending  aorta measures 50 x 46 mm. Patient started on 
amlodipine for SBP goal of 105-120. C-surgery with likely plan 
for intervention in setting of AVR above. 

# ___, Resolved: 
Unknown baseline, likely pre-renal process secondary to contrast 
load and diuresis. Creatinine monitored and medications renally 
dosed. 

# Microcytic Anemia, stable: MCV 69; Meiznert Index ~13; 
thalassemia possible versus iron deficiency. No obvious signs or 
symptoms of blood loss. 

# Hypertension: Hypertensive to 200s systolic at ___, with 
baseline hypertension and med nonadherence. Stable w/ BPs 
100-130s in hospital. Amlodipine 10 mg daily started. 

# Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure, Resolved. Presented with acute 
respiratory distress, precipitated by flash pulmonary edema. 
Patient was diuresed with IV Lasix and BIPAP quickly weaned to 
RA. Cardiac cath did not show evidence of significant coronary 
disease.

The patient was brought to the Operating Room on ___ where 
the patient underwent Bentall procedure (23mm freestyle tissue 
graft and 26mm Gelweave tube graft with sidearm) with Dr. ___.  
Overall the patient tolerated the procedure well and 
post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable 
condition for recovery and invasive monitoring.  
 POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and 
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact 
and hemodynamically stable.  Beta blocker was initiated and the 
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  The

recovery.  Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued 
without complication.  The patient was evaluated by the physical 
therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility.  By 
the time of discharge on POD 5 the patient was ambulating 
freely, the wound was healing and pain was controlled with oral 
analgesics.  The patient was discharged home in good condition 
with appropriate follow up instructions.  She does not have 
benefits for ___ services.  Free care meds are arranged.

Sternal Incision - healing well, no erythema or drainage
Edema- none
Discharge Instructions:
Please shower daily -wash incisions gently with mild soap, no
baths or swimming, look at your incisions daily
Please - NO lotion, cream, powder or ointment to incisions
Each morning you should weigh yourself and then in the evening
take your temperature, these should be written down on the chart
No driving for approximately one month and while taking
narcotics
Clearance to drive will be discussed at follow up appointment
with surgeon
No lifting more than 10 pounds for 10 weeks
**Please call cardiac surgery office with any questions or
concerns ___. Answering service will contact on call
person during off hours**
Females: Please wear bra to reduce pulling on incision, avoid
rubbing on lower edge
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Tarry stools
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Esophagogastroduodenoscopy with endoclipping of duodenal ulcers

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with h/o GERD, HTN/HL, NIDDM, 
osteoarthritis/sacroiliitis who p/w tarry stools. She was in her 
USOH until 3 days prior to ED presentation, when she developed 
well-formed, but tarry stools, recurring ___ times on a daily 
basis since that time. She denies unintentional weight loss, 
f/c/s, n/v, hematemesis, diarrhea/constipation, BRBPR, or 
PeptoBismol or vitamin/supplement use. She denies EtOH, but has 
used NSAIDs for pain control in the past. Her GERD symptoms 
remain stable and are responsive to prn Pepcid at home. Of note, 
she denies prior screening colonoscopy or endoscopy. On 
evaluation by her PCP on the day PTA, she was noted to have Hct 
of 26.6, down from 36.5 in ___, with steady decline from 45 
since ___, and sent to the ED for further evaluation.    

In the ED, VS were as follows: 97.6 88 126/90 16 100% RA. CBC 
was notable for Hct of 25.6, essentially stable from the day PTA 
(26.6), and dark brown, guiac-positive stools were found.

In the setting of BP to 192/90 on arrival on the floor, she 
denies HA, visual changes, CP, SOB, or change in urinary 
frequency.

 
Past Medical History:
GERD
HTN/HL
NIDDM
OA
B12 deficiency anemia; s/p injections in ___
HL
Sacroiliitis
S/p R hip replacement
S/p hysterectomy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother and brother with presumed CAD. Sister with breast cancer. 
No other known h/o malignancy, cardiovascular disease, or DM. 
 
Physical Exam:
Exam on admission:
VS: 98.5 74 192/90 16 99%RA. 
General: Lying down comfortably in NAD.
HEENT: PERRL, EOM grossly intact, anicteric sclera. Oropharynx 
clear.
Neck: No JVD, no LAD.
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Lungs: Faint scattered rhonchi.
Abdomen: Normoactive bowel sounds. Soft, non-tender, 
non-distended. No rebound tenderness, no guarding.
Extremities: No edema, no erythema. 2+ DP and ___ pulses 
bilaterally.
Skin: Warm, dry, no rashes, no petechiae.
Neuro: Awake, A/O x3 with some confusion about the year.
Rectal: Per ED, dark brown stool, grossly heme positive
.
Exam at discharge:
VS: 98.3 80 136/72 98%RA
Lungs CTAB, rectal exam deferred, otherwise unchanged.
 
Pertinent Results:
Admission labs:
CBC: 5.9/25.6/348
Coags: ___
Lytes: 140/4.7/107/24/39/1.2/108  9.2/1.7/3.8
LFTs: ___

Discharge labs:
CBC: 8.6/31.2/304
Lytes: ___  8.7  1.9  3.2

EGD (___): Two small ulcers were found in D1, one of which was 
clean based. The second ulcer had a visible vessel. Attempts to 
inject epinephrine and place endoclips were aborted secondary to 
severe paradoxical agitation and difficulty with sedation.

EGD (___): 
Erythema in the antrum compatible with gastritis
Erythema in the first and second part of the duodenum compatible 
with duodenitis
Ulcer in the second part of the duodenum (injection, endoclip)
Ulcer in the second part of the duodenum (injection, endoclip)
Otherwise normal EGD to third part of the duodenum    
Impression: 
Normal mucosa in the whole esophagus
Mild erythema in the antrum compatible with gastritis
Mild erythema in the duodenum compatible with duodenitis
Ulcers in the duodenum
Otherwise normal EGD to third part of the duodenum 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with h/o GERD, HTN/HL, NIDDM, 
osteoarthritis/sacroiliitis who p/w tarry stools, with duodenal 
ulcers on EGD, now s/p endoclipping x2. 
-
#Melena: Patient with known h/o GERD and NSAID use p/w ___ 
well-formed, tarry stools per day x3 days in the setting of Hct 
of 26.6, down from 36.5 in ___, but otherwise asymptomatic and 
HD stable, and IV pantoprazole bid was initiated. On EGD on ___, 
she was found to have e/o gastritis, duodenitis, and 2 proximal 
duodenal ulcers, one with a clear vessel, but endoclipping was 
not attempted due to a paradoxical reaction to anesthesia, in 
which she became agitated, and pantoprazole bolus followed by 
drip was initiated at that time. After initial EGD, she received 
1u pRBC for Hct of 24.8, with appropriate bump to 29.5, prior to 
repeat EGD on ___, with endoclipping of both duodenal ulcers 
achieved at that time. She was continued on a pantoprazole drip 
for 72 hours, after which time PO pantoprazole bid was 
initiated, for a planned 8-week total course. She received an 
additional 2u pRBC for Hct of 24.3 3 days post-EGD, with 
appropriate bump to 31.2; anemia studies were difficult to 
interpret in the setting of acute GI bleed and transfusions, and 
repeat iron studies, with treatment as indicated, may be useful 
on PCP ___. She remained HD stable throughout, with the 
exception of transiently soft pressure to 99/52 in the setting 
of labetalol uptitration (see below), without recurrence of 
tarry stools for a few days by the time of discharge. 
-
#Hypertension: Patient with known h/o HTN p/w BP of 192/90 on 
arrival to the floor, likely due to missed doses of home 
antihypertensives in the ED, without symptoms suggestive of 
end-organ damage and with improvement to 150s-160s following 
early administration of evening labetalol. Although she 
continued to have infrequent SBP to 190s on the floor, 
invariably responsive to home labetalol, she otherwise remained 
in the 150s-160s, with the exception of SBP to 220 in the 
setting of epinephrine administration on repeat EGD ___, with 
improvement to 160s following 50mg IV labetalol. After trial 
increase in home labetalol from 100mg to 200mg bid, she remained 
largely normotensive with transiently soft pressure to 99/52, 
prompting reversion to home dosing, with SBP stably 100s-140s 
thereafter.
-
___: Cr was 1.3 on admission in the setting of poor PO intake, 
with return to baseline of 0.8-0.9 following IVF administration. 
Cr remained at baseline throughout admission on gentle 
maintenance IVF, which were discontinued once PO intake was 
adequate.
-
#NIDDM: Metformin was held on admission and FSBGs remained 
well-controlled in 100s, with infrequent 200s, on Humalog 
insulin sliding scale throughout admission, with return to 
Metformin planned at discharge. 
-
#HL: Home simvastatin was continued throughout admission.
-
#Osteoarthritis/sacroiliitis: Patient with h/o OA/sacroiliitis 
initially experienced chronic low back and hip pain on home 
regimen of hydrocodone-acetaminophen prn, perhaps because of 
difficulty remembering to request, with improved pain control on 
standing acetaminophen, with minimal prn oxycodone requirement. 
She underwent physical therapy for deconditioning on this 
admission, with continued ___ planned at rehabilitation.  
-
#Transitional Issues:
-Melena: Close GI ___ has been arranged. She should remain 
on bid pantoprazole for a total of 8 weeks, up to and including 
___. Iron studies were difficult to interpret on this admission 
in the setting of acute GI bleed and transfusion; reassessment 
of iron studies, with treatment as indicated, would be advised 
on PCP ___.
-HTN: She experienced labile SBP, 100s-190s, on her home 
antihypertensive regimen, with soft pressures on uptitration of 
labetalol and ultimate return to home dosing; PCP ___ is 
being arranged.

 
Medications on Admission:
HYDROCHLOROTHIAZIDE - 25 mg tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a
day
HYDROCODONE-ACETAMINOPHEN - 5 mg-500 mg tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by
mouth every six (6) hours as needed for prn pain
LABETALOL - 100 mg tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth twice a day
LOSARTAN - 100 mg tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day
METFORMIN - 500 mg tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth twice a day
SIMVASTATIN - 40 mg tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 
2. Labetalol 100 mg PO BID 
Hold for SBP < 100, HR < 60. 
3. Losartan Potassium 100 mg PO DAILY 
4. Simvastatin 40 mg PO DAILY 
5. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-500mg 1 TAB PO Q6H:PRN pain 
6. MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 500 mg PO BID 
7. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q12H 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Duodenal ulcers s/p endoclipping
Gastritis/duodenitis
active duodenal ulcer with bleeding
acute blood loss anemia
acute renal failure
 
Discharge Condition:
Discharge condition: Improved, no recurrent tarry stools
Mental status: Occasionally mildly confused
Ambulatory status: With assistance, consistent with baseline

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you. You were admitted for 
tarry stools and declining red blood cell count and found to 
have bleeding ulcers in your small intestine, which were clipped 
and have since stopped bleeding. You also were treated with an 
antiulcer medication (pantoprazole), which you should continue 
to take at discharge for a total of 8 weeks. In addition, your 
blood pressures were occasionally elevated in the hospital, and 
your home dose of labetalol was temporarily increased, but is 
now back to normal. 

The following changes were made to your medication list:
Pantoprazole 40mg twice daily - added - Please take for 8 weeks, 
up to and including ___.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Ambien
 
Attending: ___
 
___ Complaint:
Vision loss
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
___ year-old right-handed man with a history of reported coronary 
artery disease s/p CABG, dyslipidemia, and lymphoma, who 
presents as a transfer from ___ after presentation with 
vision loss and falls.  The history is obtained from the 
patient, who has some difficulty relaying the details, and 
available
documentation.

The patient reports that he was in his usual health until ~3 
weeks ago.  One day, while opening his eyes after showering, he 
found that he could not see from his right eye. The patient 
states that vision in his left eye was preserved.  He had 
difficulty reaching for objects in the right side of his field 
of vision.  The patient also states that he had several falls at 
that time, which he also attributed to his visual loss.  
However, over the following day, he reports that the vision in 
his right eye improved.  It remained "blurred" and did not 
entirely return to baseline.  He could see objects in front of 
the eye and could reportedly discern color.  He reports that he 
was assessed by his internist for these difficulties, and it was 
presumed that he had a "stroke."  Interestingly, he states this 
evening that he did not undergo imaging of his head at that time 
and no further evaluation or management was pursued.

At the time of the event above, he had developed a building, 
sharp, right-sided headache, located retro-orbitally and 
involving the frontal and occipital regions.  It does not seem 
to radiate elsewhere.  He states that he has had the pain daily 
since that time, lasting for the majority of each day.  Though 
he has had occasional associated nocturnal awakening, he denies 
changes with position or Valsalva.  He states that he also has 
associated neck discomfort, but denies a history of trauma or 
manipulation.

According to available documentation, he was "last seen normal" 
at ~9 pm on ___ evening.  However, he awoke on ___ 
morning at ~7 am and noted worsening "blurred" vision in his 
right eye.  Though he usually walked with a walker, he was 
having worsening trouble with ambulation; the patient states 
tonight that he had fallen.  Family was apparently concerned 
that he was confused and "usually sharper" than his current 
state.  Blood pressure was 124/92, pulse 84.  His pupils were 
"pinpoint."  He was brought ___.  ___ 
physicians were concerned by the presence of "medial rectus 
weakness" on the right side.  There was no evidence of atrial 
fibrillation on EKG. CXR showed no pneumonia.  A head CT, which 
I reviewed here,
showed atrophy and a poorly defined low density region in the 
left parieto-occipital region, ~2 cm in diameter.  There was no 
hemorrhage.  He was sent to ___ for further evaluation.

Review of Systems:
Has had diarrhea for the past 4 months.  Family has told him 
that his speech is dysarthric, though he denies incomprehension. 
 He denies fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, focal weakness, 
numbness, tingling.
 
Past Medical History:
-CAD, s/p CABG, CHF, dyslipidemia, lymphoma, gout

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Daughter with hypertension

 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: T 98.1 F    BP 124/71   P 92    RR 18    SaO2 95 RA
General: NAD, well nourished
HEENT: NC/AT, sclerae anicteric, dry MM, no exudates in
oropharynx
Neck: neck has pain with minimal rotation worse toward the 
right,
no bruits
Lungs: clear to auscultation 
CV: regular rate and rhythm, no MMRG 
Abdomen:  soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present
Ext: arthritic digits, warm, no edema, pedal pulses appreciated
Skin: left deltoid ecchymosis
 
Neurologic Examination: 
Mental Status: 
Somnolent but easily arousable, difficulty relaying coherent
history, cooperative with exam 
Oriented to person, ___, ___
Attention: cannot perform days of week backward without errors 
Language: fluent, perhaps mildly dysarthric speech, no 
paraphasic
errors, naming, comprehension, repetition intact; reading intact
(uses left eye only)
Calculation: can determine 7 quarters in $1.75
Fund of knowledge: mentions recent election 
Memory: registration: ___ items, recall ___ items at 3 minutes 
No evidence of apraxia or neglect 
 
Cranial Nerves: 
Uncorrected acuity ___ on the left, ___ on the right.  
Optic
discs could not be visualized due to miosis; visual fields are
difficult to perform by confrontation, perhaps reduced blink to
threat on the right.  Pupils 1.5 mm and unreactive bilaterally. 
No ptosis.  His right eye does not adduct on leftward gaze, and
appears a bit abducted and depressed in primary position.  
Facial
sensation intact bilaterally.  Face moves symmetrically, though
with left NLFF and flattening of left forehead creases.  Hearing
reduced to conversation. Palate elevates midline. Tongue
protrudes midline, no fasciculations.  Trapezii full strength
bilaterally. 
 
Motor: 
Appears diffusely wasted, with fasciculations in legs and in 
left
hand noted.  Perhaps mildly increased tone in legs.  No pronator
drift.  Strength appears preserved throughout.    
 
Sensation: Stocking distribution loss to pin prick, temperature
(cold).  Vibration absent at ankles.  Proprioception impaired to
smaller amplitudes in fingers and toes bilaterally.  No
extinction to DSS.

Reflexes: B T Br Pa Pl 
Right     ___  2  0 
Left      ___  2  0  
Toes were mute bilaterally. 
 
Coordination: Unable to perform FNF accurately due to his
diplopia and vision loss.  He initially misses on HKS
bilaterally, but corrects with repeat attempts on each side.
 
Gait:  Retropulses on standing, unable to proceed forward

___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Neuro - Patient was admitted to the General Neurology service.  
He was evaluated by ophthalmology who felt this was most 
consistent with a partial CN III palsy secondary to ischemia or 
inflammation.  Review of CT scan showed hypodensity in 
periaqueductal area, hypodensity in L temporal area c/w old 
infarct, and soft tissue mass around the foramen magnum.  
Sedimentation rate and CRP were nl.  Electrolytes within normal 
limits.  

Initially did not tolerate MRI x2 attempts.  Required MRI with 
anaesthesia to eval for ischemic process and to further evaluate 
soft tissue mass around foramen magnum.  There was some concern 
for lymphoma given h/o lymphoma to explain both soft tissue mass 
and possible infiltrating process.  

MRI/MRA brain, orbit and neck with and without contrast showed:
1. Enhancing soft tissue lesion at the skull base, surrounding 
the dens, with 
pre-contrast signal characteristics most consistent with fibrous 
tissue, 
including central focus of hypoenhancement. This appearance 
might be seen 
with crystalline arthropathy such as CPPD arthropathy, with 
pannus secondary 
to an inflammatory arthritis such as rheumatoid or one of its 
variants 
(thought the pattern of dorsal involvement is atypical), or 
"pseudo- pannus" 
due to osteoarthritis. Though there are erosive changes in the 
dens, 
pyogenic infection is considered less likely, as there is no 
visible fluid 
signal centrally; relatively "indolent" infection is an 
additional 
consideration. Lymphomatous involvement of the dura is a more 
remote 
possibility, particularly given that the patient has been ___ 
for several 
years, and also would also not readily explain the central 
hypoenhancement. 
  
2. Subacute infarction in the right midbrain, in the region of 
the 
periaqueductal white matter and median longitudinal fasciculus, 
likely 
explaining the recent symptoms. 
  
3. Extensive small vessel ischemic disease, atrophy, and old 
left 
frontotemporal infarct with likely prior laminar necrosis and 
dystrophic 
mineralization. 

Post anaesthesia, patient had quadriparesis and bilateral ptosis 
without any sensory findings.  Gradually improved over a few 
hours.  He received vecuronium during anaesthesia and was not 
reversed.  Likely weakness was secondary to vecuronium slow to 
wear off.  Did monitor in ICU overnight, following NIF and VC, 
in case of myasthenia but in the end did not think that this was 
the cause of his weakness.  

Neuro-oncology consulted.  He felt though unlikely soft tissue 
mass is lymphoma, cannot be fully ruled out.  Recommended LP for 
cytology, but patient and family declined both in discussion 
with neuro-oncology and with primary team. The very clearly said 
that they did not want any more tests, just wanted to go home.  
We did discuss findings during admission with his primary 
oncologist Dr. ___ will continue to follow the patient 
as an oupatient.   

Neuro-surgery involved.  Based on MRI findings did not recommend 
biopsy.  

___ cranial nerve palsy with limited adduction and upgaze of R 
eye and mild ptosis is likely fascicular.  MRI showing subacute 
infarct in R pariaquiductal area consistent with clinical 
course.  Started on aspirin.  Given poor heart function, further 
discussion regarding anticoagulation may be warranted, but 
family does not want any further interventions at this time.  
Also patient is a fall risk.  continued on lipitor.  

Further history indicated ___ h/o cognitive decline. As 
inpatient mild cognitive difficulties noted on MS exams.  RPR 
NR.  B12 and folate normal.  TSH 2.4.  Mental status

CV - Ruled out myocardial infarction and monitored on telemetry 
without events.  Aspirin 325mg daily was started.  Fasting lipid 
panel chol 102, HDL 38, LDL 51, trigl 66.  Urinanalysis and Utox 
negative.  TSH 2.4.  HbA1C was 7.5%, should be addressed as an 
outpatient.   Surface echocardiogram showed EF ___, moderate 
MR and TR, at least mild pulmonary artery hypertension.  
Patient was noted to be in mild acute renal failure likely due 
to prerenal azotemia which improved slightly with mild IV 
resuscitation.  His baseline creatinine per PMD office was 1.9.  
Creatinine 1.5 on discharge.  

Metabolic - He was started on thiamine, folate and multivitamin 
for history of daily alcohol use.  

Dispo planning - Physical therapy evaluated patient and 
recommended that he needs 24hr supervision.  Also home safety 
eval.  Family refused to have us help with arranging home 
services.  They are being arranged through his oncologist, Dr. 
___.  We confirmed that their office is indeed 
arranging services.  Family also wishes to investigate 
palliative care options, but does not wish to have consult while 
inpatient.  Case discussed with PMD and oncologist.  

 
Medications on Admission:
Klor-con 20 QD
Furosemide 40mg QD
Carvedilol 3.125mg BID
Lipitor 10mg QD
Allopurinol 20mg QD
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Thiamine HCl 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Folic Acid 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Furosemide 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
6. Carvedilol 6.25 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).  
7. Atorvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
8. Allopurinol ___ mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary diagnosis:
Ischemic partial cranial nerve III palsy
soft tissue around foramen magnum

Secondary diagnosis:
Coronary artery disease
Status coronary artery bypass graft
Coronary heart failure
Dyslipidemia
History of lymphoma
Gout

 
Discharge Condition:
Partial cranial nerve three palsy.
Stable.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for double vision and falls.  You were 
diagnosed with a cranial nerve 3 palsy.  It was also noted that 
you have a soft tissue mass around the base of your skull where 
the brainstem and spinal cord meet.  It is most likely fibrous 
tissue, but lymphoma cannot be ruled out.  We recommended lumbar 
puncture but you declined.   

You need 24 hour supervision and physical therapy.  Appropriate 
services should be arranged through your primary doctors as ___ 
have declined our help with arranging services.  

Please take your medications as prescribed.

Please keep your follow-up appointments.

If you have any worsening or worrying symptoms, please call your 
PCP or come into the ED.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ initially presented to the ___ ED on ___ with 
abdominal pain. He was found to have an incarcerated incisional 
hernia at the site of his previous colostomy by CT scan. He was 
taken to the operating room overnight on ___ for a 
ventral hernia repair. For details of the operation, please see 
surgeon's operative report. He tolerated the procedure well and 
was extubated upon completion. He was subsequently taken to the 
PACU for recovery.

He was transferred to the surgical floor hemodynamically stable. 
His vital signs were routinely monitored and he remained 
afebrile and hemodynamically stable. His previously created end 
ileostomy was functioning by POD1, productive of both stool and 
gas. His diet was therefore advanced, which he tolerated without 
abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. His foley was removed and 
he voided spontaneously. 

He was encouraged to mobilize out of bed and ambulate as 
tolerated, which he was able to do independently. His pain level 
was routinely assessed and well controlled at discharge with an 
oral regimen as needed. His JP drain continued to have 
serosanguinous output and was left in place on discharge with a 
plan for removal in clinic.

follow-up scheduled with Dr. ___.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Incarcerated Ventral Hernia 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service on ___ 
with an incarcerated ventral hernia and underwent surgery to 
reduce the hernia and repair the defect. You are recoverying 
well from surgery, tolerating a regular diet, and pain is 
controlled with oral medications. You are now ready to be 
discharged home to conintue your recovery.

Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

JP Drain Care:
*Please look at the site every day for signs of infection 
(increased redness or pain, swelling, odor, yellow or bloody 
discharge, warm to touch, fever).
*Maintain suction of the bulb.
*Note color, consistency, and amount of fluid in the drain. Call 
the doctor, ___, or ___ nurse if the amount 
increases significantly or changes in character.
*Be sure to empty the drain frequently. Record the output, if 
instructed to do so.
*You may shower; wash the area gently with warm, soapy water.
*Keep the insertion site clean and dry otherwise.
*Avoid swimming, baths, hot tubs; do not submerge yourself in 
water.
*Make sure to keep the drain attached securely to your body to 
prevent pulling or dislocation.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ initially presented to the ___ ED on ___ with
abdominal pain. He was found to have an incarcerated incisional
hernia at the site of his previous colostomy by CT scan. He was
taken to the operating room overnight on ___ for a
ventral hernia repair. For details of the operation, please see
surgeon's operative report. He tolerated the procedure well and
was extubated upon completion. He was subsequently taken to the
PACU for recovery.
He was transferred to the surgical floor hemodynamically stable.
His vital signs were routinely monitored and he remained
afebrile and hemodynamically stable. His previously created end
ileostomy was functioning by POD1, productive of both stool and
gas. His diet was therefore advanced, which he tolerated without
abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. His foley was removed and
he voided spontaneously.
He was encouraged to mobilize out of bed and ambulate as
tolerated, which he was able to do independently. His pain level
was routinely assessed and well controlled at discharge with an
oral regimen as needed. His JP drain continued to have
serosanguinous output and was left in place on discharge with a
plan for removal in clinic.
On ___ (POD3), the patient was discharged home with
follow-up scheduled with Dr. ___.

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt is an ___ year old woman with history of hypertension and 
dementia who presented with hypoxia of unknown etiology.  
 
Hypoxia/Shortness of breath: 
The patient was initially admitted to the MICU for hypoxia of an 
unclear etiology, and was quickly weaned from non-rebreather 
oxygen to room air. The patient was evaluated for pulmonary 
embolism by a CT angiogram which did not show any abnormalities. 
The pt did not have fever or leukocytosis and there was no 
evidence of consolidation on chest x-ray to suggest an 
infectious cause of hypoxia. The pt had an echocardiogram which 
showed an intra-atrial aneurysm with left-to-right shunting, but 
this did not seem like the likely source of the pt's hypoxia. 
Shunt unlikely, no significant atelectasis on CT, no history of 
AVMs. Cardiac biomarkers were cycled and the patient did not 
show any evidence (on EKG or cardiac enzymes) of coronary 
disease. On the floor the pt oxygenated well with no 
de-saturations on room air, and was able to ambulate without any 
desaturations on room air. Ultimately the patient's hypoxia was 
attributed either to a temporary mucous plug or to a transient 
aspiration pneumonitis.
.
Hypertension:
The patient was continued on her home medications: Atenolol 50 
mg daily, Norvasc 10mg daily, hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily. 
 
.  
Hypercholestermia: 
The patient was continued on her home dose of Crestor.  
.  
Dementia: 
The patient was confused in the ICU, and oriented only to self. 
Initially on the floor the patient was agitiated, trying to get 
out of bed. Given the family's concern that the pt's memory was 
not benefitting from Aricept and Namenda, and that the Aricept 
and Namenda were actually causing memory impairments, the 
Aricept and Namenda were discontinued. The pt was continued on 
her home doses of her anti-depressant medications venlafaxine 
and paroxetine.
.  
Chronic renal failure: 
The patient's creatinine was noted to be at baseline (1.2 to 
1.9) during this hospitalization. Nephrotoxins were avoided. 
.  
DNR/DNI:
The patient's code status was DNR DNI during this admission, and 
this was confirmed with the patient and her family. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Amlodipine 10mg daily  
Atenolol 50mg daily  
Aricept 2.5mg daily  
hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 daily  
namenda 5mg faily  
Paroxetine  
Actonel 35mg weekly  
Crestor 20mg ___  
Venlafaxine 75mg daily  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Amlodipine 5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

2. Atenolol 25 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
3. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
4. Rosuvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. Venlafaxine 75 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).  
6. Paroxetine HCl 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a 
day.  
7. Actonel 35 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a week.  
8. Colace 50 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
9. B-12 DOTS 500 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary diagnosis:
Aspiration pneumonitis
.
Secondary diagnosis:
Dementia
Hypertension

 
Discharge Condition:
Good.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with shortness of breath and decreased oxygen 
saturation. You were transferred the the medical intensive care 
unit and quickly taken off nasal cannula oxygen. You had a 
normal chest xray that did not show pneumonia and you also had a 
normal CT scan of your chest that showed a small pulmonary 
nodule. You have not had additional shortness of breath in the 
hospital and your blood oxygen saturations have been normal. 
.
You have the below appointments, it is very important that you 
attend your follow-up appointments.
.
We have discontinued the Aricept and Namenda that you were 
taking, since your family did not think that you were 
benefitting from these medications.
.
We have continued all of your other home medications. Please 
continue taking your other home medications.
.
If you develop any sudden shortness of breath, chest pain, 
dizzyness, nausea and vomiting or lightheadedness, please call 
your primary care doctor or go to the emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt is an ___ year old woman with history of hypertension and
dementia who presented with hypoxia of unknown etiology.
Hypoxia/Shortness of breath:
The patient was initially admitted to the MICU for hypoxia of an
unclear etiology, and was quickly weaned from non-rebreather
oxygen to room air. The patient was evaluated for pulmonary
embolism by a CT angiogram which did not show any abnormalities.
The pt did not have fever or leukocytosis and there was no
evidence of consolidation on chest x-ray to suggest an
infectious cause of hypoxia. The pt had an echocardiogram which
showed an intra-atrial aneurysm with left-to-right shunting, but
this did not seem like the likely source of the pt's hypoxia.
Shunt unlikely, no significant atelectasis on CT, no history of
AVMs. Cardiac biomarkers were cycled and the patient did not
show any evidence (on EKG or cardiac enzymes) of coronary
disease. On the floor the pt oxygenated well with no
de-saturations on room air, and was able to ambulate without any
desaturations on room air. Ultimately the patient's hypoxia was
attributed either to a temporary mucous plug or to a transient
aspiration pneumonitis.
.
Hypertension:
The patient was continued on her home medications: Atenolol 50
mg daily, Norvasc 10mg daily, hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily.
.
Hypercholestermia:
The patient was continued on her home dose of Crestor.
.
Dementia:
The patient was confused in the ICU, and oriented only to self.
Initially on the floor the patient was agitiated, trying to get
out of bed. Given the family's concern that the pt's memory was
not benefitting from Aricept and Namenda, and that the Aricept
and Namenda were actually causing memory impairments, the
Aricept and Namenda were discontinued. The pt was continued on
her home doses of her anti-depressant medications venlafaxine
and paroxetine.
.
Chronic renal failure:
The patient's creatinine was noted to be at baseline (1.2 to
1.9) during this hospitalization. Nephrotoxins were avoided.
.
DNR/DNI:
The patient's code status was DNR DNI during this admission, and
this was confirmed with the patient and her family.

Amlodipine 10mg daily
Atenolol 50mg daily
Aricept 2.5mg daily
hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 daily
namenda 5mg faily
Paroxetine
Actonel 35mg weekly
Crestor 20mg ___
Venlafaxine 75mg daily

You were admitted with shortness of breath and decreased oxygen
saturation. You were transferred the the medical intensive care
unit and quickly taken off nasal cannula oxygen. You had a
normal chest xray that did not show pneumonia and you also had a
normal CT scan of your chest that showed a small pulmonary
nodule. You have not had additional shortness of breath in the
hospital and your blood oxygen saturations have been normal.
.
You have the below appointments, it is very important that you
attend your follow-up appointments.
.

benefitting from these medications.
.

continue taking your other home medications.
.

dizzyness, nausea and vomiting or lightheadedness, please call
your primary care doctor or go to the emergency room.

AMA who now presents with abdominal pain, hematuria, urinary

after one day of two maroon stools. Around 11am today the 
patient had a malodorous black formed stool with bright red 
blood on the toilet paper. He described the stool as different 
from his usual stool in character. There was no blood in the 
toilet bowl. He had another similar but smaller bowel movement 
this afternoon. No pain or straining with defecation, no 
fever/chills, no abdominal pain, no emesis. He did recently have 
an episode of gastroenteritis around ___ with emesis 
and diarrhea (multiple other family members sick as well); after 
this his stools did return to normal. He did note some dizziness 
this AM but no CP, SOB, or syncope. He does endorse mild RLQ 
discomfort that is relieved by lying flat. Of note the patient 
has been taking Naproxen 500 mg PO x2 daily for the past 2 
months for osteoarthritis pain. He rarely drinks EtOH and is not 
on steroids, though he was recently started on a topical steroid 
cream that he has been using liberally.  
In his PCP's office, VS were stable and he was not orthostatic 
(stand->seat->sup: HR 100->91->84, BP 126/60->124/58->124/64).

further evaluation. In the ED, initial vital signs were: 98.2 60

baseline 16 in ___, lytes, renal function, and coags were 
normal. Patient was given 80 mg IV bolus of pantoprazole and was 
admitted. On Transfer Vitals were: 97.9 89 129/86 16 96% RA.  
On the floor, the patient was comfortable and had no complaints. 
Overnight he had one small maroon bowel movement around 2:30a 
and remained hemodynamically stable.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with history of LGIB who is presenting with one day of 
maroon stools in the setting of 2 months of regular NSAID use.

#GI Bleed: Patient presented from PCP with reports of 2 maroon 
stools with BRBPR on toilet paper. Was hemodynamically stable 
during hospitalization. Last colonscopy in ___ showed colonic 
adenoma, internal hemorrhoids, and sigmoid diverticulosis. 
Patient had H/H at baseline during hospital course without 
concern for brisk UGIB. Rectal exam with blood in vault, 
consistent with LGIB from internal hemorrhoids. NSAIDS held. 
Sent home on stool softener and hydrocortisone suppositories. To 
follow up with GI and to have PCP check CBC as outpatient to 
ensure H/H remains stable. 

# HTN: With concern for UGIB initially held both 
hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril. Blood pressures normal 
during hospitalization, so discharged home only on home dose of 
lisinopril with instructions to follow up with PCP on blood 
pressure control. 

# MSK pain: Held naproxen with concerns of GI bleed. Pain 
controlled with tylenol, which he was discharged home on.

# Xerosis: Continued on home fluocinolone cream. 

# OSA: Continued on CPAP

# Asthma: Stable. Continued on home theophylline, fluticasone, 
salmeterol, and albuterol

# Gout: Not currently an active issue
  
# BPH: Initially held tamsulosin overnight. Restarted during 
hospitalization and discharged on tamsulosin. 

Transitional Issues:
- discharged with colace and hydrocortisone suppositories
- stop NSAIDS
- f/u outpatient cbc to ensure blood counts stable
- outpatient GI follow-up
- home hctz held for normotension, restart as indicated as 
outpatient

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay at ___. 
You were admitted for blood in your stool. Rectal exam showed 
fresh blood consistent with internal hemorrhoids, which you have 
had in the past (last seen on colonoscopy last year). Your blood 
counts remained stable, as did your vital signs, and you were 
deemed safe for discharge home with outpatient follow-up.

In the interim, please take a daily stool softener and rectal 
suppositories with hydrocortisone to help decrease the 
inflammation in your rectum. This bleeding should resolve over 
time.

You will also be provided a prescription to have outpatient 
labwork drawn and faxed to your primary doctor to ensure your 
blood counts remain stable.

Please avoid taking further aleve and switch to tylenol, not to 
exceed 3 grams per day, for arthritis pain.

Wishing you well,
Your ___ Medicine Team

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with history of LGIB who is presenting with one day of
maroon stools in the setting of 2 months of regular NSAID use.
#GI Bleed: Patient presented from PCP with reports of 2 maroon
stools with BRBPR on toilet paper. Was hemodynamically stable
during hospitalization. Last colonscopy in ___ showed colonic
adenoma, internal hemorrhoids, and sigmoid diverticulosis.
Patient had H/H at baseline during hospital course without
concern for brisk UGIB. Rectal exam with blood in vault,
consistent with LGIB from internal hemorrhoids. NSAIDS held.
Sent home on stool softener and hydrocortisone suppositories. To
follow up with GI and to have PCP check CBC as outpatient to
ensure H/H remains stable.
# HTN: With concern for UGIB initially held both
hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril. Blood pressures normal
during hospitalization, so discharged home only on home dose of
lisinopril with instructions to follow up with PCP on blood
pressure control.
# MSK pain: Held naproxen with concerns of GI bleed. Pain
controlled with tylenol, which he was discharged home on.
# Xerosis: Continued on home fluocinolone cream.
# OSA: Continued on CPAP
# Asthma: Stable. Continued on home theophylline, fluticasone,
salmeterol, and albuterol
# Gout: Not currently an active issue
# BPH: Initially held tamsulosin overnight. Restarted during
hospitalization and discharged on tamsulosin.
Transitional Issues:
- discharged with colace and hydrocortisone suppositories
- stop NSAIDS
- f/u outpatient cbc to ensure blood counts stable
- outpatient GI follow-up
- home hctz held for normotension, restart as indicated as
outpatient

Dear Mr. ___,
It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay at ___.
You were admitted for blood in your stool. Rectal exam showed
fresh blood consistent with internal hemorrhoids, which you have

counts remained stable, as did your vital signs, and you were
deemed safe for discharge home with outpatient follow-up.

junctional escape rhythm at approximately 35 BPM and retrograde
atrial conduction, baseline 1st degree AV delay and RBBB
morphology, but otherwise no ST segment changes to suggest

subsequently admitted to Medicine for further management. Of

amputation.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
=================
Mr. ___ is a ___ gentleman w/ PMH of anemia, 
hypertension, hyperlipidemia, peripheral vascular disease, AAA 
s/p EVAR, GERD, EtOH cirrhosis, who presents as a transfer from 
___ for evaluation and management of bradycardia, course 
complicated by necrotic toe s/p amputation.

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
# Peripheral vascular disease complicated by necrotic toe wound
s/p amputation: 
Patient has had significant left second toe pain and redness for 
the past several weeks, and was referred to hospital for 
possible toe debridement. Continues to report left foot pain 
associated with his wound. Likely ___ the setting of extensive 
lower extremity vascular disease. ABI: "Moderate to severe 
aortoiliac stenosis resulting ___ severely reduced flow ___ the 
left toe and moderately reduced flow ___ the distal right lower 
extremity." 

Podiatry was consulted and recommended amputation. His toe was 
amputated on ___. Vascular was consulted but differed on 
performing an angio but agreed with the toe amputation. Per 
vascular, if it does not heal well, then will consider BKA. 
Currently the foot is healing well. He was on 
Vanc/Ceftriaxone/Flagl from ___. The antibiotics were 
stopped once the margins were determined to be on pathology.   

# Macrocytic Anemia
Hb stable, but notable for an MCV of 94 on admission and a slow 
trend of increasing MCV to 101. Retic is high. Suspect the 
etiology is secondary to increased production of Retics (RDW 
also trended up) iso of either increased nutrition 
supplementation or resolution of anemia of inflammation s/p 
amputation and continued abx. MM effect is on the ddx but less 
likely based on the acuity. Discharge Hb: 9.9. Discharge MCV: 
102. 

# Capacity assessment/Code Status
There is a recurring theme of the family, particularly the son, 
being exceedingly difficult to contact ___ the past and present. 
However, we were able to get ___ contact with the daughter who 
gave consent for the procedures and stated that the brother 
"fell of the face of the earth" and would be nearly impossible 
to get ___ touch with him. Attempts to contact pt's son were 
unsuccessful.  

Daughter was OK with Full code for the procedure and 
___ period and believes it is within pt's goals of 
care. Daughter will t/b with her mother and pt's ex-wife about 
code status. However, it appears that Mr. ___ has 
capacity, or at least capacity for most situations. There was 
some concern a few months ago when he developed a stroke and had 
AMS but that appears to be resolved now. 

During this hospitalization, Mr. ___ wanted to contact 
his friend ___. Unfortunately, we were unable to 
contact him as all Mr. ___ knows is that he lives 
somewhere on ___, ___. Mr. ___ 
stated that he would be okay with ___ as his 
healthcare proxy. Please follow up on contacting his friend if 
there is a concern about his capacity/need for a health care 
proxy.     

# Intermittent sinus pauses:
Sinus node dysfunction, possibly present as early as ___. With 
caveat of dementia, not apparently symptomatic. If becomes 
symptomatic will require PPM if within goals. He remained 
asymptomatic during this hospital course and cardiology felt 
that he was stable and did not require any intervention. Prior 
EKG's show junctional escape possibly present since ___ 
with sinus bradycardia ___ ___ otherwise. His home metoprolol 
was held during admission and on discharge.

# EtOH Cirrhosis:
Patient is unable to state when he was diagnosed with cirrhosis. 
Per chart review, cirrhosis is believed to be secondary to 
alcohol. Patient is also unable to say whether he has ever 
required a paracentesis, had a bleed from his GI tract, or taken 
lactulose, although based on his pharmacy fill records it 
appears that he took lactulose briefly ___ ___. Patient 
reports that he doesn't follow with a hepatologist and his 
cirrhosis is managed by his PCP. Patient is unable to remember 
the name of his PCP, but based on pharmacy fill records, is Dr. 
___. He was continued on lactulose 30mL TID. 

# Multiple Myeloma:
He was previously DNR/DNI/DNH on hospice services at ___ 
having decided to not continue chemotherapy for Multiple 
Myeloma. However, over time he gradually improved clinically and 
was discharged from hospice. Since then, per family, he was 
changed to full code. However, there have been no discussion to 
continue any further treatment. 
hx:
- IgG lambda Multiple Myelma ISS Stage III for which he was 
placed on hospice ___ ___. Discharged from hospice a few month 
ago. 
- S/p 8 cycles Bortezomib-dex ending ___
- S/p 13 cycles maintenance

Dear Mr. ___, 
It was a privilege caring for you at ___ 
___.  

WHY WAS I ___ THE HOSPITAL?  
- You came to the hospital because your toe was infected.

WHAT HAPPENED TO ME ___ THE HOSPITAL?  
- The foot doctors ___ your ___ determined that it was so 
infected that they had to cut it off. They were worried that the 
infection would spread if they did not remove the toe.

- We started and continued high strength antibiotics until it 
was clear to us that the infection was not spreading.  We 
determined this by looking under the microscope of the tissue 
bordering your infected toe.

appointments.

location.
7. Incidentally noted is mildly enlarged, heterogeneous thyroid, 
with the largest nodule in the left lobe measuring 1.3cm. 
Thyroid needs further evaluation with ultrasound for better 
assessment.
8. Mildly dilated fluid filled lower cervical esophagus with 
thickened wall which can be due to achalasia and esophagitis or 
other causes. To correlate clinically.

Thyroid ultrasound ___: The right thyroid lobe measures 2.0 x 
2.2 x 5.3 cm. The left thyroid lobe measures 1.8 x 2.1 x 4.5 cm. 
There are multiple colloid cysts in both thyroid lobes, the 
largest of which is seen on the left and measures approximately 
1.5 cm in greatest dimension. There is a 0.7 x 0.8 x 0.8 cm 
mildly heterogeneous isoechoic nodule in the lateral aspect of 
the right thyroid lobe.   
Incidental note is made of an enlarged lymph node with internal 
architecture in the lateral aspect of the neck adjacent to the 
carotid artery and jugular 
vein. This lymph node measures 0.8 x 0.7 x 1.5 cm. No other 
pathologically 
enlarged lymph nodes are identified. A few other smaller 
subcentimeter mild heterogeneous nodules are identified in both 
thyroid lobes that do not demonstrate any specific worrisome 
intrinsic characteristics. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
1. Bilateral colloid cysts and small subcentimeter nodules that 
do not 
demonstrate any specific intrinsic worrisome characteristics. 
2. Enlarged lymph node in the left aspect of the neck with 
abnormal internal architecture. 

Carotid U/S (repeated in ___ on ___ - no significant 
stenosis bilaterally. Formal report pending. (Carotids US ___: 
There is a less than 40% right ICA stenosis and less than 40% 
left ICA stenosis with antegrade flow in both vertebral 
arteries. ). 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Neuro - The patient was admitted to the stepdown unit of 
Neurology for close monitoring of her neurological and 
cardiovascular status. She made a remarkable recovery making 
fluent and purposeful movements with the left hand and with only 
a residual pronator drift, a MRC 4+ hemiparesis, dense L facial 
droop, and slurred speech. She did neglect the R, but only 
mildly - later on it was only evident as tactile extinction on 
the L, and anosognosia with motor impersistance. She has 
hammertoes, but the R toe is downgoing and the L up on plantar 
reflexes. 

CARDIOV - Her newly diagnosed Afib was initially difficult to 
control with PRN IV medications as diltiazem and metoprolol, so 
she was started on a diltiazem drip. Her bloodpressure dropped 
and given her CHF only small IV fluid bolus were given. The next 
day cardiology was consulted and her lasix was held as 
cardiology thought she was not in significant CHF. She was 
restarted on the diltiazem drip and bolused more aggresively 
with fluids. She was transitioned to PO diltiazem over the 
weekend of ___, 25, 26. Her Lasix was resumed at 40 mg QD on 
___ due to clinically evident CHF. Her heartrate at time of 
discharge was 85-115, most measurements <100, and medications 
can further be adjusted in rehab. She does not need telemetry. 
Her PO diltiazem QID should be transitioned to slow release 
forms. 

ID - In the long ___ day weekend in the AM she was found to 
be mildly confused. U/A revealed a UTI, she was started on 
Bactrim. Note that this potentially interferes with her Coumadin 
and daily INR levels should be obtained. Bloodcultures were 
obtained for the remote possibility of endocarditis given her 
fairly recent AVR - they were negative. Finally, she was treated 
with Nystatin for thrush and with local erythromycin drops for 
conjunctivitis. 

GI - Speech and swallowing evaluation was done early during 
admission and repeated on the day of discharge. For the 
recommendations please refer to the "face sheet". She was on a 
bowel regimen during admission. 

FEN - She has needed K repletion repeatedly, and was kept on her 
home regimen of 20 mEq of KCl (PO). Please monitor closely. 

ENDO - Her insulin sliding scale and FSBG were d/c'd since they 
were normal. An ultrasound was made of the thyroid for the 
coincidental finding on conventional XRay. The ultrasound 
revealed trivial thyroid findings (see "results" section) but 
also revealed a heterogeneous lymphnode. This can be followed up 
on as an outpatient, via her PCP.

affecting the left side of your body. Quite remarkably, the 
strength in your arm and leg on the left have been spared a lot. 
With rehabilitation you will be able to recover quite a lot. 
You've also been diagnosed with a urinary tract infection, for

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___

Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
"a truck accident over a year ago I was hit from the side I 
cracked my tooth and the truck really hit me hard I can't eat 
because my face swells when I eat.I've had acupuncture, cupping 
and massages I'm sorry I'm very slow."
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ yo female of ___ descent with no known 
psychiatry history who was brought to the ED by her mother and 
sister as they are concerned about her marked behavior, mental 
status changes and decreased level of functioning over the last 
___ years. The family reportedly brought her to the ED this 
morning under the pretext that she was being seen for her 
chronic neck and tooth pain which the patient has said is the 
result of a car accident she was in several years ago. They have 
not been able to verify that she had actually ever been in a car 
accident as the patient reports the accident happened and 
___ and believes the truck hit her car on purpose. Her 
family reports that the patient was "fine" until she went to 
medical school in ___ ___ years ago and "there was a Hurricane 
and she got stuck there." They are not clear but they think she 
completed one year of medical school but while there she 
reportedly started thinking and doing odd things. For example, 
while a full-time student there, she tried to open a Starbucks 
and approached the ___ of the medical school, asking him if he 
wanted to invest and going to the bank to try to secure a loan.
.
They report that she left medical school and when she returned 
to ___ in ___, they noticed that she had "changed mentally" 
and has been "going down hill since." They said that she is not 
able to hold or find a "stable job",that she is moody with 
extreme angry outbursts. Her parents were living in ___ 
they are now are living in ___ with the patient's older 
sister. However at one point the patient was living in ___ 
with her parents, they moved back to ___, and the patient 
remained living in ___ but was ultimately evicted for a 
number of reasons and ended up homeless. Per her sister while 
the patient was living in ___, she was "doing chemical 
experiments with gasoline in the bathroom, putting dish-washing 
soap and water in the gas tank of her car and disconnected the 
exhaust pipes on the car." She was homeless in ___, picking 
up strange men that she met on the Internet and had spent the 
night with some man. They expressed concern that she might be 
pregnant as she has been gaining weight, plus she has been 
trying to access her parents' social security checks. While in 
___ she was staying up all night, talking to all kinds of 
people in the apartment complex despite the landlord's warnings. 
She did teach for a year but lost the job. The patient's cousin 
who also lives in ___ became so concerned about her behavior 
that she put her on a plane back to ___ and the pt has been 
here since ___. 
.
Her sister said that why she brought her into the ED today is 
because her behavior has been more concerning and bizarre over 
the past 2 weeks. She said the patient has been posting strange 
messages on Facebook and most recently she posted that she had 
"scheduled a Hindu cremation ceremony-I am going to need the 
next life to right what was stolen from me in this life--now 
where's my refund check." Her sister said, "I am afraid that she 
is suicidal." Her mother reported that the patient sometimes 
wakes up in the morning "screaming, leaves the house, and 
returns 2 hours later as if nothing has happened." Her sister 
said that the patient has been using vinegar for everything from 
bathing to drinking it and tried to clean her sister's apt with 
it. Her sister said that at one point she thought that a black 
van or a helicopter was following her. Her sister brought with 
her extensive documentation of what has been happening with the 
patient and had downloaded patient's postings on Facebook.
.
Upon evaluation the patient was disorganized, kept apologizing 
as she said "I'm slow" and kept referring back to the car 
accident she had been in several years ago which has not been 
verified. And then said that she had been in a bus accident ___ 
years ago. She said that "my tooth is cracked and leaking" which

Brief Hospital Course:
Psychiatric: Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o woman who was brought in by 
her family for increasingly odd and potentially dangerous 
behaviors, disorganized thinking, paranoia, and possible making 
suicidal statements, after decompensating while living in 
___ for the last ___ years. She was brought in by her family 
under the guise that the ED would help fix a tooth that was 
bothering her, though their intent was to have her 
psychiatrically hospitalized. Upon admission, patient refused to 
take all medications given her believe that she did not have a 
psychiatric illness. She remained pressured, disorganized, 
paranoid, and psychotic. She was initially extremely distrustful 
of her family. She was further fixated on marrying a Hindu man 
even though her family is Muslim, and she had significant 
distrust of the primary team with frequent requests for a 
translator (even though patient was born in the ___. and fluent 
in ___.
.
Patient gradually began accepting Risperdal, and was committed 
on a ___, where her family testified supporting her committment. 
After limited improvement on Risperdal alone, patient was 
subsequently committed on an 8b. Risperdal was gradually tapered 
up to 6mg with some improvement in her organization, although 
patient remained pressured, intrusive, concrete, and delusional. 
Cogentin 1 mg was added with good effect after patient developed 
mild stiffness/cogwheel rigidity. Ativan was also started (up to 
1 mg bid with additional prn) to target patientÂs continued 
intensity, intrusiveness, and urgency, suggestive of possible 
hypomanic symptoms, also with good effect. Basic behavioral 
modification skills (i.e., ___ were utilized to address 
patient's concrete thinking and concerns related to her family, 
with limited initial evidence of patientÂs capacity to engage in 
such treatment. Given patientÂs memory lapses and 
perseverativeness, MOCA testing was performed, revealing no 
significant cognitive impairment. Symptoms were attributed to 
patientÂs underlying thought disorder.
.
Throughout the course of her hospital stay, patient consistently 
stated she did not believe she has schizophrenia, admitting only 
to suffering from Âdepression.Â Given patientÂs severely 
impaired insight and concerns for likely medication 
non-adherence, Risperdal was subsequently gradually 
cross-tapered to Invega Sustenna. Patient received her first two 
injections on ___ and ___, respectively 234mg and 156mg. She 
tolerated this cross-taper well with no evidence of medication 
side effect. Cogentin was subsequently changed to prn. Ativan 
was continued at 1 mg bid given patientÂs continued 
intrusiveness and urgency, with no need for additional prn 
medications. With ongoing antipsychotic treatment, the patient 
had significant improvement in her paranoia and degree of 
disorganization. She continued to have persistent desire to get 
married, and this changed from a deisre to marry a hindu man to 
have her family arrange a muselum marriage for her in ___. 
While initially extremely reluctant to allow her family to 
participate in her care, she eventually was amenable to and 
helped coordinate family meeting with parents and sister. With 
increasing family involvement it was noted, that her parents 
were supporting the idea of an arranged marriage in ___, but 
ultimately all (including the patient) agreed to postpone any 
major life choices such as marriage and trauma for ___ 
year until the patient was doing well and was stable outside the 
hospital. An application for ___ services and intermediate care 
were filed, though as patient demonstrated significnat 
improvement, she was ultimately referred for stepdown at the 
___ Partial Program at ___.
.
Of note, after spending her first trial day to the ___ Partial 
Progam on day pass, patient reportedly informed ___ staff that 
she had a dental appointment at ___, at which point she left 
___ unaccompanied and without primary teamÂs awareness. Per AWA 
protocol, ___ public safety, police, and family were notified 
immediately. Patient ultimately returned to ___ on her own a 
few hours later, after having successfully received dental care 
at ___ at a ___ clinic. While her 
elopement was of significant concern to all parties, it did 
demonstrate that patient was organized enough to make her own 
appointment, obtain bus/train fare, and learn the public 
transportation system on her own, thus demonstrating significant 
improvement in her degree of organization and ability to care 
for herself in a less restrictive environment. After completing 
a second successful trial day to the ___ Partial Program, 
patient was discharged to their care. Per ___ Partial staff, 
patient was noted to be eager, appropriate, and with good 
participation during groups during her two trial days, with no 
anxiety or distress observed. Patient herself repeatedly 
expressed her enthusiasm for moving into the ___ and 
starting the ___ Partial Program. At time of discharge, the 
patient no longer presented as an acute risk to herself. She had 
no evidence of agressiveness or suicidality through out her 
admission. She was court committed under concern for ability to 
care for herself, but at time of discharge she appeared to be 
maintaining her ADLS well, was agreeable to Invega Sustaina, 
ongoing mental heatlh treatment, had improved relationships with 
her family and a clear desire to stay where her parents were, 
and an ability to make follow up appointments. Her boundaries 
with others had also significantly improved during the admission 

.
Medical: Upon admission, Ms. ___ complained of significant 
tooth pain after a reported MVA in ___ earlier this year. 
She was evaluated by dentistry and found to have a cap missing. 
Dental films demonstrated no sign of infection. As complete 
dental work could not be performed in the hospital, the plan was 
to have the cap fixed after hospital discharge, though as noted 
above, patient arranged initial dental treatment on her own 
while on day pass. Further dental work to be arranged by patient 
and her family. There were otherwise no acute medical issues 
during patientÂs hospital stay.
.
Legal: ___
Social/Milieu: In the intial portion of her hospitalization, Ms. 
___ was paranoid about her family. She refused to have the 
team speak to her family, At the time of dischagre, this 
paranoia about her family had resolved, and she was most focused 
on healing the family, staying on good terms with them and 
moving forward. Her family was involved in her care through out 
her hospitalization to different degrees based on the patients 
cooperation. At time of discharge a family meeting was held with 
her sister, mother and father. All of her family members 
appeared to understand her illness and the importance of ongoing 
psychiatric care and need for medication. They were ultimately 
in support of her discharge plan to the ___ and the 
partial hosptial program. In the future her mother will consider 
having the patient stay with her and intends to remain a close 
support.  On the unit, patient demonstrated increased activity 
and engagement with others as her symptoms improved. She had 
good group attendance, and she was observed to be sociable with 
select peers and staff. While perseverative and intrustive at 
times, she was in good behavioral control, with no need for 
chemical or physical restraint.
.
Risk Assessment: No evidence of an acute safety risk at this 
time. Due to her
limited insight into her illness, Ms. ___ does have the 
chronic risk of treatment non-adherence, but this risk has been 
minimized with injectable medication and comprehensive treatment 
program connected to her living arrangement. Her family will 
also continue to closely monitor her treatment adherence. There 
was no evidence for suicidality or thoughts of harm at any time.
.
Dispo: Patient discharged to ___ and ___ Partial Program 
at ___. Psych testing can be considered in the future if 
patient continues to struggle with information processing.

hours) as needed for anxiety/insomnia.

a day) as needed for EPS, muscle stiffness, rigidity.

Intramuscular once a month: next due ___.

Extended Care

___

I. Schizophrenia, paranoia and disorganization most prominent
II. deferred

IV. financial stressors, unstable living environment, family 
conflict

Mental Status: Cooperative with decreased paranoia, concrete, 
perseverative.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Please follow up with all outpatient appointments as listed - 
take this discharge paperwork to your appointments.
-Please continue all medications as directed.
-Please avoid abusing alcohol and any drugs--whether 
prescription drugs or illegal drugs--as this can further worsen 
your medical and psychiatric illnesses.
-Please contact your outpatient psychiatrist or other providers 
if you have any concerns.
-Please call ___ or go to your nearest emergency room if you

best of health.

not been able to verify that she had actually ever been in a car

___ and believes the truck hit her car on purpose. Her

and she got stuck there." They are not clear but they think she

number of reasons and ended up homeless. Per her sister while

experiments with gasoline in the bathroom, putting dish-washing

up strange men that she met on the Internet and had spent the

She did teach for a year but lost the job. The patient's cousin
who also lives in ___ became so concerned about her behavior
that she put her on a plane back to ___ and the pt has been
here since ___.
.
Her sister said that why she brought her into the ED today is
because her behavior has been more concerning and bizarre over
the past 2 weeks. She said the patient has been posting strange
messages on Facebook and most recently she posted that she had
"scheduled a Hindu cremation ceremony-I am going to need the
next life to right what was stolen from me in this life--now
where's my refund check." Her sister said, "I am afraid that she
is suicidal." Her mother reported that the patient sometimes
wakes up in the morning "screaming, leaves the house, and
returns 2 hours later as if nothing has happened." Her sister
said that the patient has been using vinegar for everything from
bathing to drinking it and tried to clean her sister's apt with

van or a helicopter was following her. Her sister brought with

.

at ___ at a ___ clinic. While her
elopement was of significant concern to all parties, it did
demonstrate that patient was organized enough to make her own
appointment, obtain bus/train fare, and learn the public
transportation system on her own, thus demonstrating significant
improvement in her degree of organization and ability to care
for herself in a less restrictive environment. After completing
a second successful trial day to the ___ Partial Program,
patient was discharged to their care. Per ___ Partial staff,
patient was noted to be eager, appropriate, and with good
participation during groups during her two trial days, with no
anxiety or distress observed. Patient herself repeatedly
expressed her enthusiasm for moving into the ___ and
starting the ___ Partial Program. At time of discharge, the
patient no longer presented as an acute risk to herself. She had
no evidence of agressiveness or suicidality through out her
admission. She was court committed under concern for ability to
care for herself, but at time of discharge she appeared to be
maintaining her ADLS well, was agreeable to Invega Sustaina,
ongoing mental heatlh treatment, had improved relationships with
her family and a clear desire to stay where her parents were,
and an ability to make follow up appointments. Her boundaries
with others had also significantly improved during the admission
.
Medical: Upon admission, Ms. ___ complained of significant
tooth pain after a reported MVA in ___ earlier this year.
She was evaluated by dentistry and found to have a cap missing.
Dental films demonstrated no sign of infection. As complete
dental work could not be performed in the hospital, the plan was
to have the cap fixed after hospital discharge, though as noted
above, patient arranged initial dental treatment on her own
while on day pass. Further dental work to be arranged by patient
and her family. There were otherwise no acute medical issues
during patientÂs hospital stay.
.
Legal: ___
Social/Milieu: In the intial portion of her hospitalization, Ms.
___ was paranoid about her family. She refused to have the
team speak to her family, At the time of dischagre, this
paranoia about her family had resolved, and she was most focused
on healing the family, staying on good terms with them and
moving forward. Her family was involved in her care through out
her hospitalization to different degrees based on the patients
cooperation. At time of discharge a family meeting was held with
her sister, mother and father. All of her family members
appeared to understand her illness and the importance of ongoing
psychiatric care and need for medication. They were ultimately
in support of her discharge plan to the ___ and the
partial hosptial program. In the future her mother will consider
having the patient stay with her and intends to remain a close
support. On the unit, patient demonstrated increased activity
and engagement with others as her symptoms improved. She had
good group attendance, and she was observed to be sociable with
select peers and staff. While perseverative and intrustive at
times, she was in good behavioral control, with no need for
chemical or physical restraint.
.
Risk Assessment: No evidence of an acute safety risk at this
time. Due to her
limited insight into her illness, Ms. ___ does have the
chronic risk of treatment non-adherence, but this risk has been
minimized with injectable medication and comprehensive treatment
program connected to her living arrangement. Her family will
also continue to closely monitor her treatment adherence. There
was no evidence for suicidality or thoughts of harm at any time.
.
Dispo: Patient discharged to ___ and ___ Partial Program
at ___. Psych testing can be considered in the future if
patient continues to struggle with information processing.
Medications on Admission:
None
Discharge Medications:
1. lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a
day).
2. lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8
hours) as needed for anxiety/insomnia.
3. benztropine 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times
a day) as needed for EPS, muscle stiffness, rigidity.
4. Invega Sustenna 117 mg/0.75 mL Syringe Sig: One (1) syringe
Intramuscular once a month: next due ___.
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
I. Schizophrenia, paranoia and disorganization most prominent
II. deferred
III. s/p MVA last year
IV. financial stressors, unstable living environment, family
conflict
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Cooperative with decreased paranoia, concrete,
perseverative.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
-Please follow up with all outpatient appointments as listed -
take this discharge paperwork to your appointments.
-Please continue all medications as directed.
-Please avoid abusing alcohol and any drugs--whether
prescription drugs or illegal drugs--as this can further worsen
your medical and psychiatric illnesses.
-Please contact your outpatient psychiatrist or other providers
if you have any concerns.
-Please call ___ or go to your nearest emergency room if you
feel unsafe in any way and are unable to immediately reach your
health care providers.
-It was a pleasure to have worked with you, and we wish you the
best of health.
Followup Instructions:
___

3.3 x 3.9 x 3.2 cm hepatic abscess ___ segment VII.  Hepatic

The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is 
seen by 2D or color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure 
is ___ mmHg. There is mild symmetric left ventricular 
hypertrophy. Regional left ventricular wall motion is normal. 
Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%).

diastolic function. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, 
ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets 
(3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and 
no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve

The newly placed left PICC line terminates ___ the lower SVC.

placement of a right-sided pigtail catheter which is

of a small left pleural effusion since yesterday. The

resolved. Stable bilateral lower lung volumes. Stable pulmonary 
vascular congestion without overt pulmonary edema. Stable mild 
cardiomegaly. Mediastinal contours and hila are unchanged. No 
pneumothorax. 
IMPRESSION:  
1.  Left PICC line ends ___ the lower SVC. 
2. New, small left pleural effusion. 
3.  Interval resolution of the heterogeneous consolidation right 
lower lung. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a healthy ___ M presenting with rigors, leukocytosis, 
liver lesion and appendiceal dilation. 
 
# Strep anginosis bloodstream infection complicated by liver 
abscess: Initially rigoring at home, blood grew strep anginosis 
and liver abscess was drained with 10cc fluid that continued 
drainage the following day. He was afebrile on therapeutic 
ceftriaxone 2gm daily, vanc and flagyl stopped. PICC placed. 
Echo negative for endocarditis, will complete minimum two week 
course, home infusoin arranged, surveillance cultures negative. 

# Tip Appendicitis: Surgery evaluated, likely seeded liver 
abscess, not thought to be contributing to acute picture, plan 
for interval appendectomy, never had significant abd pain. 

# Hypoxia: Etiology unclear, noted transiently hypoxic ___ ED, 
resolved on the floor but then CXR showed increased vasc 
congestion with top normal heart size s/p 5L resuscitation, 
never had cough though was dyspneic when rigoring, CXR follow up 
showed improvement ___ congestion and atelectasis. No evidence of 
heart failure on echo.  
  
# ___: Resolved.  

# Transaminitis: Likely sepsis, resolved with fluids.
