Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure participating ___ your care at ___ 
___. 

You were admitted because of an infection ___ your blood stream 
that was likely caused by bacteria that traveled from your 
appendix to your liver. 

You have improved with drainage of the liver infection and 
antibiotics. You will need antibiotics for another two weeks at 
least. The infectious disease team will see you at that time and 
determine if you need a longer course. The interventional 
radiologists will see you to remove the drain, and a visiting 
nurse ___ help to manage it. 

You will also need to have your appendix removed. You have been 
scheduled to see Dr. ___.

determine if you need a longer course. The interventional
radiologists will see you to remove the drain, and a visiting
nurse ___ help to manage it.

scheduled to see Dr. ___.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
shortness of breath, dizziness
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
EP study and ablation of ventricular tachycardia
ICD placement

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms ___ is a ___ woman with history of hypertension, 
hyperlipidemia, prior CAD with two "small heart attacks" 
approximately ___ years ago, presenting with episode of shortness 
of breath, dizziness and diaphoresis after shoveling snow on 
___.  
.  
She reports she was able to shovel snow for 10 minutes but 
immediately after she felt "strange". Took a 325mg aspirin but, 
continued to have lightheadedness and dizziness. Also had blurry 
vision, but denied CP, palpitations, n/v/d. Patient very active 
at baseline, goes to GYM almost every day (treadmill x 2 miles 
per day) and Tennis 4x's per wk. She has no chest discomfort, 
pain or dyspnea with these activities. Patient reports she never 
lost consciousness or fell to the groud. No smilar prior event.  

.  
She denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous 
thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, 
myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red 
stools. She denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. She denies 
exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of 
systems were negative.  
.  
In the field, EMS found patient mentating, diaphoretic and per 
report hypotensive, strips showed wide-complex tachycardia 
interpreted as ventricular tachycardia. 50mg IV Lidocaine given 
with restoration of sinus rhythm, no documentation on time 
interval.  
.  
In the ED, patient arrived with HR 85, BP 110/p and 100% O2 sat 
on ? NRB. Case discussed with cardiology fellow and admitted for 
further management. She was initally on a lidocaine gtt.  
.  
On the floor, VT did not reoccur. Pt had stress test that did 
not induce VT. Today pt went for EP study, did not have 
ablation, however, had bleeding from groin site that would only 
temporarly stop after holding pressure. Vascular team assessed 
and placed pressure dressing on groin. VS on admission to CCU 
were 149/58, 81, hct stable at 35. No pain or SOB, but is upset 
about her complications.  
 
Past Medical History:
-- CAD s/p "small heart attack" x 2 (25 and ___ years ago)  
-- Hypertension  
-- Hyperlipidemia  
-- Renal cancer s/p resection and left nephrectomy ___ years ago  


 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No family history of early MI, otherwise non-contributory.
 
Physical Exam:
VS: 98.1 139/89  65 RR 18 97% RA 
GENERAL: elderly woman, upset. Oriented x3.  
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were 
pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.  

NECK: Supple, laying down, unable to asses neck veins  
CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular 
line. RR, normal S1, S2 with S4.  
Chest: Left chest C/I/D, mild tenderness
LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp 
were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, 
wheezes or rhonchi.  
ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not 
enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits.  
EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. Hematoma in right 
groin, about 3inches, mild tenderness, no active bleeding or 
oozing  
SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.  
PULSES:  
Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+

MCV-90 MCH-32.4* MCHC-36.1* RDW-14.3 Plt ___

Eos-1.8 Baso-0.2

.

K-4.0 Cl-104 HCO3-25 AnGap-18

.
CARDIAC ENZYMES:
___ 04:51PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 CK(CPK)-117
___ 11:35PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.08* CK(CPK)-83
___ 07:35AM BLOOD cTropnT-0.07* CK(CPK)-82
___ 06:55PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.05* CK(CPK)-83
.
URINE:

RADIOLOGY:
.
___
No evidence of acute focal pneumonia.
.
CXR ___
FINDINGS: In comparison with the study of ___, the two leads 
extend to the apex of the right ventricle and the right atrium 
respectively. 
.
CXR ___
IMPRESSION: Dual-lead ICD with leads appropriately positioned. 
No 
pneumothorax. 
.
Femoral Vascular U/S ___
IMPRESSION: 
1. No evidence of pseudoaneurysm. 
2. Ill-defined hematoma overlies the vascular access site. 
.
CT abd/plevis ___
IMPRESSION: 
  
1. No retroperitoneal hematoma detected. Subcutaneous 
reticulation and 
stranding involving the right and left superficial soft tissues 
of the thigh 
with small hematoma, better evaluated on recent ultrasound 
imaging. 
  
2. Multiple hypodensities within the liver and right kidney 
which are cystic 
and not well characterized on this non-contrast-enhanced study 
although 
statistically represent cysts. 
  
3. Recommend slightly advancing Foley catheter given residual 
air within the 
bladder. 
  
4. Trace simple pericardial effusion. 
  
5. Fibroid uterus. 
  
6. Sigmoid colon diverticulosis. 

.
CARDIOLOGY:
.
TTE (___)
The left atrium is mildly dilated. The estimated right atrial 
pressure is ___ mmHg. There is mild symmetric left ventricular 
hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild to moderate 
regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with 
akinesis/thinning of the distal half of the inferolateral and 
inferior walls. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 
40-45 %). No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. 
Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. 
The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels 
are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened 
but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic regurgitation 
is seen. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with 
trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. 
Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary 
artery systolic pressure is high normal. There is a 
trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. 
IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
regional systolic dysfunction c/w prior infarction (LVEF 
40-45%). Mild mitral regurgitation most likely due to papillary 
muscle dysfunction. 
.
ETT w Nuclear Imaging (___)
Excellent exercise tolerance. No anginal symptoms with 
nonspecific T wave changes. Anterior(V1-V3) ST-T wave changes 
uninterpretable for ischemia in the presence of the RBBB. In the 
presence 
of the RBBB, the anterior(V1-V3) ST-T wave changes are 
uninterpretable 
for ischemia. Deeper T wave inversion (no J-point depression) 
was noted 
inferiorly and in the lateral precordial leads (nonspecific 
finding). 
The rhythm was sinus with frequent multiformed VPDs, infrequent 
ventricular couplets and, in post-exercise period, one 5-bt run 
of an 
acclerated idioventicular rhythm(rate~72-94) was noted. Resting 
baseline hypertension. Nuclear report sent separately. 
.
NUCLEAR IMAGING - INTERPRETATION: 
The image quality is good. 
Left ventricular cavity size is normal. 
Resting and stress perfusion images reveal a large severe fixed 
defect in the lateral wall and a large severe fixed defect in 
the inferolateral wall.   
Given severe photopenia in the affected segments, wall motion in 
these areas cannot be determined, but presumed akinetic. 
Otherwise, wall motion is normal. 
The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 44%. 
No comparisons. 
Two large severe fixed defects consistent with prior infarction. 

Ejection fraction 44%. 
.
EKG:
Sinus rhythm. Prior inferolateral myocardial infarction. Right 
bundle-branch block. Probable true posterior component as well. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ is a ___ with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, CAD (old 
MIs), admitted with ventricular tachycardia, converted to NSR 
with lidocaine, transferred to the CCU s/p failed ablation c/b 
groin bleeding.
.  
# VENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA: Pt is has a hx of CAD with prior 
inferior infact ___ years prior.  She was admitted with 
hemodynamically stable monomorphic VT with excertion after 
shoveling snow. She was started on lidocain gtt, that was 
stopped on ___. She underwent stress test on ___, with no VT 
induced. The patient underwnet EP study on ___, but were unable 
to ablate the source of her VT.  Post-op her course was 
complicated by hematoma and low urine output and monitored in 
the CCU. A U/S showed no pseudoaneurysm and an ill-defined 
hematoma. She also had a CT-scan on ___ that did not show RP 
bleed.  Her Hct dropped to 26, but remained stable. Her urine 
output improved with IVF.  She was started on amiodarone 200mg 
TID on ___.  She remained stable and while she had occasional 
episodes of ___ beat V-tach on tele she remained asymptomatic. 
She underwent successful ICD placement on ___. She recieved one 
dose of Vancomycin prior to the procedure as well as 12 hours 
after placement.  The likely source of her VT was thought to 
from prior scar from MI. She was discharged on Amiodarone 200mg 
BID (which will be continued until her cardiology follow-up) and 
her prior dose of atenolol 50mg daily.  Her nifedipine was 
discontinued.  She was also started on Keflex x2days.  She will 
have follow-up with device clinic in one week as well as 
follow-up with Dr. ___ in approx 1 month.   
.  
# Pump: Her stress MIBI showed wall motion defect, likely from 
old MI, EF of 44%. Her metoprolol was held in the setting of 
bleeding, but restarted when stable. She was continued on 
atenolol and lisinopril as an outpatient.
.  
# HTN: Her home nifedipine and atenolol were discontinued on 
admission.  Additionally, she was started on metoprolol and 
continued on her lisinopril.  Her BP meds were held after the 
procedure due to concerns of bleeding.  Her BP ranged between 
130-160's during her admission, but improved when she was placed 
back on her home medications.  She she was stablized and put 
back on her home atenolol and lisinopril. 
. 
# CONTACT: Husband (______ / ___. ___ 
___.  
 
Medications on Admission:
Nifedipine ER 60mg  
Lisinopril 20mg daily  
Atenolol 50mg daily  
Crestor 5mg daily  
Fosamax  
Calcium  
Ocuvite  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ocuvite     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).  
2. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet, Chewable(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Rosuvastatin 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
4. Cephalexin 500 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) for 2 days.
Disp:*8 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Amiodarone 200 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
6. Lisinopril 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
7. Fosamax  Oral
8. Calcium  Oral
9. Atenolol 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary:
Ventricular Tachycardia
CAD s/p MI x 2 (25 and ___ years ago)  
Hypertension  
Hyperlipidemia  

 
Discharge Condition:
stable, chest pain free, ambulating, O2 sat >95%RA, normotensive

 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you while you were in the 
hospital.  You were admitted to ___ because of a heart rhythm 
problem called ventricular tachycardiac. You were evaluated by 
the rhythm specialists and underwent ablation of this rhythm.

Please take all your medications as prescribed.  The following 
changes were made to your medication regimen. 
1. Please stop taking nifedipine
2. You will continue Amiodarone 200mg twice a day
3. You will cont Keflex ___ every 6 hours for 2 days
4. Please take aspirin 81 mg daily 
 
Please follow up with the appointments below.

Please call your PCP or go to the ED if you experience chest 
pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, 
fevers, chills, or other concerning symptoms.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was transferred from the ___ Trauma service 
to ___ Orthopedic Surgery team and admitted. On hospital 
day #3 was taken to the operating room for above described 
procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for 
details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated 
the procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV 
antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
On hospital day 0, a urine culture was obtained. It was positive 
for a urinary tract infection.  She was started on a 
ciprofloxacin 250mg BID x 7 days.  On postoperative day 1 the 
patient was noted to be tachycardic to 115-120 with a new oxygen 
requirement of 2LNC and hypotension to the 90's. An EKG showed 
nonspecific changes. A CXR was unremarkable, and so a CTPE was 
performed which was negative for pulmonary embolism. 

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received lovenox for DVT 
prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The foley was 
removed and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. 
The surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical 
incision was found to be clean and intact without erythema or 
abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical 
therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and 
repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was 
tolerating a regular diet and feeling well.  The patient was 
afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's hematocrit was 
acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral 
regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and 
the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity with posterior precautions. 

 
Mrs ___ is discharged to home with services in stable 
condition.

4. Fenofibrate 67 mg PO DAILY

Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Femoral neck fracture, left hip

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).
 
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to 
continue at your previous dose while taking this medication. 
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by the visiting 
nurse or rehab facility in two (2) weeks.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after 
surgery.
 
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Posterior precautions. No strenuous exercise or heavy 
lifting until follow up appointment.  Mobilize frequently.
Physical Therapy:
WBAT LLE
Posterior hip precautions  x 2 months 
Mobilize frequently
wean from assistive devices

Treatments Frequency:
daily dressing changes as needed for drainage
wound checks daily
ice 
staple removal and replace with steri-strips on ___ at 
___ 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Cr 3, and elevated LFTs ALT>AST. While he was waiting for 
transport to BID Cardiology he left AMA on ___. He self 
presented here at BID for further workup of cardiac concerns.

In the ED, he was complaining of pleuritic chest pain and 
concerns of his heart health following this recent overdose. EKG 
showed t wave flattening and mild t wave inversion in the 
precordial inferior leads. He was afebrile, vitals were stable, 
and troponins were down-trending (0.13->0.11). Non-contrast head 
CT revealed no bleed but was notable for an incidental finding 
of a small, hypodense regnio with the left globus pallidus which 
may represent chronic microvascular ischemic changes but is 
indeteriminant in nature; an out patient head MRI without 
contrast is recommended. He was started on vancomycin and 
cefepime empirically, blood cultures x3 were drawn, and ASA & 
statin were started. 

During his stay on the medicine floor, antibiotic therapy was 
transitioned to oral levaquin and he was monitored for worsening 
respiratory status and fever. He improved on therapy despite 
lack of culture data (no sputum). A repeat TTE showed improved 
cardiac function and a bicuspid aortic valve.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr ___,

You came to ___ for chest pain, fatigue, and concerns for 
heart problems following an overdose and resulting episode of 
pneumonia. Please see more details listed below about what 
happened while you were in the hospital and your instructions 
for what to do after leaving the hospital.

It was a pleasure participating in your care. We wish you the 
best!

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team

WHAT WAS DONE WHILE YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL:

- An EKG, a test for the electrical activity of the heart, was 
conducted when you arrived in the emergency room that showed 
changes consistent with significant strain on your heart. 

- An xray of your chest revealed an infection (pneumonia) in the 
upper aspect of your right lung.

- We also performed a CAT scan of your head to make sure there 
was no bleeding and incidentally discovered a small area in your 
brain that may have diminished blood flow. However, this may be 
an artifact of the imaging. A better imaging technique (MRI) is 
suggested at a future date. While here you exhibited no clinical 
signs that were concerning for bleeding or stroke. 

- You were started on IV antibiotics to treat the pneumonia and 
transitioned to an oral antibiotic which you completed with no 
signs of resistance and improvement of symptoms. 

- During your stay at one of the outside hospitals and repeated 
here, an ultrasound of your heart was done and some issues were 
found: 

1. Flow through one of the main valves of your heart (aortic 
valve) is restricted due to, likely, an unusual structure to 
this valve. Instead of three leaves, your aortic valve has two 
leaves. This causes some restriction of flow from the heart and 
the murmur you to which you are aware. 

2. The right side of your heart was not pumping as well as it 
should. The repeated ultrasound of your heart revealed that this 
has resolved. Your heart is pumping as it should. 

- While staying with us, we were able to get you back into the 
___ clinic of your choice and we initiated your treatment. 
We discharged you on 40mg methadone daily given some concerns 
for a lower heart rate. Given concerns for your heart health 
care should be exercised as you re-start your treatment.

WHAT SHOULD YOU DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL:
- Please check in to the ___ clinic (Habit OP___ 
on ___ at 10:00am for your intake appointment.
- Please follow up your primary care provider who will be 
provided with all of the information regarding this admission. 
- Consider discussing cardiac rehab with your primary care 
provider (information was provided to you by our social worker).
- Stop all alcohol use and illicit drug use. 
- Continue smoking cessation.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:

bilateral displaced subcondylar fractures and displaced left 
mandibular parasymphysis fracture. Patient also was noted to 
have bright red blood in his bilateral external ear canals, 
nonactive, and attempts to visualize ___ were not successful. 
ENT was consulted for management of canal lacerations. They 
recommended olfloxin drops to bilateral ears and follow-up as an 
outpatient.

fracture through intraoral
approach and closed reduction with maxillomandibular fixation of 
bilateral subcondylar fractures with ___ arch bars, which went

for details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the 
patient arrived on the floor tolerating sips, on IV fluids, and 
oral analgesia for pain control.  The patient was 
hemodynamically stable.

a full liquid diet with good tolerability. The patient voided 
without problem. During this hospitalization, the patient 
ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory 
toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively participated in 
the plan of care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay.
.

liquid diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain 
was well controlled.  The patient was discharged home without 
services. The patient and his family received discharge teaching 
and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Diagnosis:
bilateral ear canal lacerations
bilateral displaced subcondylar fractures and displaced left 
mandibular parasymphysis fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery Service after a fall 
sustaining a jaw fracture. You were taken to the operating room 
with the oral surgeons and had the bones repaired and your jaw 
closed with elastics. Please continue to follow a full liquid 
diet. You were also found to have lacerations in bilateral ear 
canals. Please continue to put ear drops in as instructed.

You are now doing better, tolerating full liquids, and pain is 
improved. You are now ready to be discharged to home to continue 
your recovery. 

Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. 

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
subarachnoid hemorrhage
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Diagnostic cerebral angiogram
___ Diagnostic Angiogram

 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o M with a past medical history of HTN, HLD, and
degenerative disc disease, on aspirin 81mg, presents with neck
and headache. Patient states that as he was bending down to
retrieve something under the sink when he felt a sudden onset of
severe neck pain. The pain then radiated up to his head and he
presented to an OSH where a head CT was performed and showed
diffuse SAH. He was started on nimodipine and was transferred to
___ for further evaluation.

Patient currently reports headaches and neck pain, photophobia,
and nuchal rigidity. He denies any n/v, dizziness, visual
changes, or weakness.

 
Past Medical History:
HLD, HTN, DJD

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On admission
Hunt and ___  Fisher: 2   GCS 15  E:4 V: 5 Motor: 6
O: SBP:140  HR: 78    R: 18  O2Sats: 100%
Gen: WD/WN, comfortable, NAD.
HEENT: atraumatic, normocephalic
Pupils: 3-2mm bilaterally     EOMs: intact, 2 beat lateral
nystagmus
Neck: nuchal rigidity

Neuro:
Mental status: Awake and alert, cooperative with exam, normal
affect.
Orientation: Oriented to person, place, and date.
Recall: ___ objects at 5 minutes.
Language: Speech fluent with good comprehension and repetition.
Naming intact. No dysarthria or paraphasic errors.

Cranial Nerves:
I: Not tested
II: Pupils equally round and reactive to light, 3 to 2
mm bilaterally. Visual fields are full to confrontation.
III, IV, VI: Extraocular movements intact bilaterally without
nystagmus.
V, VII: Facial strength and sensation intact and symmetric.
VIII: Hearing intact to finger rub bilaterally.
IX, X: Palatal elevation symmetrical.
XI: Sternocleidomastoid and trapezius normal bilaterally.
XII: Tongue midline without fasciculations.

Motor: Normal bulk and tone bilaterally. No abnormal movements,
tremors. Strength full power ___ throughout. No pronator drift

Sensation: Intact to light touch

On discharge:
A&Ox3
PERRL
EOMs intact
face symmetrical
tongue midline
No pronator drift
Motor: ___ throughout
 
Pertinent Results:
___ CTA head and neck
Subarachnoid hemorrhage centered within the suprasellar and 
perimesencephalic cisterns with new intraventricular extension 
into the 
occipital horn of the right lateral ventricle. 
2. CT of the head and neck is limited secondary to timing of 
contrast bolus which limites evaluation for aneurysm. There is 
no large vessel occlusion. 
3. Stenosis at the origin of the proximal right internal carotid 
artery 
measuring approximately 53% stenosis by NASCET criteria and 
diffuse intimal thickening of the proximal left internal carotid 
artery without stenosis by NASCET criteria. 

___ diagnostic cerebral angiogram
-Negative for aneurysm

___ TCD's:
1. There was no evidence of vasospasm. 
2. This study was mildly abnormal due to below normal mean
velocities in the right anterior circulation, likely due to poor
right temporal bone window or poor angle of probe insonation. 

___ TCD's: 
1. There was no evidence of vasospasm. 
2. This study was mildly abnormal due to hyperemia in the right
proximal MCA and right terminal ICA. 

___ TCD's: 
1. There was no evidence of vasospasm. 
2. This study was mildly abnormal due to hyperemia in the right
proximal MCA and Right ACA

___ MRI OF HEAD:
1. No evidence of an arteriovenous malformation. 
2. Small scattered acute to subacute infarcts throughout the 
anterior and 
posterior circulations. The small, scattered appearance is more 
consistent 
with an embolic etiology rather than vasospasm. 
3. Subarachnoid hemorrhage in the basal and suprasellar 
cisterns, as seen on CT from ___. No hydrocephalus. 

___ MR ___ with and without contrast:
1. No evidence of a vascular malformation in the cervical spine. 

2. Degenerative disc and joint disease causes cord remodeling, 
moderate spinal stenosis at C4-5 and C5-6 levels and severe 
neural foraminal stenosis at multiple levels, detailed above. No 
cord signal abnormality. 

___ TCDs
1. There was no evidence of vasospasm. 
2. Below normal mean flow velocities in the Right ACA and
bilateral vertebral arteries. This is most likely due to poor
bone window.

CAROTID/CEREBRAL BILAT BILAT ___ 
1. No aneurysm or vascular malformation identified is the source 
of the 
patient's subarachnoid hemorrhage. Given the initial CT 
findings, this likely represents a perimesencephalic hemorrhage. 

  
2. When compared to the prior angiogram of ___ there 
is mild vessel narrowing in the bilateral ICA circulation which 
may be secondary to technique, or mild spasm. We will continue 
to monitor the patient clinically. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, the patient presented to ED with a subarachnoid 
hemorrhage.  He was taken to angio where he had a diagnostic 
cerebral angiogram which was negative for aneurysm.  He was 
transferred to the SICU for close monitoring.  He was placed on 
nimodipine for vasospasm prevention.  His blood pressure 
parameters were 100-160.  TCD's were ordered.  He was also kept 
on 100cc/hr of NS.

On ___, the patient was stable neurologically.  He was started 
on dexamethasone 4mg Q6h for his headache with plans to taper 
this over 2 weeks.  His nimodipine was adjusted to 30mg Q2h for 
hypotension.  TCD's showed no evidence of spasm.

On ___, the patient was stable and there were no events over 
night.  An MRI of the brain with and without contrast was 
scheduled for ___ to check for a micro-AVM.  TCD's showed 
hyperemia to the right MCA but no vasospasm. 

On ___, the patient remained neurologically and hemodynamically 
stable. Plan for MRI head tomorrow and Angio on ___. TCDs 
showed heperemia to R MCA and no vasospasm. 

On ___, the patient remained stable. An MRI of the head and 
neck was obtained and revealed no AV malformations but again 
confirmed subarachnoid blood in the basal and suprasellar 
cisterns. Will stay in the ICU for the weekend with plans for a 
diagnostic angiogram. TCDs study was limited but no change in 
velocity. 

Mr. ___ continued to recover well between ___ and ___.  On 
___, he was taken the angio suite for a repeat cerebral 
angiogram.  The angio was negative for any vascular malformation 
or aneurysm.  The patient returned to the ICU for further 
management.  On the same day, TCDs were performed and also 
showed no vasospasm, although the study was somewhat limited.  
The patient remained neurologically intact during this time.  
Mr. ___ was transferred to the floor for continued management.

On ___, patient remained stable on exam. He was ambulating and 
voiding appropriatedly and was discharged home in stable 
condition. 
 
Medications on Admission:
aspirin 81mg QD, HCTZ 25mg QD, simvastatin 80mg QD, vit B12,
lisinopril 5mg QAM, gabapentin 60mg TID, ibuprofen 600mg TID

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Cyanocobalamin 1000 mcg PO DAILY 
2. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN Pain 
RX *hydromorphone [Dilaudid] 2 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth Q3H 
Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*0
3. LeVETiracetam 500 mg PO BID 
RX *levetiracetam [Keppra] 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a 
day Disp #*90 Tablet Refills:*1
4. Simvastatin 80 mg PO QPM 
5. Famotidine 20 mg PO DAILY 
RX *famotidine 20 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth DAILY Disp #*60 Tablet 
Refills:*1
6. Gabapentin 600 mg PO TID 
7. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice 
a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*1
8. Dexamethasone 2 mg PO Q8H 
Please take 4mg Q8H x 1 day, 3mg Q8H x1 day, 2mg Q8H x1 day, 2mg 
BID x1 day, 2mg daily then off 
Tapered dose - DOWN 
RX *dexamethasone 2 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth please refer to 
additional instructions Disp #*17 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Non aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage
Acute to subacute infarcts of the anterior and posterior 
circulations

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Surgery/ Procedures:
Â*** You had a cerebral angiogram. You may experience some mild 
tenderness and bruising at the puncture site (groin).

Activity
ÂWe recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
ÂYou make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
ÂYou make take a shower. 
ÂNo driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
ÂIf you experienced a seizure while admitted, you must refrain 
from driving. 

Medications
ÂResume your normal medications and begin new medications as 
directed.
Â***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
Â***You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This 
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
medication until follow-up. It is important that you take this 
medication consistently and on time. 
ÂYou have been discharged on a medication to lower your 
cholesterol levels. We recommend that you continue this 
medication indefinitely. 
ÂYou may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
ÂMild to moderate headaches that last several days to a few 
weeks.
ÂDifficulty with short term memory. 
ÂFatigue is very normal
ÂConstipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

face symmetrical

Pertinent Results:
___ CTA head and neck
Subarachnoid hemorrhage centered within the suprasellar and
perimesencephalic cisterns with new intraventricular extension
into the
occipital horn of the right lateral ventricle.
2. CT of the head and neck is limited secondary to timing of
contrast bolus which limites evaluation for aneurysm. There is
no large vessel occlusion.
3. Stenosis at the origin of the proximal right internal carotid
artery
measuring approximately 53% stenosis by NASCET criteria and
diffuse intimal thickening of the proximal left internal carotid
artery without stenosis by NASCET criteria.
___ diagnostic cerebral angiogram
-Negative for aneurysm
___ TCD's:
1. There was no evidence of vasospasm.
2. This study was mildly abnormal due to below normal mean
velocities in the right anterior circulation, likely due to poor
right temporal bone window or poor angle of probe insonation.
___ TCD's:
1. There was no evidence of vasospasm.
2. This study was mildly abnormal due to hyperemia in the right
proximal MCA and right terminal ICA.
___ TCD's:
1. There was no evidence of vasospasm.
2. This study was mildly abnormal due to hyperemia in the right
proximal MCA and Right ACA
___ MRI OF HEAD:
1. No evidence of an arteriovenous malformation.
2. Small scattered acute to subacute infarcts throughout the
anterior and
posterior circulations. The small, scattered appearance is more
consistent
with an embolic etiology rather than vasospasm.
3. Subarachnoid hemorrhage in the basal and suprasellar
cisterns, as seen on CT from ___. No hydrocephalus.
___ MR ___ with and without contrast:
1. No evidence of a vascular malformation in the cervical spine.
2. Degenerative disc and joint disease causes cord remodeling,
moderate spinal stenosis at C4-5 and C5-6 levels and severe
neural foraminal stenosis at multiple levels, detailed above. No
cord signal abnormality.
___ TCDs
1. There was no evidence of vasospasm.
2. Below normal mean flow velocities in the Right ACA and
bilateral vertebral arteries. This is most likely due to poor
bone window.
CAROTID/CEREBRAL BILAT BILAT ___
1. No aneurysm or vascular malformation identified is the source
of the
patient's subarachnoid hemorrhage. Given the initial CT
findings, this likely represents a perimesencephalic hemorrhage.
2. When compared to the prior angiogram of ___ there
is mild vessel narrowing in the bilateral ICA circulation which
may be secondary to technique, or mild spasm. We will continue
to monitor the patient clinically.
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, the patient presented to ED with a subarachnoid
hemorrhage. He was taken to angio where he had a diagnostic
cerebral angiogram which was negative for aneurysm. He was
transferred to the SICU for close monitoring. He was placed on
nimodipine for vasospasm prevention. His blood pressure
parameters were 100-160. TCD's were ordered. He was also kept
on 100cc/hr of NS.
On ___, the patient was stable neurologically. He was started
on dexamethasone 4mg Q6h for his headache with plans to taper
this over 2 weeks. His nimodipine was adjusted to 30mg Q2h for
hypotension. TCD's showed no evidence of spasm.
On ___, the patient was stable and there were no events over
night. An MRI of the brain with and without contrast was
scheduled for ___ to check for a micro-AVM. TCD's showed
hyperemia to the right MCA but no vasospasm.
On ___, the patient remained neurologically and hemodynamically
stable. Plan for MRI head tomorrow and Angio on ___. TCDs
showed heperemia to R MCA and no vasospasm.
On ___, the patient remained stable. An MRI of the head and
neck was obtained and revealed no AV malformations but again
confirmed subarachnoid blood in the basal and suprasellar
cisterns. Will stay in the ICU for the weekend with plans for a
diagnostic angiogram. TCDs study was limited but no change in
velocity.
Mr. ___ continued to recover well between ___ and ___. On
___, he was taken the angio suite for a repeat cerebral
angiogram. The angio was negative for any vascular malformation
or aneurysm. The patient returned to the ICU for further
management. On the same day, TCDs were performed and also
showed no vasospasm, although the study was somewhat limited.
The patient remained neurologically intact during this time.
Mr. ___ was transferred to the floor for continued management.
On ___, patient remained stable on exam. He was ambulating and
voiding appropriatedly and was discharged home in stable
condition.

Discharge Instructions:
Surgery/ Procedures:
Â*** You had a cerebral angiogram. You may experience some mild
tenderness and bruising at the puncture site (groin).
Activity
ÂWe recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing,
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
ÂYou make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
ÂYou make take a shower.
ÂNo driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication.
ÂIf you experienced a seizure while admitted, you must refrain
from driving.
Medications
ÂResume your normal medications and begin new medications as
directed.
Â***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin,
Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon.
Â***You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this
medication until follow-up. It is important that you take this
medication consistently and on time.
ÂYou have been discharged on a medication to lower your
cholesterol levels. We recommend that you continue this
medication indefinitely.
ÂYou may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
What You ___ Experience:
ÂMild to moderate headaches that last several days to a few
weeks.
ÂDifficulty with short term memory.
ÂFatigue is very normal
ÂConstipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

Brief Hospital Course:
#) Psychiatric.
___ with h/o bipolar d/o and non-small cell lung carcinoma 
who came to the ED in a manic and psychotic state.  Pt stopped 
taking her meds in ___ after the death of her mother. She 
moved out of her house at that time and moved into her childhood 
home, separating from her husband. She has had erotomanic 
delusions (toward Dr. ___ prior PCP, since ___, 
grandiose delusions (She is GodÂs daughter, and ___ 
___), and ideas of reference (messages from the weather). 
She also intermittently stated that she was divorced from her 
husband, which she was not. Patient initially refused to accept 
the recommended dosages of antipsychotic medications. She was 
only willing to take Navane 5mg daily, a medication she was 
previously prescribed because it had minimal side effects for 
her.  She was court committed to stay in hospital and receive 
medication. She received first Invega injection on ___, 
second dose ___. Before patient received Invega injections, 
she was intermittently and inconsistently denying her delusions. 
Patient acknowledged that she denied them at times of fear 
because she was God's daughter, and was afraid she would be 
attacked by Al-Quaeda. Patient also denied them and became 
paranoid and irritable toward treatment team when she wanted to 
leave the hospital. Her delusions greatly subsided since Invega 
with improved insight, with intermittent paranoia and 
irritability. Collateral was obtained from her psychiatrist Dr. 
___ who stated that patient has a history of 
non-compliance and has had several med trials to include 
Zyprexa, Risperdal, Invega in the past, all which she stopped 
because of weight gain. Collateral obtained from her husband, 
___, was that she has had a delusion involving her 
relationship with ___ since the ___, and that her 
main issue is noncompliance with meds.  ___ is aware that 
___ has sent mail to Dr. ___, and has also driven 
by Dr. ___, but this was the first incident where 
police were involved. Collateral obtained from ___ 
unveiled that patient had been calling his office while in the 
hospital, so phone restrictions on Ms ___ were placed. Dr. 
___ was aware of ___ delusion since the ___ at which time 
he transferred her care to a different PCP. Dr. ___ 
___ husband have spoken regarding this. Dr. ___ 
___ concern regarding his safety and was referred to ___ 
legal department. Dr. ___ will also contact Dr. ___ 
___ regarding her discharge. 

Ms. ___ may continue to hold erotomanic delusions, but she has 
not endorsed any verbally during the last week of 
hospitalization.  She has shown good behavioral control and good 
judgment in the hospital.  At time of discharge, she recognized 
the severity of her actions preceding her hospitalization. The 
delusions that were prominent and leading to gross impairments 
in judgment and behavior upon admission, have greatly subsided. 
Ms. ___ denies any intention/plan to find Dr. ___ his 
family, and she recognizes doing such would likely result in 
police involvement.  She denies access to weapons such as guns, 
and she has no h/o violence. Risk of recidivism has not been 
eliminated, as delusions are fixed false beliefs, but risk is 
greatly diminished. She is agreeing to continue to take meds, 
with plan for ___ to come to her house to administer Invega. 

Patient endorsed anxiety while in the hospital and received 
Ativan 0.5mg BID prn and  0.5mg QHS prn insomnia x 1 repeat with 
adequate symptomatic control. She did not always use the 
available dose and was given risks/benefits/side effects of the 
medication given her age. She was discharged on Ativan 0.5mg 
daily prn, which patient was comfortable with.  
___ Trazadone was increased to 150mg QHS.

#) Medical.
Hypothyroidism. Patient was maintained on home dose Synthroid 
___ 5 days/week and will continue this outpatient.

HTN. Patient had one episode of HTN SBP>170 when patient was 
experiencing anxiety, however this resolved without additional 
intervention. Patient was maintained on home dose Lisinopril 
2.5mg daily and will continue this outpatient.

HLD. Patient was continued on home dose Pravastatin 10mg QHS and 
will continue this outpatient. 

h/o non-small cell lung cancer. CT chest and MRI brain was 
completed to evaluate for any evidence of recurrence of 
metastasis. CT chest showed adrenal gland thickening which was 
recommended to be followed up with either MRI or multiphase CT. 

Allergies. Patient was maintained on Fexofenadine 60mg BID for 
allergy related symptoms. Patient contributed these symptoms to 
use of Talcum powder in her hair. 

Constipation. Patient was given Lactulose 30mL BID prn 
constipation. She had daily BM and used medication when 
necessary. 

#) Safety. On initial admission, patient was very agitated, and 
was on constant observations. After first day, patient 
demonstrated safe behavior for the entirety of the 
hospitalization and was maintained on Q15minute check. 

#) Legal. Patient on Section 7,8,8b and court mandated to be 
hospitalized and receive medication. 

#) Groups/Mileau.  Patient actively participated in group 
activities and was noted to socialize with other patients. She 
was also visited by her husband.

relationship with ___ since the ___, and that her
main issue is noncompliance with meds. ___ is aware that
___ has sent mail to Dr. ___, and has also driven
by Dr. ___, but this was the first incident where
police were involved. Collateral obtained from ___
unveiled that patient had been calling his office while in the
hospital, so phone restrictions on Ms ___ were placed. Dr.
___ was aware of ___ delusion since the ___ at which time
he transferred her care to a different PCP. Dr. ___
___ husband have spoken regarding this. Dr. ___
___ concern regarding his safety and was referred to ___
legal department. Dr. ___ will also contact Dr. ___
___ regarding her discharge.
Ms. ___ may continue to hold erotomanic delusions, but she has
not endorsed any verbally during the last week of
hospitalization. She has shown good behavioral control and good
judgment in the hospital. At time of discharge, she recognized
the severity of her actions preceding her hospitalization. The
delusions that were prominent and leading to gross impairments
in judgment and behavior upon admission, have greatly subsided.
Ms. ___ denies any intention/plan to find Dr. ___ his
family, and she recognizes doing such would likely result in
police involvement. She denies access to weapons such as guns,
and she has no h/o violence. Risk of recidivism has not been
eliminated, as delusions are fixed false beliefs, but risk is
greatly diminished. She is agreeing to continue to take meds,
with plan for ___ to come to her house to administer Invega.
Patient endorsed anxiety while in the hospital and received
Ativan 0.5mg BID prn and 0.5mg QHS prn insomnia x 1 repeat with
adequate symptomatic control. She did not always use the
available dose and was given risks/benefits/side effects of the
medication given her age. She was discharged on Ativan 0.5mg
daily prn, which patient was comfortable with.
___ Trazadone was increased to 150mg QHS.
#) Medical.
Hypothyroidism. Patient was maintained on home dose Synthroid
___ 5 days/week and will continue this outpatient.
HTN. Patient had one episode of HTN SBP>170 when patient was
experiencing anxiety, however this resolved without additional
intervention. Patient was maintained on home dose Lisinopril
2.5mg daily and will continue this outpatient.
HLD. Patient was continued on home dose Pravastatin 10mg QHS and
will continue this outpatient.
h/o non-small cell lung cancer. CT chest and MRI brain was
completed to evaluate for any evidence of recurrence of
metastasis. CT chest showed adrenal gland thickening which was
recommended to be followed up with either MRI or multiphase CT.
Allergies. Patient was maintained on Fexofenadine 60mg BID for
allergy related symptoms. Patient contributed these symptoms to
use of Talcum powder in her hair.
Constipation. Patient was given Lactulose 30mL BID prn
constipation. She had daily BM and used medication when
necessary.
#) Safety. On initial admission, patient was very agitated, and
was on constant observations. After first day, patient
demonstrated safe behavior for the entirety of the
hospitalization and was maintained on Q15minute check.
#) Legal. Patient on Section 7,8,8b and court mandated to be
hospitalized and receive medication.
#) Groups/Mileau. Patient actively participated in group
activities and was noted to socialize with other patients. She
was also visited by her husband.

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Shortness of breath, respiratory failure

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Per patient's family. ___ yo male presented to ___ 
___ ED with pulmonary edema, acute respiratory failure & 
aystole s/p epinephrine and CPR in the field. According to 
daughter, pt had malaise/URTI symptoms for past couple days and 
this morning at 0500 hrs he was feeling poorly. At 0600 hrs, he 
was distressed with worsening dyspnea and "ashen" in appearance. 
When paramedics arrived, pt had laboured breathing and received 
CPAP but became bradycardic then had PEA. He was treated with 
one dose of epinephrine and CPR and returned to sinus rhythm.

In ED, pt was unresponsive with GCS 3, sinus tachycardic, 
hypertensive (BP 188/116), with sluggish pupils. Pt was 
intubated and again became bradycardic/asystolic. He responded 
with CPR and 1mg epinephrine. EKG showed sinus tachy to 130s, 
LVH, STD anterolateral leads, but no STE. CXR obtained showed 
diffuse pulmonary edema. Pt received albuterol and Lasix. Pt 
became hypertensive to 188/116, was given IV nitroglycerin, and 
BP fell to 105/76. Pt was transferred to ICU. He underwent head 
CT (positive for atherosclerosis and mild diffuse atrophy, 
negative for acute process), and afterward had GCS of 5. Pt was 
cooled with ice packs. Initial ABG showed pH 7.113 and PCo2 
89.7, and repeat ABG showed pH 7.206 and PCo2 59.2. WBC of 12, 
Mg of 2.6, K of 3.5. TSH of 10.32, T4 of 1.03. Pt received 10 
meQ potassium IV x1. Fentanyl drip was initiated at 25mcg for 
sedation.

Prior to transfer, pt was noted to have twitching and eyelid 
fluttering and was given ativan 0.5mg IV. Daughter denies 
tonic-clonic activity pre-hospital.

Pt was transferred to ___ CCU intubated with cooling pads in 
place. Cardiac arrest team was consulted and per their 
recommendations, pt was initiated on cooling protocol (34-36C). 

Pt had episodes of flickering lower lip and decorticate 
posturing with rigidity in upper limbs, but no obvious 
shivering. Pt under continuous EEG per cardiac arrest protocol 
and Epilepsy and Neurology consulted regarding seizures.
 
Past Medical History:
CHF 
Nephrolithiasis
Ankylosing spondylitis on prior CT
Hx of horseshoe kidney
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother - ___ disease
Father - died of "old age" in ___

Admission

ventilation CPAP/PSV (FiO2=50%, PEEP=8cmH2O)
Gen: Pt is unresponsive and intubated lying in bed.
HEENT: No conjunctival pallor. No icterus. Pupils are symmetric 
and reactive but sluggish.
NECK: Supple, No LAD. No JVD.    
CV: PMI in ___ intercostal space, mid clavicular line. RRR. 
Normal S1,S2. No murmurs, rubs, clicks, or gallops appreciated.
LUNGS: Good air entry bilat with crackles bilat.
ABD: NBS. Soft, obese, ND. No abdominal bruits.  
EXT: Full distal pulses bilaterally UE and ___. Not obviously 
edematous in lower limbs.
SKIN: Pink. No rashes/lesions, ecchymoses.
NEURO: Pt has occasional cough reflex but otherwise 
unresponsive. Does not respond to voice or touch. Does not 
withdraw to pain.

IMAGING:
EKG (___): Normal sinus rhythm. Left anterior hemiblock. 
Rate 57, PR 168, QRS 100, QTc (___) 440.

TTE (___): IMPRESSION: Biatrial enlargement. Mildly 
dilated LV with mild symmetric hypertrophy and moderatedly 
depressed global systolic function in a pattern most c/w 
non-ischemic etiology. Mildly dilated aortic root and descending 
thoracic aorta. Mild functional AR. Findings suggestive of 
hypertensive heart disease. LVEF <40%, pt may benefit from beta 
blocker and an ACEi or ___. The patient has a mildly dilated 
ascending aorta.

EEG (___): IMPRESSION: This is an abnormal ICU EEG study 
due to the presence of diffusely low voltages throughout the 
record without any reactivity. This background is interspersed 
with very brief bursts of generalized delta frequency activity 
that is not associated with clinical correlate. Lip twitches 
noted above are not associated with any electrographic 
correlate. Overall, these findings are suggestive of severe 
diffuse cerebral dysfunction, which is nonspecific as to 
etiology, but in this case likely secondary to hypoxic ischemic 
injury. No electrographic seizures or epileptiform discharges 
are identified. The presence of a burst suppression pattern 
following cardiac arrest is generally associated with poor 
neurologic outcome, but EEG is most helpful for prognostication 
after rewarming from hypothermia, approximately 72 hours post 
arrest. 

EEG (___): IMPRESSION: This is an abnormal ICU EEG study 
due to the presence of a burst suppression pattern where a 
highly attenuated nonreactive background is interspersed by 
brief bursts of polymorphic delta frequency waves that are not 
associated with a clinical correlate. Overall, these findings 
are suggestive of severe diffuse cerebral dysfunction. No 
electrographic seizures or epileptiform discharges were 
identified. The presence of a burst suppression pattern 
following cardiac arrest is generally associated with poor 
neurologic outcome, although EEG is most useful for 
prognostication at 72 hours following arrest. 

CXR (___): No change from ___ in the appearance of the 
monitoring and support devices.  The hazy opacification at the 
bases, especially on the left, is less prominent, which could 
reflect the decrease in layering effusion, though it could 
merely be a manifestation of a more upright position of the 
patient. Prominence of reticular markings at the bases, more 
prominent on the right, most likely represents atelectasis, 
though there may be mild asymmetric elevation of pulmonary 
venous pressure.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M w/ hx CHF s/p hypoxic PEA arrest.
Pt was brought to the CCU mechanically ventilated on fentanyl 
gtt The therapeutic hypothermia protocol was continued (33-35C, 
PCO2 35-45 with PaO2 >94%) x 24 hrs and then pt was subsequently 
rewarmed. Rewarming was completed on ___ at 1800. Pt had 
TTE which showed mildly dilated atria, EF 35%, suggestive of 
underlying untreated hypertensive disease. Pt was initially 
having lip/facial twitching and was given rocuronium and started 
on continuous EEG monitoring as per neuro and epilepsy team 
rec's. Rocuronium was discontinued at onset of rewarming. Once 
rewarmed to 37C, fentanyl was discontinued and pt was started on 
propofol infusion with midazolam boluses. All sedation was 
discontinued at ___ on ___ and period spontaneous waking 
trials were implemented with no response. For seizure-like 
activity, pt was given Keppra 1000mg daily per neuro rec's and 
EEG monitoring was discontinued.  EEG c/w hypoxic injury. After 
72 hours, patient remained without unarousable with extensor 
posturing and without pain responses. Family discussion took 
place with Neurology and CCU teams.  It was decided that care 
would be withdrawn in light of poor neurologic prognosis.  
Patient extubated and died within 12 hours. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Aspirin PRN
 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PEA arrest 
 
Discharge Condition:
Death
 
Discharge Instructions:
None
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
new onset atrial fibrillation
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with PMHx mild AS ___ 1.2-1.3), 
COPD, HLD, HTN presents with new onset AFib.

Prior to presentation, Mr. ___ noticed a progressively 
worsening shortness of breath on exertion, from tolerating two 
blocks a year ago to only half a block in recent weeks before 
feeling dyspneic. He reports having pneumonia in ___ and 
___ of this year. Two days ago, he was walking in his hallway 
when he became acutely short of breath, significantly worse than 
his baseline. He denied any chest pain but endorsed 
lightheadedness and an episode of urinary incontinence. He

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
 
You admitted to ___ because you are having 
worsening shortness of breath. 

We found that your heart was in an abnormal rhythm called atrial 
fibrillation.  We started you on a medication called diltiazem 
to help control your heart rate.  We also started you on a blood 
thinner called Xarelto (or rivaroxaban) to protect you against 
the risk of stroke.  Fortunately the medication helped you go 
back to your regular heart rhythm. You are still at risk of 
going back into atrial fibrillation and therefore we continued 
your blood thinner.
 
Please follow-up with your primary care doctor.
Please continue to take your medications as prescribed.
 
Please return to the hospital if you have sudden onset chest 
pain, shortness of breath, lightheadedness, bleeding that does 
not stop or are having any other concerning symptoms.
 
We wish you the best in health,
 
Your ___ team 
 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ line placement ___.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with PMH significant for HIV (CD4 484) and hypertension 
who presents with left sided back pain. The pain started 
abruptly 2 days ago while the patient was getting into his car. 
He denies any trauma to the area. He sought care at ___ 
___ yesterday, where he was ruled out for a kidney stone. 
He was discharged home with percocet. Yesterday evening, the 
patient syncopized while sitting in a chair. He reports feeling 
dizzy prior to the event. He hit his head on the floor and had 
loss of consciousness for approximately one minute. He denies

EKG (___)

V3-V5.

CTA CHEST/ABD (___)
1. No aortic dissection.
2. Trace left pleural effusion.
3. Chronically elevated left hemidiaphragm, stable.

HEAD CT (___)
No acute intracranial process.

ECHO (___)
The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is 
seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thicknesses 
are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Due to 
suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality 
cannot be fully excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic 
function is normal (LVEF>55%). There is no ventricular septal 
defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are 
normal. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. 
The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets 
(3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and 
no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. No masses or 
vegetations are seen on the aortic valve. The mitral valve 
appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. 
No mass or vegetation is seen on the mitral valve. There is no 
pericardial effusion. 

MRI ABDOMEN (___)
Left paraspinal musculature microabscesses centered at T12-L1, 
with extensive surrounding intra and intermuscular edema and 
hyperemia.  Abnormal enhancement extends into the left T12 
neural foramen with thickening of the epidural space, likely 
reactive in nature, and no evidence of an epidural abscess.  The 
L1 vertebral body is subtly edematous, but osteomyelitis is 
suspected of the
medial left 12th rib, surrounded by the soft tissue infection.

MRI L-SPINE (___)
1. No evidence of diskitis, osteomyelitis, or epidural 
collection.
2. Edema and mild contrast enhancement in the left posterior 
paravertebral
muscles without a fluid collection. Diagnostic considerations 
include muscle sprain or myositis, which may be inflammatory or 
infectious. Please correlate clinically.
3. Multilevel lumbar degenerative disease without significant 
spinal canal
stenosis. Mass effect on the exiting left L4 nerve root at L4-5 
and on the
exiting right L5 nerve root at L5-S1, as detailed above.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with PMH significant for HIV (CD4 484) and HTN who 
presents with nontraumatic left flank pain and syncope.

# MRSA BACTEREMIA/OSTEOMYELITIS: The patient presented with ___ 
SIRS criteria: fever, tachycardia, and leukocytosis. His only 
symptom was left flank pain. The patient was empirically started 
on vancomyin and cefepime for an unknown source. Blood cultures 
grew GPCs within 12 hours, later identified to be MRSA. The 
etiology of bacteremia remains unclear as he had no obvious skin 
lesions, recent dental manipulation, kidney stone, and IV drug 
use. He reports being sexually active. Therefore, it is possible 
that recent receptive anal sex led to microtears in the 
anorectal canal and seeded the blood stream. Echocardiogram was 
negative for vegetations. MRI showed left paraspinal musculature 
microabscesses with likely osteomyelitis of his left 12th rib. A 
PICC line was placed, and the patient will continue vancomycin 
for a total of 6 weeks. He will be followed by the infectious 
disease ___ clinic. 

# HYPONATREMIA: This was likely secondary to hypovolemia in the 
setting of sepsis. This improved with IV resuscitation.

# SYNCOPE: Admission EKG and telemetry was negative for 
arrhtyhmia. The patient did not have further syncopal episodes 
during hospitalization. Etiology of syncope felt to be vasovagal 
in the setting of severe pain.

# ST-DEPRESSIONS: Though the patient denied chest pain, 
admission EKG was notable for ST depressions in V3-V5. There was 
no prior EKG to compare. Serial EKG demonstrated improvement of 
ST-depressions. Troponins were negative x 3. CTA was negative 
for aortic dissection. 

# HIV: Most recent CD4 421, viral load <75 in ___.  He is 
sexually active with one steady male partner, with whom he has 
oral sex with on a regular basis. He had two episodes of 
receptive anal sex in the last month, with one episode that was 
unprotected with a new partner. He is not sexually active with 
his wife. His wife and the rest of his family are unaware of his 
HIV diagnosis and MSM status. He does inform his partners of his 
HIV status prior to engaging in sexual activity. The patient was 
continued on home medications.

# HYPERTENSION: He was continued on losartan and nifedipine.

# DEPRESSION: The patient was continued on citalopram.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUE:
- The patient's family is not aware of his HIV diagnosis and MSM 
status. 
- Follow up with infectious disease ___ clinic.
- The patient will require weekly blood draws: CBC with 
differential, BUN, Cr, vancomycin trough, ESR/CRP. All labs 
should be sent to ___ CLINIC at fax # ___.
- Draw labs on ___.
- All questions regarding outpatient parenteral antibiotics 
after discharge should be directed to the ___ 
R.N.s ___ or to the on-call ID fellow when the 
clinic is closed.
- Remove PICC line after completion of IV antibiotics. 
 
Medications on Admission:

daily 
2. Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY 
3. Losartan Potassium 100 mg PO DAILY 
4. NIFEdipine CR 60 mg PO DAILY 
5. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY

2. Losartan Potassium 100 mg PO DAILY 
3. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
4. NIFEdipine CR 60 mg PO DAILY 
5. Vancomycin 1500 mg IV Q 8H 
6. ATRIPLA (efavirenz-emtricitabin-tenofov) ___ mg oral 
daily

Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS:
MRSA Bacteremia
Osteomyelitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___ 
___. You were admitted with left back pain. Your 
blood cultures grew bacteria (Staph Aureus). An MRI of your back 
showed the bacteria seeded one of your ribs, which is what 
caused your pain. An ultrasound of your heart (echocardiogram), 
did not show any damage to your heart valves. We are not sure 
what caused the bacteria in the blood in the first place. 
Regardless, we started you on IV antibiotics (vancomycin), for 
which you will continue for 6 weeks. You will also follow up 
with the infectious disease doctors. In terms of working, there 
are no restrictions as long as you are able to administer your 
antibiotics. Please see below for medication changes and follow 
up appointments. 

We are glad you are feeling better and we wish you the best.

Your ___ team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Ciprofloxacin / Clindamycin / Quinidine / Niacin / 
Persantine / Diuril IV / Metolazone
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
chest pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Cardiac catheterization with drug eluting stents x2 to left 
circumflex artery

 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o F with PMH of CAD s/p CABG in 1980s, redo in ___ 
((LIMA-LAD, SVG-RCA 'y' graft to OM 'Y' graft to PDA), CKD with 
baseline Cr of 2.6 transferred to CCU in setting of ACS s/p DES 
x2 to native LCx.

Patient had sudden onset typical angina ___ chest discomfort, 
dyspnea, weakness) at 11am while taking out her trash. She 
initially presented to OSH where EKG uninterpretable in setting 
of v-paced rhythm. ___ set of enzymes were negative, but second 
set revealed troponin 0.2 (increased from 0.06), MB 18, and CK 
179; pro BNP 1573.  Patient started on heparin gtt, given ASA 
325mg (plavix deferred as on chronic therapy). Pain was treated 
with morphine - reportedly made her feel worse- and nitro gtt. 
At time of transfer, patient complained of persistant chest 
discomfort, rated ___.

Upon arrival to ___, patient complained of persistent 
discomfort despite high nitro gtt causing SBP in 80-90s.  She 
was taken semi-emergently to the cath lab and reloaded with 
plavix.  Angiography revealed thrombus in ___ which was 
treated with ___ and mid DES.  Both grafts to cx were occluded; 
the LIMA and SVG to RCA remained patent.

Cardiac review of systems is notable for ___ pillow orthopnea. 
She denies dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, 
ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope.
 
Past Medical History:
1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: +Diabetes, +Dyslipidemia, +Hypertension

2. CARDIAC HISTORY:
-CABG: REDO CABG x 4 on ___ (LIMA to LAD, SVG to RCA with "y" 
graft to SVG to OM, SVG to OM graft has "y" graft to SVG to 
DIAG) Prior CABG (___)
-PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: PTCA in RCA ___
-PACING/ICD: pacer/AICD
-CHF with EF 40%

3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
CKD with Cr of 2.6
Anemia, due to CKD
Nonhodgkins Lymphoma s/p chemo/XRT
Gout
PVD
Lymphedema on left leg
Pituitary adenoma, likey cause of frequent headaches
IBS
GERD
Arthritis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Her father died at the age of ___ from CAD. Extensive family 
history of heart disease. No family history of arrhythmia, 
cardiomyopathies, or sudden cardiac death; otherwise 
non-contributory.
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION EXAM
VS: T=Afebrile BP=104/36 HR=74 RR=20 O2 sat=92% on 4L
GENERAL: Very sleepy and tired. Oriented x3. Responded 
appropriately to questions
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were 
pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.
NECK: Supple difficult to assess JVP.
CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular 
line. RR, normal S1, S2. systolic murmur ___. No thrills, lifts. 
No S3 or S4.
LUNGS: Mild kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle 
use. Crackles bilaterally halfway up posterior lung fields, no 
wheezes or rhonchi.
ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not 
enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits.
GROIN: angioseal in both groin sites, femoral bruit over right 
groin, no obvious tenderness at either site, no hematoma felt
EXTREMITIES: Asymmetric peripheral edema noted in left leg, 
trace edema at right ankle
SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.
PULSES:
Right:  DP 1+ ___ 1+
Left:  DP 2+ ___ 2+
 
Pertinent Results:
# CARDIOLOGY

___ Cardiac Catheterization
.................

___ TTE
Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left 
ventricular cavity is moderately dilated. Overall left 
ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 25 %) 
secondary to severe hypokinesis/akinesis of the inferior, 
posterior, and lateral walls, and of the apex. Tissue Doppler 
imaging suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure 
(PCWP>18mmHg). The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus 
level. The aortic arch is mildly dilated. There are focal 
calcifications in the aortic arch. The aortic valve is not well 
seen. The study is inadequate to exclude significant aortic 
valve stenosis. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. 
There is no mitral valve prolapse. Moderate to severe (3+) 
mitral regurgitation is seen. There is borderline pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion.
Compared to prior study of ___, left ventricular 
ejection fraction and mitral regurgitation now much worse.

# RADIOLOGY

___ ULTRASOUND OF RIGHT FEMORAL CATH SITE
IMPRESSION: Small collateral coming off the right common femoral 
artery, but no evidence of AV fistula or pseudoaneurysm. No 
evidence of hematoma.

___ CXR (PA/Lat)
IMPRESSION: 
1. Mildly improved interstitial edema. 2. Small bilateral 
pleural effusions and left retrocardiac opacity which may 
represent atelectasis, although consolidation cannot be 
excluded.

___
ECHO
Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. 
There is mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic 
dysfunction with mild aneurysm/akinesis of the basal inferior

# STEMI/CAD: Patient presented with ACS/STEMI with elevated 
cardiac enzymes and an uninterpretable EKG. Cardiac 
catheterization revealed a 95% occlusion proximally in the LCx 
with filling defect/thrombus; the patient received ___ 2. 
CK-MB peaked at 15.8.  She has been chest pain free since cath. 
Post-cath, she was noted to have a femoral bruit, however there 
was no evidence of aneursym on right groin ultrasound. Patient 
received aspirin 325mg, Plavix 75mg and atorvastatin 80mg. She 
was started on metoprolol which was continued on discharge. She 
was not started on an ace inhibitor ___ given acute on 
chronic renal failure. Given the extent of her  mitral valve 
disease, surgery was consulted for the possibility of MVR but 
she was deemed not to be a suitable candidate. Her dysfunction 
will be managed medically.

# Acute on chronic CHF: Patient was in acute on chronic 
congestive heart failure with pulmonary edema on chest xray. 
Diuresis is difficult secondary to acute on chronic renal 
failure. O2 requirement increased overnight. TTE on ___ showed 
left ventricular systolic function that was severely depressed 
(LVEF= 25 %) secondary to severe hypokinesis/akinesis of the 
inferior, posterior, and lateral walls, and of the apex. Patient 
received a Lasix drip with additional doses of metolazone and 
diuril given to augment urine output. Repeat chest xray showed 
mild improvement in pulmonary edema. In order to improve her 
cardiac output, she was started on digoxin (+ ionotropic effect) 
and metoprolol (to decrease HR and improve Cardiac output). Her 
Pacemaker settings were changed to decrease AV delay to 150ms to 
provide more effective atrial kick. She was continued on low 
dose digoxin.  Her lasix gtt was converted to torsemide PO, she 
was discharged on Torsemide 60mg PO Daily.

# Acute on chronic renal failure: Creatinine was elevated 
(baseline Cr 2.6, now 4.0), likely secondary contrast-induced 
nephropathy secondary to dye load from cardiac catheterization. 
We expect creatinine to peak at 48-72 hours post-exposure. No 
electrolyte abnormalities currently. Medications were renally 
dosed. Fractional excretion of urea was <30%, which indicated a 
pre-renal component as well. Urine culture showed 2 epis, sm 
leuk, 3 WBC, few bacteria, 14 hyaline casts. Her Cr improved 
slightly with diuresis to 3.7 but essentially stabalized close 
to 4. She will need further monitoring and workup of her renal 
failure after discharge.

# Leukocytosis: WBC increased from 8.1 to 11.6. Had elevated 
temperature but not true fever, and it spontaneously resolved. 
No bandemia on differerential. She had an infectious workup 
which included urinalysis and culture as well as a chest xray. 
Lipase was within normal limits.

# Nausea: Patient had intermittent nausea which resolved with 
ondansetron. Etiology unclear.

# Hyperlipidemia: Chronic. Patient is currently receiving 
atorvastatin 80mg daily.  Her gemfibrozil was held in setting of 
high-dose atorvastatin. She was discharged on atorvastatin 80mg 
daily

# Rash/Allergy: She developped an itchy maculopapular rash that 
progressed to cover her entire body. Dermatology was consulted 
and they recommended clobetasol cream BID which she is 
continuing on discharge. Her reaction was thought ___ either 
metolazone or diuril which she received slightly prior to the 
rash.

# GERD: Chronic, stable. Omeprazole was discontinued and patient 
was started on famotidine instead.

# Anemia: Chronic; patient receives Procrit injections twice a 
month and is on folic acid and vitamin B12 supplementation. Her 
hematocrit trended down; etiology unclear. and she was 
transfused with 1U pRBCs on ___. She was started on iron 
supplementation in addition to folic acid & vit B12. She 
received a similar dose of Procrit based on hospital dosing, but 
should resume her previous dosing of Procrit upon discharge. 

# Gout: Stable. Allopurinol was stopped temporarily given 
worsening renal function.

# Diet: Patient was on a diabetic, heart healthy, low sodium, 
low potassium diet.

# DVT Prophylaxis: Patient received heparin products during this 
admission.

# Code status: her code status was discussed and changed to DNR 
but okay to intubate.

Discharge Instructions:
You had a heart attack and required two drug eluting stents be 
placed in your left circumflex artery. Your heart function is 
weaker now so we adjusted your medicines and geve you diuretics 
to get rid of the extra fluid. Your kidney function is worse so 
we stopped some medicines until after your kidneys improve. Your 
blood pressure was low but is normal now after medication 
adjustment. You tallked to a cardiac surgeon about fixing your 
mitral valve but surgery is not a safe option for you so you 
will continue to be treated with medicines to help your heart 
work as efficiently as possible. 
.
We made the following changes to your medicines:
1. Stop taking Furosemide
2. Start taking Torsemide 80 mg daily instead to get rid of 
extra fluid
3. Increase aspirin to 325 mg and continue Plavix daily for at 
least one year. Do not stop taking these medicines unless Dr. 
___ it is OK to do so. 
4. Stop taking Prilosec, aldactone, allopurinol, calcitriol, 
lopid and diovan. You should restart these medicines when your 
kidneys improve. 
5. Start taking potassium daily to increase your potassium 
levels
6. STart taking Heparin injections until you are walking 
regularly to prevent blood clots
7. Start taking colace, senna, miralax and bisacodyl to prevent 
constipation
8. STart Sevelamer to decrease your phosphate levels. Stop 
Calcitriol for now. Dr. ___ adjust these medicines
9. Change B12 to daily pills until you are able to return for 
your bi weekly injections
10. STart Trazadone to help you sleep
11. STart Hydroxyzine and Clobesetrol to help with the itch
12. STart tylenol as needed for pain
13. Stop simvastatin and start Atorvastatin to lower your 
cholesterol. 
14. Start Metoprolol succinate to lower your heart rate and help 
your heart pump better.  
.
Weigh yourself every morning, call Dr. ___ weight goes 
up more than 3 lbs in 1 day or 5 pounds in 3 days. 
Follow a low salt diet.

___
