Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute on Chronic systolic congestive heart failure: not on
___ because ___
Non ST Elevation myocardial Infarction
Acute on Chronic Kidney Injury
Iron Deficient anemia
Non-___ Lymphoma
Pacer/Internal defibrillator
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
You had a heart attack and required two drug eluting stents be
placed in your left circumflex artery. Your heart function is
weaker now so we adjusted your medicines and geve you diuretics
to get rid of the extra fluid. Your kidney function is worse so
we stopped some medicines until after your kidneys improve. Your
blood pressure was low but is normal now after medication
adjustment. You tallked to a cardiac surgeon about fixing your
mitral valve but surgery is not a safe option for you so you
will continue to be treated with medicines to help your heart
work as efficiently as possible.
.
We made the following changes to your medicines:
1. Stop taking Furosemide
2. Start taking Torsemide 80 mg daily instead to get rid of
extra fluid
3. Increase aspirin to 325 mg and continue Plavix daily for at
least one year. Do not stop taking these medicines unless Dr.
___ it is OK to do so.
4. Stop taking Prilosec, aldactone, allopurinol, calcitriol,
lopid and diovan. You should restart these medicines when your
kidneys improve.
5. Start taking potassium daily to increase your potassium
levels
6. STart taking Heparin injections until you are walking
regularly to prevent blood clots
7. Start taking colace, senna, miralax and bisacodyl to prevent
constipation
8. STart Sevelamer to decrease your phosphate levels. Stop
Calcitriol for now. Dr. ___ adjust these medicines
9. Change B12 to daily pills until you are able to return for
your bi weekly injections
10. STart Trazadone to help you sleep
11. STart Hydroxyzine and Clobesetrol to help with the itch
12. STart tylenol as needed for pain
13. Stop simvastatin and start Atorvastatin to lower your
cholesterol.
14. Start Metoprolol succinate to lower your heart rate and help
your heart pump better.
.
Weigh yourself every morning, call Dr. ___ weight goes
up more than 3 lbs in 1 day or 5 pounds in 3 days.
Follow a low salt diet.
Followup Instructions:
___

right lung base aeration as well as decrease in the subcutaneous 
air within the right chest wall.  Left lung is clear.  There is 
no change in the left basal/lingular atelectasis. 
  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the hospital and taken to the 
Operating Room where she underwent a right thoracotomy and 
tracheobronchoplasty with mesh and bronchoscopy with lavage. She 
tolerated the procedure well and returned to the TSICU in stable 
condition. She maintained stable hemodynamics and her pain was 
controlled with an epidural. Her ___ drain put out a modest 
amount of fluid and had no air leak.  She underwent vigorous 
pulmonary toilet including chest ___, nebulizers and incentive 
spirometry and her oxygen saturations were in the 95% range on 2 
liters.  She had no dysphagia post op and her diet was slowly 
advanced from sips to regular which she tolerated well.

Following transfer to the Surgical floor her ___ drain was 
removed on post op day #2 as the drainage was minimal and there 
was no air leak.  Her epidural was removed on post op day #4 as 
it migrated out of position and she had better pain control with 
oral narcotics and Tylenol.  Her right thoracotomy site was 
healing well. 

Her pulmonary status improved daily and her congestion had 
slowly resolved with the help of Mucomyst nebulizers and 
Mucinex.  The Interventional Pulmonary service evaluated her as 
she was concerned that her right incisional pain had increased 
and wondered if it was from her small right pleural effusion. An 
ultrasound was done on ___ which showed a small right 
pleural effusion, too small to drain and unlikely the cause of 
her pain.  her Gabapentin was increased from 200 mg TID to ___ 
mg TID and she continued with Oxycodone, Lidoderm patch and 
Tylenol. She was encouraged to wean the oxycodone down in a few 
days and she will also continue her mucomyst nebulizers.  Her 
ambulatory room air saturations were 94%.  She was discharged to 
home on ___ and will follow up with Dr. ___ in 2 
weeks.

SOB/wheezing  
10.  Budesonide 0.5 mg IH BID  
11.  fluticasone propionate 220 mcg inhalation BID  
12.  Fluticasone-Salmeterol Diskus (500/50)  1 INH IH BID

14.  Montelukast 10 mg PO QHS  
15.  tiotropium bromide 2.5 mcg/actuation inhalation DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Severe diffuse tracheobronchomalacia.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
* You were admitted to the hospital for surgery on your airway 
and you've recovered well. You are now ready for discharge. 
 
* Continue to use your incentive spirometer 10 times an hour 
while awake along with your flutter valve.

* Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or 
drainage.   Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.

* You may need pain medication once you are home but you can 
wean it over the next week as the discomfort resolves.  Make 
sure that you have regular bowel movements while on narcotic 
pain medications as they are constipating which can cause more 
problems.  Use a stool softener or gentle laxative to stay 
regular.

* No driving while taking narcotic pain medication.

* Take Tylenol on a standing basis to avoid more opiod use.

* Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your 
incisions

* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat 
dry
 * No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed
 * No lotions or creams to incision site

* Walk ___ times a day and gradually increase your activity as 
you can tolerate.

Call Dr. ___ ___ if you experience:
 -Fevers > 101 or chills
 -Increased shortness of breath, chest pain or any other 
symptoms that concern you.

 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ s/p CABG X2 (___), complete heart block s/p PPM (___),
hld, htn, HFpEF (ef 50-55% as of ___, mild AS, OSA, who
presented with CP and SOB. He was then transferred for NSTEMI 
and
mild decompensated CHF.

Mr. ___ was in his normal state of health until several days 
ago
when he developed a UTI for which he was treated with Keflex. A
few days into his treatment with Keflex, he noted numbness
sensation at the corner of his mouth which then spread around 
his
mouth. Keflex was stopped and he was treated with oral steroids
for allergic reaction.

On the ___ day of steroids, he developed substernal chest
pressure at rest, similar to typical angia. His angina is
typically brought on by exertion when he works (works as a
___). He tried SL nitro X4, however the pressure continued
to escalate in severity over the course of a few hours. Pressure
radiated to left neck and he had associated SOB. He denied
diaphoresis, nausea, palpitations, diazzineess during this time.

He then presented to ___ (___) where he was given
nitro and ___. Trop was 0.06 and peaked the following morning at
28.7. His proBNP was 3340. ECG showed paced rhythm. He was
treated with ___, Clopidogrel, heparin gtt and high intensity
statin. Also given Lasix 40mg IV that was transitioned to 40mg
PO. His D-dimer was elevated, though LENIs were negative. He was
also noted to be hypertensive for which labetalol was increased
to 100mg TID, e was continued with home lisinopril 40mg and
nifepidine 60mg. Over the course of the first day at ___, his symptoms resolved. e was then transferred directly
to ___ on his request as Dr. ___ is his cardiologist. Being
managed for further NSTEMI work-up.

His medical regimen at time of transfer was:
___ 81
atorvastatin 80mg
cholecalciferol 1000unit QD
Clopidogrel 75 QD 
furosemide 40mg PO (started at ___)
glipizide 10mg QD

lisinopril 40mg QD
metformin 1000mg
nifedipine ER 60mh
nitro SL

held:

no specific complaints.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:  
Positive per HPI.  
Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain,
dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea,
ankle edema, palpitations, syncope, or presyncope.  

On further review of systems, denies fevers or chills. Denies 
any
prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary
embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint 
pains,
cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. Denies exertional
buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were
negative.  
 
Past Medical History:
1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS  
- Diabetes  
- Hypertension  
- Dyslipidemia  
2. CARDIAC HISTORY  
Per ___ transfer notes:
- CABG X2 SVG-OM1 and SVG-RPDA (___) 
- ___ Cath:
1. Coronary angiography in the right dominant system 
demonstrated
three vessel disease. The ___ had no angiographically apparent
disease. The mid and distal stents in the LAD were patent. The
stent in the Diagonal branch was patent. The LCx had a mid 40%
stenosis. OM1 was diffusely diseased with a 99% proximal
stenosis. The RCA was occluded mid vessel which extended to the
crux. The RV marginal branch had an 80% proximal stenosis. 
2. Arterial conduit angiography revealed the SVG to OM1 occluded
and the SVG to R-PDA to be occluded. 
3. Limited resting hemodyanamics revealed normal central aortic
pressure with a BP of 138/73 and mean of 101 mmHg. 
4. Unsuccessful attempt to POBA the OM1. Final angiography
revealed a 
99% residual stenosis, no angiographically apparent dissection,
and TIMI 2 flow. 
5. Successful PTCA and stenting of the RV Marginal with a 2.25 x
20mm 
Taxus Atom drug eluting stent. Final angiography revealed no
residual 
stenosis, no angiographically apparent dissection, and TIMI 3
flow. 
6. Unsuccessful attempt to wire the RCA. Final angiography
revealed 100% residual stenosis, no angiographically apparent
dissection, and TIMI 0 flow.  (see PTCA comments for details) 
7. Successful deployment of a TR Band achieving right radial
artery 
hemostasis.

Brief Hospital Course:
# Adrenal insufficiency/Hypotension - Patient has history of 
panhypopituitarism secondary to pituitary adenoma s/p radiation 
therapy.  On hormonal replacement at home.  Her symptoms of 
hypotension likely due to acute adrenal insufficiency, as she 
has been sick recently which represents an additional stressor, 
and her body was unable to compensate.  Patient's BP improved 
following pressors initiation and steroid administration in the 
ED.  No signs of active infections to suggest sepsis.  She was 
able to be weaned off of neosynephrine very quickly suggesting 
the steroids were effective in treating her hypotension.  
Dehydration likely also contributing to hypotension. Weaned off 
pressors completely on the night of admission.  Started on 
hydrocortisone 100 mg q8h, and continued on desmopressin.  
Endocrine consult obtained and recommended decreasing 
hydrocortisone to 50mg q8h for 2 days and then the patient was 
eventually weaned down to her home dose of hydrocortisone 10mg 
PO am and 5mg PO pm.  Her blood pressure remained stable on her 
home dose and PO fluidsand it was felt she was stable and ready 
for discharge with follow up with her PCP, ___.  Her 
desmopressin and levothyroxine for panhypopituitarism was 
continued throughout the course of her hospital stay.
.
# Transaminitis - Acute increase LFTs was likely ___ hypotension 
in the setting of chronic liver disease. Pt presented with ALT 
72, AST 244, lipase 99.  LFTs peaked at ALT 308 AST 803 and then 
downtrended as BP stabilized. Patient does have history of NASH 
followed at ___. RUQ u/s showed fatty infiltration, nodularity, 
evidence of portal HTN.  Pt LFT trended down during her hospital 
stay.  Given her elevated LFT, we did not restart her metformin 
at time of discharge 
.
Daibetes: Pt metformin was held and she was started on an 
insulin sliding scale.  Given Ms. ___ elevated transaminitis 
in the setting of shock liver, her metformin was not restarted 
at the time of discharge.  We advised her to make an appointment 
with her endocrinologist within 2 weeks who would repeat her lab 
work and decide how to continue to manage her diabetes at that 
time.  
.
# Hyperkalemia - presented with K of 6.7, improved to 4.0 with 
fluid resuscitation and hydrocortisone.  Likely ___ to acute 
renal failure.  After the initial correction, hyperkalemia was 
not an issue during this admission.
.
# Acute renal failure - presented with creatinine of 5.0, 
improved to 1.1 with IV fluids, stress dose steroids and 
pressors.  Her creatinine was stable at 0.9 at the time of 
discharge.  
.
# Nausea/vomiting/diarrhea - Most likley represents viral 
gastroenteritis. no fevers at home.  continued to be afebrile 
during the course of her hospital stay.  She had liquid diarrhea 
in the ED and c-diff was negative.  At the time of discharge she 
was having formed stools.
.
# ?PNA - CXR with RUL opacity (aspiration vs atalectasis), 
abdominal XR without any intraabdominal processes.  CT abdomen 
showed some bibasilar atelectasis vs aspiration.  Received 
cipro, flagyl, and vancomycin in the ED, but no overt symptoms 
of pneumonia.  Antibiotics were not continued in the MICU. 
Respiratory status remained stable throughout her hospital stay. 

.
# Fatigue - mother says that patient often will tune other 
people out when she is feeling sick.  However, patient initially 
appeared very fatigued, falling asleep during conversation, very 
limited attention.  Per mother, patient is usually much more 
interactive and lively.  TFT's were unremarkable. On second day 
of admission patient showed marked improvement, conversing, 
alert, able to get out of bed with assistance. Pt remained alert 
and interactive for the rest of her hospital stay.
.  
# Seizure - mother reports that she has seizures nearly every 
day lasting ___ seconds.  They are characterized with her 
repeating words, no shaking. Carbamezapine home dose was 
continued.  Pt did not have any seizures while in the MICU or on 
the medicine floor
.
# ?HTN - lisinopril held given ARF and hypotension.  Her 
creatinine returned to baseline and her BP stabilized in the 
MICU and remained stable on the floor.  Her lisinopril was 
restarted at time of discharge.  According to her PCP, 
lisinopril was started for renal protection not for 
hypertension.
.
# ?Anxiety - buspirone continued at daily dosing as opposed to 
BID given acute renal failure.  At the time of discharge she was 
told to restart her BID doseing.
 
Medications on Admission:
buspirone 15 mg BID
carbamazepine XR 200 mg daily
desmopressin 0.4 mg BID
enbrel sure click, 50 mg/mL 3.92 mL package - 2 shots/week
hydrocortisone 10 mg qAM, 5 mg qPM
levothyroxine 0.125 mg daily
lisinopril 10 mg daily
magnesium gluconate 250 mg daily
metformin 500 mg BID
premphase 0.625/5 mg daily
vitamin D ___ IU qmonthly
cholest off (dietary supplement) tablet
omega 3 fish oil 1000 mg daily

(1) Tablet Sustained Release 12 hr PO DAILY (Daily).

day.  
3. Enbrel SureClick 50 mg/mL (0.98 mL) Pen Injector Sig: Two (2) 
shots Subcutaneous once a week.  
4. hydrocortisone 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Every 
morning.

afternoon.  
6. levothyroxine 125 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).

.

Discharge Instructions:
You are being discharged from ___ 
___.  You were admitted on ___ for dehydration from 
vomiting and diarrhea and had extremely low blood pressures that 
you required more than 9 liters of fluid placed into your veins 
and two types of  medicine (pressors and steroids) that keep the 
blood pressure elevated.  You needed this blood pressure support 
for a short period of time and eventually you were doing well 
withoout the fluids, but was still getting high dose steroids 
for help with your blood pressure.  You were transferred from 
the intensive care unit to the regular floor for further care.  
While on the regular floor, we lowered your hydrocortisone back 
to your home dose of 10mg in the morning and 5mg in the 
afternoon.  
.
In the setting of your dehydration and low blood pressures your 
had some shock to your liver and your liver enzymes rose 
significantly.  We cannot restart your metformin because your 
liver enzymes are high and so it was decided that your metformin 
was held and endocrine decided that you should not resume 
metformin until you are seen by an endocrinologist. please make 
an appointment to be seen by your endocrinologist in the next 
two weeks.
.
The following medication was STOPPED:
Metformin 500mg by mouth two times a day
.
Please take your other medications as prescribed.

#Chronic Abdominal Pain. Ms. ___ has been having chronic 
abdominal pain for several months which has resulted in nearly 
30lb weight loss. She reports that she is unable to consume 
meals by mouth aside from coffee and occasional bites of fruit. 
She has had an extensive work up as an outpatient with no clear 
etiology identified. NJ tube was placed on ___ and tube 
feeds initiated without incident. She reached her goal rate on 
___. She underwent endoscopic ultrasound and EGD which was 
unremarkable. MRE revealed mild prominence of the CBD (which is 
likely related to her cholecystectomy). GI was consulted, 
thought that her current presentation can be explained by 
narcotic bowel syndrome, with frequently recurring abdominal 
pain that worsens with continued or escalating doses of 
narcotics. They have advised slow weaning from her opiate 
regimen and replacement with alternative pain modalities. DDx 
for her abdominal pain include adrenal insufficiency (AM 
cortisol normal), porphyria (urine porphobilinogen negative), 
angioedema (C4 negative), and lead poisoning.

She has a follow up nutrition appointment scheduled for ___, 
___ with her dietician. Her pain was treated with her home 
pain regimen: PO hydromorphone 2mg q6 PRN, PO oxycodone 5mg q6h 
PRN, duloxetine 60 mg, and ondansetron 4mg q8 prn for nausea.

#GERD. She was continued on her home omeprazole.

Report History 
 MON ___ 5:21 ___
by INFORMATION,SYSTEMS  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was transferred from ___ for surgical 
revascularization after ruling in for NSTEMI and cardiac 
catheterization that revealed Left Main and multi vessel disease 
for which and IABP was placed. He was admitted to the CVICU and 
remained pain free on IABP, Nitroglycerin and heparin infusion. 
He underwent routine preoperative evaluation and was cleared for 
surgery.
The patient was brought to the Operating Room on ___ where 
the patient underwent coronary artery bypass grafting by Dr. 
___ - see operative note for details. In summary he had: 
Urgent coronary artery bypass grafting x3, with left internal 
mammary artery graft to left anterior descending, reverse 
saphenous vein graft to the ramus intermedius branch and 
diagonal branch. Overall the patient tolerated the procedure 
well and post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable 
condition for recovery and invasive monitoring. 
He did well post-operatively and was extubated shortly after 
arrival to CVICU. POD 1 found the patient alert, oriented and 
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact 
and hemodynamically stable.  Beta blocker was initiated and the 
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  The 
patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further 
recovery.  All chest tubes, lines and pacing wires were 
discontinued per cardiac surgery protocol without complication.  
Once on the stepdown floor the patient worked with nursing and 
was evaluated by the Physical Therapy service for assistance 
with strength and mobility. The remainder of his hospital stay 
was uneventful.  By the time of discharge on POD 5 the patient 
was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain was 
controlled with oral analgesics.  The patient was discharged 
home, to a friend's house, with visiting nurses in good 
condition with appropriate follow up instructions.
Of note, the patient does have a history of AAA. Imaging during 
this admission, ___, reveals, "Infrarenal abdominal aortic 
aneurysm up to 4.3 cm.  Right common iliac artery aneurysm up to

Urgent coronary artery bypass grafting x3, with left internal
mammary artery graft to left anterior descending, reverse
saphenous vein graft to the ramus intermedius branch and
diagonal branch. Overall the patient tolerated the procedure
well and post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable
condition for recovery and invasive monitoring.
He did well post-operatively and was extubated shortly after
arrival to CVICU. POD 1 found the patient alert, oriented and
breathing comfortably. The patient was neurologically intact
and hemodynamically stable. Beta blocker was initiated and the
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight. The
patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further
recovery. All chest tubes, lines and pacing wires were
discontinued per cardiac surgery protocol without complication.
Once on the stepdown floor the patient worked with nursing and
was evaluated by the Physical Therapy service for assistance
with strength and mobility. The remainder of his hospital stay
was uneventful. By the time of discharge on POD 5 the patient
was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain was
controlled with oral analgesics. The patient was discharged
home, to a friend's house, with visiting nurses in good
condition with appropriate follow up instructions.
Of note, the patient does have a history of AAA. Imaging during
this admission, ___, reveals, "Infrarenal abdominal aortic
aneurysm up to 4.3 cm. Right common iliac artery aneurysm up to
2.5 cm." Results communicated to PCP.

text:
Name:  ___         ___ No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
 burning paresthesias
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Lumbar puncture ___
 
History of Present Illness:
___ year-old right-handed woman with a
history including pituitary microadenoma who presents with a
three month history of symtoms including headache,
lightheadedness, and burning paresthesias.  
.
The patient first began to feel unwell in ___.  She
recalls being seated at work when she started to see "squiggly
lines" in both visual fields.  About two hours later she
developed a throbbing bifrontal headache that radiated to the
occipital regions.  The headache rated ___.  There were no 
clear
triggers, exacerbating factors, or other associated symptoms. 
She has had similar headaches in the past, and attributed the
discomfort to stress.
.
The following week she began to have frequent headaches.  She
describes a throbbing discomfort in the bifrontal region that
radiated back to the occipital region.  The headaches rated
___ in intensity.  There was no clear trigger.  There were no
exacerbating factors.  The discomfort was associated with
"pressure" across the eyes and forehead.  There was no
concomitant nausea, vomiting, phonophobia, photophobia, or
sensorimotor disturbance.  Aspirin and tylenol provided relief.
.
Around the same time, she began to develop dizziness.  She
characterizes the sensation as "the early buzz with a glass of
wine" or the feeling one has while getting off a boat.  She 
found
that when she quickly turned her head, it felt as though it took
a moment for her eyes to catch up and adjust.  There was no 
clear
trigger for the sensation such as moving from a stand to a sit,
although the sensation did tend to occur more frequently when 
she
was in the upright position and moving about.  There were no
exacerbating factors, alleviating variable, or associated
symptoms.  It could last all day.
.
For these symptoms, she presented to her PCP who attributed the
symptoms to a sinus infection.  She was prescribed a course of
amoxicillin.  The headache resolved within 24 hours.  However,
because the dizziness did not resolve, she returned to the PCP. 
He prescribed a four-day course of prednisone 40 mg per day.  
.
By early ___, she developed a tingling that predominently
affected the left cheek.  She presented to an ED where a
non-contrast CT of the head was done.  It was reportedly 
negative
except for "fluid in the nasal cavity."  She googled her
symptoms, however, and found that multiple sclerosis could be an
explanation.  She says she became panicked at the thought.  That
night, she developed "burning" in a band across the back between
the two shoulders.  It did not radiate.  There were no
exacerbating factors or associated symptoms other than the 
facial
paresthesias and dizziness.  She presented to her PCP the next
day; the burning completely resolved following his reassurance.
.
For one week thereafter, her only symptom was the dizziness.  
She
followed up with her PCP again, and was reassured.  She was then
symptom-free for two-weeks, the timing of which corresponded 
with
vacation.
.
Thereafter, the dizziness returned.  It became associated with a
pressure across the eyes. The sensation was somewhat relieved by
sudafed.
.
In ___, she developed facial paresthesias again.  Now the
abnormal sensations involved the cheek and chin L>R.  On ___,
she flew to ___ for vacation.  Her face felt tingly and
"inflamed" during the flight.  However, throughout the vacation,
she actually felt much better with almost complete resolution of
all symptoms.  The facial symptoms returned on the flight home.
.
On ___, she returned to her PCP.  He suggested the sinus
infection had returned.  He presecribed erythromycin and
prednisone 40 mg x 4 days.  However, she became worried that the
therapies were not helping - and that the sinus infection could
not account for all the symptoms.  That night she developed
burning that encompassed the entire back.  It lasted all night. 
She identifies stress as a precipitant.  During a visit to a 
lake
the next day, the symptom completely resolved.
.
On ___, she developed a sense of sunburn on her back.  Her
forearms, L>R began to feel "funny," as did the medial aspect of
her right lower leg.  It spontaneously resolved the next day.  
.
On ___, both arms started to feel as if they were burning. 

The burning progressed over the next day to encompass the neck
and entire torso (back and front) to the level of the waist.  
She
further desccribes it as a sense that she is being cut by 
razors.
The pain rates ___ at worst.  It has been constant with waxing
and waning intensity.  It changes location.  At night it is most
pronounced in an escutcheon pattern from the chest to the
epigastrium; this pain is worse with lying down and better with
standing and moving around.  
.
She has never had any similar symptoms (or ophtho symptoms) in
the past.  To address the symptoms, she has tried pepcid,
benadryl, and had her IUD removed.  Ibuprofen 800 mg has 
provided
some relief.
.
She met with neurologist Dr. ___ on ___ who
coordinated an MRI of the brain and spinal cord to evaluate for
inflammatory, structural, and demyelinating processes.  The MRI
of the brain showed no definite focal lesions to suggest a
demyelinating etiology.  The MRI of the cervical spine showed
reversal of cervical lordosis and multilevel degenerative
disease, most pronounced from C4-6.  Dr. ___
referred her for an allergy evaluation ___ it was thought
she could be be suffering from chronic sinusitis or allergic
rhinitis in addition to a neurologic process. Given an 
escalation
in symptoms, it was recommended she be admitted to the neurolgy
service for an expedited evaluation.  She is most concerned by
the degree of discomfort and the possibility of multiple
sclerosis.

NEUROLOGICAL REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

- Negative for: vertigo, vision loss, blurred vision, double
vision, difficulty hearing, tinnitus, trouble swallowing,
difficulty producing or understanding speech, focal weakness,
numbness,  bowel incontinence, urinary incontinence or 
retention,
difficulties with gait, incoordination.

.
# Neuro: Patient was admitted for assessment of paresthesias and 
all over intermittent body pains. Patient had considerable 
concerns regarding MS was also able to reproduce symptoms with 
hyprventilation. MRI brain and spine were essentially 
unremarkable. LP showed 1RBC and 1 WBC with normal Pr and Glc. 
Lyme PCR and OCBs pending at time of writing. TSH was normal and 
RAST and IgE pending at time of writing. TSH, ESR and CRP were 
normal. There is no current evidence of MS. ___, there are so 
far no signs on exam, imaging, or CSF studies to suggest a focal 
structural nervous system lesion or 
infectious/inflammatory/demyelinating condition that could 
explain her symptoms.  There is a more prominent disc bulge at 
C5-C6 which indents the ventral surface of the cord, but this 
cannot account for her symptoms. Patient was given a soft 
cervical collar for this. Patient did note once-yearly migraine 
headaches, and some of her symptoms may be related to acephalgic 
migraine. Some of her upper torso symptoms sound most related to 
GERD and not neurological. In the meantime, trial of 
prophylactic migraine treatment with nortriptylline was started 
to see if this improves her symptoms. GERD therapy was was 
changed from famotidine to pantoprazole. Patient will follow-up 
with neurology.
.
.
Pending investigations:
Lyme PCR and OCBs pending at time of writing. 
RAST and IgE pending at time of writing.
 
Medications on Admission:
- ibuprofen 400-800 mg prn pain
- pepcid 20 mg po bid
- claritin D 12hr

day (at bedtime)) as needed for anxiety, insomnia.

Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO once a day.
Disp:*14 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills:*0*
3. nortriptyline 10 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO at 
bedtime.
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
4. loratadine 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H PRN.  
5. soft cervical collar
6. ibuprofen 200 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO every ___ 
hours as needed for pain.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home

Migraine

 
Discharge Condition:

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for evaluation of body tingling and headaches. 
You were evaluated for multiple sclerosis. You had MRI scan of 
head, neck and thoracic spine, all of which didnt show major 
abnormalities and there was no evidence of multiple sclerosis. 
You had diagnostic spinal tap and several MRIs which didnt show 
evidence of MS, though finals reads and a few studies are still 
pending at this time. 

We have started you on a new medication called nortriptiline for 
headache and anxiety as your symptoms could be aggravated by 
anxiety. Please also take ibuprofen 600-800mg by mouth as needed 
every ___ hours. Please follow up with the appointments as 
scheduled. Please take your medications as advised.

burning paresthesias
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Lumbar puncture ___
History of Present Illness:
___ year-old right-handed woman with a
history including pituitary microadenoma who presents with a
three month history of symtoms including headache,
lightheadedness, and burning paresthesias.
.
The patient first began to feel unwell in ___. She
recalls being seated at work when she started to see "squiggly
lines" in both visual fields. About two hours later she
developed a throbbing bifrontal headache that radiated to the
occipital regions. The headache rated ___. There were no
clear
triggers, exacerbating factors, or other associated symptoms.
She has had similar headaches in the past, and attributed the
discomfort to stress.
.
The following week she began to have frequent headaches. She
describes a throbbing discomfort in the bifrontal region that
radiated back to the occipital region. The headaches rated
___ in intensity. There was no clear trigger. There were no
exacerbating factors. The discomfort was associated with
"pressure" across the eyes and forehead. There was no
concomitant nausea, vomiting, phonophobia, photophobia, or
sensorimotor disturbance. Aspirin and tylenol provided relief.
.
Around the same time, she began to develop dizziness. She
characterizes the sensation as "the early buzz with a glass of
wine" or the feeling one has while getting off a boat. She
found
that when she quickly turned her head, it felt as though it took
a moment for her eyes to catch up and adjust. There was no
clear
trigger for the sensation such as moving from a stand to a sit,
although the sensation did tend to occur more frequently when
she
was in the upright position and moving about. There were no
exacerbating factors, alleviating variable, or associated
symptoms. It could last all day.
.
For these symptoms, she presented to her PCP who attributed the
symptoms to a sinus infection. She was prescribed a course of
amoxicillin. The headache resolved within 24 hours. However,
because the dizziness did not resolve, she returned to the PCP.
He prescribed a four-day course of prednisone 40 mg per day.
.
By early ___, she developed a tingling that predominently
affected the left cheek. She presented to an ED where a
non-contrast CT of the head was done. It was reportedly
negative
except for "fluid in the nasal cavity." She googled her
symptoms, however, and found that multiple sclerosis could be an
explanation. She says she became panicked at the thought. That
night, she developed "burning" in a band across the back between
the two shoulders. It did not radiate. There were no
exacerbating factors or associated symptoms other than the
facial
paresthesias and dizziness. She presented to her PCP the next
day; the burning completely resolved following his reassurance.
.
For one week thereafter, her only symptom was the dizziness.
She
followed up with her PCP again, and was reassured. She was then
symptom-free for two-weeks, the timing of which corresponded
with
vacation.
.
Thereafter, the dizziness returned. It became associated with a
pressure across the eyes. The sensation was somewhat relieved by
sudafed.
.
In ___, she developed facial paresthesias again. Now the
abnormal sensations involved the cheek and chin L>R. On ___,
she flew to ___ for vacation. Her face felt tingly and
"inflamed" during the flight. However, throughout the vacation,
she actually felt much better with almost complete resolution of
all symptoms. The facial symptoms returned on the flight home.
.
On ___, she returned to her PCP. He suggested the sinus
infection had returned. He presecribed erythromycin and
prednisone 40 mg x 4 days. However, she became worried that the
therapies were not helping - and that the sinus infection could
not account for all the symptoms. That night she developed
burning that encompassed the entire back. It lasted all night.
She identifies stress as a precipitant. During a visit to a
lake
the next day, the symptom completely resolved.
.
On ___, she developed a sense of sunburn on her back. Her
forearms, L>R began to feel "funny," as did the medial aspect of
her right lower leg. It spontaneously resolved the next day.
.
On ___, both arms started to feel as if they were burning.
The burning progressed over the next day to encompass the neck
and entire torso (back and front) to the level of the waist.
She
further desccribes it as a sense that she is being cut by
razors.
The pain rates ___ at worst. It has been constant with waxing
and waning intensity. It changes location. At night it is most
pronounced in an escutcheon pattern from the chest to the
epigastrium; this pain is worse with lying down and better with
standing and moving around.
.
She has never had any similar symptoms (or ophtho symptoms) in
the past. To address the symptoms, she has tried pepcid,
benadryl, and had her IUD removed. Ibuprofen 800 mg has
provided
some relief.
.
She met with neurologist Dr. ___ on ___ who
coordinated an MRI of the brain and spinal cord to evaluate for
inflammatory, structural, and demyelinating processes. The MRI
of the brain showed no definite focal lesions to suggest a
demyelinating etiology. The MRI of the cervical spine showed
reversal of cervical lordosis and multilevel degenerative
disease, most pronounced from C4-6. Dr. ___
referred her for an allergy evaluation ___ it was thought
she could be be suffering from chronic sinusitis or allergic
rhinitis in addition to a neurologic process. Given an
escalation
in symptoms, it was recommended she be admitted to the neurolgy
service for an expedited evaluation. She is most concerned by
the degree of discomfort and the possibility of multiple
sclerosis.

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE

Flank pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Pt is a ___ with a recent history of L kidney infarction and 
significant L renal artery thrombosis who presented to the ED 
with hematuria and flank pain as a transfer from OSH.

The patient initially presented on ___ at OSH with left flank 
pain and was subsequently found to have a left kidney 
infarction, and started on Lovenox bridge to Coumadin 2.5 mg 
qday.  At the time, echocardiography did not demonstrate a 
thromboembolic source. Patient has had several workups in the 
past for palpitations, but there was also no diagnosis of atrial 
fibrillation or atrial flutter on both 15- and 30-day Holter 
monitors.  

She represented to ___ on ___ with frank painless hematuria 
and subjective fever (only on day of readmission), and at that 
time, the patient was admitted for acute management of left 
renal artery thrombosis, and underwent thrombectomy and stent 
placement.  The patient was discharged, but presented again 12 
hrs later with left flank pain, increased abdominal pain, 
inability to void, and passing only clots. Patient received a 
3-way bladder irrigation which lavaged a considerable number of 
clots prior to transfer to ___.  She was also started on 
Levaquin for concern that the patient might have a comcomitant 
cystitis due to the frank blood or a urinary tract infection.
.
In the ED, the patient VS: 97.4, 86, 120/63, 16, 99% on RA.  
Exam was notable for mild abdominal tenderness without guarding 
or rebound. Labs notable for normal Chem7, WBC 16.6, Hct 32.7, 
___ 45.3, PTT 43.8, and INR 4.5.  UA showed 3 WBC and few 
bacteria. Patient was given 2 mg Zofran, 2 mg Dilaudid, and 5 mg 
Reglan for pain and nausea. 
.  
On the floor, VS: 98.1, 86, 150/88, 20 96% on RA. Patient 
reporting ___ abdominal pain after receiving another 1 mg 
Dilaudid and 0.25 mg Ativan.    
.  
Review of systems:  
(+) Per HPI  
(-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or 
gain. Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or 
congestion. Denied cough, shortness of breath. Denied chest pain 
or tightness, palpitations. Denied nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, 
constipation. No recent change in bowel habits. Denied

Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you ___ 
___.  You were admitted with blood in your urine.  
This is a result of the recent blood clot you had in your 
kidney.  

You were evaluated by urology specialists.  An ultrasound showed 
that you had no more bloody clots in your bladder and normal 
blood flow in your left renal artery and vein. 

The blood in your urine decreased.  However, we expect that the 
blood in your urine will likely continue for at least the next 
two weeks.  The most important thing is that your blood levels 
have remained stable.

We recommend that you follow-up with your primary care physician 
(see appointment below) to have your blood levels checked within 
the next week.  We are also working on having an appointment 
scheduled with a urologist (see below) in case your bleeding 
should continue past two weeks.  

Thank you for letting us participate in your care.  Best wishes 
in your recovery.

Brief Hospital Course:
She was admitted on ___ and was taken to the operating 
room. She underwent coronary artery bypass grafting x 3. Please 
see operative note for full details. She tolerated the procedure 
well and was transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for 
recovery and invasive monitoring. She weaned from sedation, 
awoke neurologically intact and was extubated on the day of 
surgery. She was weaned from Neo gtt, transfused 1PRBC for acute 
blood loss anemia. She was initially A-paced over sinus 
bradycardia out of the OR, then developed rate controlled atrial 
fibrillation. Beta blocker was initiated and she was diuresed 
toward her preoperative weight. Plavix was started instead of 
Brilinta for recent RCA stent.  She remained hemodynamically 
stable and was transferred to the telemetry floor on POD2 for 
further recovery. Once on the step down floor she worked with 
nursing and was evaluated by the physical therapy service for 
assistance with strength and mobility. By the time of discharge 
on POD 4 she was ambulating freely, the wound was healing, and 
pain was controlled with oral analgesics. She was discharged 
home in good condition with appropriate follow up instructions.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital because you had knee pain and 
swelling. You were presumed to have non-septic pre-patellar 
bursitis, in which a small sac of fluid in front of the kneecap 
becomes irritated. You completed the steroids 
(methylprednisolone) that your Primary Care Physician gave you. 
We have given you Tylenol and naproxen to take at home as 
needed. You can continue with ice packs, compression, and 
elevation of the leg.

In addition, we noted you had elevated blood sugars when you 
came in. We checked your hemoglobin A1c level, which is an 
indicator of blood sugars over 3 months, and it was elevated, at 
12.7%. We changed your diabetes drugs by continuing you on your 
home metformin (1000 mg twice a day), increasing your dose of 
glyburide (to 10 mg twice a day), but also by starting you on 
insulin Lantus (15 units at bedtime). You should continue to use 
these medications at home as directed by the diabetes doctor and 
nurse you met in the hospital.

We offer some recommendations on using insulin:
Â Take your insulin consistently.
Â Always check the appearance of your insulin before using it. 
Do not use it if it looks different than it usually does (if 
there are clumps in it, or if it looks cloudy when it should be 
clear).
Â Keep your insulin in a cool, dry place (refrigerator, not 
freezer); keep away from direct light.
Â Inject each insulin dose in a different spot (at least two 
inches away from the site of the last dose).
Â If you have any questions or concerns about your insulin, call 
your healthcare provider.
Â Never skip your insulin unless instructed by your healthcare 
provider.
Â When travelling, keep insulin with you in a carry-on bag.

We offer some recommendations about checking your glucose 
levels:
Â Check your blood sugar every morning before you eat.
Â Bring your glucose meter to your Primary Care and Diabetes 
doctors' appointments.
Â Please call your doctor if you have a blood sugar greater than 
300 for more than 4 hours.
Â Blood sugar less than 70 is too low for most people with 
diabetes; call your doctor if you have a low blood sugar.
Â With low blood sugar you may feel: shaky, sweaty, weak; 
irritable, anxious; very hungry; numbness or tingling around 
your lips; confused or having a sudden mood change.
Â When you feel that your blood sugar may be low, you should 
check your blood sugar with your meter; if you canÂt check your 
blood
sugar right away, treat yourself as if the blood sugar is low.
Â If you have a blood sugar reading below 70, or if you think 
your blood sugar is low but canÂt check it, you should eat 15 
grams of carbohydrates immediately. For example: 3 glucose 
tablets, half a cup of fruit juice or non-diet soda.
Â It takes about 15 minutes to start to feel better. Rest for 15 
minutes. After 15 minutes, if you do not feel better and your 
blood sugar is still not over 70, treat it again with the same 
amount of food.
Â Always carry with you lifesavers or glucose tablets to treat a 
low blood sugar.

It is very important for you to follow up at the ___ on 
___. High blood sugar levels may lead to other health 
problems and can be prevented with good diabetes management.

It was a pleasure to take care of you.

Sincerely,
Your ___ Team

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted to the hospital because you had knee pain and
swelling. You were presumed to have non-septic pre-patellar
bursitis, in which a small sac of fluid in front of the kneecap
becomes irritated. You completed the steroids
(methylprednisolone) that your Primary Care Physician gave you.
We have given you Tylenol and naproxen to take at home as
needed. You can continue with ice packs, compression, and
elevation of the leg.
In addition, we noted you had elevated blood sugars when you
came in. We checked your hemoglobin A1c level, which is an
indicator of blood sugars over 3 months, and it was elevated, at
12.7%. We changed your diabetes drugs by continuing you on your
home metformin (1000 mg twice a day), increasing your dose of
glyburide (to 10 mg twice a day), but also by starting you on
insulin Lantus (15 units at bedtime). You should continue to use
these medications at home as directed by the diabetes doctor and
nurse you met in the hospital.
We offer some recommendations on using insulin:
Â Take your insulin consistently.
Â Always check the appearance of your insulin before using it.
Do not use it if it looks different than it usually does (if
there are clumps in it, or if it looks cloudy when it should be
clear).
Â Keep your insulin in a cool, dry place (refrigerator, not
freezer); keep away from direct light.
Â Inject each insulin dose in a different spot (at least two
inches away from the site of the last dose).
Â If you have any questions or concerns about your insulin, call
your healthcare provider.
Â Never skip your insulin unless instructed by your healthcare
provider.
Â When travelling, keep insulin with you in a carry-on bag.
We offer some recommendations about checking your glucose
levels:
Â Check your blood sugar every morning before you eat.
Â Bring your glucose meter to your Primary Care and Diabetes
doctors' appointments.
Â Please call your doctor if you have a blood sugar greater than
300 for more than 4 hours.
Â Blood sugar less than 70 is too low for most people with
diabetes; call your doctor if you have a low blood sugar.
Â With low blood sugar you may feel: shaky, sweaty, weak;
irritable, anxious; very hungry; numbness or tingling around
your lips; confused or having a sudden mood change.
Â When you feel that your blood sugar may be low, you should
check your blood sugar with your meter; if you canÂt check your
blood
sugar right away, treat yourself as if the blood sugar is low.
Â If you have a blood sugar reading below 70, or if you think
your blood sugar is low but canÂt check it, you should eat 15
grams of carbohydrates immediately. For example: 3 glucose
tablets, half a cup of fruit juice or non-diet soda.
Â It takes about 15 minutes to start to feel better. Rest for 15
minutes. After 15 minutes, if you do not feel better and your
blood sugar is still not over 70, treat it again with the same
amount of food.
Â Always carry with you lifesavers or glucose tablets to treat a
low blood sugar.
It is very important for you to follow up at the ___ on
___. High blood sugar levels may lead to other health
problems and can be prevented with good diabetes management.
It was a pleasure to take care of you.
Sincerely,
Your ___ Team

Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___

Service: PSYCHIATRY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
"I'd like to know what the hell happened, what's going on with 
me, and what to do so it doesn't happen again."
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
Patient reports that he has been feeling depressed for several 
months.  This is in the context of several stressors: his 
ongoing divorce from his wife (which he
initiated), his separation from his 4 children who live with his 
wife), ___ stressors, unhappiness at work, and his concerns 
that his perceived memory loss is actually developing 
Alzheimer's disease, which his mother suffered from.  He began 
treatment with a therapist, Dr. ___ in ___, in 
late ___.  This ___, she suggested he see a 
psychiatrist for treatment of his depression, so he saw Dr. 
___ for one appointment, at which he was 
prescribed Wellbutrin 200mg TID.  He felt that the Wellbutrin 
was not treating his anxiety symptoms appropriately enough 
described below), so he increased the dose on his own, to 
800mg/day and then 1200mg/day, all with only minor relief.

Patient reports that today at work, where he assists in managing 
an ice-skating rink, he began crying at his desk.  He had been 
feeling "spacey," feeling like the sounds of peoples' voices 
were going over his head, and detached.  He also felt "tipsy" 
and "clumsy," and "panicked."  He called his PCP (Dr. ___ 
___ ask what the maximum dose of Wellbutrin daily was, 
and he left a message.  He had called his psychiatrist 3 days 
previously to ask for an urgent appointment, but was unable to 
reach her. Today, he called a list of several ___ 
psychiatrists to schedule an urgent appointment, but was unable 
to reach anybody.

The patient reports feeling "sad," poor sleep with early morning 
wakening, good appetite, normal energy level, and appropriate 
level of interest in every day activities.  He denies 
hopelessness.  He denies SI at this time, but reports that years 
ago (he doesn't remember when), he had thoughts of SI but no 
plan, and he denies any past attempts.  He says that he lives 
with and takes care of an elderly man ___ years old).  He says 
that he has no social supports. Towards the end of the 
interview, he told me "I feel lost...I'm scared," and then he
suddenly became tearful and requested a minute to gather 
himself. He stated that he did not want inpatient treatment, but 
was amenable to a PHP.

After I arranged an intake appointment at ___, I 
returned to speak with the patient.  At this time, the patient 
reported to me that he has been having thoughts of suicide, for 
an uncertain length of time.  He endorsed plan of crashing his 
car, but would make certain that he did not hurt or kill 
anybody.  He says that he did not bring this up before or with 
his psychiatrist or therapist because he did not want the 
attention or to be admitted to the hospital.  He is concerned 
about his job, and how he will be perceived at work.

Brief Hospital Course:
1. Legal: ___
2. Medical: The patient had no medical issues while on Deac-4.

3. Psychiatric: On admission, the patient's wellbutrin was 
discontinued.  After a one day holiday, he was started on celexa 
10mg daily, and was offered seroquel 50mg PRNs for 
agitation/anxiety.  His therapist (Dr. ___ and 
psychiatrist (Dr. ___ were contacted, both of whom 
expressed significant concern regarding the patient's safety.  
They discussed his past endorsements of SI and brief HI directed 
at his wife, of his loneliness, and of their belief that he was 
"extremely high risk" to suicide.  He acknowledged this concern, 
and was agreeable to continued hospital stay.  His celexa was 
increased to 20mg daily and then to 40mg daily.  During one of 
his episodes of heightened anxiety, the patient took seroquel 
PRN and reported that it provided significant, though not 
complete, relief of his symptoms.  He also used seroquel 125 mg 
qhs for sleep with good result.

4. Psychosocial: While in the ___, the patient initially 
expressed frustration and disagreement with his involuntary 
admission.  However, he signed a CV on admission and throughout 
his stay on Deac-4, he was agreeable to continuing his hospital 
stay.  He expressed anger at the SW for confronting him about 
his smile, which seemed incongruent with his reported mood.  He 
underwent psychological testing (a ___ with Dr. ___ and 
did not test as abnormal.  When presented with the results of 
the ___ test, the patient was unhappy that the results 
demonstrated no significant symptoms.  He said that he felt he 
was "sicker than the test showed," and that he would like to 
retake it.  He said that he does not want to be discharged and 
would like to stay inpatient longer.  Per Dr. ___ 
patient was "angry" with him towards the end of the interview.  
On ___, Mr. ___ met with the team and acknowledged that 
prolonging his stay would not likely be helpful to him and that 
he needed to get back out in the world and confront his 
problems.  He was willing to accept follow-up treatment in a 
partial hospital program as a transition from the inpatient 
setting.  

Attending Addendum
During all his stay here we did not find any evidence to suggest 
clear cut, acute imminent suicidality or homicidality, but 
nevertheless he will always remain somewhat of a risk for acute 
depression. We have started him on Celexa and hope that he 
continues it. An after care plan was set up with his 
participation and it is hoped that he will make use of it. There 
was also some evidence that long hospital stays for him could 
actually prolong his return to better functioning by fostering 
regression. He was noticed as becoming dependant on being in the 
hospital and himself felt the same.
 
Medications on Admission:
wellbutrin 200mg TID (patient taking up to 1200mg daily)
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Citalopram 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Quetiapine 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QHS (once a 
day (at bedtime)).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Quetiapine 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO at bedtime: 
Take along with 100 mg qhs tablet for total dose of 125 mg.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Axis I: depression NOS
Axis II: deferred
Axis III: trigger finger
Axis IV: financial stressors, relationship stressors
Axis V: 51

VSS - T 98.2 BP 121/68  HR 66  RR 16  o2 sat 98% RA

wearing casual clothes.  No abnormal movements.  Cooperative 
with the interview.  Good eye contact. Speech - normal rate and 
volume.  Mood -
'Okay.'  Affect - slightly tense, some inappropriate smiles 
TF - linear.  TC - denies SI, denies HI, no evidence of
delusions.  Perception - denies AVH.  I/J - fair/fair.

Please take medications as prescribed.
Please attend outpatient appointments as scheduled.
If you are feeling unsafe or that your condition is worsening, 
call ___ or go to your nearest ___.

complete, relief of his symptoms. He also used seroquel 125 mg
qhs for sleep with good result.
4. Psychosocial: While in the ___, the patient initially
expressed frustration and disagreement with his involuntary
admission. However, he signed a CV on admission and throughout
his stay on Deac-4, he was agreeable to continuing his hospital
stay. He expressed anger at the SW for confronting him about
his smile, which seemed incongruent with his reported mood. He
underwent psychological testing (a ___ with Dr. ___ and
did not test as abnormal. When presented with the results of
the ___ test, the patient was unhappy that the results
demonstrated no significant symptoms. He said that he felt he
was "sicker than the test showed," and that he would like to
retake it. He said that he does not want to be discharged and
would like to stay inpatient longer. Per Dr. ___
patient was "angry" with him towards the end of the interview.
On ___, Mr. ___ met with the team and acknowledged that
prolonging his stay would not likely be helpful to him and that
he needed to get back out in the world and confront his
problems. He was willing to accept follow-up treatment in a
partial hospital program as a transition from the inpatient
setting.
Attending Addendum
During all his stay here we did not find any evidence to suggest
clear cut, acute imminent suicidality or homicidality, but
nevertheless he will always remain somewhat of a risk for acute
depression. We have started him on Celexa and hope that he
continues it. An after care plan was set up with his
participation and it is hoped that he will make use of it. There
was also some evidence that long hospital stays for him could
actually prolong his return to better functioning by fostering
regression. He was noticed as becoming dependant on being in the
hospital and himself felt the same.
Medications on Admission:
wellbutrin 200mg TID (patient taking up to 1200mg daily)
Discharge Medications:
1. Citalopram 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Quetiapine 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QHS (once a
day (at bedtime)).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Quetiapine 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO at bedtime:
Take along with 100 mg qhs tablet for total dose of 125 mg.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Axis I: depression NOS
Axis II: deferred
Axis III: trigger finger
Axis IV: financial stressors, relationship stressors
Axis V: 51
Discharge Condition:
VSS - T 98.2 BP 121/68 HR 66 RR 16 o2 sat 98% RA
MSE- Older AAM, appearing younger than stated age, well groomed,
wearing casual clothes. No abnormal movements. Cooperative
with the interview. Good eye contact. Speech - normal rate and
volume. Mood -
'Okay.' Affect - slightly tense, some inappropriate smiles
TF - linear. TC - denies SI, denies HI, no evidence of
delusions. Perception - denies AVH. I/J - fair/fair.
Discharge Instructions:
Please take medications as prescribed.
Please attend outpatient appointments as scheduled.
If you are feeling unsafe or that your condition is worsening,
call ___ or go to your nearest ___.
Followup Instructions:
___

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:

___- Laparoscopic cholecystectomy 

 
History of Present Illness:
HPI(4): Ms. ___ is a ___ female with PMH of
hypertension and recently diagnosed gallstones who presents with
severe epigastric abdominal pain with associated nausea and
vomiting.

The patient reports she first developed abdominal pain about 1
month prior to admission. Saw PCP had negative ___ scan (had
associated SOB) and ultimately had blood work and ultrasound 
___
which showed gallstones. She was scheduled for cholecystectomy 
on
___. 

Since that time, the patient has been having ongoing abdominal
pain, poor po intake.  She reports intermittent abdominal pain
over the past month. She will have a few good days and then her
pain will return.  When her pain is present is about a ___ in
severity located in the epigastrium.  This past week the patient
has less pain for a few days. She subsequently had a steak with
___ fries and the next day and had ___ chop ___. She
then developed worsening ___ abdominal pain. The pain now
radiates to her back. She had associated nausea with vomiting 
she
attributes the vomiting to pain.  She reports the pain is worse
with standing and moving and improves when she lays still. She
has not taken any medication to help manage her pain.  Yesterday
given her severe pain with nausea and vomiting she presented to
the emergency department at ___ and was transferred to ___.

Currently the patient reports her pain is a ___ in severity. It
is worse with moving. She reports associated dark urine which
started ___.  She has not noticed any change to her bowel
habits other than she is having less frequent bowel movements.

but
no other shortness of breath.  Denies chest pain.  She also
decides denies fever or chills. She reports rare alcohol use.

and symmetric bilaterally in all limbs

speech fluent, moves all limbs, sensation to light touch grossly

CV: RRR

laparoscopic incisions well approximated with dermabond. 

 
Pertinent Results:

Labs at ___: 
___ 05:20AM BLOOD WBC: 12.8* RBC: 5.37* Hgb: 15.5 Hct: 
45.2* MCV: 84 MCH: 28.9 MCHC: 34.3 RDW: 13.4 RDWSD: 41.___ 
___ 05:20AM BLOOD ALT: 286* AST: 143* AlkPhos: 269* 
TotBili: 1.3

RUQ ultrasound: ___
IMPRESSION: 
1. Echogenic liver consistent with steatosis. Other forms of 
liver disease including steatohepatitis, hepatic fibrosis, or 
cirrhosis cannot be excluded  on the basis of this examination. 
2. Cholelithiasis without evidence of acute cholecystitis. 

___ 05:44AM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-30* 
Glucose-NEG Ketone-NEG Bilirub-SM* Urobiln-2* pH-5.5 Leuks-NEG
___ 05:44AM URINE RBC-3* WBC-3 Bacteri-FEW* Yeast-NONE 
Epi-5

___ 5:44 am URINE
                            **FINAL REPORT ___
   URINE CULTURE (Final ___: 
      MIXED BACTERIAL FLORA ( >= 3 COLONY TYPES), CONSISTENT 
WITH SKIN
      AND/OR GENITAL CONTAMINATION. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with history of hypertension 
and biliary colic who presents with abdominal pain, N/V and 
found to have gallstone pancreatitis. On admission lipase was 
elevated at ___ and ultrasound showed cholelithiasis. The 
patient was admitted to the Medical service for ERCP and 
management of gallstone pancreatitis. On ___ the patient 
underwent ERCP with sphincterotomy. Post procedure labs trended 
down. Informed consent was obtained and she was taken the 
operating room with the Acute Care Surgery Service for 
definitive management. Please see operative report for details. 
She tolerated the procedure well and was admitted to the Acute 
Care Surgery Service post operatively.

Pain was well controlled. Diet was progressively advanced as 
tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. The patient 
voided without problem. During this hospitalization, the patient 
ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory 
toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively participated in 
the plan of care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged home without services. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires 
futher investigation.
1. Losartan Potassium 25 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild/Fever  
2.  Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY:PRN Constipation - Second 
Line  
3.  Losartan Potassium 25 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1.  Gallstone pancreatitis.
2.  Chronic cholecystitis.
3.  Obesity, BMI equals 47.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery Service with 
abdominal pain and found to have gallstones in your gallbladder 
blocking the flow of bile. You underwent endoscopy to clear the 
blockage and then you were taken to the operating room and had 
your gallbladder removed laparoscopically. 

You are now doing better, tolerating a regular diet, and pain is 
well controlled. You are now ready to be discharged to home with 
the following discharge instructions:

ACTIVITY:
 
o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
o You may climb stairs. 
o  You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
o  Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
o  You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
o  You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
o  You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
You might feel somewhat depressed.
o  You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages 
called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
is normal.
o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
please call your surgeon.
o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text: Name: ___ Unit No: ___ Admission Date: ___ Discharge Date: ___ Date of Birth: ___ Sex: F Service: MEDICINE Allergies: Pentothal Attending: ___. Chief Complaint: Back pain Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: Cardiac catheterization with BMS to LCx History of Present Illness: This is an ___ y.o. female without much past medical history who presents as a code-STEMI. At about 10:00 am this morning she was sitting down in a chair when she had sudden tight feeling back pain. She describees this pain as being in the middle of her back between her shoulder blades and radiating in between them. There was no radiation to the neck or left arm. She denies any frank dyspnea thought reports she was breathing "shallowly." She also reports profuse diaphoresis and some nausea though she did not vomit. She called a friend who urged her to call EMS, which she did. They arrived and field EKG's showed ST depressions in the precordial leads consistent with posterior STEMI. Thus, she was brought straight to ___ for intervention. Of note she did receive NTG in the field with minimal improvement in her symptoms. . In the ED initial vitals were HR 69, BP 157/80, RR 21, O2 Sat 99% on RA. She was continuing to have back pain of ___. After receiving heparin, ASA, and BB she was taken to the cath lab and received BMS to a totally occluded LCx. During the catheterization she did have chest pain briefly but this resolved and she was pain free after the procedure. Post procedure EKG's showed resolution of her ST depressions in the precordial leads. . On arrival to the floor she is breathing comfortably on 2 L by NC. She denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. . Cardiac Review of systems is notable for two pillow orthopnea that has been going on for years. She denies PND. No syncope or presyncope. She has had significant lower extremity edema with skin changes for years. This does not appear to be worsening recently. The patient does not have dyspnea on exertion but ambulates minimally between the four rooms of her apartment at baseline. She has been housebound for some time. She has never had chest pain or known CAD in the past. . REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: No fevers, chills, night sweats. The patient has not had any recent weight changes. No chronic cough or shortness of breath. No abdominal pain or nausea, vomiting, diarrhea. No melena or hematochezia. No history of easy bleeding or bruising. Past Medical History: She denies any history of CAD and reports having had lipids checked in the past that were "good". She has never been diagnosed with hypertension. Past medical history somewhat difficult to assess given patient has not seen a doctor in some years secondary to her obesity and poor mobility. Other Past Medical History: -OSA -Asthma (no chronic treatment) -History of "shocks" (sounds like TIA had dysarthria for < 1 hour *1) -TKR on left side -Partial colon resection for two cancerous polyps Social History: ___ Family History: Notable for father dying when when was in her ___ secondary to cancer. Multiple cancers in her father's family. Maternal side of family has history notable for longevity. No family history of premature CAD or sudden death. Physical Exam: VS: Afebrile, HR 74, RR 20, BP 134/65, O2 Sat 93% on RA Gen: Obese elderly female laying in bed in NAD HEENT: No appreciable JVD CV: RRR, no M/R/G appreciated, distant heart sounds Pulm: CTAB Abdomen: Obese, Soft, NT, ND, BS+, periumbilical hernia (nontender), old scar below umbilicus from colon resection Extremity: Demarcated area of erythema on R antecubital fossa at site of prior IV with small dried pus at venous puncture site, slightly warm, not indurated, no cords. Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___

DVT/occulsion of IVC filter 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
IVC revascularization and thrombolysis with alteplase and U/S 
lysis

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with pmh of HTN, lupus, chronic/recurrent DVT s/p IVC 
filter, presents for revascularization/thrombolysis of chronic 
occlusive IVC filter thrombus.  

Pt was first diagnosed with LLE DVT approx ___ yrs ago.  At this 
time, he was initiated on coumadin therapy.  Despite coumadin 
tx, the clot migrated from the left leg up to the IVC.  As such, 
an IVC filter was placed at ___ and his systemic 
anticoagulation was discontinued.  About one year after d/c 
coumadin, he developed another DVT in his R leg.  He was 
referred to a hematologist in ___, Dr. ___ restarted 
his coumadin (lifelong therapy) and diagnosed him with lupus.  
Pt said the only manifestation of lupus has been coagulation 
d/o, which suggests he only has antiphospholipid antibody 
syndrome and not SLE.  His lupus anticoagulants ___, ACL-ab 
and beta-2 glycoprotein 2) are unknown.   

Pt has been bothered by frequent ___ pain and chronic venous 
stasis.  He wears compression stockings, which help, but as soon 
as he takes them off the edema re-accumulates.  His pain is 
mostly felt in the calves R>L.  Pain is not exertional and 
generally occurs when he is sitting or standing.  He reports 
that he walks about 5mi/day at work and tolerates this well.  

Pt reports that he was fed up with having chronic DVTs and found 
Dr. ___ on ___.  

In ___ repeat ___ dopplers showed chronic nonobstructive 
thrombus in right common femoral and the popliteal veins and 
left common and superficial femoral, deep femoral and popliteal 
veins.  A CT scan showed occlusion of IVC below the filter.  

He was referred to Dr. ___ thrombolysis and 
revascularization procedure.  

On arrival to the floor, patient is AOx3, in NAD and does not 
have any focal neurological deficits.    
 
ROS: pt denies chest pain or sob, no DOE, orthopnea or PND.  He 
denies palpitations.  Reports occassional dizzy spell but no 
syncope. Denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, pulmonary 
embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint 
pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. denies 
recent fevers, chills or rigors.  denies exertional ___ pain.  No 
malar rash or levido reticularis.  All of the other review of 
systems were negative.  
 
Past Medical History:
1. Hypertension
2. Hyperlipidemia
3. Bilateral ___ DVT's s/p IVC filter placement at ___ 
approximately ___ years ago.  
4. Diagnosis of lupus per patient report (only manifested by 
venous clots, so likely actually APS)
5. Epilepsy on Dilantin. Has not had a seizure in ___ years 
ago
6. ? cervical disc disease

___

Mother had DVT after hysterectomy.

___ Cath Report:
BRIEF HISTORY:   ___ year old male with chronic bilateral ___ DVTs 
and IVC 
obstruction, referred for possible thrombolysis. 
  
INDICATIONS FOR CATHETERIZATION:   
IVC thrombus 
  
PROCEDURE:      
Peripheral Catheter placement was performed. 
Peripheral Catheter placement was performed. 
Peripheral Imaging was performed. 
Peripheral Lysis/thrombectomy was performed. 
Peripheral Lysis/thrombectomy was performed. 
 
 
 
 
  
**___ RESULTS 
              
  
___ COMMENTS: Using micropuncture needle kit and ultrasound 
guidance, 
___ sheaths were placed in bilateral femoral veins. An angled 
glide wire 
was used to direct through the chronic thrombus past the IVC 
filter. 
Powered injector venograms showed heavy thrombus in bilateral 
iliac/femoral veins and occlusion of IVC upto the IVC filter 
with 
multiple collaterals. EKOS catheters were advanced over the 
0.034 inch 
wires, through the IVC thrombus and U/S faciliated thrombolysis 
initiated, using alteplase. ___ sheath were sutured in place. 
Patient 
was transfered to the CCU for ongoing treatment. 
  
 
  
TECHNICAL FACTORS:  
Total time (Lidocaine to test complete) = 1 hour 48 minutes.  
Arterial time = 1 hour 46 minutes.  
Fluoro time = 27.8 minutes. 
Effective Equivalent Dose Index (mGy) = 1331 mGy. 
Contrast injected:  
          Non-ionic low osmolar (isovue, optiray...), vol 94 ml 
Premedications:  
          Midazolam 1 mg IV 
          Fentanyl 50 mcg IV 
Anesthesia:  
          1% Lidocaine subq.  
Anticoagulation:  
          Heparin 6000 units IV 
Cardiac Cath Supplies Used: 
          .035IN TERUMO, ANGLED STIFF 260CM GLIDEWIRE 
          .035IN ___, SUPRA CORE 300CM 
          .035IN ___, SUPRA CORE 300CM 
          ___ COOK, ___ 0 45CM 
          - ALLEGIANCE, CUSTOM STERILE PACK 
          - MERIT, LEFT HEART KIT 
          ___ TERUMO, NTA 65CM GLIDECATHETER 
          ___ COOK, MICROPUNCTURE INTRODUCER SET 
          ___ COOK, MICROPUNCTURE INTRODUCER SET 
          .035IN TERUMO, ANGLED 180CM GLIDEWIRE 
          30CM EKOS, EKOSONIC 106CM 
          18CM EKOS, EKOSONIC 106CM 
  
  
COMMENTS:      
1. Chronic thrombotic occlusion of the IVC at the site (and 
below) of 
the previously placed IVC filter. The caliber of IVC is severely 

diminshed and filter compressed. 
2. Bilateral iliac, femoral vein thrombi 
3. Placement of EKOS catheters bilateral iliac veins and IVC for 
U/S 
facilitated thrombolysis 
4. ___ venous sheaths sutured in place 
  
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:     
1. Ongoing EKOS Rx in CCU 
2. Continue heparin and alteplase 
3. Restudy in AM 

___ Cath Report:
BRIEF HISTORY:   ___ year old male with EKOS facilitated 
thromblysis of 
IVC, now for relook venography 
  
INDICATIONS FOR CATHETERIZATION:   
Venous thrombosis 
  
PROCEDURE:      
Peripheral Imaging was performed. 
Peripheral PTA was performed. 
Peripheral Lysis/thrombectomy was performed. 
Peripheral Lysis/thrombectomy was performed. 
 
 
 
 
  
**PTCA RESULTS 
              
  
PTCA COMMENTS:  Using sterile preparation, A J wire was advanced 
through 
the EKOS catheter, after clipping 10 cm proximal to insertion in 
the 
venous sheath. Catheters were then removed and sheaths 
exchanged. An 
___ 0 ___ sheath was inserted through the venous sheath for 
venograms. 
Post lysis, bilateral iliac and IVC angio showed persistent 
occlusion 
with slight improvement in iliac veins. We then decided to 
perform 
angioplasty. A 3.0 X 120mm admiral followed by a 4.0 X 120mm 
admiral OTW 
balloon was used for angioplasty of IVC, bilateral iliac/femoral 
veins. 
This improved flow slightly and established flow from the right 
iliac 
vein through the IVC, past the filter. Procedure was then 
finished and 
sheaths removal manually. 
  
 
  
TECHNICAL FACTORS:  
Total time (Lidocaine to test complete) = 0 hour40 minutes.  
Arterial time = 0 hour40 minutes.

          4.0MM EV3, ADMIRAL 120MM 
          - ___, ___ 0 45CM 
          - ALLEGIANCE, CUSTOM STERILE PACK 
          - ___, PRIORITY PACK ___ 
  
  
COMMENTS:      
1. Partial success after EKOS facilitated thrombolysis with 
recanalized 
of chronically occlusive IVC thrombus 
2. PTA of IVC, bilateral iliac/femoral veins

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ underwent typical preoperative testing and was brought 
to the Operating Room on ___ where the patient underwent 
Coronary artery bypass grafting x ___, Maze, 
Ligation of Left atrial appendage.  Overall the patient 
tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was 
transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and 
invasive monitoring.  
POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and 
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact 
and hemodynamically stable.  Beta blocker was initiated and the 
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  On 
POD 2, he had EKG changes and TTE was checked showing mild basal 
inferior wall hypokinesis, but he remained hemodynamically 
stable.  He was transferred to the telemetry floor for further 
recovery.  Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued 
without complication.  He resumed his home Pradaxa for Afib 
after wires were removed.  He was evaluated by the Physical 
Therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility.  By 
the time of discharge on POD 5 the patient was ambulating 
freely, the wound was healing and pain was controlled with oral 
analgesics.  The patient was discharged to home in good 
condition with appropriate follow up instructions.
