Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ underwent typical preoperative testing and was brought
to the Operating Room on ___ where the patient underwent
Coronary artery bypass grafting x ___, Maze,
Ligation of Left atrial appendage. Overall the patient
tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was
transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and
invasive monitoring.
POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and
breathing comfortably. The patient was neurologically intact
and hemodynamically stable. Beta blocker was initiated and the
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight. On
POD 2, he had EKG changes and TTE was checked showing mild basal
inferior wall hypokinesis, but he remained hemodynamically
stable. He was transferred to the telemetry floor for further
recovery. Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued
without complication. He resumed his home Pradaxa for Afib
after wires were removed. He was evaluated by the Physical
Therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility. By
the time of discharge on POD 5 the patient was ambulating
freely, the wound was healing and pain was controlled with oral
analgesics. The patient was discharged to home in good
condition with appropriate follow up instructions.

History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ year old right handed woman, who is 3 months
postpartum, and presents with dizziness, blurry vision, and left
sided numbness and weakness. She has had 2 weeks of dizziness 
and
blurry vision. With the dizziness her vision gets blurry. Denies
vision blackouts or black spots in vision. The dizziness comes
and goes, randomly without clear triggers and lasts for around 
10
seconds. She needs to hold onto something around her for fear 
she
will fall. It is a spinning sensation and she gets it up to 4
times per day. 

She has had a headache and left sided numbness and weakness for
the past 3 days. The headache is different from her typical
migraine headaches. The pain is in the forehead and wraps around
the back and top of the head as well. It is pounding and is 
worse
at night when laying down and can be ___ in severity. She
vomited once today at noon. 

She feels numbness in the left leg side in the leg. At night she
also gets the numbness in her left arm as well. There is
associated muscle cramps sometimes as well. Lately, when getting
up to feed her baby, she feels the left leg has no strength. 

 
Review of Systems: Patient endorses chills, left leg cramping,
and night sweats. She denies, loss of vision, diplopia,
dysarthria, dysphagia, difficulties producing or comprehending
speech. Denies cough, shortness of breath.  Denies chest pain or
palpitations.  Denies diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. 
No recent change in bowel or bladder habits.  No dysuria. Denies
rash.

CT head
No acute intracranial process.

EKG
Sinus bradycardia. Normal tracing. Compared to the previous 
tracing  
of ___ no diagnostic interim change. 

MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST; MRA BRAIN W/O CONTRAST; MRV HEAD W/O 
CONTRAST; -MRA NECK W&W/O CONTRAST
1. No evidence of dural venous sinus thrombosis. 
2. Essentially unremarkable MRA of the head allowing for motion 
artifact. 
3. Normal MRA of the neck. 
4. Nonspecific left frontoparietal white matter lesions.  
Differential 
diagnosis is broad and includes sequela of chronic migraines, 
prior trauma, 
demyelinating, infectious, and inflammatory etiologies. 
5. The adenoids are prominent, likely reactive in nature.  
Correlation is 
recommended. 
  
RECOMMENDATION(S):  Point 5:  The adenoids are prominent, and 
may be reactive 
in nature.  If clinically indicated, direct visualization may 
yield additional 
formation. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The morning after presentation, Ms. ___ reported attenuated 
numbness of tingling of the left arm and face. She had extensive 
give-way weakness of the
left arm which was greatly attenuated with contralateral
distraction. The face was symmetric and the leg strong. Both
basic and cortical sensory tests of the left side were normal.

Ms. ___ laboratory work-up including the following: Her CBC 
and BMP were normal. Her LFTs were normal. Her trop was normal. 
Her A1c was 5.1, and her lipid panel was pending at the time of 
discharge. TSHw as 4.1. Serum tox panel was neg. 

Her EKG revealed sinus bradycardia unchanged from ___. 
Her CT head and her MRI/A head and neck and MRV head did not 
demonstrate any acute intracranial process. The final reads on 
the CT and MRI were pending at the time of discharge.

Her presentationw was determined to be due to musculoskeletal 
issues related to postural changes during breastfeeding. 
Demyelinating disease could not be ruled out. Given her history 
of migraine, a complex migraine was on the differential but 
would be unlikely to produce a sustained left-sided deficit and 
with persistent symptoms after headache resolution. It is also 
possible that she was elaborating on resolved symptoms of 
complex migraine so that she could be taken seriously. Seizure 
unlikely to produced sustained symptoms. Stroke/TIA were thought 
to be unlikely.

Given the absence of neurological exam abnormalities, she was 
discharged home with plan for outpatient cervical spine MRI to 
evaluate for demyelination.

Transitional issues:
1. ___ need direct visualization of adenoids
2. Lipid panel
3. Final read on MRI describes nonspecific left frontoparietal 
white matter lesions; has follow-up in neurology clinic and will 
require further work-up to rule out demyelinating disease
4. Will need outpatient MRI cervical spine with and without 
contrast to evaluate for demyelinating lesions

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Paresthesia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted for evaluation of your 3 days of left sided 
weakness and tingling. Your examination and imaging did not 
reveal any evidence of stroke or inflammation, which is 
reassuring. You will need to continue the work-up once you leave 
the hospital. We have ordered an MRI of your cervical (upper) 
spine to see if this might contribute to your weakness. It's 
also possible that your neck pain and numbness may be due to 
breastfeeding and holding your newborn. You should make sure to 
take breaks, as needed, and also switch arms when holding the 
baby if one arm feels tired. 

Please follow up as scheduled below and call or come back in if 
you have any new/worsening symptoms.

It was a pleasure meeting you!
Your ___ Neurology Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
The morning after presentation, Ms. ___ reported attenuated
numbness of tingling of the left arm and face. She had extensive
give-way weakness of the
left arm which was greatly attenuated with contralateral
distraction. The face was symmetric and the leg strong. Both
basic and cortical sensory tests of the left side were normal.
Ms. ___ laboratory work-up including the following: Her CBC
and BMP were normal. Her LFTs were normal. Her trop was normal.
Her A1c was 5.1, and her lipid panel was pending at the time of
discharge. TSHw as 4.1. Serum tox panel was neg.
Her EKG revealed sinus bradycardia unchanged from ___.
Her CT head and her MRI/A head and neck and MRV head did not
demonstrate any acute intracranial process. The final reads on
the CT and MRI were pending at the time of discharge.
Her presentationw was determined to be due to musculoskeletal
issues related to postural changes during breastfeeding.
Demyelinating disease could not be ruled out. Given her history
of migraine, a complex migraine was on the differential but
would be unlikely to produce a sustained left-sided deficit and
with persistent symptoms after headache resolution. It is also
possible that she was elaborating on resolved symptoms of
complex migraine so that she could be taken seriously. Seizure
unlikely to produced sustained symptoms. Stroke/TIA were thought
to be unlikely.
Given the absence of neurological exam abnormalities, she was
discharged home with plan for outpatient cervical spine MRI to
evaluate for demyelination.
Transitional issues:
1. ___ need direct visualization of adenoids
2. Lipid panel
3. Final read on MRI describes nonspecific left frontoparietal
white matter lesions; has follow-up in neurology clinic and will
require further work-up to rule out demyelinating disease
4. Will need outpatient MRI cervical spine with and without
contrast to evaluate for demyelinating lesions

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted for evaluation of your 3 days of left sided
weakness and tingling. Your examination and imaging did not
reveal any evidence of stroke or inflammation, which is
reassuring. You will need to continue the work-up once you leave
the hospital. We have ordered an MRI of your cervical (upper)
spine to see if this might contribute to your weakness. It's
also possible that your neck pain and numbness may be due to
breastfeeding and holding your newborn. You should make sure to
take breaks, as needed, and also switch arms when holding the
baby if one arm feels tired.
Please follow up as scheduled below and call or come back in if
you have any new/worsening symptoms.
It was a pleasure meeting you!
Your ___ Neurology Team

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___ yo female who presented with sub-acute course of 
fevers, dyspnea, dry cough, and malaise.  
.  
#Community-acquired pneumonia - Cough and fatigue, leukocytosis, 
and chest xray findings suggested pneumonia.  Patient has some 
risk for resistent bacteria given that she works at a rehab 
facility but she has no other risk factors so will require 
treatment only for CAP.  The patient had a CTA chest performed 
to rule out thromboembolic disease.  No venous thromboembolism 
was noted, but it did show a left lower lobe pneumonia with an 
initial read of possible empyema.  Further radiologic review 
suggested this was not the case, but the patient remained 
hospitalized for two nights for monitoring.  She did have a 
moderate amount of pleuritic and musculoskeletal pain that was 
managed with scheduled tylenol.  Cough suppressants were given 
with good effect.  The patient slowly improved clinically, 
leukocytosis resolved, and the patient was discharged two days 
after admission.  She was initially treated with levofloxacin 
during her course, but her insurance does not cover this 
antibiotic, so she was discharged with a 7 day course of 
azithromycin and cefpodoxime.  She will likely need follow up 
imaging to ensure clearance and if still positive or poor 
response to treatment may need repeat CT to ensure no empyema.
She was maintained on influenza precautions, as the results of 
her nasal swab were pending throughout her course.  She will 
wear a mask at home while symptomatic until instructed 
otherwise.
.  
#. Pleuritic chest pain- PE already ruled out as above, unlikely 
cardiac given negative enzymes and EKG and most likely her PNA 
is causing pleurisy.  
.  
#. HTN: Atenolol was continued, patient was normotensive.  
.  
#. Anemia/Fatigue: This seems to be a chronic problem for her 
likely exacerbated by her new infection.  Anemia work up did not 
reveal overt iron-deficiency anemia.  Guaiac was negative.  TSH 
mildly elevated at 4.5.  Patient will discuss further evaluation 
with her PCP.  It was thought that atenolol, which was recently 
started, may have been contributory.
.
#. CODE: Full

with good effect. The patient slowly improved clinically,
leukocytosis resolved, and the patient was discharged two days
after admission. She was initially treated with levofloxacin
during her course, but her insurance does not cover this
antibiotic, so she was discharged with a 7 day course of
azithromycin and cefpodoxime. She will likely need follow up
imaging to ensure clearance and if still positive or poor
response to treatment may need repeat CT to ensure no empyema.
She was maintained on influenza precautions, as the results of
her nasal swab were pending throughout her course. She will
wear a mask at home while symptomatic until instructed
otherwise.
.
#. Pleuritic chest pain- PE already ruled out as above, unlikely
cardiac given negative enzymes and EKG and most likely her PNA
is causing pleurisy.
.
#. HTN: Atenolol was continued, patient was normotensive.
.
#. Anemia/Fatigue: This seems to be a chronic problem for her
likely exacerbated by her new infection. Anemia work up did not
reveal overt iron-deficiency anemia. Guaiac was negative. TSH
mildly elevated at 4.5. Patient will discuss further evaluation
with her PCP. It was thought that atenolol, which was recently
started, may have been contributory.
.
#. CODE: Full

(started today)

sublingually q 5 minutes x 3 as needed for chest pain Call ___
if
pain not relieved after 3 NTG tabs
SIMVASTATIN - 20 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day
.

ASPIRIN - (OTC) - 81 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day

mg (1,500 mg)-200 unit Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth twice a day
NAPROXEN SODIUM [ALEVE] - (OTC) - 220 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by
mouth once a day as needed for pain

(every 6 hours) as needed for cough.

(Daily).

Name:  ___             Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
chest pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
cardiac catherization ___

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with strong fam history of 
heart disease who presents with chest pain. He had acute onset 
of chest pain while baking gingerbread last night. The pain went 
across his chest from one shoulder to the other and down his 
left arm, as well as radiating to the back. He was also 
diaphoretic and lightheaded, but had no nausea or vomiting. He 
was not short of breath at the time, but did become short of 
breath at the hospital later on. Pain lasted ___ hours total and 
was constant. He endorses similar chest pain before on exertion, 
but much less severe and self-limited. Patient is mostly 
sedentary, but denies any SOB with activity, no orthopnea/PND, 
no ___ edema.   
.  
He initially presented to an OSH where troponin I was 0.03 and 
CTA was concerning for aortic dissection. He received 1L IVF, 
aspirin 325 mg, nitro paste 1 inch, nitro gtt, and morphine 4 mg 
IV. He was transfered to ___ for further management.  
.  
In the ___ ED, initial VS were: HR 58, BP 116/72, RR 18, 98% 
on 6L NC. Cardiac surgery and radiology reviewed the OSH images 
and felt that the patient was not having an aortic dissection. 
Cardiology was consulted due to concern for STEMI, but repeat 
troponin was only 0.05. He was given 2L NS, nitro paste, 
morphine 2 mg IV x 2, heparin 5000 unit bolus and started on a 
heparin drip. He was guaiac negative on rectal exam. Vitals on 
transfer were Pain 0, BP 116/60, HR 67, R 22, 95% 3L.  
.  
On return to floor after cath and PCI, the patient was chest 
pain free, no SOB, no palpitations. 
 
Past Medical History:
Herniated disc in the low back  
s/p arthroscopic surgery on the left knee 
does not have PCP and has not seen physician in ___ years
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father - MI in ___  
Mother - arrhythmia?  
Brother - died at ___ of a cardiomyopathy  
Brother - age ___, s/p stent for CAD 
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: T: 98.9  BP: 115/91  P: 77  R: 20   O2: 93% RA  
General: Morbidly obese, alert, oriented, no acute distress  
HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear  
Neck: supple, JVP not visible due to obesity, no LAD  
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, 
ronchi  
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs 
appreciated.  
Abdomen: soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present, no rebound 
tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly  
Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or 
edema  
Neuro: CNII-XII grossly intact. 
 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:

17.6 >---< 354
     44.3
NEUTS-73.9* ___ MONOS-3.7 EOS-0.6 BASOS-1.2
.
137 | 105 | ___  / 126
4.7 | 22  | 0.8 \
.
___ PTT-27.9 ___
.
Cardiac biomarkers:
___ 06:20PM   CK(CPK)-206*, CK-MB-10 MB INDX-4.9, 
cTropnT-0.05*
___ 11:55PM   CK(CPK)-709*, CK-MB-94* MB INDX-13.3* 
cTropnT-0.36*
___ 05:45AM   CK(CPK)-1210*, CK-MB-173* MB Indx-14.3* 
cTropnT-1.87*
___ 09:30AM   CK 1122, cTropnT-2.10*
.

ALT-40 AST-110* CK(CPK)-1122* AlkPhos-62 Amylase-45 TotBili-0.4
.
%HbA1c-6.7*
Triglyc-229* HDL-25 CHOL/HD-9.0 LDLcalc-155*
.
UA
URINE  BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-25 GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG 
BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-6.5 LEUK-NEG
___ BACTERIA-OCC YEAST-NONE EPI-0
.
EKG:  
___ - SR at 86, STE III, STD I and avL  
___ - SR at 90, STD I, aVL, V1, poor R wave progression  

___ - SR at 89, ?STE III; STD in I, aVL, ___ 18:14 - SR at 57, STE in aVR?, STD in ___ 18:33 - SR at 50, 1mm STD V3 and ___ 19:27 - SR at 58, no ST changes  
___ - SR at 72, 1mm STE in III  
___ - SR at 69, 1mm STE III, aVF; STD in aVL 
.
IMAGING:
CXR: No definite acute process. 
.
CT C/A/P
1. No evidence of aortic dissection. 
2. Significant hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Please 
correlate 
clinically. 
3. Numerous subcentimeter pulmonary nodules, and equivocal 
centrilobular 
ground-glass opacity in the right upper lobe raises possibility 
of the 
respiratory bronchiolitis/DIP spectrum of disease related to 
smoking. Followup high-resolution chest CT recommended in 3 - 6 
months. Findings were posted to the ED dashboard, and discussed 
with Dr. ___ at that time. 
.
CARDIAC CATH
1. Selective coronary angiography in this left dominant system 
demonstrated two vessel disease. The LMCA had mild plaquing 
throughout. 
The LAD had a proximal 70% stenosis, a mid vessel 60% stenosis 
and a 
distal vessel 70% stenosis. The Cx was a large vessel with a 
subtotal 
occlusion in the distal portion of the vessel after the takeoff 
of OM2. 
The RCA was a small non-dominant vessel with no angiographically 

apparent disease. 
2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed elevated left sided 
filling 
pressures with an LVEDP of 18 mmHg. The central aortic pressure 
was 134/ 
80 mmHg. There was no transaortic valve gradient on pullback of 
the 
catheter from the LV to the aorta. 
.
TTE:
The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. 
There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal 
cavity size and global systolic function (LVEF>55%). Due to 
suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality 
cannot be fully excluded. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, 
ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets 
(?#) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion. 
There is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is 
seen. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. There 
is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is 
seen. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a 
fat pad. 
.
CXR (PRE-OP)- no acute abnormalities
 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old male who presents with acute onset of 
chest pain and EKG/cardiac biomarkers c/w STEMI.  
.  
# Chest pain, STEMI - Patient with multiple cardiac risk 
factors: strong family history, smoking, obesity, and story 
concerning for ACS. Patient had been initially transferred for 
possible aortic dissection based on OSH CTA. However his CTA was 
reviewed by cardiac surgery and radiology and felt not to 
represent dissection. 
EKG showed ST elevations in the inferior leads. Initial cardiac 
biomarkers were minimally elevated (0.03 at OSH and 0.05 at 
___ ED) so patient was admitted to cards service for cath in 
AM. He received ASA, Plavix, statin, nitro paste paste, 
morphine, IVF and was started on heparin gtt. Chest pain 
resolved and did not recur overnight. Cardiac cath on ___ 
revealed left dominance and distal L Circ subocclusive disease, 
and DES was placed there. There was also diffuse 60-70% LAD 
disease, which was not amenable to PCI. Patient is candidate for 
endoscopic LIMA to LAD, and he was evaluated by cardiac surgery. 
Pre-op evaluation was done (CXR, anesthesia consent) and he will 
follow up with Dr. ___. 
Post-cath EKGs showed improvement of ST elevations and cardiac 
biomarkers began to trend down by ___ AM. Patient was started 
on metoprolol and lisinopril, which should be titrated as 
outpatient. 
Patient was evaluated for risk factors including DM (HbA1c 6.8) 
and hyperlipidemia (chol 226, HDL 25, calcLDL 155, ___ 229). 
Patient will be seen at ___ to evaluate for new diagnosis of 
diabetes. 
.
.  
# Pump - Patient had no signs or symptoms of congestive heart 
failure. TTE showed globally normal function with LVEF 55%, but 
could not rule out focal wall motion abnormality completely 
given suboptimal study. Patient started on ACEi. 
.  
# Rhythm - Patient had 11 beat run NSVT prior to cath, and 9 
beat NSVT at 18:00 ___ which was asymptomatic and occurred 
before beta-blocker had been given. After starting beta-blocker, 
patient had no further events on telemetry for 36 hours.
.  
# Leukocytosis - Likely secondary to STEMI. No evidence of UTI. 
CT chest abnormal, but no definitive PNA and patient afebrile 
and without significant respiratory symptoms. CXR wnl. WBC 
trending down at discharge. 
.  
# Pulmonary nodules, lymphadenopathy - Patient had abnormal 
chest CT with hilar and mediastinal LAD, and multiple pulmonary 
nodules. He will need outpatient follow-up in ___ months with 
repeat high res chest CT.
.
#. Transaminitis: AST elevated c/w muscular release ___ STEMI. 
Trending down at discharge. 
.
Patient was given information to set up new PCP at ___ 
___. He was instructed to set up regular follow up with 
family cardiologist. He will see Dr. ___ will ___ 
cardiac surgery follow-up.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. Clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO DAILY (Daily): 
Take 2 tabs every morning for 2 weeks then take 1 tab every 
morning daily.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Toprol XL 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: Two (2) 
Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Simvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
primary:
ST elevation myocardial infarction
.
secondary:
hyperlipidemia
pre-diabetes

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status:Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness:Alert and interactive
Activity Status:Ambulatory - Independent

 
Discharge Instructions:
 
It was a pleasure taking care of you. You were admitted for 
chest pain and were found to have a heart attack. You underwent 
cardiac catherization, which showed an occlusion of one of the 
coronary arteries that supplied blood to your heart muscle. A 
stent was placed to restore blood flow to your heart. Because of 
the stent, you will need to take certain medications daily, and 
follow up with a PCP and cardiologist regularly.
.
Please take the following new medications:
- Aspirin 325 mg daily to protect your heart
- Simvastatin 80 mg daily for cholesterol
- Metoprolol XL 50 mg Take 2 tabs daily to protect your heart 
and lower blood pressure
- Plavix 150 mg daily for two weeks then 75 mg daily to protect 
the stent in your heart
- Lisinopril 5 mg daily to protect your heart and lower blood 
pressure
.
You should consider quiting smoking. You should talk to your new 
primary care doctor about ways to help quit. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

the stent in your heart
- Lisinopril 5 mg daily to protect your heart and lower blood
pressure
.
You should consider quiting smoking. You should talk to your new
primary care doctor about ways to help quit.

Brief Hospital Course:
#?Passed ampullary stone vs ?SOD 
Given reported fevers to 101, liver lab abnormalities and mild 
leukocytosis, will start antibiotics with ciprofloxacin/flagyl 
for empiric coverage.
Pt was monitored with no objective fevers while in house. ERCP 
was consulted and pt underwent extensive imaging including CTAP, 
RUQUS and MRCP. His labs improved with IVFs and abx alone. MRCP 
showed CBD dilation up to 1.1cm, but negative for e/o a stone or 
mass. Per radiology read, possible ___ sphincter of Oddi 
dysfunction. No MRI evidence of cholangitis, however. ___ d/w 
ERCP and hepatology; impression was possible passed ampullary 
stone but could not rule out SOD (though pt did not meet ___ IV 
critera). No e/o GB infection noted despite careful review of 
imaging with radiology. ERCP felt there was no role for ERCP 
intervention. Pt was given # to call for outpatient ERCP ___ 
___ to consider additional workup. Pt was given add'l abx 
to complete a full 5 day course of antibiotics.

#Diffuse papulosquamous eruption: Rash is very prominent, 
sparing
palms and soles. Per derm, ddx includes pityriasis rosea, 
secondary syphilis,
hepatitis C induced lichen planus, lichenoid drug eruption,
psoriasis, and pityriasis rubra pilaris. 
s/p punch biopsy ___, results pending at the time of discharge. 
Derm to call pt with results. 
They rec'd Triamcinolone 0.1% cream twice daily to trunk
and extremities and Hydrocortisone 2.5% cream twice daily for
face and genitals.
In terms of workup HIV negative; RPR negative. HCV VL ND.
Rash uploaded to OMR via PhotoConsult.

#Chronic hepatitis C
Unable to complete Harvoni as medication was lost when he was in 
jail
Already Hepatitis B vaccinated
HCV VL sent, pending at time of d/c but returned ND shortly 
after d/c.

#PSA
#Opioid dependence: Patient urine tox screen positive for both 
methadone and
opioid as well as cocaine. Pt admitted to intermittent IN 
cocaine use, declined assistance with abstinence.
He was continued on his home methadone maintenance (75mg); Habit

Tablet Refills:*0

Consider prescribing naloxone at discharge

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Possible passed ampullary gallstone

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
You came to the hospital for evaluation of fever, abdominal 
pain, elevated liver labs and a rash.
We did testing and imaging studies which did not show any 
evidence of a gallstone or gallbladder infection. You did not 
have further fevers here in the hospital.
Your ___ was reviewed by the liver doctors and advanced 
___, who felt your presentation may have been a result 
of a stone that has passed though (but no longer present in) the 
liver drainage system. Alternative etiologies include "sphincter 
of oddi" dysfunction" though you did not meet the typical 
criteria for this disorder.
The Gi doctors here recommended follow up with your regular Gi 
doctors at ___, but also recommended follow up with the advanced 
GI clinc:
 Call the office ___ ___ or ___ 
to make an apt at which time you can be evaluated for further 
testing. They did not feel that you needed to stay in the 
hospital for further testing.
 
The skin doctors also recommended that you continue the two 
ointments they had recommended: 

1. Triamcinolone 0.1% cream twice daily to affected areas on 
trunk
and e extremities.  Please order 454 g jar. Not to be used for
more than 2 weeks consecutively. 
Sideeffects include dyspigmentation, skin atrophy, history. 
2. Hydrocortisone 2.5% cream twice daily for affected areas on 
the
face and genitals. Not to be used for more than 2 weeks.
Side effects include dyspigmentation, skin atrophy, history.

They will call you in ___ days with the results of the biopsy 
and determine if you need to follow up with your primary care 
doctor or to be seen in the ___ clinic.

You can try 20mg pantoprazole 30 minutes before breakfast for 
you dyspepsia (upset stomach) and follow up with you primary 
care doctor or GI doctor for further evaluation as needed.

If you develop worsening abdominal pain, recurrent 
fevers/chills, nausea/vomiting or yellowing of your skin, or 
worsening of your rash please call your doctor or return to the 
emergency department. 

It was a pleasure taking care of you!

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PSYCHIATRY
 
Allergies: 
amoxicillin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
"I was on Celexa and it felt like it wasn't helping enough."
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None.
 
History of Present Illness:
For further details of the history and presentation, please see 
___ including Dr. ___ admission note dated ___. 
. 
Briefly, this is a ___ employed, married Caucasian woman, 
previously diagnosed with mood disorder, anxiety disorder, s/p 
one prior suicide attempt via hanging, who self presented to 
___ with complaints of worsening depression, suicidal ideation 
in the setting of recent medication change and numerous ongoing 
psychosocial stressors. 
. 
ED Course: patient was in good behavioral control and did not 
require physical or chemical restraints. 
. 
Patient seen in team. Upon interview with Ms. ___, who was 
cooperative with examination and a reliable historian, she 
confirmed the history provided initially in the ED. Reported 
that she had been struggling with her depression and anxiety 
over the past few months, noting she had been on Celexa, "but I 
felt like it wasn't helping enough... I knew I needed a change 
and so I stopped the Celexa and saw my psychiatrist, who put me 
on Abilify on ___ Stated that since this change, she felt 
as if her "manic" episodes were more frequent, and noted that 
she was having more thoughts of wanting to die. Patient went on 
to state that she had attempted suicide in the past and 
reported, "I wouldn't kill myself... I wouldn't do that to my 
kids." She did note that she had been on Latuda in the past, 
which she found helpful-- prior to this medication trial patient 
reported she had been having "outbursts, punching myself" and 
that the Latuda helped with this. However, she developed nausea, 
and so this was discontinued and Sertraline was started but 
reportedly not effective.
. 
In terms of depressive symptoms, Ms. ___ reported a 
longstanding history of depression beginning at age ___ that 
resulted in cutting. She stated that at the time, she would 
"feel numb and that was the only thing I could do to feel." Does 
not recall why she felt numb, stating she felt she was "really 
happy as a child." Reported chronic depression, but states she 
is "able to hide it better at work than at home," while at home 
"I will get mad at the littlest thing and lose it." She also 
reported associated "racing thoughts" with difficulty processing 
thoughts and emotions, difficulty concentrating. Stated she has 
had
intermittent suicidal ideation with thoughts of jumping in front 
of a train, overdosing or hanging herself. Denies intent or 
plan. Reported feeling anxious, worrying a lot about her 
finances with history of panic attacks where she will feel 
clammy, sweaty, periods of nausea, vomiting that can last 3 
hours. Endorsed
ongoing stressors, particularly financial stressors, noting that 
her fiancÃ© of ___ years has been out of work. States she I  
the main bread___, but also his primary caretaker for her 
children, both frequently come home and the hospital has not 
been done, which she finds frustrating.
. 
Patient also reported periods of "dissociation" where "I feel 
like I'm floating, nothing is real... I don't feel like I'm in 
my body and I feel like I'm in a dream." She has difficulty 
identifying triggers to dissociation at this time.  
. 
On psychiatric review of systems, patient denied a history of 
manic symptoms including decreased need for sleep, racing 
thoughts for days at a time, risky behaviors, worsening 
impulsivity or increased pending.  Denied grandiosity.  Denied 
history of psychosis including auditory visual hallucinations, 
delusions.  Denied drug or alcohol use at this time.

 
Past Medical History:
Past psychiatric history:
- Diagnoses: MDD, BPAD type II, dissociative disorder. Recently
diagnosed about ___ year ago with bipolar affective disorder.  Of
note, patient is unclear where this diagnosis came from.
- SA/SIB: ___ s/p hanging with resultant hospitalization at
___ of cutting and scratching 
- Hospitalizations: ___, where she received a course of ECT

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old employed ___ woman, previously 
diagnosed with mood disorder, anxiety disorder, one prior 
suicide attempt via hanging, who self-reported to ___ with 
complaints of worsening depression and suicidal ideation in the 
setting of recent medication change and numerous ongoing 
psychosocial stressors.
.
Upon interview, the patient endorsed struggling with depression 
and anxiety over the past few months. She clarified that she had 
been on Sertraline for the past 1 to 2 months which did not give 
her significant symptomatic improvement; her outpatient 
psychiatrist started Abilify on ___ and there was 
miscommunication as patient thought she was supposed to 
discontinue the Sertraline and only take the Abilify. Since 
starting Abilify, patient noted increase in frequency of "manic" 
episodes, having increased thoughts of wanting to die, and 
episodes of "dissociating" during which she feels like she is 
"floating, nothing is real... I don't feel like I'm in my body 
and I feel like I'm in a dream". Psychiatric review of systems 
was significant for anxiety regarding financial situation and 
panic attacks. Mental status examination upon admission was 
significant for incongruence in affect and mood (reporting 
feeling "depressed" and symptoms of depression with euthymic 
affect).
.
Diagnostically, given  the longstanding nature of her depression 
with affective instability, reactive mood with history of self 
injurious behaviors in the past, limited coping skills and 
mental status examination notable for euthymic affect with rapid 
improvement of depressive symptoms in the setting of the 
stabilizing environment of the milieu, I believe her depression 
is most likely consistent with underlying character pathology 
rather than a primary mood disorder. Of note, although she 
carries a diagnosis of BPAD, nothing in my history that is 
concerning for a discrete hypomanic or manic episode. She may 
have met criteria for major depressive disorder in the past, but 
she does not appear depressed on my examination. Of note, she 
likely does meet criteria for generalized anxiety disorder 
. 
#. Legal/Safety: Patient was admitted to Deaconess 4 on a 
___ upon admission, patient signed a Conditional 
Voluntary status which was accepted. Patient denied suicidal 
ideation or thoughts of self-harm, was on 15 minute checks for 
safety, and did not require physical or chemical restraints. 
.
#. Unspecified Mood Disorder
- Since admission, patient has denied suicidal ideation and 
thoughts of self-harm. While she initially endorsed feeling 
depressed, patient reported significant improvement in mood 
while on the unit. She had good participation in her care, 
attending groups regularly. 
- Discontinuation of Abilify was discussed with patient as her 
current symptoms did not indicate psychopharmacologic 
intervention for acute psychosis or mania and she had complaints 
of symptoms of restlessness that resembled akathisia. To treat 
depressed mood, risks and benefits of starting Lexapro 5 mg PO 
QD and Lamictal 25 mg PO QD were discussed and patient agreed to 
start this pharmacologic regimen for the inpatient stay. Upon 
contacting Dr. ___ was clarified that Abilify was meant 
to be added-on as augmentation for treatment of depression; 
however, as patient seemed to have improved mood by inpatient 
day 3, the regimen of Lexapro and Lamictal was continued with 
plans to focus on therapy for stabilization of symptoms as 
outpatient. Lamictal was switched from QD to QHS. 
- Individual, group, and milieu therapy was continuously 
provided during the admission. A family meeting with her husband 
was held prior to discharge to discuss the hospital course; her 
husband was supportive of the patient and plan to discharge with 
outpatient supports with no safety concerns. 
.
#. Anxiety Disorder
- Patient continued to report periods of anxiety symptoms that 
she experiences at her baseline. As patient reported that 
anxiety symptoms at baseline respond well to supportive measures 
and talking about her emotions, she was encouraged to attend CBT 
groups on the unit. She was continued on Ativan 0.5 mg po bid 
prn anxiety 
- Hydroxyzine PO Q6H PRN was initially ordered at 25 mg and 
increased to 50 mg for patient needing to request additional 
Ativan 0.5 mg PO BID PRN for anxiety and sleeping. As patient 
felt that medication was not sufficient for helping her sleep, 
Hydroxyzine was discontinued and Trazodone was started at 25 mg 
PO QHS PRN which was increased to 50 mg with good result. 
.
#. Substance Use: 
- Patient reported history of EtOH binge use behavior in the 
past, currently denying misuse/abuse at this time. Received 
education on risks and benefits of alcohol use, and patient 
stated she would continue to avoid drinking excessive amounts of 
alcohol
.
#. GERD: stable 
- Patient was continued on home regimen of Omeprazole 20 mg PO 
QD.
.
#. Hypothyroidism: by history, stable 
- Patient's TSH was checked upon admission which was within 
normal limits (TSH 3.8 on ___. Patient also reported that 
she has not been on any medications for her thyroid for a while 
as she has been stable. No medications were given for 
hypothyroidism during this admission.
.
#. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: with chronic neuropathic pain 
- Patient's home regimen of Gabapentin 1200 mg PO BID was 
continued.
.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. ARIPiprazole 10 mg PO DAILY 
2. LORazepam 0.5 mg PO BID:PRN anxiety 
3. Gabapentin 1200 mg PO BID 
4. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY

Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Aphasia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
tPA ___

 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ year old man with a history of prior TIA and
Crohn's disease who presented to an outside hospital with the
worst headache of his life today. The headache began at 1pm. It
began while he was driving. At first he thought it was from the
sun, but then it got worse over the course of an hour. He does
not get headaches at baseline and has never had a HA like this
before. It is bifrontal.  He was found by his wife at 4pm,
clutching his head, who took him to ___. While
in triage, he developed a global aphasia. NCHCT did not show
bleeding nor early infarct signs or other obvious explanation 
for
his symptoms. He was seen as a tele stroke by ___ neurology 
and
his exam was significant for a severe global
(expressive>receptive) aphasia. NIHSS was 5 for LOC questions
(2), language (2), and dysarthria (1). He was in significant
distress from the headache. He was given tPA and transferred to
___ for further care and consideration of intra-arterial
intervention.

Upon arrival to ___, he continues to be aphasic and complains
of a headache. History is limited by his aphasia. In the ED
CTA/CTV was negative for large vessel occlusion or VST on prelim
read. HA was treated with morphine. He also had difficulty with
urination in the ED.

Has a h/o TIA in the past. Over the past ___ years, has had ___
episodes of speech difficulty, each lasting ___ minutes. None
this severe. None associated with headache. He is on aspirin for
stroke prevention.
 
Review of Systems: HA and per HPI, otherwise difficult to obtain
with his aphasia. 
 
Past Medical History:
- previous TIA
- Crohn's disease
- asthma
- acid reflux
- BPH
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
- stroke in father
 
Physical ___:
========================
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM
========================
Vitals:  93 155/89 19 100% RA 
General: Awake, cooperative, NAD.
HEENT: NC/AT
Neck: Supple. 
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation bilaterally
Cardiac: RRR, no murmurs
Abdomen: soft, nondistended
Extremities: no edema, warm. Some bruises/hematomas at venous
puncture sites.
Skin: no rashes or lesions noted.

NEUROLOGIC EXAMINATION

___ Stroke Scale - Total [4]
1a. Level of Consciousness -0
1b. LOC Questions -2
1c. LOC Commands -0
2. Best Gaze -0
3. Visual Fields -0
4. Facial Palsy -0
5a. Motor arm, left -0
5b. Motor arm, right -0
6a. Motor leg, left -0
6b. Motor leg, right -0
7. Limb Ataxia -0
8. Sensory -0
9. Language -2
10. Dysarthria -0
11. Extinction and Neglect -0

 
-Mental Status: Alert and interactive with exam. Speech is 
fluent
with frequent paraphasias, for example "I know contrails
kerstails contrails contrails." Unable to name any items on
stroke card. Makes mistakes with repeating phrases. Able to
follow two step command. Unable to read. Becomes frustrated with
language deficits. Describes cookie jar picture as "a woman, 2
children, falling contrails..." Speech began to improve ~10:30 
pm
in the ED.

-Cranial Nerves:
I: Olfaction not tested.
II: PERRL 3 to 2mm bilaterally.  VFF to confrontation with 
finger
wiggling - no extinction to DSS. 
III, IV, VI: EOMI without nystagmus.   
V: Facial sensation intact to light touch in all distributions 
VII: No facial droop with symmetric upper and lower facial
musculature bilaterally  
VIII: Hearing intact to voice.
IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically.
XI: full strength in trapezii bilaterally.
XII: Tongue protrudes in midline with full ROM right and left 
 
-Motor: Normal bulk throughout. No pronator drift bilaterally. 
No
tremor noted. 
 Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE IO  IP Quad Ham TA ___
L  ___   ___  ___   5   5    5     5   5
R  ___   ___  ___   5   5    5     5   5
 
-DTRs:
    Bi  Tri  ___  Pat  Ach
L   3    3     3     3+   2
R   3    3     3     4    2
- Toes were mute bilaterally.
- Crossed adductors and pec jerk present bilaterally
- couple beats of clonus at right knee

-Sensory: No deficits to light touch, pinprick throughout 

-Coordination: No dysmetria on FNF or HKS bilaterally. 

-Gait: deferred post tPA

========================
DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM
========================
Tmax: 37 Â°C (98.6 Â°F)  
T current: 36.8 Â°C (98.3 Â°F)  
HR: 82 (64 - 92) bpm  
BP: 126/72(84) {90/58(67) - 151/93(106)} mmHg  
RR: 15 (10 - 19) insp/min  
SPO2: 94%  
General: Awake, cooperative, NAD.  
HEENT: NC/AT  
Neck: Supple.  
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation bilaterally  
Cardiac: RRR, no murmurs  
Abdomen: soft, nondistended  
Extremities: no edema, warm. Some bruises/hematomas at venous 
puncture sites.  
Skin: no rashes or lesions noted.  
 
-Mental Status: Alert and interactive with exam. Oriented to
person, place and time. Speech is fluent with intact naming of
high and low frequency object. Able to perform complex commands
and repeat. No apraxia or hemi-neglect observed. 

-Cranial Nerves:  
I: Olfaction not tested.  
II: PERRL 3 to 2mm bilaterally. VFF to confrontation with finger
wiggling - no extinction to DSS.  
III, IV, VI: EOMI without nystagmus.  
V: Facial sensation intact to light touch in all distributions  
VII: No facial droop with symmetric upper and lower facial
musculature bilaterally  
VIII: Hearing intact to voice.  
IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically.  
XI: full strength in trapezii bilaterally.  
XII: Tongue protrudes in midline with full ROM right and left  
 
-Motor: Normal bulk throughout. No pronator drift bilaterally.
No tremor noted.  
Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE IO IP Quad Ham TA ___  
 L ___ 5 5  
 R ___ 5 5  
 
-DTRs: ___ were mute bilaterally  
-Sensory: No deficits to light touch, pinprick throughout   
-Coordination: No dysmetria on FNF or HKS bilaterally  
-Gait: Stable with independent ambulation

 
Pertinent Results:
==========
LABS
==========
___ 12:44AM BLOOD ___ PTT-26.4 ___
___ 02:59AM BLOOD ALT-24 AST-27 LD(LDH)-208 AlkPhos-84 
TotBili-0.5
___ 02:59AM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01
___ 12:32AM BLOOD %HbA1c-5.2 eAG-103
___ 02:59AM BLOOD Triglyc-114 HDL-62 CHOL/HD-3.2 
LDLcalc-111
___ 02:59AM BLOOD ASA-NEG Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-NEG 
Bnzodzp-NEG Barbitr-NEG Tricycl-NEG

==========
IMAGING
==========
CTA HEAD AND NECK (___):
1. Principal arteries of the head and neck are patent, with no 
evidence of 
stenosis, occlusion, dissection or intracranial aneurysmal 
formation. 
2. Hypoplastic A1 segment of the left anterior cerebral artery, 
with distal reconstitution via collateral flow from the right 
ACA and A-comm. 
3. Diminutive left P1 and left posterior communicating artery 
with small 
caliber of the P2 and distal left PCA branches which opacify. 
4. No intracranial hemorrhage. 

MRI HEAD WITHOUT CONTRAST (___):
1. No evidence of acute infarct or acute intracranial 
hemorrhage. 
2. Punctate gradient echo susceptibility of the right coronal 
radiata likely represents prior microhemorrhage. 
3. Nonspecific periventricular subcortical T2/FLAIR white matter 

hyperintensities, commonly seen in setting chronic 
microangiopathy in a 
patient of this age. 

NCHCT (___):
No acute intracranial process.  No intracranial hemorrhage.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ yo man with a past medical history notable 
for Crohn's disease and previous TIAs who presented to an OSH 
___ with the worst headache of his life. He later developed a 
global aphasia and was given tPA. He was then transferred to 
___ and admitted to the neurologic ICU for post-tPA 
monitoring.

Overnight, pt remained hemodynamically and neurologically 
stable. His neurological deficits resolved. MRI did not reveal 
an ischemic stroke. Upon further history taking on hospital day 
#2, pt reported that he first began to see "rippling waves" 
prior to the onset of a HA 20 minutes later. About an hour after 
developing the HA, he experienced word finding difficulty which 
prompted his presentation to the ED. His symptoms resolved after 
~4 hours. At discharge, it was felt that pt likely experienced a 
complex migraine. Still, pt was discharged on his home aspirin 
81mg daily for secondary stroke prevention has he had a history 
of TIAs and migraine with aura. Pt was recommend to use Naproxen 
as needed as an outpatient for a migraine abortive agent.
 
Medications on Admission:
- Flovent 110 mcg inhaler, 1 puff BID
- omeprazole 20mg dialy
- Proair HFA 90 mcg inhaler, ___ puffs q4-6 hours prn
- aspirin 81mg daily
- B12
- omega 3 fatty acid
- vitamin D 1000u daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain, fever 
2. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
3. Fluticasone Propionate 110mcg 2 PUFF IH BID 
4. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Complex migraine

 
Discharge Condition:
Alert and interactive with exam. Oriented to person, place and 
time. Speech is fluent with intact naming of high and low 
frequency object. Able to perform complex commands and repeat. 
No apraxia or hemi-neglect observed. Names ___ F words in 1 
minute and 14 animals in 1 minute.
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted with a bad headache and global aphasia that 
was concerning for a stroke, so you received a medication called 
tPA. Your MRI did not show a stroke, and some of the other 
symptoms you described were more suggestive of a complex 
migraine. 

If you have another severe headache, please try naproxen 500 mg 
(this is an over the counter medication) as this can abort your 
headache. If you see waves in your vision, this may represent a 
migraine aura and we would recommend you take naproxen at this 
time.

It was a pleasure taking care of you in the hospital, and we 
wish you the best!

Sincerely,
Your ___ Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Allergies/ADRs on File
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
s/p cardiac arrest
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
tracheostomy/PEG placement ___
 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ year old female with a history of HIV, 
dextrocardia and Type 2 DM who presents after a cardiac arrest, 
course complicated by possible seizures requiring transfer to 
___ for cEEG monitoring.

Per ___ course documentation: call to ___ came at 
1055am. Was at a work event and became unresponsive. CPR was 
started by bystanders and later on police. AED placed and was 
shocked once. EMS arrived 5 minutes later, pt was in PEA. 
Received epi 1mg at 11:02am and then again at 11:07am. ROSC 
after second dose. At 11:!2am received amiodarone 150mg IV. Also 
received 750cc NS through left IO. Unclear when she was 
intubated but had heavy vomitus in tube and so was reintubated. 

Of note, she did have months of progressive chest pain and 
breathing that was off according to his coworkers. Was supposed 
to get a stress test one month ago but was aborted given 
concerning findings in the stress lab. Went to a hospital, 
unclear which one, but was discharged the following day on 
atorvastatin 20mg as one of her medications. No other 
information is known about what happened afterward as patient 
became more reserved about sharing health history with 
coworkers. 

At ___, had at least two episodes of what could have 
been tonic clonic episodes s/p 2mg IV Ativan once for each 
episode. Also received 1 gram keppra load as well. 

Pertinent labs: 
-WBC 10.96, H/H 10.___.5
-U/A neg nitri neg WBC esterase
-ABG pH 6.85 CO2 85 O2 68
-glucose 441 HCO3 14
-trop <0.012 BNP 59
-negative urine tox

CT head no acute intracranial hemorrhage, territorial infarct. 
Cooling protocol initiated at OSH. Transferred to ___ for 
further EEG monitoring. Additionally, cardiology consulted given 
patient's troponin elevation who did not recommend 
heparinization or catheterization.

While in the ___ ED patient had further work up post arrest. 
Patient arrived intubated and a femoral line was placed for 
central access. Neurology was consulted and exam notable for 
minimally reactive pupils, no gag reflex and no withdrawal to 
painful stimuli.

There was additional concern for possible DKA (blood sugar 415 
with pH of 7.15, no urine sample. Patient received 2L NS and was 
placed on an insulin gtt.

In ED,
Initial VS:  
-___ 36 98% Intubation 

Labs significant for:  
- CBC: 4.1/11.2/171
- Chemistry: 141/4.3/105/11. BUN 18 Sr Cr 1.0
- LFTs: ALT 112, AST 191, AP 113, Tbili 0.2 Albumin 2.8
- Utox negative
- Top: 0.29
- Lactate 6.7
1840 VBG: pH 7.16 pCO2 45 HCO3 17

Patient was given: 
___ 17:05 IVF  NS 1000 mL  
___ 17:22 IV DRIP Fentanyl Citrate 
___ 17:22 IV DRIP Propofol 
___ 18:08 IVF  NS 1000 mL  
___ 18:46 IV DRIP Insulin Started 6 UNIT/HR 
___ 18:46 IVF 40 mEq Potassium Chloride / NS 250 mL/hr 
___ 19:01 IV Magnesium Sulfate 
 
Imaging notable for:  
___ CXR: 1. Central bilateral pulmonary opacities are 
consistent with pulmonary edema. 
2. ET tube terminates 7.3 cm above the carina. 

Consults:  
-cardiology consulted: admit to MICU
-post cardiac arrest team: TTM at 35 degrees, check ABG with 
lactate, wean 02 to sats >94%, HOB > 30 degrees, seek underlying 
etiology, EEG in ICU 

VS prior to transfer:  T36.2 HR107 BP 87/53 94% intubated

On arrival to the MICU, patient is intubated and sedated without 
pupil response, corneal reflex. 
 
Past Medical History:
HIV
Possible DM Type 2
Dextrocardia
Hypertension 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Unknown
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM
VITALS: Reviewed in metavision  
GENERAL: sedated, intubated
HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear. Pupils non 
reactive to light, no corneal reflex
NECK: supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD  
LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, 
rhonchi  
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops  
ABD: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no 
rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly  
EXT: cool  
SKIN: no obvious skin defects 
NEURO:  no pupil response, no corneal reflex, no withdrawal to 
noxious stimuli

of both lungs may be in keeping with severe multifocal pneumonia 
or diffuse alveolar damage/ARDS.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with a history of HIV, 
dextrocardia and Type 2 DM, who presented after a cardiac 
arrest, course notable for treatment of CAP, no evidence of post 
arrest seizures, overall poor prognosis, transitioned to 
inpatient hospice, died on ___.

ACUTE ISSUES
============
#S/P Cardiac arrest
#Anoxic brain injury:
Unclear etiology of arrest though differential includes 
arrhythmia and underlying infection. On admission, the patient 
was unresponsive and without purposeful movement. She underwent 
targeted temperature management and re-warmed with overall poor 
neurologic prognosis and no change in mental status. MRI with 
significant anoxic injury. Initial family meetings yielded a 
change in code status to DNR/OK to intubate. After discussion 
with son decision was made to pursue trach/peg. She was 
reevalated by neurology 1 month post-arrest where it was again 
felt that her neurologic prognosis remained poor. After 
discussion with her son, decision was made to transition to 
DNR/DNI and eventually to hospice care in order to respect her 
overall goals of care. She passed away on ___. PCP was 
notified via telephone re: patient's death.

#Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: 
Intubated following arrest, CT with multifocal consolidations 
however stable O2 requirement. Formerly on CAP treatment 
(ceftriaxone, doxy) early in her hospitalization, now off. 
Notably with irregular breathing pattern. The patient continued 
to have fevers that were felt to be central/neurologic in 
origin. Cultures remained negative. While in the MICU, the 
patient was weaned off mechanical ventilation onto trach mask. 
Transferred to the floor and continued to have intermittent 
tachypnea, but remained stable on trach mask. She was suctioned 
as needed for mucous plugging.

#Skin Breakdown under tracheostomy
Ulceration noted under trach site secondary to microvascular 
ischemic related to trach pressure and tight sutures. She was 
followed by wound care, with daily dressing changes to relieve 
pressure on the wound and keep clean and uninfected.

#Sinus Bradycardia: 
Not on sedation or medications that commonly cause bradycardia. 
EKG showed normal PR interval. Could be an electrical conduction 
problem ie SSS given cardiac arrest but more likely is 
significant neurologic injury. The patient never required 
atropine or pacing.

#Normocytic Anemia: 
Ongoing downtrend during hospitalization. No evidence of 
bleeding, DIC or hemolysis. Retic inappropriately low given 
degree of anemia, likely some degree of suppression. Brown soft 
stools. Felt to be due to polyphlebotomy and critical illness.

#Thrombocytopenia: 
Likely related to critical illness.

CHRONIC/STABLE ISSUES:
#DMII: A1c 11.7, poorly controlled. The patient was started on 
tube feeds in-house and placed on glargine and a regular insulin 
sliding scale. These were discontinued when the patient was 
transitioned to ___ focused care.

#HIV: On home Descovy and raltegravir. These were discontinued 
when the patient was transitioned to ___ focused care.

Unknown
 
Discharge Medications:
None
 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PEA Arrest
Anoxic brain injury

 
Discharge Condition:
See information for outside providers. Patient expired.

 
Discharge Instructions:
See information for outside providers. Patient expired.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___

History of Present Illness:
Mrs. ___ is an ___ year old female with history of CAD s/p 
PCI with stent x 2 (unknown date), DM II, HTN and TIA's, 
transferred from ___ after referral from her PCP's 
office for bradycardia and hypotension.  One day prior to 
admission, she was shopping with her daughter and developed 
chest pressure radiating to her back, shortness of breath, and 
sensation of feeling that she was going to pass out.  Pressure 
went away with rest.  She affirms that the pressure across her 
chest is similar to her previous anginal symptoms.  On the 
morning of admission, she developed chest pressure shortly after 
waking and walking around the house and feeling of an irregular 
heart rate.  This was associated with shortness of breath as 
well.  She returned to bed after breakfast and awoke again with 
continued pain.  She took nitroglycerin with some improvement.  
She then went to her PCP's office where she was bradycardic to 
40's with LBBB and hypotensive to 90's.  She recieved SL NTG 
with resolution of symptoms and was sent by ambulance to ED.  
Other symptoms include cough for past 1.5 weeks, slightly 
productive, but denies fever, chills, rhinorrhea, diarrhea.  She 
was treated with a ___ for this.
.
At ___ vitals were 97.6 HR 53  BP 154/83 RR 22 and 
in atrial fibrillation.  There is then notation that she 
spontaneously converted to sinus bradycardia within the next ___ 
minutes.  She was given 1L NS and Aspirin 325 mg then

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old male admitted to the hospital with right groin pain. 
 Upon admission, the patient was hypotensive with tachycardia 
and there was concern for sepsis.  The patient was started on 
clindamycin, ciprofloxacin, and flagyl.   He was admitted to the 
intensive care unit for monitoring.  ___ was consulted but were 
unable to place ___ drain because the abscess cavity had 
collapsed.  The patient was taken to the operating room where he 
underwent incision and drainage of right medial and posterior 
thigh.

The operative course was stable.   A kerlex was left in the 
wound and the wound was left open with a ___ drain in place. 
Intra-operatively he received 1u PRBC for low Hct, 1L LR and 
vancomycin. He had a 50cc blood loss.  The patient was extubated 
after the procedure and monitored in the recovery room.  He 
returned to the intensive care unit for monitoring. 

The patient was transferred to the surgical floor on POD #2. He 
resumed a regular diet. His antibiotics were discontinued. The 
___ drain was removed on POD #4 and a vac dressing was 
placed and vac dressing changes undertaken every 3 days.  The 
patient's electrolytes were monitored and he was noted to have a 
sodium between 128 and 133. He was started on a baby aspirin for 
an elevated platelet count.  He continued on his salt tablets. 
In preparation for discharge, the patient was evaluated by 
physical therapy.  Recommendations were  made for discharge to a 
rehabilitation facility to help the patient regain his strength 
and mobility. 

The patient was discharged on POD #9. His vital signs were 
stable and he was afebrile.  His white blood cell count trended 
down and his sodium normalized at 133.  Follow-up appointments 
were made in the acute care clinic.  Discharge instructions were 
reviewed and questions answered.

History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is an ___ yo RH F with a history of possible HTN (not 
on any anti-HTN medications), Crohn's disease s/p ileostomy, and 
ongoing L corneal infection who presents with a L 
parieto-occipital IPH plus possible new diagnosis of Afib with 
RVR (not on anticoagulation or rate control medications).

She was last known well ___ evening when talking on the phone 
with her daughter at 9 ___ and later sending an email to her 
neighbor. ___ AM, a neighbor who was meeting her at her home for 
breakfast noted that she seemed confused. Ms. ___ answered 
the door for her neighbor but did not respond to questions or 
speak initially. She was grabbing for objects in the air that 
did not exist. There was no evidence of trauma, though her 
daughter did note that there was shampoo on the floor of her 
bathroom and wondered if she'd fallen there. 

She was transported to ___ where she was noted to be 
unable to follow commands or speak. VS were notable for BP 
190s/100s, HR 150s. EKG at OSH showed Afib. NCHCT at 12:20 
showed a 2.5x2.5 cm L parieto-occipital hemorrhage. CTA 
head/neck from OSH was unremarkable. She was given a total of 
Metoprolol 15 mg IV for Afib with RVR and started on a 
Clevidipine gtt for her BPs. At ~ 2PM, Ms. ___ had a focal 
seizure consisting of R head and eye deviation with R arm 
jerking. This lasted for approximately 3 minutes and resolved 
with administration of 2 mg IV Ativan. She was also loaded with 
1000 mg IV Keppra at this time. Repeat NCHCT at ~16:00 showed a 
stable L parieto-occipital IPH but with possible new SAH. 

Ms. ___ daughter notes that she seems to be improved on 
transfer from OSH to here. She feels that she is beginning to 
have some speech output now which she had not previously. She 
also seems more alert to her. 

Ms. ___ has had no history of stroke, syncope, bleeds, and 
no complaints of headaches recently. 

 
Past Medical History:
- ?HTN - not on any anti-HTN medications, but daughter notes one 
episode several months ago of high BP for which she follows with 
a cardiologist.

protective contact in place, topical antibiotic, systemic 
anti-viral).

-Several SCC/BCC lesions

___

No family history of strokes, aneurysms, bleeding disorders

-Mental Status: Alert. Opens and closes eyes to verbal command. 
Cannot repeat. Cannot sing Happy Birthday. Answers "yes" 
initially to all questions. Says "can I have [non sensical 
syllables]" and rubs her lips - her daughter indicates that she 
often complains of dry mouth. Does not follow any other 
commands. Says multiple other non-sensical syllables. 

-Cranial Nerves:  
I: Olfaction not tested.  
II: L pupil 5 and unreactive (baseline since L corneal infection 
over last several days per daughter). R pupil 3 to 2 and brisk. 
No blink to threat bilaterally.

horizontally

-SensoriMotor: Normal bulk, tone throughout. R pronator drift.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,  
You were hospitalized due to symptoms of headache/confusion 
resulting from an ACUTE BRAIN HEMORRHAGE, a condition where 
blood accumulates in an area of your brain. The brain is the 
part of your body that controls and directs all the other parts 
of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived of its 
blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms.  
Brain hemorrhage can have many different causes, so we assessed 
you for medical conditions that might raise your risk of having 
hemorrhage. In order to prevent future hemorrhages, we plan to 
modify some risk factors. Your risk factors are:  
High blood pressure
Age
Possible cerebral amyloid angiopathy
Atrial fibrillation
Possible metastasis status post melanoma resection
 
We are changing your medications as follows:  
Started Metoprolol 12.5 mg TID

Please take your other medications as prescribed.  
Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.  
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since hemorrhages can 
recur, please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence 
of these symptoms:  
- sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
- sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
- sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
- sudden weakness of one side of the body  
- sudden drooping of one side of the face  
- sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body

History of Present Illness:
___ PMH COPD, interstitial lung disease, pulmonary fibrosis, has 
been ___ O2 since this year, with multiple hospitalizations for 
COPD, maintained on steroids. He has history of multiple 
hospitalizations for COPD and IPF exacerbation, had presented to 
BID-P from rehab with hypoxia and worsening shortness of breath. 


On his presentation he was afebrile and his initial 
investigations were remarkable for chronic interstitial changes 
without evidence of pneumonia, WBC of 21,000, He required bipap 
in ED and then was transferred to the ICU for further 
monitoring. Obese, HTN, CKD. Arrived ___, started refusing 
BIPAP, then tried ___ and high flow. On ___ 
the patient started complaining of abdominal pain. Ultrasound 
showed gallbladder wall thickening and ascites, wall 6mm, acute 
vs chronic cholecystitis. Bili 4.8. WBC down to 13, then when to 
18. He was mildly hypothermic, was started vanc, zosyn, MRSA 
swab positive. Flu negative. Blood cultures were negative.

His renal function yesterday showed new oliguria and rising 
creatinine. Surgery recommended percutanous cholecystectomy. ___ 
recommended HIDA scan prior. Abdomen more distended, with 
bladder pressure of 24. CT scan last night without contrast 
showed no gallbladder thickening. The patient was intubated 
given worsening of respiratory failure. He was started on neo, 
on prop, fentanyl. His bilirubin increased to 6.5. Transaminitis 
in 200s. Lactate 2.8. Transferred 2.8. Large ascites. His vent 
settings were: PCV 100%, 10 PEEP, RR 16, Pressure 16.

He was transferred to the ___ for further evaluation and ERCP.
On arrival to the MICU, the patient was intubated on pressors.

(+) Per HPI  

 
Past Medical History:
COPD
Interstitial Pulmonary Fibrosis (PFT in ___, with total 
lung capacity 56% predicted, diffusion capacity 34% predicted)
Pulmonary Hypertension
Morbid Obesity
Cirrhosis, Pulmonary Hypertension (unsure but based on imaging)

No siblings and no biological children.

===========================
Vitals: ___  HR 99-113, BP 76/29, Rr26  88% ET 100% APRV
GENERAL: Intubated, sedated, does not open eyes or follow 
commands 
HEENT: Pupils 4mm bilaterally, reactive, Sclera anicteric, does 
not track, dry mucous membranes
NECK: supple, JVP unable to assess given edema, no LAD  
LUNGS: Rhonchorous through lung fields, has prolonged expiratory 
phases
CV: Tachycardic, normal S1 S2, systolic murmur present 
throughout 
ABD: hypoactive bowel sounds present, distended, tympanic 
throughout, does not appear to wince/withdraw with deep 
palpation
EXT: largely edematous throughout, cool extremities, unable to 
palpate distal pulses 
SKIN: cool and edematous, enlarged scrotum, scattered ecchymosis 
over arms bilaterally 
NEURO: unable to assess

in place

Patient expired at 1:50 am, ___ 
 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:
================

___ 02:42PM BLOOD WBC-21.8* RBC-5.13 Hgb-16.5 Hct-52.9* 
MCV-103* MCH-32.2* MCHC-31.2* RDW-18.6* RDWSD-69.4* Plt Ct-40*
___ 02:42PM BLOOD Neuts-92* Bands-2 Lymphs-1* Monos-4* 
Eos-0 Baso-0 ___ Metas-1* Myelos-0 AbsNeut-20.49* 
AbsLymp-0.22* AbsMono-0.87* AbsEos-0.00* AbsBaso-0.00*

Mg-2.7*
___ 02:56PM BLOOD Type-CENTRAL VE pO2-52* pCO2-82* pH-7.09* 
calTCO2-26 Base XS--7
___ 02:56PM BLOOD Lactate-2.7* K-6.1*

Outside Hospital labs: 
WBC 18, MCV 100, 91% neutrophils, creatinine 2.8, AST 203, ALT 
222
CI 3.3 Peripheral resistance 1763, SVI 27

MICROBIOLOGY:  
Flu negative, no growth on bcx
Urine culture no growth
Sputum: gram negative rods, normal flora

IMAGING: 
=========
___ RUQ u/s: 
1. A small liver with coarsened architecture is concerning for 
liver 
cirrhosis. 
2. Moderate to large amount of ascites predominantly centered in 
the right 
upper quadrant. 
3. Cholelithiasis and Gallbladder wall thickening measuring up 
to 8 mm.  This is most likely due to underlying liver disease, 
cholecystitis cannot be entirely excluded and if it is of 
clinical concern HIDA scan could be 
considered. 
4. No definite flow noted within the portal vein, however given 
the 
significant limitations of the study at this may be due to 
technical 
difficulties.  Short-term follow-up could be performed for 
reassessment or CT examination could be considered. 

___ CXR post line placement: Scattered radiation related to 
the patient's body habitus greatly obscures detail on 
radiographs.  The new right IJ central line tip appears to be 
located at the cavoatrial junction.  No evidence of 
pneumothorax. 

___ CXR: Worsening pulmonary edema, with suspected 
retrocardiac atelectasis.  Scattered radiation related to the 
patient's body habitus greatly obscures detail. 

___ Records: 
CXR: low lung volumes, diffuse reticular interstitial densities 
consistent with fibrosis. No edema. 

CT abdomen and pelvis: 
Both lung bases, airspace disease consistent with pneumonia.
There is ascites, nodular liver consistent with cirrhosis, 
normal spleen and pancreas
In gallbladder, stones layering, no definite wall thickening 
(although seen on ultrasound), ascites around gallbladder
No transhepatic access route to gallbladder would be available 
percutaneous cholecystotomy. 
Kidneys are unremarkable. 
No pelvic masses. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with hx of pulmonary fibrosis and 
COPD, with frequent hospitalizations, presented with hypoxemic 
respiratory failure, transferred to ___ intubated and on 
pressors, given concerns for respiratory failure and 
intra-abdominal physiology, here with multiorgan failure .

#Mixed Shock/Multi Organ Failure: Patient presented with 
hypotension, requiring pressor support with evidence of end 
organ hypoperfusion with elevated lactate, LFTs, and anuric 
renal failure. It appeared that his initial chest xray was 
concerning for chronic interstitial process/possible pneumonia, 
with elevated WBC and he has a high bilirubin and LFTs, 
concerning for intrabadominal process including cholecystitis, 
cholangitis, pancreatitis, or hepatitis. Patient may have been 
in "cold shock" with high Hct, concern about hemoconcentration 
related to capillary leak from sepsis and minimal preload. ECG 
suggested possible inferior wall ischemia and Troponin is 
elevated. His CVP was ___, with PEEP of 14, arguing for 
hypovolemia, with no clear history suggestive of cardiogenic 
shock. A central line was placed, and he was started on 
Norepinephrine, along with Vasopressin to maintain MAP. NICOM 
trial did not show fluid response. He was started on IV stress 
dose steroids, and then on IV vancomycin/cefepime/metronidazole 
for broad coverage. He was paralyzed to decrease demand.  He 
continued to have difficulty oxygenating as below. His family 
was contacted given his multiorgan failure. They elected to not 
proceed with CVVH as his prognosis still would be poor. Surgical 
consultants including interventional radiology and surgery were 
contacted and recommended no surgical intervention given high 
mortality associated with any invasive procedure. On ___ am, 
Resident physician was called to bedside by RN for asystole. 
Family was at bedside, On exam, patient was without pulse, 
breath sounds, or heart sounds, with no response to painful 
stimuli. Time of death 1:50am. Family declined autopsy. 
 
#Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure/Respiratory Acidosis: Patient had 
baseline pulmonary fibrosis, COPD with multiple 
hospitalizations, with likely poor respiratory reserve, low 
baseline FVC, with concern for ARDS given bilateral infiltrates 
with a low FIO2/PaO2, triggers being pneumonia vs sepsis from 
intra-abdominal infection. Oxygenation had been inadequate 
despite FIO2 100% and PEEP up to 18. He was switched to APRV and 
was on ARDS net protocol. He passed away given multi organ 
failure as above.

#Transaminitis/Intra-abdominal infection: Patient had started 
reporting abdominal pain at OSH per report, with worsening 
direct bilirubinemia, with concerns for obstruction, but given 
imaging findings, possible cholecystitis that triggered his 
decompensation and sepsis. He may have had a component of shock 
liver as well.  It was unclear the chronicity of liver disease, 
perhaps NASH with possible SBP as the inciting trigger. He was 
not a candidate for any intervention given his critical status. 

#Renal Failure: Patient presented with non gap metabolic 
acidosis, likely in RTA in setting of renal failure. His renal 
failure was likely due to hypoperfusion from sepsis with low CO 
and was anuric. Bladder pressure is approximately ___ and

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with hx of pulmonary fibrosis and
COPD, with frequent hospitalizations, presented with hypoxemic
respiratory failure, transferred to ___ intubated and on
pressors, given concerns for respiratory failure and
intra-abdominal physiology, here with multiorgan failure .
#Mixed Shock/Multi Organ Failure: Patient presented with
hypotension, requiring pressor support with evidence of end
organ hypoperfusion with elevated lactate, LFTs, and anuric
renal failure. It appeared that his initial chest xray was
concerning for chronic interstitial process/possible pneumonia,
with elevated WBC and he has a high bilirubin and LFTs,
concerning for intrabadominal process including cholecystitis,
cholangitis, pancreatitis, or hepatitis. Patient may have been
in "cold shock" with high Hct, concern about hemoconcentration
related to capillary leak from sepsis and minimal preload. ECG
suggested possible inferior wall ischemia and Troponin is
elevated. His CVP was ___, with PEEP of 14, arguing for
hypovolemia, with no clear history suggestive of cardiogenic
shock. A central line was placed, and he was started on
Norepinephrine, along with Vasopressin to maintain MAP. NICOM
trial did not show fluid response. He was started on IV stress
dose steroids, and then on IV vancomycin/cefepime/metronidazole
for broad coverage. He was paralyzed to decrease demand. He
continued to have difficulty oxygenating as below. His family
was contacted given his multiorgan failure. They elected to not
proceed with CVVH as his prognosis still would be poor. Surgical
consultants including interventional radiology and surgery were
contacted and recommended no surgical intervention given high
mortality associated with any invasive procedure. On ___ am,
Resident physician was called to bedside by RN for asystole.
Family was at bedside, On exam, patient was without pulse,
breath sounds, or heart sounds, with no response to painful
stimuli. Time of death 1:50am. Family declined autopsy.
#Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure/Respiratory Acidosis: Patient had
baseline pulmonary fibrosis, COPD with multiple
hospitalizations, with likely poor respiratory reserve, low
baseline FVC, with concern for ARDS given bilateral infiltrates
with a low FIO2/PaO2, triggers being pneumonia vs sepsis from
intra-abdominal infection. Oxygenation had been inadequate
despite FIO2 100% and PEEP up to 18. He was switched to APRV and
was on ARDS net protocol. He passed away given multi organ
failure as above.
#Transaminitis/Intra-abdominal infection: Patient had started
reporting abdominal pain at OSH per report, with worsening
direct bilirubinemia, with concerns for obstruction, but given
imaging findings, possible cholecystitis that triggered his
decompensation and sepsis. He may have had a component of shock
liver as well. It was unclear the chronicity of liver disease,
perhaps NASH with possible SBP as the inciting trigger. He was
not a candidate for any intervention given his critical status.
#Renal Failure: Patient presented with non gap metabolic
acidosis, likely in RTA in setting of renal failure. His renal
failure was likely due to hypoperfusion from sepsis with low CO
and was anuric. Bladder pressure is approximately ___ and
there may be an element of abdominal compartment syndrome but
suspect ATN given hyoperfusion. Patient's family was informed
about options of CVVH, but ultimately decided against further
intervention.
#Coronary Artery Disease/atypical chest pain: Per report,
patient presented with atypical chest pain, with no gross EKG
changes and normal troponin. Patient was given full dose
aspirin. It appears last echocardiogram was with preserved EF
with possible basal inferior hypokinesis. Bedside ECHO shows
fairly normal overall cardiac function initially.

-Multi-Organ Failure
-Septic Shock
-Acute Hypoxic Failure
-Anuric Renal Failure

ASESSMENT and PLAN:
Mr. ___ is a ___ M w PMHx of HTN, HLD, DMII who 
presented with sudden onset dizzines and falling to the R at 
~1600 on ___ and received tPA at ~1800 at ___. He 
was then transferred to ___ for further management. 
Clinically, his exam is consistent with a cerebellar insult - 
confirmed by imaging. His CTA appears to show a cutoff of the R 
___ and MRI brain shows small, incomplete ___ territory 
infarction with extension into the lateral medulla. 
Etiology is likely multifactorial as he has HTN, HLD, and DM2. 
Mr. ___ was monitoring x24hrs post-24hrs in the ICU with 
optimization of medical risk favors. He was stable >24hrs s/p 
tPA and was transferred to the floor. On the floor, ___ felt that 
givened continued ataxia with gait, he'd benefit from rehab. 
Etiology is unlikely to be artery-artery embolic given clean CTA 
and unlikely to be cardioembolic given clean echo and negative 
telemetry in house. Primary vascular occlusion (given his 
vasculopath risk factors) was felt to be the most likely 
etiology.

OSA control will be extremely important to prevent risk for 
future stroke as well. We do recommend outpatient sleep study 
evaluation for Mr. ___. 

#NEURO - partial ___ territory infarct
- MRI: R cerebellar and R lateral medulla restricted diffusion
- repeat NCHCT @ 24hrs post-tPA stable without blood
-- ASA81 and SQH restarted
- BP well controlled on home BP meds
- LDL 105 and HBA1c 7.7
- passed bedside swallow, but per family has been coughing
-- also passed formal swallow evaluation for regular consistency 
diet
- increased home lovastatin 40->80 mg daily given LDL of 105
- per family, very poor and fractured sleep -> c/f OSA
-- recommend outpatient sleep study

# CV:
- CE negative
- Monitor by telemetry
- BP well controlled on home medications
- TTE of poor quality but no definite valvular pathology or 
pathologic flow identified
- ___ considered but felt to be low yield given the negative 
telemetry in house and given multiple vascular risk factors. 

# ENDO:
- Finger sticks QID, insulin sliding scale as an inpatient
- Restarted home metformin on discharge 

# FEN:
- passed bedside and formal S+S

# TOX/METAB:
- LFTs WNL
- urine and serum tox screens WNL

# ID:
- UA with blood but no infection
- CXR without evidence of infiltrate or PNA

Extended Care

R ___ stroke

Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted with a stroke in the R back of your brain - 
this caused you to be uncoordinated on the R side. Your risk 
factors for stroke are your high blood pressure, high 
cholesterol, and diabetes and it will be important to keep these 
under good control. 

Given that your cholesterol was high (LDL 105, we like LDL to be 
around 70 after for stroke prevention), we increased your home 
statin dose to Lovastatin 80 mg daily. You should take aspirin 
81 mg daily as well to decrease your risk for future stroke.
