Brief Hospital Course:
ASESSMENT and PLAN:
Mr. ___ is a ___ M w PMHx of HTN, HLD, DMII who
presented with sudden onset dizzines and falling to the R at
~1600 on ___ and received tPA at ~1800 at ___. He
was then transferred to ___ for further management.
Clinically, his exam is consistent with a cerebellar insult -
confirmed by imaging. His CTA appears to show a cutoff of the R
___ and MRI brain shows small, incomplete ___ territory
infarction with extension into the lateral medulla.
Etiology is likely multifactorial as he has HTN, HLD, and DM2.
Mr. ___ was monitoring x24hrs post-24hrs in the ICU with
optimization of medical risk favors. He was stable >24hrs s/p
tPA and was transferred to the floor. On the floor, ___ felt that
givened continued ataxia with gait, he'd benefit from rehab.
Etiology is unlikely to be artery-artery embolic given clean CTA
and unlikely to be cardioembolic given clean echo and negative
telemetry in house. Primary vascular occlusion (given his
vasculopath risk factors) was felt to be the most likely
etiology.
OSA control will be extremely important to prevent risk for
future stroke as well. We do recommend outpatient sleep study
evaluation for Mr. ___.
#NEURO - partial ___ territory infarct
- MRI: R cerebellar and R lateral medulla restricted diffusion
- repeat NCHCT @ 24hrs post-tPA stable without blood
-- ASA81 and SQH restarted
- BP well controlled on home BP meds
- LDL 105 and HBA1c 7.7
- passed bedside swallow, but per family has been coughing
-- also passed formal swallow evaluation for regular consistency
diet
- increased home lovastatin 40->80 mg daily given LDL of 105
- per family, very poor and fractured sleep -> c/f OSA
-- recommend outpatient sleep study
# CV:
- CE negative
- Monitor by telemetry
- BP well controlled on home medications
- TTE of poor quality but no definite valvular pathology or
pathologic flow identified
- ___ considered but felt to be low yield given the negative
telemetry in house and given multiple vascular risk factors.
# ENDO:
- Finger sticks QID, insulin sliding scale as an inpatient
- Restarted home metformin on discharge
# FEN:
- passed bedside and formal S+S
# TOX/METAB:
- LFTs WNL
- urine and serum tox screens WNL
# ID:
- UA with blood but no infection
- CXR without evidence of infiltrate or PNA

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted with a stroke in the R back of your brain -
this caused you to be uncoordinated on the R side. Your risk
factors for stroke are your high blood pressure, high
cholesterol, and diabetes and it will be important to keep these
under good control.
Given that your cholesterol was high (LDL 105, we like LDL to be
around 70 after for stroke prevention), we increased your home
statin dose to Lovastatin 80 mg daily. You should take aspirin
81 mg daily as well to decrease your risk for future stroke.

atrium or left atrial appendage. No atrial septal defect is seen 
by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are 
normal. Regional left ventricular wall motion is normal. Overall 
left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The 
ascending aorta is mildly dilated. There are simple atheroma in 
the descending thoracic aorta. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are 
mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Mild (1+) 
aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There 
is no pericardial effusion. Dr. ___ was notified in

Patient is A paced and receiving an infusion of Phenylephrine. 
Biventricular systolic function is unchanged. Mild mitral 
regurgitation persists. Aorta is intact post decannulation. Rest 
of examination is unchanged.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Referred to cardiac catheterization and found to have left main 
disease.  Was admitted to the hospital, cardiac surgery was 
consulted and underwent preoperative workup.  On ___ he was 
taken to the operating room for coronary artery bypass graft 
surgery.  See operative report for further details.  Post 
operatively he was taken to the intensive care unit for 
management. That evening he was weaned from sedation, awoke 
neurologically intact and was extubated without complications.  
Post operative day one he was started on betablocker and 
diuretic.  He continued to progress and was transferred to the 
floor.  Chest tubes and epicardial wires were removed per 
protocol.  He was noted on post operative day two for epitaxis 
which was treated with pressure and afrin which resolved.  He 
was placed on ocean spray for moisture with good response.  His 
blood levels remained stable.  Physical therapy worked with him 
on strength and mobility with recommendation for home.  He 
continued to progress and was discharged home with services on 
post operative day four.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F with h/o opioid dependence and IVDU 
with recent use, 15 weeks pregnant, who presents with L arm 
redness and swelling c/w cellulitis in the setting of recent 
injection drug use in the area, found to have GPC bloodstream 
infection and LUE DVT.

Acute Group A Strep bloodstream infection:
LUE cellulitis with septic thrombophlebitis:
Possible acute aortic valve endocarditis
Source of BSI is LUE cellulitis caused by injection use in that 
arm.  US negative for abscess, though exam has a superficial 
thrombophlebitis.  The erythema has extended beyond the initial 
boundaries, which could be due to her DVT.  She is on 
appropriate antibiotic therapy based on culture data so for now 
will monitor.  There is no sign for septic joint currently based 
on exam.  Her echo was reviewed and findings raised concern for 
AV endocarditis/vegetation.  She currently has no signs/symptoms 
of CHF
- ID consulted: recommending CTX 2g IV q24, day 1 = ___.  ___ 
weeks of treatment recommended
- SHE WILL REQUIRE TEE TO EVALUATE FOR AV ENDOCARDITIS.
- Monitor LUE for extension of erythema swelling.  Could 
consider re-imaging  if continues to worsen.
- Pain control with PO and IV Morphine as below.

Hypotension:
Hypotension on the night of admission since stabilized.  Likely 
multifactorial to include clonidine use for withdrawal symptoms 
the first nite, and infection with volume depletion.  BP 
improved with IVF.  Normal lactate re-assuring.
- Clonidine stopped
- Monitor BP.  DC BP 110s/80s

Acute LUE DVT:
Found on US.  Likely provoked in setting of IVDU and cellulitis. 
 Her pregnancy state is also contributing.  This is likely 
contributing to her worsening LUE swelling
- Elevation, warm packs
- Lovenox 1mg/kg q12 startged: 50mg SC q12
- In discussion with ___, recommend continuing therapy for 6 
months and/or 6 weeks after delivery of her baby

Opioid dependence with IVDU and withdrawal:
Has had periods of sobriety with medication maintenance: 
suboxone and methadone in the past.  She came in with mild-mod 
withdrawal, but became hypotensive with clonidine.  Given her 
ongoing pain, she was initiated on PO and IV Morphine which 
would alleviate her withdrawal symptoms.  Please see below for 
dosing.  SW met with the patient and she expressed desire to 
stop IV heroin.

Pregnancy:
US reviewed.  ___ consulted here.  Started prenatal vitamins.  
HIV and HBV negative.  GC/Chlamydia negative.
- RPR, rubella, varicella, PENDING ON TRANSFER

HCV:
HCV serology negative last year.  This is reported and will need 
confirmation

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. This patient is not taking any preadmission medications

7.  Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY  
8.  Promethazine 25 mg PO Q6H:PRN nausea

Extended Care

Group B strep acute bloodstream infection/sepsis
Left upper extremity cellulitis
Left upper extremity DVT with superficial thrombophlebitis
Opioid dependence/IV heroin use
Chronic HCV

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old gentleman with history of hepatitis C 
who presents with accidental PineSol ingestion and was 
subsequently found to have acute renal failure, which improved 
to the patient's approximate baseline with fluids.

ACTIVE ISSUES:
===============
# Acute renal failure
# Anion gap acidosis: 
The patient presented for accidental PineSol ingestion, but 
admission labs were remarkable for a serum creatinine of 3.7 and 
FENa of 0.44% with a mild gap acidosis. Urinalysis was 
unremarkable and sediment analysis was nondiagnostic. Creatinine 
downtrended with IV fluids, likely in response to volume 
depletion in the setting of poor fluid intake combined with mild 
starvation ketoacidosis from poor PO intake. Cr returned to 
normal at 1.0 at time of discharge.
  
# Toxic Ingestion: 
The patient initially presented to the Emergency Department for 
an accidental PineSol ingestion; per the patient, he had 
accidentally drank approximately 2 tablespoons of cleaner that 
his wife had poured into a cup on a table to use for cleaning, 
thinking it was tea. He denied any suicidal ideations or 
thoughts of self-harm with assessment by psychiatry during 
hospitalization. Admission labs were remarkable for an elevated 
anion gap of 23 that normalized with fluids but thought to be a 
separate process as discussed above. A toxicology consult was 
called, but the amount of toxin the patient ingested and the 
timing of the observed laboratory abnormalities were not 
consistent with damage due to acute toxin ingestion so no 
further intervention was warranted. 

# Polysubstance Abuse: 
The patient endorsed a history of both heroin and cocaine abuse, 
using both substances multiple times per week. Urine toxicology 
screen was positive for both substances on admission. He was 
placed on ___ protocol with lorazepam, methocarbamol, 
loperamide, and Vistaril as needed. A social work consult was 
placed in order to help the patient transition to a ___ 
clinic for further management of opiate abuse, in an effort to 
maintain and promote sobriety.

# Depression: 
The psychiatry consult liaison service was consulted; the 
patient expressed no suicidal or homicidal ideations. He denied 
ingesting PineSol in an effort to harm himself. Recommended 
continued follow-up on an outpatient basis.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
==============
# Hepatitis C: 
The patient has a history of chronic hepatitis C, diagnosed in 
___. Hepatitis C viral load was 8,850,000 IU/mL. The patient 
will follow-up with his new primary care physician for further 
evaluation and treatment.

# Tobacco Abuse: 
The patient was maintained on a nicotine patch while in-house

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
=====================
- Needs to regularly establish care with a primary care 
physician, appointment arranged
- Continue Hepatitis C monitoring on an outpatient basis
- Recommend intensive outpatient detoxification program for 
heroin and cocaine addiction with referral for ___ clinic, 
which patient reported had been a barrier before
- Ensure adequate hydration and PO intake given acute kidney 
injury that resolved with fluids
- Recommend outpatient psychiatry referral
- Encourage smoking cessation

# Code Status: Full Code
# CONTACT: ___ ___
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Naproxen 500 mg PO Q12H 

 
Discharge Medications:
None
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis:
Acute Kidney Injury
Toxic Ingestion

Secondary Diagnosis:
Heroin Abuse
Cocaine Abuse

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Intermittently Alert and interactive vs 
sleepy and lethargic.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a plasure taking care of you at ___ 
___. You were admitted for an accidental ingestion of 
PineSol. Additionally, your kidneys were injured from inadequate 
fluid intake. You were given IV fluids and your kidney function 
improved. 

Avoiding further heroin and cocaine use is essential for your 
health. You can injure your kidneys and other vital organs, such 
as your brain and your heart with continued drug use. 

Please avoid NSAID use (aspirin, ibuprofen, naproxen, etc.) due 
to your kidney injury, you can use Tylenol if needed for pain 
(do not exceed maximum dose of 3 grams per day). 

Please attend all of your follow-up appointments as scheduled. 
If you need to change an appointment, please attempt to make a 
new appointment as close to your originally scheduled 
appointment, in order to ensure safe follow-up.

We wish you the best in health,

Your Care Team at ___
 
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is ___ with h/o CAD who was transferred from ___ 
___ with an NSTEMI. Per report, the patient was at his 
wife's wake earlier in the day, returned to his apartment felt 
unwell and tired, with one episode of emesis. He denied ever 
having chest pain or shortness of breath. As per report, he sat 
down and then went outside for some fresh air, and his symptoms 
improved mildly.  Given the aforementioned symptoms, the patient 
presented to the ___ for eval. Troponin was elevated at 
1.02. EKG was notable for  "diffuse ST elevations"
Also noted to have creat 1.9, and HCT 25. While there is was 
given full dose ASA and started on heparin drip; also given 
zofran for nausea. The family was undecided about the option for 
cath, but the patient was transferred here in the setting of 
possible cath. 

  
In the ___ ___, inital VS: 96.8 100 113/76 15 100%. The patient 
was found to be in atrial fibrillation (unsure how new). EKG 
revealed ST depression in V2-V4. Posterior EKG with out STE. 
Labs notable for HCT 28; troponin here 0.41. Heparin drip was 
continued. The patient hypotensive in the ___ with SBPs in 
___. He received 1L bolus with minimal improvement in BPs. 
Given anemia, supratherapeutic PTT and hypotension, a rectal was 
performed ( guiac neg).  After rectal was performed the patient 
became unresponsive, eye rolled to the back of his head, became 
bradycardic to the ___ and hypotensive to the ___. Another liter 
of NS was run wide open. Pt's pressure improved to 105/70 with 
three-fourths of the liter in. Decison was made to transfer to 
CCU for further care.

On the floor the patient denies any chest pain and shortness of 
breath. Had on emesis of bilous emesis relieved with zofran.  
Collateral information was obtained from the family. The patient 
had two episodes of syncope while leaving his wife's wake with 
out LOC but no head strike. Was caught by his son prior to 
falling. LOC lasted ___ secs each time, and was then 
responsive to voice. The patient denies any prodromal sx prior 
to the syncope. Never had CP or SOB but was nauseous. He denies 
any prior anginal sx with exertion or at rest prior to this 
episode, but family reports that he has had some decondition 
during the last ___ months secondary to the weather and being 
less active.

Also of note the pt and family report that he has had previous 
vagal episode in the setting of having a colonoscopy.

Name: ___ Unit No: ___ Admission Date: ___ Discharge Date: ___ Date of Birth: ___ Sex: M Service: PSYCHIATRY Allergies: Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs Attending: ___. Chief Complaint: "I'm so anxious, no one will help me at ___ when it comes to my mental issues" Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: None History of Present Illness: Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o M, w/hx of PSA and dependence, hx of Mood d/o NOS, hx of previous suicide attempts (unclear how accurate), transferred from ___ after recent detox after expressing suicidal ideation after transferred to ___ program today. Sent to ___ ED on ___ for safety evaluation. Mr. ___ reports that he had some sobriety for the first two months of the year, when he relapsed on Vicodin, clonazepam, methadone, and alcohol. Per BEST,was at ___ from ___ for unknown reasons. He then presented to ___ ___ ED for detox, and Tox Screen + for benzos and cocaine, and was transferred to ___ for detox on ___ he was detoxed from benzo's and opiates. Then on ___ was stepped down to the ___ residential treatment program. At ___, pt. exhibited irritability, and expressed anger towards hospital policies such as insurance issues, not being able to be prescribed particular meds such as methadone or ativan. He then endorsed SI and intent to act upon it on ___ pt. reports "a check" coming in on the ___, and plans to get a hotel room, buy pills, and overdose per the DDART progress notes. Then per the PN, stated he had many "insurance coverage concerns", and he wants to "say the right thing", "so that I can get the best treatment". DOC was notified, and then reported he wanted to cut himself. Pt. confirms the story above, and reports that he is quite upset at how his "mental issues" are being ignored at ___, when asked to be more specific, states that he was not on a high enough dose of methadone and not prescribed ativan. Per BEST, they stated that he was to be discharged today from ___ as he had no more authorized days left per their report, and was to start a PHP there while staying at ___ ___ and that the above mentioned concerns about insurance coverage, may be related to possible pending discharge. Pt. denies this was an issue. Reports currently his anxiety and depressed mood are so overwhelming right now, with acute stressor of cousin's suicide last week, that he continues to think about suicide. States he may OD, or may cut wrists, not quite sure. States that unless he gets treated with "methadone and ativan", he doesn't know "what I might do". But, then reports some future orientation about wanting to get finances straightened out, find housing resources, etc. Upon ROS: reports daily anxiety, depressed mood, mood lability often becoming easily irritable/angry, poor sleep, some decreased pleasure in activities, difficulty concentrating, impulsivity evidenced by substance abuse and impulsive financial decisions. Denies AVH/IOR/PI.
Tox Screen +cocaine today; slightly possible that it may be from use last week, denies use during stay at ___ or at ___ today. Per BEST team, there are a number of inconsistencies in the Past Hx, Social Hx, and HPIs in their previous evaluations, so the below information may not completely be accurate; discrepancies will be noted below. Also noted that in some past evaluations, pt. would present for detox ___, and at times when he found out he would not be admitted, would suddenly endorse SI, though he had in the initial work-up.
Pt. becomes extremely upset, when I request to speak with collateral info re: his safety in recent past prior to ___. Refuses to let me speak with his parents, sister, or friend (whose house he was staying at). Past Medical History: Past Dx: Depression Past Admissions: Most recently at ___ as stated above, last at ___ in ___ and states he has been there a total of about 6 times. ___ in ___ (pt. denies this). Reports stays at ___ in the past. Previous Med Trials: Vistaril, Neurontin, Paxil (sexual dysfunction) Previous Suicide Attempts: Per pt. reports 3 attempts; states he had 3 overdoses, most recent in ___ which required an ICU stay per his report. Per BEST evals, some evaluations say he had 10 suicide attempts, others state "none ever", with various methods that are inconsistent with other evaluations. So, very unclear. Current Treaters: none
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Reports Hepatitis C, denies IVDU. ALLERGIES: NKDA Social History: SUBSTANCE ABUSE HISTORY: Pt. denies tobacco or IVDU. Longstanding hx of polysubstance abuse/dependence, states he started using since the age of ___, ___ notes say drinking about a pint a day until his admission, pt. reports a couple drinks per day. Also was using methadone ___ per day bought from the streets, as well as Klonopin 8mg per day until his admission at ___. Reports longest sobriety was 4 months in ___ ___ notes say 11 months in ___. Denies hx of withdrawal seizures, DTs, hallucinosis. Has had multiple detox and dual dx admissions. Has some hx of AA/NA involvement. Has a sponsor per his report.
SOCIAL HISTORY: ___ Family History: Mother with depression, Aunt with ___ FAMILY Hx of Suicide: Reports cousin committed suicide by OD last week, and brother with suicide by CO poisoning at age ___. Physical Exam: VS: 98.3; 78; 152/98; 18; 98% RA
PE: stable for admission
MSE: APPEARANCE & FACIAL EXPRESSION: Caucasian M, overweight, in hospital gown,laying on gurney (initially pupils dilated). BEHAVIOR: No involuntary movements noted; no psychomotor agitation/retardation noted ATTITUDE: uncooperative with interview at times SPEECH: (on initial interview had rapid rate) but on subsequent interviews normal rate, able to be interrupted, normal volume, prosody, no dysarthria noted MOOD: "anxious" AFFECT: irritable, limited range THOUGHT FORM: generally linear, but can be circumstantial at times, easily redirected THOUGHT CONTENT: no overt delusions noted, denies paranoia ABNORMAL PERCEPTIONS: denies audiovisual Hallucinations NEUROVEGETATIVE SYMPTOMS: see above SUICIDALITY/HOMICIDALITY: reports SI without specific plan or intent at this time, but makes conditional statement, saying "if I can't get the help I need for my mental issues, I don't know what I may do". INSIGHT AND JUDGMENT: limited/limited
COGNITIVE ASSESSMENT: SENSORIUM (E.G., ALERT, DROWSY, SOMNOLENT): Alert ORIENTATION: Oriented to year, month, date, ___ ATTENTION (DIGIT SPAN, SERIAL SEVENS, ETC.): refuses MOYB MEMORY: refuses CALCULATIONS: 7 quarters in $1.75 FUND OF KNOWLEDGE: appropriate PROVERB INTERPRETATION: refuses Pertinent Results: ___ 04:30PM ALT(SGPT)-104* AST(SGOT)-49* ALK PHOS-64 TOT BILI-0.3 ___ 04:30PM CHOLEST-147 ___ 04:30PM %HbA1c-7.4* ___ 04:30PM TRIGLYCER-361* HDL CHOL-20 CHOL/HDL-7.4 LDL(CALC)-55 ___ 01:15AM GLUCOSE-327* UREA N-15 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-131* POTASSIUM-4.2 CHLORIDE-96 TOTAL CO2-30 ANION GAP-9 ___ 01:15AM ASA-NEG ETHANOL-NEG ACETMNPHN-NEG bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG tricyclic-NEG ___:15AM URINE bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG opiates-NEG cocaine-POS amphetmn-NEG mthdone-NEG ___ 01:15AM WBC-9.1 RBC-5.08 HGB-15.7 HCT-42.7 MCV-84 MCH-30.8 MCHC-36.7* RDW-12.6 ___ 01:15AM NEUTS-59.4 ___ MONOS-6.5 EOS-1.7 BASOS-0.7 ___ 01:15AM URINE COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Clear SP ___ ___ 01:15AM URINE BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG GLUCOSE-1000 KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-7.0 LEUK-NEG Brief Hospital Course: 1. LEGAL Patient was admitted on a conditional voluntary.
2. PSYCHIATRIC On admission the patient was placed on 15 minutes checks because he felt safe, was not actively suicidal and reported he would be able to talk to staff if he developed thoughts of hurting himself. A safety plan was made and placed in his chart. On admission the patient's trazodone was stopped and he was started on Mirtazapine 7.5mg QHS to help improve his sleep, mood and anxiety. He reported continued poor sleep so his Mirtazapine was increased to 15mg and then again to 30mg daily. Hydroxazine 50mg PRN was used for anxiety throughout the day with good clinical effect. The patient requested Wellbutrin and trazodone, but he was encouraged to be patient with the Mirtazapine as he had only been on it for a couple of days. By hospital day 5 the patient reported that his sxs had much improved on mirtazepine. He was feeling less anxious and depressed and also reported that he was more hopeful about the future. He had several goals in place including working on his housing and improving his physical health (via diet and exercise) to address his new onset DM. He had no further thoughts of self harm. He was tolerating the mirtazepine well. He was discharged on Mirtazepine as well as Hydroxazine PRN QHS.
3. MEDICAL On ED admission the pt was noted to have an elevated glucose at 327. Repeat labs 9 hours later revealed a persistent elevated Glu of 239. A hemoglobin A1c and lipid profile were notable for hgba1c 7.4 and elevated triglyceride of 361. The pt denied personal h/o of DM but reported a strong family h/o of adult-onset ___ clinic was consulted for further recs. They evaluated the pt and diagnosed him with diabetes mellitus. He was started on Glyburide 5mg daily and Lispro Insulin sliding scale. He had finger sticks QAC and QHS and closely monitored by ___. His BS remained not well controlled and thus his glyburide was increased to 5mg BID and then later to 7.5mg BID. He also required insulin coverage via sliding scale. He was not started on Metformin secondary to elevated LFTs (ALT 104, AST 49) believed to be due to his h/o of Hep C and/or past Etoh abuse. His LFTs did later improve (suggesting ETOH hepatitis as the source) but metformin was still avoided given pt's strong ETOH hx and concern that if he would relapse it would be dangerous for him to be on Metformin. Insulin as an outpt was discussed with ___. They felt that given that the pt is homeless, has no current outpt PCP and it is unclear whether he could be able to handle insulin injections on his own, it was best that insulin be avoided as an outpt especially as his BS were showing improving with oral agents alone. Nutrition was consulted to help the pt develop better eating habits. The patient was also provided with handouts educating him on Diabetes and the ___ provided him with a glucometer. The ___ clinic did wish to see the patient as an outpatient and the clinic was contacted to schedule an appt for the patient. Unfortunately at the timing of this note the clinic had not yet established a specific appt date. The patient was provided with their number and instructed to call there and arrange to be seen in one month by Dr. ___ fellow. The patient's PCP, ___, was also contacted. She was not available to make an appt so the patient was instructed to contact her office and make a f/u appt within the next ___ weeks.
4. PSYCHOSOCIAL The patient made an effort to attend groups at times. He intermittently participated in the milieu. During the first few days of admission his mood was occassionally a bit labile especially with regards to decisions about his disposition planning. However by the time of discharge he was pleasant and cooperative and was eager to work with the social worker and case manager to help with his disposition.
5. DISPO Patient is being discharged to ___ program ___ ___ ___. Since he is being discharged to this facility and thereafter to a partial program, they will need to arrange for outpatient treaters including psychiatrist and therapist. As noted in HPI, the patient currently does not have a psychiatrist or therapist. Medications on Admission: (per ___ Med List) *Trazodone 100mg PO qhs *Folate, thiamine, multivitamin *prn motrin 400mg PO q4hrs *prn mylanta *prn MOM ___: 1. ___ 30 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime). LEGAL Patient was admitted on a conditional voluntary.
2. PSYCHIATRIC On admission the patient was placed on 15 minutes checks because he felt safe, was not actively suicidal and reported he would be able to talk to staff if he developed thoughts of hurting himself. A safety plan was made and placed in his chart. On admission the patient's trazodone was stopped and he was started on Mirtazapine 7.5mg QHS to help improve his sleep, mood and anxiety. He reported continued poor sleep so his Mirtazapine was increased to 15mg and then again to 30mg daily. Hydroxazine 50mg PRN was used for anxiety throughout the day with good clinical effect. The patient requested Wellbutrin and trazodone, but he was encouraged to be patient with the Mirtazapine as he had only been on it for a couple of days. By hospital day 5 the patient reported that his sxs had much improved on mirtazepine. He was feeling less anxious and depressed and also reported that he was more hopeful about the future. He had several goals in place including working on his housing and improving his physical health (via diet and exercise) to address his new onset DM. He had no further thoughts of self harm. He was tolerating the mirtazepine well. He was discharged on Mirtazepine as well as Hydroxazine PRN QHS.
3. MEDICAL On ED admission the pt was noted to have an elevated glucose at 327. Repeat labs 9 hours later revealed a persistent elevated Glu of 239. A hemoglobin A1c and lipid profile were notable for hgba1c 7.4 and elevated triglyceride of 361. The pt denied personal h/o of DM but reported a strong family h/o of adult-onset ___ clinic was consulted for further recs. They evaluated the pt and diagnosed him with diabetes mellitus. He was started on Glyburide 5mg daily and Lispro Insulin sliding scale. He had finger sticks QAC and QHS and closely monitored by ___. His BS remained not well controlled and thus his glyburide was increased to 5mg BID and then later to 7.5mg BID. He also required insulin coverage via sliding scale. He was not started on Metformin secondary to elevated LFTs (ALT 104, AST 49) believed to be due to his h/o of Hep C and/or past Etoh abuse. His LFTs did later improve (suggesting ETOH hepatitis as the source) but metformin was still avoided given pt's strong ETOH hx and concern that if he would relapse it would be dangerous for him to be on Metformin. Insulin as an outpt was discussed with ___. They felt that given that the pt is homeless, has no current outpt PCP and it is unclear whether he could be able to handle insulin injections on his own, it was best that insulin be avoided as an outpt especially as his BS were showing improving with oral agents alone. Nutrition was consulted to help the pt develop better eating habits. The patient was also provided with handouts educating him on Diabetes and the ___ provided him with a glucometer. The ___ clinic did wish to see the patient as an outpatient and the clinic was contacted to schedule an appt for the patient. Unfortunately at the timing of this note the clinic had not yet established a specific appt date. The patient was provided with their number and instructed to call there and arrange to be seen in one month by Dr. ___ fellow. The patient's PCP, ___, was also contacted. She was not available to make an appt so the patient was instructed to contact her office and make a f/u appt within the next ___ weeks.
4. PSYCHOSOCIAL The patient made an effort to attend groups at times. He intermittently participated in the milieu. During the first few days of admission his mood was occassionally a bit labile especially with regards to decisions about his disposition planning. However by the time of discharge he was pleasant and cooperative and was eager to work with the social worker and case manager to help with his disposition.
5. DISPO Patient is being discharged to ___ program ___ ___ ___. Since he is being discharged to this facility and thereafter to a partial program, they will need to arrange for outpatient treaters including psychiatrist and therapist. Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo female with h/o HTN, PMR, hypothyroidism, severe 
scoliosis, OA with recent weight loss presenting after an 
episode of confusion which has now resolved.  
.  
# Altered mental status: 
Briefly, the patient described feeling "shaking inside" in the 
evening, and was nervous, went to sleep around midnight and woke 
up the following day at 2pm when her daughter came by.  Patient 
had not been eating or taking her meds at home the day of her 
confusional episode per her daughter and was not making sense on 
finding her after she had woken up, but there was no evidence of 
neurologic abnormalities, urinary or fecal incontinnce or trauma 
and patient remembers feeling disoriented and no observed 
seizure acitivity, making seizure unlikely. She denies CP and 
ECG was unremarkable for ischemic changes but does have somewhat 
prolonged QT, but ACS unlikley. Could have been arrythmia, but 
sx do not seem to fit with this and no LOC. She has no focal 
infectious findings and CXR, UA and head CT were unremarkable 
and she is afebrile. Her TSH on ___ was 4.1, making 
hypothyroidism/hyperthyroidism very unlikley. Also, consider 
depression, but unlikely to present with an acute altered mental 
status. Given her poor PO intake, it is possible that she became 
dehydrated and delerious from this. The only laboratory 
abnormality was hypokalemia which may be nutritional in 
combination with diuretic. She is also on meds that can cause 
confusion including neurontin and mirtazapine, but there have 
been no recent changes in the doses and she is now asymptomatic. 
She has been on the neurontin and tramadol for ___ years per her 
daughter-the daughter investigated her pill box and they were 
correctly allotted.  

Pt completed her ___, no events on tele. She is currently close 
to her baseline as per her daughter and patient. Daughter aids 
the patient very much and is interested in home services.  

B12, folate, TSH were checked and within normal limits, RPR 
pending.
Her state of "inner shakiness" is felt to be due to 
hypovolemia/lack of po intake, and possibly medication effect.  
She will be going home with her daughter, then will have home 
services.  Her family and the patient are not interested in 
placement at this time. They will arrange for a companion for 
the patient throughout the day.
.  
# Hypokalemia: Likely nutritional and may have baseline loses 
___ to diuretic  
She will go home on 20mg po q day K-dur until ___ when it 
will be rechecked, and followed up by her PCP.
.  
# HTN: continued on her home meds  
.  
# ___ edema: left lower extremity more edematous than the right 
in the past, chronic from left hip surgery, no palpable cords, 
right ___ appeared more edematous on this admission, ___ was 
done which was negative for DVT.
.
# Hypothyroidism: TSH 4.4. Continue levothyroxine  
.  
# OA: continue neurontin, celebrex, tramadol  
.  
# GERD/hiatal hernia: continnued reglan, PPI and H2 blocker  
.  
# FEN/GI - diet, electrolyte repletion prn  
.  
# PPx - hep sc, bowel regimen  
.  
# Code - Full for now as she feels "if something could be done I 
would want it, but I wouldn't wantto be kept on machines." In 
discussion, seems that she is considering being DNR/DNI but has 
not specifically decided this or discussed this with her 
daughter ___, who is her HCP.  
.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo female with h/o HTN, PMR, hypothyroidism, severe
scoliosis, OA with recent weight loss presenting after an
episode of confusion which has now resolved.
.
# Altered mental status:
Briefly, the patient described feeling "shaking inside" in the
evening, and was nervous, went to sleep around midnight and woke
up the following day at 2pm when her daughter came by. Patient
had not been eating or taking her meds at home the day of her
confusional episode per her daughter and was not making sense on
finding her after she had woken up, but there was no evidence of
neurologic abnormalities, urinary or fecal incontinnce or trauma
and patient remembers feeling disoriented and no observed
seizure acitivity, making seizure unlikely. She denies CP and
ECG was unremarkable for ischemic changes but does have somewhat
prolonged QT, but ACS unlikley. Could have been arrythmia, but
sx do not seem to fit with this and no LOC. She has no focal
infectious findings and CXR, UA and head CT were unremarkable
and she is afebrile. Her TSH on ___ was 4.1, making
hypothyroidism/hyperthyroidism very unlikley. Also, consider
depression, but unlikely to present with an acute altered mental
status. Given her poor PO intake, it is possible that she became
dehydrated and delerious from this. The only laboratory
abnormality was hypokalemia which may be nutritional in
combination with diuretic. She is also on meds that can cause
confusion including neurontin and mirtazapine, but there have
been no recent changes in the doses and she is now asymptomatic.
She has been on the neurontin and tramadol for ___ years per her
daughter-the daughter investigated her pill box and they were
correctly allotted.
Pt completed her ___, no events on tele. She is currently close
to her baseline as per her daughter and patient. Daughter aids
the patient very much and is interested in home services.
B12, folate, TSH were checked and within normal limits, RPR
pending.
Her state of "inner shakiness" is felt to be due to
hypovolemia/lack of po intake, and possibly medication effect.
She will be going home with her daughter, then will have home
services. Her family and the patient are not interested in
placement at this time. They will arrange for a companion for
the patient throughout the day.
.
# Hypokalemia: Likely nutritional and may have baseline loses
___ to diuretic
She will go home on 20mg po q day K-dur until ___ when it
will be rechecked, and followed up by her PCP.
.
# HTN: continued on her home meds
.
# ___ edema: left lower extremity more edematous than the right
in the past, chronic from left hip surgery, no palpable cords,
right ___ appeared more edematous on this admission, ___ was
done which was negative for DVT.
.
# Hypothyroidism: TSH 4.4. Continue levothyroxine
.
# OA: continue neurontin, celebrex, tramadol
.
# GERD/hiatal hernia: continnued reglan, PPI and H2 blocker
.
# FEN/GI - diet, electrolyte repletion prn
.
# PPx - hep sc, bowel regimen
.
# Code - Full for now as she feels "if something could be done I
would want it, but I wouldn't wantto be kept on machines." In
discussion, seems that she is considering being DNR/DNI but has
not specifically decided this or discussed this with her
daughter ___, who is her HCP.
.

___ h/o sarcoid, myasthenia ___ s/p thymectomy, hypertension,

___ transferred to ___ due to concern for 
ischemic colitis.

Ms. ___ was in her usual state of health yesterday morning. 
She notes she felt quite well. However, around noon time while 
she was driving she describes acute onset abdominal cramping, 
which were primarily ___ in nature. Due to these 
cramps, she decided to drive back home. As she got out her car, 
she felt lightheaded and diaphoretic and had a syncopal episode. 
She was down for a few minutes then was able to get up and go 
into her home. She went to the restroom and had an episode of 
hematochezia. As we went to get up from the toilet, she again 
felt lightheaded and had a syncopal episode. This cycle repeated 
about 4 times with repeated syncopal episodes as she tried to 
stand up and episodes of hematochezia. She also noted right 
ankle pain. Due to the repeat episodes as well as her right 
ankle pain, she decided to go to the hospital. 

Notably, she describes previously episodes of significant 
cramping in the past which has attributed to IBS. Her last 
bleeding episodes was about ___ years ago, she does not recall 
what the etiology was.

She has been eating and drinking well, but admits she has been 
under significant amount of stress. She does not take NSAIDs or 
other blood thinners. Her last colonoscopy was in ___ and it 
showed hemorrhoids. She notes she has had awake colonoscopies 
due to her risk with sedation given her myasthenia ___. 

In the ___, she was hemodynamically stable without 
significant decrease in her Hct. However, her CBC showed 19% 
bands. ___ with Cr: 1.6 ___: 0.9-1). Lactate of 1.7. Troponin: 
0.01.  EKG showed sinus tachycardia without ischemic changes. CT 
(w/ PO contrast) showed colonic wall thickening involving the 
distal transverse colon and descending colon. They noted 
ischemic colitis as their primary differential. She also had R 
ankle XR which was initially read without fracture, however has 
subsequently been read as nondisplaced oblique fracture of the 
distal fibular shaft. Due to her significant bandemia and 
concern for decompensation, she was transferred to the ___.

In the ___ ___, she continued to be HD stable. Her labs were 
stable with resolved bandemia and improved renal function. GI 
was consulted in the ___.

During my interview, she notes her pain has resolved. She has 
had subsequent bowel movement without evidence of hematochezia. 
She has had no nausea or vomiting.

Colonoscopy:
Erythema and petechiae in the sigmoid colon and distal 
descending colon compatible with mild colitis (biopsy)
The prep was inadequate to detect polyps. Because of the poor 
prep in the cecum, the terminal ileum was unable to be entered.
Otherwise normal colonoscopy to cecum

CT A/P Second Read - IMPRESSION: 
Limited noncontrast examination demonstrates likely thickening 
of the
descending colon, suggestive of colitis.  This finding is 
nonspecific, but
most likely infectious.  Given relatively limited 
atherosclerotic disease
burden, ischemic colitis is thought to be less likely.

TTE - The left atrium is normal in size. No atrial septal defect 
is seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall 
thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is top 
normal/borderline dilated. There is mild global left ventricular 
hypokinesis (LVEF = 40-45 %). The estimated cardiac index is 
normal (>=2.5L/min/m2). Doppler parameters are indeterminate for 
left ventricular diastolic function. Right ventricular chamber 
size is normal with mild global free wall hypokinesis. The 
aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good 
leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic 
regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally 
normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Trivial mitral 
regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure 
could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. 
IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Borderline dilated left 
ventricular cavity size with mild global hypokinesis. Normal 
right ventricular cavity size with mild global hypokinesis. No 
pathologic valvular findings. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ h/p sarcoid, myasthenia ___ s/p thymectomy, hypertension, 
secondary hyperparathyroidism, GERD, SIBO, osteopenia, thyroid 
nodule who initially presented to ___ with syncope 
___ transferred to ___ due to concern for 
ischemic colitis.

# GIB: DDx included infections colitis, ischemic colitis, AVM or 
diverticular bleed. While there was initial concern for ischemic 
colitis on OSH CT, second read of CT here was not felt to be 
consistent with this etiology. She had no further bleeding 
episodes here and H/H remained relatively stable after initial 
slight downtrend. Of note, on further discussion with the 
patient, she endorses a long standing ___ year) history of 
intermittent abdominal cramping sometime associated with syncope 
and/or hematochezia. She underwent colonoscopy here which only 
showed mild colitis. Biopsies were pending at the time of 
discharge and will need to be followed up. The patient was urged 
to continue to follow up with GI as an outpatient for continued 
evaluation of her symptoms.

# Syncope: Ultimately seemed most consistent with vasovagal 
etiology (she endorses intermittent abdominal cramping as above, 
with associated syncope when cramping is particularly bad). No 
events on telemetry. TTE without significant valvular pathology. 
ECG was checked on the day of discharge for QT monitoring and 
did show some nonspecific T wave changes compared to admission 
ECG and priors. Pt never complained of chest discomfort. 
Troponin was checked and was normal. This was communicated with 
her PCP via phone conversation.

# Pancytopenia: Etiology not entirely clear. Possible component 
of acute blood loss anemia initially and platelet consumption in 
the setting of GI bleed. Counts were stable at the time of 
discharge. Pt should have CBC repeated at ___ appointment next 
week and should be referred for further evaluation if cell 
counts remain low.

# Right ankle fracture: Occurred during syncopal episode. Ortho 
involved. Recommended boot, WBAT, follow up in ___ days.

# Myasthenia ___: Pt had previously undergone awake 
colonoscopies ___ concern for sedation in the setting of her 
known MG. However, after discussion with her neurologist, she 
underwent colonoscopy this admission with conscious sedation. 
She tolerated this without issue.

# Systolic Dysfunction: TTE showed EF of 40-45%. Pt endorses 
known h/o systolic dysfunction ___ "viral illness" for which she 
sees a cardiologist. She should continue to follow with 
cardiology.

# HTN: Antihypertensive agents on hold in the setting of GIB. 
Given that BP was on the low end of normal throughout admission, 
only restarted HCTZ at discharge. BP should be rechecked at 
follow up appointment and lisinopril restarted as needed.

# Anxiety: Continued Ativan, Fluoxetine and Nortryptiline.

# Osteopenia: Continuing calcitriol and vita.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
- Needs GI and cardiology f/u. F/u in ___ clinic as scheduled.
- Please repeat CBC at f/u appointment to ensure improvement in 
pancytopenia.
- Please repeat ECG at f/u appointment as discussed.
- Please repeat BP at f/u appointment and consider restarting 
lisinopril as needed.
- GI bx pending at the time of discharge and will need to be 
followed up.

2. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO EVERY OTHER WEEK 
3. FLUoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY 
4. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 
5. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 
6. LORazepam 0.5 mg PO BID PRN Anxiety 
7. Nortriptyline 10 mg PO QHS 
8. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY

Home

GI Bleeding
Colitis
Ankle Fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You presented to the hospital with abdominal cramping and GI 
bleeding. There was concern for possible colitis, and you were 
transferred to ___ for further evaluation. You were seen by 
our GI team, and you underwent a colonoscopy. You had no further 
episodes of bleeding here, and your blood counts have been 
stable. It is important that you follow up with your doctors to 
review the findings of your colonoscopy.

Your presentation was also notable for an episode of passing out 
(this has happened to you in the past as well in the setting of 
abdominal cramping). You sustained an ankle fracture from this. 
You were fitted with an aircast boot. You need to follow up in 
orthopedics clinic as instructed. 

It was a pleasure taking part in your medical care.

could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion.
IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Borderline dilated left
ventricular cavity size with mild global hypokinesis. Normal
right ventricular cavity size with mild global hypokinesis. No
pathologic valvular findings.
Brief Hospital Course:
___ h/p sarcoid, myasthenia ___ s/p thymectomy, hypertension,
secondary hyperparathyroidism, GERD, SIBO, osteopenia, thyroid
nodule who initially presented to ___ with syncope
___ transferred to ___ due to concern for
ischemic colitis.
# GIB: DDx included infections colitis, ischemic colitis, AVM or
diverticular bleed. While there was initial concern for ischemic
colitis on OSH CT, second read of CT here was not felt to be
consistent with this etiology. She had no further bleeding
episodes here and H/H remained relatively stable after initial
slight downtrend. Of note, on further discussion with the
patient, she endorses a long standing ___ year) history of
intermittent abdominal cramping sometime associated with syncope
and/or hematochezia. She underwent colonoscopy here which only
showed mild colitis. Biopsies were pending at the time of
discharge and will need to be followed up. The patient was urged
to continue to follow up with GI as an outpatient for continued
evaluation of her symptoms.
# Syncope: Ultimately seemed most consistent with vasovagal
etiology (she endorses intermittent abdominal cramping as above,
with associated syncope when cramping is particularly bad). No
events on telemetry. TTE without significant valvular pathology.
ECG was checked on the day of discharge for QT monitoring and
did show some nonspecific T wave changes compared to admission
ECG and priors. Pt never complained of chest discomfort.
Troponin was checked and was normal. This was communicated with
her PCP via phone conversation.
# Pancytopenia: Etiology not entirely clear. Possible component
of acute blood loss anemia initially and platelet consumption in
the setting of GI bleed. Counts were stable at the time of
discharge. Pt should have CBC repeated at ___ appointment next
week and should be referred for further evaluation if cell
counts remain low.
# Right ankle fracture: Occurred during syncopal episode. Ortho
involved. Recommended boot, WBAT, follow up in ___ days.
# Myasthenia ___: Pt had previously undergone awake
colonoscopies ___ concern for sedation in the setting of her
known MG. However, after discussion with her neurologist, she
underwent colonoscopy this admission with conscious sedation.
She tolerated this without issue.
# Systolic Dysfunction: TTE showed EF of 40-45%. Pt endorses
known h/o systolic dysfunction ___ "viral illness" for which she
sees a cardiologist. She should continue to follow with
cardiology.
# HTN: Antihypertensive agents on hold in the setting of GIB.
Given that BP was on the low end of normal throughout admission,
only restarted HCTZ at discharge. BP should be rechecked at
follow up appointment and lisinopril restarted as needed.
# Anxiety: Continued Ativan, Fluoxetine and Nortryptiline.
# Osteopenia: Continuing calcitriol and vita.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
- Needs GI and cardiology f/u. F/u in ___ clinic as scheduled.
- Please repeat CBC at f/u appointment to ensure improvement in
pancytopenia.
- Please repeat ECG at f/u appointment as discussed.
- Please repeat BP at f/u appointment and consider restarting
lisinopril as needed.
- GI bx pending at the time of discharge and will need to be
followed up.
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO EVERY OTHER DAY
2. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO EVERY OTHER WEEK
3. FLUoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY
4. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY
5. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY
6. LORazepam 0.5 mg PO BID PRN Anxiety
7. Nortriptyline 10 mg PO QHS
8. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY
Discharge Medications:
1. Calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO EVERY OTHER DAY
2. FLUoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY
3. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY
4. LORazepam 0.5 mg PO BID PRN Anxiety
5. Nortriptyline 10 mg PO QHS
6. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY
7. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO EVERY OTHER WEEK
8. HELD- Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY This medication was held. Do
not restart Lisinopril until you follow up with Dr. ___.
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
GI Bleeding
Colitis
Ankle Fracture
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
You presented to the hospital with abdominal cramping and GI
bleeding. There was concern for possible colitis, and you were
transferred to ___ for further evaluation. You were seen by
our GI team, and you underwent a colonoscopy. You had no further
episodes of bleeding here, and your blood counts have been
stable. It is important that you follow up with your doctors to
review the findings of your colonoscopy.
Your presentation was also notable for an episode of passing out
(this has happened to you in the past as well in the setting of
abdominal cramping). You sustained an ankle fracture from this.
You were fitted with an aircast boot. You need to follow up in
orthopedics clinic as instructed.
It was a pleasure taking part in your medical care.

to 25mg three times a day. Overall, he has been feeling very 
anxious without any sensation of a rapid heartbeat. He is aware 
of some dyspnea with exertion and intermittent lightheadedness. 
He was referred for PVI/LAT ablation.

showed pericardial effusion. A pericardial drain was placed, 
subsequently draining 500cc of bloody fluid. He was paralyzed 
and intubated during the procedure.

phenylephrine.

appears depressed. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly

There are no echocardiographic signs of tamponade.  

TTE ___:
he left atrium is dilated. No spontaneous echo contrast or 
thrombus is seen in the body of the left atrium/left atrial 
appendage or the body of the right atrium/right atrial 
appendage. The left atrial appendage emptying velocity is 
depressed (<0.2m/s). There is suspicion for patent foramen ovale 
though not confirmed (clip 52). Overall left ventricular 
systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular 
chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The ascending, 
transverse and descending thoracic aorta are normal in diameter 
and free of atherosclerotic plaque to 45 cm from the incisors. 
The aortic valve leaflets are moderately thickened. The study is 
inadequate to exclude minimal aortic valve stenosis. Trace 
aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. 
IMPRESSION: No intracardiac thrombus. Normal biventricular 
systolic function. Mild mitral and tricuspid regurgitation. 
Lipomatous intraatrial septum.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ is a ___ with history of afib s/p cardioversion 
___, and newly diagnosed L atrial tachycardia on Xarelto and 
flecainide, who presented to the CCU following a pulmonary vein 
isolation complicated by pericardial effusion, cardiac 
tamponade, and resultant hypotension requiring intubation.

# Pericardial effusion: Intitially with hypotension secondary to 
tamponade physiology. Most likely a complication of perforation 
during PVI procedure. S/p 500cc drainage of frank blood in the 
cath lab ___, w/ pericardial drain placement. Within several 
hours of CCU admission, drain output was 0cc and TTE 
demonstrated no more effusion. He was started on colchicine 
0.6mg PO BID for 6 weeks, and will f/u with Dr ___. 

# Intubation: Intubated during the PVI given hypotension and 
distress. Quickly extubated without complicatins in the CCU 
within a few hours. Rsepiratory status stable thereafter. 

#. PAF/atrial tachycardia: s/p CV in ___, maintaining sinus 
rhythm on flecainide up until recently with evolution of left 
atrial tach. Now s/p PVI though procedure not completed, 
complications per above. He went into atrial tach a few times 
while in the CCU, w/ rates up to 120's and mild SOB feeling, 
which resolved w/ IV metoprolol. Sent home on rivaroxaban, 
metoprolol, flecainide, ASA 325mg daily. Will f/u with Dr 
___ in ___ in 2 weeks. 

#.Obstructive sleep apnea: non-compliant with CPAP at home.

#.Diabetes: held home metformin, Prandin , Glipizide in house, 
used HISS. Home meds started on discharge. 

#.HTN:: metoprolol and lisinopril held during admission, 
restarted on discharge. 

#.HLD: continued home rosuvastatin

#.GERD: continued home PPI

Transitional Issues:
# colchicine for 6 weeks
# ASA 325 for 1 month
# f/u with Dr ___ in ___ in 2 weeks

Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___

Cough, vomiting

None

 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ year old wheelchair-bound woman with multiple 
medical problems, who presents with chief complaint of cough and 
vomiting.
The patient is visiting ___ from her group home in ___, 
and was in her usual state of health until this morning when 
vomitied (non bloody, non bilious) at approximately 4AM, 
followed by acute coughing, some mild respiratory distress, 
"hyperventilating".  She therefore was brought to the ED by her 
house officer (from her group home whom she is on vacation 
with).  
In the emergency room, she was noted to be afebrile, tachycardic 
with HR in 130's, systolic blood pressure was 100.  She was 
administered 2L of IVF with HR decrease to 100, systolic blood 
pressure elevated to 120.  Labs demonstrated hyponatremia with 
Na 126 and leukocytosis with WBC 12.3.  Blood cultures were 
sent.  CXR notable for a RLL pneumonia.  The patient was 
administered levofloxacin and flagyl, as well as a nebulizer 
treatment (noted to have prolonged I/E ratio on exam, although 
no wheezes) and admitted for further management.
Currently pt states that she feels "much better".  Is noted to 
be slightly tachypnic with prolonged expiratory phase which both 
she and her house officer states is her baseline.  Denies SOB, 
CP/pressure, nausea, diarrhea, any other complaints.
.
.

Patient is a ___ year old wheelchair bound woman with multiple

.
1. Pneumonia:  Per history, appears likely to be an aspiration 
pneumonia as patient developed distress immediately after 
vomiting.  On presentation, chest x-ray demonstrated a right 
lower lobe pneumonia, consistent with an aspiration event.  She 
was treated with levofloxacin, flagyl, oxygen, with improvement 
in her symptoms.  Speech and swallow evaluation was considered, 
but per health care aide, patient has recently had a swallow 
evaluation and is maintained on a ground diet.  She was 
discharged home to complete a 5 day course of levofloxacin, a 7 
day course of flagyl, and to follow up with a physician if 
symptoms were to worsen at all.
.

hyponatremia.  Her hyponatremia on presentation improved with 
IVF in the emergency department.  She was otherwise maintained 
on her outpatient fluid restriction of 1.5 liters/day.
.

.

.

zestril
.

.
7. Peripheral Vascular disease:  Continued outpatient plavix
.
8. GERD:  Continued outpt protonix
.
9. FEN:  Ground diet, fluid restriction to 1500cc/day.

text:
Name:  ___            Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Codeine / Penicillins
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Light-headedness, low blood pressure
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
___ w/ hx HTN who presents from primary care clinic with 
hypotension and near syncope.  
Patient felt lightheaded and dizzy while in the cafeteria. He 
walked to ___ for evaluation. He has a history of presyncopal 
episodes back in ___ and he was supposed to undergo echo but 
did not have this done. He denied chest pain, shortness of 
breath, abdominal pain, fevers, dysuria.  
Of note he is on several antihypertensives including nifedipine, 
labetalol and lisinopril. His blood pressures have been labile. 
When he was taking Adderall he said that his blood pressures 
were really high in the 160s/110s and he was started on 
labetolol with improvement to the 120s/80s on average. On days 
when he didn't take the Adderall his blood pressures were lower. 
His Adderall was stopped by his psychiatrist and he was recently 
started on Parnate for his depression. Since then he notes that 
his blood pressures have been running low in the 100s/70s. He 
has been decreasing his labetalol from 600 TID to currently 300 
TID.  
At ___, SBP was noted to be initially 151/124. On recheck it was 
74/47. He had a mild headache and tunnel vision. EKG in the 
office showed sinus tachycardia at 104, normal axis/int, no 
stigmata  
of ischemia/infarction. He was given a total of 700 cc NS and 
sent to the ED for further evaluation. Systolic BP prior to 
leaving the office was 84.  
In the ED initial vital signs were 97.8 98 92/52 16 97%. ECG: 
NSR 90, NA/NI, JP elevation inf/ant leads. Labs significant for 
Cr of 3.7 (Baseline 1.0-1.4). UA showed few bacteria and 9 
whites. Of note he arrived with PIV which was d/c'd on arrival 
with large clot from vein. No s/s of phlebitis. He was given 2 
additional liters of NS and sent to the floor for further 
evaluation. vitals prior to transfer were 97.9 88 124/63 16 96% 
RA.  
Currently, he feels well. He denies any further dizziness or 
lightheadedness.  

 
Past Medical History:
hypertension  
hyperlipidemia  
asthma  
bipolar affective disorder  
seasonal allergies  
sleep apnea on CPAP  
attention deficit disorder

___
Family History:
father with MI in ___, mom and brother with hypertension

ronchi

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

Thank you for choosing us for your care. You were admitted to 
the general medicine service at ___ for treatment of an 
episode of presyncope (near-fainting) in the setting of low 
blood pressure. Your labs also showed acute kidney injury which 
can arise in the setting of dehydration. The underlying cause of 
this event is thought to be a combination of recent changes in 
your psychiatric medications, insufficient oral hydration, and 
an extensive antihypertension regimen (which was initiated when 
you were previously on adderall and may not be needed moving 
forward). 

We treated you with normal saline fluid resuscitation and your 
blood pressure returned to within normal limits. We also 
temporarily discontinued nifedipine, lisinopril, and labetalol. 
We restarted labetalol at a lower dose of 200 mg po three times 
a day on the day of discharge but we do not feel that you need 
the other anti-hypertensives, especially since you are no longer 
taking adderall. We also monitored your heart on telemetry to 
rule-out any signs of arrythmia which can also be the cause of a 
near-syncopal episode. Finally, your kidney function tests 
returned to the normal baseline after your hydration improved.  

We recommend that you see your primary care physician within the 
next week for a blood pressure check and reevaluation of your 
antihypertensive medications. We also recommend that you see 
your psychiatrist Dr. ___ to discuss the role that your 
psychiatric medications may have contributed to this episode of 
low blood pressure and dehydration.

___

questions about medications with the treatment team, and I  
answered the patient's questions.  The patient appeared able to

On presentation, the patient was evaluated and felt to be at an 
increased risk of harm to herself and/or others based upon 
worsened symptoms of depression, increased alcohol intake, and 
suicidal ideation with plan but no intent.  Their static factors 
noted at that time include history of substance abuse, recent 
discharge from an inpatient psychiatric unit, age, and chronic 
medical illness.   The modifiable risk factors including 
suicidal ideation, hopelessness, limited coping skills, and 
substance abuse were addressed with alcohol detoxification on 
CIWA protocol, medication changes including starting Prozac, 
group/milieu therapy, and motivational interviewing.  Finally, 
the patient is being discharged with many protective risk 
factors, including help-seeking nature, future-oriented 
viewpoint, sense of responsibility to family, children in the 
home, lack of suicidal ideation and strong social supports.  
Overall, based on the totality of our assessment at this time, 
the patient is not at an acutely elevated risk of self-harm nor 
danger to others. 

Our Prognosis of this patient is fair, based on above mentioned 
medication adjustments and inpatient therapies. However, the 
patient is at high risk of relapse based on history of relapse 
and continued access to alcohol.
